site_title: Wing Tai retrenches 20 staff in retail restructuring
summary: Wing Tai Retail has retrenched 20 employees, accounting for less than 1% of its retail headcount, as part of its business restructuring exercise. The affected staff received a compensation package and a one-time grant to upgrade their skills. The retail group will review its store distribution following the restructuring, and the Singapore Industrial and Services Employees' Union (SISEU) will provide assistance to affected employees, including job searching, career coaching, and employability training.

site_title: Sterling tumbles to 2020 lows as investors dash for safety
summary: The pound dropped nearly 1% against the euro and dollar on Friday, reaching its lowest against the dollar since October, amid concerns over the fast-spreading coronavirus. Investors shifted to safer currencies like the Japanese yen, Swiss franc, and US dollar, while the Australian dollar fell 2%. Analysts cited Britain's large current account deficit and reliance on overseas investment as factors contributing to the sterling's decline, despite no specific news on the day.

site_title: Fifa chief Infantino accepts games are at risk due to coronavirus
summary: Fifa president Gianni Infantino expressed concerns that international soccer matches in March could be threatened by the coronavirus pandemic. The World Health Organization has raised its global spread and impact risk alert to "very high," and six countries have reported their first cases. Infantino hopes the European Championship and Olympic Games will go ahead unaffected, but acknowledged that the health of people is more important than football games. He suggested that games could be postponed or played without spectators until the outbreak decreases.

site_title: China reports 47 more coronavirus deaths
summary: China reported 47 more coronavirus deaths, raising the death toll to 2,835, with 427 new cases, bringing the total infections to 79,251.

images.alt_text: China on Saturday reported 47 more deaths from the new coronavirus, raising the death toll in the country to 2,835.

site_title: Oil prices sink to lowest in over a year, biggest weekly drop since 2016
summary: Oil prices dropped to their lowest in over a year, with the Brent future for May delivery falling 4% to $49.67 a barrel, amid fears of a slowing global economy due to the spread of the coronavirus. The decline was the biggest weekly drop since 2016. The World Health Organization raised its impact risk alert to "very high" as the virus spread to six countries across three continents. The drop in oil prices is expected to have a significant impact on the energy market.

images.alt_text: Oil prices slumped for a sixth day in a row on Friday to their lowest in more than a year, causing futures to drop by the most in a week since 2016, as the spread of coronavirus stoked fears that a slowing global economy would hit energy demand.

site_title: Ho Bee Land Q4 net profit soars on fair value gains
summary: Ho Bee Land's net profit surged 225% to S$267.6 million for the fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2019, driven by fair value gains of S$243.7 million on its two largest investment properties, Metropolis in Singapore and Ropemaker Place in London.

site_title: US to push production of protective gear for coronavirus
summary: The US will invoke the Defense Production Act to boost production of protective gear for the new coronavirus. The Trump administration has also issued travel advisories for several countries, including Italy and South Korea, and is considering a ban on entry for travelers from countries with the most cases. The US has reported around 60 confirmed cases, with fears of a wider outbreak. A vaccine may take up to 18 months to develop, and the US is ramping up testing capabilities. The US stock market plummeted, with the S&P 500 falling for the seventh straight day, amid concerns of a potential pandemic.

site_title: Mercedes-Benz CLA 200 Shooting Brake: The bold and the booty-ful
summary: The Mercedes-Benz CLA 200 Shooting Brake is a compact car with a big boot, marketed as a "shooting brake" to add luxury appeal. The term originated from horse-drawn carriages, referring to custom-built wagons for hunting parties. This style has seen a resurgence in recent years, allowing carmakers to charge more for their vehicles. The CLA 200 Shooting Brake combines a sleek package with ample cargo space, making it an attractive option for those seeking a stylish and practical car.

site_title: Harley-Davidson CEO steps down after 5-year sales slump
summary: Harley-Davidson CEO Matt Levatich stepped down after a 5-year sales slump, with shares plummeting 18% this year. The company's US sales dropped for a fifth consecutive year in 2019, and retail sales in the US have only risen once in the past 21 quarters. Levatich's departure comes after the company failed to achieve its growth goals, including increasing revenue from outside the US by 2027. Interim CEO Jochen Zeitz, a board member credited with reviving the Puma sneaker brand, will take over the role.

site_title: US: Dow slumps again to finish worst week since October 2008
summary: US stocks ended the worst week since the 2008 financial crisis, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average finishing 1.4% lower at 25,409.36. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also declined, with the Dow and S&P 500 falling over the last seven days amid concerns over the coronavirus's global spread. Investors anticipate broader economic dislocation and recession, with some seeing the pullback as a potential buying opportunity.

site_title: Malaysia's turmoil deepens with Mahathir's fate in doubt
summary: Malaysia's 94-year-old Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's fate is uncertain after the royal palace rejected a plan for a parliament vote to select a new leader, citing disrespect to the monarch. Mahathir's party, the Pakatan Harapan, dropped him as their candidate for the premiership, instead choosing Muhyiddin Yassin as the next-in-line. This move follows Mahathir's suggestion of a parliamentary vote to choose a new prime minister, which was deemed unacceptable by the palace.

images.alt_text: Dr Mahathir said this week he would return to power if enough lawmakers back him, and wants to build a "government that doesn't side with any party".

site_title: Gold consolidates after a blistering rally
summary: Gold prices reached new highs this week, closing at US$1,689.56 per ounce, but failed to break the US$1,700 psychological level. The metal's rally was driven by concerns over the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on global growth, leading investors to seek safe-haven assets. A loose monetary policy and falling US dollar, Treasury yields, and equity prices further supported gold. However, physical demand in India and China may weaken, and technical indicators now indicate a consolidating sideways pattern, positioning gold for a bullish trend.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. In the US, stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, while in Europe, stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector drag. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in H2. London's Heathrow plans to increase airport fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case.

site_title: Robust R&D, healthcare systems paramount in virus fight
summary: A new coronavirus, Covid-19, has emerged, posing a significant public health emergency globally. The International Monetary Fund warns that economic growth in China may slow due to the outbreak. Three key risks to the global economy are emerging: China's lack of transparency and leadership, the US's inadequate response, and the vulnerability of emerging markets and developing countries. Despite the challenges, medical advancements and public health efforts are underway, and investing in science and research is seen as a crucial step in combating the virus and preventing future pandemics.

site_title: ESG investing in the year of the Rat
summary: Interest in ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) investing continues to grow, with 80% of clients expressing interest in sustainable investing. To navigate this space, investors should consider three key tips: 1) not following the herd, ensuring ESG issues are addressed, and thoroughly evaluating ESG solutions. This includes being aware of potential "rat holes" such as climate risk, governance issues, and social controversies, and scrutinizing fund exclusions, ESG strategies, and team expertise. By doing so, investors can make informed decisions and capitalize on macro trends in sustainable investing.

site_title: Kencana Agri narrows FY2019 net loss to US$12.8m
summary: Kencana Agri narrowed its FY2019 net loss to US$12.8 million, down from a loss of US$23.8 million the previous year. Revenue declined 17% to US$104.1 million due to lower crude palm oil ASP and sales volume. The company attributed the improvement to stronger palm oil prices in Q4 2019 and 2020. Kencana chairman Henry Maknawi expressed uncertainty about the company's future, but emphasized operational efficiency. CEO Albert Maknawi resigned as COO, and Tonny Hermawan was appointed to the role.

site_title: Higher fair value, other gains boost UOL's FY2019 earnings
summary: UOL Group's FY2019 net profit rose 14% to S$478.8 million, driven by higher fair value and other gains of S$165.1 million. Revenue dipped 5% to S$2.3 billion, mainly due to lower progressive recognition of revenue from development projects. Despite a 4% decline in hotel operations, revenue from management services and technologies increased 25%. The company expects challenges this year due to the Covid-19 outbreak, with hotel occupancies ranging 40-50%.

site_title: OKP swings into red for Q4, posts net loss of S$1.8m
summary: OKP Holdings, a construction firm, reported a net loss of S$1.8 million in Q4 2020, compared to a net profit of S$2.7 million in the previous year. Revenue rose 20.5% to S$22.1 million, but gross profit margin fell due to rising costs and a competitive pricing environment. The company expects higher costs and remains cautiously optimistic, citing a healthy pipeline of construction projects. The group plans to diversify its business, improve productivity, and upgrade its talent pool to drive growth.

site_title: Singapore aims to halve 2030 peak emissions by 2050
summary: Singapore aims to halve its 2030 peak emissions by 2050, committing to an absolute peak emission level of 65 million tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent (MtCO2e) by 2030. The country will also include nitrogen trifluoride as its seventh greenhouse gas. To achieve this, Singapore will focus on transformations in its industry, economy, and society, leveraging technologies such as carbon capture and storage, and low-carbon fuels. The country's new targets, submitted to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change, represent progress and ambition in addressing climate change, but experts say achieving the goal will be a "monumental task".

images.alt_text: Mr Teo says that Singapore aims to achieve net-zero emissions as soon as viable in the second half of the century.

site_title: Honeywell sees surge in demand for face masks in North America, China
summary: Honeywell reports a surge in demand for protective face masks globally due to the coronavirus outbreak, citing increased demand in North America, Europe, India, and China. The company is increasing production at multiple facilities worldwide to meet the growing demand. Honeywell is also prepared to partner with the US government to support national response efforts. As of the latest World Health Organization figures, over 82,000 people have been infected and over 2,700 deaths have been reported in China, with 57 deaths in 46 other countries.

site_title: SIA cuts senior management pay by 10-15%; staff offered voluntary no-pay leave
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is cutting senior management pay by 10-15% and offering a voluntary no-pay leave scheme to employees amid the Covid-19 outbreak, which has led to a decline in travel demand. CEO Goh Choon Phong will take a 15% pay cut, while executive vice-presidents and senior managers will receive reduced pay cuts ranging from 10-12%. The airline group will also extend a voluntary no-pay leave scheme to staff, allowing them to take leave of up to six months.

site_title: Reits (February 29-March 1, 2020)
summary: Real estate markets saw fluctuations in the first week of March 2020. In the US, mortgage rates rose after five consecutive weeks of decline. In Singapore, the Q3 condo launch wave may test demand for projects above the S$3,000 psf benchmark. Manhattan rents reached a record high, with potential for further increases. In other news, Goldman Sachs acquired Seoul hotel and retail assets, and UK homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high. WeWork secured new tenants at its Singapore location after emerging from bankruptcy.

site_title: Time for Joscelin Yeo to swim into Hall of Fame
summary: Former Singaporean swimmer Joscelin Yeo is being considered for induction into the Sport Hall of Fame, despite being one of the country's most decorated athletes. Yeo, a 40-medal winner at the Southeast Asian Games, has impressive credentials but remains ineligible for the Hall of Fame due to a mysterious oversight. The criteria for selection include athletes who win gold at the Asian Games or Paralympics and can be considered national icons, with Yeo easily qualifying under the latter criterion.

site_title: Govt has resources and will to act if more support needed to mitigate Covid-19: Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat reassured that the government has the resources and will to act if needed to mitigate the Covid-19 outbreak. Budget 2020 is calibrated to the current situation, with measures to support sectors such as tourism, accommodation, and aviation. The government will also provide additional support to the self-employed, taxi and private hire car drivers, hawkers, and others. Beyond the crisis, Heng emphasized the need to tackle longer-term issues like fiscal sustainability and economic transformation, including climate change and addressing structural changes in the labour force.

site_title: Super cushioned running shoes are all the rage, but they're not for everyone
summary: Researchers at Oregon State University-Cascades conducted studies on the effects of maximalist running shoes on recreational athletes. The studies found that runners wearing these shoes tend to pound harder and pronate more than in standard shoes, potentially increasing the risk of running injuries. The findings suggest that extra cushioning in shoes can affect balance and road feel, leading to subtle changes in running form. The researchers advise runners to try out maximal shoes before buying and to ease into training slowly.

site_title: Rex International posts Q4 net loss, but swings back to black for FY2019
summary: Rex International posted a Q4 net loss of $3.8 million, reversing a net loss of $7.6 million in the previous year. However, its FY2019 net profit soared to $19.4 million, primarily due to the absence of a tax expense and increased other income. Revenue fell 67% to $135,000, while earnings per share rose to 1.5 cents. The company attributed its performance to prudent cash management and a strategy to remain debt-free.

site_title: Coronavirus wipes up to 70m euros off Deutsche Post's Feb earnings
summary: The coronavirus outbreak has impacted Deutsche Post's operating profit, wiping up to 70 million euros off its February earnings. The company also expects a one-off charge of 300-400 million euros related to its electric van business. Despite this, Deutsche Post maintains its forecast for group earnings before interest and tax (EBIT) of more than 5 billion euros for 2020. The company is ending its cooperation with Ford on van production and focusing on operating its current fleet, which will lead to the one-off charge. A recovery in business is expected when the crisis is over.

site_title: Virus concerns hit shares in builder of world's tallest tower
summary: Shares of Emaar Properties PJSC, developer of the Burj Khalifa, plummeted 10% this week due to concerns over the novel coronavirus' impact on Dubai's real estate, hospitality, and retail industries. The company's subsidiaries, Emaar Malls and Emaar Development, also suffered losses of 4.7% and 8.4% respectively. The UAE's flight suspensions to Iran and China further exacerbated the situation, affecting Emaar's revenue and net income. The decline in visitor numbers from China and Iran could deal a significant blow to the Emaar companies, which rely on foreign tourists and investors.

site_title: UOL net profit up 14% for FY19
summary: UOL Group reported a 14% increase in net profit to S$478.8 million for FY19, driven by higher fair value and other gains. Revenue declined 5% to S$2.28 billion due to lower progressive recognition of revenue from development projects and hotel operations. The company has proposed a first and final dividend of 17.5 cents per share. UOL's hotel occupancies are currently around 40-50% due to the Covid-19 outbreak, and the company has cut staff and bookings.

site_title: BTS cancel concerts as South Korea virus cases rise faster than China
summary: K-pop megastars BTS cancelled four Seoul concerts scheduled for April due to South Korea's rapid rise in novel coronavirus cases, with over 200,000 fans expected to attend. The decision was made to prioritize health and safety amid the outbreak, which has spread globally and led to cancellations and postponements of various events, including the K-league football season and the World Team Table Tennis Championships. South Korea reported 571 new cases, taking its total to 2,337, with the country's death toll remaining at 13.

site_title: Asia markets battered on fears of coronavirus-induced recession
summary: Asia markets plummeted on Friday, with the MSCI Asia-Pacific Index experiencing its seventh consecutive loss, as investors fear a coronavirus-induced recession. The US S&P 500 had its worst day since October, with analysts predicting further declines. Asian equities have absorbed initial shockwaves and traded at lower valuations, providing some protection. Despite this, US market performance may worsen before improving, and global growth forecasts may be revised downward, with Fitch Solutions Macro Research predicting a 2.6% global growth forecast for 2020.

site_title: Properties in tech hubs offer investors more promise
summary: Prime properties in tech hubs have outperformed traditional markets, with cities like Shenzhen, Berlin, and San Francisco experiencing significant price rises over the past five years. Shenzhen saw a 93% price increase, while Berlin rose 53% and San Francisco 28%. The trend is attributed to the growing wealth generated by the tech industry, with Asian cities like China and Hong Kong also performing well. Established markets like London and New York remain expensive, but may offer relatively good value, while areas tapping into newly created wealth are expected to perform strongly.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Tee International's group CFO Yeo Ai Mei has tendered her resignation, citing a desire to dedicate more time to her personal commitments. She will leave the company on August 31, 2020, and serve a six-month notice period. The engineering group is currently searching for a replacement.

site_title: When a 'buy' goes bad, who is in the wrong?
summary: A Singapore-based start-up company, THB, deceived investors by providing false information about its business operations and products. Research analyst Mohd Hamdan, hired by THB, failed to conduct adequate due diligence and provided a misleading research report. Chong, a colleague at Natures Harvest Investment Management, relied on Hamdan's report and issued a "buy" recommendation, which was later used by portfolio manager Saravanan to invest in THB, resulting in significant losses for his clients. The Securities and Futures Act prohibits misleading statements and the CFA Institute Code of Ethics and Standards of Professional Conduct emphasize the importance of diligence and reasonable basis in investment recommendations.

site_title: WHO raises global virus risk to maximum level
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) raised its global risk assessment of the new coronavirus to its highest level, citing rapid spread to new zones and concerns over Africa's preparedness. The virus has killed over 2,800 people and infected over 84,000 worldwide, with cases emerging on every continent except Antarctica. Global investors ran scared, with world markets suffering their worst week since the 2008 financial crisis, while drastic measures were put in place, including quarantines and travel bans, in countries such as Switzerland, Saudi Arabia, and Italy.

site_title: Sanofi to pay US$11.9m to resolve US drug kickback probe
summary: Sanofi has agreed to pay US$11.9 million to resolve allegations that it used a charity to encourage the use of a high-priced multiple sclerosis drug, in a settlement related to a US Justice Department probe into industry-wide kickback practices. Sanofi did not admit wrongdoing as part of the settlement. This is the latest company to settle claims stemming from the probe, which is part of an industry-wide investigation into patient assistance charities.

site_title: US personal spending slows in January, but remains robust
summary: US personal spending slowed in January to a 0.2% gain, missing the median estimate, but remained robust. Personal income rose 0.6%, driven by employee compensation and social security benefit payments. New vehicles and food/accommodation supported the rise in personal spending on goods, while services were driven by retail sales. Economists now expect a 1.5% annualized growth pace for the first quarter, down from 1.7% in early January.

images.alt_text: Personal spending rose 0.2 per cent from the prior month after an upwardly revised 0.4 per cent gain in December, Commerce Department data showed.

site_title: Investment sanity checks as Covid-19 fears take over
summary: Investors are advised to build resilient portfolios for the long term amid the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on global financial markets. Despite rising infections in developed countries, the author believes the negative impact will be short-lived. Key findings include bonds having priced in significant economic damage, while equities have factored in a sharp economic slowdown. Investors are recommended to focus on bond-like securities and dividend-yielding equities, as well as long-term growth themes in technology, healthcare, and millennial consumption.

site_title: STI has worst week in 8 years as Covid-19 fears escalate
summary: Singapore stocks experienced their worst weekly performance in 8 years due to the escalating Covid-19 fears, which have taken a global turn. The outbreak's economic fallout is now being feared, potentially leading to a global recession. Investors are concerned about the sustained spread of the novel coronavirus in the US, with cases surging in South Korea and Italy.

site_title: Hiap Hoe returns to the black with net profit of S$16.2m in Q4
summary: Singapore property developer Hiap Hoe reported a net profit of S$16.2 million for Q4 2023, reversing a net loss of S$13.3 million in the same period last year. Revenue rose 11.5% to S$35.6 million, driven by gains from the acquisition of a Perth property and hotel operations. Full-year net profit was S$22.1 million, up from a net loss of S$9.9 million in 2018. The company has proposed an unchanged final dividend of one cent per share.

site_title: Bonuses for public officers in Covid-19 crisis; pay cuts for MPs, ministers
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced that public officers on the frontline of the Covid-19 crisis in Singapore will receive up to one additional month of special bonus. In contrast, political and public service leaders will take pay cuts to show solidarity with fellow Singaporeans. The pay cuts include a one-month cut for all political office-holders and MPs, and a half-month cut for senior public service officers. The moves aim to demonstrate trust and solidarity between the government and the people during the crisis.

site_title: Days of department stores are numbered
summary: Department stores, which have been around for over 150 years, are facing significant challenges. Despite still operating efficiently, their returns on equity have declined steadily since 2006, with many struggling to make a profit. The shift to online shopping has led to a decline in sales, causing department stores to become glorified showrooms rather than places to buy things. Only a few department stores, such as Japan's Takashimiya, are able to adapt and potentially reap the rewards of rising consumer wealth.

site_title: New coronavirus cluster surfaces in Singapore
summary: A new coronavirus cluster, the fifth in Singapore, has emerged at Wizlearn Technologies, with two new confirmed cases. The cluster includes four colleagues, bringing the total confirmed cases to 98. Three patients have been discharged, with 69 now fully recovered. The new cases are Singapore permanent residents with no recent travel history to China or South Korea. The Ministry of Health is monitoring the situation and is taking steps to contain it.

site_title: EC World Reit cuts Q4 DPU, sees muted demand in Wuhan
summary: EC World Reit posted a 3.8% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.51 Singapore cents for the fourth quarter, despite higher revenue and net property income. The trust retained 5% of capital distribution for general working capital and "unforeseen contingencies." This marks a decrease from 1.57 cents a year earlier, primarily due to muted demand in Wuhan.

site_title: IHH Healthcare's Q4 net earnings dive to RM40.6m
summary: IHH Healthcare's fourth-quarter net earnings plummeted to RM40.6 million, a 92% decline from the same period last year, due to higher net interest expenses and depreciation from new hospital projects. Despite this, new CEO Kelvin Loh vows to implement a strategy refresh and portfolio review to drive growth, focusing on expanding established clusters, reviewing under-performing assets, and leveraging international scale.

site_title: South Korea reports 594 more coronavirus cases, total 2,931
summary: South Korea reported 594 new coronavirus cases on Saturday, bringing the national total to 2,931, with three additional deaths. Over 90% of the new cases were in Daegu and its neighboring North Gyeongsang province. Authorities have urged caution, but not considered a citywide quarantine, instead advising against large outdoor meetings or indoor religious assemblies. The national toll now stands at 16 deaths.

images.alt_text: South Korea confirmed 594 more coronavirus cases on Saturday, the biggest increase to date for the country and taking the national total to 2,931 infections with three additional deaths.

site_title: Ex-Barclays bankers cleared over 2008 Qatar fees in blow to UK fraud office
summary: Three former Barclays executives, Roger Jenkins, Tom Kalaris, and Richard Boath, were unanimously acquitted of charges related to funneling £322m in secret fees to Qatar in 2008. The acquittal is a blow to the UK's Serious Fraud Office, which had estimated the case had cost £10m. The case centered on alleged unlawful financial assistance to Qatar through a £3 billion loan, but the men claimed the fees were legitimate mechanisms to pay Qatar while extracting commercial business. The verdict marks the end of efforts to hold top bankers accountable for decisions during the credit crisis.

site_title: Streamlining govt e-services, expanding digital MC scheme among Smart Nation efforts unveiled
summary: Singapore's government has unveiled digitalisation efforts to streamline common services and expand the use of digital Medical Certificates (MCs). The Moments of Life (MOL) app will be enhanced to house government services on a single site, personalized for each user, and will be available to all citizens. The government also plans to roll out DigiMC to the private healthcare sector and expand its GoBusiness licensing portal to benefit other industries. These efforts aim to improve citizen engagement and reduce costs for businesses.

site_title: Arsenal loss shows cost of Champions League absence
summary: Arsenal FC has reported its first overall loss in nearly 20 years, £27.1 million, due to the cost of participating in the Europa League instead of the Champions League. The loss was attributed to increased player wages and limited player trading activity. The club's parent holding company stated that the absence from the Champions League will continue to apply pressure to their financial results, despite increased commercial revenues from Adidas and Emirates. This loss follows their shock Europa League exit and a struggle to qualify for next season's Champions League.

site_title: Corona beer maker says US sales remain strong despite virus outbreak
summary: Constellation Brands Inc, the maker of Corona beer, reported strong US sales for its Corona Extra beer despite the global spread of the coronavirus. CEO Bill Newlands stated that the company has not seen an impact on its operations or business, with limited exposure to international markets affected by the outbreak. Newlands attributed the strong sales to the company's focus on the US market.

site_title: Banyan Tree Q4 profit more than doubles to S$12.8m
summary: Banyan Tree Holdings' net profit more than doubled to S$12.8 million in the fourth quarter, driven by a 71% rise in revenue to S$158.5 million. However, the full-year net profit tumbled 95.2% to S$651,000. The company attributed the decline to the COVID-19 outbreak, which is expected to weigh on its hotel and resort-related businesses. Despite this, the group is on track to secure 30 deals annually to double its operating footprint by 2025 and plans to open eight new resorts in the next 12 months.

site_title: WHO warns of coronavirus spreading worldwide as 5 countries report first cases
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) warned of a potential pandemic of the coronavirus, with five countries reporting their first cases, including Nigeria, Estonia, Denmark, Netherlands, and Lithuania, all linked to travel history with Italy. The WHO's Christian Lindmeier stated that the outbreak is getting bigger and could spread worldwide. Mainland China reported 327 new cases, taking its total to over 78,800, with nearly 2,800 deaths. The US and other countries are taking measures to curb the spread, including cancelling events and stockpiling medical supplies. The global economy has also been severely impacted, with the US stock market experiencing its worst week since the 2008 financial crisis.

site_title: US consumer spending slows in January; income surges
summary: US consumer spending rose 0.2% in January, less than expected, amid unseasonably mild weather and reduced demand for heating and clothing. Despite a slower spending pace, personal income jumped 0.6% and wages rose 0.5%, boosting savings to $1.33 trillion. Inflation remained benign, with the core PCE price index increasing 1.6% year-over-year. The coronavirus outbreak has raised concerns about the economy, with financial markets increasing bets on Federal Reserve interest rate cuts and the US central bank's desire to keep monetary policy on hold.

site_title: Development charge rates mostly unchanged in latest review
summary: The Singapore government has left development charge (DC) rates largely unchanged for the next half year, with the only exception being a 0.2% average decrease in non-landed residential use for the March 1 to Aug 31 period, marking the third consecutive decline. This decision reflects the stable property market and lack of transaction evidence supporting rate cuts. DC rates remain unchanged for all other use groups, including landed residential, commercial, hotels/hospital, and industrial, with some sectors experiencing reductions in response to specific transaction evidence.

site_title: Dry weather more of an issue for Golden Agri than Covid-19
summary: Golden Agri-Resources posted a net profit of US$239.6 million for its fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2019, tripling the US$79.3 million reported a year ago, driven by strengthening palm oil prices. The company attributes the increase to dry weather affecting output, which is expected to slow supply growth. Despite Covid-19 disruptions, GAR remains confident in selling palm oil to other markets. The company's full-year net profit came in at US$194 million, reversing a net loss a year ago, with revenue slipping 10.3% to US$6.43 billion.

site_title: Covid-19 slows China's major projects in Asia
summary: China's trillion-dollar Belt and Road Initiative is slowing due to the COVID-19 pandemic, which has cut off labor supplies and equipment imports needed for major infrastructure projects in Asia. Over 133 countries have imposed entry restrictions on Chinese citizens or those who have visited China, hindering construction progress. China-backed projects in Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, Indonesia, Nepal, and others are being delayed or slowed down, with some requiring Chinese workers to return to resume work. The pandemic's impact comes after a pushback against Belt and Road projects in several countries, with Chinese officials downplaying the disruption's impact on investments.

site_title: Powell says Fed ready to act as coronavirus poses 'evolving' economic risks
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell stated the central bank is prepared to act to support the economy due to evolving economic risks posed by the coronavirus epidemic. Despite the fundamentals of the US economy remaining strong, Powell acknowledged the potential for economic damage and expressed the Fed's willingness to use its tools to mitigate risks. The Fed is closely monitoring the situation and will act as appropriate, with traders now pricing in a high chance of interest rate cuts by March and July.

site_title: US dollar dives to 7-week low against yen on Fed rate cut hint
summary: The US dollar hit a 7-week low against the Japanese yen after Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell hinted at a potential interest rate cut in response to the coronavirus outbreak. The yen surged to a 1.51% gain, reaching a 107.92 against the dollar. Powell stated the Fed will "act as appropriate" to support the economy, but noted the economy remains in solid condition. The move is seen as a safe-haven currency response to global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Activist investor wants to oust Twitter chief Dorsey: media
summary: Activist investor Elliott Management, led by billionaire Paul Singer, has acquired a stake in Twitter and is pushing to remove co-founder and CEO Jack Dorsey due to his divided attention between running the social media firm and his financial transactions startup Square. The firm claims Dorsey intends to live part of each year in Africa, further citing his divided focus as a reason for the proposed change.

site_title: Collapse of Singapore commodities firm leaves lenders exposed
summary: A Singapore commodities firm, Agritrade International, has defaulted on US$244 million of loans, leaving lenders, including ING Bank and MUFG Bank, with potential losses of hundreds of millions of dollars. Agritrade allegedly misrepresented its financial position to lenders, and its CEO, Ng Xinwei, and his father, Ng Say Peck, are accused of fraud. The company's financial struggles come amid global market turmoil, with Chinese economic growth slowing and oil prices remaining depressed. A Singapore court has appointed interim judicial managers to oversee the company, and negotiations are underway to inject funds and repay creditors.

images.alt_text: Lenders including ING Bank NV have accused a Singapore commodities firm of fraud after it defaulted on debt and left the financiers facing potential losses of hundreds of millions of dollars in their liabilities.

site_title: US postpones summit with Asean leaders amid coronavirus fears: sources
summary: The US has postponed a summit with Asean leaders scheduled for March 14 due to coronavirus concerns. The meeting, planned in Las Vegas, was intended to follow a November summit in Bangkok, where President Donald Trump did not attend. The decision was made in consultation with Asean partners, citing the need to work together to defeat the virus. The summit's new date has not been announced.

site_title: Rock band Green Day among musicians pulling out of Asia tour dates
summary: US rock band Green Day has canceled all Asian tour dates due to the coronavirus outbreak, following other artists such as BTS and Stormzy who have also postponed their performances in the region. The Hella Mega tour was set to visit Singapore, Bangkok, Manila, and other cities in early March before a European leg in May. Green Day announced the decision on its official website, stating they will reschedule the shows once health and travel concerns are alleviated.

site_title: Virus slows China's major projects in Asia
summary: China's trillion-dollar Belt and Road Initiative is facing setbacks due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with over 133 countries imposing entry restrictions on Chinese citizens. Major infrastructure projects in Asia, including Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, Nepal, and Indonesia, are experiencing delays and slowdowns due to a lack of Chinese labor and equipment imports. Chinese state-owned companies are taking precautions, such as quarantining personnel and restricting travel, to prevent the spread of the virus. The impact is expected to be felt across the region, with some projects potentially delayed or slowed down.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore commits to an absolute peak emission level of 65 million tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent by 2030. Frontline officers in the Covid-19 crisis will receive a bonus of up to 1 month, while office-holders and MPs will face cuts. The country also streamlines its government services and enhances its digital services. Meanwhile, Singapore shares sink 5.3% on the week, and investors are bracing for a global economic slowdown due to the Covid-19 outbreak.

site_title: China's factory activity posts record contraction as coronavirus bites
summary: China's factory activity contracted at the fastest pace on record in February due to the coronavirus outbreak, with the official Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling to a record low of 35.7. This marks a significant contraction, with deepening cracks in the economy already hit by the trade war. Economists expect further stimulus measures as the economy is expected to suffer another sharp blow in the first quarter, with predictions of 2.0% year-on-year growth.

images.alt_text: Factory activity in China contracted at the fastest pace on record in February, highlighting the damage from the coronavirus outbreak on the world's second-largest economy.

site_title: Google cancels internal conference over coronavirus concerns
summary: Google cancelled a major internal conference in Las Vegas over coronavirus concerns, citing the evolving situation and risk of spreading the respiratory virus. The event, set for March, would have brought thousands of employees together from two continents. The company also banned employee travel to and from South Korea and Japan starting March 2, following an internal memo revealing an employee had contracted the virus after traveling to an affected area. The broader impact on Google's business is unclear, but the company's advertising revenue may be affected by a general economic slowdown.

site_title: IHH Healthcare Q4 net profit falls 15%, announces strategy refresh
summary: IHH Healthcare's fourth-quarter net profit fell 15% to RM289.8 million, driven by higher net interest expenses and depreciation from new hospital projects. New CEO Kelvin Loh has announced a strategy refresh, focusing on growth through expanded metro area clusters, reviewing its asset portfolio, and leveraging international scale to achieve stronger synergies. The company will also divest underperforming assets and redeploy capital to improve returns.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit buys asset in Germany for 16.6m euros
summary: Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (Cromwell E-Reit) has acquired a light industrial/logistics asset in Germany for 16.6 million euros, increasing its German exposure to 6.5%. The asset, built in 2017, has 30,557 sqm of net lettable area and is fully let to Euro Pool System International until May 2024. The deal follows Cromwell E-Reit's second light industrial/logistics acquisition in Germany within three months, with a 6.3% net operating income yield. The acquisition is expected to be completed in April and is in line with the Reit's growth strategy.

site_title: Amazon defers 'non-essential' moves even in US as corporate travel bans spread
summary: Amazon has deferred all non-essential travel within the US and globally, following other corporations in taking measures to protect employees from the spread of coronavirus. This decision comes as six countries report their first cases of the virus, and at least 2,797 deaths have been reported globally. Google has also set new restrictions for travel to South Korea and other affected areas. These measures aim to mitigate the spread of the virus and ensure employee safety amid rising coronavirus fears.

site_title: New coronavirus cluster with 4 staff infected, including 2 new cases announced
summary: A new coronavirus cluster in Singapore has surfaced, with four staff members infected, including two new cases announced. The cluster is linked to Wizlearn Technologies, an e-learning solutions company, and includes colleagues. The total number of confirmed cases is now 98, with 69 having fully recovered. The two new cases, a 44-year-old woman and a 24-year-old man, are Singapore permanent residents with no recent travel history to China or South Korea. The Health Ministry is monitoring the situation and conducting contact tracing.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares slide 1.5% on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed 1.5% lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 22.95 points to 1,482.64. Losers outnumbered gainers 1,056 to 124, with a total of 5.1 billion lots traded worth RM4.7 billion.

site_title: Koufu Q4 net profit falls 13.4% to S$6.5m
summary: Koufu reported a 13.4% decline in Q4 net profit to S$6.5 million, driven by sharp depreciation charges of S$20.7 million due to new leasing standards. Revenue rose 5.7% to S$60.3 million, with earnings per share down to 1.17 cents. Full-year net profit rose 13% to S$27.7 million, with earnings per share increasing to 4.99 cents. The company proposed a final dividend of 1.5 cents per share, up from 1.2 cents previously.

site_title: Yongnam Holdings FY2019 net loss widens to S$53.1m
summary: Yongnam Holdings reported a net loss of S$53.1 million for FY2019, widening from a net loss of S$51 million the previous year. The company attributed the higher loss to an impairment charge, operational restructuring costs, and loss on disposal of assets. Revenue grew 27.1% to S$205.1 million, driven by specialist civil engineering and design-and-build business segments. The group's order book stood at S$405 million, and it is actively pursuing S$1.3 billion of infrastructure and commercial contracts.

site_title: Yangzijiang's Q4 net profit falls 30% to 642.3m yuan
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding reported a 30% decline in Q4 net profit to 642.3 million yuan, due to lower foreign exchange-related gains and a decrease in trading revenue. Revenue fell 2% to 4.85 billion yuan. Despite this, the company delivered more vessels and has an outstanding order book of US$2.9 billion for 75 vessels, expected to maintain a healthy utilisation rate until 2021. A final cash dividend of 4.5 Singapore cents per share was proposed for the full year.

site_title: Singapore shares sink further on Friday, tumble 5.3% on the week
summary: Singapore's shares plummeted 5.3% on the week, marking their worst performance since August 2011, amid the global spread of the Covid-19 outbreak. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 169.95 points to 3,011.08, its lowest closing since October 2018. The market saw heavy selling, with investors worried about a global recession. The decline was widespread, with all 30 STI constituents closing in the red, and trading volume reached a 2019 daily average.

site_title: Yongnam's FY19 net loss widens to S$53.1m
summary: Yongnam Holdings posted a net loss of S$53.1 million for FY19, widening from a net loss of S$51 million the previous year. The loss was attributed to an impairment charge, operational restructuring costs, and a loss on disposal of assets. Revenue grew 27.1% to S$205.1 million, driven by higher contributions from specialist civil engineering and design-and-build business segments. The company's order book stood at S$405 million, and it is pursuing approximately S$1.3 billion worth of infrastructure and commercial contracts.

site_title: Ho Bee Land Q4 net profit more than triples to S$267.6m
summary: Ho Bee Land's Q4 net profit soared to S$267.6 million, more than tripling from the previous year, driven by fair-value gains on investment properties totaling S$243.7 million. Revenue rose 3.6% to S$54.3 million, while earnings per share increased to 40.23 cents. The company reported a 23.1% rise in full-year net profit to S$332.3 million, despite a 90.3% decline in associate profits due to lower residential unit handovers. The board recommended a total dividend of 10 cents per share.

site_title: Hiap Hoe returns to black in Q4, posts net profit of S$16.2m
summary: Hiap Hoe, a Singaporean property developer, reported a net profit of S$16.2 million for the fourth quarter, a turnaround from a net loss of S$13.3 million in the previous year. Revenue rose 11.5% to S$35.6 million, driven by higher revenue from hotel operations. For the full year, net profit came in at S$22.1 million, with earnings per share increasing to 4.7 cents. The company has proposed a final dividend of one cent per share.

site_title: BTS, the K-pop supergroup that's changed the music business
summary: BTS, the South Korean supergroup, continues to evolve their image and music. Their latest album, Map of the Soul: 7, features a darker aesthetic, a departure from their previous colorful style. The group's emotional honesty, as expressed through their lyrics and personal vlogs, sets them apart from other K-pop acts. With their underdog story of surpassing odds, BTS has become one of the highest-earning K-pop acts and the unofficial face of Korean music worldwide, breaking traditional forms of Western masculinity. Their unique approach has cemented their global influence in the music industry.

images.alt_text: The Bangtan Boys' public image, one that doesn't rely on traditional forms of Western masculinity, is constantly evolving, as is their music.

site_title: Hong Kong media tycoon Jimmy Lai arrested over pro-democracy rally
summary: Hong Kong media tycoon Jimmy Lai, a vocal critic of Beijing, was arrested for taking part in a pro-democracy rally last year. Lai, 72, is accused of joining an unauthorized assembly on August 31, 2020, and faces up to five years in jail. He is also charged with intimidating a reporter in 2018. The arrest is part of a broader crackdown on pro-democracy activists following last year's protests, which sought greater freedoms in Hong Kong.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets plunge over 3% on virus fears
summary: European stock markets plummeted over 3% on Friday due to coronavirus fears, with Frankfurt's DAX 30 index falling 3.6% and Paris' CAC 40 index shedding 3.2%. The decline was attributed to bank and healthcare sector concerns. This follows previous market volatility, with US stocks also experiencing fluctuations amid US-EU trade talks and tariff threats.

site_title: Streamlining govt e-services, digiMC enhancements among Smart Nation initiatives
summary: Minister-in-Charge Vivian Balakrishnan announced Smart Nation initiatives to streamline government services and enhance digital capabilities. The Moments of Life (MOL) app will be improved to house commonly-used services on a single site, personalized for users' needs. The app will also include expanded use of digital Medical Certificates (MCs). Additional improvements will be announced this year, with the app currently having 120,000 downloads.

site_title: Mahathir loses party support for PM job
summary: Malaysia's interim Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad lost support from his own party, Bersatu, and the king requested more time to resolve the political impasse. No one has majority support among lawmakers, and plans to contact party leaders for prime minister nominations are underway. The king also postponed parliament's March 2 meeting, as proposed by Mahathir. The monarch's decision was criticized by lawmakers, who accused Mahathir of disrespecting the country's monarch and pre-empting the king's announcement. The situation remains unresolved, with no clear resolution in sight.

site_title: Banyan Tree Q4 profit more than doubles to S$12.8m
summary: Banyan Tree Holdings reported a net profit of S$12.8 million for the fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2019, more than doubling from S$5.6 million in the same period last year. Revenue rose 71% to S$158.5 million, driven by higher revenue from all operating segments. Earnings per share increased to 1.52 Singapore cents, up from 0.67 cents last year.

site_title: Rolls-Royce reports £852m operating loss on Trent 1000
summary: Rolls-Royce reported a 2019 operating loss of £852 million due to increased costs tackling durability problems with its Trent 1000 engine. Despite this, underlying core operating profit rose 25% to £810 million, and core free cash flow was £911 million. The company expects the novel coronavirus to impact air traffic growth in the near term, but long-term growth trends remain intact.

site_title: Olam's Q4 profit quadruples; declares 4.5-cent final dividend
summary: Olam International's Q4 profit has quadrupled to S$313.4 million due to substantial one-off divestment gains and improved performance across various business segments. The company also declared a 4.5-cent final dividend. This marks a significant increase from the same period last year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end with deep losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 2.42% on Friday, following a global sell-off amid concerns over the economic impact of the coronavirus. The Hang Seng Index fell to 26,129.93, losing over 4% since last Friday. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined, with losses of 3.71% and 4.93%, respectively. The decline marks the second consecutive day of losses for Hong Kong stocks, which have dropped more than 5% over the week.

site_title: SIA cuts senior management salaries, offers voluntary no-pay leave scheme
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is cutting senior management salaries by 10-15% starting March 1 due to the COVID-19 outbreak's impact on travel demand. CEO Goh Choon Phong will take a 15% cut, while executive vice-presidents will receive a 12% reduction, and senior vice-presidents will get a 10% cut. The airline is also offering a voluntary no-pay leave scheme to staff, allowing them to take leave of one week to six months without losing their jobs. This move aims to save jobs as the airline reduces capacity by 9.1% in its group-wide network.

site_title: Australia: Shares post worst weekly drop since 2008 financial crisis
summary: Australian shares plummeted 3.3% on Friday, marking their worst weekly drop since the 2008 global financial crisis. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell to 6,441.20, its worst monthly decline since August 2015. Fears of a coronavirus pandemic and global recession are driving the decline, with Moody's predicting a pandemic will trigger a global recession in the first half of the year. The market has slid 10.5% since its last peak, entering a technical correction.

site_title: New Zealand confirms first coronavirus case
summary: New Zealand confirmed its first coronavirus case on February 28, 2020. A 60-year-old female New Zealand citizen who recently arrived from Iran and traveled to Auckland via Bali tested positive. She is being treated in an Auckland City Hospital and in isolation to prevent spread. Health officials downplayed the risk to the public, stating the chances of a community outbreak remain low. Strict travel bans on arrivals from Iran were also introduced.

site_title: DC rates trimmed 0.2% on average for non-landed residential use
summary: The Singapore government has trimmed the development charge (DC) rates for non-landed residential use by 0.2% on average, effective March 1, 2020 to Aug 31, 2020. This is the second cut in a year, following a 0.3% reduction in September 2019. DC rates remain unchanged for other use groups, including landed residential, commercial, and industrial properties.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks see worst week in 8-1/2 yrs
summary: South Korea's stock market experienced its worst week in 8.5 years, with the KOSPI index plummeting 8.1% from last week. The benchmark index ended down 3.30% at 1,987.01, its lowest finish since September 2019. Foreign investors dumped $2.88 billion worth of KOSPI stocks this week, citing uncertainty over the coronavirus outbreak's spread. The KOSPI has fallen 9.59% so far this year, with analysts suggesting a rebound is unlikely until the virus slows down.

site_title: Chinese ride-sharing cars install added layer of protection amid virus
summary: Chinese ride-sharing giant Didi Chuxing is installing protective shields and providing protective gear to its drivers amid the coronavirus outbreak. The company, which serves 46 locations in Beijing, is installing 100-200 shields per day at no charge to drivers. Drivers, like Wang Xiurong, are required to disinfect their vehicles every four hours and wear protective gear, including plastic gloves and face masks. The move aims to reduce the risk of transmission between drivers and passengers.

site_title: Virus game 'Plague' app pulled in China
summary: A popular virus simulation game "Plague Inc" has been pulled from Apple's App Store in China due to "illegal" content, according to its developer Ndemic Creations. The decision comes as China battles a deadly new coronavirus outbreak, which has killed over 2,700 people and infected nearly 79,000. Ndemic said the game's removal was not clear linked to the outbreak, and the company is trying to contact the Cyberspace Administration to understand their concerns. Players in China criticized the decision on social media, with some praising the game's educational value.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares down more than 3.6% at close on virus fears
summary: Tokyo shares plummeted 3.6% at close on Friday, extending losses for a fifth day amid US and European sell-offs due to coronavirus fears. The Nikkei 225 dropped 3.67% and the Topix index lost 3.65% as global economic concerns worsened. Factory production edged up 0.8% in January, but the jobless rate rose to 2.4%, the first increase in four months, further exacerbating fears of a global slowdown.

site_title: Collapse of Singapore commodity firm leaves lenders exposed
summary: A Singapore commodities firm, Agritrade International, has defaulted on debt, leaving lenders including ING Bank and MUFG Bank facing potential losses of hundreds of millions of dollars. The firm's CEO, Ng Xinwei, and his father, Ng Say Peck, are accused of fraud by lenders, who claim they misrepresented the company's financial position. Agritrade International's subsidiary is in default on $244 million of loans, with lenders holding approximately $600 million of the company's $1.5 billion liabilities. A Singapore court has appointed interim judicial managers to oversee the company.

site_title: Uniqlo reopens more China stores, most partner factories restart
summary: Uniqlo has reopened over 100 stores in China, with 125 remaining closed due to the coronavirus outbreak, after almost all partner factories have restarted. The company, which operates 750 stores in China, secured most of its necessary inventory and remains committed to the market. Despite the ongoing supply chain disruption, Uniqlo plans to continue expanding into new markets, including Europe and Asia. The company's focus on China, as well as Southeast Asia, will remain key pillars of its business growth.

site_title: 'No one cares': Locked-in Wuhan residents adapt to find food
summary: Residents in Wuhan, China, locked down since January 23, are struggling to access basic necessities like food as the city's lockdown has been tightened. Online group-buying services have become the primary means of acquiring groceries, but many residents are finding it difficult to access food due to limited options and high prices. Some neighborhoods have reported "no one cares" about the situation, with residents feeling like refugees. The lockdown has also split the city into silos, with varying levels of control and access to food.

site_title: Hyundai Motor halts work at factory after worker tests positive for coronavirus
summary: Hyundai Motor shut down a factory in South Korea on February 28, 2020, after a worker tested positive for the new coronavirus, disrupting production of popular models such as the Palisade. The factory, which produces sport utility vehicles, was closed in Ulsan, with 34,000 workers affected. Hyundai has placed colleagues in close contact with the infected employee in self-quarantine and taken steps to test them for possible infection. The company has also disinfected the factory and did not provide a timeline for resuming production.

site_title: Climate change: Singapore to set absolute emissions target with peak in 2030
summary: Singapore is set to enhance its climate pledge and long-term strategy, aiming to halve its emissions by 2050 after they peak in 2030. The city-state will submit an absolute peak emission level of 65 million tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent by 2030. To achieve this, Singapore will focus on transforming its industry, economy, and society, as well as developing new technologies like carbon capture and low-carbon fuels. The government will also work with industries to make necessary adjustments and build their competitive advantage.

site_title: Virus slows China's major projects in Asia
summary: China's Belt and Road Initiative, a $1 trillion infrastructure project in Asia, is slowing due to the novel coronavirus outbreak. The virus has cut off Chinese labor supplies and equipment imports, affecting projects in Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, Nepal, and Indonesia. Over 133 countries have imposed entry restrictions on Chinese citizens, and China has imposed quarantines and travel curbs. Construction delays and cancellations are reported, including the March opening of South Asia's tallest communications tower and the Padma Multipurpose Bridge in Bangladesh. China's Foreign Minister downplays the impact, saying it won't have any negative effects on the project.

site_title: KrisEnergy Q4 loss widens to US$82.7m despite higher revenue
summary: KrisEnergy, a debt-restructuring firm, reported a net loss of US$82.7 million for the fourth quarter of 2019, despite a 100% increase in revenue to US$35.1 million. Higher finance costs and depreciation charges contributed to the widening loss. The company's accumulated losses led to no dividend declaration for the year, with a full-year net loss of US$168.9 million.

site_title: No special session of Malaysian parliament on Monday says speaker
summary: Malaysia's parliament will not hold a special session on Monday to decide on the next prime minister, as planned by interim premier Mahathir Mohamad, following a letter from the speaker that did not adhere to parliamentary procedure. The king had failed to find a candidate with a clear majority, and an election would be called if lawmakers couldn't decide on a leader. The move has been criticized by Malaysian lawmakers from across the political spectrum, with some accusing Dr Mahathir of pre-empting the king.

site_title: Singapore bank lending ticks down in January as business loans decline
summary: Singapore bank lending declined 0.2% in January to S$691.15 billion, with business loans falling 0.3% to S$428.35 billion, amid a drop in loans to financial institutions and manufacturing firms. Consumer loans remained steady, but fell 1% year-on-year. Economists caution that the data may not accurately reflect the economic impact of Covid-19, which started in earnest in late January, and suggest that February and March data may be a better indicator. The decline in business loans may also be influenced by the Chinese New Year holidays and uncertainties over visitor arrivals and spending.

site_title: Frontline officers in Covid-19 crisis to get bonus of up to 1 month; cuts for office-holders, MPs
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced in Parliament that frontline officers in the Covid-19 crisis, including healthcare workers, will receive a special bonus of up to one month. In contrast, all political office-holders and MPs will get a one-month pay cut, while senior public service officers will take a half-month pay cut. The government has allocated S$400 million in support for the hardest-hit sectors of tourism, accommodation, and aviation, and will also provide additional aid to self-employed and freelancers.

site_title: Tokyo Disney parks closing for two weeks on virus fears: statement
summary: Tokyo Disneyland and DisneySea are closing for two weeks due to concerns over the new coronavirus. The closure, effective from February 29 to March 15, was announced by the operator Oriental Land in response to government urges to limit the virus spread. The parks, which attract over 30 million visitors annually, are expected to reopen on March 16, pending further developments and government guidance.

site_title: Covid-19 has triggered a fallout in commodity prices, says Olam
summary: Olam International, a Singapore-listed agri-food giant, reports a robust set of fourth-quarter results, with net profit quadrupling to $313.4 million due to divestment gains. The company flags potential fallout in commodity prices and rising counterparty risks from customers in China amid the Covid-19 outbreak. Demand for food items previously led by the thriving out-of-home dining segment in China is significantly impacted, while commodity prices have seen a fallout, particularly in palm oil, grains, and dairy.

site_title: Netlink NBN Trust, vendor end project for support systems
summary: Netlink NBN Trust and a vendor have agreed to mutually discharge a project contract for a new business support system and operation support system. The trust expects to write off S$15.4 million in capitalized project costs, including S$6.1 million in internal staff costs and S$9.3 million in third-party costs. The mutual discharge will allow the trust to focus on its core business and operations, and it will continue to explore options for upgrading its business support systems. The decision is not expected to have a material impact on the trust's distribution for the financial year ending March 31, 2020.

site_title: Baidu warns of big hit from coronavirus outbreak
summary: Baidu, China's largest internet search giant, has warned of a potential 5-13% drop in first-quarter revenues due to the coronavirus outbreak, citing economic uncertainty and limited business visibility. The company forecasts revenues between 21-22.9 billion yuan for the first three months of the year. Despite steady annual revenue growth, Baidu's online marketing revenues dropped 5% to 78.1 billion yuan, and its cloud services, smart devices, and iQIYI platform drove growth. The company has also been investing in advanced technologies like AI and driverless cars.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI sinks 2.7% on Friday afternoon
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 2.7% to 3,028.01 points on Friday, its steepest decline since February 2016. The decline followed a fierce sell-off on Wall Street amid growing concerns over the virus outbreak's economic impact. Volume traded at 2.1 billion securities, exceeding its 2019 average, with decliners outpacing advancers 407 to 78. Major bluechip stocks, including Singtel, DBS, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank, also fell.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit to buy industrial property in Germany for 16.6m euros
summary: Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (Cromwell E-Reit) has agreed to acquire a freehold light industrial/logistics asset in Germany for 16.6 million euros (S$25 million). The property, fully let to Euro Pool System International until May 2024, offers a 6.3% net operating income yield. The acquisition is expected to increase Cromwell E-Reit's exposure to Germany, with its portfolio size in the country rising to 136.6 million euros. The deal is expected to be completed in April after conditions are satisfied.

site_title: Rental rebates for virus-hit retail tenants at Starhill Global Reit's Wisma, Ngee Ann City
summary: Starhill Global Reit has announced rental rebates and marketing assistance to support its retail tenants affected by the coronavirus outbreak. The measures include a one-time rental rebate for tenants in Singapore, which will be "more than the property tax rebate" announced in Budget 2020, and flexibility to operate shorter hours. The company also plans to provide parking redemption and promotional offers at Wisma Atria to attract shoppers. The move is aimed at helping tenants weather the financial impact of the virus.

site_title: Hyflux creditors to file proofs of claim by new March 11 deadline
summary: Hyflux creditors have been given an extended deadline to file proofs of claim by March 11, allowing them to vote on the Utico rescue deal. Creditors, including bank lenders and trade creditors, must submit their claims by 5pm on the new deadline. Holders of Hyflux's notes, perpetual securities, and preference shares are not required to file a proof, as their holdings will be recorded in the Central Depository Pte Ltd and Hyflux will seek court leave to file on their behalf. A court hearing will take place on March 10 to apply for leave to convene the scheme meeting.

site_title: Asia: Markets battered as fears of Covid-19 induced recession gathers pace; STI down 2.5%
summary: Asian markets plummeted on Friday, with the STI down 2.5%, as investors braced for a global economic slowdown due to the Covid-19 outbreak. The decline is part of a week-long downturn, with the MSCI Asia Pacific index on track for its seventh consecutive loss. Despite this, some analysts see Asian equities as more resilient, with lower valuations providing protection from further falls. US markets also suffered, with the S&P 500 and Dow Jones experiencing their biggest single-day drops in records, as investors worry about the impact of the outbreak on the US economy.

site_title: K-pop group BTS cancels concerts as S Korea virus cases pass 2,000
summary: BTS has cancelled four Seoul concerts scheduled for April due to the novel coronavirus outbreak in South Korea, which has surpassed 2,000 cases. The concerts, expected to draw over 200,000 fans, were part of the group's promotion for their new album, Map of the Soul: 7. The decision was made due to uncertainty and a desire to prioritize the health and safety of the fans and artists. The cancellation is the latest in a series of events and activities to be postponed or cancelled in South Korea and around the world due to the outbreak.

site_title: AirAsia X defers A330neo deliveries as coronavirus hits demand
summary: Malaysian long-haul budget airline AirAsia X defers delivery of 78 Airbus A330neo planes due to the coronavirus' impact on demand, citing lower forward bookings and fares. The airline may sell two A330s and return five others to lessors, with negotiations underway for a 30% cut in lease rates. AirAsia X has also cancelled 600 flights in March and reported a widened net loss of RM95.8 million. The airline plans to move towards a dual-fleet strategy with A321s replacing A330s on routes of four to six hours when demand recovers.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 22.67 points or 1.51% to 1,482.92 at 9:03am on Friday, with losers beating gainers 366 to 42. The decline followed a global trend as stocks in Europe and the US also fell due to concerns over US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: GIC chief risk officer to retire, deputy assuming role
summary: GIC's Chief Risk Officer, Chia Tai Tee, is retiring on March 31 and will be succeeded by Deputy Chief Risk Officer Jin Yuen Yee on April 1. Three Chief Investment Officers will also join the group executive committee, overseeing risk management and asset classes. The new appointees will have formal responsibilities to manage enterprise-level issues and chart the future of the Singapore sovereign wealth fund, which manages over $100 billion in assets.

site_title: IOC 'fully committed' to Tokyo Games despite virus: Olympics chief
summary: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) president Thomas Bach has reaffirmed the organization's commitment to holding the 2020 Tokyo Games as planned despite the growing new coronavirus outbreak. Bach stated that the IOC is "fully committed" to a successful Games, starting on July 24. This comes as the outbreak has led to the postponement or cancellation of other sports events in Japan and around the world.

site_title: Tee International CFO quits
summary: Tee International's CFO, Yeo Ai Mei, has resigned to dedicate more time to personal commitments, effective August 31, 2020. She served six-month notice and was appointed in July 2018. The company is seeking a replacement for the CFO position. Tee International recently sold its 63.3% stake in Tee Land to Amcorp Group for S$50.6 million, with shares rising 2.2% following the announcement.

site_title: IndoAgri Q4 loss narrows to 11.35b rupiah on crude palm oil price recovery
summary: IndoAgri, a subsidiary of IndoFood, reported a narrowed net loss of 11.35 billion rupiah for its fourth quarter ended December 31, 2019, compared to a loss of 211.7 billion rupiah the previous year. The improved performance was attributed to a strong recovery in crude palm oil prices and gains from changes in biological assets. Revenue fell 6.4% to 3.56 trillion rupiah, while the loss per share decreased to 8.1 rupiah from 151.7 rupiah. The full-year net loss widened to 411.35 billion rupiah, and no dividend was declared for the full year.

site_title: Nigeria confirms coronavirus case, first in sub-Saharan Africa: minister
summary: Nigeria has confirmed its first case of the novel coronavirus in sub-Saharan Africa, with an Italian citizen who recently returned from Milan, Italy. The patient is clinically stable and being managed at the Infectious Disease Hospital in Lagos. This marks the first case in Nigeria and the second in Africa, following earlier cases in Egypt and Algeria. The World Health Organization warned that African health systems are ill-equipped to respond to a potential outbreak.

images.alt_text: Nigeria on Friday announced the first confirmed case of the novel coronavirus in sub-Saharan Africa.

site_title: Australian regulators examine banks' pandemic preparations
summary: Australia's prudential and corporate regulators are examining banks' pandemic preparations amid a potential coronavirus outbreak. The Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA) has contacted banks and other financial institutions to ensure they have adequate contingency plans in place. Prime Minister Scott Morrison has triggered emergency measures to combat the spread of the disease. The regulator is also monitoring developments and liaising with entities to understand potential impacts on their businesses. Deloitte Access Economics estimates the coronavirus could cost the Australian economy up to A$5.9 billion in the first half of the year.

site_title: South Korea's extra budget to fight coronavirus set to beat 11.6t won Mers spending
summary: South Korea is set to allocate a supplementary budget of at least 11.6 trillion won (S$13.3 billion) to combat the economic impact of the coronavirus, surpassing the 2015 Mers outbreak spending. The budget will focus on small businesses, the medical and tourism sectors, and include tax breaks and cheap loans for affected individuals. The government plans to spend over 75% of the budget within the first two months, aiming to cushion the economic hit. The supplementary budget will be submitted for parliamentary approval next week, with the exact funding details yet to be disclosed.

site_title: Singapore stocks tumble amid global rout; STI drops 2%
summary: Singapore stocks plummeted 2% to 3,048.95, following a global Wall Street rout. The Straits Times Index dropped 62.75 points, with decliners outnumbering advancers 197 to 29. Key banks, including Singtel, Genting Singapore, and United Overseas Bank, fell, while airline SATS and shipbuilder Yangzijiang Shipbuilding also declined. The global market downturn was attributed to concerns over the impact of Covid-19 on economic growth, with the US Dow slumping 1,200 points and the S&P 500 plummeting 4.4%.

site_title: Japan to send vice justice minister to Lebanon after Ghosn escape
summary: Japan plans to send Deputy Justice Minister Hiroyuki Yoshiie to Lebanon to discuss the failed attempts to extradite former Nissan CEO Carlos Ghosn, who escaped to Lebanon in 2019. Yoshiie will meet with Lebanese justice minister and officials to explore options for Ghosn's return for trial on financial misconduct charges. The move comes after Japan's efforts to secure Ghosn's return failed, and Yoshiie will return to Tokyo on Tuesday.

images.alt_text: Japan on Friday said it would send a deputy justice minister to Lebanon after failed attempts to get former Nissan chief Carlos Ghosn to return for trial on financial misconduct charges.

site_title: Yeo Hiap Seng Q4 profit dives 81.5% on lower fair value gains
summary: Yeo Hiap Seng's Q4 net profit plummeted 81.5% to S$338,000, despite a 6.3% increase in revenue to S$84.2 million. Lower fair value gains on investment properties, mainly due to a 50% decrease to S$2.4 million, were the primary cause. Earnings per share dropped to 0.06 Singapore cents, down from 0.31 cents last year. The company proposed a final dividend of S$0.02 per share and a one-time special dividend of S$0.01 per share.

site_title: New Zealand to release data on China trade amid coronavirus outbreak
summary: New Zealand is set to release provisional data on its trade with China for the four weeks to Feb 23, amid the coronavirus outbreak. The data, to be released on Monday, will provide an initial snapshot of trade value and key exports with China. The move comes as global markets face their worst week since the 2008 financial crisis, with investors bracing for the virus to become a pandemic. The release is seen as a response to heightened interest in the impact on businesses from the epidemic.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei plunges nearly 3% at open on virus fears
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index plummeted nearly 3% at open on February 28, 2020, due to US and European sell-offs amid concerns over the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak. The broader Topix index also declined 2.64%. Investors were worried about the economic implications of the virus, leading to a significant drop in the stock market.

site_title: Japan's Jan factory output beats expectations, inventories rise
summary: Japan's factory output rose 0.8% in January, beating expectations, as the country seeks relief from an economy facing recession risks due to the coronavirus outbreak. The increase followed a 1.2% rise in December and was driven by a surge in car and transport equipment output. Inventories also rose 1.5% in January, the largest gain since 2018, while retail sales fell 0.4% in the same period. The better-than-expected output reading may provide some relief to policymakers struggling to boost growth amid the outbreak's economic fallout.

site_title: Australia: Shares slide into technical correction as coronavirus spreads
summary: The Australian share market slid into correction territory, with the S&P/ASX 200 index falling 3.5% to 6,426.8, amid mounting fears over the global spread of the coronavirus. This is the market's biggest weekly fall since the 2008 global financial crisis. The benchmark has slid 10.7% since its last peak a week ago, with iron-ore prices tumbling and energy stocks also being heavily impacted.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars suffer the world's woes, yields hit record lows
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars are experiencing significant losses due to fears over the global economy and the spread of the coronavirus. Despite the Australian dollar briefly recovering from its 11-year low, it remains down 0.8% for the week. Analysts predict two rate cuts by the Reserve Bank of Australia this year, while the US Federal Reserve is expected to cut interest rates in March. Bond yields have hit record lows, with Australian 10-year bonds reaching 0.838%. The kiwi dollar has also fallen 0.8% for the week, with investors pricing in a 50-50 chance of a second rate cut by year-end.

site_title: South Korea's coronavirus cases pass 2,000: authorities
summary: South Korea reported 256 new coronavirus cases, bringing the total to 2,022, with over 90% of cases in Daegu, the epicentre of the outbreak. No further deaths were reported, keeping the toll at 13. Authorities are investigating over 210,000 Shincheonji Church members, with the city's mayor predicting the total could reach 3,000 in the coming days.

site_title: Facebook cancels developer conference as tech companies respond to virus
summary: Facebook cancels its annual developer conference, F8, due to concerns over the coronavirus, as tech companies worldwide respond to the global outbreak. The company will instead host "locally hosted events, videos, and live streamed content." Other companies, including Microsoft, Beautycounter, and Indeed, have also cancelled or postponed events and restricted international travel. The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports a coronavirus case of unknown origin in northern California, and California Governor Gavin Newsom is monitoring over 8,400 people for coronavirus symptoms.

site_title: Facebook sues analytics firm for data misuse
summary: Facebook has filed a federal lawsuit against oneAudience, a data analytics firm, for allegedly using "malicious" software to collect user data on social media platforms. OneAudance paid software makers to install the software, which allowed them to gather information about people on Facebook and other social media sites. Facebook had previously taken enforcement measures against oneAudance, including disabling apps and sending a legal notification.
