OneAudance declined to cooperate with an audit, prompting Facebook to take further action.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks battered at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted almost 2% in early trading on Friday, following a global market rout fueled by the spread of the coronavirus. The Hang Seng Index fell 529.56 points to 26,249.06, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 66.69 points to 2,924.64. The Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 63.31 points to 1,831.82, amid fears of a global economic impact.

site_title: China reports 44 new virus deaths, lowest rise in new cases in over a month
summary: China reported 44 new virus deaths, the lowest daily rise in new cases in over a month, with a total of 2,788 fatalities in mainland China. The death toll is concentrated in Hubei province, with 78,824 infections reported. The general decline in new infections in China comes as the World Health Organization warns of a "decisive point" in the epidemic. China has also taken measures to prevent imports, ordering arrivals from affected countries to self-quarantine for 14 days.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Jardine C&C, Olam, Venture, Yangzijiang, Haw Par, Hong Leong Finance
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Key stocks to watch on Friday included Jardine C&C, Olam, Venture, Yangzijiang, Haw Par, and Hong Leong Finance, with each company reporting new developments. Jardine C&C saw a 2% drop in shares after reporting a marginally higher earnings, while Olam International more than quadrupled its net profit to S$313.4 million. Venture Corp reported a 10.6% drop in net profit, and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding saw a 30% drop. Haw Par Corporation posted a 1.8% increase in net profit, while Hong Leong Finance's net profit fell 12.9%.

site_title: Mixed messages, test delays hamper US coronavirus response
summary: The US coronavirus response is hampered by mixed messages, test delays, and limited testing capabilities. Despite warnings of an inevitable outbreak, only a handful of public health departments can test for the novel virus, and the federal government lacks adequate funding and protective masks. The CDC has advised Americans to prepare for domestic acceleration of the virus, but conflicting messages from the White House have added to the uncertainty. With 60 confirmed US cases, the US is struggling to keep up with the true figure, and experts fear widespread community spread and inadequate preparedness.

site_title: EC World Reit cuts Q4 DPU, sees muted demand for Wuhan asset
summary: EC World Reit's distribution per unit (DPU) fell 3.8% to 1.51 Singapore cents for Q4 2020, due to muted demand for its Wuhan asset. The Reit retained 5% of capital distribution for working capital and unforeseen contingencies. Gross revenue grew 10.2% to S$25.9 million, while net property income (NPI) rose 17.4% to S$24.5 million. The Reit's Wuhan asset, which accounts for 1.6% of NPI, is expected to see muted demand due to the coronavirus situation.

site_title: First case of coronavirus confirmed in Netherlands
summary: The first case of coronavirus in the Netherlands was confirmed on February 27, 2020, in a patient who had traveled to northern Italy. The patient was placed in isolation, and those in close contact with them were checked out. The National Institute for Public Health and the Environment advised the public to be cautious to avoid further infections.

site_title: Suit Up
summary: Spring fashion trends feature pinstripe suits with a casual twist, seen in wraparound styles at Dolce & Gabbana, Emporio Armani, and Chalayan. Satin fabrics also make a statement. Meanwhile, the fashion world is moving beyond traditional boardroom attire, embracing more relaxed and modern looks.

site_title: Golden Agri-Resources triples earnings for Q4
summary: Golden Agri-Resources reported a net profit of US$239.6 million for its Q4 2019, tripling the previous year's US$79.3 million, driven by strengthening palm oil prices and a US$214 million net fair value gain. Revenue edged up 3% to US$1.7 billion. For the full year, net profit reversed to US$194 million, while revenue slipped 10.3% to US$6.43 billion. The company is confident in long-term palm oil demand fundamentals and expects a short-term impact from the novel coronavirus.

site_title: Top Democrat signals Sanders needs majority to claim nomination
summary: US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi signaled that Democratic presidential frontrunner Bernie Sanders needs an outright majority of delegates to win the nomination, not just a plurality. Sanders is battling moderate rivals, and party leaders are eager to prevent his ascendancy. Pelosi stated that the person with a majority plus one will be nominated, and she pledged the party's wholehearted support for the eventual nominee, emphasizing unity.

site_title: California monitoring 8,400 for possible coronavirus but lacks test kits
summary: California is monitoring over 8,400 people for possible coronavirus symptoms after a case of unknown origin was reported, potentially the first incident of the virus spreading within US communities. The state lacks test kits, with only 200 available, and is appealing for expanded testing protocols. California's Governor Gavin Newsom expressed concerns about the inadequate testing capacity, while the CDC director Robert Redfield announced that more test kits are being sent to California and backs expanded testing.

site_title: Beyond Meat triples sales but shares fall after profit miss
summary: Beyond Meat Inc reported a 7% drop in shares after missing earnings expectations and announcing executive chairman Seth Goldman's resignation. Despite tripling fourth-quarter sales to $98.5 million, the company reported a 1 cent per share loss, narrowly missing analyst expectations. The company's share price has risen four-fold since its IPO, but is now trading at 232.8 times expected earnings, leading some to view the stock as overvalued. Despite this, Beyond Meat expects net revenue of $490-510 million this year, a 64-71% increase from 2019.

site_title: Technical glitch halts trading at Canada's TMX amid market selloff
summary: Canada's TMX Group halted trading at its three local bourses on Thursday due to a technical glitch, nearly two hours before the scheduled closing. The halt affected the TSX, TSX Alpha, and TSX-Venture exchanges, causing concerns over market visibility and capacity issues. The glitch occurred amid a surge in market activity due to the global spread of the coronavirus outbreak. TMX said it is investigating the problem and apologized for the inconvenience.

site_title: Europe: Pandemic fears pummel stocks into correction territory
summary: European stocks fell 3.8% on Thursday, entering correction territory, as concerns over the coronavirus pandemic deepened. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index has dropped over 10% from its record high, with basic resources and travel stocks among the worst performers. Investors' optimism turned to pessimism in just a week, driven by a spike in infections outside China, particularly in Italy.

site_title: Lines go dead for some Circles.Life staff
summary: Circles.Life, a Singapore-based telco startup, is cutting staff as part of its downsizing efforts. The company, which has around 500 employees across three offices, confirmed the layoffs, stating that less than 5% of its global headcount has been axed. Sources indicate the cuts are deeper, particularly in Taiwan and Australia markets, and that no department was spared. The move comes after Circles.Life secured funding from Warburg Pincus and other investors, and follows its rapid growth, including expansion into Taiwan and Australia.

site_title: ECB plays down immediate action against economic impact of coronavirus
summary: European Central Bank policymakers downplayed immediate action to counter the economic impact of the coronavirus, citing uncertainty over the long-term implications. ECB President Christine Lagarde and others said it was too early to gauge the virus's impact, and the time for central bank action had not come yet. The ECB has already pushed interest rates to record lows and resumed a bond-buying program, but policymakers expect a limited hit to economic growth, with Austrian governor Robert Holzmann predicting a rebound.

site_title: Chinese scientist sentenced to prison in US for technology theft
summary: A Chinese scientist, Hongjin Tan, was sentenced to 24 months in federal prison for stealing next-generation battery technology from Phillips 66 in Oklahoma. Tan, a 36-year-old Chinese national, pleaded guilty to stealing trade secrets worth over $1 billion. The Justice Department described the theft as another instance of China's attempts to steal American intellectual property, which is detrimental to national security and the free-market economy. Tan must also pay $150,000 in restitution to his former employer.

site_title: Bryant NBA memorabilia items to go on the auction block
summary: Kobe Bryant's personal memorabilia, including his 2000 NBA Finals uniform and handprints from Grauman's Chinese Theatre, are set to be auctioned off in April. The items, valued between $4,000 and $20,000, were collected by Julien's Auctions and will be part of a larger sale of over 300 sports items. The auction aims to pay tribute to Bryant, a five-time NBA champion and 18-time NBA All-Star, who tragically passed away in a helicopter crash last month at age 41.

site_title: SGX gives listcos 2-month breather for AGM amid fears of large gatherings during outbreak
summary: SGX has granted a 2-month extension to all listed companies, not just those with China operations, to hold their annual general meetings (AGMs) by June 30, 2020, due to concerns about large gatherings amid the Covid-19 outbreak. Companies must still issue annual reports and unaudited financial statements on time, and can consider alternative arrangements such as virtual information sessions and proxy voting. The extension aims to ensure shareholders continue to receive timely information while minimizing risks associated with large gatherings.

site_title: Yangzijiang Q4 net profit falls 30%
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, China's largest non-state owned shipbuilder, reported a 30% drop in net profit to 642.3 million yuan in its fourth quarter, mainly due to lower foreign exchange-related gains. Revenue fell 2% to 4.85 billion yuan. The company delivered more vessels in the quarter but saw a decrease in trading business revenue. A final cash dividend of 4.5 Singapore cents per share was proposed for the full year.

site_title: Oil prices dive to lowest in over a year on coronavirus fears
summary: Oil prices plummeted to their lowest in over a year due to concerns about a pandemic slowing the global economy and eroding demand for crude. On February 27, 2020, Brent crude dropped 2.3% to $52.18 a barrel, and West Texas Intermediate futures fell 3.4% to $47.09 a barrel, their lowest levels since December 2018 and January 2019, respectively. The surge in new coronavirus infections outside China further fueled the decline, marking the first time since the outbreak began that new cases outside China exceeded those in China.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Podcasting and Leadership in the Exponential Era
summary: Glenn van Zutphen interviews Graham Brown, author of "Leadership in the Exponential Era", about the impact of the Asian Century on businesses, upskilling the workforce, and the future of radio and conversations in the exponential era. Brown emphasizes the need for companies to adapt to changing complexities and the importance of authentic leadership in uncertain times. The conversation highlights the need for Singapore to prioritize tracking leadership development to boost its global competitiveness.

site_title: Olam Q4 profit more than quadruples on higher earnings, exceptional gains
summary: Olam International, an agri and food giant, reported a net profit of S$313.4 million for Q4 2019, more than quadruple the S$75.3 million a year ago. Revenue rose 3.3% to S$8.74 billion, driven by higher contributions from food staples and packaged foods. The company also recorded net exceptional gains of S$83.7 million and recommended a final cash dividend of 4.5 Singapore cents per share, up from 4 cents a year ago. This brought the full-year net profit to S$564.2 million, up 62.2% from the previous year.

site_title: Federal Reserve seen slashing rates amid virus threat, low inflation
summary: The Federal Reserve is expected to cut interest rates amid the growing threat of the new coronavirus, with traders betting on a 54% chance of a rate cut as soon as next month. The Fed has already lowered rates three times last year and has room to cut further, but officials are cautious due to low inflation. The US economy is already feeling the impact of the virus, with major corporations such as Best Buy and Apple warning of potential earnings losses.

site_title: Malaysia announces stimulus package to blunt coronavirus hit
summary: Malaysia's interim Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad announced a stimulus package worth RM20 billion (S$6.6 billion) to counter the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak, which is expected to weaken economic growth this year. The package includes measures to support businesses and individuals, as well as stimulate demand for travel and tourism. The government has lowered its economic growth forecast to 3.2-4.2% and widened its fiscal deficit target to 3.4% of GDP.

images.alt_text: Malaysia, in the grip of a political leadership battle, announced a package of measures to counter the coronavirus outbreak, which is set to weaken economic growth this year.

site_title: Bob Iger's creative endeavours
summary: Bob Chapek, 60, has taken over as Disney's chief executive, succeeding Bob Iger two years earlier than expected. Chapek, known as "Bob C" inside Disney, has a 27-year tenure with the company, mostly in unflashy businesses like consumer products and film distribution. He is not a high-profile executive, preferring to keep a low profile. Chapek has training wheels, serving as executive chairman under Iger for the next 22 months. He is known for setting clear goals and empowering lieutenants, and has experience in theme park operations and consumer products.

site_title: Competition watchdog gives nod to ARA, Logos deal
summary: The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) has cleared the proposed merger between Logos China Investments and ARA Logistics, a unit of ARA Asset Management. The deal has been deemed not to infringe the Competition Act.

site_title: Apple investor vote sounds 'warning' over China app takedowns
summary: Apple's investor proposal calling for the company to report on its commitment to freedom of expression in China received 40.6% support, a significant increase from previous years, indicating a growing concern among investors about Apple's actions in China. The proposal, which highlighted the 2017 removal of VPN apps from the App Store, prompted Apple to respond to the vote and has led to a statement from the company reaffirming its commitment to freedom of expression as a human right.

site_title: US: Stocks drop more than 4%, extending rout amid coronavirus fears
summary: US stocks plummeted 4.4% on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling nearly 1,200 points to 25,766.64, its worst session in over two years. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also slumped 4.4% and 4.6%, respectively. The losses are attributed to growing concerns over the coronavirus, with 50 countries now affected and the risk of a global slowdown. Market experts warn of a possible recession, citing lofty valuations and the need for a correction.

site_title: Economic and market fallout from Covid-19 set to worsen before it gets better
summary: The global outbreak of Covid-19 is expected to worsen the economic and market fallout, potentially leading to a downward revaluation of the US bull market. The virus's spread in South Korea, Europe, and Iran has triggered a rout in stock markets, with the S&P 500 slumping 8% over five trading days. Global growth is expected to take a hit, with two downside scenarios: a decline in world GDP of 0.4-1.3% in 2020. Monetary and fiscal stimulus may help cushion a downturn, but businesses and investors are bracing for sharp market drawdowns and disruptions to production and consumer spending.

site_title: MPs urge more help for firms amid Covid-19 outbreak
summary: Singaporean MPs urged more support for firms amid the Covid-19 outbreak, calling for longer duration and faster disbursal of assistance. Many requested help for construction firms, healthcare workers, and freelancers, and some proposed measures such as lower rents and taxi rentals. The MPs also highlighted concerns over skills upgrading, environmental sustainability, and fiscal sustainability, with some suggesting measures to alleviate cash flow woes and promote cleaner vehicles. The Budget debate continues on Friday with a round-up speech by Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat.

site_title: Confidence returning for UK consumers and companies: surveys
summary: Confidence among UK consumers and companies has reached its highest level in 18 months, according to surveys. GfK's consumer confidence index rose to -7 in February, while a Lloyds Bank survey found business confidence remained at a 14-month high of 23%. Companies turned positive about Brexit for the first time since September 2018, and hiring intentions rose for a fourth month in a row. The optimism suggests the UK economy will grow slightly in the first quarter of 2020, despite the potential impact of coronavirus.

site_title: Building Food Empire up from Russia to Asia
summary: Singapore-listed Food Empire Holdings, a 3-in-1 instant coffee mix business, is shifting its focus from Eastern Europe to a multi-regional approach with Asia at the forefront. The company, which has spent decades building its business in Russia, Kazakhstan, and Ukraine, now sees Vietnam as its second-largest market. This strategic shift aims to expand Food Empire's presence and growth potential in the Asian market.

site_title: USD falls, virus impact lifts rate-cut expectations
summary: The US dollar fell 0.4% to 98.658, its weakest since February 12, amid rising expectations for a Federal Reserve interest rate cut to offset the impact of the novel coronavirus. The euro rose 0.6% to its highest in over two weeks, while investors bet on a European Central Bank rate cut. Money markets now price a 25 basis-point Fed rate cut by April and a 10 basis-point ECB rate cut in July, with US rates expected to fall more significantly.

site_title: Successful But Lonely At The Top
summary: A Singaporean businessman who lost his company in 2008 struggled with depression, suicidal thoughts, and feelings of loneliness after losing his business and reputation. He was unable to seek help due to fear of being judged by his peers and the stigma surrounding mental health issues in Singapore. Experts estimate that 100% of C-level managers suffer from anxiety and 70-80% experience depression, with 10% having suicidal thoughts. A survey found that 30% of senior executives have undergone bouts of depression, but only 20% are willing to discuss their mental health with their companies. The article highlights the need for corporate mental health programs and removing the stigma surrounding mental illness.

site_title: Infected flight attendant worked LA route: S Korea
summary: A Korean Air flight attendant working on flights between Seoul and Los Angeles tested positive for the novel coronavirus, according to South Korea's disease control agency. The flight attendant, in her 20s, worked on flights KE017 and KE012 on February 19-20, and later tested positive for the virus. This brings the total number of infected people in South Korea to 1,595, making it the largest number outside of China. The Korea Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is investigating people who had contact with the employee on the flight.

site_title: Hong Kong property tycoon Peter Woo to take Wheelock private
summary: Hong Kong property tycoon Peter Woo is taking Wheelock private with an offer to shareholders to buy out their shares at a 52% premium. The Woo family will pay HK$12 cash per share and offer one share each of Wharf Real Estate Investment and Wharf Holdings. The deal values Wheelock shares at HK$71.90 each, with a total transaction value of around HK$147.6 billion. Analysts predict a high success rate for the privatisation, with Wheelock's other shareholders potentially receiving all-cash offers.

site_title: SPH Reit tenants to get more help to pull through virus outbreak
summary: SPH Reit has announced additional assistance packages for its tenants to help them weather the Covid-19 outbreak. The packages will be tailored to individual tenants' circumstances and will include initiatives to raise footfall and reduce staff costs. The company will also pass on a 15% property tax rebate announced in Budget 2020. Precautionary measures such as enhanced cleaning and disinfecting have been implemented, and tenants will be allowed to shorten hours to reduce staff costs. The move aims to mitigate the decline in footfall and tenant sales.

site_title: Asean moving up the startup menu for global investors
summary: South-east Asia's startup scene is gaining global attention, with 315 VC deals worth $5.8 billion raised by non-regional investors in 2019, according to Preqin data. Despite the COVID-19 outbreak, interest remains robust, with investors expecting to continue deploying capital in the region. Key factors drawing investors include the region's young demographics, fast-growing GDP, and relatively cheaper startup valuations. Corporates and family offices from outside the region are also investing, with Chinese and Korean corporations making a notable presence in Vietnam.

site_title: Watches on Show
summary: LVMH Watch Week Dubai 2020 took place in February, showcasing the group's watchmaking brands, including Bvlgari, Hublot, TAG Heuer, and Zenith. The event highlighted Bvlgari's new Serpenti Seduttori Tourbillon, the smallest women's tourbillon on the market, powered by a rare tourbillon movement, BVL150. This revival of small mechanical movements, lost in the early 1970s, marks a return to traditional watchmaking techniques, blending Swiss knowledge and jewelry-making expertise.

site_title: Venture Corp's profit falls 10.6% as costs hike outstrips revenue rise
summary: Venture Corp, a Singapore-based electronics manufacturing services firm, reported a 10.6% drop in net profit for the fourth quarter, driven by rising costs. Revenue edged up 2.9% to S$932.1 million, but raw materials costs rose 4.9%. The company expects a stronger second half of 2020, despite disruptions from the Covid-19 outbreak. Venture's shares closed up 13 cents, or 0.79%, at S$16.50.

site_title: Will the coronavirus lead to the Great Sino-American De-coupling?
summary: The COVID-19 outbreak may lead to the Great Sino-American De-coupling, with US national borders potentially being strengthened to protect against future foreign threats. This idea was first introduced by Nassim Taleb, who described the 2008 financial crisis as a "black swan" event. The unpredictability and transformative consequences of the COVID-19 outbreak have led some to consider it a black swan event, potentially altering global economic dynamics and increasing tensions between the US and China.

site_title: Microsoft joins Apple and HP in paring back outlook due to virus
summary: Microsoft joins Apple and HP in reducing its quarterly outlook due to the novel coronavirus outbreak, citing supply chain disruptions and slowing production of computers. The company expects to miss its earlier guidance for fiscal third-quarter revenue in its Windows personal-computer software and Surface device business. The move reflects broader industry concerns about the virus's impact on the global economy and technology sector.

site_title: PM Johnson gives EU 4 months to make a Brexit deal - or he walks
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson has given the European Union 4 months to agree to a Canada-style trade deal, warning that if no deal is reached by June, the UK will walk away from negotiations. The UK's negotiating mandate, released Thursday, emphasizes sovereignty and sets a tough timetable for the talks. The EU and UK have differing views on issues such as regulations, state aid, and access to waters, which could make reaching a deal challenging.

site_title: SIFA 2020: Sterling slate of shows
summary: The 2020 Singapore International Festival of Arts (SIFA) is considered the best edition yet, helmed by director Gaurav Kripalani. The festival features a diverse slate of shows, including 100% Singapore, a social experiment featuring 100 Singaporeans, and As The World Tipped, a gravity-defying dance performance. Tan Dun's Buddha Passion, a six-act choral work, and Ensemble Intercontemporain's closing night performance, are also highlights. SIFA 2020 aims to please both connoisseurs and casual audiences, showcasing accessible and crowd-pleasing programming that balances niche and crowd-pullers.

site_title: Chinatown's Porcelain Hotel up for sale with S$115m guide price
summary: The Porcelain Hotel in Singapore's Chinatown is up for sale with a guide price of S$115 million. The 138-key boutique hotel spans four storeys and occupies a 10,143 sq ft land area. The buyer can opt for vacant possession or a sale and leaseback arrangement, with potential for repositioning and converting the ground floor into food and beverage use. Real estate funds, developers, and hotel operators are expected to show interest, as the property is a rare opportunity to own a row of shophouses with hotel approval in the area.

site_title: Online sales help some retailers cushion blow from outbreak
summary: The COVID-19 outbreak has led to a decline in physical retail sales in Singapore, but online sales are helping some retailers cushion the blow. Furniture retailer Ikea has seen a 14.5% increase in online sales, while homegrown brands Awfully Chocolate, Mothercare, and Iuiga have also experienced significant online growth, with some reporting a doubling or tripling of sales. Online sales are now contributing to a larger share of their overall revenue, providing respite for retailers who have invested in integrated online channels.

site_title: Navigating uncertainty and creating a resilient tomorrow
summary: The COVID-19 outbreak has significantly impacted businesses worldwide, causing uncertainty, supply chain disruptions, and a talent shortage. Companies are activating business continuity plans, shifting to remote work, and re-calibrating strategies to ensure workforce safety and well-being. To mitigate the impact, business leaders must think differently, act with vision, and execute with agility, allocating resources nimbly and focusing on building strong organizational culture. Five key steps to mitigate the impact include reimagining business practices, evaluating risks, and positioning for growth, as 84% of Singapore CEO respondents expect global GDP to decline.

site_title: Norway's wealth fund not adjusting portfolio to virus outbreak for now
summary: Norway's sovereign wealth fund, valued at $1.1 trillion, is not planning to adjust its portfolio in response to the novel coronavirus outbreak, citing a 30-year investment horizon. CEO Yngve Slyngstad stated that the fund is monitoring market fluctuations, but it's difficult to analyze this type of risk, and therefore, no major buying or selling decisions are expected. The fund's 2019 results showed a record $180 billion return, with a 25% increase in the MSCI World Index.

site_title: More spice needed at The Blue Ginger
summary: The Blue Ginger, a Peranakan restaurant, has opened its new offshoot in Great World City. Despite its heritage and authentic cuisine, the restaurant prioritizes volume business over quality, resulting in unimpressive dishes such as kueh pie tee and ngoh heong. However, some items like otah otah and sotong keluak show promise. The service is friendly and attentive, but the restaurant falls short in its execution. Overall, the new Blue Ginger is an average dining experience, with a rating of 5.5.

images.alt_text: Sotong keluak is closer to squid ink than black nut sauce, but at least the squid is nice and tender.
Above: Nonya noodles would be quite enjoyable if they had eased up on the cornstarch to thicken the gravy and just let the broth soak in naturally.
The otah otah, despite an odd rubbery texture, has a pleasing old-school mix of spices and kaffir leaves that's comfortingly familiar.
Above: The durian cendol is a huge disappointment with its fossilised green worms and the pasty sago gula melaka.
Above: Commercial cups of kueh pie tee with so little filling, topped with a sliver of shrimp to justify its S$2 a cup price.

site_title: Out of the Box
summary: Cheryl Chan, a finance industry worker, commissioned architect Wu Yen Yen to design a unique two-storey plus attic semi-detached house in Bukit Timah. Chan wanted a fun space for her kids, large bedrooms, and interesting spaces. Wu created a spiral staircase connecting the second floor to the attic, accessible through secret doors in the kids' bedrooms. The house also features a spacious, naturally ventilated bathroom and a Parisian-style bathroom with a skylight. Chan appreciates the surprises and creative spaces in her new home, which she believes should include both fun and practical elements for both kids and adults.

site_title: Team Bloomberg's Instagram posts dodging scrutiny
summary: Several high-profile Instagram accounts, including World Star Hip Hop and Funny Hood Vidz, posted sponsored content for Michael Bloomberg's presidential campaign without using Instagram's official disclosure tool, allowing the campaign to escape scrutiny. The accounts, which have millions of followers, posted fake "relatable" tweets and edited videos, but their private status prevented non-followers from seeing the ads. Facebook, which owns Instagram, has been scrambling to respond to the campaign's tactics, but has not yet penalized the meme accounts involved.

images.alt_text: Facebook, which has spent years preparing for the 2020 presidential elections, has been caught off-guard by the Bloomberg campaign's aggressive and unorthodox use of social media.

site_title: US growth in Q4 is unrevised at 2.1%, but bumpy road ahead
summary: The US economy grew at a 2.1% annualized rate in the fourth quarter, matching expectations. Despite this, economists predict a bumpy road ahead due to the impact of the novel coronavirus on the manufacturing and services sectors, including potential supply chain disruptions and a slowdown in consumer spending. Financial markets remain volatile, with investors seeking safe-haven government bonds. The US central bank has signaled its intention to keep monetary policy on hold, and President Trump has assured Americans of the low risk from the outbreak.

site_title: MOH confirms 3 new Covid-19 cases; four others recovered and discharged
summary: The Ministry of Health in Singapore confirmed 3 new Covid-19 cases, including one linked to a previous case, bringing the total number of cases to 96. Four others have recovered and been discharged, with 66 fully recovered. Eight hospital patients are in critical condition, and a 12-year-old Raffles Institution student is among the new cases.

site_title: Interview - Choe Peng Sum, CEO of Pan Pacific Hotels Group
summary: Pan Pacific Hotels Group CEO Choe Peng Sum is navigating the challenges of the coronavirus pandemic with experience and resilience. Despite the crisis, the group is on track to open 15 properties in the next two years, including its first European location in London. Choe emphasizes the importance of trust, safety, and team spirit in hospitality, and is developing a new lifestyle brand to compete with the rise of millennials and Airbnb. The group is also exploring partnerships with other hotel chains and expanding into emerging markets. With a focus on people and a hands-on approach, Choe aims to build a trusted brand that prioritizes guest interests.

images.alt_text: Choe Peng Sum.

site_title: House Specials
summary: Fine dining restaurants are investing in in-house specialists to elevate the dining experience, moving away from external expertise. Three Michelin-starred restaurant Les Amis has hired a cheese and caviar master, a pasta maker, and a tea expert, while another restaurant, Cloudstreet, has introduced a non-alcoholic pairing program. In-house experts provide personalized experiences, sharing stories about products and ingredients, and offer bespoke pairings. This approach is driven by the need to differentiate restaurants in a competitive market, and diners' increasing expectations for unique experiences.

site_title: Head Start
summary: Luxury watch brands Vacheron Constantin, Laurent FERRIER, Chanel, and Bell & Ross unveiled new timepieces ahead of major watch shows. Vacheron Constantin launched its first dedicated ladies' line, Égérie, with three models featuring interchangeable straps and diamond pave bezels. Laurent FERRIER's Galet Annual Calendar School Piece "Vintage" is a limited edition modelled after vintage timepieces of the 1950s. Chanel's J12 X-Ray is a transparent, all-sapphire watch with a hand-wound movement and sapphire strap links. Bell & Ross's BR 03-92 GREY LUM features a Super-LumiNova C3 treatment for maximum visibility.

images.alt_text: 01 VACHERON CONSTANTIN EGERIE
02 LAURENT FERRIER GALET ANNUAL CALENDAR SCHOOL PIECE "VINTAGE"
03 CHANEL J12 X-RAY
04 BELL & ROSS BR 03-92 GREY LUM

site_title: Malaysian lawmakers meet on Monday to resolve impasse
summary: Malaysian lawmakers are set to meet on Monday to resolve the country's political impasse after the king failed to find a candidate with a clear majority to become the next prime minister. Interim Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has announced that elections will be called if no one gets majority support from parliament on March 2. The impasse stems from an internal battle of power between Mahathir and long-time rival Anwar Ibrahim, who is backed by the Pakatan Harapan coalition. The country's economy, which is growing at its slowest pace in a decade, is at stake, with a RM20 billion stimulus package announced to counter the global coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: US, India deepen bilateral bonds, despite deal disappointment
summary: US President Donald Trump's two-day visit to India ended without a comprehensive trade deal, despite discussions on energy, telecoms, and defence agreements. The meeting aimed to strengthen bilateral ties and boost economic cooperation, but the "Namaste Trump" rally in Ahmedabad was marred by deadly Hindu-Muslim communal clashes in Delhi. Despite the disappointment, the US and India signed several agreements, including a defence-related deal, and the two countries expressed their commitment to a strong relationship. The visit was seen as a morale booster for both leaders, particularly Trump, ahead of the US presidential election in November.

site_title: StanChart posts strong results but Covid-19, economic woes cast shadow over profits
summary: Standard Chartered posted a 46% jump in annual profit to $3.7 billion, but warned of worsening asset quality and loan growth due to the Covid-19 epidemic, particularly in Hong Kong. Analysts predict at least two quarters of declining asset quality and loan growth for lenders with significant earnings from Hong Kong. The bank cited lower interest rates and the outbreak as factors contributing to its revised earnings target, now expected to meet in 2022.

site_title: A formula for growth after the startup stage
summary: A new report by TrueSpace and Gallup suggests that second-stage companies need to adopt a strategic approach to expand and achieve long-term growth. The report identified five conditions for successful growth, including a clear focus on the target market, which can lead to stronger revenue. The conditions were compiled from data on nearly 2,500 entrepreneurs in the US over five years. Experts agree that a strategic approach is necessary, as opportunistic growth strategies often fail as companies grow. Companies that have implemented the TrueSpace model have seen significant increases in revenue, with some reporting seven times their revenue in enterprise value.

site_title: Leading tech firms can help create the future
summary: Singapore's 2020 Budget emphasizes the role of technology companies in driving the country's technological and economic progress. The government aims to build enterprise capabilities, deepen partnerships, and develop its people through collaborations with academia, research institutes, startups, and SMEs. Key initiatives include a coastal and flood protection fund, a new job-matching initiative, and investments in digital connectivity and automation solutions. The government encourages technology companies to co-create the future with SMEs, academia, and research institutes, focusing on sustainable power, digital connectivity, and environmental issues.

site_title: STI ends lower despite late rally
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.2% lower at 3,111.70, despite a late rally, amid ongoing concerns over the Covid-19 outbreak. Tech manufacturers AEM Holdings, Frencken Group, and UMS Holdings rose, while property listings PropNex and APAC Realty edged up. Analysts expect further recovery in the property market if the outbreak is short-term.

site_title: Private home rents firm amid tight supply, rising expat demand
summary: Rentals of private homes in Singapore have risen 1.4% year-on-year in Q4 2019, the highest since 2012, driven by strong expat demand and a tightening of new inventory supply. The rental index was boosted by the non-landed home segment, with rents increasing 1.9% y-o-y. With fewer private homes being completed and some stock being removed, landlords are now able to charge more, with some securing rentals up to $500 higher per month. Experts expect rental growth to remain steady in 2020, with a 1-3% increase anticipated.

site_title: Singapore O&G ex-director charged with 2 counts of cheating
summary: A former director of Singapore O&G, Christopher Chong Meng Tak, has been charged with two counts of cheating. Chong, 62, allegedly dishonestly concealed a $1.5 million payment from dermatologist Joyce Lim Teng Ee and falsely represented it to Bank Julius Baer. This led to SOG paying $26.5 million to Lim and Bank Julius Baer accepting the payment. Chong faces up to 10 years in jail and/or a fine if found guilty.

site_title: Haw Par FY19 net profit edges up 1.8%
summary: Haw Par Corporation reported a 1.8% increase in net profit to S$182.2 million for FY19, driven by higher sales from its healthcare business in the first half. Revenue rose 2.6% to S$244 million, but gross profit margin fell to 57.2% due to increased cost of sales. The company proposed a second and final dividend of 15 cents per share, totaling 30 cents per share for the year. Executive director Han Ah Kuan will retire and step down at the end of June 2020.

site_title: Is craft beer losing its fizz?
summary: Craft beer in Singapore faces a saturated market, with 20 local brands competing for attention. Despite this, small batch brewers are holding up, and the industry remains a niche sector. Meanwhile, experts discuss various topics, including disrupting aging, sustainable investing, and the future of department stores.

site_title: The newest of the new at VinExpo in Paris
summary: VinExpo, a wine and spirits trade fair in Paris, showcased new and innovative products, including whiskey from Tibet and organic champagne. The three-day event, attended by 2,800 exhibitors from 20 countries, aimed to establish Paris as the world's top wine and spirits marketplace, surpassing its long-standing home in Bordeaux. The event's new CEO, Rodolphe Lameyse, expressed ambitions to make VinExpo the leading platform for the industry, marking a shift from the traditional German trade show, ProWein.

site_title: What's Up This Week
summary: Key events include the return of Garden Beats and Singapore Rockfest music festivals, with Foals and Gioli & Assia headlining. Meanwhile, a new Latin American-themed home barbecue service, Ola Kitchen Group, has launched, and a chic Nonya food outlet, New Nonya, has opened in Great World City. Comedian John Cleese is touring with his stand-up show "In Praise Of Silly" and fashion designers have collaborated with Net-a-Porter for International Women's Day. Art Basel has launched an Online Viewing Room to showcase artworks digitally due to Covid-19 cancellations.

site_title: Thailand's richest man is building Bangkok's tallest skyscraper
summary: Thailand's richest man, Charoen Sirivadhanabhakdi, plans to build Bangkok's tallest skyscraper, valued at US$948 million, with completion expected in 2025. The tower, designed by Adrian Smith + Gordon Gill Architecture, will surpass the current record of 318 meters and feature hotels, shops, and offices. Despite the challenging property and tourism markets due to the novel coronavirus, Asset World's CEO, Wallapa Traisorat, remains optimistic, expecting growth in the tourism industry and a short-term impact on the market.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Amara Holdings reported a 12% decline in net profit to S$28.2 million for FY2019, despite stable revenue of S$105.3 million. Medtecs International saw a 27.6% rise in net profit to US$1.2 million, attributed to higher revenues and improved efficiency. Hotel Properties' net profit fell 53% to S$57.1 million, mainly due to a decrease in share of results from associates. All three companies recommended dividends, with Amara paying two cents per share and Hotel Properties declaring a total of 10 cents per share.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks down more than 2% on virus worries
summary: Tokyo stocks declined over 2% on Thursday due to concerns over the spreading coronavirus outbreak. The benchmark Nikkei 225 fell 2.13% to 21,948.23, while the Topix index dropped to 1,568.06. US President Donald Trump stated the US is prepared to escalate its response if the outbreak continues to spread. This news dampened investor sentiment, contributing to the decline. Global stocks finished mixed after two sessions of concern over the virus.

site_title: US: Stocks open sharply lower on virus fears
summary: US stocks opened sharply lower on Thursday, joining global sell-offs due to fears of the coronavirus growing into a significant international health crisis. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 1.8% or 480 points, the S&P 500 slid 2.1% to 3,050.44, and the Nasdaq Composite Index dropped 2.7% to 8,736.12. This marks the fifth consecutive day of declines for the blue-chip index. Market concerns over the virus's spread led to a sell-off across most global bourses.

site_title: HL Finance posts 12.9% drop in net profit
summary: HL Finance reported a 12.9% drop in net profit to S$103.1 million for the year ended Dec 31, 2020, due to a net loss allowance of doubtful debts and higher interest expense. Net interest income fell 4.9% to S$201.7 million, while net loan assets grew 12.4% to S$11.6 billion. The group's earnings per share declined to 23.09 cents, and a final dividend of 10 cents per share was proposed. Chairman Kwek Leng Beng expressed caution for 2020 due to geopolitical uncertainties and the Covid-19 outbreak.

site_title: Coronavirus outbreak at 'decisive point': WHO chief
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) chief, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, stated that the new coronavirus outbreak has reached a "decisive point" and urged countries to take action to contain its spread effectively. He warned that the virus has pandemic potential and emphasized the need for swift action to prevent infection and save lives. The WHO is working closely with the Tokyo Olympic Games organizers and does not anticipate a decision on the event's postponement or cancellation in the near future.

site_title: China pushes firms to get back to work even as virus fears persist
summary: China is urging companies to resume full production and normal life despite the COVID-19 pandemic, with over 200 million workers yet to return from the extended Chinese New Year holiday. The government has offered incentives, such as bonuses and subsidies, to encourage workers to return. However, many companies face challenges in implementing strict hygiene measures and complying with local authorities' guidelines, with some reporting only 30% of offices open. The goal is to restart China's economy, which has been severely impacted, with President Xi Jinping aiming for a growth rate of at least 5% this year.

site_title: Top China ports start unclogging backlog
summary: China's top container ports are easing cargo backlogs as workers return to their posts after easing travel curbs and city lockdowns. The virus, which originated in Wuhan, killed over 2,700 and infected over 78,000 in China, causing massive port congestion. Turnaround times at Zhoushan port, the third-largest in the world, improved from 60 hours to 13,235 containers cleared on Feb 22. Processing rates at other ports also increased, with some surpassing year-ago rates. Logistics is starting to revive, with the director of the Shipping Information Research Institute saying the "turning point has arrived."

site_title: UK rejects EU trade demands, threatens to walk away
summary: The UK has rejected EU trade demands, setting out its red lines for negotiations starting on Monday. The UK government has refused to accept common trading standards and continued fishing rights, warning it could walk away from talks if a broad outline of a deal is not agreed by a June meeting. This move puts the prospect of a chaotic Brexit back on the table, potentially disrupting trade and economic ties with the EU.

site_title: India fines jewellery firm for withholding information in US$2b bank fraud
summary: India's securities regulator fined jewellery retailer Gitanjali Gems 50 million rupees (S$973,430) for failing to disclose information related to a US$2 billion fraud at Punjab National Bank. The fraud, allegedly involving Gitanjali's promoter and managing director Mehul Choksi and billionaire jeweller Nirav Modi, led to losses of roughly US$2 billion for PNB. The regulator also fined Choksi and another executive for their role in the case, citing "deliberate defiance" and "hiding crucial information" from investors and regulators.

site_title: Singapore Design at the Olympics
summary: Singaporean artist Theseus Chan has been invited by the Tokyo Organising Committee of the Olympic and Paralympic Games to create an artwork for the 2020 Summer Olympics. Chan, 59, is a skateboarding enthusiast and founder of design studio Work, and his artwork "Extreme Revelations" features actual grind marks from skateboards. The piece explores the connection between skateboarding and the Olympics, questioning the traditional standards of merit. Chan will also be part of the Olympic torch relay in March, running 200m through Tokyo's streets.

site_title: Samsung Hub level 11 sold at record S$3,800 psf
summary: A South Korean high net worth individual (HNWI) has bought the 11th floor of Samsung Hub in Singapore's Raffles Place financial district for S$50 million, or S$3,800 per square foot. This is the highest psf price achieved for an office floor in the 999-year leasehold building, surpassing the previous record set in 2018. The floor is fully leased, with a net yield of 2.5% based on the transaction price. The sale is seen as a sign of confidence in Singapore's office market, despite sluggish economic growth projected for the year.

images.alt_text: Samsung Hub is one of the very few 999-year leasehold/freehold buildings in the CBD offering strata office play to investors.

site_title: Jardine C&C FY2019 underlying net profit holds steady at US$863m
summary: Jardine Cycle & Carriage (Jardine C&C) reported a 1% increase in underlying net profit to US$863 million for FY2019, driven by lower corporate costs. Revenue declined 2% to US$18.6 billion, mainly due to weaker sales in Singapore, Malaysia, and Vietnam. The company's Indonesian subsidiary Astra's revenue remained stable, while its direct motor interests business faced challenges. The company expects challenging market conditions in Indonesia and potential impact from the Covid-19 outbreak in the year ahead.

site_title: WHO can learn from IMF in handling pandemics
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) is urging countries to learn from the International Monetary Fund's (IMF) experience in handling pandemics. The IMF's approach to data tracking and reporting can be applied to global health crises, including the COVID-19 pandemic. A global surveillance facility, modeled after the Gavi vaccine alliance, could provide countries with funding and technical assistance during outbreaks. The facility would help build resilient systems before epidemics strike, and countries could be incentivized to report data through no-fault epidemic insurance. Investing in tracking and controlling diseases can save money and lives, with examples of successful interventions in the past, such as the eradication of smallpox.

site_title: Jardine C&C's underlying net profit inches up 1% to US$863 million
summary: Jardine Cycle & Carriage's (Jardine C&C) underlying net profit for FY2019 rose 1% to US$863 million, driven by lower corporate costs and stable contributions from Indonesian subsidiary Astra. Revenue declined 2% to US$18.6 billion, impacted by lower car sales in Singapore, Malaysia, and Vietnam. The company's overall net profit more than doubled to US$881 million, with earnings per share increasing to US$2.23. However, Chairman Ben Keswick warned of challenging market conditions in Indonesia and potential impact from the Covid-19 virus outbreak.

site_title: Airlines use world's strongest disinfectants to fight virus
summary: Airlines such as Qantas, Korean Air, and Singapore Airlines' Scoot have increased aircraft-cleaning efforts to combat the novel coronavirus, using hospital-grade disinfectants capable of stopping diseases like Hepatitis B and MRSA. Qantas used Viraclean, a pink, lemon-scented liquid, while Korean Air opted for MD-125, a diluted version of D-125. The planes were thoroughly cleaned, including air filters replaced and surfaces wiped down, before being cleared for commercial use. The increased cleaning measures aim to ensure passenger safety and prevent further spread of the virus.

site_title: Malaysia's parliament to decide next PM - Mahathir
summary: Malaysia's interim Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad announced that the king will call on parliament to decide who has enough support to become the next prime minister. Following a two-day meeting with parliament members, Mahathir stated that no prime minister candidate had a distinct majority. If no candidate can prove a majority, snap elections will be held on March 2 to determine the next prime minister.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's services sector saw a 4.6% increase in takings in Q4 2019, driven by a recovery in recreation and personal services spending. Meanwhile, a 99-year-old hotel in Chinatown, the Porcelain Hotel, is up for sale with a guide price of S$115 million. Cloud-kitchen startup Dahmakan raised US$18 million in a Series B funding round, while SATS implemented pay cuts and voluntary unpaid leave amid the COVID-19 outbreak. A former director of Singapore O&G was charged with cheating in relation to an allegedly dishonest deal, and Singapore shares fell 0.2% on the STI.

site_title: SPH Reit offers tenants more help to weather Covid-19 outbreak
summary: SPH Reit is offering additional assistance packages to its tenants amid the Covid-19 outbreak, including tailored support based on individual business needs. The real estate investment trust (Reit) will also introduce initiatives to encourage mall visits, such as complimentary parking and preferential rates for events. Tenants will be allowed to shorten operating hours to reduce staff costs. These measures aim to mitigate the decline in footfall and tenant sales, and come on top of a 15% property tax rebate announced in Budget 2020.

site_title: StanChart posts strong results but coronavirus, economic headwinds to hamper profit growth
summary: Standard Chartered posted a 46% jump in annual profit, but warned that the coronavirus epidemic will hinder profit growth, particularly in its main markets of China and Hong Kong. The bank expects a rise in bad loans due to the epidemic, although no specific guidance was provided. This news comes as rival HSBC Holdings anticipates loan losses of up to $600 million if the virus persists.

site_title: Yanlord Q4 net profit rises over 7 times to 2.1b yuan
summary: Yanlord Land Group reported a 7-fold increase in Q4 net profit to 2.1 billion yuan, driven by a significant rise in recognised revenue. The group delivered 8.07 billion yuan in revenue, more than tripling from the previous year. Despite a lower average selling price per square metre, the company remains cautiously optimistic about its performance in the next reporting period. Yanlord plans to launch new projects in Q1 2020, including Yanlord Riverside Gardens and Yanlord Marina Peninsula Gardens, to continue growing its business.

site_title: Malaysia announces economic package to blunt coronavirus hit
summary: Malaysia announces a 20 billion ringgit (S$6.6 billion) economic package to support businesses affected by the coronavirus outbreak. The package will provide support to the tourism industry, which has been severely impacted by the virus. The move follows similar measures taken by Indonesia, Singapore, and Hong Kong. Malaysia's economy has slowed to its weakest pace since 2009, and the government has widened its fiscal deficit target for 2020. The central bank has already cut its benchmark interest rate and is expected to make further policy easing.

site_title: Hong Leong Finance FY19 net profit falls 13% to S$103.1m
summary: Hong Leong Finance reported a 12.9% decline in net profit to S$103.1 million for FY19, driven by a S$1.6 million net loss allowance for doubtful debts and higher interest expense. Despite a 13.3% increase in interest income, the net interest margin declined 17 basis points. The group's chairman, Kwek Leng Beng, expressed caution for 2020 due to geopolitical uncertainties and the Covid-19 outbreak, but expects some cushioning from the economic impact due to its domestic focus.

site_title: Geneva watch fair cancelled due to coronavirus, Baselworld still on
summary: The Geneva Watch Fair has been cancelled due to the coronavirus outbreak, while the Baselworld event remains on, with organizers evaluating the situation. The cancellation affects many Chinese retailers and watch lovers, who are the biggest customers of Swiss watches. The Fine Watchmaking Foundation, which organizes the Geneva show, made the decision to anticipate potential risks. Baselworld, dominated by Richemont brands, is still scheduled to take place from April 30, with measures in place to protect exhibitors, visitors, and employees.

site_title: US Q4 growth stays at 2.1%
summary: The US economy grew moderately in the fourth quarter at a 2.1% annualized rate, supported by a smaller import bill, according to the Commerce Department's second estimate. This growth pace matched the July-September quarter, but fell short of the Trump administration's 3% target for the year. Financial markets have been spooked by the coronavirus outbreak, leading to a sell-off in stocks and a boost in safe-haven government bonds. Economists expect the manufacturing sector to take a hit due to supply chain disruptions and exports, potentially eroding consumer confidence and hurting consumer spending.

site_title: Sinostar PEC FY2019 net profit jumps 37.5% to 113.7m yuan
summary: Sinostar PEC Holdings reported a 37.5% jump in FY2019 net profit to 113.7 million yuan, driven by a 62% increase in revenue to 3.7 billion yuan. The company's newly acquired subsidiary Dongming Qianhai contributed to the growth. Despite a decrease in revenue from another subsidiary, the company remains cautious about the Covid-19 outbreak's impact on the Chinese economy. Construction of a new polypropylene production plant is on track for completion by Q4 2020, and the company will focus on cost efficiency and cash flow management.

site_title: Coronavirus: 12-year-old RI student and his family member among 3 new confirmed cases
summary: Three new cases of coronavirus disease (Covid-19) were confirmed in Singapore, bringing the total number of cases to 96. The new cases include a 64-year-old woman, a 44-year-old man, and a 12-year-old Raffles Institution student, all Singaporeans. Four others have recovered and were discharged, with eight patients in critical condition in the intensive care unit. The total number of fully recovered cases is 66.

site_title: Venture Corp Q4 net profit falls 10.6% to S$96.3m
summary: Venture Corp, an electronics manufacturing services firm, reported a 10.6% decline in Q4 net profit to S$96.3 million, despite a 2.9% increase in revenue to S$932.1 million. The drop was attributed to increased spending on raw materials and employee benefits. Despite a challenging global supply chain due to the Covid-19 outbreak, the company expects a stronger second half of 2020 and is well-positioned to capture new business opportunities.

site_title: Taiwan raises epidemic response level to highest on coronavirus concerns
summary: Taiwan raised its epidemic response level to the highest due to concerns over the coronavirus, with 32 cases and one death reported. The government approved a US$2 billion package to cushion the economy's impact and enhanced its defense against the virus. Travel and tourism links with China were suspended, and penalties were imposed for violating home quarantine orders. Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen vowed to integrate all government resources to fight against the coronavirus threat.

site_title: China Everbright Water FY19 profit rises 23% to HK$833.5m
summary: China Everbright Water reported a 23% increase in net profit to HK$833.5 million for FY19, driven by higher revenue from its construction segment. Revenue rose 16% to HK$5.55 billion, with operation revenue boosted by new projects and tariff hikes. The company proposed a final cash dividend of 3.74 HK cents, and its shares traded at S$0.30, down 3.2% at the time of the announcement.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets slide more than 2%
summary: European stock markets slid over 2% in early trading on Thursday, driven by concerns over the impact of the coronavirus on global growth. London was down 2.5%, while Frankfurt, Paris, and Milan fell 2.4%, 2.3%, and 1.9% respectively. Analysts attribute the decline to investor concerns about the virus's effect on the economy.

site_title: Maybank books record annual profit, flags virus impact
summary: Malayan Banking (Maybank) reported a record annual profit of RM8.2 billion, driven by strong performances in its insurance and Islamic banking businesses. The lender's fourth-quarter net profit rose to RM2.45 billion, beating analysts' forecast. Despite concerns over the coronavirus outbreak, US elections, and tensions in the Middle East, Maybank expects its full-year financial performance to be satisfactory. The bank set a target for return on equity of 10-11% and plans to seek selective growth opportunities.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 10.40 points to 1,505.59 on Thursday, with a trading volume of 3.5 billion lots worth RM2.7 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 621 to 264.

site_title: Singapore shares extend losses as Covid-19 contagion fears persist
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.2% to 3,111.70, despite a rebound after breaching the 3,100 support level, amid ongoing Covid-19 contagion fears. Tech manufacturers AEM Holdings, Frencken Group, and UMS Holdings rose, while property listings PropNex and APAC Realty edged up. Analysts expect a short-term recovery in the property market if the outbreak is contained.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks close at 4-mth low as central bank dashes rate cut hopes
summary: South Korean stocks closed at a four-month low on Thursday, falling 1% to 2,054.89, as the central bank unexpectedly held interest rates steady, disappointing investors seeking stimulus to combat the economic impact of the coronavirus. The Bank of Korea downgraded its growth outlook, citing fears the outbreak could derail the country's economy. Foreigners sold $334.93 million worth of KOSPI stocks, and the KOSPI has fallen 6.50% this year.

site_title: New BT app experience coming your way
summary: The Business Times (BT) will relaunch its mobile apps in March, featuring a new reading experience with a streamlined navigation, cleaner layout, and improved performance. The new apps will be faster, more secure, and offer read-time indicators, bookmarking function improvements, and a curated home screen with editorial highlights and trending news. iPhone users must run at least iOS 11, while Android users must run at least Android 6. The updated apps aim to provide an intuitive and easier-to-navigate experience for users, aligning with BT's goal of being a daily companion for busy readers.

site_title: Haw Par Corp FY2019 net profit edges up 1.8% to S$182.2m
summary: Haw Par Corporation reported a 1.8% increase in FY2019 net profit to S$182.2 million, driven by 2.6% revenue growth to S$244 million. However, gross profit margin fell to 57.2% due to increased cost of sales. Earnings per share rose to 82.4 cents, and the board proposed a second and final dividend of 15 cents per share. Executive director Han Ah Kuan will retire in June 2020.

site_title: CSE Global Q4 earnings up 60.1% to S$8.1m
summary: CSE Global, a mainboard-listed company dealing in oil and gas, and telecommunications, reported a 60.1% rise in Q4 net profit to S$8.1 million, from S$5.1 million last year. Revenue rose 57.7% to S$156.6 million, driven by growth in the Americas and Asia-Pacific regions. The company recommended a final dividend of 1.5 Singapore cents per share, unchanged from last year. Despite ongoing global challenges, the company expects a steady flow of orders from existing clients and aims to grow organically and explore value-accretive acquisitions.

site_title: Japan at 'crossroads' of coronavirus outbreak, expert warns
summary: Japan is at a "crossroads" in preventing a major coronavirus outbreak, with domestic transmissions expected to be a critical factor in determining the country's response to the pandemic. Experts warn that the next three weeks will be crucial in determining the spread of the virus, and if domestic transmissions are not brought under control, the government may need to reconsider hosting the Olympics. Japan has confirmed at least 186 domestic infections and has faced criticism for its handling of the crisis, including a quarantine on a cruise ship that resulted in multiple new cases among passengers.

site_title: AB InBev forecasts worst quarter in decade on virus outbreak
summary: AB InBev, the world's largest brewer, forecasts a 10% decline in first-quarter profit due to the coronavirus, its worst quarterly drop in at least a decade. The brewer blamed raw material costs and a slowdown in China's market, with shipments already slowing in the country. AB InBev has reopened over half of its 33 China breweries and is reallocating beer distribution to other outlets. The company expects a rebound in the later part of the year, but its 2020 forecast of 2-5% growth would be the weakest in four years.

site_title: Governments ramp up preparations for coronavirus pandemic
summary: Governments worldwide are ramping up preparations for a potential coronavirus pandemic as the virus spreads globally, with over 80,000 infected and 2,800 deaths reported. Australia and Taiwan have taken emergency measures, while the US has postponed joint military drills and the UK has issued a travel warning for South Korea. The number of cases outside China has surpassed those within the country, and several countries have reported their first cases, including Brazil, Denmark, Estonia, and Pakistan. The US, South Korea, and other countries are taking precautions to limit the spread of the virus, with stock markets and oil prices experiencing significant declines.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon down 0.9% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.9% to 3,090.77 on Thursday, amid uncertainty surrounding the Covid-19 outbreak. The market has been pricing in the economic impact of the virus, which has spread to Europe and the Middle East. Key decliners included Genting Singapore, DBS, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank, while PropNex shares edged up 0.9% after reporting a quadrupled net profit.

site_title: JPMorgan names veteran Gori as new Asia Pacific chief executive
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co. named Filippo Gori as its new Asia Pacific chief executive officer, overseeing 17 markets in the region. Gori, a veteran of 20 years, takes over from Nicolas Aguzin, who will lead the bank's international private banking business. Gori will oversee strategy and operations in addition to his current roles as head of banking in Asia Pacific and Hong Kong chief executive.

images.alt_text: JPMorgan Chase & Co on Thursday named veteran Filippo Gori as its new Asia Pacific chief executive officer to oversee strategy and operations of the Wall Street bank across 17 markets in the region.

site_title: Chinatown's Porcelain Hotel up for sale with S$115m guide price
summary: The Porcelain Hotel, a 138-key boutique hotel in Singapore's Chinatown, is up for sale via expression of interest with a guide price of S$115 million. The 99-year leasehold hotel occupies a 10,143 sq ft land area and has an estimated GFA of 38,686 sq ft. The guide price works out to S$830,000 per key or S$2,950 per square foot, lower than recent hotel and shophouse transactions. The buyer can opt for vacant possession or a sale and leaseback arrangement, with the potential for repositioning and converting the ground floor into food and beverage use.

site_title: OCBC to provide abridged Q1, Q3 results
summary: OCBC Bank announced it will provide abridged financial disclosures for its first-quarter and third-quarter 2020 performance, following the Singapore Exchange Regulation's removal of mandatory quarterly reporting. The disclosures will include key financial data and business commentary. This decision comes as the regulator scrapped mandatory quarterly reporting for listed companies, except for those associated with higher risks.

site_title: Thai tycoons in fray as Tesco sets bid deadline for US$9b Asia business
summary: Tesco has set a deadline for bids on its Asian business, valued at up to $9 billion, as Thai billionaires Dhanin Chearavanont's CP Group, Central Group, and Charoen Sirivadhanabhakdi's TCC Group vie for the asset. The bidding process is competitive, with most large banks involved, and antitrust concerns may pose a challenge. Tesco will review bids and make a decision next month, despite the impact of the coronavirus outbreak on near-term growth estimates for Thailand.

images.alt_text: British retailer Tesco has asked bidders to submit binding offers for its Asian business by Friday, in a deal that will see Thai billionaires fight for an asset valued at up to US$9 billion.

site_title: Alphabet still facing questions over data use in its Toronto smart city project proposal
summary: Alphabet's Sidewalk Labs is facing concerns over its proposed smart city development in Toronto, with the Digital Strategy Advisory Panel questioning the invasive data-gathering technology. The panel wants more clarity on the use of digital approaches over non-digital solutions. Sidewalk Labs has agreed to scale back plans, but the revised proposal still raises concerns about data privacy. The Waterfront Toronto board will make a final decision on the project in May, amid Canada's digital privacy law upgrade.

site_title: Indonesia's virus support may not be enough for growth: Nomura report
summary: Indonesia's COVID-19 stimulus package is unlikely to boost the economy, according to a Nomura report. The package, valued at 0.06% of GDP, is seen as a reallocation of existing funds rather than new spending. Two-fifths of the aid will support the aviation and tourism sectors, but most of the funds will come from already-budgeted grants and state-owned enterprises. The report concludes that a wider budget deficit may be needed to deliver meaningful growth support. The stimulus measures are expected to have a limited impact on Indonesia's growth outlook.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower as coronavirus continues to spread
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on February 27, 2020, as investors closely watched the spreading coronavirus outbreak. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index slipped 0.69% to 22,272.26. The broader Topix index also declined 0.69%. The lower opening was attributed to concerns over the virus's impact on the global economy.

site_title: Pay cuts, voluntary unpaid leave at SATS amid Covid-19
summary: SATS, an airport and food services provider, has implemented pay cuts and voluntary unpaid leave amid the COVID-19 outbreak. Management team members took a 10% pay cut, while employees aged 55 and above were offered early retirement. Staff can also opt for voluntary unpaid leave without job replacement. The measures aim to save costs and mitigate the impact of declining passenger and cargo volumes on the business. SATS shares have fallen 17.2% since the year began due to the pandemic's economic impact.

site_title: Cloud-kitchen startup Dahmakan raises US$18m in Series B round
summary: Malaysia-based cloud-kitchen startup Dahmakan has raised US$18 million in Series B funding, bringing its total funding to US$28 million. The round was led by Rakuten Capital, with other investors including White Star Capital, JAFCO Asia, and Korean food delivery unicorn Woowa Brothers. The funds will be used to build Dahmakan's in-house operating system, which streamlines the value chain from food product development to delivery. This system makes the kitchens more profitable and easier to operate than traditional quick-service restaurants, according to CEO Jonathan Weins.

site_title: Singapore O&G ex-director charged with cheating
summary: A former director of Singapore O&G, Christopher Chong Meng Tak, has been charged with two counts of cheating in relation to an allegedly dishonest deal. Chong, a 62-year-old Malaysian, concealed a $1.5 million payment from dermatologist Joyce Lim Teng Ee and misrepresented it to Bank Julius Baer, causing the bank to accept the payment. He also failed to disclose his interest in a wholesale trade company, Paromay, which received the payment. Chong faces fines and up to 10 years in jail if convicted.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower as virus worries persist
summary: Australian shares ended lower for the fourth consecutive session due to lingering concerns over the coronavirus pandemic. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.8% to 6,657.90, wiping out about $100 billion in market value. Prime Minister Scott Morrison acknowledged the risk of a global pandemic, with 23 reported cases in Australia, all of whom have since recovered. Local businesses have cut $500 million from profit forecasts amid the outbreak, with heavyweight financial stocks weighing on the benchmark.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index slipped 0.8 per cent, or 50.20 points, to 6,657.90 at the close of trade.

site_title: Asia: Markets extend losses as virus takes hold around world
summary: Asian markets continued to fall on February 27, 2020, as the coronavirus pandemic spread globally, with over 40 countries affected and a global death toll of around 2,800. China reported its fewest daily deaths in almost a month, while the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention warned of a potential outbreak. Investors are growing fearful of the economic impact, with several big companies expecting sales to be hit. The global economy is expected to face more uncertainty, with analysts warning of worse to come.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts see strong demand for gloves lifting Riverstone FY20 earnings
summary: Analysts at CGS-CIMB and DBS Group Research remain bullish on Riverstone Holdings' FY2020 earnings, citing strong demand for healthcare and cleanroom gloves amid the Covid-19 outbreak. The analysts forecast a 20% year-on-year sales growth, with healthcare gloves contributing 85% of the volume. Riverstone's gross margin is expected to remain above 20%, higher than the industry average. The analysts have a "add" call on Riverstone, with target prices of S$1.30 and S$1.34, respectively, making the stock a 45% discount to its peers.

site_title: Singapore service sector takings up by 4.6% in Q4 2019
summary: Singapore's services sector saw a 4.6% year-on-year growth in Q4 2019, driven by a recovery in recreation and personal services spending. Despite this, the sector's operating income grew only 3.6% for the full year, down from 7.4% in 2018 and 6.8% in 2017. This marked a broad-based decline, with education being the only industry to post quicker growth.

site_title: Dovish board member calls for review of Bank of Japan's policy framework
summary: Bank of Japan board member Goushi Kataoka has called for a review of the central bank's monetary policy framework to address the impact of the coronavirus outbreak on the economy. Kataoka believes the BOJ should re-examine its tools for propping up inflation and coordinate policies with the government to boost economic growth. The dovish member's comments come as the economy risks tipping into recession.

site_title: Competition watchdog gives nod to ARA, Logos deal
summary: The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) has cleared the proposed merger between Logos China Investments and ARA Logistics, a unit of ARA Asset Management. The deal, announced in December, aims to establish a logistics real estate platform in the Asia-Pacific region. The CCCS concluded that the merger will not infringe the Competition Act, allowing the deal to proceed.

site_title: Australia: Shares wobble amid coronavirus fears; New Zealand up
summary: Australian shares wobbled amid coronavirus concerns, with the S&P/ASX 200 index down 0.2% at 6,133.80. The decline follows a 6.3% loss in the previous four sessions, as investors weighed uncertainty over the global economic impact of the virus. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.3% after three consecutive losses. Gainers included a2Milk, which jumped 9% on solid profit growth, and Lynas Corp, which gained after Malaysia approved a new licence.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars downtrodden as funds flee virus risks
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars have fallen to 11-year lows due to investors hedging against coronavirus risks. The Australian dollar dropped to US$0.6554, while the New Zealand dollar fell to US$0.6284. Investors expect a potential rate cut by the Reserve Bank of Australia and New Zealand, with a 40% chance of a cut in April and 68% in May. The economic downturn has also led to a decline in business investment and confidence in both countries, with the Reserve Bank of Australia and New Zealand under pressure to respond with monetary easing.

site_title: Coronavirus? Trump says be a germophobe like him
summary: US President Donald Trump advised people to be germophobes like him to protect against the coronavirus, emphasizing frequent hand-washing. He recounted a recent encounter with someone who was sick and how he avoided physical contact by excusing himself to wash his hands. Trump's habit of hand-washing has been a quirk, and he suggested washing hands but not necessarily grabbing every handrail unless necessary.

site_title: Korean Air crewmember who was on flights to LA tests positive for coronavirus: reports
summary: A Korean Air flight attendant who worked on flights between Seoul and Los Angeles has tested positive for coronavirus, according to local media reports. The crewmember was on a Korean Air KE958 flight from Israel to Incheon on February 15-16, which included a South Korean tour group with 31 coronavirus cases. Korean Air has referred inquiries about the employee's itinerary to the Korea Centres for Disease Control and Prevention. The airline will continue to work with authorities to ensure passenger and employee safety.

site_title: Singapore biotech firm Veredus launches Covid-19 test kit for hospital, lab use
summary: Singapore-based biotech firm Veredus Laboratories has received provisional authorisation for its Covid-19 test kit, VereCoV, for in-vitro diagnostic use. The kit, which can detect both Covid-19 and Sars viruses simultaneously, has an accuracy rate of 99% and can provide results in two hours. The test kit, launched earlier this month for research use, is now commercially available for hospitals and labs to test patients for clinical diagnosis, marking a breakthrough in Covid-19 detection.

site_title: IMF, World Bank consider 'virtual' annual meetings in April as coronavirus spreads
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank are considering scaling back or holding "virtual" annual meetings in April due to the spread of the new coronavirus. The Spring Meetings, which bring together 10,000 officials, journalists, and business people, are scheduled for April 17-19 in Washington, DC. Concerns about the close interactions among people from 189 member countries and the potential for the virus to spread have prompted the institutions to consider modifying the meetings. Options include scaling back the number of meetings, canceling external events, or holding virtual meetings via teleconference.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 0.95 points higher at 1,496.14, with a 0.06% gain. The market saw 143.34 million lots traded worth RM41.24 million, with 132 gainers surpassing 113 losers.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Wilmar, Yanlord, SIIC Environment, Halcyon Agri, GSH Corp
summary: Stocks to watch on Thursday included Wilmar International, City Developments Limited, Yanlord Land Group, Oxley Holdings, SIIC Environment, Halcyon Agri Corporation, GSH Corporation, and others, with notable developments such as Wilmar's CFO retirement, CDL's potential REIT listing, and Yanlord's surged net profit. Other companies reported varying financial results, including Halcyon Agri's net profit increase, GSH's net loss, and QAF's significant jump in net profit.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower but Shanghai rises
summary: Hong Kong stocks began Thursday with a 0.6% decline, or 167.32 points, to 26,529.17, as the coronavirus continues to spread globally. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.3%, and the Shenzhen Composite Index increased 0.5%, amid signs the outbreak is easing on the mainland. The US stock market also edged down from records, despite fresh tariff threats.
