images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks started Thursday with another loss as the coronavirus continues to spread around the world with more new infections confirmed outside China than inside for the first time.

site_title: Lloyd's of London trials first electronic insurance exchange
summary: Lloyd's of London has launched its first electronic insurance exchange, marking a significant modernization effort. The exchange, for simple insurance risks, is part of the market's efforts to become more efficient and competitive. Lloyd's has taken a 40% stake in an existing electronic placement system, PPL, and aims to complete the complex risk exchange within the next 12 months. While some industry sources approve of the modernization plans, others express concerns about the potential disruption to the traditional face-to-face business model.

site_title: China reports 29 more coronavirus deaths, lowest since January
summary: China reported 29 new coronavirus deaths, the lowest daily figure in almost a month, bringing the total death toll to 2,744 in mainland China, according to the National Health Commission. The number of fresh infections rose slightly.

site_title: Trump says US coronavirus spread 'not inevitable', mulls new travel bans
summary: President Donald Trump said the US coronavirus spread is not inevitable, contradicting a senior health official, as he considers travel restrictions on Italy and South Korea. The US has identified 60 cases, with 15 detected through the public health system and 45 repatriated from abroad. Trump appointed Vice-President Mike Pence to lead the response, amid dire warnings that countries are not ready to contain the outbreak. The CDC urged Americans to prepare for cancellations and urged schools and businesses to develop teleworking plans.

site_title: South Korea holds interest rate despite virus fears
summary: South Korea's central bank maintained its key interest rate at 1.25% despite growing concerns over the coronavirus's impact on the export-reliant economy. The decision defied expectations for a cut, with only 10 out of 26 economists predicting the bank would stand pat. The Bank of Korea's Monetary Policy Board made the decision in a move to limit the spread of the virus and contain crowds. The rate has been unchanged since 2019, and the decision suggests the bank is prioritizing economic stability over interest rate cuts.

site_title: Australia Q4 capital spending slips, bolsters need for more RBA support
summary: Australian business investment declined 2.8% in the December quarter to A$28.5 billion, missing market forecasts, and reinforcing expectations of another Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) rate cut later this year. The decline was led by mining and building sectors, with spending plans for 2020/21 at A$100.2 billion below forecasts. The RBA cut interest rates three times last year, and financial markets imply a 50-50 chance of a cut to 0.5% by May. The economic outlook appears to be dampening investment intentions, and the RBA is under pressure to loosen policy in its May budget.

images.alt_text: Australian business investment unexpectedly fell last quarter led by declines in the mining and building sectors, frustrating hopes for a long-awaited pick up in spending and reinforcing expectations of yet another rate cut later this year.

site_title: Saudi Arabia suspends entry for pilgrims over coronavirus
summary: Saudi Arabia has suspended entry visas for pilgrims and tourists from countries with high Covid-19 cases, citing concerns over the spread of the virus. The suspension applies to Umrah pilgrims and visitors from countries including Iran, Kuwait, and Bahrain, where the virus has seen a recent surge. The move aims to protect the health and safety of citizens and pilgrims.

site_title: South Korea reports 334 new coronavirus cases, total 1,595
summary: South Korea reported 334 new coronavirus cases, bringing its total to 1,595, with no new deaths. The country's toll remains at 12. The outbreak is still the largest outside of China, where the disease first emerged.

site_title: Centurion Q4 earnings rise 38% to S$73.1m
summary: Centurion Corporation reported a 38% rise in net profit to S$73.1 million for its fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2019, driven by higher revenue from new accommodation assets. Earnings per share increased 37.5% to 8.69 cents. The company attributed the growth to its expanded portfolio.

site_title: Malaysia approves 3-year licence for Lynas' rare earths plant, shares jump
summary: Malaysia has approved a 3-year licence for Lynas' rare earths plant, allowing the Australian miner to continue processing rare earths at its $800 million plant in Kuantan. The renewal removes a key risk, sending Lynas' shares up 11% to $1.98. To meet conditions, Lynas must build a cracking and leaching facility outside Malaysia and develop a permanent disposal facility for waste within the first year. The approval is seen as a catalyst for higher prices and a "buy" recommendation has been issued by analyst Dylan Kelly.

site_title: Coronavirus to have serious economic impact in the short term: New Zealand finance minister
summary: New Zealand's finance minister warns that the coronavirus outbreak will have a serious economic impact in the short term, potentially leading to a global pandemic and recession. The government may consider immediate fiscal stimulus to support the economy if the situation worsens.

site_title: Old wine in new cans? South African startup sniffs new export opportunity
summary: A South African startup, Uncanny Wines, is introducing canned wines in the country, targeting domestic drinkers first and exporting to the US and Europe. The company's premium red and white wines are certified by South Africa's Wine and Spirit Board and are vegan-friendly and sulphur-free. The 250ml aluminium cans are priced around 40 rand (S$3.60) each, and the company expects to launch a Pinotage Rosé soon. The initial response has been positive, with customers praising the convenience and quality of the product.

site_title: Thailand's richest man building Bangkok's tallest skyscraper
summary: Thailand's richest man, Charoen Sirivadhanabhakdi, plans to build Bangkok's tallest skyscraper through his company Asset World Corp. The tower, expected to be completed in 2025, will be a record-breaker, surpassing Thailand's current tallest building. Despite the challenges posed by the coronavirus and a property glut, Asset World's CEO, Wallapa Traisorat, is optimistic about the project, citing Bangkok's tourism industry's ability to bounce back. The skyscraper will be a key part of the company's aggressive growth strategy, which includes other ambitious projects in the pipeline.

site_title: Indigenous protests escalate after Canada rail blockades cleared
summary: Protests by Indigenous groups in Canada over a natural gas pipeline in British Columbia escalated after police cleared an 18-day rail blockade. The blockades, which disrupted rail traffic and supply chains, led to job layoffs and shortages. New protests have popped up across the country, with some demonstrators lighting fires on tracks, throwing rocks, and vandalizing government offices. The government and federal police are working to resolve the situation, with Prime Minister Justin Trudeau urging the blockades to come down.

site_title: Yanlord ups Q4 profit over 8 times to 2.1b yuan
summary: Yanlord Land Group's fourth-quarter net profit surged to 2.1 billion yuan (S$417 million), more than eight times the previous year. Recognized revenue increased by more than triple to 8.07 billion yuan, driven by a significant increase in gross floor area delivered. The group's full-year net profit was down 5% to 3.35 billion yuan, while revenue was down 25% to 18.67 billion yuan. Despite this, the company remains cautiously optimistic about its performance for the next reporting period.

site_title: Apple investor vote sounds 'warning' over China app takedowns
summary: Apple shareholders voted 40.6% in favor of a proposal calling for the company to report on its commitment to freedom of expression in China, a significant increase from previous years. The proposal highlighted Apple's 2017 removal of virtual private network apps from its App Store in China, which critics saw as a step to preserve access to the country's vast market. Apple has signaled it will respond to the vote, with its CEO, Tim Cook, potentially facing pressure to address concerns about the company's human rights policy in China.

images.alt_text: An Apple Inc shareholder proposal critical of the company's app removals in China received a relatively high level of support at the iPhone maker's annual meeting on Wednesday, enough to push the company to respond, experts said.

site_title: New Zealand business confidence drops in January on coronavirus fears
summary: New Zealand's business confidence dropped in January due to coronavirus fears, according to an ANZ Bank survey. The survey's headline measure showed a net 19.4% of respondents expecting the economy to deteriorate over the year ahead, up from 13.2% in December. Meanwhile, only 12.0% of respondents expected their own businesses to grow in the next 12 months, down from 17.2% last month. The decline in business confidence reflects growing alarm about the economic outlook in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak in China.

images.alt_text: New Zealand's businesses sentiment dropped in January as the coronavirus outbreak in China caused widespread alarm about the outlook for the economy and the prospects of firms, an ANZ Bank survey showed on Thursday.

site_title: Covid-19: Is it a force majeure event for business?
summary: The COVID-19 outbreak has raised questions about its impact on business contracts, specifically whether it constitutes a force majeure event or a frustration. The World Health Organization has declared the outbreak a global health emergency, and governments have implemented restrictions on travel, import, and human resources, causing significant disruptions to industries such as tourism, hospitality, construction, and shipping. Some contracts may be terminated or suspended due to force majeure, while others may be subject to frustration if unforeseen events render performance radically different from the intended terms. Businesses are advised to assess the applicability of force majeure clauses or frustration to manage uncertainties.

site_title: Air New Zealand warns of virus impact as profits dive
summary: Air New Zealand has reported a 34% drop in interim net profit to NZ$101 million due to the impact of the novel coronavirus. The airline warned that the virus would affect its bottom line, citing weaker demand, a sluggish global cargo market, and ongoing unrest in Hong Kong. Flights to Asian routes have been suspended or cut back, with overall flights to Asia expected to be down 17% between February and June. The airline forecasts pre-tax earnings of NZ$300-350 million for the full year, down from previous estimates.

site_title: HRnetGroup posts 7.1% rise in FY19 profit, sees potential revenue impact from virus
summary: HRnetGroup reported a 7.1% rise in FY19 profit to S$51.6 million, driven by earnings per share growth to 5.13 Singapore cents. However, the company expects potential revenue impact from the coronavirus outbreak, particularly in Q2 2020, due to clients delaying hiring and start dates. Group revenue declined 1.3% to S$423.1 million, while gross profit fell 6.3% to S$145.6 million. A final cash dividend of 2.8 Singapore cents was proposed for 2019.

site_title: Oil prices drop to lowest in more than a year as coronavirus spreads
summary: Oil prices dropped to their lowest in over a year due to fears that the coronavirus would lead to a decline in energy demand. Brent crude settled at $53.43 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude at $48.73 a barrel, with prices influenced by the spread of the virus in Europe, the Middle East, and concerns of a US outbreak. The US government reported a drop in petrol inventories, but experts believe the virus will continue to impact oil prices.

site_title: Two new Covid-19 cases; 62 out of 93 confirmed cases fully recovered
summary: Two new Covid-19 cases were confirmed in Singapore, bringing the total number of cases to 93. Of the 93 cases, 62 have fully recovered. The Ministry of Health reported this update on February 26, 2020.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Thursday's open tracking US retreat; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.2% at Thursday's open, tracking US losses, with the Straits Times Index dropping 6.69 points to 3,110.83. The decline was attributed to a mix of banks, with DBS and United Overseas Bank shedding 0.3% each, while OCBC gained 0.2%. The US Dow and S&P 500 fell 0.5% and 0.4%, respectively, while the Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.2%.

site_title: PropNex Q4 profit more than quadruples on surge in commission income
summary: PropNex, a Singaporean real estate agency, reported a net profit of S$8.2 million for its Q4 2020, more than quadrupling from S$1.8 million in the same period last year. Revenue rose 57.9% to S$131 million, driven by a surge in commission income from project marketing services. The company proposes a final cash dividend of 1.5 cents and a special dividend of 0.75 cents per share. Despite the COVID-19 outbreak, PropNex expects healthy underlying demand for private new launches and robust HDB resale demand in 2020.

site_title: Pressure mounts on Australia pensions to drop fossil fuels
summary: Australia's fourth-largest pension fund, UniSuper, faces pressure to drop fossil fuel investments amid mounting calls to meet the Paris climate agreement. Protests took place at a UniSuper event in Canberra, with over 10,000 signing an open letter demanding the fund scrap investments in companies expanding fossil fuel output. Similar demands have been made at HESTA, a fund managing A$55 billion in retirement savings for health workers. The protests come as Australia's deadly wildfires heighten concerns about climate change, with peers like Europe's ABP leading the way in cutting exposure to high-emitting companies.

site_title: Microsoft expects financial hit from coronavirus spread
summary: Microsoft lowered its revenue estimates for the current quarter due to the coronavirus epidemic, citing lower sales of Windows software and Surface devices. The company expects a financial hit, with revenues falling short of earlier forecasts. The impact of the outbreak on Microsoft's supply chain and manufacturing, particularly in factories run by partners, is a major concern. As the situation evolves, Microsoft will prioritize employee safety and continue to support relief efforts, including donating technology to hospitals and medical workers.

site_title: Eurex senses Brexit momentum in euro clearing battle with London
summary: Eurex Clearing, an arm of Deutsche Boerse, is gaining momentum in the euro clearing battle with London, driven by Brexit and EU policymakers' push for control of the euro. The company has seen a 190% increase in euro-denominated interest rate customers, with 320 active clients, and aims to reach a 25% market share in clearing contracts. Eurex's profit-share scheme and favorable interest rate conditions are attracting clients away from London's LCH, which may struggle to maintain its dominant market share without EU permission.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Heng Chee How's response to the Budget 2020 manpower initiatives
summary: Heng Chee How, deputy secretary-general of NTUC, discusses Budget 2020 manpower initiatives on the Money FM podcast. The measures aim to resolve job retention, mid-career switching, and the nation's talent strategy. Key points include increasing the Professional Conversion Programmes (PCPs) to support mid-career professionals, introducing a new Mid-Career Conversion Programme, and enhancing the Work-Profit Link scheme to encourage job retention. The measures aim to address prevailing manpower concerns and support Singapore's talent strategy.

site_title: US farmers cautious on income, investment: survey
summary: US farmers are cautiously optimistic about 2020 due to new trade agreements, but remain hesitant to invest in their businesses. A survey found that 86% plan to keep capital investments to a minimum, citing higher operating costs and concerns about commodity prices. Despite this, US farm incomes are projected to rise 3.3% to $96.7 billion, driven by government subsidies, and median household income is expected to decline 0.3% to $76,810. The new US-China and North American trade agreements are expected to lift exports, but farmers remain cautious about investing in the short term.

site_title: Scramble to contain coronavirus as infections spread
summary: The novel coronavirus has spread globally, with over 80,000 cases reported in 34 countries, including Europe, Latin America, and Asia. The World Health Organization (WHO) warned of a potential pandemic, with cases now being recorded outside China more frequently than inside the country. New cases emerged in Brazil, Greece, Georgia, Norway, France, Spain, Croatia, Austria, North Macedonia, and Algeria, linked to Italy's outbreak. Several governments advised against travel to Italy, and the European Union sought to calm hysteria over the outbreak.

site_title: Europe: Stocks 'take a breather' as earnings soothe selling fever
summary: European stocks ended flat on Wednesday, recouping losses from the previous day, as strong earnings from utilities and automobiles distracted investors from the coronavirus outbreak. The Stoxx 600 benchmark closed unchanged, with utilities and automobiles leading gains. Travel stocks were the worst hit, with airline stocks bearing the bulk of losses, while resource and oil stocks also dropped. Analysts suggested investors were taking a "breather" after an extended sell-off, and European companies are expected to report a 1.2% fall in profits in the fourth quarter.

site_title: The Bernie juggernaut can be stopped
summary: Bernie Sanders' surprise win in Nevada's Democratic presidential caucuses has shifted the conventional wisdom, with the 78-year-old senator expanding his electoral base and gaining support from Hispanic, moderate, and suburban white voters. Sanders' campaign is now seen as a "political insurgency" driven by young supporters, and his main rivals face formidable obstacles in challenging his position. Former VP Joe Biden, Senator Amy Klobuchar, and Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren may drop out of the race after Super Tuesday, allowing billionaire Michael Bloomberg to potentially emerge as a leader of the "Stop Bernie" forces.

site_title: Brazil confirms Latin America's first coronavirus case
summary: Brazil confirmed its first coronavirus case, a 61-year-old resident from the Lombardy region of Italy, on February 26, 2020. The patient is in home isolation and is reportedly "fine." Health Minister Luiz Henrique Mandetta downplayed the virus as a simple flu, but acknowledged the virus's unpredictable nature. The case has caused a 7% drop in Sao Paulo's stock exchange and a decline in Brazil's real currency to a historic low. Authorities are investigating 20 cases, including 12 from Italy and one from China.

site_title: SIIC Environment Q4 profit dips 11.9%
summary: SIIC Environment reported a 11.9% drop in net profit to 150.1 million yuan (S$29.9 million) in Q4 2020, down from 170.4 million yuan in the same period last year. Earnings per share fell to 5.77 fen from 6.54 fen a year ago. This was largely due to a 98.8% decrease in other gains and losses, which previously included gains from subsidiary disposal and bargain purchases.

site_title: Indonesia to raise palm oil export levies
summary: Indonesia plans to increase palm oil export levies to support its biodiesel expansion programme. The levies, currently set at US$50 per tonne, will be raised due to the widening price difference between biodiesel and standard diesel. The government aims to increase the biodiesel programme to reduce energy imports and promote sustainable palm oil practices. The increase in levies is expected to help finance subsidies and replanting programmes for smallholders.

site_title: CDL mulls Singapore Reit for UK commercial properties
summary: CDL is exploring a potential real estate investment trust (Reit) listing on the Singapore bourse to hold UK commercial properties, including Aldgate House and 125 Old Broad Street, as early as this year.

site_title: Singapore's January factory jump may prove short-lived
summary: Singapore's factory output unexpectedly rose 3.4% in January, driven by a surge in biomedical manufacturing, despite economists' expectations of a 5.8% drop. However, analysts warn that the rise is likely short-lived due to the ongoing Covid-19 epidemic's negative impact on global supply chains and end-market demand. Biomedical manufacturing output surged 41.1%, while electronics declined 7.2% for the third consecutive month, with transport engineering also experiencing a broad-based decline. Analysts predict a potential monetary policy easing by the central bank in April, but a real factory recovery will depend on containing the virus globally.

images.alt_text: Singapore's factory output turned in a surprise rise in January on a surge in biomedical manufacturing, even as electronics remained in contraction, according to preliminary figures from the Economic Development Board (EDB) released on Wednesday.

site_title: Oil slides for 4th day as pandemic fears deepen
summary: Crude oil prices slid for a fourth day on February 26, 2020, as the coronavirus pandemic deepened, with Brent crude falling 2% to $53.84 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude dropping 1.7% to $49.05 a barrel. Gold prices rose 0.7% to $1,646.19 an ounce, while safe-haven assets such as safe-haven gold, palladium, and platinum also saw gains. The International Energy Agency (IEA) reduced its forecast for global oil demand growth due to the pandemic, and investors are seeking safe-haven assets amid uncertainty over the virus's impact on the global economy.

site_title: US: Dow ends choppy session lower; Nasdaq gains
summary: US stocks ended a choppy session mostly lower on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 0.5% to 26,957.86, and the S&P 500 shedding 0.4% to 3,116.46. The Nasdaq Composite Index edged up 0.2% to 8,980.77, despite growing concerns over the economic impact of the coronavirus epidemic, which saw 8 new countries report cases. Tech stocks like Apple and Netflix rose, while travel and oil-linked companies fell.

site_title: DBS offers loans, digital trade financing solutions in 2nd round of virus relief measures
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest lender, has unveiled its second round of virus relief measures, offering financial relief packages and digital initiatives to help businesses cope with the ongoing outbreak. The measures include a collateral-free digital business loan of up to S$50,000 for small and medium-sized enterprises, with interest rates estimated to be about 30% lower. The bank also upped the number of free FAST transactions to 50 a month and digitalized 11 common trade financing processes to reduce physical handling of cheques.

site_title: Pomp and pageantry, but what did Trump's India trip achieve?
summary: US President Donald Trump's India trip aimed to influence Indian-American voters and gain Major Non-NATO Ally status, but analysts argue the trip was largely symbolic and lacking in substance. Despite this, India benefited from the visit, gaining MNNA status and securing a trade deal worth over $3 billion in defense equipment. The trip also helped build personal chemistry between Trump and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, but the bilateral relationship faces challenges, including a stalled trade deal and differing positions on issues like Kashmir and the citizenship law.

site_title: Governments try to save renters money by banning brokers' fees
summary: New York has banned brokers' fees for renters, aiming to save them money. However, real estate agents warn that landlords will pass these costs on to tenants. Preliminary findings from Germany suggest that a ban may not significantly affect rental prices, as consumers often ignore extra charges. The new rules could benefit rent-regulated apartments, where landlords cannot quickly increase prices. Opponents argue that the changes could lead to job losses among agents and may not be directly applicable to New York's market, which differs from Germany's and Scotland's.

site_title: A new calculator sheds light on high-flying US unicorn price tags
summary: A new calculator, developed by finance professors Ilya Strebulaev and Will Gornall, provides a more accurate valuation of high-flying US unicorns by accounting for favourable terms large investors negotiate. The calculator, available at valuation.vc, calculates the fair value of common shares and options, revealing discrepancies between headline valuations and actual values. For example, DoorDash's common share value is estimated at $169, while Impossible Foods' is estimated at $9.24, compared to their reported valuations of $189.70 and $10.60, respectively. The calculator aims to bring transparency to the startup world.

site_title: Relief measures for retail sector do not address structural issues
summary: The Singapore government's relief measures for the retail sector, including a 15% property tax rebate and landlord promises to pass on savings to tenants, are deemed insufficient to address the sector's structural issues, such as e-commerce, high occupancy costs, and manpower shortages. Retailers, including food and beverage outlets, continue to struggle with slow footfall and sales, with some experiencing cash flow droughts due to travel bans on Chinese visitors. Experts predict a potential decline in tourist arrivals and spending, and a structural shift towards online platforms, with some predicting landlords may be unlikely to cut rents, at least in the short term.

site_title: Mahathir, Anwar vying to be the next Malaysian prime minister
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has resigned, leaving a power vacuum and a struggle between his former ally Anwar Ibrahim, 72, and his own supporters for the top job. Dr. Mahathir, 94, proposed a unified administration without party affiliations, while Anwar opposed forming a "backdoor government" and is now the candidate of the Pakatan coalition. Sultan Abdullah Sultan Ahmad Shah has been meeting all 222 elected Members of Parliament to determine the next prime minister, with Anwar having the support of 39 seats and potential alliance partners. A candidate must have the support of at least 112 MPs, heightening the chances of a snap election.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's decades-old political rivals Mahathir Mohamad and Anwar Ibrahim both set out claims to lead the country on Wednesday after Dr Mahathir's shock resignation as prime minister on Monday.

site_title: JPMorgan warns investors of climate change
summary: JPMorgan Chase has added "climate change" as a risk factor in its annual regulatory report, citing potential impacts on operations and customers. The bank warned of risks including droughts, flooding, wildfires, and rising sea levels, which could lead to negative consequences for clients' business models. The disclosure comes after JPMorgan vowed to stop financing coal-fired power plants unless using carbon capture technology and won't provide project financing for new oil and gas developments in the Arctic. The move reflects growing pressure from environmental activists.

site_title: Worried Chinese consult online doctors about virus
summary: In response to the COVID-19 outbreak, hundreds of millions of Chinese consumers are seeking online medical consultations due to quarantine restrictions and concerns about contracting the virus. The epidemic has led to a surge in demand for online healthcare services, benefiting a fledgling industry that has struggled to gain traction. Many Chinese are too worried to leave their homes or visit hospitals, opting instead for online consultations, which are becoming a popular alternative for addressing non-coronavirus health issues.

site_title: China's yuan proves resilient amid novel coronavirus epidemic
summary: China's yuan is approaching its strongest level since August against a basket of 24 exchange rates, despite the country being most affected by the novel coronavirus epidemic. The currency has stabilized in recent days due to government stimulus, a buoyant domestic stock market, and a slowdown in new infections. Analysts predict the yuan may outperform over the next month as investors reprice regional currencies. China's economy is expected to grow at its slowest pace in decades this quarter, with the government announcing aid measures to stem the virus' spread.

site_title: Internet giants fight spread of Covid-19 untruths
summary: Internet giants Google, Facebook, and others are fighting the spread of COVID-19 misinformation. In a meeting with the World Health Organisation (WHO), they discussed tactics such as promoting reliable information and fact-checking dubious claims. WHO director-general Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus said social media platforms are taking steps to limit the spread of misinformation. Google is ranking authoritative sources higher in search results and labeling fact-checked results. Facebook is blocking or restricting hashtags used to spread misinformation and conducting proactive sweeps to remove content.

site_title: Hong Kong flags record budget deficit as virus, protests cripple economy
summary: Hong Kong has unveiled a record budget deficit of 4.8% of GDP, or HK$139.1 billion, due to the ongoing protests and novel coronavirus pandemic. The budget includes cash handouts to residents and business tax breaks to soften the economic blow. Analysts expect the stimulus to provide some financial relief, but longer-term questions remain about restoring public trust in the government. The deficit is a record in nominal terms and is expected to continue for the next five years, with a projected shortfall of HK$120 billion in mostly one-off relief measures.

site_title: Leonardo da Vinci show smashes Louvre's all-time record
summary: A record-breaking 1.1 million people visited the Louvre's Leonardo da Vinci exhibition in Paris, surpassing the museum's all-time attendance record. The exhibition, held to mark the 500th anniversary of da Vinci's death in France, drew twice the numbers of the previous largest show at the museum. The event was a significant success, demonstrating the enduring popularity of the artist's work.

site_title: Life isn't always sweet in the C-suites
summary: A Singapore-based mental health counsellor estimates that 70-80% of top executives suffer from depression. The founder of a failed F&B company shares his personal experience of depression and suicidal tendencies during a crisis, highlighting the mental health impact on C-suite executives. Meanwhile, veteran hotelier Choe Peng Sum emphasizes the need for level-headedness during the coronavirus outbreak and shares plans for expansion. Fine-dining restaurants are developing in-house experts for unique beverage pairings, while watch shows and the Singapore International Festival of the Arts are upcoming events.

site_title: SPH acquires six aged care assets in Canada for C$232.9 million
summary: SPH acquires six aged care assets in Canada for C$232.9 million, comprising five Ontario properties and one Saskatchewan property, with 717 suites and 90% occupancy rates. The acquisition is part of SPH's strategy to expand its aged care and healthcare business in overseas markets with favourable demographics. The deal is expected to be completed by May and will be funded by a combination of internal funds and debt, following previous investments in Japan and the healthcare industry in Singapore.

site_title: US firms still have confidence in Singapore as a business hub despite Covid-19
summary: US firms remain confident in Singapore as a business hub despite the COVID-19 pandemic, with 98% of polled companies expressing long-term confidence in the country. The government's response to the outbreak, including effective health and safety updates, has boosted confidence. Only 1 in 10 firms reported temporary or permanent layoffs or salary cuts, and 5% have repatriated expatriate staff. Companies are refocusing their business strategies and enforcing flexible-work policies, but 72% expect a fall in revenues this year, with the travel and hospitality sector most affected.

site_title: CapitaLand, SMRT join wage-saving moves
summary: Singapore state investment firm Temasek and property giant CapitaLand, along with SMRT Corp, have announced wage-saving measures to mitigate the impact of the Covid-19 outbreak. CapitaLand will freeze wages for managerial staff, cut senior management pay by 5-15%, and offer rewards points and vouchers to its retail tenants. SMRT Corp will reduce salaries by up to 5% and bonus payments by 0.5 months. The measures aim to show solidarity with stakeholders and support affected businesses.

site_title: Chan Chun Sing repeats call to landlords, banks to pass on budgetary support
summary: Singapore's Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing urged landlords and banks to pass on Budget 2020 support and reliefs to tenants and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to help them cope with the coronavirus outbreak. The government has already provided a 15% property tax rebate and a temporary bridging loan programme, but some landlords remain non-committal. Chan called on big firms to help small ones and for banks to be more understanding with loan repayments for SME clients facing cash flow problems.

site_title: Co-working operators soldiering on amid virus fears
summary: Co-working operators in Singapore are adapting to the Covid-19 pandemic, with some suspending community events while others seeing increased demand from companies seeking alternative locations for their employees. WeWork, with 12 locations in Singapore, is helping its members navigate disruptions and has received inquiries from companies for business continuity planning. Other operators, such as Justco and The Work Project, are also experiencing increased demand despite suspending events. Most companies are following government guidelines, and some operators have implemented their own business continuity plans to minimize risk.

site_title: CapitaLand says traffic at Singapore malls almost back to normal
summary: Singapore mall traffic, particularly in suburban areas, has almost returned to normal, with a 5% decrease from pre-Covid-19 levels, according to CapitaLand's Q4 results briefing. Foot traffic dropped by 50% when Singapore raised the Disease Outbreak Response System Condition (Dorscon) level on February 7. The company's lodgings business in Singapore is less affected, with occupancy at 70% in some areas, while China's Tier 1 cities see 70% occupancy, with Tier 2 cities at 40%.

site_title: STI slides as US warns of sustained virus spread
summary: The Singapore Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.3% to 3,117.52 on Wednesday, with all but two blue-chip stocks ending in the red. The market volatility measure is now 13.8%, the highest close for the past year. The sell-off in Asia was more measured than in Europe and the US, possibly due to regional markets already pricing in the economic impact of COVID-19. Despite this, US futures reversed course after Europe opened, causing further declines.

site_title: Indonesia mulls merging top lender BRI with state firms
summary: Indonesia's state-owned enterprises minister, Erick Thohir, announced plans to merge state-controlled Bank Rakyat Indonesia (BRI) with two state financial firms, Pegadaian and Permodalan Nasional Madani (PNM), by June. The goal is to create an extraordinary bank with no overlapping services. However, BRI's CEO, Sunarso, stated that the merger structure has not been decided yet, and cooperation between the companies is also an option. The government aims to reduce the number of state companies and improve profitability.

site_title: BreadTalk yet to receive notice from trustee to repay S$100m notes
summary: BreadTalk Group, a Singapore-based food and beverage player, has breached financial covenants on its S$100 million notes due in 2023. The trustee has not given notice to repay the notes, but has the discretion to do so. BreadTalk believes the breaches are irreparable and has no certainty of success in addressing the issues. The company is evaluating options, including waivers and amendments, and has appointed a new CFO. BreadTalk's shares are trading at S$0.645, awaiting a trading halt to be lifted.

site_title: Saudi Arabia to host world's richest horse race
summary: Saudi Arabia is hosting the world's richest horse race, the Saudi Cup, with a US$20 million cash prize on offer. The event aims to boost the kingdom's battered global image and is part of a soft power push by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman to diversify its oil-reliant economy. The event will attract about 10,000 spectators and feature international jockeys, including Frankie Dettori and Ryan Moore, with the winner walking away with US$10 million. Critics accuse Saudi rulers of "sportswashing" to improve their image, but the event is seen as a positive step for the sport in the region.

site_title: Heathrow says halting new runway would be 'financial suicide'
summary: London Heathrow airport's CEO, John Holland-Kaye, says halting the construction of a new runway would be "financial suicide" and hinder the UK's post-Brexit trade efforts. The project, worth $20 billion, is opposed by campaigners and some politicians due to its environmental impact. Heathrow is concerned that blocking the runway will benefit rival airports like Paris Charles de Gaulle, which is expected to become Europe's busiest hub in two years. The CEO argues that a larger Heathrow is essential for the UK's global trade ambitions.

site_title: Mining giant Rio Tinto assessing coronavirus threat
summary: Rio Tinto assesses coronavirus threat, citing potential "significant uncertainty" in the short-term, despite reporting an eight-year high in profits due to iron ore's price surge in 2019. The company plans to adjust production levels and product mix to meet customer requirements, and aims to make its operations carbon neutral by 2050. However, Rio won't set targets for pollution caused by customers using its products, setting it at odds with peers like BHP Group.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 5.69 points to 1,495.19. The market saw a loss of 538 gainers to 350 losers, with a trading volume of 3.9 billion lots worth RM3.1 billion.

site_title: lates
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. In other market news, stocks in Europe and the US declined, with bank and healthcare sectors dragging down the market. The US stock market edged down from record highs amid tariff threats, while the US and EU continued to focus on tariffs. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, and Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss. Additionally, Heathrow Airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade, and Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case.

site_title: CapitaLand Q4 profit almost doubles to S$926.6m
summary: CapitaLand, Asia's largest diversified real estate group, reported a net profit of S$926.6 million for the fourth quarter of 2020, almost doubling from the previous year. The company maintained its unchanged dividend of 12 cents per share as a prudent measure to remain resilient during the Covid-19 outbreak. CapitaLand acquired a UK business park for £126.7 million and remains focused on growth, with a strong balance sheet and disciplined approach to seek counter-cyclical opportunities.

site_title: P2P lenders face big test amid virus outbreak
summary: P2P lenders face a significant test amid the ongoing COVID-19 outbreak, which threatens small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) with cash flow issues and dwindling sales. Despite added risks, fintechs say they are well-equipped to handle the challenges, having adapted their lending models and credit assessments to account for the heightened risks. Platforms have tightened their credit assessment and diversified investments to property-backed loans. Fintechs expect to see increased demand for loans, but also face the risk of loan delinquencies. Experts believe fintechs' agility and ability to adjust to market conditions will be key to their success in this challenging period.

images.alt_text: Fintechs such as peer-to-peer (P2P) lenders have burst onto the scene in the past few years to address a credit gap that they say is untouched by banks.

site_title: Pentagon's pledge on rules-based AI usage a notable development
summary: The US Pentagon has adopted ethical principles for the use of artificial intelligence (AI) in the military, following recommendations from the US Defence Innovation Board. The principles, which include guidelines for the use of AI, the exercise of judgment and care, and the minimization of unintended bias, aim to prevent misuse of AI. The move is seen as a significant step towards establishing universal governance rules on AI usage, following growing concerns about AI's potential for misuse and the need for international consensus.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Wilmar International's CFO Stephen Ho Kiam Kong will retire on May 31, 2020, after eight years. He will be succeeded by deputy CFO Charles Loo Cheau Long, who joined the company in 2010. No further details on Loo's tenure are mentioned.

site_title: Efficient supply chains underpin the rise of sustainable e-commerce
summary: The global shift to e-commerce has led to growing consumer demand for sustainable and transparent supply chains. Consumers expect businesses to prioritize environmental impact, with 60% seeking sustainable packaging and 50% preferring carbon-neutral deliveries. To meet these expectations, companies must invest in supply chain transparency, leveraging technology platforms to track product origins, production conditions, and carbon footprints. By doing so, businesses can reduce inefficiencies, increase agility, and improve profitability while supporting the growth of e-commerce.

site_title: Disney chief executive Bob Iger steps aside
summary: Disney CEO Bob Iger steps down after 15 years, replaced by 27-year veteran Bob Chapek. Iger's departure comes after four previous delays of his retirement. Chapek, who was chairman of Disney's parks business, will lead the company.

site_title: Lufthansa and United weigh takeover of Portugal's TAP
summary: Lufthansa and United Airlines are considering a potential takeover of Portugal's TAP-Air Portugal, a 50% state-owned airline, according to a report by the German newspaper Sueddeutsche Zeitung. The process could take time, with talks not close to a conclusion. TAP is also owned by a private consortium led by David Neeleman. The move comes as Lufthansa implements a cost savings program to counter the impact of the coronavirus outbreak. The three airlines, all members of the Star Alliance, declined to comment on the talks.

site_title: TSMP to deliver personal care packs to SGH front-line staff
summary: TSMP Law Corporation is delivering 1,000 personal care packs to Singapore General Hospital's front-line staff as part of its Handprint initiative. The care packages, valued at SGD, include items such as thermal tumblers, antiseptic wipes, and medicated plasters. The initiative, led by joint managing partner Stefanie Yuen Thio, aims to show appreciation for the hospital's healthcare heroes during the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: USD recovers from low as markets pare Fed bets
summary: The US dollar recovered from a two-week low on Wednesday as investors reduced expectations of the Federal Reserve cutting interest rates due to the novel coronavirus spread. Fed vice-chair Richard Clarida stated it's too soon to gauge the impact on the US economy, contradicting market expectations. Despite this, money markets still expect 60 basis points of cuts by the end of the year. The dollar edged 0.1% higher against a basket of rivals, while the Australian and euro currencies struggled near 11-year lows.

site_title: NTUC to match PMEs to new jobs ahead of displacement
summary: The NTUC Job Security Council will match professionals, managers and executives (PMEs) with new jobs ahead of displacement, aiming to minimize unemployment duration. The initiative, to be implemented by the labour movement, will provide relevant training if a skill gap exists. This move follows a growing concern about job displacement in the Singapore economy.

site_title: CDL chairman optimistic about outlook for 2020
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL) executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng expressed optimism about the outlook for 2020 despite the disruption caused by the Covid-19 outbreak. The company posted a 12.5% rise in net profit to S$87.7 million for the fourth quarter, driven by increased revenue from its core business segments. CDL plans to launch several new projects, including a 566-unit private residential project and a proposed condo development on the Irwell Bank Road site. The company also explored the possibility of redeveloping Fuji Xerox Towers, which could lead to a 25% uplift in gross floor area.

site_title: Wall Street wakes up to coronavirus
summary: Global markets plummeted on Monday, with the US stock market suffering its worst day in two years, as the coronavirus spread beyond China and raised concerns about the global economy. Despite initial optimism, investors now fear a potential recession and a sharp slowdown in global growth, with the first quarter of 2020 expected to be the slowest since 2008. Analysts predict a brief slowdown followed by a recovery, but the economic impact will vary by nation, with countries like Japan and Italy at high risk. The pandemic is accelerating de-globalization and shifting companies towards local production and consumption.

site_title: ISEC Healthcare Q4 net profit edges up 1% to S$2.3m
summary: ISEC Healthcare reported a 1% increase in Q4 net profit to S$2.3 million, driven by an 11% rise in revenue to S$11.6 million. However, the full-year net profit was down 11% to S$7.5 million, despite revenue growth. Impairment losses and a higher effective tax rate contributed to the lower profit. The company declared a final dividend of 0.50 cent per share and its shares closed up 0.5 cent or 1.45% to S$0.35.

site_title: Oxley unit in Cambodia to seek compensation from ex-contractor
summary: Oxley Holdings' subsidiary, Oxley Gem (Cambodia) Co, plans to seek compensation from its former contractor, Sino Great Wall International Engineering Co (SGW), for damages suffered due to repeated contract breaches. The breaches led to significant delays and difficulties in the development of The Peak, a 55-storey mixed hotel project in Cambodia. Oxley Gem terminated the contract with SGW in October and has since appointed a new contractor, China Railway Urban Construction Group Co, to finish the project. Oxley Gem successfully obtained an injunction order to evict SGW, and the company is now seeking compensation for damages.

site_title: Peugeot maker assures investors it can face market downturn
summary: PSA Group, the maker of Peugeot, raised its dividend and assured investors it can withstand a deepening car market slump. Despite a 10% drop in European car sales to 3.5 million vehicles in 2019, the company's profit margin widened to 8.5% due to cost-cutting measures and increased sales of higher-priced models. CEO Carlos Tavares said the company is in a more robust situation than a few years ago, and its earnings of €6.32 billion exceeded expectations. The shares rose 5% following the announcement.

site_title: Frasers Property offers support to Singapore mall tenants
summary: Frasers Property Retail (FPR) has offered support to 14 mall tenants in Singapore affected by the novel coronavirus outbreak. Tenants will receive security deposit conversions to banker's guarantees and a 15% property tax rebate. FPR may introduce additional rental reliefs for tenants most affected. The company has also implemented marketing initiatives and reduced atrium rental rates to drive shopper traffic. This move follows similar initiatives by other landlords, including CapitaLand and Mapletree Commercial Trust, amid the pandemic's impact on the retail sector.

site_title: QAF ups Q4 earnings more than 4 times to S$22.5m
summary: QAF Ltd's net profit for Q4 jumped more than fourfold to S$22.5 million, driven by its Australian pork production unit Rivalea, which enjoyed tax benefits. This boosted its bottom line. Rivalea's profits were not liable for tax under an existing tax benefits structure. The company's primary production segment saw a significant increase in profits.

site_title: China steps up data collection campaign to combat Covid-19
summary: China has launched a nationwide data collection campaign to combat the COVID-19 outbreak, with at least 15 provinces and cities collecting data on citizens' movements in public areas. Residents are being asked to scan QR codes using their mobile phones and fill in forms with information such as travel history and body temperature. The data is being used to track infected individuals and prevent the spread of the virus, but critics are raising concerns over privacy and the extent of the data repository being built on citizens.

site_title: Home Depot's profit gains on revved-up home market
summary: Home Depot Inc. posted a profit of $2.28 per share in the fourth quarter, exceeding analysts' projections by 17 cents. The company raised its forecast for same-store sales to as much as 4% for this year, following a 3.5% forecast cut three months ago. The US housing market's recovery, driven by lower borrowing costs, boosted home prices and led to increased renovations. Home Depot's shares have been recovering as the housing market strengthened, and the company expects to capitalize on the trend with its investments in technology and supply chain.

images.alt_text: Home Depot will continue to capitalise on the strength in the housing market and its investments in technology and supply chain.

site_title: No plans to waive foreign worker levy: Josephine Teo
summary: Singapore's Manpower Minister Josephine Teo announced that the government does not plan to waive foreign worker levies despite calls from business leaders and MPs to do so due to the coronavirus outbreak. The government's Stabilisation and Support Package, unveiled last week, includes measures to support businesses and workers, but Teo emphasized that preserving local employment is a priority. Waiving levies for foreign workers would not benefit employers with only local employees, and would also undermine longer-term efforts to reduce reliance on foreign manpower.

images.alt_text: Mrs Teo says waiving levies for foreign workers in general will not benefit the many employers who only have local employees.

site_title: Coronavirus: 2 new cases confirmed with no previous links
summary: Two new cases of the coronavirus disease (Covid-19) were confirmed in Singapore, bringing the total number of cases to 93. The two men, aged 47 and 38, do not have recent travel history to China and are in stable or improving condition in the hospital. Contact tracing is underway to establish if they have any links to previous cases. Four others have recovered and been discharged, with 62 fully recovered and 31 still in hospital, seven in critical condition.

site_title: Oracle says it is funding 'dark money' group that is fighting Big Tech
summary: Oracle Corp has funded the Internet Accountability Project (IAP), a conservative non-profit group promoting tougher privacy rules and stronger antitrust enforcement against Big Tech companies. Oracle donated between $25,000 and $99,999 to IAP in 2020, as disclosed in a new report. The group has filed an amicus brief supporting Oracle's position in a copyright case against Google, and the US Supreme Court will hear oral arguments on March 24. The IAP's funding is part of Oracle's efforts to take on rivals such as Amazon and Google, including a legal dispute over Java programming code in Android phones.

site_title: GSH Corp posts Q4 net loss of S$1.3m on impairment loss
summary: GSH Corp, a property developer, reported a Q4 net loss of S$1.3 million, mainly due to an impairment loss of S$13.7 million from an associated company. Revenue more than doubled to S$50.4 million, driven by property business growth. The company's full-year net profit surged 28% to S$7.6 million, with earnings per share increasing to 0.388 cents. Despite this, shares closed down 3.03% to S$0.32.

site_title: HK's exchange turns from tough year to trading boom
summary: Hong Kong's stock exchange reported a 1% increase in net income and 3% gain in revenue in 2019, despite a challenging year marked by anti-government protests and a 18% drop in trading volumes. The exchange weathered the storm by benefiting from a rise in initial public offerings and strong revenue from its Stock Connect program. Trading volumes have surged in 2020 due to the coronavirus, with the exchange exceeding HK$100 billion in trading on 16 out of 20 days after the Chinese New Year holiday.

site_title: Mahathir seeks unity government as Anwar vies for power
summary: Malaysia's Mahathir Mohamad, the world's oldest head of government, has called for a unity government without political parties following his shock resignation as prime minister. He was immediately named as interim prime minister by the king, but his supporters say Anwar Ibrahim, his former ally, has also been put forward for the role. The struggle between the two men has shaped Malaysian politics for decades, and the king is meeting all 222 elected members of parliament to determine their preferred prime minister or whether they want fresh elections.

site_title: No notice to repay S$100m notes received from trustee so far: BreadTalk
summary: BreadTalk Group has not received a notice to immediately repay its S$100 million notes due in 2023 following a technical breach of financial covenants. The breaches are deemed irreparable and cannot be remedied, resulting in an event of default. The trustee may accelerate the repayment, but it is not obligated to do so without a written request from noteholders or an extraordinary resolution. BreadTalk is evaluating options, including waivers and amendments, and has engaged with its bankers to address the breaches.

site_title: Javid warns Johnson not to ignore UK Treasury over spending
summary: UK former Chancellor Sajid Javid warned Prime Minister Boris Johnson not to ignore Treasury warnings over spending, citing concerns about over-centralizing power. Javid, who resigned as Chancellor two weeks ago, argued that the Treasury should remain a separate entity to provide candid advice to the Prime Minister. He also highlighted the need to balance the books, warning that passing the bill to future generations would be unfair. Javid's comments were seen as a carefully judged attack on Johnson's handling of the Treasury, and may be an attempt to pave the way for a potential return to government.

site_title: Some are preparing for Philippine bear market as stocks sink
summary: The Philippine Stock Exchange Index plummeted 3.9% to 6,909.84, marking a 6.8% three-day slump, as fears over the spreading coronavirus escalate. Analysts predict a bear market, with some gauges testing the 6,692.23 level, a 20% slide from its 2019 high. Experts warn of a "domino effect" on industries and the economy, citing a slowdown in manufacturing, supply chain disruptions, and consumer behavior changes, potentially leading to a recession.

site_title: US: Wall Street rises at open following four-day rout
summary: US stocks rose at open on Wednesday after a four-day percentage fall, their worst in over a year. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite opened higher, with gains of 0.29%, 0.37%, and 0.51% respectively. The rally followed concerns over the economic damage from the global spread of the coronavirus, but may be influenced by US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Coronavirus fears thin out the Fat Tuesday crowds in Venice
summary: Venice, Italy's most tourism-dependent city, is experiencing a significant decline in visitors due to coronavirus concerns. The city's Carnival celebrations, typically a peak tourist season, were significantly reduced, with many revellers abandoning the city before Lent. The local economy is feeling the impact, with hotel bookings down 40% and the city's historic center seeing a drastic drop in visitors. Tourism officials are urging caution, but the city's governor, Luca Zaia, reassures that Venice remains open and businesses are operating as usual.

site_title: Wilmar International CFO Stephen Ho Kiam Kong to retire in May
summary: Wilmar International announced CFO Stephen Ho Kiam Kong's retirement in May 2020, after eight years with the agribusiness group. He will be succeeded by deputy CFO Charles Loo Cheau Long. There are no concerns about financial reporting, and the company does not foresee any difficulties in meeting its reporting requirements. Wilmar shares closed down 1.2% on the announcement.

site_title: Teacher confirmed as first French coronavirus death
summary: A 60-year-old French teacher has become the country's first coronavirus death, with the victim dying in a Paris hospital. The teacher, who had not traveled to a hotspot, brings France's death toll to two, following an 80-year-old Chinese tourist who died in mid-February.

site_title: Halcyon Agri posts Q4 net profit of US$17.4m on one-off net gain
summary: Halcyon Agri Corporation reported a Q4 net profit of US$17.4 million, a significant improvement from a net loss of US$7.4 million in the same period last year. The company attributed the gain to a one-off net gain of US$46.5 million. Revenue fell 10.3% to US$480,000, while earnings per share rose to 1.09 cents from a loss of 0.46 cents. The full-year net loss narrowed to US$1.6 million from US$8.5 million in FY2018.

site_title: Coronavirus hits business in Milan as Italy death toll hits 12
summary: Italy's financial hub Milan grappled with the worsening coronavirus outbreak, with 52 new cases reported and one more death, bringing the national death toll to 12. Businesses, including the Salone del Mobile design fair, were delayed or cancelled, and cafes and restaurants were half empty. Authorities shut schools, universities, and other public places, and countries around Europe reported additional infections linked to Italy's flare-up. The European Union's health chief cautioned against panic, while the Italian government prepared measures to bolster the economy, which is expected to tip into recession due to the contagion.

site_title: US new home sales surge to 12-1/2-year high in Jan
summary: US new home sales surged to a 12-1/2-year high in January, reaching a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 764,000 units. This marks the highest level since July 2007. The increase, a 7.9% jump from the previous month, exceeds economists' forecasts of a 3.5% gain. The strong housing market may help mitigate the economic impact of the coronavirus and extend the longest economic expansion in history.

site_title: ABB's former CEO to get 13m Swiss franc payout
summary: ABB will pay former CEO Ulrich Spiesshofer 13 million Swiss francs, including 8.58 million for his notice period and 4.47 million for a non-compete clause. The payout comes despite the company missing revenue growth targets during his tenure. ABB's share price fell 9.4% during Spiesshofer's term, underperforming the blue-chip Swiss market index. The payment underscores the large sums earned by Swiss executives despite strict controls on executive pay.

site_title: Mining Giant Rio Tinto flags virus uncertainty threat
summary: Rio Tinto warns of coronavirus uncertainty, citing a windfall from iron ore's price surge in 2019 that boosted profits to an eight-year high. The miner paid out $7.2 billion in dividends, but may adjust production levels and product mix to meet customer requirements if the global growth outlook worsens. Rio aims to make its operations carbon neutral by 2050 and will spend $1 billion on the plans over the next five years. The company's shares have declined 2.8% in the past year.

site_title: Hong Kong stock exchange enjoys upbeat 2019 despite protests
summary: Hong Kong's stock exchange reported a 1% increase in net income and a 3% increase in revenue for 2019, despite an 18% drop in trading due to protests. The exchange retained its status as the world's biggest IPO market, with $314.2 billion in total IPO funds. However, the results were tempered by an uncertain 2020 outlook due to the spread of the deadly coronavirus and ongoing protests. The exchange attributed growth to its role as a crucial financial gateway for China, despite the city's economic woes.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets slide at open
summary: European stock markets slid at the start of trading on Wednesday, following Asian losses due to economic fallout from the coronavirus. London's FTSE 100 dropped 0.5%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 fell 1.0%, and Paris's CAC 40 lost 0.7%. The losses were attributed to bank and healthcare sectors. US-EU trade talks and tariff threats also weighed on investors' minds.

images.alt_text: London's benchmark FTSE 100 index dropped 0.5 per cent to 6,984.20 points at the open.

site_title: Budget debate: NTUC Job Security Council matches PMEs to new jobs ahead of displacement
summary: The NTUC Job Security Council (JSC) aims to match soon-to-be-displaced white-collared workers with new jobs in Singapore. The initiative, operationalised by the Employment and Employability Institute, will place professionals, managers, and executives (PMEs) with new jobs ahead of displacement. If a skill gap exists, JSC will work with training partners to provide relevant training. Over 4,000 companies, covering 500,000 workers, have partnered with JSC, with the goal of reducing the duration of unemployment and providing workers with skills progression and job placement.

site_title: CapitaLand senior management, board members to take pay cut amid virus outbreak
summary: CapitaLand, a property giant, has announced a pay cut for board members and senior management in response to the COVID-19 outbreak, with a 5-15% reduction in fees and salaries, effective April 1. The company also imposed a wage freeze on managerial staff and will distribute S$2 million worth of vouchers to its retail partners. This move is seen as a "show of togetherness and solidarity" with stakeholders amid the virus outbreak.

site_title: China's virus-hit airlines are showing signs of recovery
summary: China's airline industry appears to be showing signs of recovery after a month-long decline due to the coronavirus. Scheduled airline capacity within China has increased by over 25% week-on-week, with Air China Ltd adding back 306,000 seats. Analysts predict 7,923 flights will be reintroduced this week, but capacity adjustments and cancellations may occur. The recovery is attributed to a rebound in domestic capacity.

site_title: Anwar confident of forming next government
summary: Malaysian politician Anwar Ibrahim expressed confidence in forming the next government, potentially allowing him to succeed long-time rival Mahathir Mohamad as prime minister. Anwar's camp has reportedly secured the numbers to form the administration, with a regional alliance on Borneo pledging to abide by the king's decision. The king will meet with lawmakers to determine who has majority support, and Anwar's bloc will rely on this support to command a majority in the 222-seat parliament. Anwar's confidence comes after the former ruling alliance agreed to propose him as prime minister to the king.

images.alt_text: Malaysian politician Anwar Ibrahim said he was "confident" his camp has the numbers to form the next government, which would potentially allow him to finally succeed long-time rival Mahathir Mohamad as prime minister.

site_title: New Chinese billionaires outpace US by 3 to 1: Hurun Global Rich List
summary: China has outpaced the US by 3 to 1 in creating new billionaires, with 182 new Chinese billionaires emerging in the past year, taking the total to 799, according to the 2020 Hurun Global Rich List. This surge is attributed to the mini-boom in the coronavirus outbreak, which fueled stock valuations in online education, online games, and vaccinations. The US had 59 new billionaires, with Amazon founder Jeff Bezos retaining the top spot, while Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba's founder Jack Ma rose to No. 21 overall.

site_title: Starbucks to launch Beyond Meat plant-based breakfast sandwich in Canada
summary: Starbucks is set to launch a Beyond Meat plant-based breakfast sandwich in Canada starting March 3, marking the coffee chain's first imitation meat product. The sandwich will feature Beyond Meat, cheddar cheese, and an egg on an artisanal bun. This move intensifies the rivalry between plant-based meat producers and comes as restaurants compete for a share of the expanding morning food business. Starbucks aims to increase its plant-based offerings for environmentally sustainable operations, building on its existing 20% food business revenue.

site_title: Five more Chinese regions lower emergency response level as virus threat recedes
summary: Five Chinese regions, including Inner Mongolia, Xinjiang, Sichuan, Jilin, and Hainan, have downgraded their emergency response levels to address receding health risks from the coronavirus outbreak. China's four-tier response system, with level I being the most serious, now indicates that the health threat has diminished. This decision follows a nationwide assessment of the outbreak's impact.

site_title: Singapore shares slide 1.3% after US warns of sustained Covid-19 spread
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.3% on February 26, 2020, after US health officials warned of a sustained spread of the novel coronavirus. The STI traded in a range before closing at 3,117.52 points. Most Asia-Pacific benchmarks, including Australia, Japan, China, and South Korea, also posted losses. Despite the sell-off, analysts remain positive about some Singapore-listed companies, such as Penguin International, citing its increasing profitability and healthy balance sheet.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's NTUC Job Security Council is piloting an initiative to match displaced white-collared workers with new jobs. Industrial production rose 3.4% in January, exceeding expectations. DBS has introduced digital relief measures for companies to adapt to the pandemic. CapitaLand's senior management and board members will take pay cuts amid the virus outbreak. The Straits Times Index fell 1.3% due to US warnings on sustained Covid-19 spread.

images.alt_text: The labour movement is piloting an initiative to match soon-to-be-displaced white-collared workers with new jobs in a bid to reduce the duration of unemployment.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks further hit by virus fears
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 0.73% on Wednesday, following a worldwide decline as coronavirus fears worsen global economic concerns. The Hang Seng Index fell to 26,696.49, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes also declined. The decline is attributed to the extensive spread of the virus, which fans fears of a severe hit to the global economy.

site_title: Magnitude 6.2 quake strikes Indonesia's Tanimbar region: EMSC
summary: A magnitude 6.2 earthquake struck Indonesia's Tanimbar region on February 26, 2020, at a depth of 49 kilometers. The European Mediterranean Seismological Centre reported no tsunami potential from the quake. Indonesia, situated on the Pacific "Ring of Fire", frequently experiences deadly earthquakes and tsunamis.

site_title: Two Malaysia camps emerging in fight to form new government
summary: Malaysia's political landscape is shifting as two camps emerge in the fight to form the next government. The former ruling coalition Pakatan Harapan, led by Mahathir Mohamad, is sticking together with 41% of parliamentary seats. In contrast, the opposition coalition Barisan Nasional and an allied Islamic party hold 27%. Dr. Mahathir's leadership status is uncertain, with options to link up with either bloc or seek another combination of parties. The power struggle complicates Anwar Ibrahim's quest for prime minister and hampers the government's ability to address the economic slowdown and coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: China says Wall Street Journal admitted mistakes in recent communications
summary: China's foreign ministry stated that the Wall Street Journal admitted mistakes in recent communications regarding a February column with a racist headline. China demands the newspaper formally apologize and hold those responsible accountable. The Wall Street Journal declined to apologize, leading to the revocation of press credentials for three journalists with the newspaper's Beijing bureau. China seeks a formal apology from the newspaper for the column, which referred to China as the "real sick man of Asia".

site_title: American Chamber of Commerce firms keeping headcount in Singapore despite virus hit
summary: American Chamber of Commerce firms in Singapore report that despite the ongoing COVID-19 outbreak, most companies will not permanently repatriate foreign staff or lay off employees. The majority of firms, 98%, remain confident in Singapore as a business destination, citing the government's effective response to the outbreak. However, only 29% of respondents believe the situation on the ground is more under control than perceived, and fewer than half of companies have a formal disease outbreak response plan in place.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks fall as virus spread shows no signs of abating
summary: South Korean stocks fell 1.28% on Wednesday, with the main KOSPI index ending at 2,076.77, as the country reported 169 new coronavirus cases, pushing the total tally to 1,146. Foreign investors dumped shares, selling $728.36 million worth of KOSPI stocks, contributing to the decline. The KOSPI has fallen 5.5% so far this year, with the number of new cases showing no signs of abating, weighing down local stocks.

site_title: Koon Holdings creditors' meeting adjourned; debt restructuring scheme approved for unit
summary: Koon Holdings' subsidiary Koon Construction & Transport (KCT) has received creditor approval for its debt restructuring scheme, as part of the group's debt restructuring exercise. A creditors' meeting for Koon Holdings itself was adjourned due to a major creditor requesting more information before voting. The company will convene the adjourned meeting at a later date and address creditors' concerns. The debt moratorium for Koon Holdings expires in April 2020.

site_title: Birkin bag maker Hermes starting to see return to normal in China amid outbreak
summary: Hermes, the luxury handbag maker, reports a return to normality in China, with four of its 43 mainland stores still closed due to the COVID-19 outbreak. The company's CEO, Axel Dumas, stated that it's too early to estimate the impact of the health crisis on its group, but noted that 80% of its manufacturing capacity is based in France, unaffected by disruptions. Sales growth in the fourth quarter of 2019 slowed due to protests in Hong Kong and a sales tax increase in Japan, but remains in line with analyst expectations.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon down 0.9% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.9% on Wednesday, closing at 3,129.17, after 813.3 million securities worth S$684.8 million changed hands. Decliners outnumbered advancers 261 to 119. Key decliners included Golden Agri-Resources (-2.4%), Genting Singapore (-1.8%), and banking stocks such as DBS (-0.8%), United Overseas Bank (-0.6%), and OCBC Bank (-0.4%). This downward trend was mirrored in other Asia-Pacific regions, including Japan's Topix and South Korea's Kospi.

site_title: Malaysia's Anwar seeks to become PM amid turmoil
summary: Malaysian opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim is being considered for prime minister after his alliance partner and rival, Mahathir Mohamad, resigned on Monday. Mahathir, 94, was named interim prime minister by the king with full powers. Anwar, 72, and Mahathir formed a surprise pact in 2018, but their alliance has been marked by turmoil. Anwar's supporters have put his name forward for prime minister, amidst a struggle that has shaped Malaysian politics for decades. The outcome is uncertain, but Anwar's rise could signal a shift in the country's leadership.

site_title: Virus alarm drives rotation into gold with record ETF flows
summary: Global investors are flocking to gold, driving record ETF flows amid the coronavirus outbreak. Gold holdings in ETFs surged 25 consecutive days, reaching a record 2,624.7 tonnes. Prices have risen 18% last year and 5% in 2020, reaching a 7-year high. Analysts predict a prolonged downturn in growth due to the virus, keeping gold elevated and driving further ETF inflows. Goldman Sachs forecasts prices may reach $1,850 an ounce if the disruption persists into the second quarter.

site_title: CAD not taking further action on China Environment ex-chairman
summary: The Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) of the Singapore Police Force will not take further action against Huang Min, former executive chairman of China Environment, due to insufficient evidence of a criminal offence committed in Singapore. The CAD reviewed the case, but found no evidence to substantiate allegations against Mr. Huang and former CFO Chiar Choon Teck. The company had previously lodged a complaint against them in 2016 regarding non-existent receivables, and is currently under investigation by the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority.

site_title: Qatar eyes diplomatic win with US, Taleban deal
summary: Qatar is poised to reap a diplomatic dividend as it prepares to host a deal in Doha that would see the US withdraw thousands of troops from Afghanistan in exchange for security commitments from the Taliban. The negotiations, facilitated by Qatar, have created a neutral space for talks and boosted the country's international profile despite a painful embargo enforced by neighboring countries. If successful, the deal could cement Qatar's role as trusted brokers and bolster its alliances, with Qatar's Emir Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad Al-Thani set to ride high on the success of the mediation efforts.

site_title: Frasers Property offers virus relief measures for Singapore mall tenants
summary: Frasers Property Retail (FPR) has introduced virus relief measures for 14 Singapore malls, including security deposit conversions and rental reliefs, to support tenants affected by the novel coronavirus outbreak. The measures include passing on a 15% property tax rebate to tenants and offering additional support, such as rental reliefs, to those most affected. FPR will also implement marketing initiatives to drive shopper traffic and provide marketing assistance to select tenants.

site_title: Air New Zealand tests beds for economy passengers
summary: Air New Zealand is testing "Economy Skynest" pods in economy-class, featuring six beds per pod, to address the issue of passengers not being able to stretch out on long-haul flights. The pods, measuring 200x58cm, include amenities like pillows, sheets, and earplugs. Passengers can pre-book sessions, breaking up long flights. The concept aims to improve passenger comfort and is expected to be introduced for at least a year, pending regulatory approval.

site_title: Oil slides for fourth day as virus fears deepen
summary: Crude oil prices slid for a fourth day, falling 0.6% to $54.64 a barrel for Brent crude and 0.3% to $49.74 a barrel for US West Texas Intermediate crude. Fears over the coronavirus pandemic, now found in 30 countries, have deepened, prompting a shift in focus from China to the US economy. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) and its allies are set to meet on March 5-6, with a weekly close below $55.00 a barrel expected to trigger alarm bells.

site_title: Asia: Markets take another hit as virus quickly spreads
summary: Asian markets plummeted on Wednesday as the coronavirus outbreak spreads rapidly, with the virus reported in new countries and lockdowns implemented in several nations. The US stock market also fell, with all three main indexes losing around 3% after officials warned of Covid-19's impact. Traders fear the outbreak's impact on the global economy, with investors increasingly fearful of the virus's spread.

site_title: Indonesia wants to merge top lender BRI with 2 state firms: minister
summary: Indonesia's state-owned enterprises minister, Erick Thohir, announced plans to merge Bank Rakyat Indonesia (BRI) with two state financial firms, Pegadaian and Permodalan Nasional Madani (PNM), by June. The merger aims to strengthen the country's financial sector. However, BRI's CEO stated that a final decision on the merger was still pending.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close down on pandemic fears
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on February 26, 2020, extending losses on Wall Street amid concerns over a coronavirus pandemic. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.79% and the Topix index 0.75%, as health officials warned of the increasing likelihood of a pandemic.

site_title: Startup Snapask eyes breakeven in 2020 with US$35m fresh funds
summary: Snapask, a 5-year-old tutoring app, has secured $35 million in fresh funding to expand into Vietnam and become profitable by 2020. The startup, which has raised over $50 million, plans to double its staff and open a regional headquarters in Singapore. With $3 million in new users added in the past quarter, Snapask may benefit from the coronavirus outbreak in Asia, which has led to school suspensions. The company aims to maintain its cash-flow positive operations and achieve profitability this year.

site_title: Singapore to build simulation facilities on all train lines to improve rail reliability
summary: Singapore has allocated S$100 million over five years to build simulation facilities on all train lines to enhance rail reliability. These facilities, resembling command centers, allow operators to simulate scenarios such as track faults and cyber security threats without disrupting actual train operations. The facilities, set to open progressively from 2020 to 2022, will enable testing of new signalling software and help engineers troubleshoot system faults, ultimately minimizing disruptions to passenger service.

site_title: Australia's Woolworths posts 1.7% drop in half-year profit
summary: Australia's Woolworths reported a 1.7% drop in half-year profit to A$887 million, attributed to stiff competition and deep discounting during the holiday season. The company's profit is down from A$902 million last year. Despite this, Woolworths declared an interim dividend of 46 Australian cents per share, up from 45 cents.
