site_title: Singapore factory output posts surprise 3.4% rise in January - but can the lift last?
summary: Singapore's factory output rose 3.4% in January, defying economists' expectations of a 5.8% decline, thanks to a surge in biomedical manufacturing. However, the electronics sector continued to contract, and industrial production decreased by 3.8% when excluding the volatile biomedical cluster. The increase lifted factories out of a two-month losing streak, but Barclays economist Brian Tan remains cautious on the economic outlook due to the Covid-19 outbreak.

site_title: Bob Iger steps aside as Disney CEO, hands off to company insider
summary: Bob Iger steps down as Disney CEO, handing the reins to company insider Bob Chapek, a 27-year Disney veteran. Chapek takes over effective immediately, succeeding Iger who led the media-entertainment powerhouse for over 15 years. Iger will assume the role of executive chairman and direct the company's creative endeavors. The move comes after Disney successfully integrated 21st Century Fox assets and launched its direct-to-consumer streaming service, Disney+.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open with fresh losses
summary: Hong Kong shares fell 1.54% in the opening exchanges on Wednesday, extending a retreat fueled by fears over the coronavirus. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 26,479.00, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 1.15% and the Shenzhen Composite Index tumbled 1.37%. The decline was attributed to concerns over the virus's spread worldwide.

site_title: CAO posts 13.2% rise in Q4 profit to US$21.2m
summary: China Aviation Oil (CAO) reported a 13.2% rise in Q4 net profit to US$21.2 million, driven by higher gains from jet fuel supply and trading activities. Revenue increased 16.6% to US$5.1 billion, mainly due to increased fuel volume. For the full year, net profit rose 6.4% to US$99.8 million, while revenue declined 1.3% to US$20.34 billion. CAO's board proposed a 4.7 Singapore cents per share final cash dividend for shareholder approval. The company plans to leverage its core competencies to expand globally and build structural advantages in oil products.

site_title: DBS nudges firms to go digital in second wave of Covid-19 relief measures
summary: DBS Bank in Singapore has introduced its second round of Covid-19 relief measures, including financial assistance and digital initiatives to help businesses cope with the virus outbreak. The measures include a collateral-free digital business loan of up to S$50,000 and increased free FAST transactions to promote digital adoption. DBS has also digitalized 11 trade financing processes to reduce physical reliance, offering customers a one-stop portal and instant application status notifications. The bank aims to support businesses' immediate cash flow needs and longer-term digital transformation efforts.

site_title: Dozens allowed off Japan virus-hit ship have 'symptoms': minister
summary: Japan's health minister reports that dozens of passengers who were allowed off the virus-hit Diamond Princess cruise ship have developed symptoms, including fever, and will be asked to take tests for COVID-19. Initially, 970 passengers were cleared to disembark after testing negative, but subsequent testing revealed 45 with certain symptoms, prompting concerns about the spread of the virus.

site_title: Broker's take: CGS-CIMB upgrades UMS to 'add', raises target price to S$1.08
summary: CGS-CIMB upgraded UMS Holdings to "add" with a target price of S$1.08, following the company's revised revenue forecasts upwards for its precision engineering firm. The upgrade comes after a 56% leap in Q4 revenue driven by semiconductor sales. Analyst William Tng expects a stronger earnings recovery for FY2020, but notes risks from Sino-US trade issues and the coronavirus outbreak. Maybank Kim Eng maintained a "buy" recommendation, while DBS Group Research lowered its price target to S$1.12.

site_title: China reports 52 more coronavirus deaths, lowest in three weeks
summary: China reported 52 new coronavirus deaths, the lowest in three weeks, bringing the death toll to 2,715. The new deaths were in Hubei province, with 401 of the 406 new infections also reported there. The number of fresh cases has declined, with multiple provinces reporting zero new infections. The disease has now reached dozens of countries, with South Korea's death toll rising to 11 and Italy reporting 10 deaths. Authorities are concerned that cases abroad could reintroduce new outbreaks into China, prompting quarantine measures.

site_title: AEM's Q4 earnings nearly quadruple on new orders
summary: AEM Holdings, a provider of advanced chip testing solutions, reported a nearly quadrupling of its Q4 net profit to S$16.7 million, driven by new orders and revenue growth. Revenue more than doubled to S$88.6 million, while earnings per share increased to 6.21 Singapore cents. The company revised its FY2020 revenue guidance upwards to between S$360 million and S$380 million, citing strong sales orders worth S$338 million. The company also recommended a final cash dividend of 3.1 Singapore cents per share, up from 1.9 cents in 2018.

site_title: BHG Retail Reit's Q4 DPU slips 14.7% to 0.93 S cent
summary: BHG Retail Reit reported a 14.7% drop in Q4 distribution per unit (DPU) to 0.93 Singapore cents, from 1.09 cents last year. Gross revenue rose 18.7% to S$20.4 million, while net property income (NPI) grew 11.6% to S$12.4 million. Despite a decline in DPU, the manager attributes the lower DPU to increased distribution units and management fees paid in units instead of cash, citing a strong rental reversion and higher occupancy rates.

site_title: Credit Karma founder to get billion-dollar windfall from sale
summary: Ken Lin, 44, co-founder of Credit Karma, is set to receive a billion-dollar windfall from the company's sale to Intuit Inc for approximately $7.1 billion in cash and stock. Lin, who owns 15% of the company, is expected to collect a 10-figure sum, following in the footsteps of other fintech founders who have sold their companies for significant sums. The sale marks a remarkable rise for Lin, who immigrated to the US from China as a child and has been known for his unconventional approach to business.

site_title: South Korea reports 169 new coronavirus cases, total tops 1,100
summary: South Korea reported 169 new coronavirus cases, bringing the total to 1,146, the largest outside China. An 11th person, a Mongolian man in his 30s, has died from the disease. Most new cases (90%) are in Daegu and North Gyeongsang provinces, with the city's population largely deserted due to the outbreak. Authorities have urged citizens to exercise extra caution and stay home if they have a fever or respiratory symptoms. The government has pledged to mobilize resources to control the outbreak.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Wednesday, down 15.36 points or 1.02% to 1,485.52. The market saw 143.63 million lots traded worth RM62.92 million, with losers beating gainers 254 to 60.

site_title: AI computing startup SambaNova raises US$250m in BlackRock-led funding
summary: SambaNova Systems, an AI computing firm, has raised US$250 million in a funding round led by BlackRock Inc to expand its customer base. The Palo Alto, California-based company, launched in 2017, aims to build an advanced systems platform for AI and data-intensive applications. The funding round also included Intel Corp, Alphabet, and venture capital arms of Walden International, WRVI Capital, and Redline Capital. This investment reflects investors' appetite for the AI market, which is expected to drive growth and innovation in the industry.

site_title: Most British firms in China see hit from coronavirus: survey
summary: Most British firms in China expect revenues to fall this year due to the coronavirus, with nearly 70% anticipating a decline. Half of the 135 surveyed companies expect a drop of over 10%, while a quarter anticipate a decrease of more than 20%. The epidemic has killed over 2,600 and infected over 77,000 in China, leading to widespread restrictions. The survey's findings highlight the significant impact of the virus on British businesses operating in China.

site_title: Singapore malls foot traffic almost back to normal: CapitaLand
summary: Singapore's mall foot traffic has almost returned to normal, with a 5% decline from pre-Covid-19 levels, according to CapitaLand's Q4 results briefing. Foot traffic had dropped by 50% in February after Singapore raised the Disease Outbreak Response System Condition (Dorscon) level. However, it has since recovered, with 95% of its malls experiencing foot traffic. The company's lodgings business in Singapore and China has also seen some impact but has been mitigated by longer corporate stays. CapitaLand's net profit nearly doubled to S$926.6 million for the fourth quarter, driven by better operating performance and higher gains from asset recycling.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand, CDL, SPH, Fragrance, First Resources
summary: Singapore stocks saw significant developments Wednesday, with CapitaLand's net profit nearly doubling to S$926.6 million, driven by better operating performance and asset recycling. City Developments Limited (CDL) posted a 12.5% rise in net profit, while Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) acquired aged care assets in Canada for C$232.9 million. First Resources' net profit surged 84.6% to US$32 million, boosted by higher production and sales volumes.

site_title: SPH expands aged care business with C$232.9m Canadian acquisition
summary: SPH expands its aged care business with a C$232.9 million acquisition of six Canadian assets. The portfolio comprises 717 suites across five independent living properties and one assisted living property, with an average age of seven years. This deal marks SPH's strategy to acquire cash-yielding assets in defensive sectors.

site_title: Nestle delays all business trips over coronavirus
summary: Swiss food giant Nestle has postponed all business trips until March 15, 2020, due to the coronavirus epidemic. The company has asked employees worldwide not to travel for business purposes and will review the measure as external developments unfold. Nestle employs 291,000 people globally and monitors the situation to ensure employee safety. The epidemic has spread to dozens of countries, infecting tens of thousands of people and killing over 2,600.

site_title: Singapore stocks tumble tracking US rout on virus jitters; STI opens 0.9% lower
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) declined 29.35 points or 0.9% to 3,128.89 on Wednesday, tracking a US rout amid concerns over the novel coronavirus. Heavyweight bank counters and real estate stocks fell, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC Bank losing 1-1.1%, and CapitaLand and City Developments Limited shedding 1.1-2.1%. The US benchmark indices also declined, with Tokyo stocks opening lower, following warnings from US health officials about a potential larger virus outbreak.

site_title: China quarantines 94 people on Seoul flight after three show fever
summary: China has quarantined 94 air passengers arriving from Seoul after three Chinese passengers on a flight were found to have fevers, according to state media. The passengers, who arrived in Nanjing on Tuesday, were discovered by customs personnel after a screening. The quarantine is a precautionary measure to prevent the spread of the Covid-19 virus.

site_title: Wells Fargo workers seek Washington's help with internal gripes
summary: Wells Fargo workers are taking their internal complaints to Capitol Hill, citing a toxic culture that has been brushed aside by management. An advocacy group, The Committee for Better Banks, will participate in a House Financial Services Committee hearing on March 25, with two bank workers set to testify. Wells Fargo has acknowledged the concerns, stating that management takes them seriously. The workers are seeking accountability for the bank's culture, which they claim has led to employee dissatisfaction.

site_title: First Resources Q4 earnings climb 84.6% on higher production, sales volumes
summary: First Resources, an Indonesian palm oil producer, reported an 84.6% surge in net profit to US$32 million in Q4 2019, driven by higher production and sales volumes. Revenue grew 26.6% to S$184.2 million. The company's full-year net profit sank 25.7% to US$89.1 million due to softer palm oil prices. Despite recent concerns over the novel coronavirus outbreak, the group believes supply-demand dynamics remain favourable. A final dividend of 1.725 Singapore cents per share is proposed for 2019, down from two cents in 2018.

site_title: Fragrance's fiscal 2019 profit tumbles 70.1% to S$79.9m
summary: Fragrance Group, a property developer, posted a 70.1% drop in net profit to S$79.9 million for FY2019, from S$267.2 million a year ago. Revenue fell 82.2% to S$58.2 million. The company attributed the decline to the City Gate development project in Singapore, which obtained its temporary occupation permit in 2018. Fragrance expects the market for residential properties to remain competitive and has declared an interim cash dividend of 0.35 Singapore cent per share.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall further as pandemic fears mount; New Zealand down
summary: Australian shares fell 2.2% on Wednesday, extending losses into a fourth session, amid US health officials' warnings of a domestic coronavirus outbreak. The S&P/ASX 200 index declined to 6,717.70, with nearly 93% of stocks trading in the red. Heavyweight financials and miners dragged down the bourse, while energy stocks hit a six-month low. In New Zealand, the benchmark index fell 1% as Port of Tauranga and SKY Network Television were the worst performers.

site_title: US airlines, hotels extend rebooking options as coronavirus spreads
summary: US airlines and hotels are extending rebooking options for travelers affected by the coronavirus outbreak, particularly in Italy, South Korea, and Japan. Airlines such as Delta and Air Canada are offering free rebooking or cancellations for flights to these countries, while hotels like Hyatt are waiving cancellation fees. Travel companies, including cruise lines, are also taking precautions, with Royal Caribbean canceling sailings in Southeast Asia. The US government has warned Americans to prepare for the virus to spread within the country, with cases escalating in Italy, South Korea, and Iran.

site_title: City Developments' Q4 profit up 12.5% to S$87.7m
summary: City Developments Limited (CDL) reported a 12.5% increase in net profit to S$87.7 million for the fourth quarter, driven by increased revenue from its property and hotels segments. Revenue rose 20.1% to S$946.9 million, with contributions from projects such as The Tapestry and W Singapore - Sentosa Cove. The company also recommended a final ordinary dividend of S$0.08 per share and a special final ordinary dividend of S$0.06 per share.

site_title: Europe: Stocks sink further as pandemic fears hit buying
summary: European shares plummeted 1.8% to their lowest in nearly two months, wiping nearly $700 billion from the Stoxx 600 index, due to concerns over the coronavirus pandemic's economic impact. Banking and insurance shares led declines, while Prudential Plc bucked the trend with a slight gain after a hedge fund amassed a $2 billion stake. Euro zone data showed stagnant German economic activity, and airline stocks continued to fall, with Lufthansa, EasyJet, and Ryanair losing between 1.5% to 3.6%.

site_title: Trump economic adviser sees no US recession ahead
summary: Larry Kudlow, President Trump's chief economic advisor, expressed confidence that the US economy is holding up well despite the coronavirus epidemic hitting other countries. He downplayed the economic impact of the virus, saying it won't be a "tragedy" and estimating it will take two to three weeks to determine its effects. Kudlow also dismissed speculation of an emergency rate cut by the Federal Reserve, saying he's not hearing of any plans. The US economy continues to show signs of health, with new consumer confidence figures released Tuesday.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on virus fears
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on February 26, 2020, due to concerns over the spreading coronavirus and increasing likelihood of a global pandemic. The Nikkei 225 index fell 1.21% to 22,331.85, while the Topix index declined 1.16% to 1,599.49. This extends losses seen on Wall Street.

site_title: In new gaffe, White House hopeful Biden says running for 'Senate'
summary: Joe Biden's White House bid has been marred by verbal slip-ups, days before the South Carolina Democratic primary. The former vice-president incorrectly stated he was running for the US Senate, where he served for 36 years, and also claimed to have negotiated the 2015 Paris climate accord with China's Deng Xiaoping, who died in 1997. These gaffes have raised concerns about Biden's mental acuity and come as his campaign struggles to recover from poor showings in Iowa, New Hampshire, and Nevada.

site_title: CapitaLand Q4 profit almost doubles; buys UK business park for £126.7m
summary: CapitaLand's net profit almost doubled to S$926.6 million in Q4 2019, driven by better operating performance and gains from asset recycling. The company acquired a UK business park for £126.7 million, and proposed a final cash dividend of S$0.12 per share. Despite a 46.3% revenue rise, the Covid-19 situation is expected to have an adverse impact on operations, with the group prioritizing staff and tenant well-being.

site_title: Air Canada extends flight suspension to Chinese cities, citing coronavirus
summary: Air Canada has extended its flight suspension to Chinese cities of Beijing and Shanghai until April 10 due to the coronavirus epidemic, citing health concerns. The airline initially suspended flights from January 30 to February 29. Air Canada also suspended daily flights to Hong Kong from Toronto until April 30, citing reduced market demand. The airline expects a net profit loss of approximately C$200 million in the first quarter due to travel restrictions. There have been 11 confirmed cases of the virus in Canada.

site_title: Trump plans South-east Asia summit in Las Vegas: Pompeo
summary: US President Donald Trump has invited South-east Asian leaders to meet in Las Vegas on March 12, despite fears over the coronavirus outbreak, according to Secretary of State Mike Pompeo. This comes after last year's summit was scrapped. The summit is the first high-level meeting between the US and Asean nations since 2019, when Trump skipped the event. The decision to hold the summit in Las Vegas was made after Chile canceled a Pacific Rim summit in November due to protests. Pompeo confirmed the date, saying the summit would involve Trump and other Asean leaders.

site_title: UK post-Brexit foreign review points to rocky road ahead
summary: The UK has begun its most sweeping defence and security review since the end of the Cold War, amid post-Brexit policy flux. British Prime Minister Boris Johnson is navigating disputes with US President Donald Trump and negotiating a new trade deal with the EU by December 31. This review comes after a lack of focus on international policy since 2015, and Johnson must recalibrate UK foreign and defence policy globally, from Asia-Pacific to the Americas. The outcome is uncertain, with a rocky road ahead for UK policy.

site_title: How ride will Grab-Gojek merger be?
summary: Grab and Gojek, Southeast Asia's two largest ride-hailing companies, are reportedly discussing a potential merger. Grab, valued at US$14 billion, would likely gain control of Gojek, valued at US$10 billion, in Indonesia, a key market. The deal could benefit both companies by reducing competition and increasing profitability. However, regulators may face challenges due to antitrust concerns, and cultural and ego clashes between the two companies could hinder the merger. The process is complex, with valuation and deal terms still being negotiated.

site_title: Health authorities expect coronavirus spread on US soil
summary: US health authorities expect the novel coronavirus to spread in the US, with community spread imminent, according to the CDC. Officials are urging local governments, businesses, and schools to develop plans to mitigate the outbreak, including canceling mass gatherings and teleworking. The US drug supply chain is also at risk due to the high proportion of ingredients made in China. A vaccine candidate has shown effectiveness in mice and is expected to begin human trials within a month and a half.

site_title: Virgin Australia to cut capacity after H1 underlying profit plunges 78%
summary: Virgin Australia to cut 3% capacity in second half and 5% in next year due to COVID-19's impact on demand. The airline reported a 78% fall in half-year underlying earnings, resulting in a A$88.6 million loss. Capacity cuts will be achieved by removing 7 Airbus A320 jets from budget arm Tigerair Australia. This move aims to minimize impact on the group's financial position as the coronavirus situation is expected to result in a A$50-75 million hit to earnings in the second half.

site_title: It's a two-front war on the virus and economy for China
summary: China is waging a two-front war against the novel coronavirus and its struggling economy, with President Xi Jinping personally overseeing the campaign. Despite initial optimism, the virus has shown signs of resistance, with outbreaks in hospitals and prisons. The government has postponed the annual parliamentary meeting and convened emergency meetings to address the crisis. Xi acknowledged shortcomings in the party's response but expressed confidence in eventual triumph, while also emphasizing the need to revive the economy. The stakes are high, with the global audience watching an epic battle that China cannot afford to lose either struggle.

site_title: Oil falls for third day as virus fears accelerate on US warning
summary: Oil prices fell for a third day, dropping 3% on Tuesday as concerns about the spread of the coronavirus accelerated. The US government warned Americans to prepare for the disease, and the sell-off accelerated after the US Centres for Disease Control and Prevention said Americans should begin to prepare. Brent crude fell $1.35 to $54.95 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude dropped $1.53 to $49.90 a barrel. The virus's impact on demand is expected to push oil prices down further, with crude inventories expected to rise for a fifth week.

site_title: Streaming continues to boost US music industry growth
summary: The US music industry posted its fourth consecutive year of double-digit growth in 2019, with revenue reaching US$11.1 billion. Streaming services, particularly paid subscriptions to platforms like Spotify and Tidal, accounted for nearly 80% of the industry's total revenue, growing 13% from the previous year. Vinyl sales also experienced significant growth, increasing 19% to US$504 million, while revenues from compact discs and digital downloads declined.

site_title: Hedge fund seeks break-up of UK's Prudential
summary: Hedge fund Third Point has invested over $2 billion in UK insurer Prudential and called for the company to split its Asian and US businesses, citing undervaluation and recruitment disadvantages. Third Point argues that separating the businesses would lead to cost cuts, better capital allocation, and improved management. Prudential has confirmed receiving the letter and is considering dialogue with the hedge fund. A potential split could lead to a major shake-up at the company, which has a market capitalization of $66.8 billion.

site_title: Malaysia's opposition parties call for elections
summary: Malaysia's opposition parties have called for elections, rejecting a proposed unity government led by interim Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad. The parties, including PKR, declared their opposition to a grand coalition, instead advocating for the dissolution of parliament to allow the people to decide. The king, who named Mahathir as interim prime minister, will hold individual interviews with parliament members to assess potential successors. The situation is seen as rapidly evolving, with Singapore monitoring developments closely and expressing hope for a swift agreement among parties.

site_title: Long leases 'protect Cromwell's Italy assets from Covid-19 impact'
summary: Cromwell European Reit, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust (REIT), expects its Italian properties to be less affected by the COVID-19 pandemic due to long leases on logistics, industrial, and office buildings. The REIT has seen a 30.4% increase in distribution per unit and 64.2% growth in gross revenue for the fourth quarter of 2019. Despite concerns about the pandemic's impact, the REIT's CEO Simon Garing believes the company's favorable interest rates and lease terms will offset expected rental increases.

site_title: US: Stocks suffer second straight rout on coronavirus fears
summary: US stocks plummeted for the second consecutive day, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 3.2% to 27,081.36, the S&P 500 sinking 3.0% to 3,128.21, and the Nasdaq Composite Index losing 2.8% to 8,965.61, amid concerns over the coronavirus's potential impact on the US economy. Health officials warned of community spread, while investors became increasingly pessimistic about global growth prospects. Despite this, the White House economic counselor downplayed the risk, citing "very tightly contained" cases in the US.

site_title: By George! BreadTalk's off the shelf
summary: BreadTalk Group, a Singapore-based food and beverage company, has announced a joint offer to take the company private by its executive chairman and chief executive officer, George Quek, and his wife. The move comes after the company faced significant challenges, including a 40% drop in sales from Hong Kong and a heavy blow from the coronavirus pandemic. BreadTalk Group has also seen significant executive departures, including its chief financial officer, and has struggled with debt. The private ownership is seen as a way to address the company's challenges and provide more flexibility to manage its businesses.

site_title: 5 lessons from owning a stock that made 10 times my money
summary: A writer shares his experience of buying shares of Booking Holdings (BKNG) in 2010, when the company's stock price fell due to the Icelandic volcano eruption. He initially disagreed with the market's reasoning that hotel bookings would suffer, but ultimately made a 10x return on his investment. The company has since grown to become a behemoth with over 28 million accommodation options listed on its site, offering a wide range of travel-related services. The writer emphasizes that the quality of the company matters more than timing, and that investing in a well-known company with a strong culture can lead to satisfactory returns.

site_title: British exports to EU could fall 14% in no-deal scenario: UN study
summary: A UN study found that British exports to the EU could fall by up to 14% if a no-deal Brexit scenario occurs, with a potential US$32 billion hit to exports. This could be reduced to 9% if a free trade deal is reached, primarily due to the imposition of tariffs and non-tariff measures such as quotas and licensing.

site_title: Egypt's former president Hosni Mubarak, 91, dies
summary: Egypt's former president Hosni Mubarak, 91, has died after undergoing treatment in an intensive care unit following surgery, according to state television. Mubarak ruled Egypt for 30 years until his ouster in 2011, after being arrested and cleared of charges in 2017. He was convicted in 2015 of diverting public funds and sentenced to three years in jail. Mubarak's rule was marked by autocracy and crony capitalism, leading to Egypt's first free election after his overthrow, which brought in Islamist President Mohamed Mursi.

site_title: Thousands attend LA memorial for Kobe Bryant and daughter
summary: Thousands of people attended a memorial at the Staples Center in Los Angeles for Kobe Bryant and his 13-year-old daughter Gianna, who died in a helicopter crash last month. The public memorial, dubbed "A Celebration of Life," was held in the arena where Bryant played for nearly two decades. Celebrities, athletes, and fans paid up to $224 per ticket to attend the two-and-a-half hour ceremony. The event coincided with Bryant's jersey number "24" and Gianna's "2" jersey number, with fellow Lakers legend Magic Johnson and filmmaker Spike Lee in attendance.

site_title: Expedia will cut 3,000 jobs to simplify business
summary: Expedia Group Inc. is cutting 3,000 jobs to simplify its business and achieve more disciplined growth. The staff reductions will affect approximately 500 employees at the company's Seattle-based headquarters, with the remaining 2,500 employees impacted across other locations. The job cuts are not directly related to the coronavirus outbreak, which had earlier added uncertainty to the company's profit outlook. Expedia aims to return to more streamlined operations, but no further details on the restructuring process have been provided.

site_title: Cash handouts, tax cuts on table in HK budget
summary: Hong Kong's government is expected to unveil a "recession budget" on Wednesday, focusing on tackling the economic slump amid a looming recession in 2020. The budget, which will likely tap into the city's fiscal reserve of HK$1.12 trillion, may include cash handouts and tax cuts to stimulate the economy. The government has already earmarked HK$30 billion in stimulus measures, and some economists anticipate a one-off tax reduction or a HK$10,000 cash handout to residents. The budget aims to address the city's economic downturn, which was driven by months of political unrest and the novel coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Covid-19: Three scenarios, growth and policy implications for Asia ex-Japan
summary: The COVID-19 outbreak is expected to have a sharp and temporary impact on Asia ex-Japan's growth, with the region's GDP growth forecast to be 3.7-4.1% YoY in Q1 2020 and 5.1-5.3% YoY in 2020. The impact is expected to be more pronounced in countries with high trade and travel linkages, such as Hong Kong, Singapore, and South Korea. However, once the outbreak peaks, a growth recovery is expected, driven by inventory restocking, policy easing, and the export recovery from reduced trade tensions.

site_title: Singapore shares rise on bargain hunting
summary: The Singapore Straits Times Index rose 16.04 points or 0.51% to 3,158.24 points, despite the spread of Covid-19 in South Korea and Italy. Traders are uncertain about the level of risk alert, with some stocks, like ST Engineering, advancing on bargain hunting. The conglomerate posted a 36.2% rise in Q4 net profit, and RHB Securities raised its target price to S$4.90. Banks also recovered some lost ground, with DBS Group Holdings and United Overseas Bank gaining.

site_title: Straits Trading more than doubles Q4 net to S$29.7m
summary: Straits Trading Company's net profit for Q4 2020 more than doubled to S$29.7 million, driven by its real estate segment. Revenue declined 33.1% to S$70.0 million, mainly due to a 37% fall in tin mining and smelting revenue. The group's real estate arm, Straits Real Estate, achieved outstanding financial results through acquisitions and joint ventures. Fourth-quarter earnings per share rose to 7.3 Singapore cents from 3.5 cents.

site_title: Luxury condo units in former Waldorf hotel to debut in Manhattan market glut
summary: The former Waldorf Astoria hotel in Manhattan is set to debut as a condominium, offering luxury units with historic charm. The 1,400-room hotel was purchased by China's Anbang Insurance Group in 2015 for $1.95 billion, with plans to convert a portion into for-sale apartments. However, the market has become saturated with luxury homes, and the developer, Dajia Insurance Group, is pouring $1 billion into renovations to recoup its investment. Units will not be ready until 2022, but the developer hopes to capitalize on nostalgia and the allure of owning a piece of history.

site_title: Park Hotel bags S$237m green loan from UOB
summary: Park Hotel Group secured a S$237 million green loan from UOB to refinance the refurbishment of Grand Park City Hall, a hotel it owns and manages. The loan was issued under UOB's Real Estate Sustainable Finance Framework. The hotel, which retained 90% of its building structure, incorporated sustainable features such as rainwater harvesting and energy-efficient fixtures. It received Singapore's highest green building rating, Green Mark Platinum certification.

site_title: Most Asia stock benchmarks claw back Monday's losses
summary: Asian stock markets rebounded on Tuesday, driven by investors seeking bargains amid the ongoing Covid-19 outbreak. Despite a 3.3% drop in Japan's Nikkei 225, most regional markets, including Singapore, Malaysia, Hong Kong, South Korea, and Taiwan, rose. Asian markets have been pricing in the economic effects of the outbreak for weeks, unlike Western markets. Analysts expect short-term gains to be short-lived, with near-term volatility likely to persist. Investors are advised to take a long-term view, managing risks through diversification across asset classes and geographies.

site_title: Mystery behind Singapore's largest coronavirus infection cluster solved
summary: Singapore's largest coronavirus infection cluster at the Grace Assembly of God church has been solved using a new serological test. The test, developed by Duke-NUS Medical School, detected past infections in recovered patients, tracing the cluster to two Wuhan travellers who were linked to a Chinese New Year family gathering and a church event. The investigation revealed that 23 cases were infected through contact with the Wuhan couple, who then passed the infection to a colleague, who went on to infect others at the church, resulting in 23 cases.

site_title: Scheme to let China work permit holders switch jobs
summary: Singapore has introduced a temporary scheme allowing Chinese work permit holders in manufacturing and services to switch jobs without leaving the country for six months. The move aims to soften the economic impact of the Covid-19 outbreak on businesses, particularly those facing excess manpower. The Singapore Business Federation will match companies with labor needs, and the Manpower Minister, Josephine Teo, hopes this will help businesses manage the current situation and minimize labor crunches.

site_title: 3D printing and the future of shipping
summary: 3D printing is being explored to revolutionize the shipping industry, particularly in procuring and delivering spare parts. ShipParts.com, an online e-procurement portal, is participating in a project to investigate additive manufacturing's potential. The technology could bring significant savings in cost, quality, and speed, potentially transforming the industry. This development could have a profound impact on the shipping industry, similar to the transformative effect of containerization in the past.

site_title: Use downtime to transform: DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat urged firms to use the downtime from the Covid-19 outbreak to transform and make the most of government support measures. He praised a hotel for accelerating transformation through measures such as electronic check-in forms and staff retraining. Heng emphasized that while firms should stabilize operations in the short term, they should also look at long-term moves to increase productivity and redesign processes. He hopes more companies will take advantage of the Stabilisation and Support Package and government transformation support.

site_title: George Quek leads offer to privatise BreadTalk; group in the red for Q4 and FY19
summary: BreadTalk Group has received a voluntary conditional cash offer from BTG Holding Company, a special purpose vehicle owned by founder and chairman George Quek, to privatize the food and beverage player at S$0.77 per share, representing a 19.4% premium. The offer is conditional on valid acceptances resulting in the offeror holding more than 90% of shares. The group reported a net loss of S$8.1 million for the Q4 and FY19, with revenue rising 10.1% to S$170.4 million. BreadTalk is also in technical breach of its S$100 million notes due in 2023.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Reducing the use of fossil fuels in the shipping industry
summary: Claressa Monteiro discusses reducing fossil fuel burning in shipping with Simon Bennett, general manager of sustainable development at The China Navigation Company. The company aims to encourage industry players to adopt cleaner practices. Monteiro highlights the need for the shipping industry to transition away from fossil fuels, citing its significant impact on the environment. Bennett emphasizes the importance of cooperation and innovation in achieving this goal. The conversation focuses on The China Navigation Company's efforts and potential solutions for the industry to reduce its carbon footprint.

site_title: Will Dan Loeb turn Prudential into an AIA?
summary: Billionaire investor Daniel Loeb is pushing for Prudential Plc to separate its Asian and US operations into two public listed companies, potentially listing PruAsia in Singapore or Hong Kong. Loeb's asset management firm Third Point LLC holds a nearly 5% stake in Prudential and has sent a letter to the board outlining plans to create value for shareholders by restructuring the group. Loeb believes the separation would solve problems such as prioritizing dividends over growth and lack of experience in Asia at the top ranks. If successful, Prudential's Asian business could trade like AIA Group, with Loeb estimating PruAsia could be worth around £24 per share.

site_title: SIA freezes ground staff hiring; eyes voluntary no-pay leave
summary: Singapore Airlines has introduced a hiring freeze for ground staff and is considering asking staff to voluntarily take no-pay leave due to the novel coronavirus outbreak. The airline has suspended over 3,000 flights from February to May, citing weak demand. With an excess of 500 cabin crew members and 50 pilots, SIA is taking cost-cutting measures to conserve cash and reduce costs. The airline's CEO, Goh Choon Phong, has stated that the group will not compromise its long-term competitiveness while implementing these measures.

site_title: Oei Hong Leong loses suit against Raffles Education's Chew Hua Seng
summary: The High Court in Singapore has dismissed a lawsuit by tycoon Oei Hong Leong against Raffles Education chairman Chew Hua Seng, who allegedly promised to procure a buyer for Oei Hong Leong's shares in the education provider. The court ruled that the agreement, which lasted less than two minutes, was not meant to be legally binding. Justice Lee Seiu Kin found that the discussion was not intended to create a legally enforceable contract, contrary to the plaintiffs' claims. The judgment was issued on Monday.

site_title: Vietnam is investors' favourite for growth prospects
summary: Vietnam's stocks are seen as a turnaround opportunity due to low valuations and a growing economy. The nation's benchmark gauge trades at 12 times estimated earnings, a level not seen since 2017. Vietnam has consistently grown 5% or more per year for two decades, making it a favorite among investors. Analysts expect a recovery in the market, driven by the country's strong growth prospects.

site_title: Trump says US stock market will crash if he loses election
summary: US President Donald Trump warned that the US stock market will crash if he loses the election, stating that stocks will jump higher if he is re-elected. He also announced plans for tax cuts for the middle class and touted progress on a proposed trade deal with India, citing a $3 billion defense deal and a strengthened "Quad" alliance with India, Japan, and Australia.

site_title: Apple reopens stores in China in bid to recover from virus
summary: Apple is reopening more than half of its retail stores in China, with 29 of 42 stores opening on shortened hours, in an effort to recover from sales hit tied to the coronavirus. The company's retail footprint in China is critical to its sales, and the store closures were a major factor in Apple's decision not to meet its revenue target of $63 billion for the current quarter. The pace of recovery is uncertain, with UBS analyst Timothy Arcuri predicting that February numbers will be far worse due to supply and demand issues related to the virus outbreak.

site_title: UK startup Graphcore hits US$1.95b valuation
summary: Graphcore, a UK semiconductor firm, has raised $150 million, valuing it at $1.95 billion. The company will use the funds to invest in research and development, expand globally, and support large customers. Graphcore has added engineers, expanded operations in Asia and the US, and built out a team in Oslo to create large-scale AI systems. The current round includes investors like Baillie Gifford and Mayfair Equity Partners, with Microsoft, BMW, and Samsung previously backing the firm.

site_title: US dollar pressured by expectations of Fed rate cut
summary: The US dollar weakened to 99.29 against a basket of currencies as expectations grew that the Federal Reserve would cut interest rates to relieve pressure on the economy caused by the Covid-19 outbreak. Despite rising to a three-year high last week, the dollar is expected to hold steady without good news on the virus. The Fed's potential dovish shift in policy has led money managers to price in a 25-basis-point cut for the June meeting, with traders expecting a rate cut to between 1% and 1.25% for the year.

site_title: Give FCOT shareholders fair shake in merger plan
summary: A Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) shareholder expresses concerns over the proposed merger with Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT), citing unfair treatment of FCOT shareholders compared to those of FP. FCOT has a right of first refusal to FP's 50% stake in Farnborough Business Park (FBP), but under the merger, FLT will issue new shares at a 31% premium to NAV, whereas FP's deal for FBP is valued using NAV methodology. The shareholder argues that FCOT shareholders should be treated fairly and have their stake valued similarly.

site_title: Covid-19: Singapore bars visitors from Daegu, Cheongdo
summary: Singapore is banning visitors with travel history to Daegu and Cheongdo in South Korea within the last 14 days, effective Feb 26, due to a breakthrough in linking existing Covid-19 clusters through serological testing. Returning residents and long-term pass holders with a travel history to the affected areas will be issued a 14-day Stay-Home Notice. This move comes as authorities linked a recent cluster to two existing clusters through serological testing, establishing a clear link to Wuhan travellers.

site_title: Aspial profit slides 55.2% on weaker real estate business
summary: Aspial Corporation posted a 55.2% drop in net profit to S$12.7 million for the year ended Dec 31, mainly due to weaker performance from its real estate business. Revenue fell 37.6% to S$560.2 million, with the real estate business contributing S$210.9 million, down from S$363.3 million previously. The group expects to receive A$357 million from the settlement and handover of units for its Australia 108 project in the next 12 months, contributing positively to revenue and profitability.

site_title: Covid-19 outbreak: Is it a pandemic yet?
summary: The COVID-19 outbreak is spreading rapidly, with cases reported in at least 29 countries, and is considered a pandemic despite the World Health Organization's (WHO) uncertainty. The virus spreads like influenza, through the air, and can be transmitted before symptoms appear. Vaccines are months away, and a lockdown may only delay the spread. Hospitals may become overwhelmed, and healthcare workers are at risk of infection. Governments should focus on supporting healthcare systems, conducting preparedness drills, and ensuring the distribution of critical products remains open. Transparency and public awareness are crucial for mitigating the pandemic's impact.

site_title: Face masks are Paris fashion week must-haves
summary: Paris Fashion Week has seen face masks become a must-have accessory, with two Chinese brands missing from the runway due to the novel coronavirus epidemic. The trend is a response to the ongoing crisis, which has sent shares of many fashion conglomerates plummeting. Fashionistas are torn between wearing a mask or not, but the face mask has become a staple accessory in Parisian fashion.

site_title: US consumer confidence nudges up in Feb
summary: US consumer confidence edged up to 130.7 in February, indicating steady consumer spending despite growing coronavirus fears. This is a slight departure from economists' forecasts of a 132.0 reading. The present situation measure fell to 165.1, while the expectations index rose to its highest level since January. The report contrasts with a recent IHS Markit survey showing the US manufacturing and services sectors contracted to a 76-month low due to the coronavirus outbreak. The steady consumer confidence suggests support for the economy despite the growing concerns.

site_title: Natural Cool ex-MD charged with share price manipulation
summary: Singapore's former Natural Cool managing director and chief corporate officer Wong Leon Keat has been charged with 19 offences, including share price manipulation, for allegedly creating a false appearance of Gaylin Holdings' (now Amos Group) share price between 2015 and 2016. Wong placed buy orders and purchased shares at higher prices, and failed to disclose his 50% stake in Gaylin to UOB Kay Hian. He faces up to 7 years in jail and a fine of up to S$250,000. Wong's case has been adjourned to March 24 and he has been granted bail of S$80,000.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: IReit Global Group's CEO Aymeric Thibord has resigned, leaving to pursue other career opportunities. He was appointed in 2016 and will serve his notice period until May 10. The company's board is searching for a new CEO. Sakae Holdings reported a significant decrease in fair value of equity investments due to partial returns. Darco Water Technologies warned of adverse revenue impact from the Covid-19 outbreak, and Dyna-Mac Holdings secured an in-principle award of fabrication contracts worth S$18 million.

site_title: China decouples from the West amid virus outbreak
summary: China is entering a "pre-decoupling stage" from the West amid the Covid-19 outbreak, with trade and economic figures expected to worsen due to the crisis. The country's gradual opening to the outside world has made it more fragile and vulnerable to external factors, testing its governance and economic resilience. China's top companies are suffering from a US-imposed ban on high-technology components and software, and the country needs to know how to survive in the event of extreme economic decoupling. If China passes the decoupling stress test, it may level up in governance and seize the initiative for future trade talks and competition with the US, but a stumble could leave it disadvantaged in the global economic arena.

site_title: JTC launches two industrial sites
summary: JTC launched two industrial sites in Singapore under the industrial government land sales (IGLS) programme. One site, Jalan Papan, is available for tender and spans 1.23 hectares, while the other, 160 Gul Circle, is available for application and has an area of 0.37 hectares. Both sites have a tenure of 20 years and a gross plot ratio of 1.4, zoned for heavy industrial use. The tender for Jalan Papan will close on April 21, while the application for 160 Gul Circle is open.

site_title: Prudential Singapore gives out 200 Care Kits to taxi and private hire drivers
summary: Prudential Singapore distributed 200 Care Kits containing surgical masks, hand sanitiser, and vitamin C to taxi and private hire drivers in Marina One, showing appreciation for their service during the coronavirus outbreak. The kits are part of the company's S$1.5 million PRUcare package, which includes relief measures such as deferring premium payments for SMEs and providing a one-time S$500 cash benefit for those served with quarantine orders. The move aims to support the community and help SMEs and individuals affected by the pandemic.

site_title: United Hampshire US Reit prepares to list on SGX
summary: United Hampshire US Reit, a US-focused Singapore Reit, has lodged a preliminary prospectus to list on the Singapore Exchange. The Reit has a portfolio of 22 properties with 95.2% occupancy, including grocery and necessity-based retail and self-storage properties. Key tenants include Walmart, Home Depot, and Lowe's Companies. The portfolio has a long-weighted average lease expiry of 8.4 years, providing a "balance of defensive attributes". Projected distributable income for the Reit is US$24.5 million in 2020 and US$30.5 million in 2021.

site_title: Virus outbreak can be impetus for companies to improve, diversify
summary: A Covid-19 outbreak can serve as an opportunity for companies to improve and diversify, according to a Singaporean proverb. As the outbreak disrupts supply chains, companies should adapt their offerings to reach customers, particularly in industries like healthcare, online entertainment, and goods delivery. Some companies are analyzing and reconfiguring their supply chains for agility and resiliency. The crisis also highlights the need for staff training and development, technology diversification, and long-term planning, enabling companies to stay resilient and competitive in the future.

site_title: US: Stocks open higher, stabilising after Monday's rout
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday, stabilizing after Monday's rout. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.3% to 28,032.20, while the S&P 500 added 0.2% to 3,232.56, and the Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.4% to 9,258.28. Analysts attributed the gains to bargain-hunting despite concerns over the coronavirus outbreak. The market will consider a report on US consumer confidence later Tuesday.

site_title: Selected brokerage fees to be waived for FLT odd lots following merger
summary: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT) has waived brokerage fees for odd lots of units following its merger with Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT). The waiver applies to trades of 99 units or fewer in a single day within a month of allotment and issuance. This arrangement aims to facilitate trading of odd lots, allowing unitholders to round up or down their holdings to multiples of 100 units. Clearing fees and regular trading fees remain applicable. The waiver is offered by DBS Vickers Securities, OCBC Securities, and Phillip Securities.

site_title: No let-up in push to reduce foreign labour dependency even in trying times
summary: Singapore's Budget 2020 did not include measures to loosen foreign worker policy, despite the Covid-19 outbreak. Instead, the government announced a two-phase reduction in foreign worker levies for the construction, marine shipyard, and process sectors. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat stated that the government aims to reduce foreign labor dependency through developing the local workforce and implementing productivity-boosting measures, rather than loosening policy. This decision reflects the government's long-running push to achieve economic health through reducing labor dependence.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 10.82 points to 1,500.88 on Tuesday, driven by gains. Volume reached 3.1 billion lots worth RM2.8 billion, with 531 gainers outnumbering 380 losers.

site_title: Bosses should be fair during virus crisis, people should go back to spending: Josephine Teo
summary: MANPOWER Minister Josephine Teo has urged employers to be fair and transparent with workers during the COVID-19 crisis, emphasizing the need for companies to discuss plans with unions. The government has rolled out a S$4 billion Stabilisation and Support Package to protect jobs, with a focus on boosting confidence among workers. Teo also noted that cash flow issues are a priority, and the government will continue to monitor the situation.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: BreadTalk, a Singaporean bakery chain, reported a Q4 net loss and breached financial covenants, prompting a S$0.77-per-share offer in a privatization bid. Gojek denied reports of merger talks with Grab. The Singapore High Court dismissed a lawsuit against Raffles Education chairman Chew Hua Seng. SIA froze hiring for ground staff amid an excess manpower situation, while HDB issued S$700m notes. Singapore shares rose 0.5% on the Straits Times Index.

site_title: Life3 Biotech plans to set up agri-food production pilot facility
summary: Life3 Biotech, a Singapore-based food tech startup, plans to establish the country's first integrated agri-food pilot facility at Paya Lebar. The 50,000 sq ft facility will produce 1,200 to 1,800 tonnes of plant-based alternative protein source, Veego, annually. The pilot facility aims to start production in a few months and will be used for research, offices, and an in-house farm. The facility's launch is in line with Singapore's goal of producing 30% of its food locally by 2030, promoting sustainable food sources and job opportunities for locals.

site_title: Temasek's Fullerton weighs Indian shadow bank stake sale
summary: Fullerton Financial Holdings, a subsidiary of Singapore's Temasek Holdings, is considering selling a stake in Fullerton India Credit, a shadow bank in India. The partial divestment aims to raise approximately US$350 million. Fullerton India, which has nearly 650 branches and 14,000 employees, posted a 4.4 billion rupees (S$85.6 million) after-tax profit in the first half of 2020, a 29% increase from the previous year. A final decision on the sale has not been made, and the company could still decide against the transaction.

site_title: Singapore bans short-term travellers from Daegu, Cheongdo
summary: Singapore has banned all new visitors with recent travel history to Daegu and Cheongdo in South Korea within the last 14 days, starting from Feb 26. The ban follows a breakthrough in serological testing that linked existing coronavirus clusters in Singapore to cases in these cities. The testing, which detects virus-specific antibodies, was used to identify two suspect cases and help authorities connect clusters. The restriction is similar to one already in place for short-term travellers from China, and returning residents and long-term pass holders will be placed on Stay-Home Notice.

site_title: Malaysia's opposition parties call for elections
summary: Malaysia's opposition parties have called for elections, rejecting a proposed unity government under interim Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad. The parties, including the United Malays National Organisation, PKR, and others, say they will not support a unity government and instead want parliament to be dissolved, allowing the people to decide. Meanwhile, Malaysia's king plans to meet with all parliament members to determine the next prime minister, following the constitution's rule that a majority in Parliament can claim the position.

images.alt_text: Dr Mahathir is trying to form a national unity government under his personal authority, drawing together rival parties, political sources said on Tuesday, following his shock resignation as prime minister.

site_title: Egypt's former president Hosni Mubarak dies aged 91
summary: Egypt's former president Hosni Mubarak has died at 91 after undergoing treatment following surgery. Mubarak ruled Egypt for 30 years until his ouster in 2011. He was initially sentenced to life in prison for ordering protester deaths, but was acquitted in 2017. Mubarak was also convicted of diverting public funds, but was released after serving three years. His death comes as many Egyptians view his rule as autocratic and crony capitalist, leading to Egypt's first free election and subsequent political upheaval.

images.alt_text: Former Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak has died at the age of 91 after undergoing treatment in an intensive care unit following surgery, state television said on Tuesday.

site_title: Straits Trading Q4 net profit more than doubles to S$29.7m
summary: Straits Trading's Q4 net profit more than doubled to S$29.7 million, driven by its real estate segment. The group continues to exercise prudence amid the growing scale of Covid-19, with its hospitality and resources arms expected to face challenges. Straits Trading's real estate arm presents attractive investment opportunities in the Asia-Pacific region. The company has proposed an interim dividend of six Singapore cents per share and expects to benefit from its associate ARA Asset Management's growth in global fund management business.

site_title: Coronavirus increases Iran's isolation, strains South Korea and Italy
summary: Iran's coronavirus death toll rose to 16, surpassing the global average, as the country's isolation deepened amid mounting international concern. The virus has infected 80,000 people and killed 2,663 in China, with outbreaks reported in Iran, Italy, and South Korea. Global stocks plummeted, and several countries suspended flights and closed borders due to cases linked to Iran. The World Health Organisation warns of a "pandemic" but notes the epidemic has peaked in China.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended a three-day losing streak with a 0.3% gain, closing at 26,893.23. Investors remain cautious due to coronavirus fears. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.6%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.5%. Despite the gains, investors remain on edge, with the benchmark Shanghai Composite Index shedding 0.6% to 3,013.05.

site_title: Sakae says HY2020 fair-value dive due to partial returns of equity investments
summary: Sakae Holdings reported a significant decrease in fair value of its equity investments in the half-year ended Dec 31, 2019, due to partial returns of equity investments. The company's equity investments at fair value through profit or loss decreased from S$10.5 million to S$2.3 million. The returns related to the partial return of capital from investments in Griffin Real Estate Investment Holdings and Gryphon Capital Management resulted in a net return of S$8.1 million. This led to the reduction of the group's equity investment fair value, offsetting about S$6.8 million of the returns.

site_title: China Taiping Insurance offers Covid-19 coverage for new, existing customers
summary: China Taiping Insurance has launched two new initiatives in Singapore to offer additional coverage for Covid-19 outbreak, including a Financial Aid Campaign and an enhanced Personal Accident plan. New and existing customers will receive a S$1,000 payout upon recovery, daily hospitalisation benefit, and an additional death benefit payout.

site_title: United Hampshire US Reit lodges preliminary prospectus
summary: United Hampshire US Reit has lodged a preliminary prospectus to list a US-focused Singapore Reit on the Singapore Exchange. The Reit has a portfolio of 22 US properties with an occupancy of 95.2% and a long weighted average lease expiry of 8.4 years. Key tenants include Walmart and Home Depot. The initial portfolio has an aggregate net lettable area of 3.17 million square feet and an appraised value of US$599.2 million. Projected distributable income for 2020 and 2021 is US$24.5 million and US$30.5 million, respectively.

site_title: Darco Water Technologies flags revenue impact from Covid-19 outbreak
summary: Darco Water Technologies announced that its revenue for the current financial year ending Dec 31, 2020, will be significantly impacted by the Covid-19 outbreak, mainly due to control measures in Wuhan preventing operations from resuming. The company's Wuhan-based subsidiary, Wuhan Kaidi Water Services, has been unable to return to work since the Lunar New Year, with personnel expected to resume work on March 11 at the earliest. This is expected to result in significant adverse impact on the company's results for the current financial year.

site_title: Dubai airport suspends flights with Iran, except for Teheran
summary: Dubai International Airport has suspended all flights to and from Iran, except for Teheran, following the death of two more Iranians infected with the new coronavirus, bringing the total deaths to 14. Bahrain also suspended all Dubai flights until further notice.

site_title: Dyna-Mac Holdings secures in-principle contracts worth S$18m
summary: Dyna-Mac Holdings secured in-principle contracts worth approximately S$18 million for fabrication of topside modules, pipe racks, and skids for a Floating Production Storage Offloading vessel. The contracts are from repeat and new customers and are expected to commence in Q1 2020, with completion by Q1 2021. The order is expected to positively impact earnings per share and net tangible assets for the current financial year ending Dec 31, 2020.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets stage modest rebound at open
summary: European stock markets rebounded modestly at the open on Tuesday, following a day of sharp declines due to coronavirus fears. The FTSE 100 index rose 0.5%, while the DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices gained 0.6%. Monday's losses were significant, with Frankfurt and Paris stocks falling 4% and 3.9%, respectively. The Dow suffered its worst day in two years amid growing concerns about the economic impact of the coronavirus.

site_title: Iraq bans entry of travellers from 7 countries, including Singapore
summary: Iraq has indefinitely banned entry to travellers from China, Iran, Thailand, South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Singapore due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Iraqi nationals, diplomats, and official delegations are exempt. Schools and universities in Najaf, where the first reported case occurred, are suspended for 10 days, and citizens are advised to avoid travel to the province.

site_title: Keen to maintain standards, egg tart institution Tong Heng is reluctant to expand
summary: Tong Heng, Singapore's oldest pastry shop, is hesitant to expand despite its success. The fourth-generation owner, Ana Fong, plans to maintain standards and has ruled out franchising and overseas expansion for the next couple of years. Fong values hands-on approach and quality over quantity, ensuring the business remains accessible to customers. She believes the current one-store model is sufficient, and her focus is on maintaining the brand's reputation and quality, rather than pursuing aggressive growth.

site_title: New genomic tests aim to diagnose deadly infections faster
summary: New genomic tests can diagnose deadly infections faster by rapidly sorting through a patient's DNA to identify the pathogen causing the illness. These tests can produce results in hours, a contrast to traditional methods that can take days or weeks. The tests have the potential to revolutionize the way doctors diagnose and treat infections, particularly during outbreaks like the coronavirus epidemic. However, widespread adoption is hindered by high costs, false negatives, and low sensitivity, as well as regulatory hurdles. The technology has the potential to save lives and combat antibiotic resistance, but further development and funding are needed.

site_title: Malaysian king to meet all lawmakers to decide the next PM
summary: Malaysia's 94-year-old premier Mahathir Mohamad unexpectedly resigned, sparking a political crisis. The king will meet all 222 lawmakers to decide the next prime minister, following the country's constitution. The king will hold individual interviews to assess who can command a majority in Parliament. The move comes at a bad time for the Malaysian economy, which has seen growth fall to a decade low, and was set to announce a stimulus package to deal with the coronavirus outbreak. The king will make the decision, with Mahathir serving as interim prime minister until then.

site_title: K-pop sensation BTS's label picks JPMorgan, others for IPO: reports
summary: Big Hit Entertainment, the label behind K-pop sensation BTS, has chosen JPMorgan and other firms to handle its initial public offering (IPO), with an expected valuation of up to $6.99 billion. The IPO could be one of the largest in the country's entertainment industry. BTS has achieved significant global success, with hits and sold-out US stadium tours. Analysts say the timing is right for the IPO, but some are skeptical about the lofty valuation, citing the band members' impending military service.

site_title: Apple reopens more than half of its retail stores in China
summary: Apple has reopened more than half of its retail stores in China, with 29 of 42 locations now open, following a sales hit due to the coronavirus. Most stores are operating on shortened hours, with some open for fewer than 8 hours. The company's retail footprint in China is crucial to its sales, and store closures were one of the reasons Apple missed its revenue target. Apple's CEO, Tim Cook, had previously stated that retail locations in China were "starting to reopen, but we are experiencing a slower return to normal conditions than we had anticipated."

site_title: Chinese work permit holders in manufacturing, services can switch bosses to ease virus-related labour crunch
summary: Singapore has introduced a temporary initiative allowing Chinese work permit holders in manufacturing and services to switch jobs without leaving the country, amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The measure aims to ease a labor crunch, with the agreement of both the worker and their employer. This expansion builds on a similar policy for construction, process, and marine sectors, and is seen as a practical solution to help businesses manage the current situation.

site_title: British startup Graphcore hits US$2b valuation
summary: Graphcore Ltd, a British semiconductor firm, has raised $150 million, increasing its valuation to $1.95 billion. The company will use the funds to invest in research and development and global expansion. Its chips are designed for artificial intelligence programs, which require more memory and processing power. Graphcore has partnered with Microsoft, Citadel, and other investors, and is expanding its operations in Asia and the US. The company plans to support large customers and build out a team in Oslo to create large-scale systems connecting thousands of processors.

site_title: Grab raises US$850m to expand into financial services
summary: Grab, Southeast Asia's most valuable startup, has raised US$850 million from Japan's Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group and TIS to expand into financial services. The investments, worth US$706 million and US$150 million respectively, will enable Grab to co-develop financial products and solutions with its new investors. The deal marks Grab's effort to become a one-stop shop for on-demand services in the region, and demonstrates the confidence of its investors in the company's super-app strategy.

site_title: Torrential rains flood Jakarta
summary: Torrential rains flooded dozens of Jakarta neighborhoods, inundating at least 81 areas and shutting down a dozen toll roads and commuter train lines. Floodwaters reached 127cm in some districts, with no immediate reports of casualties. This is the second major flooding in Jakarta in less than two months, following an event that killed nearly 70 people in January. The city is prone to flooding during the wet season, which starts in November.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks, won rise as investors bet on policy support
summary: South Korean stocks rose 1% on Tuesday, with the Kospi index closing at 2,103.61, driven by hopes for policy support amid the coronavirus outbreak. The country reported 130 new infections, but the spread slowed compared to the previous day. The won and benchmark bond yield also gained.

site_title: China's economy seen growing slowest since 1990 due to virus
summary: China's economy is expected to grow at its slowest pace since 1990 due to the coronavirus outbreak. The median forecast for the first quarter is 4% growth, down from 5.9% previously, with some analysts predicting as low as 2.5% growth. Full-year economic growth is forecast at 5.5%, down from 5.9% last month. The slowdown raises pressure on policymakers, with some cutting their forecasts for the first quarter and full year.

site_title: Singapore shares rise 0.5% on Tuesday as bargain hunters move in
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 16.04 points, or 0.51%, to 3,158.24 on Tuesday, driven by bargain hunting amid the Covid-19 outbreak. Advancers outnumbered decliners 237 to 197. ST Engineering advanced 5.24% to S$4.42 on a cum-dividend basis, while banking stocks closed in the green. Analysts expect FY20 revenues of banks to be impacted by Covid-19, but dividend yields may provide support.

site_title: Virus delivers blow to Hong Kong protests but rage remains
summary: Hong Kong's pro-democracy protests have been temporarily halted by the new coronavirus, but experts predict the unrest will reignite once the epidemic fades. The protests, which lasted for seven months, were fueled by a lack of democracy, erosion of freedoms, and entrenched inequality. The government's response to the virus has been criticized, with approval ratings at historic lows. Pro-democracy supporters are now exploring alternative tactics, including industrial action, and many believe the protests will continue in June to mark the one-year anniversary of the movement.

site_title: For Hilary Mantel, there's no time like the past
summary: Hilary Mantel, renowned author of the Thomas Cromwell trilogy, has completed her final book in the series, "The Mirror and the Light." The nearly 800-page novel concludes the story of Cromwell's rise and fall, after which Mantel plans to focus on writing plays. She has expressed her desire to move away from historical fiction due to the grueling research process and the stamina required. Mantel's work on the play adaptation of "The Mirror and the Light" has kept Cromwell's character vivid in her imagination, with her describing him as "more real and solid" than actual people.

site_title: Gold retreats from 7-year high, but virus fears limit losses
summary: Gold prices fell 0.7% to $1,648.36 per ounce, retreating from a seven-year high, amid concerns over the global spread of the coronavirus. Investors booked profits from the previous day's surge, while equities regained footing. However, a spike in coronavirus cases and increasing concerns about its global impact limited losses. Analysts predict gold may benefit from potential interest rate cuts by central banks and a rising US dollar is unlikely to hold back the metal's rally.

site_title: Australia: Shares extend losses as virus fears linger; NZ down
summary: Australian shares extended losses, falling 1.6% to 6,866.70, amid concerns over the coronavirus outbreak's impact on global economic growth. Prime Minister Scott Morrison warned of potential budget deficits due to the economic impact. The S&P/NZX 50 index in New Zealand also declined 1.2%. Global market sentiment was also influenced by the spread of the virus in several countries, including Kuwait, Bahrain, Oman, Afghanistan, and Iraq.

site_title: ABB Robotics targets e-commerce giants amid automotive slowdown
summary: ABB Ltd is partnering with Silicon Valley startup Covariant to develop warehouse robotics for e-commerce companies like Amazon and Alibaba. The move aims to address a gap in the order picking process and diversify ABB's revenue streams beyond the automotive industry, which has been impacted by a slowdown. The partnership is the latest step in ABB's expansion into e-commerce logistics, with the first solution currently being deployed at Bpost Group's Active Ants. This diversification effort is intended to help ABB stand on "multiple legs" and maintain steady revenue growth in 2020.

site_title: Record stash of steel in China as demand takes hit
summary: China's steel sector, accounting for over half of global production, is struggling due to the coronavirus outbreak. Nationwide stockpiles of reinforcement bar have reached a record high of 10.8 million tonnes, a 14% surge from last week. Demand has declined due to construction projects being put on hold, and steel inventories are expected to increase significantly more than normal. Mills are cutting output, but there are limits to how much they can cut without shutting down furnaces, adding downward pressure on iron ore prices.

site_title: SIA freezes hiring for ground staff, mulls other measures in response to outbreak
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has frozen hiring for ground staff amid the novel coronavirus outbreak, citing an excess manpower situation of over 500 cabin crew members and 50 pilots. The airline has also suspended non-essential duty travel and temporarily suspended over 3,000 flights from February to May. SIA has taken cost-cutting measures, including deferring capital expenditure and tightening discretionary operating expenditure. The airline is also exploring voluntary no-pay leave options for staff.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares fall more than 3.3% at Tuesday's close on virus fears
summary: Tokyo shares plummeted 3.3% on Tuesday, tracking global market declines due to fears over the new coronavirus outbreak. The Nikkei 225 index fell 781.33 points to 22,605.41, while the Topix index dropped 55.74 points to 1,618.26. Major Japanese shares, including Sony, Panasonic, Toyota, Honda, and Nissan, also declined sharply. Investors are concerned about the virus's impact on Japan's economy, which is closely tied to China. The market will continue to watch for US share movements.

site_title: Park Hotel obtains S$237m green loan from UOB
summary: Park Hotel Group has secured a S$237 million green loan from United Overseas Bank (UOB) to refinance the refurbishment of Grand Park City Hall, a hotel owned and managed by the group. The loan was issued under UOB's Real Estate Sustainable Finance Framework and aims to support the hotel's sustainable features, including a rainwater harvesting system and energy-efficient fixtures. Grand Park City Hall received the Singapore Building and Construction Authority's Green Mark Platinum certification, the highest distinction in the green building rating system.

site_title: Singapore's Bangladeshi workers have eyes on home as virus shakes community
summary: Singapore's Bangladeshi migrant workers are being influenced to return home due to the novel coronavirus outbreak, with some choosing to leave despite financial constraints. Many have already departed, citing concerns for their families' safety, and some have been infected in other countries. The Bangladeshi community in Singapore is taking precautions, with the high commission distributing masks and sanitiser, but some workers are choosing to return to Bangladesh, where there have been no reported cases of the virus.

site_title: Hammerson cuts 2020 dividend as store closures hit net rental income
summary: British shopping centre operator Hammerson slashed its 2020 dividend by 46% due to a 11.2% drop in annual net rental income, primarily caused by the collapse of UK retail chains and outlets. The company reported 308.5 million pounds in net rental income for the year ended Dec 31, down from 349.2 million pounds in 2019. Hammerson aims to reduce its net debt by selling assets and refocusing on its core divisions.

site_title: No Opec decision yet on oil cuts: Saudi energy minister
summary: Saudi Arabia's Energy Minister Abdulaziz bin Salman stated that Opec has not made a decision yet on extending or modifying its agreement to cut oil output. The organization is set to meet next week in Vienna to reassess its global cuts and output policy. Global oil demand is expected to drop this quarter due to the coronavirus outbreak, creating a significant supply surplus. Russia has not confirmed its support for a proposal for deeper production cuts of 600,000 barrels a day.

site_title: South Korea to launch mass coronavirus testing
summary: South Korea plans to conduct mass coronavirus testing on over 200,000 members of the Shincheonji Church of Jesus, where the outbreak is believed to have originated. The church has agreed to provide authorities with the names of its members. South Korea has reported its ninth death and 60 new cases, for a total of 893. The country is taking measures to contain the spread of the virus and relieve public anxiety. The outbreak has spread to about 29 countries and territories outside mainland China, with a death toll of about three dozen.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS downgrades Keppel DC Reit to 'hold'
summary: DBS Group Research downgraded Keppel DC Reit to "hold" due to investors pricing in too much growth, but raised its price target to S$2.55 from S$2.40, citing the Reit's historical track record of delivering acquisitions. Analysts expect Keppel DC Reit to deliver accretive acquisitions, but face challenges from competition and lack of pipeline from sponsor Keppel Corp. The Reit's forward yield is 3.3%, and it may need to deliver S$800-1,000m in acquisitions to surprise and re-rate further.

site_title: China aviation regulator says flights outside of Hubei to resume gradually
summary: China's aviation regulator, the Civil Aviation Administration of China, has announced that flights outside of Hubei province, the epicentre of the coronavirus outbreak, will resume gradually as factories and businesses reopen. However, flights to and from Hubei will remain suspended. The regulator is urging global aviation authorities to resume international flights to China to maintain connectivity. The industry is advised to remain vigilant about the spread of the virus outside of China and take measures to prevent its spread back into the country from international communities.

site_title: JTC launches two industrial sites
summary: JTC launched two industrial sites under the industrial government land sales (IGLS) programme. The first site, Jalan Papan (Plot 1), is available for tender with a 1.23-hectare area and a 20-year tenure. The second site, 160 Gul Circle, is available for application with a 0.37-hectare area and a 20-year tenure. Both sites are zoned "B2" for heavy industrial use and have a gross plot ratio of 1.4.

site_title: Japan urges telecommuting, staggered shifts to curb coronavirus
summary: Japan urges companies to recommend telecommuting and staggered shifts for workers to curb the spread of the new coronavirus, with 159 cases of infections reported. The government also advised people with symptoms to stay home and asked event organizers to reconsider their plans. The aim is to slow the disease's expansion and minimize deaths, rather than trying to contain it outright. The country has seen confirmed infections in various regions, including Hokkaido and Tokyo, and the health minister convened a panel of medical experts to decide on measures to rein in the disease.

site_title: Freeport CEO says 'everybody is on edge' with virus uncertainty
summary: Freeport-McMoRan CEO Richard Adkerson said the coronavirus has significantly impacted copper demand, causing a 7% drop in the metal's value this year.
