The uncertainty around the virus has led to a buildup of exchange stockpiles and potential shutdowns in industries in China, which could slow mine development and deepen a production deficit. Adkerson also stated that now is not the time for large-scale mergers and acquisitions, and that Freeport is focused on its current portfolio.

site_title: HDB issues S$700m notes due in 2027
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) issued S$700 million worth of seven-year notes with a fixed coupon rate of 1.76% per annum, rated Aaa by Moody's Investors Service. The notes mature on February 24, 2027, and were offered through placement to investors. This is part of HDB's S$32 billion multicurrency medium-term note programme to finance development programmes and working capital requirements.

site_title: Travel giant Expedia to cut 3,000 jobs: report
summary: Expedia, a leading online travel giant, plans to cut 3,000 jobs worldwide due to a "disappointing" 2019 performance. The company aims to simplify its business and achieve savings of $300-500 million in 2020. Despite an 8% sales increase in 2019, net profit and earnings per share declined in the last quarter. Expedia's chairman, Barry Diller, described the company as "bloated" and said many employees lacked clear roles. The job cuts represent about 12% of the workforce, with the decision made after determining the company had been pursuing growth in an "unhealthy and undisciplined way."

site_title: Top Ibuprofen maker rallies as China lockdown disrupts supply
summary: IOL Chemicals and Pharmaceuticals Ltd, the world's largest ibuprofen producer, is expected to benefit from China's prolonged shutdown of Hubei province, boosting prices of the non-prescription painkiller. The company's revenue is estimated to rise 25% to 21 billion rupees, with exports contributing a third. IOL's shares have risen 43% in February, their best month since October 2017, as the company supplies about a third of the world's ibuprofen requirement. The company's joint managing director, Vijay Kumar Garg, expects a supply gap and a higher price for the drug.

site_title: Malaysia's private education firm owners mull stake sale
summary: Malaysia's private education firm, SEG International Bhd, is considering a stake sale after preliminary discussions with potential advisers. Navis Capital Partners Ltd, the largest shareholder, and managing director Clement Hii have held talks with interested parties, including Chinese companies. The sale could be driven by growing demand for private education in Asia, but may be hindered by political uncertainty and the novel coronavirus outbreak. A sale could value the company at around S$255 million, with shares having dropped 2.4% in the past year. Deliberations are at an early stage with no certainty of a transaction.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon up 0.7% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 23.27 points or 0.7% to 3,165.47 as trading resumed on Tuesday, driven by bargain buying after Monday's 1.2% slide. Investors turned to the market amid uncertainty over the novel coronavirus outbreak, with traders taking a cautious approach. Volume and turnover were on track to beat 2019 averages, with local banks and a few second-line counters also advancing.

site_title: Boeing CEO faces long to-do list to collect US$7m bonus
summary: Boeing CEO Dave Calhoun is set to receive a $7 million bonus if the company successfully resolves issues with its 737 Max jetliner, Starliner spacecraft, and other programs by the end of 2023. However, if he fails to achieve these milestones, he will forfeit the payout. Calhoun's annual compensation is $10.9 million, and he also stands to receive $10 million in restricted stock over three years. The company has also revamped its board, adding directors with technical expertise in safety, engineering, and software to address concerns about Boeing's leadership and reputation.

images.alt_text: Boeing Co Chief Executive Officer Dave Calhoun stands to reap a US$7 million bonus once the planemaker finally gets the grounded 737 Max jetliner back in the air. But there's a catch, according to a company filing.

site_title: Digital bank Tonik raises US$6m in round led by Insignia, Credence
summary: Tonik Financial, a digital bank, has raised US$6 million in its first institutional round of funding led by Insignia Ventures Partners and Credence Partners. Regional family offices and angel investors also participated. The funds will be used to launch the digital bank in the Philippines, with commercial operations expected to start in the third quarter of this year.

site_title: South Korea reports 60 new coronavirus cases, total 893
summary: South Korea reported 60 new coronavirus cases, bringing the total to 893, with one additional death, according to the Korea Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Most cases are linked to the Shincheonji Church of Jesus in Daegu, with 49 new cases in the southern city and neighboring North Gyeongsang province. This marks the smallest increase in four days. The country's advanced medical system and strong culture of public accountability contribute to its reliable health statistics.

images.alt_text: South Korea reported 60 more novel coronavirus cases on Tuesday, the smallest increase for four days in the Korea Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's morning updates.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed after virus-fuelled global bloodbath
summary: Asian markets experienced a mixed day on Tuesday, with Tokyo leading losses as markets reopened after a global sell-off. The Nikkei fell 3%, while Sydney and Wellington declined 1.3% each, while Shanghai lost 0.9%. However, Hong Kong rose 0.2% and Seoul added 0.6% despite a plunge in South Korea. Bargain-buying tempered fears of a pandemic, and analysts see recent losses as a buying opportunity, looking past the virus for an improving economic outlook.

site_title: Waldorf's luxury condos to debut in Manhattan market glut
summary: The Waldorf Astoria, a Manhattan landmark, is set to re-emerge as a luxury condo building after five years of construction. China's Anbang Insurance Group Co initially bought the property for $1.95 billion in 2015, but the project has been delayed due to market fluctuations. With units expected to be ready in 2022, the developer is marketing smaller, more affordable units, including a 526-square-foot studio listed at $1.7 million. Despite a saturated luxury market, the developer believes nostalgia for the building's heritage and high-end amenities will drive sales.

site_title: Intuit to buy personal finances rival Credit Karma
summary: Intuit to acquire personal finance rival Credit Karma for $7 billion in cash and stock. The deal aims to create a digital platform to help people manage their finances and meet financial goals. Credit Karma, which has over 100 million members, will expand Intuit's services to include identity monitoring, loan shopping, and online savings accounts. The acquisition will help Intuit reach a broader audience, particularly among millennials, and enhance its financial management platform, which serves 50 million customers worldwide.

site_title: Firms should make full use of downtime due to virus outbreak to transform: Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat advises businesses to utilize downtime due to the Covid-19 outbreak to transform and grow, tapping into government support packages. He cited Parkroyal on Kitchener Road as an example of a hotel that has increased productivity through digital measures and staff retraining. Heng hopes more companies will leverage both virus relief measures and transformation packages to redesign jobs and emerge stronger during the recovery phase.

site_title: Reliance on business offices, online gaming threatens Philippine property market
summary: The Philippine economy may face challenges from a cooling property market, which could impact banks' loan portfolios. The Asean+3 Macroeconomic Research Office (AMRO) warns that financial surveillance must be tightened, particularly on large conglomerates. However, the report also notes that the reconfiguration of global supply chains presents an opportunity for growth.

site_title: Gojek denies report on merger talks with Grab
summary: Gojek denies report of merger talks with Grab, stating there are no plans for a merger and recent reports are inaccurate. The two companies' management teams have had discussions about a potential merger, but disagreements remain over control of the combined entity. Gojek does not want its operations absorbed into Grab, while Grab reportedly seeks control of the combined entity. Regulatory scrutiny may also hinder the deal, given Grab's previous anti-competition law violations.

images.alt_text: South-east Asia's two super-app titans are holding talks on a potential merger, although roadblocks remain to negotiating how control of the combined firm will be split, tech news outlet The Information reported on Tuesday.

site_title: Micro-pollution ravaging China and South Asia: study
summary: Nearly 90% of the world's most polluted cities, with deadly micro-pollution, are in China and India. The 2019 World Air Quality Report found that Bangladesh has the worst PM2.5 pollution, followed by Pakistan, Mongolia, Afghanistan, and India. China ranks 11th, with an average urban PM2.5 concentration dropping 20% in 2018 and 2019. The report highlights the significant health risks of micro-pollution, causing premature deaths and increasing life expectancy by up to six or seven years if WHO standards are met.

site_title: Norway's Equinor scraps contested plan to drill for oil in Great Australian Bight
summary: Norway's Equinor has abandoned plans to drill for oil in the Great Australian Bight, citing it as not "commercially competitive". Following peers Chevron, BP, and Karoon Energy, Equinor's decision is seen as a win for green campaigners. Australian regulators had approved the drilling plan in December, but Equinor decided to discontinue plans due to lack of profitability. Greenpeace welcomed the move, calling for the Australian government to permanently ban drilling in the Bight.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall most in over 6 months on virus concerns; New Zealand slumps
summary: Australian shares fell 2.6% to their lowest in six months due to concerns over the rapidly developing Covid-19 pandemic, which is expected to derail global economic growth. The S&P/ASX 200 index declined, with banking and energy stocks leading the decline. Similar losses were seen in New Zealand, where the benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index fell 3.2% in its worst session since 2018. Experts predict the decline may extend if the situation worsens, advising a defensive position.

site_title: Bank of Japan to act appropriately with eye on markets: senior official
summary: The Bank of Japan will take necessary steps to address market developments, including currency moves, with an eye on their impact on Japan's economy and inflation. According to Eiji Maeda, the central bank's executive director, the BOJ will scrutinize currency moves and take action as needed, regardless of whether the yen rises or falls. This approach aims to ensure the BOJ's monetary policy remains effective in supporting the Japanese economy.

site_title: Australia's Coronado warns coronavirus to hit steel demand; shares tank
summary: Coronado Global Resources Inc, an Australian coal producer, warned that the coronavirus outbreak would impact steel demand in China, curbing production in the near-term. The company expects a stimulus package to be implemented once the outbreak is contained, with steel demand expected to recover. Coronado posted lower-than-expected annual earnings, with underlying net income at US$305.5 million and a lower production outlook for 2020 due to a fatality at its Australian operations. Shares plummeted to an all-time low.

site_title: Saudi jobseekers move into Uber gear for extra cash
summary: Saudi jobseekers, struggling with high unemployment and dipping oil prices, are turning to non-traditional jobs such as driving for ride-hailing apps like Uber. Many Saudis, including 31-year-old Ibrahim Ahmed, are taking on part-time gigs to supplement their income and pay off debts. The shift towards flexible economic opportunities is seen as a cultural change in the conservative kingdom, with Uber and other companies hiring Saudi nationals, including women. The move is part of the government's efforts to wean citizens off government largesse and promote "Saudisation" in the post-oil era.

site_title: WHO warns of pandemic risk after virus peaks in China
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has warned that the new coronavirus, known as Covid-19, has peaked in China but could still grow into a pandemic. The virus has spread to over 30 countries, with more than 2,000 cases and 30 deaths reported abroad. Financial markets have reacted to the grim news, and restrictions on travelers from infected nations have been implemented. The WHO is closely monitoring the situation, and the global health community is on high alert for any further developments.

site_title: UK farm union warns against low food standards in trade deals
summary: The UK's National Farmers Union has warned that the country should not allow imports of food that fall short of its own standards in trade deals. NFU President Minette Batters said domestic production standards should be used as a benchmark, citing concerns over chemicals and animal-welfare rules. The union's comments come as the UK embarks on trade talks with other nations, including the US, which has expressed concerns over food safety rules. Trade uncertainty has weighed on UK farm sentiment, with one-year confidence at its third-lowest since 2010.

site_title: After weeks holding firm, stocks finally slide
summary: Global stock markets finally slid after weeks of calm, with indexes imploding on Monday due to concerns over the sudden surge in virus cases outside China, particularly in South Korea and northern Italy. Investor positioning and technical indicators had become stretched, priming stocks for a drawdown. This marks a reversal of the recent calm, just a week after Apple's warning about the impact of the coronavirus on sales and production.

site_title: China bans trade, consumption of wild animals due to coronavirus
summary: China's top legislature has banned the trade and consumption of wild animals, effective immediately, in an effort to combat the coronavirus outbreak. The ban comes after a growing concern over the consumption of wild animals and their potential role in spreading the disease. The decision, made in response to the deaths of almost 2,700 people in China and the global spread of the virus, will severely punish those involved in the illegal trade and consumption of wildlife.

images.alt_text: China's top legislature said it will immediately ban the trade and consumption of wild animals, in a fast-track decision it says will allow the country to win the battle against the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Japan's Nishimura says need to pay close attention on coronovirus impact
summary: Japanese Economy Minister Yasutoshi Nishimura warned that the government needs to closely monitor the impact of the coronavirus outbreak on the economy, including financial markets. He emphasized the need for economic support steps depending on the situation's urgency. Ahead of annual wage negotiations, Nishimura stressed the importance of higher wages and increased consumption to mitigate downside risks to the economy.

site_title: Natural Cool's ex-MD charged for alleged share price manipulation
summary: Former managing director Tay Peck Gek of Catalist-listed Natural Cool has been charged with 19 counts of alleged share price manipulation for creating a false appearance with respect to Gaylin Holdings' share price between 2015 and 2020. Wong Leon Keat allegedly purchased shares at inflated prices and deceived a brokerage firm about his ownership stake. He is out on S$80,000 bail and the case is adjourned to March 24.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open down over 3.5% on coronavirus pandemic fears
summary: Tokyo stocks plummeted over 3.5% on February 25, 2020, due to fears of the coronavirus pandemic disrupting economic growth. The Nikkei 225 index fell 3.58% to 22,550.17, while the Topix index dropped 3.53% to 1,614.93. Global markets were tracking similar declines, reflecting concerns about the outbreak's impact on economies.

site_title: China reports 71 more coronavirus deaths
summary: China reported 71 more coronavirus deaths, raising the total to 2,663. The National Health Commission also confirmed 508 new cases, with most in Hubei province. Multiple provinces have reported zero new cases, with the World Health Organization stating the epidemic has "peaked" in China. However, experts warn of outbreaks in other countries. China continues to struggle to resume normal activity after the virus impacted its economy, and lockdowns remain in place.

site_title: Court dismisses Oei Hong Leong's lawsuit against Raffles Edu chairman
summary: The Singapore High Court has dismissed a lawsuit by tycoon Oei Hong Leong against Raffles Education chairman Chew Hua Seng, who allegedly promised to procure a buyer for Oei's shares in the education provider. The court ruled that the promise was not legally binding, as the parties did not intend to enter into a contract at their meeting. Justice Lee Seiu Kin stated that experienced businessmen like Oei and Chew would not have contemplated a transaction without lawyers. Oei had sought damages of up to S$26.5 million.

images.alt_text: Oei Hong Leong (right) and Chew Hua Seng having champagne and shaking hands after signing a handwritten document that became the subject of a lawsuit.

site_title: Coronavirus fears loom over giant US toy show
summary: The US toy industry is grappling with the impact of the new coronavirus outbreak in China, which has slowed output and raised fears of a global pandemic. The Toy Fair in New York has seen a China Pavilion cancelled, resulting in the loss of 47 exhibitors and 550 attendees. Industry executives warn of potential shortages and delays, with some manufacturers relying on China for 85% of their production. The outbreak's effects are expected to be felt globally, with toy makers anticipating a tough year ahead.

site_title: Mastercard says coronavirus to hit first-quarter revenue
summary: Mastercard expects a 2-3% hit to its first-quarter revenue due to the coronavirus outbreak, now forecasting 9-10% revenue growth for the quarter. The company also revised its 2020 net revenue growth forecast to the low teens, citing limited impact if the virus is confined to the first quarter. The virus has killed 2,442 and infected 76,936 people in China, impacting travel and e-commerce.

site_title: History repeats as sales tax hike pushes Japan toward recession
summary: Japan's economy is on the brink of recession due to a 6.3% economic contraction in the last quarter of 2019, fueled by a 6.3% sales tax hike in October. The tax increase, intended to fund pensions and healthcare, has led to heightened price consciousness among consumers, resulting in an 11% quarterly slide in consumption. Analysts predict the economy will fall into recession, further weakening Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's already dwindling support. Experts argue that the timing of the tax hike was poor, and more direct fiscal support was needed at the time.

site_title: BreadTalk founder makes S$0.77-per-share offer in privatisation bid after Q4 net loss
summary: BreadTalk's founder George Quek and a group of substantial shareholders have made a voluntary offer to acquire the company at S$0.77 per share, representing a 19.4% premium over the closing price. The offer aims to privatize the food and beverage player, allowing it to save on listed status costs and address challenges. BreadTalk reported a Q4 net loss of S$8.1 million and a full-year net loss of S$5.2 million, citing challenges in key markets and the COVID-19 outbreak. The offer is conditional on receiving valid acceptances, and the company has a technical breach of financial covenants for its S$100 million notes due in 2023.

site_title: Revolut hits US$5.5b valuation after funding round
summary: Revolut, a digital banking app, has raised US$500 million in a funding round, valuing the company at US$5.5 billion. The Series D funding, led by TCV, brings the total funding to US$836 million. Revolut will use the funds to expand in Europe, roll out new products, and improve customer service. The company aims to build a global financial platform and has plans to expand in the US, where it will open its virtual doors this year.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, SIA, Ascendas Reit, BreadTalk, FCOT, Oxley, UMS
summary: Several Singaporean stocks experienced significant developments on Tuesday, February 25, 2020. Singtel's Indian telco joint venture merger deadline was extended due to foreign direct investment approval. Singapore Airlines suspended flights from February to May due to the Covid-19 outbreak. BreadTalk's founder and substantial shareholder made a voluntary offer to acquire the company. Frasers Commercial Trust took out a S$100 million sustainability-linked loan. Oxley Holdings priced its new S$75 million notes at 6.5% and UMS Holdings reported a 4% dip in net profit for the fourth quarter.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start day with more losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks began trading with slight losses, extending a fourth-straight day of declines. The Hang Seng Index dropped 0.37% to 26,722.39, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 1.62% to 2,982.07. The Shenzhen Composite Index declined 2.09% to 1,893.01. The losses were tempered by bargain-buying, but the decline was attributed to a steep sell-off in Europe and New York.

site_title: Singapore shares edge up at Tuesday's open; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 4.71 points or 0.2% to 3,146.91. Banking stocks were mostly up, led by DBS and OCBC Bank. The gains come despite global stocks experiencing their worst day in two years due to concerns over the novel coronavirus. Other Asian markets, including Japan and Australia, also extended losses.

site_title: IReit Global's CEO quits
summary: IReit Global Group's CEO, Aymeric Thibord, has tendered his resignation to pursue other career opportunities. He will serve a notice period until May 10, 2020, and his effective date as CEO will be announced later. The company's board is currently searching for a new CEO, with an announcement expected once the appointment is made. This news led to a 2.9% drop in IReit's units to close at 82.5 cents on Monday.

site_title: Hedge fund Third Point calls on Britain's Prudential to break up
summary: Hedge fund Third Point LLC has amassed a $2 billion stake in Prudential and called for the British insurer to split into two companies, separating its Asian and US businesses. Third Point argues that investors undervalue Prudential's Asia business due to its bundling with the complex Jackson National Life unit. The hedge fund believes a split could lead to cost cuts, better capital allocation, and improved management of the US and Asia businesses, potentially doubling the value of Prudential shares within three years.

site_title: Singapore inflation starts the year shakily
summary: Singapore's inflation remained unchanged in January at 0.8% due to a weaker-than-expected reading and the impact of the global Covid-19 epidemic. Core inflation slowed to 0.3%, below the 0.9% forecast, while services inflation eased and prices of medical products declined. Analysts expect the Monetary Authority of Singapore to ease monetary policy to neutral by April, citing subdued inflationary pressures and economic uncertainty. Forecasts for core and headline inflation in 2020 remain unchanged at 0.5-1.5%.

site_title: Pentagon adopts 'ethical principles' for artificial intelligence use
summary: The US Pentagon has adopted "ethical principles" for the use of artificial intelligence by the armed forces, aiming to collaborate with tech giants. The principles include explicit, well-defined uses for AI technology, reliable systems, and transparent use. The military will have the ability to disengage or deactivate deployed systems that demonstrate unintended behavior. The move follows 15 months of consultations with tech giants, universities, and the administration, and aims to address concerns over AI-powered decision-making.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 7.60 points or 0.51% to 1,482.46. The market saw a significant volume of 108.56 million lots worth RM60.41 million, with losers beating gainers 379 to 37. This follows a global trend of stock declines, with Europe's stocks down due to bank and healthcare sector drag, and US stocks also edging down from records amid tariff threats.

site_title: Caltex Australia delays naming new CEO as bidders line up
summary: Caltex Australia has suspended its search for a new CEO as it deals with two takeover proposals from EG Group and Alimentation Couche-Tard. Interim CEO Matthew Halliday was appointed as CFO Julian Segal, who led the company for over 10 years, plans to retire. The refiner struggles to boost refining and retail fuel margins, with full-year net profit falling 38% to A$344 million. The delay comes as the company faces pressure to revive growth amid weak consumer demand and higher crude prices. Two bidders are vying for the company.

images.alt_text: Caltex Australia on Tuesday said it had suspended its search for a new chief as it deals with two takeover proposals and tries to turn around its oil refining and marketing business.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit Q4 DPU up 30.4% to 1.03 euro cents
summary: Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (Cromwell E-Reit) reported a 30.4% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.03 euro cents for the fourth quarter of 2019, driven by 64.2% growth in gross revenue and 60.4% growth in net property income. The Reit expects DPU for 2020 to be at or above 2019 levels, citing strong local market knowledge and execution capabilities. However, the manager noted that the Covid-19 virus may pose headwinds to the European economy.

site_title: Aspial's fiscal 2019 profit falls 55.2% to S$12.7m
summary: ASPIAL Corporation reported a 55.2% drop in net profit to S$12.7 million for FY2019, mainly due to weaker performance from its real estate business. Revenue fell 37.6% to S$560.2 million, and earnings per share decreased to 0.66 cents. The group expects positive contributions from its Australia 108 project and hotel portfolio, but faces challenges from the Covid-19 virus outbreak in its jewellery business. A final cash dividend of 0.25 cents per share was proposed.

site_title: Thousands attend LA memorial for Kobe Bryant and daughter
summary: Thousands of people gathered at the Staples Centre in Los Angeles to honor basketball legend Kobe Bryant and his 13-year-old daughter Gianna, who died in a helicopter crash on January 26. The "A Celebration of Life for Kobe and Gianna Bryant" memorial was attended by celebrities, athletes, and fans, with many wearing Lakers jerseys and gold and purple colors. The event featured a 2.5-hour ceremony, a 24-page program, and a pin and black T-shirt with images of Kobe and Gianna. Fellow Laker Magic Johnson attended, praising Kobe's impact on the world and the NBA.

site_title: Oil sinks 4% on demand concerns as coronavirus spreads
summary: Oil prices dropped 4% on Monday due to concerns over the rapid spread of the coronavirus, which has infected nearly 77,000 people and killed over 2,500 in China. The virus's impact on demand has raised fears of "demand destruction," with analysts predicting a short-term effect on oil prices. Global equities also declined, and some experts, including Goldman Sachs, warned of a sharp correction in commodity prices.

images.alt_text: Oil prices slumped by nearly 4 per cent on Monday as the rapid spread of the coronavirus in countries outside China added to investor concerns over the effect on demand for crude.

site_title: Cargill to challenge Beyond Meat, Impossible Foods with new plant-based burger
summary: Cargill, the world's largest privately held company, plans to launch plant-based hamburger patties and ground "fake meat" products in April, challenging Beyond Meat and Impossible Foods in the market for imitation meat. The company, known for trading crops, will offer customers soy protein or pea protein-based products, employing its experience in the supply chain to be efficient. Cargill's entry highlights the growing popularity of plant-based foods and competition for startups in the market.

site_title: 'Age of empowerment', accusers hail Weinstein convictions
summary: Harvey Weinstein was convicted of sexual assault and rape, with six women testifying against him, including Ashley Judd and Annabella Sciorra. He was acquitted of the most serious charge, but faces a lengthy jail term. The guilty verdicts are hailed as a landmark moment for the #MeToo movement, with accusers and activists praising the women who came forward and the jury for delivering justice. The convictions mark a shift towards empowering women to speak out against sexual misconduct, according to Gloria Allred, attorney for Sciorra and Haleyi.

site_title: US still eyeing ways to curb sales to Huawei after Trump's chipmaker comments: sources
summary: US government officials continue to consider ways to restrict sales to Huawei, despite President Trump's recent comments supporting sales to China. An interagency meeting discussed proposals to limit chip sales and block jet engine sales for Huawei's new passenger airplane. While jet engine sales are no longer on the table, new restrictions aimed at limiting Huawei's presence in the global telecommunications market are still being considered. Policymakers remain divided, with some favoring a tough line on Huawei and others focusing on trading with the world's second-largest economy.

images.alt_text: US government officials are still considering ways to further curb sales to China's Huawei Technologies, despite President Donald Trump's tweets and comments last week in support of sales to China, according to people familiar with the matter.

site_title: United Airlines suspends 2020 guidance on coronavirus uncertainty
summary: United Airlines has suspended its 2020 guidance due to coronavirus uncertainty, citing heightened uncertainty over air travel demand. The company maintains a forecast for the first quarter, but expects lower passenger traffic from virus fears. If the virus runs its course by mid-May, United expects to achieve its 2020 earnings forecast of $11-13 per share. The airline's international exposure makes it more vulnerable to lower passenger traffic, with 40% of its revenues generated on international flights.

site_title: Raffles Medical steps up efforts on virus kits and screening; China hospital opening affected
summary: Raffles Medical Group has launched a digital healthcare platform, Raffles-Connect, to provide remote consultations amid the Covid-19 outbreak. The company has also made available "Virus Protect" kits and expanded its reach with a new executive health screening centre at Waterway Point. However, the opening of its new Shanghai hospital has been delayed due to the outbreak. Despite a 15.2% drop in net profit, the group expects to remain profitable in 2020 and is expected to see improved momentum at its new Chongqing hospital over time.

site_title: Money FM podcast: What does Aware think about Budget 2020?
summary: Michelle Martin discusses Budget 2020 with Shailey Hingorani, head of advocacy and research at Aware, an organization that incorporated public ideas into the budget submission. Aware's submission highlighted issues such as childcare and healthcare costs, and proposed solutions like increased funding for these areas. However, Aware's specific thoughts on Budget 2020 are not mentioned in the article, as it appears to be a missed opportunity for a direct quote.

site_title: South Korea firms prepare for worst after Samsung virus case
summary: South Korea's tech industry prepares for the worst amid a surge in coronavirus cases, with Samsung shutting down operations at a plant in Gumi City after an employee tested positive. The company's shares plummeted, and other firms, including LG Electronics, took precautions to limit the spread of the virus. South Korea's fragile economic recovery is threatened, with the nation's Centres for Disease Control reporting 161 new cases, bringing the total to 763, and a death toll of seven.

site_title: California's high housing costs drive inequality in the state
summary: California's high housing costs are driving inequality in the state, with the average home costing around $240,000 nationwide but $750,000 in San Francisco for a two-bedroom apartment. Building affordable housing costs three times as much as in Texas or Illinois, mainly due to high land and labor costs. The process of building affordable housing is cumbersome, requiring financing from six sources and lengthy paperwork, leading to delays. Governor Gavin Newsom has called the issue "insanity" and is seeking to reduce costs through innovations in construction and exemptions to environmental regulations.

site_title: Williams cancels New York Constitution natural gas pipeline
summary: Williams Companies canceled the proposed Constitution natural gas pipeline from Pennsylvania to New York, citing a diminished return on investment. The project, which was approved by the US Federal Energy Regulatory Commission in 2014, had been stalled due to opposition from environmental groups and New York Governor Andrew Cuomo. The decision follows a US$354 million impairment of the project in Williams' 2019 earnings. The pipeline was designed to transport 0.65 billion cubic feet of gas per day, but with New York's declining gas consumption, the project no longer seemed viable.

site_title: US economy faces long-lasting damage from trade war: Federal Reserve official
summary: A Federal Reserve official, Loretta Mester, says the US economy may face long-lasting damage from the two-year trade war, despite recent agreements. The outbreak of the new coronavirus in China adds uncertainty, but Mester notes the trade picture is somewhat better with a new free trade pact with Canada and Mexico. However, some foreign companies have reoriented their supply chains away from US firms, potentially leading to permanent losses. Mester also expresses concern over sluggish investment, which could dampen economic growth and living standards.

site_title: Italy authorities urge calm as coronavirus cases stabilise
summary: Italy reported its seventh death from the new coronavirus, with 229 cases, as authorities called for calm. The number of new cases has stabilized, with only 10 added since the previous day. Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte has said residents could face weeks in lockdown to stem the spread of the disease. Eleven towns in Lombardy and Veneto are under lockdown, affecting 50,000 residents, and gatherings have been banned. The country is in the "eye of the storm" of the virus, with the stock market down 5.0% and hotels worried about bookings.

site_title: Oxley unit to issue S$75m notes with 6.5% coupon
summary: Oxley Holdings' wholly-owned subsidiary, Oxley MTN, priced S$75 million, three-year notes at 6.5% per annum, maturing on Feb 28, 2023. The notes are unconditionally guaranteed by Oxley and launched under its US$1 billion guaranteed euro medium-term note programme.

site_title: Airlines plunge as Italian coronavirus outbreak threatens longer crisis
summary: European budget airlines like EasyJet and Ryanair plummeted 16.4% and 13.5%, respectively, as the spread of the Covid-19 virus in Italy raised concerns about a longer crisis. Airlines reassessed the fallout from the outbreaks in South Korea and Iran, despite no suspension of Italian flights. The slump in European stocks, the largest since mid-2016, threatens the lucrative summer tourism season. The airline downturn follows a positive outlook from Delta Air Lines on travel demand.

site_title: US: Stocks join global rout on virus, Dow ends -3.6%
summary: US stocks plummeted 3.6% on Monday, joining a global rout, as concerns over the new coronavirus spread. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 1,000 points to 27,960.80, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index fell 3.4% and 3.7%, respectively. Analysts attributed the losses to the virus' rapid spread outside of China and its potential impact on global growth and corporate earnings. Several major stocks, including Apple and American Airlines, plummeted nearly 5% each, while Gilead Sciences surged 4.6% after positive comments from a World Health Organization official.

site_title: Hong Kong stocks are trading at lowest versus world since 2004
summary: Hong Kong stocks have fallen to their lowest level relative to the world since 2004, amid concerns over the impact of the coronavirus on the economy, which was already weakened by last year's protests. The Hang Seng Index has decoupled from mainland equities, falling to a three-year low relative to the CSI 300 Index. The city's economy has been struggling due to tourism decline, retail suffering, and concerns over the virus's impact on Chinese earnings.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng Index is near its lowest level relative to the MSCI All Country World Index since 2004, even after Monday's brutal global selloff in the US. The Hong Kong gauge has also decoupled from mainland equities, falling to a three-year low relative to the CSI 300 Index.

site_title: Temasek to freeze wages; senior management to take voluntary pay cut
summary: Singapore state investment firm Temasek is implementing a wage freeze for its employees and asking senior management to take a voluntary pay cut of up to 5% due to the Covid-19 outbreak. The budget for salary and promotion increases will be donated to staff volunteer initiative T-Touch and community support. This move follows previous wage freezes during the Sars outbreak in 2003 and the global financial crisis in 2008. Temasek aims to exercise restraint and prudence as a responsible portfolio owner during challenging times.

site_title: Europe: US$474b erased from stocks as virus fears reach fever pitch
summary: A coronavirus outbreak outside China led to a 5.4% slump in European stock markets, erasing nearly US$474 billion in value. Italy reported the biggest flare-up of the virus in Europe, with at least six deaths and over 200 infections, further upsetting its economy. The pan-European Stoxx 600 dropped 3.8% to its biggest intra-day percentage slump since the Brexit vote in 2016. Investors shifted out of equities and into safe havens, with airlines and luxury goods makers among the worst performers.

site_title: Trump gets down to business in India
summary: US President Donald Trump began tough trade talks in India on Tuesday, despite shared strategic concerns over China. The talks come after a worsening US-India trade deficit, with Trump's "America First" drive. Trump hailed Prime Minister Narendra Modi at a rally, but relations remain strained over trade. First Lady Melania visited a Delhi school, while Trump focuses on reducing the US$25-billion deficit. The outcome of the talks is uncertain, with trade tensions between the two countries ongoing.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump moves from sightseeing and speech-making to tough trade talks in India on Tuesday, as First Lady Melania visits a Delhi school to witness a "happiness class".

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: UMS Holdings posted a 4% dip in Q4 net profit to S$9.2 million, with revenue soaring 56% to S$40.4 million. Singapore Medical Group rose 25.1% to S$3.7 million, while APAC Realty increased 33.3% to S$5.5 million. UMS Holdings and Singapore Medical Group declared dividends, while APAC Realty's net profit fell 42.2% to S$14 million for the full year.

site_title: Singaporeans must not succumb to fear in fight against Covid-19 scourge
summary: Singapore reported its first Covid-19 case on Jan 23, with the country taking swift action to contain the outbreak. Despite initial concerns, the government's cautious approach has balanced protection with normal life. Measures include quarantining travelers, confining those who recently visited China, and encouraging good hygiene habits. The local transmission has been well contained, with no fatalities and over half of patients discharged. The government's evidence-based approach has helped mitigate the economic impact, preventing a severe recession and protecting jobs and livelihoods.

site_title: Frasers Commercial Trust obtains S$100m sustainability-linked loan
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) has secured a S$100 million sustainability-linked loan with a five-year term. The loan has a price reduction feature, offering interest cost savings from the second year if FCOT maintains a Global Real Estate Sustainability Benchmark (GRESB) rating of four stars or higher. The loan is backed by Bank of China Limited, Singapore Branch, and the Reit's merger with Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT) may impact its GRESB ratings. FCOT's CEO stated that the loan provides an incentive to improve sustainability.

site_title: Food Empire Q4 profit jumps 84%
summary: Food Empire Holdings reported a 83.6% jump in net profit to US$5 million in Q4 2019, driven by a 4.7% revenue growth. Sales increased in Russia, Ukraine, Kazakhstan, and CIS markets, while South-east Asia sales declined 5.6%. Full-year net profit rose 44.3% to US$26.1 million, with earnings per share increasing to 4.89 US cents. The company plans to construct a second non-dairy creamer plant in Malaysia and remains focused on growing key markets and streamlining operations.

site_title: The ECB is in for a Covid-19 shocker
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is bracing for a potential economic shock from the COVID-19 pandemic, despite recent data showing a rebound in the eurozone economy. The composite purchasing managers index (PMI) rose to 51.6 in February, above the 50 level, driven by a strong services sector. However, the outbreak's rapid spread and growing number of cases in Europe, particularly in Italy, threaten to disrupt businesses and impact local services. Policymakers have been overly optimistic, and it's unclear when they will implement measures to prop up the global economy, with the ECB's president Christine Lagarde displaying excessive optimism about inflation.

site_title: Coronavirus-hit China postpones parliament for first time in decades
summary: China has postponed its annual parliament session for the first time in decades due to the coronavirus outbreak, which has infected nearly 80,000 people and claimed over 2,500 lives. The National People's Congress, which typically meets in March, will now decide on a new date after its Standing Committee postponed the event on Monday. The move is seen as a practical decision to prioritize the battle against the virus, with many top officials focused on tackling the outbreak in their home regions.

site_title: China developers face cash crunch with virus-driven home sales freeze
summary: China's developers face a cash crunch due to the novel coronavirus outbreak, which has brought the property market to a standstill. Most builders have only a three-month cash buffer, and with lockdowns in some cities entering their second month, the clock is ticking on their debts. The lockdowns have resulted in a freeze in home sales, exacerbating the financial strain on the debt-laden developers.

site_title: Some landlords offering virus relief packages to tenants
summary: Landlords in Singapore are offering virus relief packages to tenants, including offsetting rents with security deposits, restructuring rental payments, or granting rental rebates. CapitaLand announced it will release one month's worth of security deposits to offset rental payments for March 2020. Other measures include releasing rental rebates and restructuring rental payments. These initiatives aim to ease cash flows for retail tenants amid the COVID-19 outbreak.

site_title: Renewed virus concerns spook STI
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 38.83 points or 1.2% to 3,142.20, its lowest level since Feb 3, as concerns over the novel coronavirus (Covid-19) in South Korea and Italy spooked investors, causing them to rush for safe-havens like gold and US government bonds. The blue-chip index closed with all but one of its 30 components losing value, with Singtel and DBS Group Holdings being the only exceptions.

site_title: Can S-E Asia beat the 80/20 rule of venture capital?
summary: South-east Asia's venture capital scene is diverging from the traditional 80/20 rule, where 80% of returns come from 20% of startups. Unlike US-based VCs, emerging market investors focus on companies with proven technology and ideas, with a lower risk profile due to a proven starting point. Successful examples include Grab and Gojek, which adapted successful models to suit regional consumers. The region's large, young, and digitally engaged population presents opportunities for multiple successful companies to emerge, despite heightened execution risk.

site_title: As India's economy sags, even the Trump brand is struggling
summary: The Trump brand in India is struggling due to the country's economic slump. The Trump Towers complex in Pune has seen vacant apartments, a slow sales pace, and empty pools. The complex, valued at $2 million, is a rare example of the US businessman's failed foray into the Indian real estate market. The economic downturn has had a significant impact on the luxury property market, with other developers also experiencing difficulties.

site_title: More libraries doing away with overdue fines
summary: The Free Library of Philadelphia has ended its policy of charging fines on overdue materials, joining several other library systems nationwide in adopting a no-fee or amnesty policy. This shift aims to encourage patrons to return books and materials, rather than imposing financial penalties. Other cities, including Los Angeles, Chicago, and Denver, have also implemented similar policies, citing research that shows fines disproportionately affect low-income and young patrons. Libraries prioritize providing free access to information, services, and resources, highlighting their importance as community hubs.

site_title: Covid-19 spreads around globe, deepening fears of pandemic
summary: A global Covid-19 pandemic deepened on February 24, 2020, with the number of countries reporting infections exceeding 30. Iran saw a surge in fatalities, with 12 confirmed deaths, and the virus spread rapidly in South Korea, with over 830 cases and 8 deaths. Italy reported its fourth fatality, and China's death toll rose to nearly 2,600. The virus has also affected Afghanistan, Bahrain, and Kuwait, and global travel and economies have been impacted.

site_title: EPL clubs favour TV rights deals over streaming service
summary: The 20 English Premier League (EPL) clubs are opting for traditional TV rights deals over a potential streaming service, citing concerns over lower streaming revenues. Despite the league's exploration of a dedicated streaming service, clubs are hesitant to invest in a service that may not yield the desired returns. The EPL's current broadcasting rights deals, worth £3 billion annually, are expected to end in 2022, with the possibility of a pilot streaming scheme being considered.

site_title: Manufacturers' vital ingredient: technology
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector faces challenges to maintain its 20% GDP contribution, with rising labour costs and global competition. To thrive, manufacturers must innovate, digitize, and adopt technology, particularly in areas such as AI, 5IR, circular economy, and advanced food tracking and packaging. The government's investments in innovation and productivity subsidies will be crucial in supporting this shift. Key predictions include the rise of AI chatbots, digital "muscle building" through technology, and the importance of sustainability and customer engagement in the manufacturing sector.

site_title: Modi rolls out red carpet for Trump's official visit
summary: US President Donald Trump received a red-carpet welcome in India on his maiden official visit, addressing a huge rally at a mega cricket stadium in Ahmedabad. Trump praised Prime Minister Narendra Modi as an "exceptional leader" and promised a "faithful and loyal friendship" to India. Despite tensions over trade and Kashmir, the two leaders signed smaller agreements and defense deals, with discussions on a broader trade deal pending. The visit is seen as a photo opportunity, but also raises concerns over issues like religious freedom and India's citizenship law.

site_title: India High Comm to build new chancery in Stevens Road
summary: India's High Commission in Singapore plans to build a new, larger chancery on Stevens Road, with construction expected to start by the end of April or May. The new facility will have a total gross floor area of 11,582.65 square meters and will include a four-storey chancery block, a covered terrace, and a roof garden. The current Grange Road premises will be demolished and redeveloped into residential units, with the High Commissioner's office possibly being restored as a ceremonial building. The development is expected to be completed by mid-2023, with the chancery moving to Stevens Road and the Grange Road site being redeveloped into residential units.

site_title: SGX adds methanol futures and swaps to petrochem contracts
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has launched methanol futures and swaps contracts, providing an exchange-traded alternative to manage risk and improve price discovery in the methanol market. The new contracts, launched on Monday, are cash-settled in reference to the S&P Global Platts daily price assessment for methanol. This move complements SGX's existing petrochemical contracts and aims to meet the growing demand for clean energy options, driven by increasing global demand for methanol.

site_title: Sonic the Hedgehog narrowly beats Harrison Ford's Call of the Wild
summary: Sonic the Hedgehog narrowly beat Harrison Ford's Call of the Wild at the North American box office, earning US$26.3 million over the weekend. Sonic's total US$100 million in North America surpasses expectations, while Call of the Wild's US$25 million debut was initially expected to top Sonic. Despite receiving mixed reviews, Call of the Wild's PG rating and massive budget may require it to break even through international ticket sales.

images.alt_text: Harrison Ford's Call of the Wild surprisingly took the top spot last Friday, but was ultimately defeated by Sonic.

site_title: Haulio and Avantida team up to use shipping containers more efficiently
summary: Haulio, a Singaporean logistics player, has partnered with Belgian company Avantida to offer container "street turn" services, aiming to improve container usage efficiency. Through the partnership, Haulio's truckers can request containers for import/export trips using Haulio's platform, which is then connected to ocean lines' booking systems via Avantida's platform. This collaboration aims to reduce empty container returns to depots, increasing the utilization of shipping equipment.

site_title: Boosting trade through legal harmonisation
summary: Global trade is facing a major crisis due to ongoing trade wars and conflicts between the US and China, the EU, and Britain's exit from the EU. The World Trade Organization's dispute settlement mechanism has been paralyzed, leading to reduced commercial activity, higher costs, and discouraging investment. Export-dependent countries like Singapore are already feeling the effects, with exports falling due to weak demand. Harmonizing laws and regulations across countries could simplify cross-border transactions and lower costs, but progress is hindered by ongoing trade tensions and conflicts.

images.alt_text: Trade conflicts, the paralysis of the WTO's dispute settlement mechanism and Brexit have all caused the deterioration of global trade, posing a direct threat to jobs, livelihoods, and the health of the global economy.

site_title: How Asia is reinventing banking for the digital age
summary: Asia's banking sector is leading the world in digital innovations, with tech giants and traditional banks establishing new business models. Fintech innovators and digital-first banks are taking market share from traditional banks, creating opportunities for growth in consumer lending, SME lending, wealth management, and transaction banking. However, many banks are poorly equipped to seize these opportunities, facing an existential choice: reinvent themselves or disappear. To succeed, banks must invest in technology architecture, advanced analytics, talent management, and partnerships/M&A, and prioritize projects with the greatest impact on customer experience and value to the bank.

site_title: Dr M staying as interim PM until successor picked
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad unexpectedly resigned, citing accusations of forming a partnership with opposition parties he defeated. He will remain interim premier until a successor is appointed. Anwar Ibrahim, the PKR president, met with the king to express his views and seek advice, but it's unclear if he will stake a claim to form a new government. The opposition and Dr. Mahathir's coalition are in talks, and a showdown between Mr. Anwar and Muhyiddin Yassin's alliance is possible. A fresh election could be called if no one commands a simple majority in parliament.

site_title: Zaha Hadid's 'exoskeleton' tower an instant Miami landmark
summary: Zaha Hadid's One Thousand Museum in Miami has become a prominent landmark with its unique curved "exoskeleton" design. Completed in 2018, the $300 million luxury condo building honors the late Iraqi-British architect, who spent time in Miami and passed away in 2016. The 62-storey tower features a helipad, two pools, and high-end amenities, and its innovative design has been praised for its functionality and elegance. The building is now fully occupied, with residents from over 20 countries, and its units range from $5 million to $24 million.

images.alt_text: The high-rise honours the legacy of its architect, the late Zaha Hadid, who died in Miami in 2016 at the age of 65. It is her first tower in the Western hemisphere.

site_title: Parents grapple with e-learning as Chinese schools stay shut
summary: China's Covid-19 outbreak has forced schools to close, leaving parents to juggle childcare and education. To cope, many parents have turned to online learning platforms, which have seen a significant surge in demand. Chinese online education companies have benefited from the crisis, with enrollment in online classes tripling in the first 10 days of February. However, experts warn that the short-term boom may not translate to long-term growth, and the industry faces challenges in replicating the impact of in-person interaction.

site_title: Euro hit by rush for US dollar as Covid-19 spreads
summary: The euro dropped to US$1.08, its lowest in nearly three years, amid the spread of the coronavirus outside China, with fears of a pandemic driving investors to the US dollar. The Japanese yen and Swiss franc gained, but not significantly, as investors view the US economy as more sheltered. The Australian dollar tumbled to an 11-year low, while the US dollar gained 0.2% against a basket of currencies. Analysts expect the euro to move lower in the short term due to the euro zone's exposure to China.

site_title: From cash flow to marketing, help for businesses flow in amid virus outbreak
summary: FundTier, a Singapore-based crowdfunding platform, offers S$1 million in interest-free loans to local SMEs to upgrade their marketing capabilities amid the COVID-19 outbreak. Dodoca Information Technology also provides a 30% discount on its package. Meanwhile, a S$5 million fund set up by John Lim's family office, ARA Asset Management, and Straits Trading Company has received over 100 loan applications, with close to 60% meeting eligibility criteria. The fund aims to provide short-term loans to SMEs struggling with cash flow.

site_title: Lawyer Jeffrey Ong faces another 12 charges; all linked to client's missing S$33.8m
summary: Singaporean lawyer Jeffrey Ong faces 12 additional charges, bringing the total to 38, related to the missing S$33.8 million from Allied Technologies' escrow funds. Ong is accused of misappropriating sums of between S$9,967 and S$12.2 million, and forging a senior partner's signature on a cheque for S$33.2 million. The charges include 11 counts of criminal breach of trust and one count of forgery. Ong has been denied bail and remains remanded.

site_title: APAC Realty posts 33% rise in Q4 net profit of S$5.5m
summary: APAC Realty reported a 33.3% increase in Q4 net profit to S$5.5 million, driven by higher brokerage income from new home sales, resale, and rental of properties. Revenue rose 31.7% to S$107.8 million. However, the company's full-year net profit fell 42.2% to S$14 million due to lower revenue. The decline was attributed to weaker sales of resale and rental properties.

site_title: Coronavirus: one new case in Singapore, 2 others discharged
summary: Singapore reported one new case of the coronavirus disease, bringing the total to 90, with 53 fully recovered. A 75-year-old Singaporean woman, linked to the Life Church cluster, was confirmed to have Covid-19 after showing symptoms and visiting a general practitioner clinic. Seven others are in critical condition in the intensive care unit. The total number of close contacts is 2,842, with 856 currently quarantined.

site_title: SPH expands aged care business with 5.26b yen Japan acquisition
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) has acquired five aged care assets in Japan for 5.26 billion yen (S$65.8 million) as part of its strategy to expand into markets with fast-ageing populations. The properties, which offer independent living services, have a total capacity of 365 beds. This marks SPH's first overseas investment in its aged care business, following a partnership with Japanese real estate asset manager Bridge C Capital to invest in aged care and healthcare assets in Japan.

site_title: Tesla rival sets out to banish 160-year-old lead technology from cars
summary: Skeleton Technologies Group OU, an Estonian company, is developing supercapacitors to potentially replace 160-year-old lead-acid batteries in electric vehicles. These components are lightweight and long-life, distributing intensive power bursts. The goal is to eliminate lead-acid batteries used in some Tesla models, which were invented in 1859. The technology could revolutionize the automotive industry, offering a more efficient and sustainable alternative to traditional batteries.

site_title: KL government's political upheaval ends world's longest bull run
summary: Malaysia's stock market, the world's longest bull run, ended its 12-year reign as the FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI Index tumbled 2.7% following the abrupt resignation of Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad and the coronavirus outbreak, pushing the index into bear territory. The drop extends the decline from its April 2018 all-time high to 21%. The nation's largest stocks fell at least 4.5% as the ringgit weakened to its lowest since September, and bonds fell across the curve.

site_title: Prada apppoints Raf Simons as co-creative director in strategic move
summary: Miuccia Prada and Patrizio Bertelli appointed Belgian designer Raf Simons as co-creative director of Prada, aiming to shake up the brand and position it for the future. Simons and Prada will share equal creative input and decision-making responsibilities, potentially reshaping the fashion world. This move brings in a star designer, bringing fresh perspectives and expertise to the iconic Italian brand.

site_title: UMS Holdings posts 4% dip in Q4 net profit of S$9.2m
summary: UMS Holdings reported a 4% dip in Q4 net profit to S$9.2 million, down from S$9.6 million in the same period last year. Revenue soared 56% to S$40.4 million, driven by a 53% jump in semiconductor sales. Full-year net profit fell 22% to S$33.6 million, attributed to softer gross material margins. The company declared a final dividend of two cents per share and a special dividend of 0.5 cent per share. UMS shares closed at S$0.955, down 6.5 cents or 6.37%.

site_title: Coronavirus puts cruise industry in the dock
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has raised concerns about the cruise industry's reputation as a "floating petri dish" for viral outbreaks. Cruise ships have seen multiple cases of deadly viruses, chickenpox, and gastrointestinal illnesses, often affecting elderly passengers who have invested thousands of dollars in luxury holidays. These incidents highlight the risks associated with cruise travel and the need for improved health measures to protect passengers.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. In the US, stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, while in Europe, stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector concerns. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall in the second half of the year. Meanwhile, London's Heathrow Airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade.

site_title: SIA suspends flights across network, cites weak demand due to Covid-19
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) suspended flights across its network from February to May due to weak demand caused by the Covid-19 outbreak, resulting in a 7.1% decrease in scheduled capacity. Affected flights include routes to the US, Europe, North Asia, and South-east Asia, with services to US cities like Los Angeles and New York, and South Korean cities Seoul and Busan cancelled. Customers will be notified and booked on other flights.

site_title: Super-high heels free women, says shoe king Louboutin
summary: French shoe designer Christian Louboutin claims that wearing super-high heels, like his iconic six-inch stilettos, is a form of "liberty" for women, allowing them to express themselves and break free from societal norms. Despite criticism from some feminists, Louboutin believes that women do not want to give up wearing high heels, and that they are a means of empowerment, rather than enslavement. He argues that the discomfort of high heels is a small price to pay for the freedom to be feminine and express oneself through fashion.

site_title: Kuwait, Bahrain announce first coronavirus cases
summary: Kuwait and Bahrain announced their first novel coronavirus cases on February 24, 2020, with three and one confirmed cases, respectively, all originating from Iran.

site_title: Car drives into German carnival parade, several injured
summary: A car drove into a German carnival parade in Volkmarsen, injuring 10 people, including children. The driver, who has been arrested, allegedly targeted children and drove into the crowd at full throttle. Police have not confirmed whether the incident was an accident or deliberate. The motive behind the incident remains unclear.

site_title: Containing the economic fallout of Covid-19
summary: The Covid-19 outbreak is causing a significant economic downturn, with China's GDP growth forecasted to be revised downwards to below 5% in 2020. The World Bank predicts China's economy could contract as low as 2% due to the prolonged impact of the virus. The virus is also affecting global supply chains, leading to factory shutdowns, store closures, and a decline in airline traffic. Governments are responding with fiscal stimulus measures, including tax rebates and credit schemes, but analysts warn that monetary stimulus may have its limits due to record-low interest rates.

site_title: US: Dow sheds 800 points as pandemic fears grip Wall Street
summary: US stocks plummeted Monday, with the Dow shedding 800 points, as concerns over the spread of the new coronavirus gripped Wall Street. The benchmark Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 2.8% and the S&P 500 dropped 2.6%, while the Nasdaq Composite Index sank 3.1%. Widespread losses were seen across the technology, financial, and energy sectors, with European and Asian bourses also experiencing sharp declines. Analysts fear the shutdown effect in China may spread globally, dealing a blow to global growth and earnings prospects.

site_title: Virus-hit China postpones parliament for first time in decades
summary: China has postponed its annual parliament session for the first time in decades due to the ongoing coronavirus outbreak, which has infected nearly 80,000 people and claimed over 2,500 lives. The decision, made by the NPC's Standing Committee, was seen as a pragmatic move to prioritize the fight against the virus. The session, which was originally set to start on March 5, will now be held at a later date, with top officials focusing on tackling the outbreak in their home regions.

site_title: Changing hands
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. In the Singapore stock market, NTT DC Reit's public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, while Europe's stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector concerns. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss for the second half of the year. Meanwhile, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case involving 285 trillion rupiah. London's Heathrow eyed higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade.

site_title: Coronavirus: 1 new case in S'pore; 2 others discharged
summary: Singapore reported 1 new case of coronavirus, bringing the total to 90 cases, with 53 fully recovered. A 75-year-old woman, linked to a cluster at The Life Church and Missions Singapore, was confirmed with no recent travel history to China. Seven individuals remain in critical condition. The Health Ministry has identified 2,842 close contacts, with 856 currently quarantined.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares slump 2.7% on Monday amid political upheaval
summary: Malaysia's shares plummeted 2.7% on Monday amid political upheaval, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index falling 41.14 points to 1,490.06. The market saw a significant decline in volume, with 4 billion lots worth RM3.9 billion traded. Losers outnumbered gainers 1,015 to 138.

site_title: Assange would be suicide risk if extradited to US, his lawyer says
summary: Julian Assange's lawyer claims his client would be a suicide risk if extradited to the US, citing inhumane treatment and a disproportionate sentence. The extradition request is seen as motivated by politics rather than genuine crimes, with Assange's lawyer stating the US attitude towards him changed after Donald Trump came to power. Assange, founder of WikiLeaks, was previously deemed not to face action by the US government in 2013, but an indictment was brought in 2017. Assange's lawyer argues the indictment is politically expedient and undesirable.

images.alt_text: Julian Assange should not be extradited to the United States as he would not get a fair trial and would be a suicide risk, his lawyer told a British court hearing on Monday.

site_title: Forise International says it expects higher loss for FY2019
summary: FORISE International Limited expects to report a higher loss for the FY2019 due to lower corporate advisory revenue and increased impairment charges. The losses stem from the slowdown in Chinese corporate activities, the US-China trade war, and Beijing's deleveraging policy. The company's associated company, Le Rong Financial Factoring Company, also impacted its financial performance. Forise International is finalizing its financial results for Q4 and will disclose more details on Feb 29.

site_title: Unit of Singtel associate Bharti Airtel gets approval for merger
summary: Bharti Airtel, the Indian associate telco of Mainboard-listed Singtel, has received foreign direct investment approval from the Indian government. As a result, the deadline for merging Indus Towers and Bharti Infratel, a subsidiary of Bharti Airtel, has been extended to April 24, 2020, from its previous extended long-stop date of February 24.

site_title: Virus outbreak a wild card for Singapore banks' bad loan buffers
summary: Singapore banks have set lower provisions for the impact of the Covid-19 outbreak, but analysts warn that the disruption could lead to higher credit costs if the outbreak extends beyond mid-2020. Credit costs are expected to rise to 5 bps, but may be met with skepticism from investors. The banks' buffers for macro slowdowns, such as the Hong Kong economy's recession and the US-China trade war, may cushion the impact. However, analysts flag concerns about the second-order impact of the virus outbreak, which could lead to "far higher" credit costs.

images.alt_text: Singapore banks have guided on the size of provisions that can cover the impact from the Covid-19 outbreak ahead, but analysts say the lenders may have to stomach more if the disruption to supply chains and consumer demand extends beyond the first half of this year.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's core inflation missed forecasts in January at 0.3%, due to a sharper fall in retail and other goods costs. Meanwhile, JLC Advisors' Jeffrey Ong faces 12 charges, including forging a S$33.15 million cheque, and a Singaporean property tycoon's family office launched an SME loan fund that oversubscribed. The Singapore stock market skidded 1.2% due to growing Covid-19 worries. Globally, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and the US is set to raise tariffs on Asian garments.

site_title: Bleak year ahead for Bangkok condo market
summary: Bangkok's condominium market faces a bleak year due to the Covid-19 outbreak, with foreigners expected to account for as little as 10% of purchases, down from 20% two years ago. The market has been hit by travel curbs and economic havoc, leading to 100,000 vacant condominiums in and around Bangkok. Developers remain wary, with some not planning to open new projects this year. The real estate sector slowdown is expected to impact Thailand's economy, with GDP growth potentially slowing to 1.5% this year.

site_title: Mahathir's resignation accepted but will stay on as interim PM
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad unexpectedly resigned on Monday, leaving the country in turmoil, but the monarch asked him to stay on as interim premier until a successor is appointed. Mahathir, 94, cited accusations of working with opposition parties he defeated less than two years ago, but it's unclear if this marks the end of his term. The country's currency, bonds, and stock market plummeted following the resignation, and analysts predict a possible fresh election.

site_title: Food Empire posts 84% jump in Q4 net profit of US$5m
summary: Food Empire Holdings reported an 83.6% jump in net profit to US$5 million for the fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2019, with revenue growing 4.7% to US$73.3 million. The company attributed the growth to increased sales in Russia, Ukraine, Kazakhstan, and CIS markets, despite a 5.6% decline in South-east Asia sales. Net profit for the full year grew 44.3% to US$26.1 million, driven by higher sales in key markets and cost-efficient business operations.

site_title: US sees no material impact from virus on US-China trade deal
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin stated that the novel coronavirus outbreak is unlikely to have a material impact on the Phase 1 US-China trade deal, despite concerns over the global economy. Finance officials from the world's 20 largest economies expressed caution, but Mnuchin cautioned against drawing conclusions, saying it's too soon to assess the impact. The US still expects China to meet its commitments to buy more US products and services under the trade deal.

site_title: JEP Holdings FY2019 net profit nearly triples to S$6.5m
summary: JEP Holdings reported a nearly tripled FY2019 net profit to S$6.5 million, driven by a 3.6% rise in total revenue to S$89 million. The company improved its gross margin to 18% by relocating labor-intensive work to a lower-cost region and implementing cost-controlling initiatives. Earnings per share rose to 1.61 Singapore cents from 0.578 cents in FY2018. The aerospace segment remains the key revenue source, while the oil and gas segment faces challenges due to Middle East tensions and the US-China trade war.

site_title: Ascendas Reit sells Changi warehouse to Hao Mart for S$20.3m
summary: Ascendas Reit is selling a two-storey warehouse building along Changi South Street 1 to Hao Mart for S$20.3 million, a 14% premium over its original purchase price. The building, with a remaining land lease tenure of 37 years, is expected to be divested by the end of Q1 2020. The sale proceeds will be used to fund committed investments, repay debts, and distribute to unitholders, with no expected impact on the Reit's net asset value or distribution per unit for the 2020 financial year.

site_title: Grand Venture Tech posts 34% drop in FY2019 after-tax profit
summary: Grand Venture Tech reported a 34% drop in FY2019 after-tax profit to S$3.1 million, down from S$4.69 million the previous year. Revenue declined 2.3% to S$40.1 million due to lower takings in its main semiconductor segment. The company's life science, electronics, and others segment saw a 57.7% rise in sales to S$16.2 million, driven by increased customer orders. The semiconductor industry faces softer demand due to global trade tensions.

site_title: India's nationalist leader holds huge rally for Trump's visit
summary: US President Donald Trump held a rally in Ahmedabad, India, where he received a warm welcome from over 100,000 Indians at the world's largest cricket stadium. Trump promised an "incredible trade deal" and "the most feared military equipment on the planet" with India, amidst a backdrop of rising tensions over a new citizenship law. Despite a lack of progress on trade, Trump praised India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi, a nationalist leader, for his "global standing" and hinted at discussing religious freedoms in India. The visit has been seen as a counter to China's rise as a superpower, and Trump's approval rating in India remains above 50%.

images.alt_text: Mr Trump and Melania posed for pictures at the Taj, the 17th century monument to love. "It's incredible," he told reporters.

site_title: Wuhan scraps easing of quarantine hours after announcing it
summary: Authorities in Wuhan, China have reversed a decision to ease quarantine hours after announcing it, citing a lack of consent from local officials. The decision would have allowed non-residents to leave the city without symptoms, while residents with special reasons could exit. The city government has reprimanded officials involved and strictly managed passages out of Wuhan. The move comes amid criticism of Wuhan's handling of the COVID-19 epidemic, with top officials already sacked earlier this month.

site_title: S Korea's thirst for US crude to keep growing in 2020
summary: South Korea is expected to surpass Canada as the top buyer of US crude oil in 2020, driven by steep price discounts, attractive refining economics, and rebates on shipping charges. South Korean purchases more than doubled in the first 11 months of 2019 to 142.3 million barrels, with US crude shipments estimated to reach 38.57 million barrels in the first quarter of 2020. The US is set to become a net exporter of crude for the first time in 2020, and Asia is expected to be a focus for more shipments, particularly as European refiners have limited capacity for more shale.

site_title: WHO says no longer uses 'pandemic' category, but virus still emergency
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) no longer has a process for declaring a pandemic, but the Covid-19 coronavirus outbreak remains a public health emergency of international concern. The virus has spread globally, with over 77,000 known infections in China and 1,769 cases in 28 other countries. Despite easing of restrictions in China, the outbreak is still considered an international emergency, with sharp rises in new cases reported in Iran, Italy, and South Korea. WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus said containment is possible, but the situation is still critical.

site_title: Some Samsung, Hyundai workers self-quarantine as Korean Inc braces for virus impact
summary: South Korean workers at Samsung Electronics and Hyundai Motor are self-quarantining due to the coronavirus outbreak, with around 1,500 workers at Samsung's phone complex in Gumi and six employees at Hyundai's factories in Ulsan staying home. The move comes as South Korea reported 161 new cases, bringing the total to 763, and the government raised its infectious disease alert to its highest level. Both companies have restarted production and implemented measures to prevent the spread of the virus, with Samsung expecting no impact on production and Hyundai advising employees to refrain from traveling to affected areas.

site_title: Afghanistan confirms first case of coronavirus from three suspected
summary: Afghanistan has confirmed its first case of coronavirus, a patient in the Western province of Herat, who recently returned from Iran. A state of emergency has been declared in the province, and residents are advised to stay at home and restrict their movements. The patient is one of three suspected cases, and the outbreak has raised concerns of a global pandemic. This is the first reported case outside of China, where the virus has infected nearly 77,000 people and killed over 2,500.

site_title: SGX launches methanol futures and swap contracts
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has launched methanol futures and swap contracts to help producers, traders, and downstream users manage risk and improve price discovery. The new contracts are cash-settled in reference to the S&P Global Platts daily price assessment for methanol, catering to the growing demand for the chemical. This move aims to enhance price transparency and facilitate better risk management in the methanol market.

site_title: Primark owner warns coronavirus threatens clothing supplies
summary: Associated British Foods (AB Foods) warns that the coronavirus outbreak in China could lead to supply shortages on some clothing lines, potentially affecting its 2019-20 financial year. The company sources a broad assortment of products from China and typically builds inventories in advance of Chinese New Year. AB Foods plans to mitigate the impact by increasing production from existing suppliers in other regions and operating its factories at reduced capacity due to labor and logistics constraints. The company's outlook for the full-year remains unchanged.
