images.alt_text: Primark owner Associated British Foods warned on Monday there was a risk of supply shortages on some lines later in the 2019-20 financial year if delays in factory production in China are prolonged due to coronavirus.

site_title: UK Labour members vote on leader to replace Corbyn
summary: UK Labour members are voting on a new leader to replace Jeremy Corbyn, who stepped down after a second general election defeat. Three candidates, Keir Starmer, Rebecca Long-Bailey, and Lisa Nandy, are vying for the position. Starmer is considered the frontrunner, viewed as a more moderate alternative to Corbyn. The final result will be announced on April 4. This follows Labour's worst result since 1935, with the Conservative Party winning the general election.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start week with another sharp drop
summary: Hong Kong's stocks began the week with a sharp drop, falling 1.79% to close at 26,820.88. The decline was attributed to investor concerns over the coronavirus potentially becoming a global pandemic, affecting energy and tourism-linked companies. Mainland markets, however, received support from government pledges and stimulus measures, including an interest rate cut, which boosted the Shanghai Composite Index 0.28% and the Shenzhen Composite Index 1.36%.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng Index fell 1.79 per cent, or 487.93 points, to close at 26,820.88.

site_title: Singapore shares slide 1.2% on Monday as Covid-19 worries grow
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index slid 1.2% on Monday, its lowest level since February 3, as concerns over the novel coronavirus (Covid-19) in South Korea and Italy drove investors to safe-havens like gold. The benchmark index closed at 3,142.20, with all but one of its 30 components finishing in the red. The largest telco, Singtel, remained unchanged, while local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB ended lower. Analysts have downgraded several stocks, citing near-term uncertainty and potential earnings risks.

site_title: Europe: Stocks fall sharply at open on virus alarm
summary: European stock markets plummeted at the start of trade on Monday, with Italy's FTSE MIB index falling 4.2% due to growing concerns over the coronavirus outbreak. London's FTSE 100, Frankfurt's DAX 30, and Paris's CAC 40 also declined, with the latter shedding 2.9% each. The alarming news comes as Italy confirmed its fourth fatality from the Covid-19 epidemic.

images.alt_text: In Italy, which on Monday confirmed its fourth fatality from the Covid-19 epidemic, Milan's FTSE MIB benchmark shares index tumbled 4.2 per cent to 23,740.11 points.

site_title: 'Guest is God': Crowds gather to greet Trump as he lands in India
summary: US President Donald Trump arrived in Ahmedabad, India on Monday, starting a two-day visit aimed at resetting relations between the two countries, which have been strained due to a trade spat. Prime Minister Narendra Modi greeted Trump and his wife Melania at the airport. The visit is seen as a sign of converging interests between India and the US, including countering China's rise as a superpower. Trump's visit comes as India and the US seek to strengthen their ties in the face of growing competition from China.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks shed 4% as spreading virus darkens growth outlook
summary: South Korean stocks plummeted 4% as the coronavirus spread, with 161 new cases reported and the total number of infections reaching 763, including seven deaths. The Korea Centres for Disease Control and Prevention warned of a possible contraction in the first-quarter GDP. The benchmark KOSPI index has fallen for three sessions, its lowest since December 2019. The Bank of Korea may cut interest rates preemptively this week amid concerns over global supply chain disruptions.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall most since mid-August on coronavirus fears
summary: Australian shares fell 2.3% on Monday, their largest decline since mid-August 2019, amid growing concerns over the coronavirus outbreak. South Korea raised its alert level and Italy reported a third death, while the number of cases in South Korea and Italy jumped. New Zealand's benchmark index also dropped 1.8%. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at its lowest level since February 5, and the US stock market edged down from records due to tariff threats. The decline is attributed to fears of a hit to the global economy.

site_title: Barclays set to launch CEO search: report
summary: Barclays is set to launch a search for a new CEO, with Jes Staley expected to leave by the end of 2021. Regulators are probing Staley's links to Jeffrey Epstein, and the bank may appoint an external headhunting firm to identify potential successors. The process could take up to a year, following recent changes at other European top banks. Staley has told colleagues he expects to step down at the annual meeting in May 2021.

site_title: Goldman Sachs flags downside risks for commodities before China stimulus kicks in
summary: Goldman Sachs warns of a sharp correction in commodities before Chinese stimulus kicks in, potentially bringing 10% returns in the 12-month period. The bank forecasts -0.5% returns for a 3-month horizon, 4.9% for 6 months, and 9.5% for 12 months. Oil prices are expected to fall, while gold prices are expected to reach $1,750-$1,850 per troy ounce. The forecast is based on the assumption that the virus is contained during the first quarter, but any extension into the second quarter could push prices higher.

site_title: Cargill to challenge Beyond Meat, Impossible Foods with new plant-based burger
summary: Cargill is launching plant-based hamburger patties and ground "fake meat" products in April, challenging Beyond Meat and Impossible Foods for sales in grocery stores, cafeterias, and restaurants. The move highlights the growing popularity of plant-based foods and competition from major meat companies, including Tyson Foods and WH Group's Smithfield Foods. Cargill's entry into the market is expected to intensify competition in the plant-based meat industry, potentially shifting consumer preferences.

site_title: These places just restricted travel from South Korea
summary: Fourteen countries and a US territory have restricted travel from South Korea due to the sharp rise in coronavirus cases, with the US Department of State issuing a level 2 travel advisory. Measures include banning entry for those who have been in South Korea in the past 14 days and mandatory health checks. Countries with restrictions include Israel, Bahrain, Jordan, Kiribati, Samoa, Brunei, UK, Turkmenistan, Kazakhstan, Macau, Oman, Ethiopia, Qatar, Uganda, and American Samoa, where travellers must self-quarantine for 14 days.

site_title: Chinese restaurants starved for cash as virus hits industry
summary: China's restaurant industry is severely impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, with dine-in revenue plummeting to zero in many establishments. The loss is estimated to be at least a few million yuan for some companies, with many forced to suspend dine-ins to curb the spread of the virus. To mitigate losses, some restaurants are turning to delivering fresh produce and prepared ingredients directly to customers, with some companies even partnering with e-commerce platforms to share employees. The industry's cash reserves are dwindling, with many firms predicting they can only survive for three months.

site_title: World's longest bull run set to end amid Malaysia power upheaval
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI Index is set to end its 12-year bull run due to political upheaval and global market concerns. The index has dropped 21% from its 2018 peak, amid worries over the coronavirus outbreak and potential changes to the government. Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's supporters are reportedly maneuvering to form a new government excluding Anwar Ibrahim, who is set to meet with the king on Monday. The move has led to uncertainty, weakening investor sentiment and pushing the index towards bear territory.

site_title: Malaysian PM Mahathir sends resignation letter to King
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has submitted a letter of resignation to the king, amid uncertainty over forming a new governing coalition. The move follows surprise talks between his party and opposition groups, including Anwar Ibrahim, who accuses Dr. Mahathir of plotting to form a new government. Dr. Mahathir's party has also quit the ruling coalition, leaving the fate of Malaysia's politics uncertain. The turmoil has spooked investors, driving down the country's stock market and currency.

site_title: India refiners getting rare oil cheap as China demand slows
summary: Indian refining companies are taking advantage of China's reduced demand for oil due to the coronavirus outbreak, snapping up rare crude grades at lower prices. Chinese refiners have cut output by 10% in February, leading to a surplus of crude supplies. Shipping rates have plummeted, making it cheaper for Indian refiners to buy suitable grades from areas like the Mediterranean and Latin America. Prices for some grades have fallen by as much as 15%, creating an opportunity for Indian refiners to buy new and rarely purchased grades at cheaper rates.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon down 1% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 33 points, or 1%, to 3,148.03 as of 1:04 pm on Monday, amid investor concerns over the novel coronavirus outbreak. The decline was driven by fears over the spike in cases in Japan and South Korea. Local banks, including DBS, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank, also dropped. In contrast, ST Engineering posted a 36.2% rise in Q4 net profit, while Singapore Medical Group edged down after a 25.1% jump in fourth-quarter net profit.

site_title: German conservatives brood over Merkel's successor
summary: Germany's conservative Christian Democratic Union (CDU) is set to unveil its new leadership as Angela Merkel's party faces an internal crisis over how to position itself against the extremes of right and left. CDU leader Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer is expected to reveal her plans, despite the party suffering its second-worst result in a regional election, placing third in Hamburg with 11.5% of votes. The party is likely to delay naming a chancellor candidate for upcoming parliamentary elections, with a party congress in May or June expected to anoint a new party chairman.

site_title: Singapore core inflation misses forecasts in January at 0.3%
summary: Singapore's core inflation rate in January missed forecasts at 0.3%, lower than the 0.6% in December and below the 0.9% expected by private-sector watchers. Headline inflation remained unchanged at 0.8%. The decline was attributed to a sharper fall in retail and other goods prices, and the impact of the COVID-19 outbreak on consumer-facing sectors. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and Ministry of Trade and Industry said inflationary pressures are expected to remain subdued, and domestic labour market conditions have softened, leading some economists to predict a potential easing of monetary policy in April.

site_title: UniCredit's Mustier withdraws as candidate for top HSBC job
summary: Jean Pierre Mustier, CEO of UniCredit, has withdrawn from consideration to become the next CEO of HSBC Holdings, adding uncertainty to the UK lender's executive suite. Mustier, who led Unicredit's turnaround, informed HSBC chairman Mark Tucker of his decision, leaving the search for a new CEO to drag on until potentially July. The lack of clarity at the top weighs on HSBC's shares, which have dropped 7% this year. The bank is undergoing its third major overhaul in a decade amid economic slowdown, the coronavirus outbreak, and Brexit.

site_title: Ping An to counter virus outbreak with tech as slowdown saps profit
summary: China's largest insurer, Ping An Insurance, is adapting to the COVID-19 outbreak by leveraging technology, despite a slump in life insurance sales. The company has moved all life-insurance activities online, while banking services have resumed over the internet. Despite a missed earnings estimate, Ping An's management remains optimistic, citing its technology investments and plans to accelerate digitalization. Analysts predict a slowdown in new business value, but the company is providing financial support to its agent force and sees potential for recovery in the second half of the year.

site_title: China allows non-residents of Wuhan to leave virus centre
summary: China has relaxed restrictions on non-residents of Wuhan, allowing them to leave the city if they show no symptoms and have no contact with patients. The city, the epicentre of China's virus epidemic, has been under lockdown since January 23. This move is part of efforts to contain the new coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end morning with steep losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.48% in the morning session on Monday, February 24, 2020, due to growing concerns over the coronavirus and a decline in oil prices. The Hang Seng Index fell 404.97 points to 26,903.84. The global spread of the virus and a plunge in oil prices hit energy firms, while banks and healthcare companies were also affected. The losses were largely attributed to the growing concerns over the virus and the impact on the global economy.

site_title: As the startup boom deflates, tech is humbled
summary: The tech startup boom is deflating, with over 30 startups laying off more than 8,000 jobs in the past four months. The layoffs follow a difficult 2019, where prominent "unicorns" fell flat on Wall Street, and investors are pulling back, with $763 billion in US venture capital funding over the past decade. Companies like Uber, WeWork, and Casper Sleep are struggling, and venture capitalists are becoming more skeptical. A pullback is unfolding in areas like delivery, cannabis, and real estate, with some startups cutting hundreds of staff members and others shutting down.

site_title: Anwar hails 'good meeting' with Mahathir amid Malaysia rumours
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad met with opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim, signaling a potential shakeup in the ruling coalition. Rumors of a new government without Anwar, who is poised to succeed Mahathir, sparked the meeting. Despite previous pledges to hand over power to Anwar, Mahathir said he would step down only after resolving inherited problems. The meeting comes amid economic uncertainty, with Malaysia's benchmark stock index having dropped over 20% from its peak in 2018. Anwar expressed confidence in the country's ability to weather the challenges, saying, "We've been through worse before."

site_title: Indonesia market ripe for alternative-lending firms, one player says
summary: A peer-to-peer funding platform, Robocash, has identified Indonesia as a promising market for alternative lending due to its diverse online lending segment and regulatory environment. The company believes that the market's potential for growth outweighs its higher risks, citing the presence of sharia-compliant financing options. This contrasts with other Southeast Asian countries like Myanmar, Cambodia, and the Philippines, which pose higher risks due to their less mature markets. Indonesia is seen as a sweet spot for industry players, alongside Bangladesh, which is also known for its micro-finance sector.

site_title: Indonesia central bank intervenes in FX, bond markets amid capital outflows
summary: Indonesia's central bank intervened in the spot currency, bond markets, and domestic forward markets amid outflows related to the spread of Covid-19 in South Korea. The rupiah weakened 0.9% to its lowest since January 8, trading at 13,890 per US dollar. The intervention is attributed to "flight to quality" away from emerging market assets, with Bank Indonesia's head of monetary management stating that there are outflows in the bond market and banks are short covering due to the jump in virus cases in Korea.

site_title: Pricey beef lasagne, mattresses burned twice among Brexit risks
summary: The UK's new economic relationship with the EU in 2021 may face significant disruptions, according to the Confederation of British Industry. Potential consequences include businesses incurring hundreds of pounds in extra costs, such as exporting beef lasagna and registering cosmetics. Mattress-makers may burn their products twice due to differing flammability resistance rules. The UK and EU must agree on mutual recognition of standards and assessment processes to avoid such disruptions, which could impact global competitiveness, jobs, and growth.

site_title: BreadTalk requests trading halt pending announcement
summary: BreadTalk Group, a Singapore-based food and beverage operator, requested a trading halt on Monday, Feb 24, 2020, pending an announcement. The company will release its financial results for the fourth quarter and full year ended Dec 31, 2019. BreadTalk shares closed at S$0.645 on Friday, up 1.6%. The trading halt will be in effect until further notice.

site_title: Gold jumps over 2% as virus spread spurs safe-haven demand
summary: Gold prices surged over 2% on Monday, reaching their highest since February 2013, amid concerns over the spread of the Covid-19 virus and its impact on global economic growth. The virus's rapid spread in several countries outside China heightened worries about a hit to global economic growth, prompting a flight to safe havens. Lower interest rates are expected, reducing the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion. Other safe-haven assets, including the US dollar and Japanese yen, also edged higher.

site_title: Viva plans 2-month turnaround on Australian refinery unit from late Q3
summary: Viva Energy, an Australian oil refiner, plans a 2-month maintenance turnaround at its Geelong refinery, starting late in Q3, with estimated costs up to US$93 million. The turnaround will reduce production by 1-1.5 million barrels and impact refining margins. The company will import refined products to replace lost production. Viva reported a 41% fall in underlying profit for 2019, largely due to squeezed refining margins and disappointing demand for marine diesel.

site_title: ARA, Straits Trading and JL Family Office's offer of loans to SMEs oversubscribed
summary: A S$5 million loan fund set up by JL Family Office, ARA Asset Management, and Straits Trading Company to support Singaporean SMEs facing cash-flow problems due to the virus outbreak has been oversubscribed. Over 100 businesses applied, with 60% meeting eligibility criteria, and the first loan was approved and disbursed in under 48 hours. The fund has received a S$3 million contribution from Gordon Tang, majority shareholder of SingHaiyi Group, and offers loans of up to S$50,000 with an interest rate of 0.5% per month and a 2% processing fee.

site_title: JPMorgan to start UK digital consumer bank: report
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co plans to launch a UK digital consumer bank, offering savings and loan products under the Chase brand, in the next few months. The bank has been discussing approvals with regulators and will be led by Clive Adamson, former head of supervision at the Financial Conduct Authority. This move enters JPMorgan into a crowded UK consumer-banking market, where fintech players like Monzo Bank and Starling Bank have attracted millions of customers. The launch may also compete with Goldman Sachs' online-only bank, Marcus.

site_title: Impact of coronavirus ripples across Asia: 'It has been quiet, like a cemetery'
summary: The coronavirus epidemic is significantly impacting global tourism, particularly in Asia, where countries reliant on Chinese tourists are feeling the effects. Asian countries like Vietnam, Thailand, Cambodia, Malaysia, and Singapore are expected to lose at least $3 billion in tourism-related revenues due to the absence of Chinese tourists and Western travelers spooked by the virus. The World Travel & Tourism Council estimated that global tourism contributed $8.8 trillion to the world economy in 2018. Airlines alone are expected to lose $29 billion in revenues this year, with some economists warning that the epidemic could be the biggest drag on global economic growth since the financial crisis.

images.alt_text: The Arashiyama Bamboo Forest, one of the most visited sites in Kyoto, Japan, was quiet enough to hear the bamboo creaking in the wind.

site_title: China's top steelmakers Baowu, Shagang see Q1 output down due to virus outbreak
summary: China's top steelmakers Baowu and Shagang expect Q1 output to decline due to the coronavirus outbreak. Baowu predicts a 5% drop in output, while Shagang anticipates a 9% decline in February and 5% in the first quarter. The companies attribute the decline to market demand dampening and logistical difficulties. Despite this, the industry association expects steel firms' performance to decline in the first half but notes that most firms will not incur default risks.

site_title: Malaysian politics in turmoil amid new coalition talk
summary: Malaysia's ruling coalition is in turmoil as Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's party and other groups discuss forming a new government without his anointed successor Anwar Ibrahim. The two have been old rivals, with Mahathir sacking Anwar in 1998. Tensions have been growing since their alliance to win 2018 elections, and a new coalition could lead to the dissolution of parliament and a change in prime minister. The king's role in the situation is unclear, and the move could have significant implications for Malaysian politics.

site_title: Lifestyle guru Barbara 'B' Smith dies of Alzheimer's at age 70
summary: Barbara 'B' Smith, a renowned fashion model, restaurateur, author, and lifestyle guru, has died at 70 due to early-onset Alzheimer's disease. Known as one of the most important African-American style mavens, Smith was a multiple award-winning broadcast talent and entrepreneur. She appeared on numerous magazine covers, commercials, and as a spokeswoman for several brands, and launched her signature product line, Groundbreaking Line, which debuted at Bed Bath & Beyond in 2001. Smith and her husband worked to raise awareness of Alzheimer's disease, particularly for people of color.

site_title: Virus-hit China set to postpone Parliament for first time in decades
summary: China is expected to postpone its annual Parliament session for the first time in decades due to the ongoing coronavirus outbreak, which has infected nearly 80,000 people and claimed over 2,500 lives. Top officials are distracted by tackling the virus, and Beijing has imposed quarantine measures on delegates, making a postponement "very likely." The decision could signal a desperate effort by authorities to maintain the appearance of normalcy, and it may also allow for a more realistic assessment of the country's economic and policy priorities.

site_title: South Korea airlines halt flights to Daegu, city with most virus cases
summary: South Korea's Korean Air Lines and Asiana Airlines have suspended flights to Daegu, the city with the largest number of coronavirus cases, until March 28 and March 9, respectively. This decision comes as South Korea reported 763 coronavirus cases as of Monday morning.

images.alt_text: South Korea's Korean Air Lines and Asiana Airlines said on Monday they are suspending flights to Daegu, the country's fourth-largest city with the largest number of coronavirus cases, for the time being.

site_title: South Korea companies prepare for worst after Samsung virus case
summary: South Korea's technology companies, including Samsung Electronics and LG Electronics, are taking precautions against the coronavirus after a rising number of cases in the country. A Samsung employee tested positive at a local production facility, leading to the shutdown of operations at the plant. The company plans to restart operations on Monday, but shares slid 3% due to the outbreak. The death toll rose to 7, with 161 new cases reported, bringing the total to 763 confirmed cases in the country.

site_title: New Zealand extends ban on China arrivals; no curbs yet for other nations
summary: New Zealand extends its ban on arrivals from mainland China for eight more days, bringing it into its fourth week, to prevent exposure to the coronavirus. The ban has taken a toll on the country's exports to China, with delays and cancellations of goods like timber, meat, and fruit. Despite fears of a pandemic, New Zealand has no plans to widen the ban to other countries, focusing on the epicenter of the outbreak. The government is prepared to assist businesses if a long-lasting economic shock occurs, but does not expect one at the moment.

site_title: South Korea becomes biggest coronavirus centre outside China
summary: South Korea reported 161 new coronavirus cases on Monday, bringing the nationwide total to 763, making it the world's largest total outside China. The majority of cases, 129, are linked to the Shincheonji Church of Jesus in Daegu. The country has seen a rapid surge in cases since a cluster emerged from the church, adding over 700 cases in less than a week.

site_title: China says has allocated 99.5b yuan for curbing coronavirus outbreak
summary: China has allocated 99.5 billion yuan (S$19.83 billion) to curb the coronavirus outbreak, according to Assistant Finance Minister Ou Wenhan. This allocation is part of the country's efforts to combat the spread of the virus, which has affected various regions in China. The funds will be used for measures such as testing, contact tracing, and medical supplies.

site_title: Comfort and glamour at Dolce & Gabbana as show goes on in Milan
summary: Dolce & Gabbana showcased its Fall/Winter 2020 collection in Milan, featuring oversized sweaters, woolly socks, and furry slippers. The show came after Giorgio Armani announced his empty theatre presentation due to the coronavirus outbreak. Some guests wore surgical masks, adding a touch of comfort and glamour to the event. The focus on practicality and comfort was a response to the current winter chill, highlighting the brand's ability to adapt to changing times.

site_title: South Korea braces for economic pain as virus cases soar
summary: South Korea's economic recovery is threatened by the rapidly spreading novel coronavirus, with the number of infections surging from 30 to over 760 in the past week. The epidemic is expected to limit domestic consumption and exports, particularly to China. The country's first vice-minister, Kim Yong Beom, warned that the outbreak poses a "large concern" to the economy, which was recovering after a late 2019 start. At least seven people have died from the virus in South Korea so far.

site_title: Spread of coronavirus confirms WHO fears, say experts
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has confirmed its fears about the rapid spread of the coronavirus, with cases rising sharply outside of China. Experts, including Professor Devi Sridhar, are warning of a shift from containment to mitigation strategies to reduce the negative impacts of continued transmission. The WHO and governments are urged to increase vigilance and prepare for a potential global crisis.

site_title: Prada brings in star designer Raf Simons to shake up look
summary: Prada appoints Belgian designer Raf Simons as co-creative director alongside Miuccia Prada, aiming to boost creativity and shake up the brand. The move comes as Prada recovers from several years of slumping sales, facing challenges from protests in Hong Kong and the coronavirus outbreak. Shares rose initially but declined, with analysts predicting the partnership could rejuvenate the brand and make it a target for acquisition. Simons, known for conceptual runway shows, hopes the collaboration will "send a message to the world that we should not forget creativity."

site_title: Bangkok has 100,000 empty apartments. It could soon have more
summary: Bangkok's condominium market is expected to face a bleak year due to the novel coronavirus outbreak, with foreigners accounting for as little as 10% of purchases in 2020, down from 20% two years ago. There are currently 100,000 vacant condominiums in and around Bangkok, and developers remain wary of the market, with some not planning to open new projects this year. The Thai economy is also expected to slow, with a forecasted 1.5% GDP growth rate, a six-year low, and a 19% decline in the Property Development Index over the past year.

site_title: China developers face cash crunch as virus freezes home sales
summary: China's developers face a cash crunch due to the coronavirus outbreak, with most having only a three-month cash buffer. The lockdowns and travel restrictions have halted home sales, putting pressure on developers with massive debts. The property market accounts for 7% of China's GDP and its collapse could affect demand for building materials, steel, and appliances, putting millions of jobs at risk. Authorities have taken steps to help, including allowing showrooms to open with limited visitor numbers, but the industry is seen as too big to fail, and the government is considering measures to support developers.

site_title: More libraries are doing away with overdue fines
summary: The Free Library of Philadelphia has ended its policy of charging fines on overdue materials, joining several other library systems, including Los Angeles, Chicago, Denver, and San Diego, in adopting a no-fee or amnesty policy. The policy change aims to encourage patrons to return books and other materials, rather than relying on fines. Instead, patrons who fail to return items may be required to replace them with new or gently used copies. This shift is seen as a way to promote accessibility and inclusivity in libraries, which remain essential fixtures in American communities.

site_title: Chinese consumers imperil V-shaped virus rebound
summary: Chinese consumers are fueling investor optimism as the country's new Covid-19 cases slow, with 648 confirmed cases on February 22, down from 397 the previous day. Despite this, signs of stress, such as frozen salaries and mass layoffs, suggest a slower recovery. China's industrial sector, which drove its post-Sars rebound, is now being driven by consumer spending, which is expected to be hit hard by falling domestic demand. Experts warn that it will take time to nurse China's consumers back to health, and the prospects for a quick and sustained recovery are looking shakier.

site_title: Virus spread beyond China drives investors to US dollar
summary: The rapid spread of COVID-19 beyond China has driven investors to the US dollar for safety, causing Asian currencies to slide. The World Health Organization expressed concerns over the growing number of cases without a clear link to China. The US dollar strengthened against other currencies, reaching an almost three-year peak against a basket of currencies, while gold and bonds rose in response to risk aversion. The spread of the virus has raised concerns about global economic growth, with China's GDP growth expected to slow and policymakers under pressure.

site_title: Global shares drop, gold surges as investors scurry for safety
summary: Global shares plummeted on Monday as the coronavirus outbreak worsened, with South Korea and Italy reporting new infections and deaths. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index fell 1.6% to its lowest since early February, while the US dollar rose against the yen. Gold surged to a seven-year high as investors sought safe-haven assets. Economists downgraded growth forecasts for China and the world, with Oxford Economics estimating a global pandemic could lead to nearly zero economic output growth in the first half of 2020.

site_title: Oil prices fall 2% on demand concerns as virus spreads outside China
summary: Oil prices fell 2% on Monday due to concerns about a hit to demand from the rapidly spreading coronavirus outbreak outside China. Brent crude dropped to $57.00 a barrel, while US crude futures fell to $52.12. The spread of the virus, with reported cases in South Korea, Italy, and Iran, has investors worried about a massive drop in business activity globally. China, the world's largest energy consumer, will adjust policy to help cushion the economic blow, while Saudi Arabia's Energy Minister dismissed a report of considering a break from the Opec+ alliance.

site_title: Raffles Medical FY2019 profit falls 15.2% on Chongqing hospital startup costs
summary: Raffles Medical Group posted a 15.2% drop in net profit to S$60.3 million for FY2019, due to startup costs for Raffles Hospital Chongqing. Revenue grew 6.7% to S$522 million, driven by healthcare and hospital services divisions. Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortisation (Ebitda) rose 2.8% to S$105.4 million. The company expects to remain profitable in 2020, barring unforeseen circumstances. A final dividend of 2.5 Singapore cents per share is recommended, with a total dividend of 2.5 cents per share for FY2019.

site_title: Keppel says no further impairment required for associate Floatel
summary: Keppel Corp has assessed that no further impairment is required for its associate company Floatel International based on Floatel's fourth quarter results. The group accounted for a S$51 million loss in Floatel, including impairment losses, and a S$11 million fair value loss on its investment. Floatel's Q4 results showed an unsustainable financial situation with liquidity under pressure, casting significant doubt on its ability to continue as a going concern. However, Floatel has initiated discussions with key creditors and its directors believe there are reasonable expectations of success.

site_title: Pepsi to buy online snacks retailer in China
summary: PepsiCo Inc plans to acquire online snacks retailer Be & Cheery in China for $705 million. Be & Cheery sells products such as nuts, dried fruits, and meat snacks online through major e-commerce platforms. The deal aims to expand Pepsi's presence in China, where it saw double-digit revenue growth last year. The acquisition is part of Pepsi's efforts to diversify its portfolio and compete with declining sugary soft drink sales worldwide. The deal is subject to shareholder and regulatory approvals.

site_title: ST Engineering Q4 profit rises 36.2% to S$169.5m
summary: ST Engineering posted a 36.2% rise in Q4 net profit to S$169.5 million, driven by a 47.2% increase in marine sector contributions and 45.3% growth in aerospace sector revenue. Full-year net profit rose 16.9% to S$577.9 million, with earnings per share increasing to 18.53 Singapore cents. The company proposed a final dividend of 10 Singapore cents per share, subject to shareholder approval at the upcoming annual general meeting.

site_title: Xi says China facing 'big test' with coronavirus, global impact spreads
summary: China's leader, Xi Jinping, described the new coronavirus epidemic as the country's largest public health emergency since its founding in 1949, calling it a "big test" for the nation. The global outbreak has killed over 2,400 people, with China being the worst-hit, and has prompted containment measures in Italy and Iran, including lockdowns and travel bans. The World Health Organization praised China's handling of the epidemic, but criticized the country for silencing early warnings from a whistleblower doctor.

site_title: Eight companies buy back S$8 million in shares
summary: Eight companies in Singapore have collectively purchased S$8 million worth of shares in a single trading session. The Straits Times Index declined 0.7% over the period, with the iEdge S-REIT Index generating a 6.6% total return for 2020.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ST Engg, SPH, CapitaLand, Raffles Medical, Wing Tai, Hong Leong Asia
summary: ST Engineering posted a 36.2% rise in Q4 net profit to S$169.5 million, driven by increased contributions from its marine sector and aerospace arm. Singapore Press Holdings acquired five aged care assets in Japan for S$65.8 million, while CapitaLand released one month's worth of security deposits to offset mall tenants' rental payments amid the virus outbreak. Raffles Medical Group reported a 15.2% drop in net profit, while Wing Tai Asia sold 70% of its latest condominium project. Hong Leong Asia received a time extension to release its FY2019 results due to the Covid-19 outbreak.

site_title: Climate change gets first mention in G-20 finance communique of Trump era
summary: The G-20 finance communique for the first time mentioned climate change, referencing the Financial Stability Board's work on its implications for financial stability. However, the US blocked a broader reference to climate change as an economic risk, instead allowing a limited mention in the context of the FSB's work. Despite this, several G-20 sources said it marked progress toward greater recognition of the economic risks posed by climate change. The communique forecasts a modest pick-up in global growth this year and next, citing downside risks from geopolitical and trade tensions.

site_title: Singapore stocks decline at Monday's open; STI down 0.6%
summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.6% at the Monday open, falling 19.03 points to 3,162, with 145 losers outpacing 42 gainers. Key movers included Yangzijiang Shipbuilding and ComfortDelGro, while DBS, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank also fell. Conversely, Singtel rose 0.3% and ST Engineering gained 0.7%. CapitaLand and Singapore Press Holdings announced significant deals, including releasing security deposits and acquiring Japanese assets, respectively.

site_title: SPH to buy 5 aged care assets in Japan for 5.26b yen
summary: SPH to acquire five aged care assets in Japan for 5.26 billion yen (S$65.8 million), expanding its business footprint in markets with fast-ageing populations. The assets, with a total capacity of 365 beds, offer independent living services in Hokkaido, Nara, and Tokyo. The deal is part of SPH's strategy to grow its recurring income base through the acquisition of cash-yielding assets in defensive sectors. The acquisition is expected to complete by March 2020.

site_title: Sanders would 'absolutely' use US military if needed
summary: Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders has stated that he would "absolutely" use the US military if necessary to protect US interests and allies, citing threats to the American people and NATO allies. He also expressed willingness to meet with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, unlike some other Democratic candidates. Sanders listed criteria for deploying military forces, including threats to the American people and allies, and emphasized the importance of working with other countries in alliance.

site_title: China pushes factories to reopen, risking renewed virus spread
summary: China is easing restrictions on factories to reopen, despite the risk of a renewed coronavirus spread. The country's leader Xi Jinping has urged companies to resume production to meet economic growth targets. However, labor shortages and restrictions on workers from heavily infected areas remain a concern. The government has relaxed rules, allowing factories to operate without quarantining workers as long as they meet new safety guidelines. The push to restart production risks a second wave of the virus, with experts warning that a peak may occur in late February or early March.

images.alt_text: China is trying to get people back to work, risking a renewed spread of the coronavirus.

site_title: JLC Advisors' Jeffrey Ong faces 12 charges over Allied Tech's S$33m
summary: JLC Advisors' managing partner Jeffrey Ong faces 12 additional charges related to Allied Tech's S$33 million missing funds, bringing the total to 38. The charges include forgery of a cheque and alleged criminal breach of trust as a lawyer of escrow funds. Ong allegedly misappropriated funds between October 2017 and August 2018, with the missing amount being S$33.83 million. The punishment for the crime under Section 409 of the Penal Code is imprisonment for life or up to 20 years, as well as a fine. Ong is being remanded until April 7.

site_title: Australia, NZ shares drop as virus spread beyond China rattles sentiment
summary: Australian and New Zealand shares plummeted on Monday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index falling 2% and the S&P/NZX 50 index dropping 1.25%, amid concerns over the coronavirus outbreak's global impact. The International Monetary Fund trimmed its 2020 growth outlook for China and the world economy, while cases in South Korea, Italy, and Iran further dimmed global economic prospects. Energy stocks, including Woodside Petroleum and Oil Search, fell up to 5.9%, while gold miners rose 4.3% as investors sought safe-haven assets.

images.alt_text: Australian shares posted broad-based declines on Monday as a spike in fresh coronavirus cases outside China deepened concerns surrounding the epidemic's impact on global economy.

site_title: Singapore is Reit hub with most foreign IPOs
summary: Singapore has emerged as a leading Reit hub with 41 listings, including seven foreign-currency denominated ones, surpassing Hong Kong's 11. The city-state's favourable tax regime and flexible regulations have attracted international investment trusts, with Singapore-listed Reits boasting a 6.2% average forward dividend yield, one of the highest globally. This has led to significant trading activity, with Reit listings accounting for the majority of IPO proceeds in three of the last five years.

site_title: Canada warns indigenous rail blockades could cripple economy
summary: Canada's indigenous rail blockades, which have blocked rail lines for over two weeks, pose a significant threat to the country's economy, with Prime Minister Justin Trudeau urging a swift resumption of dialogue to end the crisis. The blockades, which began as a protest against a natural gas pipeline, have forced the Canadian National Railway to suspend freight traffic and lay off 1,000 people. Transport Minister Marc Garneau warned that the blockades could cripple the economy and even affect GDP if they continue. Tribal leaders have set conditions for talks to restart, including the withdrawal of federal police from ancestral lands.

site_title: Creator of iconic Lego figure dead at 78
summary: Jens Nygaard Knudsen, the 78-year-old designer behind the iconic Lego minifigure, has died in hospice care from amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). Knudsen, who worked at Lego from 1968 to 2000, created the minifigure with movable arms and legs in the 1970s and was also responsible for developing classic themes such as Space and Pirates. His design philosophy emphasized the child's imagination and play, with the minifigure having a neutral happy expression and no sex or race. Knudsen passed away last Wednesday at a hospice centre in Denmark.

site_title: Italy announces three deaths linked to coronavirus
summary: Italy reported three deaths linked to the coronavirus, with 152 confirmed cases, including the three deceased, primarily in the Lombardy region. Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte urged people not to panic and follow health authorities' advice. Measures to contain the spread include lockdowns, closures of gathering spots, and school closures in affected areas. The World Health Organization (WHO) plans to send experts to Italy to investigate the rapid increase in cases.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Budget 2020 review
summary: The Money FM podcast discusses the Budget 2020 review, breaking down its four segments: GST, Covid-19, Caring for Singaporeans, and Sustainability. The review aims to benefit Singaporeans and businesses, with key initiatives including increased support for low-income families and enhanced sustainability measures.

site_title: New Zealand moves to ban vaping ads, sales to minors
summary: New Zealand is introducing laws banning all e-cigarette advertisements and sales to minors, following a string of vaping-related deaths and illnesses globally. The government aims to regulate the market while allowing smokers to use vaping products as a quit tool. The bill, proposed to Parliament on Monday, also restricts the sale of e-cigarettes and smokeless tobacco in smoke-free areas and gives the government powers to recall or suspend products. The move aims to protect children while supporting smokers who want to quit using vaping products.

site_title: CapitaLand to release 1-month security deposits for mall tenants as part of virus relief package
summary: CapitaLand, a real estate company operating Singapore's largest mall network, announced a virus relief package for its mall tenants. The package includes releasing one month's worth of security deposits to offset rental payments for March 2020, on top of potential flexible rental payments and a one-time rental rebate of up to half-a-month for eligible tenants. This support aims to ease cash flows for food services and retail tenants operating 3,500 stores across CapitaLand malls in Singapore.

site_title: Coronavirus puts 'fragile' global recovery at risk: IMF to G-20
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warns that the global economic recovery, projected to reach 3.3% this year, is "fragile" due to the spread of the coronavirus pandemic. The IMF's Kristalina Georgieva says the virus could shave 0.1 percentage points from global growth and constrain China's growth to 5.6% this year. G-20 finance ministers and central bank governors expressed "real concern" over the economic ripple effects, with several calling for an international agreement to tax digital giants to alleviate the downside risks.

site_title: Singapore Medical Group posts 25.1% rise in Q4 profit
summary: Singapore Medical Group reported a 25.1% rise in Q4 net profit to S$3.7 million, driven by a 16.5% increase in revenue. The company declared a maiden dividend of 0.8 Singapore cent per share and expects to be impacted by the Covid-19 outbreak in the near term. Despite this, the group continues to explore growth opportunities in new markets. For the full year, net profit climbed 5.7% to S$13.7 million.

site_title: Hong Kong firms have no safety net in fight for survival
summary: Hong Kong's finance sector is facing a "tsunami-like" crisis due to the new coronavirus, with businesses already weakened by months of protests. The city lacks a bankruptcy process, forcing companies into liquidation. According to Johnson Kong, president of the Hong Kong Institute of Certified Public Accountants, if a proper legal framework existed, companies could have survived the hit. The lack of a safety net exacerbates the pain, as businesses struggle to survive amidst the economic downturn.

site_title: Experian eyes growth in Asia-Pacific
summary: Experian, a global information services company, is ramping up growth in the Asia-Pacific region with a string of investments and acquisitions. Despite the ongoing virus outbreak, the company sees a "very big" opportunity to grow in the region, where over 1 billion consumers lack access to financial services. Experian has invested or acquired seven companies since 2017, including Singapore-based Grab and Malaysian credit bureau Ramci. The company is focusing on building its innovation in-house, with an Asia-Pacific incubator and collaboration centre, and has developed solutions such as Experian X Score and Prove-ID to help consumers access financial services.

site_title: Slow recovery for Singapore companies with China operations amid outbreak
summary: Singapore companies with operations in China are expected to experience a slow recovery amid the ongoing Covid-19 outbreak. Despite the resumption of production in China's manufacturing sector, quarantines, and travel restrictions continue to hamper the movement of workers and goods. Analysts predict a 15% shortfall in production for the first quarter of 2020, with some companies, such as Valuetronics Holdings, expecting revenue shortfalls due to the temporary drop in production. Companies with strong financial positions and diversified business operations are better equipped to weather the storm, but the long-term impact of the outbreak remains uncertain.

site_title: Mega rally to kick off Trump's first official visit to India
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to kick off his first official visit to India with a massive "Namaste Trump" rally in Ahmedabad, Gujarat, on Monday. The two-day visit includes talks with Prime Minister Narendra Modi in New Delhi, with a visit to the Taj Mahal and discussions on trade, defence, and religious freedom. Despite warm rhetoric, trade tensions and disagreements on issues such as defence and Iran oil remain a significant point of friction. The visit is seen as more about pomp and ceremony than concrete agreements, with smaller agreements on Harley-Davidson imports and nuclear reactors possibly on the cards.

site_title: Digibank contender Sheng Ye eyes Singapore homecoming
summary: Sheng Ye Capital, a Hong Kong-listed supply chain financing company, is planning to bid for a wholesale digital bank licence in Singapore. The company, backed by investors including Temasek and Olympus Capital, aims to leverage its experience in China to alleviate the SME financing problem in Singapore. Led by chairman and founder Jeff Tung, a Singaporean naturalised in Hong Kong, the bid is seen as a homecoming for the entrepreneur, who wants to bring his experience to alleviate the SME financing problem in Singapore.

site_title: Gold glitters as viral gloom shines new light on rise in price since mid-Dec
summary: Gold prices have surged since mid-December, driven by the COVID-19 pandemic and its economic impact. The virus has disrupted global supply chains, leading investors to seek safe-haven assets like gold. The metal has broken above its previous seven-year high and year high, trading at $1,619 per ounce. A bullish flag pattern on the charts and Fibonacci analysis suggest potential resistance levels at $1,640 and $1,670 per ounce, while supports are at $1,611 and $1,590 per ounce. The stage is set for gold to continue its upward run amidst global uncertainty.

site_title: New coalition said to be in the making in Malaysia under Mahathir
summary: A new governing coalition in Malaysia is reportedly in the making, led by Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, with the support of 130 parliamentarians. The proposed coalition involves five parties, including Bersatu, Umno, a PKR splinter faction, PAS, and Amanah. PKR president Anwar Ibrahim confirmed attempts to shake up the Pakatan Harapan government, but no further information has been received. A new coalition requires at least 112 MPs, a majority of the 222 seats in Parliament, and Mahathir is waiting for an announcement from Umno on the new coalition.

site_title: Boris Johnson set to begin trade talks with US in two weeks: Telegraph
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson is set to begin trade talks with the US within the next two weeks, according to a report by the Telegraph. The UK government's "red lines" for the negotiations, to be published next week, will likely push back against US demands for greater access to the UK market by pharmaceutical firms. This move is seen as a response to US President Trump's recent tariff announcements, which have impacted the Asian garment industry. The outcome of the talks is yet to be determined.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson is prepared to begin trade talks with the United States within the coming two weeks, the Telegraph reported on Sunday.

site_title: FLT-FCOT merger: Will market ethos trump fairness?
summary: The proposed merger between Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT) and Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) is expected to be accretive to the distribution per unit (DPU) of both Reits, but FCOT unitholders may face a disadvantage due to the higher gearing and lower NAV compared to FLT. The merger's terms, including the issuance of new FLT units at a premium to NAV, may not be in the best interest of FCOT unitholders, who could benefit from the deal if FLT's market price continues to rise.

site_title: US dollar dented as Feb PMI disappoints
summary: The US dollar fell 0.59% against a basket of currencies after a disappointing February Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) reading, signaling stalled business activity in the manufacturing and services sectors. The euro rose 0.68% against the dollar, while the yen gained 0.5% despite being pressured by concerns over Japan's economy. The decline in the dollar was attributed to increased demand for safe havens amid the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Budget provides slight reprieve but virus fears linger
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.55% to close at 3,181.03, with a 39-point decline over the week. Analysts say Budget measures may not be enough to mitigate Covid-19's impact on local companies. Despite this, the market has been absorbing relief measures.

site_title: Covid-19: Chinese restaurants starved for cash
summary: China's restaurant industry is severely impacted by the COVID-19 epidemic, with dine-in revenue plummeting and many establishments forced to close. The country's 1.4 billion population is under quarantine or reluctant to venture out, leading to significant losses for restaurants. Many are turning to delivery services, selling fresh and frozen products, and offering prepared ingredients to stay afloat. However, the situation remains uncertain, with many facing cash flow pressures and potential job losses. Authorities are introducing measures to support the industry, but the long-term impact on employment remains a concern.

images.alt_text: A man eats in an almost empty restaurant in Beijing. Fears over the Covid-19 coronavirus have kept people at home, resulting in restaurants suffering massive drops in walk-in customers.

site_title: At Uniqlo, sustainability is in its jeans
summary: Uniqlo, the Japanese clothing brand, is prioritizing sustainability in its operations, aiming to create a more sustainable society. The company has developed a water-efficient washing process for jeans, reducing water usage by up to 99%, and plans to use this technology on all jeans made and sold by its parent company, Fast Retailing, in 2020. Additionally, Uniqlo aims to reduce single-use plastic by 85% globally by the end of 2020, with plans to phase out plastic bags in Singapore. The company's CEO emphasizes the importance of sustainability in the apparel industry, seeking to redefine what it means to be sustainable without compromising quality or value.

site_title: Spike in Covid-19 cases in Italy, South Korea, Iran
summary: A sharp rise in Covid-19 cases has been reported in South Korea, Italy, and Iran, sparking international concern. South Korea has seen over 600 cases and six deaths, while Italy has reported 132 cases and imposed curbs in affected areas. Iran has reported 43 cases with eight deaths. The virus has spread to 26 countries, killing around two dozen people, and has had a significant impact on China's economy. The World Health Organization has expressed concern about the rapid spread of the virus, particularly in areas without a clear link to China.

site_title: DBS delivers care packages to hospitals, communities
summary: DBS Bank is collaborating with social enterprises and vendors to distribute care packages and food to healthcare professionals in Singapore amid the Covid-19 pandemic. Over two weeks, 25,000 staff from seven public hospitals will receive items such as muscle ache kits, moisturisers, and facial masks. The initiative aims to show support and gratitude for healthcare staff's dedication and sacrifice, while also encouraging them that together they can overcome the virus.

site_title: Intuit nears deal to buy Credit Karma for US$7b: WSJ
summary: Intuit Inc is close to acquiring Credit Karma Inc for approximately US$7 billion in a cash and stock deal, according to the Wall Street Journal. The purchase would be Intuit's largest in its 37-year history and would deepen the maker of TurboTax into the consumer finance space. The acquisition is expected to be announced by Monday.

site_title: Broadway Industrial served 2 writs of summons, statements of claim
summary: Broadway Industrial Group received two writs of summons and statements of claim totaling approximately S$9.3 million related to the sale of its foam plastics solutions and flow control device businesses. The claims were served by Broadway Holding III Limited and two subsidiaries of the purchaser, alleging breaches of warranties and liability for losses. The company will be required to provide an indemnity for certain losses.

site_title: G-20 calls for coordinated virus response; IMF trims forecasts
summary: The Group of 20 (G-20) countries called for a coordinated response to the coronavirus outbreak, with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) predicting a lower China growth rate of 5.6% this year due to the pandemic, shaving 0.1 percentage points from global growth. The IMF also warned of more dire scenarios if the outbreak continues. Despite this, China reported a decline in new deaths and cases, and the World Health Organization (WHO) expressed concerns about the spread of the virus globally.

site_title: UK pianist Alexis Ffrench bids to change image of classical music
summary: British pianist Alexis Ffrench aims to change the perception of classical music as stuffy and outdated by using his fresh take on the genre and growing status to reach new audiences. With nearly 2 million regular listeners on Spotify, Ffrench is determined to use his influence to help young people who are disadvantaged in the classical music world. His latest album, Dreamland, features "lyrical piano songs" inspired by fans who have used his music to cope with life struggles, and he credits his disciplined upbringing for instilling in him a drive to succeed.

site_title: Hong Leong Asia given more time to release results on Covid-19 fallout
summary: Hong Leong Asia has been granted an extension by the Singapore Exchange to release its FY2019 results by March 31 due to the impact of the Covid-19 outbreak on its operations in China, where more than 80% of its revenue comes from. The company cited logistical difficulties and cybersecurity concerns as reasons for the delay, with some employees and auditors facing travel restrictions and quarantine measures. The extension will allow the company to complete its audit process and finalize its financial results.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report covers the week's tanker and dry bulk market. The Capesize market remains low, with the Atlantic improving and the Pacific Transatlantic C10 gaining modestly. The Panamax market saw significant gains, with the P1A Transatlantic round voyage increasing by $1,380. The Supramax/Ultramax market also improved, with the Baltic Supramax Index making ground. The Handysize sector showed signs of recovery, with the Baltic Handysize Index making gains for the first time since 2020. The tanker market remained steady, with the VLCC market in the Middle East static due to the ongoing effect of the Coronavirus.

site_title: Johnson under pressure to scrap third runway
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson is under pressure to scrap plans for a third runway at London Heathrow Airport, despite his previous pledge to halt the project due to environmental and aesthetic concerns. Johnson backed the high-speed railway HS2, but construction of the new runway is expected to produce significant carbon emissions. Environmental groups, including Greenpeace, are taking legal action against the project, citing concerns over noise, air pollution, and carbon emissions. A decision to scrap the runway could be made easier with the upcoming court verdict.

site_title: Covid-19: Millions of Chinese firms face collapse if banks don't act fast
summary: Millions of Chinese firms are facing financial collapse if banks don't provide immediate support due to the COVID-19 outbreak. A survey found that nearly a third of small- and medium-sized companies have only enough cash to cover fixed expenses for a month, with many struggling to meet upcoming debt and salary payment deadlines. China's banks have offered limited relief, with only 5% of small businesses receiving assistance from Industrial & Commercial Bank of China. Without immediate support, many businesses may be forced to shut down, posing a significant risk to China's economy.

site_title: US feels the ripple effects of Covid-19 as indexes dip
summary: US stocks fell sharply last week as warnings from Apple and others raised concerns about the economic impact of the ongoing Covid-19 outbreak. Infection clusters in Chinese prisons, South Korea, Italy, and other nations have scuppered hopes that the virus's spread could be slowing. The US stock market indexes are dipping, reflecting the global ripple effects of the pandemic.

site_title: Silver bullets from the Budget
summary: Singapore's 2020 Budget aims to cushion businesses against the economic slowdown caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. The government has introduced a range of measures, including a S$8.3 billion support package, to provide relief to affected sectors and individuals. Experts believe the measures will help businesses and citizens navigate the uncertain economic landscape. However, some critics argue that more support is needed, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises, to mitigate the impact of the pandemic. The government has emphasized the importance of resilience and long-term transformation in driving Singapore's economic growth.

site_title: Clearing the air on QR and disclosures
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has clarified its risk-based approach to quarterly reporting, which will require companies to wait longer between updates and instead comply with continuous disclosure requirements. The clarification comes after criticism of companies not disclosing litigation-related information promptly. RegCo has stated that companies involved in significant litigation must disclose both price-sensitive and trade-sensitive information. The move aims to protect investors and prevent disclosures snafus, but some argue for clearer criteria for regulatory concerns.

site_title: Universal whistleblowing law: Market mixed over need for it in Singapore
summary: Singapore lacks a comprehensive whistleblower protection law, but certain offenses are protected under specific legislation. Experts say the absence of a robust policy has discouraged whistleblowers from coming forward due to fear of retaliation. The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) plans to consult the market on hardcoding the policy into its Listing Rules, which would provide more targeted protection for whistleblowers. However, some experts argue that existing laws, such as defamation protection, already offer adequate safeguard for whistleblowers, and separate legislation may not be necessary.

site_title: Monese serves those shunned by big banks
summary: Monese, a UK-based digital bank, is catering to newly-arrived foreigners who struggle to open traditional accounts, a gap it spotted in early 2000. Founded by Estonia-born entrepreneur Norris Koppel, the app-based bank aims to provide financial services to those neglected by established lenders.

site_title: Avoid non-essential travel to Daegu and Cheongdo in South Korea, says MOH
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) in Singapore advises travellers to avoid non-essential trips to Daegu city and Cheongdo county in South Korea due to the increase in confirmed coronavirus cases. Those with recent travel history to these areas will be referred to hospitals for further assessment and may be asked to identify themselves. The MOH also advises travellers to exercise caution and monitor developments, with measures in place to reduce transmission risk at Changi Airport and at immigration checks.

site_title: SGX grants Hong Leong Asia time extension to release FY19 results
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has granted Hong Leong Asia a time extension to release its FY2019 results by March 31, due to the impact of the Covid-19 outbreak on the company's operations in China. Hong Leong Asia's major revenue contributions come from China, and the company's subsidiaries are facing logistical difficulties and travel restrictions, affecting the completion of external audits. The company needs more time to finalize its FY2019 results.

site_title: Covid-19: No new cases reported; two more discharged from hospital
summary: Singapore reports no new Covid-19 cases, maintaining a total of 89 cases. Two more patients have been discharged, bringing the total number of recoveries to 51. Most of the 38 confirmed cases still in hospital are stable or improving. The Health Ministry has identified 2,812 close contacts, with 908 currently quarantined.

site_title: Covid-19 hits shipping, spreading global economic strain
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic is hitting global shipping, causing a significant economic strain. The Baltic Dry Index, which measures the price of moving goods, has reached historic lows, reflecting the impact of Chinese factories on the global market. China, which accounts for 40% of global seaborne trade, is experiencing a severe outbreak, leading to lockdowns, worker shortages, and disruptions in ports. This has resulted in a decline in demand for goods, impacting exports to China and other countries, including the US and Europe. Economists warn of weeks of chaos for manufacturing supply lines and global trade, with no clear timeline for when restrictions will be lifted.

site_title: Trump plans to raise issue of religious freedom with Indian PM Modi: official
summary: US President Donald Trump will discuss religious freedom with Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi during their meetings next week, citing concerns over the Indian government's actions on Muslims and secular traditions. The issue has been a point of contention, with protests and criticism abroad over the citizenship law and Kashmir's special autonomy. Trump will emphasize the importance of democracy and religious freedom in both countries, while Modi's government has denied bias against India's 180 million Muslims. The visit marks a significant diplomatic engagement between the two nations.

site_title: More singles securing HDB flats after 2013 rule change
summary: Singles in Singapore are securing more HDB flats after a 2013 rule change allowed them to buy new flats as first-time applicants. As of 2020, 15,700 singles aged 35 and above have secured homes, with 7,700 collecting keys to their new flats. The Housing and Development Board (HDB) will offer more two-room build-to-order flats in non-mature towns, aiming to cater to the growing number of singles. The HDB has disbursed S$251 million in housing grants to singles buying BTO flats since 2013, with the Enhanced CPF Housing Grant (EHG) providing up to S$40,000 to eligible first-timer singles.

images.alt_text: HDB said it will continue to monitor the demand and calibrate its supply of two-room flats to better meet the housing needs, so that more singles will be able to realise their dream of owning a home.

site_title: UOB, Pathlight School team up to assemble care packs
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has partnered with Pathlight School to assemble 1,000 care packs for disadvantaged families in Central Singapore District, in response to the novel coronavirus outbreak. Each care pack includes essential items such as surgical face masks, hand sanitiser, and Vitamin C pastilles. The initiative aims to support those in need during this challenging time.

images.alt_text: Volunteers from UOB sourced and acquired items for the care packs which were then put together by student volunteers from Pathlight School.

site_title: The millennial bug: Redefining consumption in Indonesia
summary: Indonesia's millennial workforce, comprising nearly 70% of the current workforce, is significantly impacting various industries. Their lifestyle choices, including a preference for health-conscious habits and online shopping, are influencing property, finance, e-commerce, and media sectors. This demographic shift is redefining consumption patterns and driving growth in these industries. As a result, businesses are adapting to cater to the changing needs and preferences of millennials, shaping the future of Indonesia's economy.

site_title: Boeing suspends co-workers of pilot at centre of 737 MAX scrutiny
summary: Boeing has suspended three employees who worked with former chief technical pilot Mark Forkner, at the center of the 737 MAX scrutiny, as a federal grand jury investigates whether he intentionally misled the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) about the Maneuvering Characteristics Augmentation System (MCAS). The employees were placed on administrative leave amid a US criminal investigation, which also examines statements made to the FAA by Forkner. The moves come after Boeing's CEO, Dave Calhoun, vowed to stamp out the disturbing behavior revealed in internal messages.

site_title: More may be prepared to speak up on corporate malfeasance
summary: Singapore is set to hardcode its whistleblowing policy into the Listing Rules, aiming to encourage more people to come forward and expose corporate malfeasance. Experts believe this move will give whistleblowers the confidence to report wrongdoing without fear of reprisals. Companies are advised to adopt whistleblowing policies as an additional framework to safeguard against misconduct. The policy change is expected to increase protection for whistleblowers and reduce the likelihood of retaliation.

site_title: Wing Tai Asia sells 70% of new condo The M over weekend
summary: Wing Tai Asia sold 70% of its new condo, The M, over the weekend, with 360 units sold at an average price of S$2,450 per square foot. The majority of buyers are Singaporeans in their 30s and 40s, drawn to the project's prime location, unique design concept, and reasonable pricing. Despite the Covid-19 outbreak, over 2,000 people visited the sales gallery, and balloting was carried out to manage the high demand. The condominium is expected to be completed by the first quarter of 2024.

site_title: Concern over coronavirus spread grows with cases jumping in South Korea, Italy and Iran
summary: International concern over the spread of coronavirus grew with sharp rises in infections in South Korea, Italy, and Iran. South Korea reported over 600 cases and six deaths, while Italy imposed stringent curbs in affected areas. Iran reported 43 cases and eight deaths. The World Health Organization expressed concern about the virus's rapid spread, noting that it has killed 2,442 people in China and has spread to 26 countries. The economic impact of the disease is also significant, with the International Monetary Fund predicting a 5.6% growth rate in China and a lower global growth rate.

site_title: 'Not good enough' US Senator says of Bloomberg's non-disclosure agreement pledge
summary: US presidential candidate Michael Bloomberg has said his company has identified three women bound by non-disclosure agreements related to his past conduct, which he will release if they choose. Senator Elizabeth Warren criticized the move, calling it "not good enough," and urged a blanket release to allow women to share their stories. Bloomberg also announced an end to confidentiality agreements for sexual harassment claims at his company, citing a culture of silence and women not feeling safe.

site_title: Twitter suspends group of pro-Bloomberg accounts over 'platform manipulation'
summary: Twitter suspended around 70 accounts promoting US Democratic presidential candidate Michael Bloomberg, citing platform manipulation and spam policy violations. The accounts, which included duplicative content and coordinated efforts, were targeted for permanent suspension or account challenges. The move comes as Bloomberg's campaign invests heavily in online advertising and social media promotion, with paid organisers receiving $2,500 a month to promote his candidacy. Twitter's action aims to prevent artificial engagement and amplification of conversation.

site_title: JPMorgan, United Airlines renew credit card deal into 2029
summary: United Airlines Holdings Inc and JPMorgan Chase & Co have renewed their credit card partnership through 2029, giving the airline an extra $400 million this year. The new deal, combined with an amended pact with Visa, aims to drive growth across United's credit card portfolio. United President Scott Kirby, who will become CEO in May, has been pushing for the deal, citing its potential to strengthen ties with partners and drive industry growth.

site_title: Leow is SGA President's Trophy winner
summary: Singapore Golf Association President's Trophy winner for 2019 is James Leow, a South-east Asia Games individual gold medallist.

site_title: Covid-19: More funding for tourism firms to train staff; cash to shore up guides' wages
summary: The Singapore Tourism Board, SkillsFuture Singapore, and Workforce Singapore have introduced measures to support tourism companies hit by the novel coronavirus outbreak. These include funding for training course fees (up to 90% of costs) and salary support for hotels and guides (up to 70% and $10/hour, respectively). Additionally, tour guides will receive a $1,000 payout over three months to help with living expenses. The moves aim to bolster the tourism sector and position Singapore for a strong recovery.

site_title: Tokyo 2020 postpones volunteer training over virus fears
summary: Tokyo 2020 Olympic organisers postponed volunteer training due to the coronavirus outbreak, but reaffirmed the Games' July 24 start date. Organisers will evaluate each event on a case-by-case basis, and participants will be asked to take preventative measures. Despite mounting fears and cases in Japan, there is no consideration of cancelling the Games, according to the International Olympic Committee.

site_title: UK begins repatriating citizens from virus-stricken Japan cruise ship
summary: The British government has begun repatriating its citizens from the Diamond Princess cruise ship, quarantined off Tokyo, due to the novel coronavirus outbreak. A flight carrying 32 British and European passengers, along with British government and medical staff, departed Japan on Saturday and is expected to arrive in the UK on Saturday morning. Passengers will undergo a 14-day quarantine upon arrival. This comes after hundreds of passengers were allowed to disembark after testing negative for the virus.

site_title: Sanders blasts Russia for reportedly trying to boost his presidential campaign
summary: Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders warned Russia to stay out of US elections after American officials reported Moscow was trying to aid his campaign. Sanders, considered the front-runner for the Democratic nomination, said if elected president, he would ensure Russia does not interfere in American elections. This comes as Sanders is favored to win the Nevada caucuses on Saturday.

images.alt_text: Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders on Friday warned Russia to stay out of US elections after American officials had told him Moscow was trying to aid his campaign.

site_title: Japan confirms four more coronavirus cases, to close a school for two days
summary: Japan confirmed four new coronavirus cases, bringing the total to 99. A 60-year-old teacher in Chiba prefecture was hospitalized while showing symptoms and will close her school for two days. Two other cases, a 60-year-old man and a 50-year-old man, were confirmed in Kumamoto prefecture. Over 600 cases have been reported on the quarantined Diamond Princess cruise ship.

images.alt_text: One of the new cases is a woman in her 60s who is a junior high school teacher in Chiba prefecture, east of Tokyo, according to a prefectural government official.

site_title: Italy towns under lockdown as first European coronavirus death reported
summary: Italy has locked down 10 towns following the emergence of coronavirus cases, with the first European death reported. A 78-year-old man from the Veneto region, Adriano Trevisan, died in hospital after testing positive for the virus. The Italian health minister confirmed the death, which occurred hours after measures were taken to isolate affected areas in Lombardy. The country has seen a significant increase in cases, with 15 new infections reported in the Lombardy region.

site_title: China's central bank will guide interest rates lower to aid virus-hit economy: state media
summary: China's central bank will guide interest rates lower to aid the virus-hit economy, according to Deputy Governor Liu Guoqiang. The bank will release more liquidity to banks by adjusting reserve requirement ratios, and benchmark deposit rates will be adjusted at an appropriate time. Liu stated that the epidemic's impact on China's economy will be limited and that the country will meet its economic and social development targets this year. China's economic fundamentals are sound, with ample foreign currency reserves to support its yuan currency.

site_title: For Harry and Meghan, no more 'royal' in their brand
summary: Prince Harry and Meghan, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, have agreed to stop using the title "royal" in their philanthropic and commercial activities after this spring. They will withdraw from official royal duties and pursue new lives in the private sector, retaining their residence, Frogmore Cottage, and Sussex titles. The couple had planned to use the name "SussexRoyal" but were unable to secure trademark applications. They will continue to support charitable causes and may use the titles of Duke and Duchess of Sussex in their new ventures.

site_title: South Korea reports 142 more virus cases, bringing tally to 346
summary: South Korea reported 142 new coronavirus cases, bringing the national tally to 346, with 92 linked to a hospital in Cheongdo, a city in southern Korea. This is the sharpest spike in infections yet, surpassing the national toll outside of China. The jump in cases follows a similar spike among members of a religious sect in the nearby city of Daegu.

site_title: Covid-19 could lop US$27.8b off Asia-Pac airline revenue
summary: The International Air Transport Association (IATA) estimates that US$27.8 billion in revenue will be lost by Asia-Pacific airlines this year due to the coronavirus crisis, with a 13% decline in passenger demand, mostly in China. Airlines in China are expected to lose around US$12.8 billion in revenues, while carriers outside the region are projected to lose US$1.5 billion. This brings worldwide airline revenue lost to the virus to a projected US$29.3 billion, with some relief expected from lower fuel prices and government support.

images.alt_text: "This will be a very tough year for airlines," IATA CEO Alexandre de Juniac said in a statement. "Stopping the spread of the virus is the top priority."

site_title: 'Massive risk' drives ESG deadline at top Finnish funds
summary: Two of Finland's largest pension funds, Ilmarinen Mutual Pension Insurance Co and Varma Mutual Pension Insurance Co, aim to achieve carbon neutrality by 2035, with combined assets of $108 billion. They plan to limit investments in companies that don't take climate change seriously and develop tools to better assess companies' ESG abilities. Varma plans to exit thermal coal exposure by 2025 and oil explorers' stocks by 2030, while Ilmarinen aims to reach carbon neutrality through a portfolio-management tool.
