Investor commitments to carbon neutrality are multiplying, with the Net-Zero Asset Owner Alliance representing nearly $4 trillion.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: KIMLY to acquire S$55.8 million portfolio of properties for S$45.8 million. CNMC Goldmine Holdings posts a 80.5% decline in profit to US$244,004 for its fiscal fourth quarter. Isetan Singapore expects a substantially higher net loss for FY2019 due to impairment charges. Far East Orchard reported a net profit of S$26 million in 2019, down 21% from 2018.

site_title: How legendary Palmer teed off with Rolex brand
summary: Arnold Palmer, a legendary golfer, partnered with Rolex to launch a line of golf watches in 1959. The partnership allowed Palmer to wear the iconic timepiece on the golf course, symbolizing his status as a golf icon. The collaboration marked a significant moment in the brand's history, as it helped Rolex become synonymous with golf and cement Palmer's status as a style icon. The partnership remains an enduring legacy of Palmer's golfing career.

site_title: 'Friends' cast to reunite in HBO Max special
summary: The cast of popular TV show "Friends" is set to reunite for an untitled, unscripted HBO Max special. The special, along with all 236 episodes of the series, will be available on the streaming service when it launches in May. The reunion comes 15 years after the show's original run and follows the show's removal from Netflix. The cast, including David, Jennifer, Courteney, Matt, Lisa, and Matthew, will be reuniting for the special, which will be programmed alongside the entire "Friends" library.

site_title: Coronavirus: No new cases in Singapore on Sunday; total stays at 89
summary: There are no new cases of the coronavirus disease reported in Singapore on Sunday, bringing the total number of cases to 89. Two more patients have been discharged, with 51 having fully recovered since the first case was confirmed on January 23. Most hospitalized patients are stable or improving, with five in critical condition. The Health Ministry has identified 2,812 close contacts, with 908 currently quarantined. Singapore's Disease Outbreak Response System Condition (Dorscon) level remains orange, indicating a severe but contained outbreak.

images.alt_text: There are no new cases of the coronavirus disease, said the Health Ministry (MOH) on Sunday (Feb 23), and the total number stays at 89.

site_title: Wells Fargo to pay US$3b to settle fake accounts scandal
summary: Wells Fargo has agreed to pay US$3 billion to settle three investigations into the fake accounts scandal, which occurred between 2002 and 2016. The scandal involved employees creating millions of unauthorized accounts and credit cards to meet unrealistic sales goals, resulting in millions of dollars in fees and interest for the bank. The settlement also includes US$2.5 billion going to the federal government and US$500 million to investors, with the bank acknowledging wrongdoing and agreeing not to commit similar offenses for three years.

site_title: In next downturn, Fed may opt for quick, strong action
summary: Veteran monetary policy analysts and Federal Reserve Governor Lael Brainard argue that in the next economic downturn, the Fed may need to use its "big guns" more aggressively to fight deflation or worse. They suggest expanding the Fed's policy arsenal to include tools like forward guidance and interest rate caps to bolster its clout. The Fed is reviewing its framework and is expected to put forward any changes by mid-year, amid concerns about low inflation and low interest rates making conventional responses less potent.

site_title: First European dies from Covid-19 in Italy
summary: A 78-year-old Italian, Adriano Trevisan, has become the first European to die from the coronavirus in Italy. He died in hospital, having previously recovered from an unrelated health issue 10 days earlier. This comes as 10 towns in Italy were locked down due to new cases, and 15 people in Lombardy were discovered to have contracted the virus.

site_title: UK to start issuing post-Brexit blue passports
summary: The UK will begin issuing blue passports next month, marking a return to the iconic design after nearly three decades. The new blue cover passports, made in Poland, will replace burgundy passports introduced in 1988. The move is seen as a way to restore national identity and was a key promise made by the government during the Brexit campaign. Interior Minister Priti Patel expressed excitement about traveling with the new passport, which will feature the same blue and gold design used from 1921.

site_title: Singapore golf clubs have generally held steady on prices
summary: Singapore golf clubs, Sentosa Golf Club and Singapore Island Country Club, have maintained steady prices, with membership prices decreasing by about $10,000 since last year. This steady pricing trend is attributed to the relatively stable market conditions and demand for golfing services in Singapore.

site_title: White House to host Huawei rivals at 5G meeting, Kudlow says
summary: The White House plans to host a conference with Huawei rivals, including Nokia, Ericsson, Samsung, AT&T, Verizon, and Qualcomm, to accelerate the development of affordable 5G wireless technology. This effort aims to counter Huawei's dominance in the market. National Economic Council director Larry Kudlow announced the meeting, which may take place in early April, and expressed optimism about working with the UK government to address concerns about Huawei's technology. The US has been trying to persuade other countries not to use Huawei equipment in emerging 5G networks.

site_title: habitat may be history; honestbee looking at quick service restaurant concept
summary: Embattled startup honestbee is considering closing its concept supermarket habitat due to significant overhead costs and uncertainty over its tenancy. The company has a negative equity position of S$166.3 million and has only S$294,000 in the bank. Honestbee plans to relaunch its business as quick service restaurants in the Central Business District and heartlands, tapping its 16 food and beverage concepts. A proposed scheme of arrangement aims to restructure S$230 million of debt, but its future remains uncertain due to lack of fresh funding and potential receivables and loan repayments.

site_title: Investing during virus outbreaks
summary: Investors can navigate the current Covid-19 outbreak by analyzing hard data rather than waiting for the situation to deteriorate. The highly contagious nature of Covid-19 requires frequent hand washing and avoiding face touching, but for investors, staying invested through crisis periods is often the best decision. Stock market bottoms often coincide with WHO Global Health Emergency announcements, and the negative impact on global GDP is negligible in the medium term. A base case assumption of a non-catastrophic outcome can be measured daily by tracking R0 and case-fatality rates, providing an objective conclusion.

site_title: 'Trump cheats at golf': Bloomberg mocks president with billboard
summary: A giant billboard in Las Vegas mocks President Donald Trump, reading "Donald Trump lost the popular vote" and "Donald Trump's wall fell over." The billboard, placed 3km from Trump's hotel, is a part of Democratic White House hopeful Michael Bloomberg's efforts to fuel their feud. Bloomberg is targeting Trump rather than fellow Democratic candidates, ahead of the November election. The billboard is the latest in a series of jabs by Bloomberg against Trump.

images.alt_text: Democratic White House hopeful Michael Bloomberg mocked Donald Trump with a giant billboard on the Las Vegas Strip on Friday, fuelling their feud as the US president visits the city for a rally.

site_title: Europe: Shares slide on rise in Covid-19 cases, weak US data
summary: European shares fell 0.5% on Friday, ending a volatile week, amid concerns over the prolonged impact of the coronavirus outbreak. The US services sector contracted for the first time since 2016, and business activity in the euro zone remained slow. Auto stocks led losses, down 1.9%, as the outbreak disrupted industrial activity in China, a major trading partner for European manufacturers. The Stoxx 600 index shed 0.6% for the week, marking its worst performance since January.

site_title: SBS Transit CEO to step down, COO to be acting CEO from March 1
summary: SBS Transit's CEO, Yang Ban Seng, will step down on March 1, with COO Cheng Siak Kian taking over as acting CEO. Cheng, 50, replaces Yang, 63, who will remain as executive deputy chairman. Cheng joined SBS Transit in 2015 and previously led ComfortDelGro's Australia operations. Lim Jit Poh, chairman of SBS Transit and ComfortDelGro, praised Cheng's leadership skills and experience, saying he is confident the company will reach "even-greater heights."

site_title: US: Coronavirus fears, US business data drag down Wall Street
summary: US stocks declined on Friday, with the Nasdaq experiencing its worst daily percentage drop in about three weeks, due to concerns over the coronavirus and a slowdown in US business activity. The technology sector led the declines, with Microsoft, Amazon, and Apple suffering significant losses. The S&P technology index fell 2.3%, while chipmakers plummeted 3%. The decline was fueled by investor fears about economic growth, with the S&P 500 also experiencing a drop.

site_title: Gold hits new highs as virus outbreak spreads
summary: Gold prices hit a seven-year high, extending a six-day rally, amid concerns over the coronavirus pandemic's spread beyond Asia. The US Dollar Index also surged, reaching a 100, despite concerns about corporate earnings. Central banks' accommodative monetary policy and financial uncertainty are expected to boost gold demand. However, inflation concerns in China and weaker economic growth expectations in India may impact prices. Gold prices are expected to remain bullish, with technical support levels at $1,620 and resistance at $1,650.

site_title: Understanding the 'cytokine storm' that is Covid-19
summary: Singapore is currently under Dorscon Orange, with 86 patients diagnosed and 5 in intensive care due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The virus causes a "cytokine storm" in the body, leading to a massive immune response that can be overwhelming and cause severe illness. To protect themselves, Singaporeans should practice good hand hygiene, wash hands frequently with soap and water, and avoid touching their eyes, face, or hair. Masks are also recommended for those who are sick to prevent transmission to others, but not for the general public. The public should avoid fear-mongering and misinformation, and instead trust expert advice and reliable sources.

site_title: STI finishes the week in sniffles, down 1.2%
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 17.65 points or 0.55% to 3,181.03 on Friday, marking a 1.2% decline for the week. The biggest losers included Singapore Exchange, United Overseas Bank, and Hongkong Land, despite Jefferies raising its target price on Singapore Exchange. The decline was attributed to uncertainty over the novel coronavirus outbreak and concerns over the exchange's long-term growth. Regional benchmark indices were also down, with China's Shanghai Composite rising 0.31%.

site_title: Why Amazon may be sweating when you click 'buy'
summary: Amazon is grappling with potential disruptions to its supply chain due to the coronavirus outbreak in China, where the company relies heavily on factories for production. In response, Amazon has made larger and more frequent orders of Chinese-made products, deviating from its usual automated purchasing process. The company has also contacted third-party merchants to assess potential supply chain impacts and is giving them extra time to get products to its warehouses without penalty. This approach exposes Amazon to greater supply chain risks, as it typically keeps fewer items on hand than its peers.

site_title: Deutsche Messe sets up regional HQ in Singapore
summary: Deutsche Messe, a German event organiser, has set up its regional headquarters in Singapore, further solidifying the city-state's position as a hub for industry events. The company will also host the Industrial Transformation Asia-Pacific trade show from 2021 to 2025, a commitment that renews a previous agreement. This move aims to accelerate the adoption of Industry 4.0 technologies across the Asia-Pacific region, with Singapore's strong MICE ecosystem and geographical location seen as ideal for expanding the company's presence in the region.

site_title: Gold's 'cold blooded' gain shows virus-induced rush into havens
summary: Gold prices surged as much as 2% amid concerns over the coronavirus outbreak, reaching a seven-year high. The S&P 500 Index fell, and business activity in the US shrank for the first time since 2013, disrupting supply chains. Investors sought safe-haven assets, driving up gold futures and Treasury yields, while call options traded to a record high. Analysts expect looser budgets globally due to the outbreak, with some predicting gold prices could reach $1,750-$1,850 an ounce if the virus is not contained.

images.alt_text: Investors are rushing to the safety of gold amid a selloff in US stocks on mounting concerns the coronavirus outbreak will derail global growth.

site_title: Wuhan woman with no symptoms infects five relatives with coronavirus: study
summary: A 20-year-old Chinese woman from Wuhan traveled 675km north to Anyang, infecting five relatives without showing symptoms, according to a study published in the Journal of the American Medical Association. The woman tested negative for the virus initially but later tested positive, sparking concerns about the virus's ability to spread asymptomatically. This case study suggests that preventing Covid-19 infection may be challenging, with key questions including the frequency of transmission and the timing of a positive test during an asymptomatic period.

images.alt_text: A 20-year-old Chinese woman from Wuhan, the epicentre of the coronavirus outbreak, travelled 675km north to Anyang where she infected five relatives, without ever showing signs of infection, Chinese scientists reported on Friday, offering new evidence that the virus can be spread asymptomatically.

site_title: Austrian raises 250m euros from Art Nouveau landmark
summary: Austrian billionaire Rene Benko sold 99-year bonds worth 250 million euros to German insurer R+V Versicherung, securing a 99-year lease on a historical Vienna property valued at 130 million euros. The deal yields 1.5% and is based on an annual rent of 3.5 million euros. The historic building, Postsparkasse, will remain open to the public and architecture students, and its revaluation increased to over 300 million euros after the deal with the Austrian government's real estate manager BIG.

site_title: Covid-19: Important that retail investors do not panic
summary: The COVID-19 outbreak has complicated investment scenarios, but retail investors should not panic. Markets tend to trade on fundamentals over the long run, making it best to hold onto positions. Despite the virus, recent positive indicators included the US-China trade deal and improved electronics exports from Singapore. The Straits Times Index had shown a 5% gain in 2019, and early optimism led to a sharp rise in the index during the first three weeks of January. Investors should focus on long-term fundamentals rather than short-term market fluctuations.

site_title: A Democratic piñata party
summary: Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders coasted through a debate despite a clumsy defense, largely thanks to billionaire Michael Bloomberg's attacks. Sanders was repeatedly hit by Bloomberg, but his campaign's handling of his medical records and the divisiveness of his supporters drew criticism. Sanders' defensive response was deemed Trumpian, and his lack of transparency was highlighted. Bloomberg's own performance was marred by evasiveness, while other candidates, including Elizabeth Warren and Pete Buttigieg, handled criticism more effectively. The debate showed Sanders' need to improve his handling of attacks and maintain transparency in his campaign.

site_title: Bourbon fascination
summary: La Maison du Whisky is celebrating its inaugural Bourbon Month with Prohibition-style cocktails inspired by the era of speakeasies and moonshine. The menu features classic drinks with ingredients like juice, sweetener, fresh garnish, and long pours of soda to mask the quality of the low-quality moonshine. According to the bar's marketing manager, the idea was to make the drinks enjoyable despite the questionable quality of the liquor.

site_title: Man who acted for SembMarine units in Brazil gets nearly 20 years jail for graft
summary: A Brazilian court has sentenced Guilherme Esteves de Jesus to 19 years and 4 months in prison for corruption, money laundering, and participation in a criminal organization. De Jesus, a consultant for SembMarine's Brazilian unit, was found guilty of making payments in connection with contracts with Brazilian rig supplier Sete Brasil in 2012. This is part of the ongoing Operation Car Wash anti-corruption probe. Another SembMarine employee, Martin Cheah Kok Choon, is also facing charges.

site_title: Reits (22-23 February, 2020)
summary: Realtors in Singapore are preparing for a Q3 wave of condo launches, which may test demand for projects above the S$3,000 psf benchmark. In the US, mortgage rates have risen after five weeks of declines. Manhattan rents have hit a record, with further increases expected. In the UK, homebuyer demand has rebounded to a six-month high. Meanwhile, New World is selling China property assets after a loan deal. WeWork has secured new tenants and filled more space at 21 Collyer Quay after its bankruptcy. Goldman Sachs has also acquired a large hotel and retail portfolio in Seoul.

site_title: A new decade, a new #10YearChallenge
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

As the world ages, Singapore and other Asian Pacific countries face significant healthcare costs due to an aging population. By 2030, over 1 in 5 Singaporeans will be 65 or older, and 1 in 4 will be severely disabled. Muscle loss is a major concern, with 1 in 5 elderly Singaporeans having low muscle mass. A balanced diet with high protein and regular exercise can help minimize age-related muscle loss. The Singapore government is also promoting initiatives like the "Stand4Strength" test to assess muscle health and encourage healthy aging.

site_title: Oil slides 1% on renewed fears over toll from coronavirus
summary: Oil prices fell 1% on Friday due to renewed concerns over the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak, with Brent crude settling at $58.50 a barrel and US crude futures at $53.38 a barrel. Opec and allied producers showed no rush to curb output, despite the decline. The selloff was triggered by signs of infections outside China's Hubei province and G20 policymakers' talks on the global economy in Saudi Arabia. Investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions in their decision to sell oil.

site_title: Grab reinstates incentives scheme after backlash from drivers
summary: Grab has reinstated its incentives programme for drivers in Singapore after a backlash from drivers who felt the aid package was unfair. The programme, Weekly Cover, provides S$85 or S$45 per week in income support to eligible drivers, replacing the original incentives scheme. Grab and the National Private Hire Vehicles Association (NPHVA) will continue discussions to review the scheme. The reinstatement comes after a meeting with NPHVA and representatives from the Land Transport Authority.

site_title: Covid-19: Do not force staff to take leave, MOM warns employers
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Manpower (MOM) warns employers not to force staff to take leave for the 14-day mandatory stay-home notice or leave of absence (LOA) due to COVID-19. Employers who do so may have their work-pass privileges suspended. Employers are encouraged to adopt fair employment practices, such as allowing staff to work from home or providing additional paid leave. Those under the notice cannot leave their homes for 14 days. MOM also offers financial help to eligible employers under the LOA support programme.

site_title: Sembcorp Industries posts Q4 loss of S$15m on impairments
summary: Sembcorp Industries posted a net loss of S$15 million in Q4 due to a downturn in the marine sector and impairments of its UK energy asset. Excluding exceptional items, the conglomerate would have posted a 24% rise in net profit to S$126 million. The company's group president attributed the losses to economic and industry factors, including a slower-than-expected retirement of coal and older gas-fired power plants in the UK.

site_title: HSBC is no man's land for its interim CEO - or anyone
summary: HSBC is embarking on a radical overhaul, cutting up to 35,000 jobs, reducing gross assets by over $100 billion, and shaving annual costs by $4.5 billion, as part of its efforts to address sub-par performance. Interim CEO Noel Quinn is overseeing the plan, but the bank's delay in confirming him as permanent CEO undermines his authority and may impede the search for a replacement. The restructuring makes HSBC even more vulnerable to the economic challenges in Hong Kong and mainland China, where the bank is heavily reliant for profits.

site_title: Woods keen on social golfers using different equipment from pros
summary: Tiger Woods suggests allowing recreational golfers to use different equipment from professionals to reduce the increasing hitting distance in the game. He proposes a "bifurcation" in the rules, which would cater to social golfers. This move aims to make the game more accessible and enjoyable for players of various skill levels.

site_title: Aspial unit moves to fend off S$545,000 claim from bankrupt contractor
summary: Aspial's unit World Class Land (WCL) is being named a defendant in winding-up proceedings by Authentic Builder's liquidators, claiming S$545,000 in unpaid works for the Waterfront @ Faber development. Aspial and WCL dispute the claim, stating the amounts were paid or not payable. They intend to instruct solicitors to apply to dismiss the proceedings. The company's shares closed flat at S$0.16 on Friday.

site_title: Buyers snap up 25 units of Luxus Hills landed development
summary: Bukit Sembawang Estates sold 25 units of its Luxus Hills landed development at an average selling price of S$2,060 per square foot. The developer ended previews and closed showhouses due to strong sales, with the remaining 14 units yet to be released. This marks a significant sale for the 999-year leasehold development, despite the Covid-19 outbreak.

site_title: Liang Sandwich Bar closures 'unauthorised, but temporary'
summary: Liang Sandwich Bar, a scallion pancake business, has closed all four Singapore outlets due to unauthorized closures. However, the closures are temporary and not permanent, according to the company. The closures were deemed unauthorized by the master franchisee.

site_title: Mardan, 52, considers Senior option
summary: Former Singapore professional golfer Mardan Mamat, 52, is considering retirement after 25 years as a pro golfer. He is weighing his options, including the Senior Tour, which could provide a steady income. Mamat's career is at a crossroads, and a decision is expected soon.

site_title: Japan to limit foreign ownership in 12 key sectors
summary: Japan is finalizing a plan to tighten scrutiny of foreign investment in 12 key sectors, including defense, nuclear power, and telecommunications, as part of efforts to boost direct investment and address national security concerns. The government will require pre-screening for foreign investors purchasing a stake of 1% or more in these sectors, down from 10%. Approximately 400-500 listed Japanese companies will fall under this criteria, with the list to be published in April. Finance Minister Taro Aso aims to encourage Japan-bound investment and respond to concerns about national security.

site_title: Chinese markets act like there is little risk left from Covid-19
summary: Chinese investors are feeling relatively optimistic about the market's performance despite the ongoing COVID-19 outbreak. The CSI 300 Index rose 1% on Friday, with daily turnover exceeding 1 trillion yuan for the third time this week. Chinese government bonds have also seen significant gains, while the yuan remains near its strongest level since August. This resilience stands out against other Asian markets, where concerns about the virus are driving declines. Authorities' support measures, including policy rate cuts and tax reductions, have helped to boost investor sentiment.

site_title: United Engineers to be delisted from SGX with effect from Feb 26
summary: United Engineers (UE) will be delisted from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on February 26, 2024, following its privatization by major shareholder Yanlord Land. The company's preference shares will also be delisted at the same time. This decision comes after most shareholders tendered their shares in December 2019, resulting in UE's free float falling below 10%.

site_title: UOL to pass property tax rebate savings on to tenants at its three malls
summary: UOL Group, a Singapore property developer, will pass on all savings from the 15% property tax rebate announced in Budget 2020 to retail tenants at its three malls, United Square, Velocity@Novena Square, and Kinex. This will be done on a targeted basis, with no reduction in rents specified. UOL will also provide over S$500,000 in marketing assistance and offer free parking at the malls. Tenants can shorten operating hours and receive discounts through the mall's loyalty program.

site_title: UOB Q4 net profit up 10%; bank looks to South-east Asia to sustain growth
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has reported a 10% rise in net profit to S$1.01 billion for the fourth quarter of 2019, driven by growth in wealth management and credit cards fees. The bank is diversifying its business to South-east Asia, where it expects supply chain disruptions to accelerate trade and foreign direct investment opportunities. UOB has also proposed a final dividend of 55 cents and special dividend of 20 cents per share. The bank's full-year net profit grew 8% to a record S$4.34 billion, and it remains focused on sustaining its momentum in fee income growth and expanding its presence in the region's millennial market.

site_title: China coronavirus outbreak has not yet peaked says politburo
summary: China's coronavirus outbreak has not yet reached its peak, according to a meeting of the ruling Communist Party, citing severe and complex conditions in Hubei province and Wuhan city. The government will continue to consolidate achievements and extend combat successes, with a focus on Beijing's epidemic control work. The meeting also emphasized the economy's long-term improving momentum, with fiscal and monetary policies to be more proactive and flexible to fend off systemic financial risks.

site_title: Financial services the sector leader for gender lens funds
summary: Financial services is the top sector leader for gender lens funds, despite a lack of women's progress in the sector. Research has shown that companies with higher women-in-leadership metrics outperform on financial and share price criteria. However, financial services has the broadest wage gap in the US, with women earning just 63% of what men make. Emerging WIL progress is seen in banking and insurance, with some firms, such as Bank of America, scoring high in gender equality rankings. This trend may indicate that financial services is not a mismatch, but rather a sector where women are making strides, despite the industry's overall lack of progress.

site_title: Budget could cut prejudice against hiring older workers
summary: Singapore's government has introduced budgetary measures to boost jobs for mid-career and older workers, aiming to remove the prejudice against recruiting mature workers. The Senior Worker Support Package and Mid-Career Support Package provide grants and incentives to encourage companies to hire and retain older workers, targeting those aged above 50. Recruiters believe these measures can kickstart a mindset shift, promoting diversity and inclusion in the workplace, and reducing aged-related discrimination.

site_title: OCBC sees 2% revenue growth hit for 2020 from virus outbreak
summary: OCBC Bank expects a 2% revenue growth hit for FY2020 due to the novel coronavirus outbreak, despite a solid Q4 earnings report with a 34% increase to S$1.24 billion. The bank raised dividends, with a higher payout ratio of 47%, and expects a gradual recovery in the third quarter. Credit costs and non-performing loans are projected to rise, but the magnitude of increases will be limited. OCBC's CEO Samuel Tsien expects the bank's capital position to remain strong, with a common equity tier one ratio of 14.9%.

site_title: Memiontec to raise funds in Catalist listing for regional expansion
summary: Memiontec Holdings, a Singapore-based water treatment firm, is set to list on the Catalist board with a proposed initial public offering (IPO) of 33.5 million placement shares at S$0.225 each. The company plans to use its net proceeds to invest in build-own-operate-transfer (BOOT) projects, expand its sales and distribution business, and for general working capital. Memiontec aims to expand into new markets, including South-east Asia, through business collaborations and strategic alliances. The company has a strong track record of profitability, with a net profit of S$4.6 million in FY18, and has long-term customers from both the public and private sectors.

site_title: Coming soon: airline Wi-Fi that actually works
summary: A new technology architecture by the Seamless Air Alliance aims to make airline Wi-Fi more efficient and cost-effective. The modular design features open interfaces and components that can be easily swapped out, potentially saving carriers billions of dollars. This development, driven by forces to lower costs, could bring reliable and glitch-free internet access to the skies, satisfying online experiences for travelers.

images.alt_text: For passengers, the Seamless Air Alliance may change the entire airport experience. Your mobile connection would migrate from one system to another, from the terminal onto the jet bridge and down the aisle to your seat - without the need to log in or pay.

site_title: Far East Orchard posts 21% fall in 2019 net profit of S$26m
summary: Far East Orchard reported a 21% decline in 2019 net profit to S$26 million, down from S$33 million in 2018, due to higher finance costs and a fall in share of profit from joint ventures. Revenue rose 3.4% to S$156 million, driven by higher sales at UK student accommodation properties and management fees from hotels. The company expects a slowdown in travel demand amid the Covid-19 outbreak and proposes a first and final dividend of six cents per share.

site_title: US services, manufacturing sectors hit wall in Feb
summary: US business activity in the manufacturing and services sectors stalled in February due to concerns over the coronavirus, according to a survey by IHS Markit. The services sector Purchasing Managers' Index fell to 49.4, its lowest since October 2013, indicating contraction for the first time since 2016. The manufacturing sector barely escaped contraction, with a reading of 50.8. Companies are cautious about spending due to worries about a broader economic slowdown and uncertainty ahead of US presidential elections. The coronavirus outbreak has dealt a setback to hopes for a rebound in business investment.

site_title: Tried & tested
summary: Equipment brands are working to make golf clubs swing faster, pushing technology and innovation. Meanwhile, in other news, a low-profile property trust is investing in a data centre, US weekly jobless claims have fallen, and China is urging South-east Asia to support openness amid US tariffs. Chinese property shares surged on unverified reports of a meeting to revive the sector. Reliance Jio has delayed its India IPO, and China has unveiled new steps to aid employment amid trade tensions.

site_title: Coronavirus: 10 more patients discharged; 1 new case linked to woman with dengue
summary: Singapore reported 10 more patients discharged from the coronavirus, bringing the total number of discharged cases to 47, or more than half of the 86 total cases. One new case was confirmed, linked to a woman with dengue, and 5 are in critical condition in the ICU. The Health Ministry has identified 2,696 close contacts, with 1,122 currently quarantined.

site_title: Singapore banks cautious about H1 with outbreak hitting customers
summary: Singapore banks are cautious about the upcoming half-year due to the ongoing COVID-19 outbreak, with about 10% of their total loan portfolio exposed to vulnerable sectors. Despite meeting or exceeding market expectations with their 2019 earnings, the banks warned of significant impact on tourism, retail, and manufacturers. DBS, OCBC, and UOB have raised their dividend payout and introduced relief packages for customers, but expect tepid loan growth and higher credit costs. The banks forecast a V-shaped recovery in 2021, driven by a single event, and are gunning for a marginal uptick in credit costs.

site_title: DBS' US$1b perp said to set benchmark for other Asian banks
summary: DBS Bank has successfully issued a US$1 billion 3.3% perpetual AT1 bond, setting a benchmark for other Asian banks to follow. The deal is Asia's first US dollar AT1 issue in 2020, with the lowest coupon rate of 3.3% worldwide. Despite the COVID-19 outbreak, DBS received significant soft orders and ultimately priced the deal at 3.3%, with net proceeds to be used for the bank's finance and treasury activities. The deal has been well-received by investors, with the bulk of the orders coming from Asia.

site_title: China office, retail sectors may slow down: Knight Frank
summary: China's commercial real estate markets are expected to slow down due to the ongoing Covid-19 outbreak. Office leasing activities are projected to decrease, with rents facing downward pressure, while retail markets are impacted, with some landlords reducing or waiving rents. However, industries such as online education, gaming, and healthcare are expected to be positively affected. The industrial market is less impacted, with e-commerce companies and manufacturers driving demand for logistics and warehousing.

site_title: US:Tech stocks drag Wall St lower as coronavirus spreads
summary: US stocks fell on Friday, dragged down by technology stocks for a second day, as investors sought safer assets amid the spread of the coronavirus. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.25%, the S&P 500 fell 0.38%, and the Nasdaq Composite declined 0.44%. The decline followed a spike in new coronavirus cases in China and elsewhere, with investors seeking refuge in gold and government bonds.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 73.45 points, or 0.25 per cent, at the open to 29,146.53.

site_title: Lebanon announces first coronavirus case
summary: Lebanon confirmed its first case of the novel coronavirus, a 45-year-old Lebanese woman who had traveled from Qom, Iran, with a high fever but stable condition. The woman had been on a flight from Iran, and all passengers on the same flight have been contacted by health authorities. Anyone returning from Iran will be asked to observe a two-week home quarantine. This comes as China reported a total of 2,236 deaths and over 75,000 infections, with the virus first detected in late December.

images.alt_text: Health Minister Hassan Hamad said the Covid-19 virus was found in a 45-year-old Lebanese woman who had travelled from Qom in Iran

site_title: World Class Global posts 41% slide in 2019 net profit of S$13.6m
summary: World Class Global, a CATALIST-listed property developer, reported a net profit of S$13.6 million in 2019, down 41% from 2018. Revenue fell 54% to S$205 million, primarily due to the settlement of Australia 108 and AVANT residential developments in Melbourne. The company expects positive contributions from Australia 108 and ongoing projects, which have signed sales contracts amounting to around S$400 million. Despite the COVID-19 outbreak, World Class Global anticipates a positive hotel industry in Penang, Malaysia, with a potential increase in hotel keys to 350.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 3.78 points to 1,531.20. The market saw 2.7 billion lots traded worth RM2.1 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 439 to 391.

site_title: Kimly acquires portfolio of food outlet properties for S$55.8m
summary: Kimly, a Catalist-listed coffee shop consolidator, has agreed to acquire a S$55.8 million portfolio of food outlet properties, comprising four coffeeshops, three industrial canteen units, and a restaurant unit. The acquisition will be funded with S$45.8 million in cash and S$10 million from a share issuance. The deal aims to expand Kimly's network of food outlets in mature estates with established footfalls, capitalizing on the limited supply of long-term leasehold coffeeshop properties in Singapore.

site_title: Isetan Singapore warns of 'substantially higher net loss' for FY2019
summary: Isetan Singapore expects to report a substantially higher net loss for FY2019, mainly due to impairment charges on property and equipment. The 12-month loss is attributed to these charges, which will be announced on or before Feb 29. The company's shares closed flat at S$4.34 on Friday.

site_title: Maxi-Cash posts 43% rise in 2019 net profit of S$14.8m
summary: Maxi-Cash Financial Service reported a 43% rise in 2019 net profit to S$14.8 million, up from S$10.4 million in 2018. Revenue grew 7.28% to S$218.5 million, driven by higher takings from pawnbroking and retail businesses. The company proposed a final dividend of S$0.0035 per share, unchanged from 2018. Despite challenging operating conditions, Maxi-Cash plans to launch new products and services, and improve its network of stores to reach a wider customer base.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore banks are cautious over the next three to six months due to the virus outbreak, with 10% of their loan portfolio seen to be exposed to vulnerable sectors. DBS priced a $1b perp deal at 3.3%, its lowest coupon rate. The Securities Investors Association (SIAS) will remain independent, refusing to promote Utico's rescue package for Hyflux. UOL Group will pass property tax rebates on to tenants at its malls. The Singapore stock market fell 0.6% on Friday as Covid-19 weighs on sentiment.

site_title: Memiontec to raise funds in Catalist listing for regional expansion
summary: Memiontec Holdings, a water treatment firm, is raising funds through a Catalist listing in Singapore. The company plans to list 33.5 million placement shares at S$0.225 each, with executive chairman and CEO Tay Kiat Seng and managing director Soelistyo Dewi Soegiharto holding 81.5% of the company post-placement. The IPO aims to expand businesses, explore merger and acquisition opportunities, and invest in build-own-operate-transfer projects. Memiontec currently operates in Singapore, Indonesia, and China, with a focus on regional expansion and innovative water technologies.

site_title: Grab reinstates incentives scheme after driver backlash
summary: Grab has reinstated its incentives program for drivers after a backlash following the announcement of a Covid-19 aid package. The program, called Weekly Cover, was initially met with criticism that it replaced the existing incentives scheme. Grab has agreed to continue discussions with the National Private Hire Vehicles Association to review the scheme. The reinstatement aims to provide better earnings security for drivers amid a decline in demand due to the pandemic.

site_title: Durians stack up in Malaysia as coronavirus freezes China demand
summary: Malaysia's durian exports to China have been severely impacted by the coronavirus outbreak, with a sharp decline in Chinese tourists and resulting port congestion. Normally, China accounts for 79% of Malaysia's frozen durian exports, but trade has ground to a halt. One exporter expects to lose up to 15 million ringgit if shipments do not resume soon, while durian stall operators have seen a 80% drop in tourists and 20% in prices. The shortage is expected to continue for several months, posing a significant threat to Malaysia's durian export industry.

site_title: Starburst Holdings says expects new contract win for its unit
summary: Starburst Holdings' wholly-owned unit has been awarded a contract for a shooting range specialist and associated works in South-east Asia. The unit had tendered for the project and the main contractor has accepted its proposed sub-contract. The group is awaiting the official contract agreement. This new win is expected to bring more work to the unit.

site_title: Jaguar Land Rover shelves plan to sell bonds to raise cash
summary: Jaguar Land Rover has shelved plans to issue a US dollar bond due to investors demanding too high an interest rate to compensate for the risk posed by the coronavirus. The company had planned an eight-year bond in the high 7% yield range but canceled the plan after warning of supply chain disruptions and potential losses. Jaguar has around $6 billion in liquidity to tackle near-term maturities and is not facing near-term funding pressures. The company had previously raised debt in November, selling $864 million of debt and another $200 million in euros in the following month.

site_title: EU leaders eye follow-up summit after budget talks deadlock
summary: European Union leaders are considering a follow-up summit to reach a budget agreement, as talks on the trillion-euro budget broke down due to disagreements over spending levels and rebates. The "Frugal Four" countries, including the Netherlands and Denmark, want to keep spending at 1% of the EU's gross national income, while southern and eastern countries push for a ceiling closer to 1.1%. The lack of an agreement could lead to further summits and disrupt spending plans for 2021, including funding for poorer regions.

site_title: Bukit Sembawang sells nearly two-thirds of homes at Luxus Hills' final phase
summary: Bukit Sembawang Estates Limited sold 25 out of 39 units at Luxus Hills' final phase, with 25 landed homes sold. The sold units include inter-terraces, corner terraces, semi-detached houses, and a villa, following private previews.

site_title: SBS Transit CEO to step down, COO to be acting CEO from March 1
summary: SBS Transit CEO Yang Ban Seng will step down on March 1, replaced by COO Cheng Siak Kian as acting CEO. Cheng, 50, has been with the company since 2015 and previously led ComfortDelGro's Australia operations. Yang will remain executive deputy chairman and managing director of ComfortDelGro. The change is seen as a natural choice, with Yang praising Cheng's experience in running SBS Transit's bus operations and rail business.

site_title: AGV Group proposes 5-for-1 rights issue to 'enhance cash position'
summary: AGV Group has proposed a 5-for-1 renounceable non-underwritten rights issue to raise S$3.6 million to S$19.3 million, aiming to enhance its cash position and financial flexibility. The move comes after its independent auditor raised concerns about the group's ability to continue as a going concern in January. The group plans to issue up to 929.7 million new rights shares at S$0.025 apiece.

site_title: Singapore shares fall 0.6% on Friday as Covid-19 weighs on sentiment
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.55% to 3,181.03 on Friday, marking a 1.2% decline for the week. The decline was attributed to the ongoing impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on market sentiment. Key losers included the Singapore Exchange, United Overseas Bank, and Hongkong Land. Despite positive financial results from UOB and OCBC Bank, local banks DBS and OCBC Bank also saw a decline.

site_title: honestbee mulls permanent closure of habitat
summary: honestbee, a struggling startup, is considering a permanent shutdown of its concept supermarket habitat due to significant overhead costs and uncertainty over its tenancy. The company plans to relaunch its business in the form of Quick Service Restaurants, utilizing the 16 food and beverage concepts at the habitat. Honestbee aims to repay US$230 million of debt via a debt-to-equity swap, with some creditors expressing support for the scheme. The company's decision to close the habitat is a result of insufficient working capital and opposition from the landlord, LHN Space Resources.

site_title: Singapura Finance posts 3.1% dip in 2019 net profit of S$7.5m
summary: Singapore Finance reported a 3.1% decline in 2019 net profit to S$7.5 million, down from S$7.8 million in 2018. Total income rose 2.2% to S$21.8 million, while total operating expenses increased 6.1% to S$14.1 million. The company attributed the decline to higher operating expenses and lower net interest income. Despite this, a dividend of 3.5 cents per share is proposed for 2020. The company expects a challenging economic outlook but will focus on managing expenses and seeking new business opportunities.

site_title: Covid-19 could accelerate supply chain shift to Asean
summary: The Covid-19 outbreak is likely to accelerate the shift in supply chains away from China, with ASEAN countries, particularly Vietnam and Thailand, poised to benefit from this structural shift. Japanese automakers and Samsung have accelerated relocation plans due to the virus, while foreign direct investment inflows in Vietnam and Thailand have surged. This "China+1" strategy will help MNCs diversify their risks, and ASEAN is well-positioned to capitalize on this trend.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks close the week lower on virus fears
summary: South Korean shares fell 1.5% on Friday, closing the week lower due to concerns over the coronavirus outbreak. The KOSPI index dropped 32.66 points, or 1.49%, to 2,162.84, with exports to China slumping and overall sales affected by the virus outbreak. The South Korean government reported 52 new cases of the disease, taking the national tally to 156, and China's commerce ministry warned of a disruption to its economy. The decline marks the KOSPI's 3.60% weekly loss.

site_title: LifeBrandz to acquire Yakiniku restaurant in Japan for S$200,000
summary: LifeBrandz has entered a non-binding Memorandum of Understanding to acquire Beef by Koh, a Japanese restaurant serving Yakiniku and other cuisine, for S$200,000. The deal is subject to due diligence and LifeBrandz shares closed flat at S$0.003. Beef by Koh operates one restaurant in Tokyo and is owned by Japanese citizen Koichiro Ara, who is the sole director and beneficial owner. The acquisition is LifeBrandz's first venture into Japan's restaurant industry.

site_title: SIAS and its advisers to remain independent, let Hyflux PnP holders 'decide for themselves'
summary: SIAS and its advisers will remain independent in advising on Hyflux's rescue package, with no assurance of higher fees for supporting the deal. Despite Utico's offer to increase adviser fees to S$50 million if all advisers support the scheme, SIAS's advisers will act independently and PnP holders will decide for themselves. The group's advisers, Drew & Napier and PricewaterhouseCoopers Advisory Services, will not be swayed by incentives and will provide unbiased advice to PnP holders.

site_title: SGX injects another S$5m into subsidiary SGX Bond Trading
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has injected another S$5 million into its subsidiary SGX Bond Trading, bringing the total investment to S$10 million. The capital will be used to fund operations and meet regulatory capital requirements. The move signals SGX's commitment to the success of its OTC Trading Platform for Asian Bonds, the first dedicated venue for Asian bond trading. SGX shares fell 2.27% to S$9.05 following the announcement.

site_title: UOL to pass property tax rebates on to tenants at its 3 malls
summary: UOL Group, a property developer, will pass on the 15% property tax rebate announced in Budget 2020 to retail tenants at its three malls, United Square, Velocity@Novena Square, and Kinex. The rebate will be given in a targeted manner, and the company will also provide more than S$500,000 in marketing assistance. Free parking and shortened operating hours will be offered to tenants. UOL shares fell 0.5% on the news.

site_title: Europe: Stocks dip at open
summary: European stock markets declined at the start of trade on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 index down 0.5% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 index also falling 0.5%. The Paris CAC 40 index dropped 0.6%. The declines were attributed to bank and healthcare stocks. US-EU trade tensions remain a focus, despite stocks reaching fresh records earlier in the week.

site_title: China firms in US$10b share sale rush as funding rules eased amid virus worries
summary: China's listed companies are rushing to raise over $10 billion in shares amid eased fundraising rules to combat the coronavirus. The new rules allow companies to sell up to 30% of their capital via private placements, up from 20%, and lift the number of investors from 10 to 35. This move comes as China pumps liquidity into the financial system and the stock market rebounds. Companies face cash strains, with over 75% of respondents saying the epidemic is straining their liquidity, and some reporting an 80% slump in revenue.

site_title: Samsung Electronics names ex-finance minister as its new board chairman
summary: Samsung Electronics has named former South Korean finance minister Bahk Jae Wan as its new board chairman, succeeding Lee Sanghoon who resigned after being jailed for alleged union-busting activities. Bahk is Samsung's first outside director to hold the chairman position.

images.alt_text: Samsung Electronics said on Friday that it has named former finance minister and its outside director, Bahk Jae Wan, as its board chairman.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower on worries over fast-spreading coronavirus
summary: Australia's shares closed 0.3% lower on Friday amid concerns over the fast-spreading coronavirus, despite recording a third weekly gain. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell, with energy stocks leading the losses, while miners BHP Group and Rio Tinto declined. However, Caltex Australia saw its best week since early January as a takeover tussle for the company gained momentum. New Zealand's benchmark index rose marginally, driven by gains from local banking shares.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower as traders eye virus impact
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Friday, slipping 0.39% or 92.41 points to 23,386.74, amid concerns over the coronavirus outbreak's impact on the world's third-largest economy. Investors took to the sidelines ahead of a long weekend, with the Nikkei 225 index ending down 0.03% or 0.48 point at 1,674.00.

site_title: Japan to limit foreign ownership in 12 sectors: sources
summary: Japan is finalizing a plan to tighten foreign ownership scrutiny in 12 key sectors, including defence, nuclear power, and telecommunications, under the new law. Foreign investors purchasing a stake of 1% or more will be subject to pre-screening, as opposed to 10% currently. The move aims to boost direct investment and address national security concerns, following similar steps taken by the US and Europe. About 400-500 listed Japanese companies will fall under the criteria, with the list of firms to be published in April.

site_title: China launches 1.4b yuan fund to combat fall armyworms, locusts
summary: China has allocated 1.4 billion yuan to combat fall armyworms and locusts affecting its massive agriculture sector. The funds will be used to prevent and control pests in 21 provinces, including Yunnan and Guangxi, and distribute 30 million yuan for locust control efforts in 15 provinces. The measures aim to protect key crops such as corn and wheat, amid concerns over food security.

site_title: Gigacover extends free Covid-19 coverage to insured freelancers, Gojek drivers
summary: Insurance provider Gigacover is extending its Covid-19 coverage to insured freelancers, including Gojek drivers, at no additional cost. The coverage now includes one-time payouts for stay-home notice (SHN) and leave of absence (LOA) due to Covid-19. Eligible insured freelancers can receive up to S$400 for SHN/LOA, and up to S$6,500 for hospitalization leave, on top of other benefits previously announced by Gojek. The additional coverage is extended on a "goodwill basis" by Gigacover and Etiqa Insurance.

site_title: SoftBank's Masa and his bankers grab a shared ride
summary: SoftBank's Masayoshi Son and Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group (MUFG) have formed a three-way deal worth over $700 million, with MUFG investing in Grab, a South-east Asian ride-hailing giant. The deal aims to expand Grab's financial services and provide MUFG with an alternative to its underperforming digital banking efforts. SoftBank avoids a cash call from its most promising unicorn, while Grab gains access to MUFG's capital and expertise in the region. The deal also gives SoftBank a chance to reduce its reliance on the Vision Fund.

site_title: Panic buying inflation tipped to fade as virus hammers demand
summary: A coronavirus outbreak in China is causing shortages of goods and food, potentially leading to inflation in Asia. However, economic growth in China and the region is expected to slow, with tourism, travel, and manufacturing plummeting. Commodity and energy costs have already fallen, and inflation is expected to be offset by downward pressure on prices. Central banks and finance ministries may need to lower interest rates and increase spending to counteract the slump, and the impact on prices will depend on when factories in China return to work and supply chains are restored.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish lower on virus worries
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 1.1% on Friday amid concerns over the deadly coronavirus's impact on earnings and economic growth. The Hang Seng Index closed at 27,308.81, while mainland China's Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.3%. The Shenzhen Composite Index increased 1.1%. The decline in Hong Kong stocks follows rising virus worries outside China.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng Index fell 1.1 per cent, or 300.35 points, to 27,308.81.

site_title: Singapore banks see 10% of portfolio vulnerable to virus outbreak impact
summary: Singapore banks, including DBS, OCBC, and UOB, have expressed caution over the next three to six months due to the ongoing novel coronavirus outbreak, with approximately 10% of their total loan portfolio exposed to vulnerable sectors such as tourism, retail, and manufacturers. The banks have raised their dividend payout and proposed relief packages to support customers facing cash flow challenges. Despite this, they are forecasting a V-shaped recovery in 2021 and a marginal uptick in credit costs, driven by a lower-for-longer rates environment.

site_title: CNMC Goldmine Q4 profit plunges 80.5% on lower sales
summary: CNMC Goldmine Holdings reported a 80.5% decline in Q4 profit to US$244,004, down from US$1.3 million a year ago. Revenue fell 39.7% to US$7.6 million due to lower production and sales volume of fine gold. Despite this, the company's full-year net profit more than doubled to US$4.4 million. The company proposes a final tax-exempt dividend of 0.2 Singapore cent and a special tax-exempt dividend of 0.4 Singapore cent, subject to shareholder approval.

site_title: Coronavirus weakens job market for record number of China graduates
summary: China's record 8.7 million-strong university graduating class faces a weakened job market due to the coronavirus outbreak. Many students are stuck at home as corporate recruitment events are cancelled or postponed, and companies are recruiting fewer people than last year. The proportion of companies seeking over 500 new employees has dropped by more than half, and some firms have started laying off workers. Graduates are bracing for a competitive market and are considering alternative career options, such as joining the army or volunteering in poorer western regions.

site_title: China's ambitious 5G push heading into slow lane due to coronavirus disruptions
summary: China's rollout of 5G telecom networks is facing delays due to disruptions caused by the coronavirus outbreak. Tenders for six major 5G projects have been postponed since January 31, and production at two key fibre optic cable makers, Yangtze Optical Fibre and Cable Joint Stock Ltd Co, and FiberHome Telecommunication Technologies Co Ltd, has been severely impacted. The lockdown in Wuhan, where the companies are based, is also hindering the transportation of goods and staff shortages. Analysts predict that the delays could impact China's goal of having nationwide 5G networks ahead of other countries.

site_title: Tokyo to cancel or postpone major indoor events for next 3 weeks: report
summary: The Tokyo Metropolitan government has decided to cancel or postpone major indoor events for the next three weeks in an effort to slow the spread of the coronavirus. This measure comes as Japan prepares to host the 2020 Olympic Games in July. The city has already seen cases of the virus in Japan, with over 1,000 reported cases in the country. The decision aims to minimize the risk of transmission and prevent further spread of the virus.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks lower at Friday's open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index falling 0.6% due to concerns over the rising death toll from the new coronavirus. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined, with the Hang Seng Index closing at 27,450.46. The decline was influenced by Wall Street's market trends, where investors were spooked by the global health crisis.

site_title: Malaysia's Jan CPI up 1.6% y-o-y, fastest since May 2018
summary: Malaysia's January consumer price index (CPI) rose 1.6% from a year earlier, the fastest pace in nearly two years, according to government data. The increase was driven by a rise in the transport sector, primarily due to higher fuel pump prices. All 12 sectors tracked by the index showed price increases except for the clothing sector, which fell 1.2%. The central bank expects headline inflation to remain modest in 2020, higher than the previous year.

site_title: Industry 4.0 tradeshow in Singapore renewed for further 5 years
summary: Industry 4.0 trade show Industrial Transformation Asia-Pacific in Singapore has been renewed for another 5 years, with a memorandum of understanding signed between the Singapore Tourism Board, Deutsche Messe, and local partner SingEx. The show, which focuses on Industry 4.0 technologies, will be held from 2021 to 2025, with plans to develop and anchor new events in Singapore. Deutsche Messe will also establish its South-east Asian headquarters in Singapore, expanding its trade fairs in the region.

images.alt_text: (from left) Hannover Fairs Asia-Pacific managing director Katariina Rohrbach, Singapore Tourism Board director of exhibitions and conferences Andrew Phua, and SingEx Exhibitions executive director for events James Boey, signing a memorandum of understanding for the continued organising of the trade show.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon down 0.1% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index declined 0.1% to 3,196.30 on Friday, with 168 decliners outnumbering 140 advancers. Banking stocks were mixed, with DBS gaining 0.4%, UOB losing 0.3%, and OCBC rising 0.3%. In the region, Australian shares fell 0.2%, Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index dropped 0.6%, and China's Shanghai Composite Index declined 0.3%.

site_title: Malaysia probes dozens over virus misinformation
summary: Malaysia is investigating 27 individuals for spreading misinformation about the coronavirus, amid a global surge in false claims. The country has 22 confirmed cases, with the virus having killed over 2,200 people worldwide. The investigation comes as governments across Asia crack down on false information online, which has spread rapidly. The actions are part of a broader effort to combat misinformation and protect public health.

site_title: The multimillionaire family shaping Singapore's iconic skyline
summary: A Singaporean multimillionaire family, the Yongs, has controlled the private empire Woh Hup Holdings Pte for nearly a century, shaping the city's iconic skyline with projects such as Gardens by the Bay and Jewel Changi Airport. The fourth generation is set to take over, with Michelle Yong, the granddaughter of the family's chairman, leading the charge. Under her leadership, Woh Hup has diversified into entertainment, luxury apartments, and boutique residential properties, maintaining control despite Singapore's transformation. The family's estimated wealth is around $600 million.

site_title: South Korea's February exports to China shrink as coronavirus hits supply chains
summary: South Korea's February exports to China declined 3.7% as the coronavirus outbreak disrupted global supply chains. Overseas sales rose 12.4% overall, but average exports per working day contracted 9.3%. Shipments to China and Singapore fell, while exports to the US and Vietnam surged. Analysts expect the outbreak to harm global growth and gloom is spreading among South Korean manufacturers. The decline in exports signals a grim outlook for Asia's fourth-largest economy.

site_title: Man linked to SembMarine jailed for almost 20 years in Brazil corruption probe
summary: A Brazilian court has sentenced Guilherme Esteves de Jesus, a consultant linked to SembCorp Marine, to 19 years and four months in prison for corruption, money laundering, and participation in a criminal organization. Esteves was involved in contracts with Brazilian rig supplier Sete Brasil in 2012. This case is part of the Operation Car Wash anti-corruption probe, which has also implicated politicians and large Brazilian companies, including state-owned oil company Petrobras.

site_title: Australia wine faces 'toughest year' in memory after fires, drought
summary: Australia's wine industry is facing its toughest year in memory due to devastating wildfires and drought. Smoke taint from the fires has damaged grapes, with some winemakers scrapping vintages or producing reduced quantities. The NSW state government is offering subsidized testing for growers, and the industry is exploring ways to use tainted grapes to create new products. Years of drought are expected to impact the size of the 2020 vintage, potentially down 10-15%, with the country's wine exports expected to benefit from the reduced supply.

site_title: HSBC offers cash management advice for Singapore firms amid outbreak
summary: HSBC Singapore is providing cash management advice and expedited payment handling to help businesses manage cash and liquidity amid the COVID-19 outbreak. The bank has assembled a liquidity and cash management BCP advisory team and will prioritize clients requiring urgent support. Measures include digital document submission, expedited manual payment handling, and a 90-day moratorium for submitted documents, aiming to ease the impact of the outbreak on corporate treasuries.

site_title: Liang Sandwich Bar closures were unauthorised: master franchisee
summary: Liang Sandwich Bar, a scallion pancake business endorsed by Taiwanese singer-songwriter Jay Chou, has temporarily closed its four Singapore outlets due to unauthorized actions by the local master franchisee. The closures, which are not permanent, are part of a rebranding effort to Liang Crispy Roll, which will debut in Singapore in Q4 2020. The local franchisee has been censured and taken measures to resolve the matter. Despite the disruption, the brand remains committed to launching new outlets in Singapore and internationally.

site_title: South Korea confirms 52 more coronavirus cases, total 156
summary: South Korea reported 52 new coronavirus cases, bringing the total to 156, the second-highest national total outside China. Most cases, 43, were in Daegu and its neighboring provinces. The Korean Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have confirmed the outbreak's center in the southern city.

site_title: Bank of Japan governor sees moderate economic growth, eyes coronavirus impact
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda expects Japan's economy to continue a moderate recovery, despite uncertainty due to the new coronavirus outbreak. The virus' impact on Japanese exports, output, and inbound tourists from China is a concern, with Kuroda watching the effects with "grave concern". The economic outlook remains uncertain, but Kuroda remains optimistic about the country's economic growth.

images.alt_text: Japan's economy is likely to continue a moderate recovery as downward pressure seen in the last quarter tapers off, although the new coronavirus outbreak creates uncertainty on the economic outlook, Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda said on Friday.

site_title: Coronavirus widens Hong Kong anger at government, China
summary: Hong Kong's residents have lost confidence in the government's handling of the new coronavirus outbreak, with widespread anger and frustration fueled by the lack of a complete border closure with mainland China. Pro-democracy protesters have largely disappeared from the streets, but business leaders and union figures are joining forces to attack Carrie Lam's administration for its response. A survey shows three-quarters of residents want the border closed, and a medical workers' strike has taken place, with some calling for renewed protests this summer. The anger is seen as a new front in the ongoing pro-democracy movement, which began last year with protests against a bill allowing extradition to mainland China.

site_title: Top HSBC Asia retail banker promoted to global role in merged wealth business
summary: HSBC has named Kevin Martin, its head of Asia Pacific retail banking and wealth management unit, as the chief operating officer of the newly created global wealth and personal banking business. The move comes as part of a strategy overhaul to merge the bank's private banking and retail wealth businesses. Martin, who previously served clients with over $5 million in investable assets, will oversee the new business. The merged entity aims to serve clients across the globe with a unified wealth and personal banking platform.

site_title: Virus to hit Ping An Insurance's business in first half 2020
summary: Ping An Insurance Group, China's largest insurer, expects the coronavirus outbreak to affect its business in the first half of 2020 due to a slowdown in agent-driven sales. The virus has killed over 2,100 people and infected nearly 75,000 in China, causing disruptions to businesses and factories. Despite this, the company expects its business to bounce back in the second half of the year, driven by a likely recovery in China's economy. The outbreak may also affect the quality or yields of credit assets and investment assets.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 5.59 points or 0.36% to 1,529.39. The market saw 130.13 million lots traded worth RM62.87 million, with losers beating gainers 172 to 95.

site_title: China's passenger car sales tumble 92% in first half of Feb due to virus outbreak
summary: China's passenger car sales plummeted 92% in the first 16 days of February due to the coronavirus outbreak. The country recorded 4,909 units sold, down from 59,930 units a year earlier. Few dealerships are operating, with minimal customer traffic, according to the China Passenger Car Association. The virus outbreak has significantly impacted businesses across China, leading to a substantial decline in car sales.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at open tracking Wall St selloff; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.1% to 3,194.42 at the open, tracking a Wall Street selloff. The Straits Times Index declined 4.26 points, with 78 decliners outnumbering 59 advancers. Banking stocks, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC, dropped, despite positive financial results from UOB and OCBC. The Dow, S&P 500, and Nasdaq also fell in the US, amid concerns over the Covid-19 outbreak in China.

site_title: Australia's regulator flags new internal bank stress-testing framework
summary: Australia's prudential regulator, APRA, is developing a new internal bank stress-testing framework following a review that found banks needed to improve their internal systems. The review, conducted by self-assessments from 28 banks, identified areas for improvement in stress testing and found that about half of the banks lacked well-defined risk appetites. The new framework will be developed concurrently with APRA's annual stress tests, which will be conducted instead of the previous three-yearly checks. The regulator will consult the industry on the framework's development in the second half of the year.

site_title: 125.4m new units in Prime US Reit to begin trading on Feb 21
summary: Prime US Reit will begin trading 125.4 million new units on the Singapore bourse on Feb 21, bringing the total units in issue to 1.05 billion. The new units were issued at US$0.957 apiece as part of a private placement to raise US$120 million for an acquisition.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand: Shares retreat from record highs as virus spreads
summary: Australian and New Zealand shares retreated from record highs on Friday, February 21, 2020, amid mounting concerns over the spread of the coronavirus. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.2% as fears of a prolonged global economic impact intensified. South Korea reported 52 new cases, bringing its total to 156, and 25 other countries have reported 1,076 cases to the World Health Organization. The epidemic is expected to disrupt economic growth in China and potentially derail a projected global recovery in 2020, according to the International Monetary Fund.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open flat as traders eye coronavirus impact
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on February 21, 2020, as investors assessed the impact of the coronavirus outbreak on Japan's economy. The Nikkei 225 index initially slipped 0.12% but recovered to a 0.07% gain, ending at 23,494.64. The broader Topix index rose 0.24%. The market reaction was cautious, with traders weighing the potential economic impact of the outbreak.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OCBC, UOB, Sembcorp, DBS, Wilmar, Hongkong Land, ComfortDelGro, StarHub
summary:
Here is a summary of the article in 100 words or less:

Several Singaporean companies reported earnings on Friday, with OCBC Bank's net profit growing 34% to S$1.24 billion in Q4, while UOB's net profit rose 10%. Sembcorp Industries posted a net loss of S$15 million, and DBS Group will provide abridged financial disclosures. Wilmar International's core net profit lifted by 23% to US$410 million, while Hongkong Land acquired a prime site in Shanghai for S$6.2 billion. Other companies, including ComfortDelGro, StarHub, Sheng Siong, OUE, Chip Eng Seng, Roxy-Pacific Holdings, Sunpower Group, and Vividthree Holdings, also reported earnings or announced significant developments.

site_title: Asia-Pacific airlines could lose US$27.8b to coronavirus: IATA
summary: Asia-Pacific airlines could lose US$27.8 billion in revenue this year due to the coronavirus crisis, according to the International Air Transport Association. The estimated 13% decline in passenger demand, primarily in China, is the first time since the 2008-2009 financial crisis that demand for air travel has declined. Airlines in China's domestic market are expected to lose around US$12.8 billion, while carriers outside the Asia-Pacific region may suffer US$1.5 billion in losses. Governments and airlines are taking measures to mitigate the impact, but the exact loss on profits remains uncertain.

site_title: Alita Resources' proposed delisting gets SGX nod
summary: Alita Resources, a CATALIST-listed lithium miner, received approval from the Singapore Exchange to proceed with its proposed delisting. The company does not require shareholder approval, as a court application has been made to transfer shares to a related Chinese entity, China Hydrogen Energy, for nil consideration. Shareholders, who will see their investments go to zero, are fighting the takeover. Alita shares have been suspended from trading since last August due to a loan default. The company will provide updates on the delisting process in due course.

site_title: Irish PM resigns to caretaker role as government formation founders
summary: Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar resigned as taoiseach, but will remain in a caretaker role, as the country's three main parties struggle to form a coalition government after an inconclusive election. Sinn Fein leader Mary Lou McDonald received the most votes, but fell short of the 80 needed to take office. At least three parties are needed to form a majority government, and talks between Sinn Fein and smaller parties are ongoing, potentially leading to a new election.

site_title: Qatar says Saudi blocks official from Gulf coronavirus summit
summary: Qatar's Health Minister, Hanan al-Kuwari, was barred from a Gulf coronavirus summit by Saudi Arabia, despite being invited by Saudi King Salman. This move has been seen as a politicization of a humanitarian sector, amid long-standing tensions between Qatar and Saudi Arabia, which severed diplomatic ties in 2017. Qatar expressed concern over Saudi's actions, which come as the region struggles to respond to the coronavirus epidemic.

site_title: Soft inflation adds to Japan's economic woes, keeps Bank of Japan under pressure
summary: Japan's annual core consumer inflation rose 0.8% in January, slightly above economists' estimates, keeping the Bank of Japan under pressure to maintain its monetary stimulus. The economy remains fragile due to weak growth, a coronavirus outbreak, and weak wage growth, with some economists predicting a technical recession this quarter. The Bank of Japan is hesitant to top up its stimulus, fearing it would have limited ammunition for future crises. Governor Haruhiko Kuroda has expressed willingness to consider additional easing if the outbreak significantly threatens the economy.

images.alt_text: Japan's annual core consumer inflation picked up only slightly in January, keeping the Bank of Japan under pressure to maintain its massive monetary stimulus to support a fragile economy saddled with weak growth and prices.

site_title: OCBC expects 2% dip in 2020 revenue growth on virus impact; ups dividend on higher Q4 profit
summary: OCBC Bank expects a 2% dip in 2020 revenue growth due to the novel coronavirus outbreak, with a base case scenario of the virus settling down by June. The bank's net profit grew 34% to S$1.24 billion in Q4, driven by wealth management, higher income from trading, and insurance franchise. OCBC raised its dividend payout by 23% to S$0.53 per share. Credit costs and non-performing loan ratio are expected to increase slightly, but the bank's exposure to vulnerable sectors is limited.

site_title: Budget moves 'prioritise viable firms for a reason'
summary: The Singapore Budget 2020 has been criticized for prioritizing firms that are doing well over those struggling financially. The 25% corporate income tax rebate and enhanced Wage Credit Scheme aim to support "viable firms" that have been hit by the Covid-19 outbreak, rather than those in a loss-making position. Experts argue that resources are better spent on firms with potential to transform, rather than propping up struggling ones.

site_title: Sembcorp sinks into the red with S$15m Q4 loss
summary: Sembcorp Industries reported a net loss of S$15 million for its fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2019, due to lower revenue from its energy and marine segments. Revenue fell 10% to S$2.32 billion, while net profit for the full year was down 29% to S$247 million. The company recommended a final cash dividend of three Singapore cents per share, up from two cents a year ago. Despite a transformation plan, Sembcorp cited downside risks to global economic growth due to geopolitical tensions and the Covid-19 outbreak.

site_title: UK PM Johnson says looking forward to meeting Trump in June
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson expressed enthusiasm for meeting US President Donald Trump in June, following reports of a postponed meeting in early 2020. The planned visit was rescheduled for the G-7 Summit in the US, amid strained relations over issues such as Huawei's role in the UK's mobile network and the Iran nuclear deal. Johnson and Trump reaffirmed their commitment to the UK-US relationship and look forward to discussing bilateral and international issues at the summit. The meeting is seen as an opportunity for the two nations to strike a trade deal.

site_title: honestbee's habitat to remain closed till end-Feb amid virus outbreak
summary: honestbee is extending the closure of its Pasir Panjang habitat supermarket until Feb 29 due to concerns over the novel coronavirus (Covid-19) outbreak in Singapore. The initial closure, which began on Feb 10, was initially set to last until Feb 23. honestbee will use the time to improve its technology infrastructure to enhance customer experience. The decision follows the Singapore government's raising of the Disease Outbreak Response System Condition to Orange, the second-highest level.

images.alt_text: honestbee is extending the suspension of operations at its habitat supermarket until Feb 29.

site_title: UOB to launch digital bank TMRW next in Indonesia this year
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) plans to launch its digital bank, TMRW, in Indonesia this year, following its successful launch in Thailand in 2019. The bank aims to capture a S$10 billion market opportunity in ASEAN, targeting young professionals and millennials. TMRW is expected to run at a 35% cost-to-income ratio and be marginal-cost positive within five years. The bank's expansion follows DBS' launch of its digibank in Indonesia, and UOB posted a 10% rise in net profit for its fourth quarter.

site_title: Japan's factory activity shrinks at fastest pace since 2012 on coronavirus jolt
summary: Japan's factory activity shrank at its fastest pace in seven years in February due to the coronavirus outbreak, with the manufacturing purchasing managers' index falling to 47.6 from 48.8 in January. This marks the longest contraction since 2009 and increases pressure on policymakers to increase stimulus. New orders declined at the fastest pace in over seven years, while overall output and backlogs of work also dropped. A recession in Japan's economy is now a significant concern, with economists warning of a technical recession.

site_title: China's Hubei province reports 115 more coronavirus deaths
summary: China's death toll from the coronavirus epidemic rose to 2,233 after 115 more people died in Hubei province, mostly in Wuhan. The province reported 411 new cases, with 319 in Wuhan and the rest in other cities. The death toll includes 1,699 in Wuhan and 534 in other areas.
