The revised criteria for counting patients will now only include those diagnosed by laboratory tests, potentially complicating efforts to track the spread of the illness.

site_title: UOB Q4 profit up 10% to S$1.01b
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) reported a 10% increase in its fourth-quarter net profit to S$1.01 billion, driven by growth in net interest income and trading and investment income. The bank's annualized earnings per share rose 9.3% to S$2.35. UOB recommended a dividend of 55 Singapore cents and a special dividend of 20 cents per share, and its net interest margin decreased four basis points to 1.76%. The bank's non-performing loans ratio remained unchanged at 1.5%.

site_title: ST Engineering JV to sell 30 aircraft engines
summary: ST Engineering's aerospace arm, TOTAL Engine Asset Management (TEAM), is selling 30 aircraft engines through a securitisation structure, freeing up capital for future investments. The sale, valued at US$257 million, will reduce TEAM's capital employed and enable the group to scale up its engine leasing business. The transaction, the company's first securitisation, includes fixed-rate notes and equity notes, with TEAM retaining 10% of the equity notes. The sale is expected to be a "major milestone" for the engine leasing business, allowing the company to lower its capital requirements and create value for lessors.

site_title: US: Stocks descend as coronavirus rattles traders
summary: US stocks declined on Thursday, retreating from solid gains due to concerns over the coronavirus outbreak in China. Over 2,118 people have died and 74,000 infected, with the virus spreading to 25 countries. The Dow fell 0.4% to 29,219.98, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq also dropped, with Apple and Goldman Sachs shares falling 1.0% and 1.9% respectively. Despite this, some analysts say the market decline is healthy and that the US economy has solid fundamentals.

site_title: Petrobras workers suspend 2-week strike, accept mediation
summary: Workers on strike at Petrobras, a state-run oil company in Brazil, have temporarily suspended their 2-week stoppage and accepted mediation to resolve their dispute. The strike, which began on February 7, was called to protest layoffs at a loss-making fertilizer factory in Parana. The company stated that the strike did not impact production. The FUP union, representing the striking workers, has agreed to negotiate with Petrobras to resolve the issue.

site_title: DBS prices US$1b perp deal at 3.3%, first callable in 2025
summary: DBS Group announced a US$1 billion perpetual capital securities deal with a 3.3% coupon rate, the lowest for any AT1 US dollar deal. The securities, expected to be rated Baa1(hyb) by Moody's, will be issued under the group's US$30 billion global medium-term note programme and will not be callable until 2025. Net proceeds will be used for DBS Group's finance and treasury activities. Over 304 accounts received US$5.5 billion in orders, with 77% coming from Asia.

site_title: Oil prices rise as US crude stocks build less than expected
summary: US oil prices rose slightly on Thursday after the US Energy Information Administration reported a smaller-than-expected increase in crude stocks, with Brent crude futures up 19 cents to $59.31 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures up 49 cents to $53.78 a barrel. However, concerns about the spread of the coronavirus outside China and its potential impact on global demand limited gains. Analysts expect oil prices to remain volatile due to the ongoing pandemic and global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Uber reactivates Colombia service after three-week hiatus
summary: Uber reactivated its service in Colombia after a three-week suspension due to a court ruling that found the company benefited from unfair competition. The US giant suspended its operations in February after losing a case brought by taxi drivers. Uber introduced a new model requiring users to subscribe to a 17-point contract to apply for transport services. The measure is described as temporary and aimed at reducing damage caused by the court verdict. Uber plans to seek $250 million in damages from Colombia in international arbitration.

site_title: Six workers rescued from underground cigarette factory in Spain
summary: Spanish police have rescued six Ukrainian workers trapped in a counterfeit cigarette factory four meters underground in Malaga, Spain. The factory, which produced over 3,500 cigarettes an hour, was discovered last week and its 20 suspected operators were arrested on February 13. The workers were left without air after the generator ran out, and their cries for help were ignored due to the factory's soundproofing. Police used a forklift to rescue the workers, who were forced to work in "extremely dangerous and toxic conditions."

site_title: Three new coronavirus cases in Iran after two deaths
summary: Iran has confirmed three new coronavirus cases and two more deaths, bringing the total to five cases with two fatalities, mostly elderly Iranian citizens. The deaths were reported in the city of Qom, a center for Islamic studies and tourists. In response, Iraq banned travel to and from Iran, closing border crossings and requiring Iraqi nationals returning from Iran to undergo 14-day quarantine. The government in Iran has set up a top-level body to fight the virus' spread, but public confidence in government pronouncements has plummeted amid concerns of a cover-up.

site_title: White House trumpets economic success compared to Obama
summary: The White House has released its Economic Report of the President, claiming significant economic growth under President Donald Trump compared to his predecessor Barack Obama. The report states that Trump's policies produced economic growth that surpassed the previous administration's, with Tomas Philipson, acting director of the Council of Economic Advisors, noting that the growth is "not a continuation of expansion after great recession." The report highlights various economic indicators, including low unemployment, rising wages, and increased economic output, as evidence of Trump's economic success.

images.alt_text: With the US presidential campaign heating up, the White House continues to look backward, comparing President Donald Trump's economic record to his predecessor Barack Obama.

site_title: Munich property boom prompts sale of 'social bonds' to protect renters
summary: Munich, Germany is selling a social bond worth 120 million euros to help offer affordable housing for renters, amid a city-wide housing crunch. The bond, which matures in 2023, will be used to buy apartments and rent them out at affordable prices. The move aims to address soaring property prices, with existing apartments rising 189% since the financial crisis. The sale is the first of its kind by a European city, and city officials hope it will set a precedent for other municipalities.

site_title: From electric (car) dreams to reality
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced that by 2040, all cars in the country will be electric, phasing out internal combustion engines. This bold vision aims to reduce the country's carbon footprint and promote a sustainable future. The move is part of the government's efforts to transition the car industry and encourage consumers to adopt electric vehicles.

site_title: Tesla gets court approval to clear forest for German Gigafactory
summary: Tesla has received court approval to clear a forest in Germany for its first European Gigafactory, despite opposition from environmental activists. The court rejected urgent applications to stop tree felling, allowing the US electric carmaker to proceed with its plans to build the factory in Brandenburg, a state surrounding Berlin. The decision marks a defeat for local environmental groups, who had initially welcomed Tesla's investment as a vote of confidence in Germany. The court's ruling is final, allowing Tesla to continue with the land clearing process.

site_title: Europe: Shares mark worst day in 3 weeks on weak earnings, coronavirus risks
summary: European shares fell 0.9% on Thursday, marking their worst day in three weeks, due to disappointing earnings and concerns about the global impact of the coronavirus outbreak. A near 2% drop in insurance stocks led losses, while luxury stocks, which rely on Chinese demand, also declined. Despite this, some sectors, such as autos and technology, rose, with Renault and Tomra Systems gaining 3% and 19% respectively. Research suggesting the virus could spread more easily than previously thought added to market concerns, although expectations of a pickup in growth from the second quarter have kept equity markets near record highs.

site_title: Changi Airport tenants get 50% rental rebate for six months
summary: Changi Airport tenants will receive a 50% rebate on monthly basic rent for six months due to weaker travel and consumer demand following the Covid-19 outbreak. This rebate, valued at S$112 million, is on top of an automatic rental offset linked to passenger traffic. The airport operator will also shorten operating hours for non-essential tenants and offer marketing initiatives to boost consumer demand. Airlines and cargo operators are receiving additional support, including 100% parking charge rebates and 10% landing charge rebates.

site_title: Chinese man argues against deportation from Canada, citing virus
summary: A Chinese man, Ruepang Cao, 36, argued against deportation from Canada due to the risk of COVID-19 in his native Guangdong province. Cao, who had been rejected for asylum in 2004, claimed he faced a significant risk of harm from the virus. However, a Canadian judge ruled that the risk was low, citing low infection and mortality rates in many parts of China. Cao's deportation was allowed to proceed, despite his lawyer's claims that he was put on a flight to China.

site_title: OUE profit jumps to S$255m on divestment, development gains
summary: OUE, a Singapore property group, reported a net profit of S$255.2 million in 2019, up from S$10 million in 2018, driven by development income and divestment gains. Revenue rose 44.8% to S$930.8 million, led by sales of development properties. OUE also booked a gain on the disposal of its minority stake in an Aquamarina Hotel. The company proposed a final dividend of six Singapore cents, down from 12 cents in the fourth quarter. Despite challenges in the hospitality business due to the coronavirus outbreak, OUE expects office rents to remain stable in the near future.

site_title: iFast aims to crack 20% ROE through digital banking in 5 years
summary: iFast Corporation, a Singapore-based fintech firm, aims to achieve a 20% return on equity (ROE) from its digital banking unit within the next five years. The company, which operates a wealth management platform, plans to secure deposits through its existing network and target the mass affluent market. With a proposed wholesale bank license in Singapore, iFast aims to integrate its platform into the digital bank and boost service fee income to achieve a better capital liquidity ratio and ROE.

site_title: Democrats make it personal in scorching debate
summary: In a heated Democratic presidential debate, candidates mounted personal attacks on each other, with Senator Elizabeth Warren and former Vice President Joe Biden targeting Michael Bloomberg over his past support for stop-and-frisk policing and allegations of disrespect towards women. Warren also criticized Bloomberg's nondisclosure agreements with former female employees, while Biden called for their release. The debate highlighted the urgency of the moment, with Senator Bernie Sanders gaining strength and Bloomberg facing scrutiny over his record. The attacks reflected the increasing competitiveness of the Democratic primary, with Sanders and Bloomberg vying for the nomination.

site_title: Scaling up sustainable finance in Asia
summary: Central banks and regulatory authorities in Asia are increasingly involved in the climate debate, with 94% of respondents in a survey by the South East Asian Central Banks (SEACEN) Centre believing their institutions should encourage low-carbon financing and green initiatives. However, only 29% have issued financing instruments or implemented regulatory policies to encourage private financing for low-carbon investments. Asian central banks, such as the People's Bank of China and the Reserve Bank of India, have taken various actions to mitigate climate risk, including setting mandatory disclosures and launching green refinancing policies. The SEACEN Centre aims to explore how central banks can implement climate-related measures, including stress testing and carbon-based capital buffers.

site_title: A good start for Ichigo Ichie
summary: Chef Akane Eno's debut kappo restaurant, Ichigo Ichie, has opened at the InterContinental hotel in Singapore, offering a unique blend of familiar and inspired original creations. The restaurant serves high-end, uncomplicated Japanese cuisine, with dishes such as cold prawn somen and shabu shabu, all crafted personally by the enthusiastic and genuine chef. With a focus on seasonal ingredients, the menu is priced around S$268 for a full dinner service. Despite a slight loss in quality due to increased pressure, the restaurant is a pleasant surprise and a testament to Chef Eno's skills, earning a rating of 7.

site_title: UBS names ING boss Hamers as CEO to replace its current chief
summary: UBS Group has named Ralph Hamers, the CEO of ING Groep, as its new CEO, replacing Sergio Ermotti who has been with the bank for nearly a decade. Hamers starts on November 1 and succeeds Ermotti, who oversaw the bank's wealth management business. Hamers' appointment replaces speculation about Iqbal Khan, a star wealth manager who joined UBS last year. Under Hamers' leadership, ING steered to profitability and invested heavily in digital transformation, with a focus on online offerings.

site_title: STI slips as Budget optimism wanes
summary: Singapore's stock market retreated slightly on Thursday as post-Budget optimism waned and concerns over the global impact of the COVID-19 outbreak resumed. Despite the most expansionary budget in over two decades, the benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) closed down 0.47% at 3,198.68, bucking the trend. Analysts expect the local market to remain volatile until the effectiveness of Singapore's measures to fight the outbreak becomes apparent, with some predicting a Q2 recovery.

site_title: Coronavirus outbreak cools China's red-hot home rental startups
summary: China's online real estate startups, including Danke, have been severely impacted by the COVID-19 outbreak, with many landlords and tenants demanding rent waivers or payment deferrals. The sector, which was expected to rapidly expand, is now facing financial pressure due to inflated fixed costs and declining revenue. Authorities have imposed stricter measures, including requiring landlords to alert authorities about tenants from Wuhan, further exacerbating the crisis. The outbreak has dealt a significant blow to the sector, which was previously valued at $2.2 billion, and its future prospects remain uncertain.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Strategies to amplify branding for businesses & start-ups
summary: A Money FM podcast discusses strategies for businesses and start-ups to amplify their branding. The episode shares insights on effective branding, marketing, and leadership. Key takeaways include the importance of authenticity, tracking leadership development, and eliminating executive chairs. Experts also highlight the need for systems leadership in managing complexity during mergers and acquisitions. The podcast aims to provide actionable advice for businesses looking to boost their branding and stay competitive in the market.

site_title: Sembcorp Marine posts Q4 loss of S$77.7 million
summary: Sembcorp Marine reported a net loss of S$77.7 million for the Q4 2019 due to a downturn in the offshore and marine space. Despite this, the company remains hopeful of brighter prospects ahead, citing increased enquiries for projects in its Singapore yards. Management expects supply chain disruptions to affect production, but is preparing for the eventuality through automation and outsourcing. The company's full-year loss nearly doubled to S$137.2 million, but it added new jobs worth S$1.49 billion to its orderbook.

site_title: Hyflux has till March 10 to get court okay for scheme meeting
summary: Hyflux has until March 10 to obtain court approval for its scheme meeting. The company's new lawyers from Clifford Chance have a tight deadline to prepare documentation, including an agreement on adviser fees for Utico. The scheme meeting is set for May 26, and Hyflux must finalize its plans by then. This comes as the company navigates its financial challenges and embarks on a restructuring process.

site_title: A president who is his own worst enemy
summary: President Donald Trump's re-election prospects are hindered by his self-destructive behavior and divisive personality, rather than his policies. Despite being acquitted by the Senate after an impeachment trial, Trump's response to the acquittal was aggressive, with him accusing Democrats of a "corrupt" impeachment and ordering the firing of White House officials who testified against him. This behavior has alienated many of his supporters, who are now questioning their decision to vote for him in 2016. In contrast, Democratic presidential candidate Amy Klobuchar is seen as a unifying figure who could potentially defeat Trump in the 2020 election.

site_title: Income inequality falls to lowest in nearly two decades
summary: Singapore's income inequality has fallen to its lowest level in nearly two decades, with the top 10% household income group experiencing a 0.4% rise in real terms last year. This reduced the income gap, which has been narrowing since the government's push for higher wage thresholds for lower-income workers. The Gini coefficient, measuring income inequality, fell to 0.452, the lowest since 2001. Despite slower growth in household income for the top 10%, economists attribute this to the rising wealth of the group due to soaring stock and property prices.

site_title: Turbulent fourth quarter ahead for SIA as impact of outbreak takes hold
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is expected to face turbulence in the fourth quarter due to the impact of the Covid-19 outbreak, with reduced passenger yields and declining cargo traffic out of China. The carrier has already cancelled over 700 flights and reduced capacity, and analysts predict a loss of S$280 million in the fourth quarter. Despite cost-cutting measures, SIA's operating costs could reach S$6.5 billion, making it difficult to offset losses from lower demand.

site_title: 2020 Mini JCW Countryman review: Country dancing
summary: The 2020 Mini JCW Countryman is a sport utility vehicle with sportscar performance, boasting 306 horsepower and a 0-100km/h time of 5.1 seconds. Its all-wheel drive, eight-speed gearbox, and mid-life revamp make it a unique blend of speed and practicality. While it excels in terms of traction and grip, its suspension can feel firm and jarring in Sport mode, adding to the car's wild and humorous driving experience. Priced at S$218,888, the JCW Countryman offers a good balance of performance and value.

site_title: Rioja Gran Reserva, a wine beginning to be shaped by time
summary: Rioja Gran Reserva, a wine traditionally aged for at least five years, is adapting to changing consumer habits and market trends. With the rise of the global economy and increased accessibility, many producers are shifting their focus from age to terroir, allowing wines to be released earlier. Producers like R Lopéz de Heredia continue to age their gran reservas, but some label wines by their provenance, bypassing the need for pre-sale aging. Three examples of Rioja Gran Reserva, Faustino I 2006, Bodegas Riojanas Rioja Gran Reserva Monte Real 2010, and La Rioja Alta Rioja Gran Reserva 904 2009, showcase the characteristic mellow texture and flavor of aged wines, with the 2006 Faustino I being the oldest and most evolved of the three.

site_title: Now serving: a plate of uncertainty
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has disrupted the dining industry, with restaurants experiencing varying levels of impact depending on their location, clientele, and business model. While high-end restaurants and those catering to wealthy clients from mainland China have seen a decline, others in lower-density areas or hard-to-book spots have remained unaffected. Restaurants are adapting by introducing food delivery services, reducing rent, and implementing enhanced hygiene measures. Consumers are also changing their behavior, with many opting for private dining, food delivery, and avoiding buffets due to concerns about public health.

site_title: Why innovation is about more than shiny gadgets
summary: Innovation is not solely defined by high-tech gadgets, but encompasses a broader range of forms, including radical and incremental changes in various industries. It can occur in small startups or large corporations, and can be driven by entrepreneurship or other factors. Shiny technology may grab headlines, but true innovation involves more than just new devices.

site_title: Sheng Siong Q4 profit flat at S$17.4m; new stores important source of revenue growth
summary: Sheng Siong, a Singaporean supermarket operator, reported a fourth-quarter net profit of S$17.4 million, down 0.4% from the same period last year. Revenue rose 11.8% to S$247.9 million, driven by new store openings. The company attributed revenue growth to new stores, which accounted for an 8.6% increase, and China. Comparable same-store sales grew 1.8% and full-year earnings per share rose 7% to 5.04 cents. A final dividend of 1.80 cents per share has been proposed, and the company is preparing for potential disruptions from the novel coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Sing dollar breaches 1.40 against USD as recession concerns grow
summary: The Singapore dollar (SGD) has breached 1.40 against the US dollar, its lowest level in over two months, amid growing recession fears due to the novel coronavirus outbreak. The currency's slide reflects weakness in Asian currencies, with the Asia Dollar Index retreating to 103.50. Economists predict the SGD may rebound to 1.37 by the end of the second quarter, but warn of considerable uncertainty on the macro front for Singapore and Asia. The Monetary Authority of Singapore has downgraded its growth forecast to between -0.5% and 1.5% for 2020.

site_title: SGX RegCo urges caution when dealing in Vividthree shares
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has urged caution when dealing in Vividthree shares, citing a review of trades between Sept 9, 2019, and Feb 19, 2020. A small group of connected accounts accounted for over 90% of traded volume, with 71% of on-market trades being "cross trades" between these accounts. Vividthree announced a placement of up to 15.88 million shares on Feb 12, following a decline in its share price since mid-January 2020. SGX RegCo is working closely with authorities on the matter.

site_title: Wilmar Q4 core net profit up 23% to US$410m on tropical oils, oilseeds
summary: Wilmar International reported a 23% increase in core net profit to US$410 million in Q4, driven by strong performance from tropical oils and improved oilseeds crush margins. This is a 120% increase from the same period last year, excluding a one-off impairment charge. The company's agri-business group net profit reached US$438 million.

site_title: New Stamford Tyres outlet woos both young and old
summary: STAMFORD Tyres has opened its 11th retail outlet in Alexandra Village Industrial Estate, Singapore. The new service centre combines a classic location with a modern approach. The outlet offers a range of tyre and automotive accessories to both young and old customers. This marks the Mainboard-listed retailer's expansion into the Singapore market.

images.alt_text: The company sees the new outlet's proximity to the Alexandra automotive belt as a plus.

site_title: Cardboard Dwellings
summary: Interior design consultant Wilfred Cheah, 55, creates intricate paper artworks of houses, including HDB flats and Peranakan shophouses, with 90% cardboard and details like toothpicks and toilet paper. His artworks, which take two weeks to complete, aim to capture the life and soul of a bygone era. Cheah, who grew up in a 1960s HDB flat, now accepts commissions for custom pieces, inspired by his childhood and daily life. His realistic renditions have gained attention on Facebook, with many commenting on their accuracy.

images.alt_text: A Peranakan House.
Recreation of a HDB block of flats.
Close up of items found along the corridors.
Close up of items found along the corridors.
Close up of items found along the corridors.
Cardboard artist Wilfred Cheah.
Details of a Peranakan shophouse.

site_title: MG ZS EV review: A bright spark
summary: The MG ZS EV is considered the best electric car in its price range, rivaling combustion cars. It boasts a spacious cabin, smooth acceleration, and a quiet ride. The electric motor provides instant response in Sport mode, and the car's handling is designed for comfort rather than thrill. With a claimed range of 335km and a price of S$126,888, the MG ZS EV offers a battery-powered bargain. Its Chinese origins have contributed to its affordability, and it is assembled to a high standard.

site_title: Daniel Cordaro, Founder & CEO of The Contentment Foundation
summary: American psychologist Daniel Cordaro, founder of The Contentment Foundation, argues that true happiness lies in being content with one's life, rather than pursuing external sources of joy. This concept, rooted in ancient philosophies, contrasts with the modern idea of "pursuing happiness" which leads to chronic dissatisfaction. Cordaro suggests that cultivating inner joy requires self-awareness, mindfulness, and accepting one's emotions, rather than trying to avoid or suppress them. He also notes that contemporary lifestyles, including social media and technology, can prevent people from developing contentment, and encourages individuals to find a balance between engagement with the world and maintaining inner peace.

site_title: Cool Capsules
summary: Capsule hotels originated in Japan's Osaka city in the late 1970s as a solution to a spa's problem with men sleeping in and snoring. The first capsule hotel, Capsule Inn Osaka, opened in 1979, featuring small fibreglass pods stacked on top of each other. Today, capsule hotels have become socially acceptable and cool, with various establishments offering unique experiences, such as Hotel J-Ship and A-Style Shinsaibashi, catering to different needs and preferences. Rates vary, but they are affordable, offering a timely reminder that good things come in small packages.

site_title: Budget 2020 pushes the boundaries for internationalisation
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat's Budget 2020 introduces measures to support Singapore companies in internationalizing, including enhanced Market Readiness Assistance, expert advice on Free Trade Agreements, and the Singapore Business Federation's GlobalConnect@SBF programme. The Executive-in-Residence Programme also aims to help companies grow regionally and globally. Additionally, the Networked Trade Platform is being rolled out to reduce non-tariff barriers to trading across borders, with collaborations with other territories underway. The government hopes these efforts will encourage more Singapore companies to succeed overseas.

site_title: Making her mark
summary: Japanese chef Akane Eno has opened her own restaurant, Ichigo Ichie, in Singapore, serving her unique style of kappo kaiseki cuisine. Eno, 42, is one of few female Japanese chefs to helm her own restaurant, having previously worked in Tokyo and Singapore. Her restaurant showcases her personal collection of pottery and features a menu that blends traditional Japanese flavors with inspiration from other cuisines. Eno's cooking is described as authentic and genuine, drawing from her extensive culinary experience and personal inspirations.

site_title: Why firms need investor relations
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has abolished mandatory quarterly reporting for most listed companies, shifting to a risk-based approach. Only companies with a modified auditor opinion on their financial statements or those with significant regulatory concerns will have to continue with quarterly reporting. Investor relations (IR) is emphasized as a dynamic tool to enhance corporate governance standards and practices. Effective IR can foster greater transparency and stronger corporate governance, and companies that prioritize IR are more likely to achieve sustained corporate performance and investor confidence.

site_title: Fintech investments in Singapore more than double in 2019
summary: Fintech investments in Singapore more than doubled in 2019 to US$861 million, driven by big gains in funding to payments and insurtech startups. This led to the country becoming the fifth-largest fintech market in the Asia-Pacific by funds. Payments startups received 39% of the total funds, while insurtechs accounted for 25%. The number of deals also increased by 52% to 108. Singapore's fintech ecosystem is expected to continue growing, with a shift in investment trends expected as new digital banks enter the market.

images.alt_text: Fintech investments in Singapore more than doubled to US$861 million in 2019 from the year before, led by big gains in funding to payments and insurtech startups.

site_title: US housing starts fall, building permits near 13-year high
summary: US housing starts fell 3.6% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.567 million units in January, but building permits surged to a near 13-year high of 1.551 million units, lifting the housing market to sustained strength. The data supports the Federal Reserve's decision to keep interest rates unchanged, with housing accounting for 3.1% of the economy. The housing market remains a solid link in a cooling economy, with single-family starts rising and multi-family housing permits reaching a 14-year high.

site_title: Yen slides further to hit 10-month low
summary: The Japanese yen slid to a 10-month low of 111.84 to the dollar, surpassing a key technical barrier, amid a strengthening US dollar and improving risk appetite in global markets. Economic news from Japan, including a drop in new Covid-19 infections and a cut in benchmark lending rates, also contributed to the yen's weakness. Analysts attribute the yen's decline to Japanese asset managers selling local assets in favor of US shares and gold, rather than a broader "risk on" sentiment.

site_title: Co-Living Gets A Heritage Spin
summary: Co-living spaces, where residents share a legacy home with strangers, are gaining popularity in Singapore. Hmlet introduced the concept in 2017, and new players Figment and Cooliv are now incorporating architectural heritage into their designs. These co-living spaces offer shorter leases, communal events, and spaces to foster community bonds. By tapping into Singapore's heritage appeal, these new players are shaking up the co-living market, providing an alternative to traditional rentals and co-working spaces. This trend is expected to continue, changing the way people look at accommodation in the city-state.

site_title: Investment banks cosy up to VCs in hunt for potential unicorns
summary: Investment banks in Asia are strengthening ties with venture capital firms to capitalize on the region's rapidly rising startup valuations. By building early relationships with startups, banks aim to facilitate larger funding rounds, often worth billions of dollars, and earn a cut. This strategy allows banks to tap into the private market and position themselves for future IPOs, M&A, or larger capital raises. In return, banks help VCs professionalize companies and generate liquidity for earlier investors, creating a mutually beneficial arrangement.

site_title: How to buy a bargain BMW
summary: BMW is offering discounted prices on 350 used cars provided to the Singapore Airshow. The 320i, 520i, and 730Li sedans, previously used for VIP transport, are now on the market with prices reduced by S$20,000 "overtrade" deals. This partnership aims to boost sales, with only around 70 cars remaining from the event. The move can help buyers snag lightly-used cars at lower prices, with prices starting from S$185,888 for the 320i and S$222,888 for the 520i.

site_title: Opportune time for workers, firms to put SkillsFuture credits to good use
summary: Singapore's SkillsFuture initiative, launched five years ago, aims to promote lifelong learning and skill development among citizens. The program has seen a 14% increase in training participation, with over 500,000 Singaporeans using their initial credits for courses like coding and foreign languages. The government recently announced a one-off credit top-up of S$500 for those aged 25-60, and a S$10,000 grant for employers to support staff training. Experts emphasize the importance of employers investing in staff skills to build a stronger and more resilient workforce, which can help other businesses succeed.

site_title: Is remote working the future of work?
summary: A growing number of tech companies, such as Automattic and GitLab, are adopting an "all-remote" work model, where employees work from home full-time, potentially changing the future of work. Studies have linked remote working to higher job satisfaction, productivity, and organizational commitment. These companies use digital platforms to facilitate collaboration and transparency, reducing the need for physical co-location. GitLab's all-remote model has allowed it to hire the best talent globally and reduce politics and power struggles, resulting in a more cohesive and transparent organization. The trend may have long-term implications for management and the role of AI in decision-making.

images.alt_text: Researchers have linked the decentralisation of work to higher job satisfaction, productivity and organisational commitment - as well as decreased stress levels and exhaustion.

site_title: Soul Brothers
summary: Phunk, a Singapore-based art and design collective, marks its 25th year with a retrospective exhibition titled "Control Chaos." Founded by four friends Alvin Tan, Melvin Chee, Jackson Tan, and William Chan in 1994, the group has garnered international recognition, including the President's Design Award in 2007. The exhibition features a mix of chaotic and controlled designs, reflecting the group's design philosophy. Phunk's style blends Eastern and Western sensibilities, and they continue to collaborate with clients and artists, with no plans to disband. The exhibition runs until March 20 at the National Design Centre.

images.alt_text: Control Chaos, an artwork reflecting the state of the world.
DISCO, a public art installation at Promenade MRT station.
Love Bomb, an installation with the message that love is the most powerful force in the world.
Melvin Chee, Alvin Tan, Jackson Tan and William Chan.

site_title: BMW 2 Series Gran Coupe review: Baby Gran
summary: BMW's 2 Series Gran Coupe is a compact four-door car that lives up to its badge, offering a convincing blend of style and performance. The car features a sleek design, frameless doors, and a clean interior layout. The 218i model starts at S$160,888 and is priced to tempt buyers, while the M235i xDrive model brings 306 horsepower and all-wheel drive for S$249,888. The 2 Series Gran Coupe is ideal for young couples with one child, offering a balance of agility and stability, making it a delightful driving experience.

site_title: Office or Club?
summary: Two co-working spaces, Crane and No18 Singapore Capitol, have opened in Singapore, offering a hospitality and wellness vibe. Crane expanded its space in mid-2019, while No18, a Swedish high-end co-working brand, has set up its first location in Asia. Both spaces feature unique decor, wellness facilities, and access to fitness and spa services. Members can choose private offices, hot-desking options, or work from mid-century-era sofas and lounge chairs. The spaces aim to provide an environment where work, leisure, and well-being can coexist.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's household income inequality has fallen to an 18-year low, with a Gini coefficient of 0.452. The South Korean won and Singapore dollar are experiencing a decline in value amid the spread of the coronavirus in Asia. ANZ has cut Singapore's 2020 growth outlook to 0.4% due to fiscal support and public consumption. Meanwhile, Hongkong Land has purchased a prime plot in Shanghai's West Bund for 31 billion yuan. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.47% due to waning budget euphoria.

site_title: StarHub Q4 gain up, but top line continues shift towards lower-margin enterprise business
summary: StarHub reported a net profit of S$34.9 million for its Q4 2019, up from S$19.8 million in the same period last year, driven by cost-cutting measures. Despite a 1.8% decline in service revenue, the company expects service revenue to improve by 1-3% in 2020. However, margins are expected to slip due to a shift towards lower-margin cyber security and managed services, with full-year operating profit down 6.4% to S$255.9 million.

site_title: China benchmark loan rate drops after PBOC eases policy
summary: China's benchmark loan rate dropped to 4.05% for one-year loans and 4.75% for five-year loans after the People's Bank of China (PBOC) eased policy to combat the economic impact of the Covid-19 outbreak. The move aims to blunt the economic impact and is seen as a sign of the central bank's intention to hold its stance on property policy. The LPR decline is expected to lead to lower borrowing costs in the wider economy, with forecasts suggesting further declines and possible reserve ratio cuts in the coming months.

site_title: What's Up This Week
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

The Oscar-winning film "Parasite" is now playing in Singapore in a new black and white version, while singer RRILEY releases her third solo track "Love Me Like A". Modern Thai chef Ian Kittichai joins forces with Kirk Westaway at Jaan for a four-hands dinner. Netflix releases a live-action adaptation of Yangsze Choo's novel "The Ghost Bride", but fans are advised to read the book instead. The Singapore Sling is set to be revived at cocktail bar Maison Ikkoku, while a group of young artists showcase new approaches to photography at Undescribed #5.

site_title: Lloyds looks past misselling era with fresh growth forecast
summary: Lloyds Banking Group has set a 12-13% growth forecast for this year, driven by a clearing sense of direction after the Brexit uncertainty and a charge for compensating customers who were missold payment protection insurance. The bank's shares rose 4.2% in early trading. CEO Antonio Horta-Osorio attributed the improved outlook to cost discipline, despite missing analyst forecasts in the fourth quarter. A new three-year plan will be developed in June, with the board proposing to reduce the CEO's maximum pay to £7 million.

site_title: Big names at National Gallery
summary: National Gallery Singapore is set to feature four prominent artists in 2020: Pablo Picasso, Henri Matisse, Georgette Chen, and Latiff Mohidin. The exhibitions, including "Matisse & Picasso: Friends, Rivals," will showcase iconic works from around the world, with loaned artworks and archival material from public and private collections. Georgette Chen's Nanyang era paintings will be highlighted in November, while Latiff Mohidin's avant-garde paintings and literary output will be featured in March. The exhibitions mark the museum's fifth year of exhibiting great art.

site_title: HSBC targets the globally mobile with US$1.4t wealth business
summary: HSBC plans to invest heavily in its combined retail and private banking business, targeting internationally minded customers in markets like China, the US, and Singapore. The bank aims to grow in Britain, Hong Kong, and Mexico, focusing on mortgages, wealth, and insurance products. HSBC will also target wealthier customers who travel or invest often overseas, particularly in China, where its share is smaller. The bank is making management changes, including naming Kevin Martin as chief operating officer of the new global wealth and personal banking business, and will expand partnerships with asset managers like BlackRock.

site_title: US: Wall Street eases at open as virus fears build
summary: US stocks opened slightly lower on Thursday, February 20, 2020, amid growing concerns over the global economic impact of the coronavirus epidemic. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.18%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.17%, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.18%. E*Trade Financial surged on a buyout offer from Morgan Stanley. The decline was attributed to a spike in coronavirus cases outside China, raising fears about the global economic impact.

site_title: Movie outbreaks
summary: Film depictions of global diseases, such as COVID-19, often adhere to scientific facts and sociological truths. Movies like Contagion (2011) and Pandemic (2020) on Netflix accurately portray the transmission of viruses, government responses, and human behavior during outbreaks. These films, despite dramatic elements, hold up well to reality and offer an essential understanding of the emotional, social, and political implications of a virus outbreak. The COVID-19 pandemic has sparked renewed interest in these films, with many viewers turning to them for information and reassurance.

site_title: China tests its soft power with neighbours over coronavirus outbreak
summary: China held a special meeting with Southeast Asian nations, known as ASEAN, to discuss the coronavirus outbreak, seeking expressions of support amid criticism of its handling of the epidemic. China's foreign minister, Wang Yi, called for solidarity and confidence, stating that "fear is more threatening than the virus and confidence is more precious than gold." The meeting came as travel restrictions have idled the Chinese economy and impacted key elements of President Xi Jinping's Belt and Road Initiative. While some ASEAN countries, such as Cambodia and Laos, expressed support, others, like Singapore and the Philippines, have imposed stricter measures.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.82 points to 1,534.98. The market saw 3 billion lots traded worth RM2.3 billion, with 436 losers outnumbering 405 gainers.

site_title: Not a Budget to be sniffed at; economy is in good hands
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat unveiled Singapore's Budget 2020 to tackle the Covid-19 outbreak, address economic uncertainties, and press on with economic transformation. The budget features a record $10.9 billion overall budget deficit and $6.4 billion in measures to mitigate the economic impact of the pandemic. Key measures include a $6 billion Assurance Package, a $4 billion Stabilisation and Support Package, and a 30% property tax rebate for hotels and Mice venues. The budget also includes a 8% wage subsidy, a $500 top-up to the SkillsFuture Credit, and a range of cash payouts for Singaporeans, including up to $300 for all eligible individuals.

site_title: Handling Gen-Z staff? Hire a 'generational consultant'
summary: The article discusses the growing need for generational consultants in the workplace as five distinct generations (traditionalists, baby boomers, Generation Xers, millennials, and Generation Zers) coexist. To attract and retain Gen Zers, companies are adopting strategies such as personalized onboarding, flexible work schedules, and corporate social responsibility. However, some critics argue that these efforts ignore deeper structural issues, such as low wages and high debt levels. Companies like Virgin are using insights from generational consultants, like the Stillmans, to create programs that cater to the needs and preferences of Gen Zers, including field trips, side hustles, and a more relaxed interview process.

site_title: DBS says it will provide abridged financial disclosures in place of QR
summary: DBS Group announced it will provide abridged financial disclosures for its first- and third-quarter performance to shareholders, replacing quarterly reports following the Singapore Exchange's removal of mandatory reporting. The updates will include key financial information and business commentary. DBS will continue making quarterly dividend payments and release the first-quarter update on April 30.

site_title: Sunpower to invest in Jiangsu biomass co-generation plant
summary: Sunpower Group plans to invest in a biomass co-generation project in Jiangsu province, China, with an estimated investment of 420 million yuan (S$84 million). The project, set to be developed under a joint venture, will supply civil heating to homes and electricity to the state grid, meeting China's national development policies. Upon completion, the plant will effectively alleviate environmental pollution, recycle local agricultural waste, and provide pollution-free heating. The project is in line with Sunpower's key business development strategy to grow its green investment portfolio.

site_title: OUE posts FY19 net profit of S$255.2m on 45% rise in revenue
summary: OUE, a Singaporean property group, reported a net profit of S$255.2 million in FY19, up 44.8% from FY18, driven by revenue from development properties and sales of units under deferred payment schemes. The company also booked a S$136.6 million gain from the disposal of its Aquamarina Hotel stake. Despite challenges in the hospitality sector due to the coronavirus outbreak, OUE expects office rent growth to taper off and remain stable in the near future.

site_title: Coronavirus: S'pore confirms first patient with both Covid-19 and dengue
summary: Singapore has confirmed its first patient with both Covid-19 and dengue, a 57-year-old Singaporean woman who visited the hospital twice, initially for dengue symptoms. After developing respiratory symptoms, she was tested for coronavirus disease and confirmed to have Covid-19. The patient is in isolation and others who were in contact with her while she was a dengue patient are now quarantined. This is the only known case of co-infection of the two diseases in Singapore.

site_title: Coronavirus: 1 new case in S'pore, no known link yet to previous cases; 3 patients discharged
summary: Singapore reports 1 new case of coronavirus, bringing the total to 85. The new case is a 36-year-old male with no recent travel history to China, and is currently warded at the National Centre for Infectious Diseases. Three more patients were discharged, with 37 cases fully recovered. Most of the remaining 48 cases in hospital are stable and improving, with 4 in critical condition. The government has identified 2,616 close contacts, with 1,147 currently quarantined.

site_title: One new Covid-19 case in Singapore; no known link yet
summary: Singapore reported one new Covid-19 case, bringing the total to 85, with the patient being a 36-year-old male Chinese national with no recent travel history to China. Three more patients were discharged, with 37 cases fully recovered. The majority of 48 hospital cases are stable, and 2,616 close contacts are being monitored, with 1,469 having completed quarantine.

images.alt_text: One new case of the novel coronavirus disease was confirmed on Thursday, bringing the total number of infected people here to 85.

site_title: StarHub nearly doubles Q4 net profit to S$34.9m on cost-cutting
summary: StarHub nearly doubled its Q4 net profit to S$34.9 million, driven by cost-cutting measures, despite a 1.8% year-on-year decline in revenue to S$608.4 million. Service revenue fell 3% to S$443.7 million, mainly due to declines in core mobile, pay television, and broadband businesses. The company has achieved 64% of its S$210 million cost savings target and expects FY2020 service revenue to improve by 1-3% despite the ongoing Covid-19 outbreak.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: ComfortDelGro Taxi is providing S$10 million in rental rebates to cabbies until April 2020, on top of an earlier S$18 million package, and daily rebates of S$16.50 (S$660) until March and S$10 (S$360) in April. Singapore O&G reported a net loss of S$8.9 million for Q4, driven by impairment of goodwill and higher operating expenses. Sasseur Reit's DPU declined 18.5% due to lower income tax expense and a one-off adjustment. Hongkong Land acquired a 23.1-hectare site in Shanghai for S$6.2 billion.

site_title: Europe: Stocks waver in early deals
summary: European stock markets wavered in early deals on Thursday, with the FTSE 100 index up 0.1% and the DAX 30 index down 0.3%. The Paris CAC 40 dipped 0.1% due to bank and healthcare sector drag. The focus remains on US-EU trade talks and tariff threats, which have been affecting market sentiment.

site_title: Wilmar International core profit rises 23% to US$410m in Q4
summary: Wilmar International reported a 23% increase in core net profit to US$410 million in the fourth quarter, driven by strong performance from its tropical oils and oilseeds divisions. Net profit for the agri-business group rose 120% to US$438 million, while revenue marginally rose 0.5% to US$11.3 billion. The company expects higher palm oil prices to benefit its tropical oils division in the coming year. Wilmar's shares fell 0.49% to S$4.04 before the results were announced.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific Holdings Q4 net profit soars 332% to S$20.2m
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings reported a 332% surge in Q4 net profit to S$20.2 million, driven by a 747% increase in revenue to S$261 million. The company successfully launched all six remaining developments in 2019, with strong demand for its residential projects. Full-year earnings per share rose 42% to 2.32 cents, and a final dividend of 1.09 cents per share was proposed, up from 0.705 cents last year.

site_title: Gold hits 7-year high on virus fears
summary: Gold prices hit a 7-year high amid concerns over the coronavirus outbreak, which may retard global growth and lead to monetary policy easing by the Federal Reserve. The metal has risen 6% this year, driven by economic uncertainty and potential stimulus measures. Spot gold traded at US$1,607.95 an ounce, with prices expected to top US$1,650 in the coming weeks.

site_title: E-commerce sites to be digital banking battlefield: S&P report
summary: E-commerce sites, particularly Sea Ltd's Shopee and Alibaba Group's Lazada, are expected to become key players in digital banking in Singapore and Southeast Asia. A report by S&P Global Market Intelligence suggests that partnering with e-commerce companies could be the quickest way for branchless banks and technology firms to gain scale. The report notes that e-commerce sales in the region are estimated to grow to $79.29 billion in 2022, and affiliates of these companies have applied for bank licenses in Singapore. This could lead to the emergence of digital banking as a major force in the region.

site_title: Hongkong Land buys 31b yuan prime plot on Shanghai's West Bund
summary: Hongkong Land has acquired a 23.1-hectare mixed-use site in Shanghai's West Bund for 31 billion Chinese yuan (S$6.2 billion). The site will be used for office, retail, residential, and hotel purposes, with a 40-70 year land use rights term. The acquisition is in line with the company's strategy to develop prime sites in key gateway cities across Asia. Development is expected to be completed by 2027, providing a stable stream of recurring earnings.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close lower on virus worries
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed lower on Thursday due to concerns over the impact of the new coronavirus on corporate earnings and economic growth. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.2%, while mainland China's Shanghai Composite Index rose 1.8% after the central bank cut borrowing costs. The Shenzhen Composite Index also increased 2.2%. The contrast in market movements reflects differing concerns about the virus's economic impact.

site_title: Oil rises on supply woes; demand concerns from coronavirus ease
summary: Oil prices rose on Thursday, extending gains from the previous session, due to supply disruptions in Libya and potential cuts in Venezuelan crude. Brent crude futures rose 0.2% to $59.26 a barrel, while West Texas Intermediate climbed 0.5% to $53.54 a barrel. Demand concerns eased slightly after a decline in new coronavirus cases in China, but supply worries remain. Analysts predict Brent crude may reach $60.22 a barrel.

site_title: ComfortDelGro increases taxi rental rebates by another S$10m
summary: ComfortDelGro Taxi has increased its taxi rental rebates by another S$10 million, providing S$28 million in relief to cabbies until the end of May 2020. The daily rental rebate will decrease from S$660 in March to S$30 in April and S$20 in May. The move aims to help cabbies cope with the slump in ridership due to the novel coronavirus outbreak, with some seeing their income drop by 20-30%.

site_title: Sheng Siong posts flat Q4 net profit of S$17.4m
summary: Sheng Siong, a Singaporean supermarket operator, reported a flat fourth-quarter net profit of S$17.4 million, down 0.4% from the same period last year. Revenue rose 11.8% to S$247.9 million, driven by new store openings and growth in China. Comparable same-store sales contracted 1% in the first quarter of 2019 and ended flat for the full year. The company proposes a final dividend of 1.80 cents per share and plans to continue expanding its store count and improving efficiency to mitigate the impact of the novel coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Singapore shares fall 0.5% as Budget euphoria wanes
summary: Singapore's stock market fell 0.5% on Thursday as the post-Budget euphoria waned, with concerns over global growth resuming. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,198.68, down 15.03 points, following Standard Chartered's lower 2020 global growth forecast to 3% due to China's revised growth forecast. Despite measures to fight the Covid-19 outbreak, the market remains cautious, with local banks and travel-related stocks leading the decline.

site_title: Ex-minister Yaacob Ibrahim joins Chip Eng Seng as independent director
summary: Former Singaporean Minister for Communications and Information Yaacob Ibrahim has joined Chip Eng Seng as an independent director. This marks the first time Professor Yaacob, 64, has served as a director of a listed company on the Singapore Exchange. He previously served as director of Surbana Jurong from January 2020. The board has also formed a three-person investment committee, chaired by independent director Low Teck Seng.

site_title: Top Glove unit prices RM1.3b perpetual sukuk at 3.95% in maiden offering
summary: Top Glove, a Malaysian glove manufacturer, raised RM1.3 billion through its maiden sukuk transaction, priced at 3.95% per annum. The perpetual non-callable five-year sukuk has an issue date of Feb 27, 2020, and an expected first call date of Feb 27, 2025. This marks the company's first sukuk issue.

site_title: Ley Choon units win construction, repair contracts worth S$55.6m
summary: Ley Choon Group, a Catalist-listed company, has secured three construction and repair contracts worth approximately S$55.6 million for underground utilities infrastructure and road works. The contracts, won by the company's subsidiaries Teacly, Ley Choon Constructions and Engineering, and Pan Alliance Technology International, are not expected to significantly impact the company's earnings for the current financial year.

site_title: SGX RegCo urges caution when dealing in Vividthree's shares
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has urged investors to exercise caution when dealing in Vividthree Holdings' shares due to a review of trades between Sept 9, 2019 and Feb 19, 2020. A small group of connected accounts accounted for over 90% of traded volume, with cross trades making up 71% of on-market traded volume. This followed Vividthree's announcement of a placement of up to 15,880,000 shares at a premium of 27.3% to the volume-weighted average price.

site_title: Lenovo's Q3 beat, confidence on managing virus impact boost shares
summary: Lenovo reported a 11% increase in net profit to $258 million for the Q3 period, beating analyst estimates. Revenue rose to a record $14.1 billion, driven by strong demand for PCs and smart devices. Despite disruptions from the coronavirus outbreak, Lenovo's global operations are expected to help manage the impact, with most factories in China reopened and operational on a limited basis. The company's global manufacturing base and supply chain efficiency are seen as advantages in addressing supply challenges. Shares rose nearly 8% following the announcement.

site_title: Maersk says outlook hit by uncertainty due to coronavirus
summary: AP Moller-Maersk, the world's largest container shipping company, has revised its 2020 outlook due to the coronavirus outbreak, citing "considerable uncertainties." The company expects its operating profit to reach $5.5 billion, lower than analysts' estimates of $5.94 billion. Maersk has canceled over 50 departures from China and is monitoring the virus's impact on global trade, with a possible peak within the next two weeks. The company's financial performance improved last quarter, but the outlook remains uncertain due to US-China trade tensions and oversupply in the industry.

images.alt_text: AP Moller-Maersk, the world's largest container shipping company, said 2020 will be marred by "considerable uncertainties" due to the outbreak of the coronavirus and its impact on global trade.

site_title: Australia launches national inquiry into bushfires
summary: Australia has launched a national inquiry into its five-month bushfire crisis, which killed over 30 people and destroyed thousands of homes. The inquiry, led by former Air Force chief Mark Binskin, will focus on improving preparedness, resilience, and response to natural disasters. The inquiry's findings are expected to be reported by August 31, with recommendations to be acted upon before the next bushfire season. The inquiry comes amid criticism of the government's response to the crisis and calls for action on climate change, with the government planning to focus on adaptation and resilience rather than reducing emissions.

site_title: Australia: Shares close at record highs
summary: Australia's shares closed at a record peak, rising 0.3% to 7,162.5, driven by China's rate cut to support its virus-hit economy. However, domestic employment data showed a higher-than-expected unemployment rate, sparking expectations of further monetary easing. The ANZ research noted that wages growth is set to remain weak, pushing the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) to cut interest rates again in Q2. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index reached a fresh record high.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close higher on cheap yen, US rallies
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher for the second consecutive day, driven by a cheaper yen and Wall Street rallies. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index gained 0.3%, while the Topix index rose 0.2%. The positive trend was attributed to a drop in new coronavirus cases in China, boosting investor sentiment.

site_title: UBS names ING chief Hamers to head Swiss banking giant
summary: UBS has named ING Group CEO Ralph Hamers to succeed Sergio Ermotti as head of the Swiss banking giant. Hamers, 53, will join UBS's executive board on Sept 1 and take over as CEO on Nov 1. He has led ING Group since 2013, overseeing a digital innovation shift. Hamers' appointment comes as UBS lowered its medium-term profitability targets due to low interest rates and market conditions. The move aims to ensure a smooth transition after Ermotti's tenure, which included a massive restructuring after the 2008 financial crisis.

site_title: Swiss watchdog slams Julius Baer's efforts to fight money laundering
summary: Switzerland's financial watchdog Finma has found significant shortcomings in Julius Baer's efforts to combat money laundering over nearly a decade. Finma has appointed an auditor and prohibited the bank from large acquisitions until it complies with the law. The bank's failings were linked to alleged corruption cases involving Venezuelan oil company PDVSA and world soccer body Fifa. Julius Baer has acknowledged the findings and stated it will rapidly implement measures to strengthen its compliance and risk culture.

site_title: UOB partners Pathlight School to donate 1,000 care packs to disadvantaged families amid Covid-19
summary: UNITED Overseas Bank (UOB) has partnered with Pathlight School to donate 1,000 care packs to disadvantaged families in Central Singapore District amid the novel coronavirus outbreak. Each care pack contains essential items such as surgical face masks, hand sanitizer, and Vitamin C pastilles. The care packs were assembled by student volunteers from Pathlight School and will be distributed starting from February 22. This initiative aims to provide support to those in need during the pandemic.

site_title: Leak of closed-door Chan Chun Sing meeting 'deeply disappointing': SCCCI president
summary: Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SCCCI) president Roland Ng calls a leaked recording of a closed-door meeting with Minister Chan Chun Sing "deeply disappointing" and a betrayal of trust. The 25-minute recording, which covered the coronavirus outbreak and economic situation, was circulated on social media. Ng is investigating the matter, which has serious implications for the SCCCI and Minister Chan. The leak has raised questions about the chamber's security and the minister's ability to maintain confidentiality.

site_title: Asia weakness drags on Accor revenue growth in 2019
summary: Accor reported a 16% increase in annual sales to 4.05 billion euros (US$4.37 billion) in 2019, slightly slower than expected. Street protests in Hong Kong and transport strikes in France impacted performance, as did trade tensions between the US and China in the Asia-Pacific region. The company also noted a decline in sales due to weakness in Asia. Accor plans to step up its share buyback program this year and next.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks fall as jump in virus cases stoke economic worries
summary: South Korean stocks fell 0.67% on Thursday, with the KOSPI index ending at 2,195.50, after the government reported 31 new coronavirus cases, bringing the total infected to 82. The spike in cases heightened investor concerns about the economic impact, weighing on the won. Foreigners were net buyers of $93.22 million worth of shares. The KOSPI is down 0.10% so far this year, despite a 2.6% gain in the previous 30 trading sessions.

site_title: Singapore's household income inequality falls to 18-year low
summary: Singapore's household income inequality has fallen to an 18-year low, according to the Singapore Department of Statistics. The Gini coefficient, which measures income inequality, decreased to 0.452 in 2019, from 0.458 in 2018 and 0.398 after adjusting for government transfers and taxes. Median household income from work rose 1.4% in nominal terms to S$9,425, and 1% in real terms. This improvement is attributed to the redistributive effect of government transfers, with resident households receiving an average of S$4,682 per household member in 2019.

site_title: Nine dead in 'xenophobic' Germany bar shootings
summary: Nine people, including several victims of Kurdish origin, were killed in a shooting at a shisha bar and cafe in Hanau, Germany. The suspect, 43-year-old Tobias R., was identified as having far-right beliefs and left behind a manifesto and video material suggesting a xenophobic motive. Police found R. and his 72-year-old mother dead in a murder-suicide. The attack follows a growing concern about an increasingly emboldened far-right movement in Germany, with similar incidents including a deadly anti-Semitic attack in Halle and the murder of a pro-migrant politician last year.

images.alt_text: Police officers secure a street near one of the shooting sites. A gunman with suspected far-right beliefs killed nine people at a shisha bar and a cafe in the German city of Hanau, police said Thursday, before apparently killing himself and his mother.

site_title: ANZ cuts Singapore's 2020 growth outlook to 0.4%
summary: ANZ has downgraded Singapore's 2020 economic forecast to 0.4% due to the impact of the Covid-19 outbreak. The downgrade follows other banks such as Standard Chartered, which also cut its global growth forecast, citing uncertainty around the timing of the recovery. ANZ's head of Asia research, Khoon Goh, expects a significant hit to the economy in Q1 2020, with growth contracting by 1% year-on-year, and a modest recovery in Q2.

site_title: Fintech investment in Singapore more than doubled in 2019: Accenture
summary: Fintech investments in Singapore more than doubled in 2019 to US$861 million, driven by big gains in payments and insurtech startups. The number of deals rose 52% to 108, with 39% of total funds raised going into payments startups and 25% into insurtechs. Singapore is now the fifth-largest fintech market in the Asia-Pacific, with a strong growth in the ecosystem boding well for its future development, according to Accenture.

site_title: 1MDB fugitive Jho Low spotted in virus-hit Chinese city
summary: Malaysian fugitive Jho Low, accused of plundering billions from sovereign wealth fund 1MDB, has been spotted in Wuhan, China, amid the coronavirus outbreak. Authorities imposed a lockdown in the city, but it's unclear if Low had left before the lockdown. Low is wanted for his role in the 1MDB scandal, which led to the downfall of former Malaysian leader Najib Razak in 2018.

site_title: Forever 21's new owners in talks to keep most US stores open
summary: Forever 21's new owners, Authentic Brands Group, Simon Property Group, and Brookfield Property Partners, plan to keep most US stores open under a new CEO, who will be named soon. The new owners, who paid $81 million and assumed liabilities, aim to keep 448 US stores in business. The decision comes after Forever 21 filed for bankruptcy in September due to large locations, losses in international markets, and online competition. The new owners are in talks with landlords to keep as many stores open as possible.

site_title: Brokers' take: KGI downgrades EHT on missed estimates, no near-term catalysts
summary: KGI Securities downgraded its call on Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) to "neutral" and cut its target price to US$0.51 from US$0.61 due to the hospitality group's fourth-quarter results falling below estimates by 18% and its distribution per unit missing its own initial public offering forecast by 24.4%.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand, Sembcorp, SembMarine, Sasseur Reit, Perennial, LMIRT
summary: Several Singaporean companies reported new developments that may impact trading on Thursday, February 20, 2020. CapitaLand offered a free parking promotion to boost footfalls amid the Covid-19 outbreak, while Sembcorp Industries received approval for its Veolia ES Singapore acquisition. SembMarine reported a net loss, and Sasseur Reit's distribution per unit declined 18.5%. Perennial Real Estate Holdings saw a revenue boost, and LMIRT posted a high distribution per unit. These developments led to varying stock price movements, with some companies closing higher and others lower.

site_title: Trump economist says 'uncertainty' from trade disputes hit business investment
summary: US President Donald Trump's global trade battles and resulting uncertainty hit business investment, contributing to a slowdown in US growth last year. According to the administration's top economist, Tomas Philipson, trade uncertainty may have reduced US and world gross domestic products by as much as 1 per cent. Philipson expects investment to rebound this year if uncertainty settles down, and the CEA report projects economic growth of 3.1 per cent this year, with continued growth through 2024, if the Trump administration's proposed reforms are enacted.

site_title: KrisEnergy to miss principal, interest payments on more debts
summary: KrisEnergy, a debt-laden upstream oil and gas firm, will miss principal and interest payments totaling US$4.5 million and S$4.2 million due on February 21 and 22, 2020, respectively. The company has already missed a previous interest payment in December 2019. KrisEnergy is undergoing a restructuring process, aiming to conserve cash and protect stakeholders' interests while formulating a "holistic and equitable" restructuring proposal. The company's total debts stood at around US$558.8 million as of June 30, 2019.

site_title: Demand for disease-themed movies and games explodes
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in demand for disease-themed movies, games, and TV series, providing a form of coping mechanism for worried viewers. Documentaries, disaster flicks, and games like "Plague Inc" and "Contagion" have seen significant spikes in downloads and views, with some titles experiencing a resurgence in popularity. Experts attribute this trend to the need for people to process and make sense of their fears, with online discussions serving as a form of collective coping.

site_title: Singapore dollar, South Korean won get dumped as virus cases rise
summary: The South Korean won and Singapore dollar plummeted against the US dollar as the coronavirus spread worsened in Asia. The won dropped 1% and the Singapore dollar fell to its lowest in almost three years, with Singapore's currency falling 0.5% weaker. The economic fallout continues to worsen, with the sudden spike in South Korea's virus cases and Japan's cruise ship deaths. Asian currencies are experiencing significant losses, with a gauge of implied volatility rising 12 basis points. The economic impact of the virus is expected to strongly affect both economies.

images.alt_text: The South Korean won and the Singapore dollar, two of Asia's most trade-sensitive currencies, are getting dumped as the coronavirus spread worsens in Asia.

site_title: 2 remisiers jailed for aiding in market rigging of Koyo shares
summary: Two remisiers, Teo Boon Cheang and Goh Qi Rui Rayson, were jailed for their roles in manipulating the shares of Catalist-listed Koyo International between 2014 and 2016. Teo, 51, was sentenced to three months, while Goh, 35, received four months. They were part of a scheme that artificially pushed up Koyo's share price, with the company's CEO holding a significant stake. The market was severely distorted, with the share price increasing from 16 cents to 40 cents during the scheme. Five others, including the CEO, have been charged and their cases are pending.

site_title: China announces biggest drop in new coronavirus cases in almost a month
summary: China reported the largest drop in new coronavirus cases in nearly a month, with 394 new cases confirmed nationwide, following adjustments to case counting methods. The country has now reported over 74,500 infections and 2,118 deaths, with most cases in Hubei province. The number of new cases has been steadily falling, with only 45 additional cases reported outside of Hubei.

site_title: Asia: Coronavirus fears weigh on markets
summary: Asian markets were weighed down by coronavirus fears, despite China reporting a drop in new cases and easing borrowing costs. China's People's Bank of China lowered its loan prime rates, but analysts deemed it insufficient. The World Health Organization praised progress in fighting the virus, but IMF chief Kristalina Georgieva warned a long-lasting outbreak could impact the global economy. Markets reacted negatively, with Hong Kong and Seoul falling, while Japan and Sydney rose.

site_title: Google plans to move UK users' accounts outside EU jurisdiction
summary: Google plans to move its UK users' accounts outside the European Union jurisdiction to the US, reducing data protection. The move, prompted by Britain's exit from the EU, will place sensitive personal information under US law enforcement's reach. Google assures users their data collection and processing practices won't change, but critics argue the shift will leave users with less protection. Other US tech companies, like Facebook, are expected to make similar choices in the coming months.

site_title: Lenovo warns of coronavirus challenges, Q3 profit beats expectations
summary: Lenovo reported a better-than-expected quarterly profit and record revenue, despite facing short-term volatility and challenges from the coronavirus outbreak. The company's factories in Wuhan, the epicentre of the outbreak, remain shut, while those in Shenzhen and Hefei resumed work on February 10. Lenovo attributed the disruption to local governments' Lunar New Year holiday and travel curbs. The company's Q3 profit beat expectations, with revenue reaching a record high.

site_title: Bitcoin volatility jumps to three-month high after late plunge
summary: Bitcoin experienced a 65% surge in volatility over the past 10 days, reaching its highest level since November 6. The cryptocurrency plummeted 8% in a sudden session, only to recover somewhat, trading at $9,572. This volatility is attributed to highly leveraged derivatives positions being called, but also reflects investors' search for alternative assets amid coronavirus concerns. Despite the recent volatility, Bitcoin is still up 30% for 2020.

site_title: China FM to meet Asean peers at coronavirus summit
summary: China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi is set to meet Asean peers in Laos for crisis talks over the coronavirus, which has affected economies dependent on trade and tourism. The meeting aims to project regional solidarity and counter the virus's impact on China-backed 'Belt and Road' schemes. Over 2,000 people have died from the virus, mostly in China, with cases reported in Southeast Asian countries including the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, and Vietnam. The summit follows a similar meeting in 2003 over Sars.

site_title: Court adjourns Hyflux's leave application for scheme meeting to March 10, extends moratorium
summary: A Singaporean court has adjourned Hyflux's leave application to convene its scheme meeting to March 10, 2020, and extended its moratorium to April 30, 2020. The court requires Hyflux's lawyers to indicate which creditor groups are likely to oppose the scheme before then. The company's lawyers are working under a tight timeline to meet the May 26 deadline to complete potential white knight Utico's investment, addressing four outstanding issues including financial and KYC due diligence.

site_title: Higher expenses, impairment drag Singapore O&G into the red
summary: Singapore O&G, a healthcare provider, reported a net loss of S$8.9 million in Q4 2020 due to higher expenses and impairment of goodwill, which increased to S$11.9 million. Despite a 21.8% revenue growth to S$10.7 million, the company expects a decline in medical tourism and private healthcare visits due to the Covid-19 outbreak. However, directors expect the group to remain profitable at the operational level in the next 12 months.

site_title: SembMarine sinks into the red with S$77.7m Q4 loss
summary: SembMarine, a Singapore-based rig builder, reported a net loss of S$77.7 million for its fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2019, down from a net profit of S$5.9 million a year ago. Revenue fell 31.7% to S$623.5 million, mainly due to lower revenue recognition from rigs and floaters projects. The company expects business activity levels to remain low for all segments except repairs and upgrades, which continue to improve. A no-dividend recommendation was made for the full year.

site_title: Thai retail giant launches record-breaking IPO
summary: Thai retail giant Central Retail launched its record-breaking IPO, raising around $8.1 billion with shares offered at 42 baht. The company, which owns hundreds of malls, electronics, and convenience stores, is seeking to raise 71 billion baht ($3.2 billion) despite a sputtering economy hampered by the new coronavirus. The IPO made a modest quarter baht gain in early trading.

site_title: China cuts benchmark lending rate to prop up virus-hit economy
summary: China lowered its benchmark lending rate by 10 basis points to 4.05% and 5 basis points to 4.75% to support its virus-hit economy. The move aims to lower financing costs for businesses and cushion the blow to growth caused by the coronavirus outbreak. The decision was widely expected and follows similar moves by the central bank to ease the impact of the virus. Economists warn of potentially lower growth, with some analysts predicting a slump to 3% due to widespread business disruption.

site_title: Australia's jobless rate jumps to 5.3%, Australian dollar comes off highs
summary: Australia's jobless rate surged to 5.3% in January, beating forecasts, but analysts attributed the increase to more people entering the labor market. The country saw 13,500 net new jobs, with full-time work rising 46,200, but part-time jobs fell 32,700. The Australian dollar dropped after the data, as investors believe the Reserve Bank of Australia will remain patient in cutting interest rates, with a quarter-point cut not expected until September or October.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon down 0.5% on day
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.5% on Thursday, with the STI index closing at 3,197.82 points, down 15.89 points. Decliners outnumbered advancers 177 to 170, with S$559.4 million worth of securities changing hands. Key decliners included Singtel, DBS, United Overseas Bank, and OCBC Bank. The decline was part of a broader Asia-Pacific market trend, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng and South Korea's Kospi also falling.

site_title: Silicon Valley inventor of 'cut, copy and paste' dies
summary: Larry Tesler, inventor of the 'cut, copy and paste' command, has died at 74. A pioneer in human-computer interaction, Tesler worked at Xerox, Apple, Amazon, and Yahoo, and was a graduate of Stanford University. He developed the 'cut, copy & paste' command, which was incorporated into Apple's Lisa computer in 1983 and the original Macintosh in 1984. Tesler's work revolutionized user interaction with computers, making it easier for people to work with digital text. He spent 17 years at Apple, rising to chief scientist.

images.alt_text: "The inventor of cut/copy & paste, find & replace, and more was former Xerox researcher Larry Tesler," the company tweeted.

site_title: This revamp will be different, says HSBC boss; staff not so sure
summary: HSBC's interim CEO Noel Quinn unveiled a bank-wide overhaul, aiming to reduce costs, simplify the business, and increase capital efficiency. However, investors and employees are skeptical, given Quinn's temporary position and the bank's history of struggling to implement successful restructuring plans. The overhaul includes cutting 35,000 jobs, suspending buybacks for two years, and revamping US and European businesses to save $4.5 billion in costs. Despite the bank's efforts, investors express concerns about the plan's execution and potential future cost-cutting measures.

site_title: Thai banker makes a US$2.7b bet to secure family's legacy
