summary: Thai banker Chartsiri Sophonpanich, chairman of Bangkok Bank, has made a US$2.7 billion bid to acquire Indonesia's PT Bank Permata, aiming to secure his family's legacy for a fourth generation. The deal, 25 years in the making, marks a bold move by the 60-year-old banker, who has previously played it safe after the Asian financial crisis. Bangkok Bank's current market capitalization is US$9 billion, and Chartsiri plans to keep the current management in place to grow return-on-equity to double digits. The acquisition, if approved, would give Bangkok Bank access to Indonesia's large and growing population, as well as corporate banking, retail lending, and small- and medium-sized enterprises.

site_title: Boustead Projects ties up with Sunseap to install rooftop solar energy systems
summary: Boustead Projects, a Singapore-based real estate player, has partnered with Sunseap Group to install rooftop solar energy systems at its properties. The partnership aims to better utilize rooftop space and provide clean energy solutions to clients and tenants. Sunseap will be Boustead Projects' exclusive solar energy partner and preferred electricity retailer in Singapore, offering lower-cost energy options. The collaboration will also expand Sunseap's presence in the region.

site_title: Singapore shares edge up at Thursday's open; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 6.83 points or 0.2% to 3,220.54. The benchmark gained momentum after Wall Street stocks rose overnight, driven by China's pledge to support local businesses affected by the Covid-19 outbreak. Gainers outnumbered losers 80 to 27, with Keppel Reit and ESR-Reit leading the gains. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.4% in the US, while other Asia-Pacific markets also rallied on expectations of more Chinese stimulus.

site_title: Japan hits back at 'chaotic' cruise ship quarantine claims
summary: Japan has pushed back against criticism of its "chaotic" quarantine measures on the Diamond Princess cruise ship, which has reported 621 confirmed cases of coronavirus among passengers and crew. The country's health ministry defended its procedures, citing consultations with experts and measures such as handwashing stations and medical worker protocols. A specialist in infectious diseases had criticized the ship's quarantine procedures as "completely chaotic" in a video that was later deleted. Despite this, more passengers are leaving the ship, raising concerns about the safety of releasing them into Japan's crowded cities.

site_title: Kickstarter is first major tech firm to unionise
summary: Kickstarter, a major tech firm, has become the first internet company to unionize, with employees voting 46 to 37 in favor of organizing. The Brooklyn-based platform, known for its generous pay and perks, has established a union called Kickstarter United. This historic move marks a significant milestone for organized labor in the tech sector, setting a beachhead for future unionization efforts.

images.alt_text: Employees of crowd-funding platform Kickstarter showed up to a freshly-unionised workplace on Wednesday after an historic vote establishing a "beachhead" for organised labour in the tech sector.

site_title: Sasseur Reit's Q4 DPU drops 18.5% to 1.629 S cents
summary: Sasseur Reit, a Chinese outlet mall owner, reported a 18.5% decline in its distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.629 Singapore cents for Q4 2019, due to lower income tax expense and a one-off adjustment. Rental income under entrusted management agreements fell 9% to S$28.2 million. This marks a significant drop from the year-ago period, primarily attributed to tax losses and reserve adjustments in 2018.

site_title: ESR Cayman to issue S$225m in 5-year senior notes
summary: ESR Cayman, a logistics real estate giant, will issue S$225 million in 5-year senior notes at par, maturing on Feb 26, 2025, with a fixed coupon rate of 5.1% per annum. The notes will be used to refinance existing borrowings, fund potential acquisitions, and cover working capital requirements. The notes were launched under ESR Cayman's US$2 billion multicurrency debt issuance programme, with joint bookrunners Credit Suisse, DBS Bank, and United Overseas Bank managing the offer and sale.

site_title: iFast Q4 profit up 14.4% to S$3m
summary: iFast Corporation reported a 14.4% increase in net profit to S$3 million for Q4 2019, with earnings per share rising to 1.12 Singapore cents. Revenue grew 20.8% to S$33.8 million, driven by higher contributions from business divisions. Despite the COVID-19 outbreak, the company believes growth opportunities in Asia's wealth management industry remain substantial, and it is well-positioned to benefit in the medium to long term.

site_title: UK employers offer lowest pay awards since Dec 2018: XpertHR
summary: UK employers offered staff the lowest annual pay awards since December 2018, with a median 2.1% rise, down from 2.2% in the final quarter of 2019. This marks the lowest pay awards in over a year, amid signs of a slower economy. Despite low unemployment, stagnant economy growth and a median pay rise of 2.1% suggest caution from employers. This trend may continue over the coming months, according to XpertHR analyst Sheila Attwood.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.19 points or 0.21% to 1,537.35, driven by higher volumes and a slight gain-to-loss ratio of 162:71. This follows a global trend of stocks opening higher, with Europe and the US experiencing gains despite concerns over US-EU trade talks and new Trump threats.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on cheap yen, US rallies
summary: Tokyo stocks rose for the second day in a row, driven by a cheaper yen and Wall Street rallies. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index gained 1.24% to 23,691.92. Traders were also optimistic about a drop in new coronavirus cases in China. Meanwhile, US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, and Europe's stocks were dragged down by bank and healthcare shares.

site_title: Fossil fuel methane emissions 'vastly underestimated'
summary: Researchers have found that fossil fuel methane emissions are 25-40% higher than previously estimated, with the potent greenhouse gas responsible for 16% of global warming. The study, published in Nature, suggests that human activity, particularly fossil fuel extraction and distribution, is a major contributor to methane emissions, which are 21 times more efficient in trapping solar radiation than carbon dioxide over a 100-year timescale. The findings could force a reassessment of the fossil fuel industry's role in curbing climate change.

site_title: New British £20 banknote, featuring artist Turner, enters circulation
summary: A new British £20 banknote featuring 19th-century painter J.M.W. Turner entered circulation on February 20, 2020. The durable polymer note marks a major step forward in combating counterfeiting, replacing the existing paper £20 note featuring Adam Smith. Turner's self-portrait and famous painting "The Fighting Temeraire" are featured on the new note. The Bank of England expects half of cash machines to dispense the new notes within two weeks. A new polymer £50 note featuring Alan Turing is set to enter circulation next year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks higher at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.4% to 27,767.28, driven by hopes that the new coronavirus would have a short-term impact on the global economy. Mainland China's benchmark Shanghai Composite Index also rose 0.2%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 0.27%. The gains were influenced by Wall Street's buoyant markets, where investors were reassured by the potential limited economic impact of the coronavirus.

site_title: China's Hubei province reports 108 more coronavirus deaths: official
summary: China's Hubei province reported 108 additional coronavirus deaths, bringing the national death toll to 2,112. Most deaths occurred in Wuhan, the epicentre of the outbreak. Over 74,500 people have been infected nationwide. The province reported 615 new cases, with 13 elsewhere, but reduced previous cases by 279, resulting in a net increase of 349 new cases. The adjustment in case numbers was not immediately explained.

site_title: Montreal ends electric scooter experiment, citing 'disorder'
summary: Montreal ended its electric scooter experiment after a six-month pilot, citing an 80% delinquency rate in complying with traffic and safety regulations. Only 20% of scooters were parked in dedicated spaces, and riders frequently broke rules and parked illegally. A total of 110 parking offences and 333 tickets were issued. The city has decided not to renew the permits for electric scooters, but will continue to allow electric bikes with tighter regulations.

site_title: Perennial Real Estate Q4 earnings more than double to S$38.5m
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings reported Q4 earnings more than doubling to S$38.5 million, driven by 44% revenue growth from Singapore and China properties. Earnings per share rose to 2.32 cents from 0.96 cents. The company proposed a first and final dividend of 0.2 cents per share for FY2019, down from 0.4 cents in FY2018. Full-year net profit sank 95.1% to S$3.8 million, while revenue rose 58.7% to S$124.2 million.

site_title: Coronavirus study pinpoints African nations' vulnerabilities
summary: A study by The Lancet suggests that Egypt, Algeria, and South Africa are at high risk of suffering from the coronavirus due to their high levels of travel and trade with China. Despite efforts to strengthen preparedness, some African countries remain ill-equipped to deal with the threat, and more needs to be done with surveillance and rapid identification of suspected cases. Only Egypt, Algeria, and South Africa have prepared health systems in the continent, while others, such as Nigeria and Ethiopia, require support.

images.alt_text: "African countries have recently strengthened their preparedness to manage importations of Covid-19 cases," said study author Dr Vittoria Colizza, of France's Sorbonne university.

site_title: Petrobras hits all-time profit record in 2019
summary: Brazilian state-run oil firm Petrobras reported a record profit of 40.1 billion reais (S$12.81 billion) in 2019, exceeding its highest ever figure. Despite missing fourth-quarter expectations, the firm's strategy of focusing on deepwater production and exiting non-core activities appears to be paying off. The company's 2019 profit surpasses previous records, demonstrating the success of its strategy.

site_title: Irish regulator readies draft decisions in first big tech privacy probes
summary: Ireland's Data Protection Commission (DPC) has prepared draft decisions on probes into several major technology firms, including Facebook, Twitter, and Google, under the EU's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR). Two of the 21 ongoing investigations have reached the decision-making phase, focusing on a Twitter bug and WhatsApp's data sharing with Facebook. The DPC will share its draft decisions with other EU regulators for consultation before finalizing the verdicts, which could impose fines of up to 4% of a company's global revenue or €20 million.

site_title: France steps up probe into Ghosn's Versailles wedding
summary: French investigators are stepping up their probe into Carlos Ghosn's lavish parties at the Palace of Versailles, including his 2016 wedding. Ghosn, former Nissan and Renault CEO, is suspected of wrongly obtaining use of the palace in exchange for a sponsorship deal. He faces potential charges in France and is also being investigated by France's tax fraud office over suspicious financial transactions. Ghosn denies all charges and plans to take Renault to court to claim unpaid pension and retirement pay. The investigation follows Ghosn's arrest in Tokyo in 2018 and his subsequent escape to Lebanon.

site_title: Internet and social media safety must evolve with the times
summary: Singapore, a digitally connected city, faces significant cyber safety concerns due to its high smartphone penetration rate and widespread social media usage. 20% of all crimes in Singapore are cyber crimes, with social media occupying a major proportion. To address these concerns, social media companies must balance their benefits with limitations, while public education efforts and evolving policies are crucial for maintaining safety and trust online.

site_title: Qantas axes flights across Asia as virus scares off flyers
summary: Qantas is reducing flights across Asia by 15% until at least May due to the coronavirus outbreak, affecting routes to China, Hong Kong, Singapore, Japan, and Thailand. The airline is also cutting 2.3% of domestic flights. Qantas' CEO Alan Joyce stated the airline could double capacity cuts if the situation worsens, and expects a potential hit to profit of up to A$150 million. The airline reported a first-half profit of A$771 million, beating some estimates.

site_title: Oil up more than 2% on slowing coronavirus cases, US move on Venezuela
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% on Wednesday as concerns about declining demand due to the coronavirus outbreak in China eased, while supplies tightened due to the US move to cut off Venezuelan crude. New coronavirus cases in China fell for a second day, and China is expected to cut its benchmark lending rate to stimulate its economy. The oil market is also showing signs of prompt demand, with the front-month Brent futures market moving deeper into backwardation.

images.alt_text: Oil prices gained more than 2 per cent on Wednesday as worries eased about demand declining due to the spread of coronavirus cases in China, while supplies tightened as the United States moved to cut off more Venezuelan crude from the market.

site_title: World first: Infertile cancer patient has baby using frozen egg
summary: A 34-year-old French woman, who was rendered infertile by breast cancer treatment, gave birth to a baby boy after one of her frozen eggs was matured, frozen, and then thawed and fertilized. The eggs were frozen five years earlier after being removed from her ovaries and allowed to develop in a laboratory. Six of the eggs survived the thawing process, and one was successfully fertilized, resulting in a healthy baby boy named Jules. This breakthrough technique, known as in vitro maturation (IVM), has shown that women in this situation can have children, offering a new hope for fertility preservation in cancer patients.

images.alt_text: In a world first, a woman rendered infertile by cancer treatment gave birth after one of her immature eggs was matured, frozen, and then - five years later - thawed and fertilised, researchers in France reported.

site_title: SoftBank to borrow 500b yen by pledging telecom unit stock
summary: SoftBank plans to borrow up to 500 billion yen (S$6.3 billion) by pledging shares of its Japanese telecom unit as collateral to raise capital for operations. The two-year loan, with a one-year extension option, will be provided by 16 financial institutions. This move aims to address demands from activist investor Paul Singer, who has acquired a stake in SoftBank and advocates for a share buyback and governance changes. The loan will be used to fund operations and help SoftBank meet its financial obligations.

site_title: Pompeo lands in Saudi Arabia for talks focused on Iran
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo landed in Saudi Arabia on Wednesday for talks focused on countering Iran, amid heightened regional tensions following the killing of Iranian general Qasem Soleimani. Pompeo will meet with King Salman, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, and Foreign Minister Faisal bin Farhan to discuss security issues and pressure Iran to change its behavior. The visit comes as the US continues to impose sanctions on Iran and amid concerns over human rights in Saudi Arabia, including the case of detained US national Walid Fitaihi.

site_title: Europe: Shares hit record high on drop in new virus cases, hopes of China stimulus
summary: European shares reached a record high on February 19, 2020, driven by a decline in new coronavirus cases in China and hopes of stimulus from Beijing. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.8% with chipmakers, such as Dialog Semiconductor and STMicroelectronics, leading the rally. Analysts believe the outbreak might be contained by April, supporting forecasts of a recovery. Despite this, companies like Adidas and Puma reported a hit to their business due to store closures and fewer Chinese tourists.

site_title: Homebuilder sentiment in US eases while staying near 20-year high
summary: US homebuilder sentiment in February remained near a 20-year high at 74, according to the National Association of Home Builders/Wells Fargo Housing Market Index. Lower borrowing costs and steady job growth fueled demand, but builders grappled with increasing construction costs. Sentiment was strongest in the South, while the Northeast reached a 14-year high. The overall gauge increased from December's 76, indicating steady growth in residential construction contributing to economic growth.

site_title: Argentina's debt 'not sustainable,' says IMF
summary: Argentina's debt is deemed unsustainable by the IMF, citing a decline in the country's ability to service its debt and a sharp depreciation of the peso. The IMF urges the government to generate funds from private investors to address the issue, following a $195 billion debt renegotiation. The country's public debt rose to nearly 90% in 2019, and inflation remains high. The IMF will continue to engage with the Argentine government to discuss economic plans and policies, with a meeting between the IMF chief and the economy minister scheduled for the upcoming G-20 Finance Ministers meeting.

site_title: Ransomware shuts US gas compressor for 2 days
summary: A recent ransomware attack on a US natural gas compressor facility forced a two-day shutdown, the latest in a string of attacks targeting the country's energy infrastructure. Hackers gained control of the facility's IT system via a malicious link sent via email, and the attacker likely explored the network to identify critical assets before executing the ransomware attack. The incident highlights the risk posed by ransomware to industrial control systems, and the facility's emergency response plan did not specifically address the risk of cyber-attacks.

site_title: Top Pentagon official resigns at Trump's request
summary: Top Pentagon official John Rood resigned at Donald Trump's request after certifying Ukraine's reforms, contradicting Trump's claim that funds were withheld due to corruption. This move undercut Trump's argument in the Ukraine scandal that led to his impeachment. Rood's certification allowed Ukraine to receive $250 million in military aid, further fueling the controversy.

site_title: Indonesian parliament wants to tax wider range of plastics
summary: Indonesia's parliament has urged the government to tax a broader range of plastic products, including those that are not initially proposed, to discourage their use and reduce pollution. The government had initially planned to impose excise taxes on plastic bags, sweetened beverages, and polluting vehicles. However, the parliament has held off on these plans, instead focusing on a wider range of plastic products. This move aims to cut waste and pollution in South-east Asia's largest economy.

site_title: Easing Singapore property curbs not on radar: DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat stated that Singapore has no immediate plans to ease property curbs, citing the need to stabilize the economy and address long-term structural issues. The curbs, implemented in 2018, penalize developers for failing to complete and sell new projects within five years. Despite recent loosening of restrictions, Heng emphasized that the focus is on long-term stability, not short-term market fluctuations.

site_title: Benefits of China trade truce 'limited': Federal Reserve officials
summary: Federal Reserve officials say the benefits of the US-China trade truce are limited, citing concerns over economic dangers despite the agreement's impact on reducing downside risks and boosting business sentiment. The "phase one" deal with China prevented some tariffs from taking effect, but punitive duties remain on about two-thirds of goods traded between the two countries. The truce also contributed to the signing of a continental free trade pact with Mexico and Canada.

site_title: Spain tweaks the odds on Blackstone's property bet
summary: Spain is considering rent controls to curb rising housing costs, which could impact foreign investors like Blackstone that have profited from the country's housing market. Since the economic crisis in 2013, rents have increased by 50% and median tenants spend a quarter of their income on housing, exceeding European standards. This could lead to a shift in property investments, with comparable yields available in other European countries. The proposed rent controls may also impact property values and housing supply, making Spanish property a less attractive bet for foreign investors.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Using AI to enable smart cities
summary: A Singapore-based start-up, Zinier, uses AI to enable smart cities through Field Services Automation. Co-founded by Andrew Wolf, the company's technology is being explored in various cities. Zinier's AI solution aims to improve urban management and services, making cities more efficient and sustainable.

site_title: US: Nasdaq, S&P 500 end at records as coronavirus worries subside
summary: US stocks closed at records on February 19, 2020, as fears about the economic impact of the new coronavirus outbreak in China subsided. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 indices reached all-time highs, driven by investor confidence. The virus has killed over 2,000 people in China and spread globally, prompting flight cancellations and business closures. Despite concerns, US stocks powered forward, driven by reduced worries about the economic damage.

site_title: Nomura is finally making money from Asia investment banking
summary: Nomura Holdings Inc's investment banking business in Asia is set to return to profit this fiscal year after over a decade of losses, driven by cost cuts and revenue gains from financing and deal-making in India and Australia. Revenue is expected to rise by about one-third, with private financing and deal-making in these countries leading the growth. The firm's focus has shifted to financing and capital markets in India and building a sponsor business in Australia, helping to revitalize profit in the region.

site_title: EU leaders to clash over money as Brexit blows hole in budget
summary: EU leaders will clash over the 2021-2027 budget due to a 75 billion euro hole left by Britain's exit. The bloc faces costly challenges like becoming carbon neutral by 2050, with a starting point for talks at 1.074% of gross national income (GNI). This contrasts with EU national budgets, which average 47% of annual GDP. The budget is crucial for the next seven years, with talks centered on the bloc's willingness to contribute.

site_title: Japan exports, machinery orders fall as virus impact grows
summary: Japan's exports and machinery orders fell in January, marking the 15th straight month of decline, as the country grappled with the COVID-19 outbreak and a recent sales tax hike. Exports fell 2.6% year-over-year, while core machinery orders plummeted 12.5% month-over-month, indicating a challenge for the economy to overcome external and domestic pressures, potentially teetering on the edge of a recession.

site_title: Great Eastern's Q4 profit more than doubles to S$287m
summary: Great Eastern, the insurance arm of OCBC Bank, reported a net profit of S$287 million for its fourth quarter of 2019, more than doubling from the previous year's S$136.9 million. The company's total weighted new sales gained 19% to S$395 million, driven by its businesses in Singapore and Malaysia. Gross premiums rose 8% to S$3.24 billion, while operating profit inched up 1% to S$173.7 million. The company's full-year net profit rose 36% to S$1 billion, with a recommended final dividend of S$0.50 per share.

site_title: A much-needed leg-up Budget for the current turmoil and the future
summary: Singapore's Budget 2020 provides a much-needed leg-up to businesses amid the Covid-19 outbreak, with a bumper package to help firms and households tide over the crisis. The budget also flags plans to tackle longer-term issues like economic transformation and climate change. Key initiatives include a job support scheme, wage credit scheme, corporate tax rebate, and a new enterprise credit for firms to enhance their operations. The government has pledged $5 billion to address climate change, with funds and incentives pledged under this year's budget. The budget aims to support industries and workers, while also promoting sustainable growth and transformation.

site_title: China's virus-hit industrial cities start to ease curbs, restore production
summary: China's industrial cities are easing curbs and restoring production as the country tries to balance containing the coronavirus outbreak with shielding the economy. Major manufacturing hubs on the Chinese coast have relaxed restrictions on people and traffic movement, allowing factories to resume production. By the end of February, 60-80% of production activities are expected to reach normal levels, with normal production expected by mid-to-late March. However, economists warn that the disruption to production could extend into the second quarter, potentially slowing China's growth to 4.5% in the first quarter.

site_title: Western vendors' 5G mobile technology on par with Huawei, says US
summary: US officials say European countries have no reason to use Huawei's 5G mobile technology, citing Sweden's Ericsson, Finland's Nokia, and South Korea's Samsung as alternatives. Deputy Assistant Secretary Robert Strayer stated that Western vendors offer technology on par with Huawei, with open architecture and more functionality, creating opportunities for US and European companies. The US wants its allies to consider the security and economic implications of using Huawei's technology, which Washington claims creates espionage risks. The European Union allows member states to decide Huawei's role in 5G networks.

site_title: STI snaps losing streak after Budget 2020
summary: Singapore equities snapped a four-session losing streak on February 19, 2020, after the government announced support measures to aid companies affected by the Covid-19 outbreak. The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 0.7% to 3,213.71, with aviation-related stocks, such as Singapore Airlines and SATS, rising due to lifted sentiment. Investors were encouraged by the government's support package and hopes of further stimulus measures from China, which helped to lift global sentiment and boost trading volume.

site_title: The humbling of Goldman Sachs
summary: Goldman Sachs, once considered the world's most powerful investment bank, has seen its fortunes wane. Despite its efforts to deliver a modest pitch to investors, the bank's share rating remains low, with rival JPMorgan rated twice as highly. Critics have long accused Goldman of its networking and rent-skimming practices, but the bank's post-crisis curbs have handicapped its ability to manipulate capitalism. CEO David Solomon must now motivate his staff to hustle hard again, using the laughter of rivals as an asset to drive change.

site_title: Higher costs seeping into supply chains with virus outbreak: OCBC
summary: A Covid-19 outbreak in China is causing significant disruptions to regional supply chains, resulting in a 20% increase in costs for traders and distributors. The impact is being felt across various sectors, including manufacturing, distribution, and healthcare, with some businesses citing difficulties in sourcing alternative suppliers outside of China. To alleviate cash flow pressures, OCBC is offering relief measures, including extended bridging loans and flexible trade terms, to help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in the region. The bank is also tapping its regional presence to connect SMEs with suppliers beyond China, particularly in the healthcare sector.

images.alt_text: "The impact on businesses is already becoming quite widespread, beyond just the more frontline industries (such as tourism). It's not just about footfall coming into Singapore, it's now also about trade and supply chain," says Mr Goh.

site_title: No collateral needed for retail investors to trade
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has decided not to require retail investors to pledge collateral on their open stock positions, as initially proposed in a 2014 consultation paper. This decision comes after assessing the combined impact of various market initiatives implemented since 2014. The move aims to improve market functions and trading practices in the securities market.

site_title: Car COEs rebound; other categories fall
summary: The Singaporean car certificate of entitlement (COE) market rebounded, with COE prices increasing for cars up to 1,600 cc and above 130 bhp. COE for open category vehicles and motorcycles also rose. Despite the increase, the overall market remained weak, attributed to the ongoing novel coronavirus outbreak. Industry watchers attribute the rebound to a positive consumer response to price reductions following a previous plunge in premiums.

site_title: Budget 2020+: From Singapore to Singaporeans
summary: Singapore's Budget 2020, announced by Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat, prioritizes addressing the present situation with strength while maintaining future security. Despite the Covid-19 outbreak, the Budget delivered targeted reliefs to sectors hardest hit, exceeding expectations. The government has shown resilience in combating the crisis, with swift delivery of plans to deal with the crisis. The Budget aims to support businesses and individuals, while maintaining economic stability.

site_title: Apartment rents in HK sink to lowest in nearly 2 years
summary: Hong Kong apartment rents have dropped to their lowest level in nearly two years, according to property agency Spacious. The decline is attributed to the COVID-19 outbreak and anti-government protests, which have reduced demand. Homeowners are now more inclined to lease rather than sell, contributing to the decrease. Advertised residential prices on a per-square-foot basis are the least since March 2018.

site_title: Hong Kong's Teflon home prices are virus-proof
summary: Hong Kong's housing market has proven resilient to months of protests and the coronavirus epidemic, with home prices dropping only 6.1% from their record high in June. The dominance of family-controlled companies, low interest rates, and limited leverage among homeowners have contributed to this stability. In contrast, commercial property, including office and retail sectors, has seen a significant decline, with vacancy rates reaching a 10-year high and rents plummeting. Investors are advised to consider cash-rich developers with a focus on housing, such as Sun Hung Kai Properties and CK Asset Holdings.

site_title: Can crisis unlock a force for good among businesses?
summary: COVID-19 has sparked fears of a business slowdown but has also uncovered examples of corporate goodness, accelerating innovation and spur a willingness to try new things. Businesses are seizing the opportunity to accelerate innovation, partner others, and exemplify the importance of collective action. Companies are stepping up to support the community, such as delivering medical supplies, providing financial assistance, and offering care packages. This crisis has the potential to unlock a force for good among businesses, leading to a new "Zeitgeist" where businesses prioritize purpose and social responsibility, and stakeholders expect more from companies.

site_title: UK heralds end of 'cheap labour from Europe' with points system
summary: The UK has announced its post-Brexit points-based immigration system, prioritizing high-skilled workers from around the world to end reliance on "cheap labour from Europe". The government aims to bring overall migration numbers down, driven by concerns over high EU immigration levels. This move follows the 2016 Brexit vote and is part of a broader effort to control migration. Key details include a points system for skilled workers, with a focus on attracting high-skilled talent to the UK.

site_title: Macy's, Renault credit downgrade rekindle fears
summary: Macy's Inc and Renault SA were downgraded to junk status, rekindling fears of a potential uptick in "fallen angels" in the US corporate bond market. Macy's lost an investment-grade rating due to its failure to adapt to changing consumer habits, while Renault was downgraded after posting its first annual loss in a decade. The downgrades follow Kraft Heinz Co's downgrade to junk last week, and experts predict a significant increase in fallen angels this year, with up to $90 billion of investment-grade debt potentially downgraded to high yield.

site_title: New York eyes luxury buildings in search for homeless fix
summary: New York City is requiring luxury developers to fill vacant affordable units with shelter residents if they fail to find tenants through a lottery. About 200 units, mostly in Manhattan and Brooklyn, will be repurposed as permanent housing for families in shelters who can live independently. The city will pay the developers' rent for these units, which will be limited to middle-income tenants earning up to $124,930. This move aims to combat homelessness and provide high-quality housing to those in need.

site_title: Corporates should embrace Budget's farsightedness
summary: Singapore's Budget 2020 prioritized economic resilience amidst the COVID-19 pandemic, introducing fiscal measures to support small businesses and workers. The government maintained focus on key issues like climate change, technological disruption, and inequality, despite the pandemic's economic impact on large companies. The budget's direction and leadership were seen as a positive development, with the Straits Times Index showing minimal decline, indicating the market's confidence in the government's actions. This approach allowed for long-term planning and strategic decision-making.

site_title: Asian Healthcare Specialists finishes buying Cornerstone Asia Health stake
summary: Asian Healthcare Specialists has completed the acquisition of a 51% stake in Cornerstone Asia Health, paying for it with the issuance of new shares and cash from its 2018 initial public offering. The acquisition brings in 13 medical specialists and doctors with over 20 years of experience, expanding AHS's capabilities in anaesthesia, dermatology, and other medical services. The move aims to strengthen AHS's capabilities in delivering complex and specialized healthcare services through a team of cross-disciplinary medical specialists.

site_title: Who's being a currency manipulator now?
summary: The US has accused China of currency manipulation, but the move has sparked concerns about the rule of law and fairness in trade practices. The US has established criteria for determining currency manipulation, but the Trump administration has introduced a new rule allowing for additional levies on imports from countries deemed currency manipulators without a legal process. This move has raised questions about the legitimacy of the US's own currency policies, as the US is free to manipulate its currency while no other country is subject to the same rules.

site_title: Singapore should lead hub to manage ocean plastic
summary: Singapore is positioning itself as a leader in addressing the ocean plastic crisis, with the launch of a $106 million investment fund dedicated to treating waste effectively and preventing ocean plastic. The fund aims to unlock billions of dollars from public and private investors and demonstrate the financial returns of investing in ocean plastic solutions. Singapore's strong economy, trade relationships, and commitment to sustainability make it well-suited to take on this role, particularly in the South and Southeast Asia region. The country can spur the development of a local circular economy through investment in technologies and industries that convert plastic waste into value.

site_title: Budget 2020's short-term stimulus could be smaller than it seems
summary: Singapore's Budget 2020, with a projected overall deficit of S$10.9 billion (2.1% of GDP), may not provide sufficient support due to its timing and limitations. Economists expect monetary easing at the next MAS policy meeting in April, citing a need for more direct government consumption and investment to maximize fiscal stimulus. The budget's measures, including a S$6 billion package to accompany the eventual GST hike and S$5 billion for the Coastal and Flood Protection Fund, may not be enough to mitigate the economic effects of the Covid-19 outbreak, which is expected to last longer than anticipated.

images.alt_text: While Budget 2020's projected overall deficit is the largest in over a decade, its fiscal impulse should not be overstated, said economists. More support might be needed, not least if the Covid-19 outbreak persists longer than expected.

site_title: CapitaLand introduces free parking at its malls during lunch, dinner hours
summary: CapitaLand, a government-linked landlord, has introduced free parking at its malls during lunch and dinner hours to boost footfalls amid the Covid-19 outbreak. The company is also providing a comprehensive support package for retailers, including flexible rental payments, a S$10 million marketing assistance program, and a review of security deposits. This move aims to ease retailers' cash flow and support their sales during the pandemic.

site_title: New face of GOP may be Hawley - amid populism, nationalism, nativism
summary: Republican Senator Josh Hawley, a self-proclaimed Trumpist and economic nationalist, is emerging as a new face of the GOP. He has targeted Big Tech giants Google, Amazon, and Facebook, proposing legislation to break them up and regulate their practices. Hawley has also accused social media of anti-conservative bias and has forced tech executives to behave in a "responsible way" during congressional hearings. His campaign against Big Tech may signal a shift towards populism, nationalism, and nativism in the Republican Party, potentially transforming it from a pro-free market party to an economic nationalist force.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Sembcorp Industries received approval from the Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore to acquire Veolia ES Singapore (Vess) for approximately S$28 million. The merger will continue to face sufficient competition in the market. Hyflux has received an interest from a major Chinese entity to invest in the water treatment firm with a joint venture partner. ARA US Hospitality Trust posted a lower-than-expected distribution of 1.08 US cents for the fourth quarter, citing lower room revenue and occupancy.

site_title: Young leaders from Singapore business families set up S$5m fund for SMEs
summary: Young leaders from prominent Singapore business families have established a S$5 million fund to provide short-term working capital loans to local SMEs impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic. The fund, called the Helping Our Promising Enterprises (Hope) fund, will offer loans of up to 12 months at a fixed rate of 0.5-0.75% per month, with a minimum loan amount of S$50,000. The fund aims to support over 100 SMEs and will be administered through Goldbell's private debt investment platform. The initiative is part of a broader effort by the private sector to support SMEs during the pandemic.

site_title: Producer prices in US rise more than forecast on services
summary: US producer prices rose 1.7% in January, exceeding forecasts, indicating potential inflationary pressures. Core producer prices increased 1.7% from a year earlier, driven by a 0.7% surge in services costs. Goods prices excluding food and fuel rose 0.3%, with iron and steel scrap surging the most since 2017. The report suggests potential price pressures at the consumer level, highlighting the need for policymakers to monitor inflation.

site_title: Attracting talent 'still a hurdle for Singapore deep-tech startups'
summary: Singapore's deep-tech startups face a significant hurdle in attracting talent, despite government efforts to provide additional funding and support. Industry players cite a lack of researchers' willingness to transition into entrepreneurship, citing the structured rigour of academia and the challenging process of finding co-founders. To address this, experts recommend a combination of "push" and "pull" techniques to attract and retain talent, including showcasing success stories and offering job perks. The S$300 million government injection aims to spur over S$800 million in private funding over the next 10 years, with programs such as the T-Up initiative to help defray talent costs.

images.alt_text: Talent is key for deep-tech to take off here, and although the niche sector was in the spotlight in the startup space in Budget 2020, few here see entrepreneurship as a viable path, industry players said.

site_title: Singapore looking for new sources of masks
summary: Singapore is seeking new sources of masks amid the Covid-19 pandemic, with Minister Lawrence Wong announcing plans to manufacture them locally. This comes as three new cases bring the total infected to 84. The move is in response to other Asian countries clamping down on mask exports.

site_title: Pompeii restoration unearths surprise treasures
summary: Archaeologists completed a massive restoration of Pompeii, unearthing vivid frescoes and never-before-seen inscriptions. The 6-year project, costing $113 million, reinforced walls, repaired structures, and excavated untouched areas. New discoveries include a fresco of a gladiator and an inscription proving the city was destroyed on October 17, 79 AD, not August 24. The restoration has breathed new life into the historic site, preserving ancient buildings and artifacts. Further discoveries are expected through ongoing excavation projects.

images.alt_text: The House of Lovers, a two-storey home called domus (family residences for the upper classes), on the archaeological site of Pompeii.

site_title: Rush on stores - panic buying or exerting control?
summary: In Singapore, a rush for basic necessities such as toilet paper, dry food products, and rice has occurred amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The surge in demand has led to empty store shelves, prompting some stores to impose purchasing limits. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong assured Singaporeans that the city-state has ample supplies, urging calm. This behavior is attributed to a natural response to loss of psychological control.

site_title: Sanders surges to double digit lead: poll
summary: Bernie Sanders leads the Democratic presidential nomination race with a double-digit lead, surpassing 32% support, up from 23% last month. Moderate Joe Biden slumped by 16 points, while Mike Bloomberg and Elizabeth Warren trail behind. Sanders' strong performances in Iowa and New Hampshire caucuses contributed to his surge. A Democratic debate featuring Bloomberg, who faces criticism over his campaign spending, is set to take place on the same day.

site_title: Budget 2020: Boon for some, muted impact for most listed firms
summary: Budget 2020 in Singapore had a muted impact on listed firms, with most businesses not expected to see a major revenue uplift. The measures, aimed at cushioning the blow from the Covid-19 outbreak, were largely focused on sectors hit hard. Notable exceptions include Sheng Shiong, a supermarket operator, which saw a significant boost. Analysts expect some consumer sector players to benefit from the measures, but overall, the impact is expected to be limited.

site_title: The grown-up version of life with housemates
summary: Singapore's co-living trend is gaining popularity among millennials, offering a more flexible and designer-centric alternative to traditional long-term apartment leases. Purpose-built apartments, such as Figment's shophouse conversions and Cooliv's colonial-era apartments, are being designed to attract short-stayers. The concept combines shared facilities with individual rooms, catering to those seeking flexibility and community. Meanwhile, the Contentment Foundation, founded by Daniel Cordaro, aims to teach people how to find inner bliss through scientific research and old-school philosophy, promoting a more contented lifestyle.

site_title: StanChart commits US$75b towards Sustainable Development Goals
summary: Standard Chartered has committed $75 billion towards the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) by 2024, aiming to reduce emissions by 2030 and source energy from renewable sources. The bank will cease support for clients generating more than 10% of earnings from thermal coal by 2030 and finance $35 billion in clean technology and $40 billion in sustainable infrastructure. StanChart's goal is to catalyze SDG financing and provide sustainable finance to emerging markets, where the UN estimates a $2.5 trillion annual investment gap in meeting the SDGs.

site_title: Two Iranians die after testing positive for coronavirus
summary: Two Iranians have died in a hospital in Qom, Iran, after testing positive for the new coronavirus. The deaths were confirmed by Iran's health ministry, with the patients initially put in isolation. This comes as the death toll from the virus in mainland China surpassed 2,000, with authorities tightening containment measures in Wuhan. The Iranian cases are separate from the ongoing outbreak in China.

site_title: Hard to meet product delivery schedules due to Covid-19: Valuetronics
summary: Valuetronics, an electronics manufacturing services firm, reported that its factories in China's Guangdong province resumed operations this week, but with reduced production capacity due to the ongoing coronavirus outbreak. The company expects a temporary drop in production and may not meet originally planned product delivery schedules, potentially resulting in a revenue shortfall for the six months ending March 31, 2020. Some workers were unable to return to work due to administrative measures to curb the spread of the virus.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end the day higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.5% on Wednesday, driven by investor optimism that policymakers will introduce measures to mitigate the impact of the new coronavirus on corporate earnings and economic growth. The Hang Seng Index closed at 27,655.81, while mainland China's Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.3%. The move contrasts with declines in Europe and the US, where stocks were weighed down by bank and healthcare sector concerns.

site_title: Vicom share split: No consensus on impact to volume and price
summary: Vicom, a 67% owned subsidiary of ComfortDelGro Corp, has proposed a share split of its ordinary shares into four, aiming to make the stock more affordable for investors. The theoretical post-split share price would be S$1.953, up from S$7.813. The move has already led to a 8.7% gain in shares since the announcement, and investors expect it to increase the company's market capitalization. However, some analysts believe the stock's liquidity and valuation remain a concern, with some predicting the share price could remain supported by its steady dividends and growing profits.

site_title: Beyond just a Budget, let's look at the strategic underpinnings
summary: Singapore's Budget 2020, presented on February 19, 2020, was unexpected and addressed both the global Covid-19 crisis and the country's economic outlook. The budget focused on virus relief measures, but also included long-term strategies to boost economic growth and competitiveness. Key initiatives included investments in healthcare, education, and infrastructure. The budget aimed to mitigate the economic impact of the pandemic while laying the groundwork for a stronger, more sustainable Singapore.

site_title: Foreign worker quota cuts: Tough love for the construction sector
summary: The Singapore government has cut foreign worker quotas for the construction sector, a move seen as a step towards transforming manpower-intensive industries. This decision, part of the Budget, prioritizes targeted support for tourism-related sectors affected by the Covid-19 outbreak. The curbs on skilled foreign labor are believed to be a long-term strategy, rather than a response to the immediate crisis. The move aims to promote local talent and address labor shortages in key industries.

site_title: Hotel, retail complex impacted by Covid-19: Bund Center Investment
summary: Bund Center Investment, a hotel and retail complex, reported that business has been impacted by the Covid-19 outbreak, particularly in its Golden Center retail complex in Ningbo and the Westin Bund Center Shanghai. The company temporarily closed the Golden Center in Ningbo and implemented measures to prevent the spread of the virus at the Westin Bund Center Shanghai. The group will continue to monitor the situation and announce reopening plans when appropriate, while stepping up cleaning and disinfection efforts.

site_title: RH Petrogas says it expects to swing into the red for FY19
summary: RH Petrogas expects to swing into a loss for the year ended Dec 31, 2019, mainly due to increased production costs and higher depletion and amortisation of oil and gas properties.

site_title: Samsung set to gain from Apple's virus-triggered operations woes
summary: Samsung is poised to benefit from Apple's production woes due to the novel coronavirus in China, as half of its smartphones are manufactured in Vietnam, where the virus has had limited impact. Apple announced it will not meet its revenue guidance for the March quarter, citing production and sales issues in China. Samsung has largely ceded the China market to rivals and is not expected to suffer from store closures and demand drops. Analysts expect Samsung to see a positive impact on its mobile division but a negative impact on its chip and display businesses due to its reliance on Chinese manufacturing and parts.

site_title: Sri Lanka will not honour UN pledge on war probe
summary: Sri Lanka's Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa announced the country's withdrawal from a UN resolution investigating alleged war crimes committed during the 2009 conflict with Tamil separatists. The resolution, adopted in 2015, called for accountability and reparations for victims. Rajapaksa cited the US ban on Sri Lankan army chief Shavendra Silva as a reason for the withdrawal, saying it was due to the country's co-sponsorship of the resolution. This move comes after his brother, President Gotabaya Rajapaksa, had previously vowed not to honor the resolution.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 2.92 points lower to 1,534.16 on Wednesday, with 416 losers outnumbering 406 gainers. The index saw a 2.5 billion lots trading volume worth RM2 billion.

site_title: DLF Holdings sells BMW for S$72,000 to 'enhance cash flows'
summary: DLF Holdings, a Catalist-listed engineering firm, sold a BMW 528iA for S$72,000, a 21.2% discount from its net book value of S$114,322. The sale is expected to enhance the company's cash flows and allow its resources to be deployed for other uses. DLF will book a loss of S$42,322 on the disposal, but considers it in the group's interests. The sale is part of the company's efforts to optimize its assets and improve its financial position.

site_title: US: Nasdaq hits record high at open on China stimulus hopes, drop in new virus cases
summary: The Nasdaq composite hit a record high at the open on Wednesday, driven by hopes of China's stimulus measures and declining new coronavirus cases. The Dow Jones and S&P 500 also opened higher, with the Nasdaq gaining 50.07 points to 9,782.81. The positive market sentiment was tempered by ongoing US-EU trade tensions, but investors remained optimistic about the economic outlook.

site_title: Car COEs rebound while others continue to slide
summary: Singapore's car COE prices rebounded slightly, with COEs for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp rising to $32,999 and $32,889 respectively. However, other categories, such as open COE and commercial vehicle COE, fell. Industry watchers attribute the rebound to a positive consumer response to price reductions, but note that the market remains weak due to the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: JCG Investment sets up JV with Natasha Skincare
summary: CATALIST-LISTED JCG Investment has formed a joint venture with Natasha Skincare, a beauty brand in Indonesia, to include a medical aesthetic clinic, medi-spa, chiropractor and physiotherapy services in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. The JV will start operations in March 2020 with each party holding a 56% stake initially, with plans to transfer shares to doctors or operators. The partnership aims to expand JCG's business in Malaysia and Indonesia, and enhance its customer base in cosmetic surgery and anti-ageing businesses.

site_title: Talent investor Entrepreneur First unveils latest batch of deep techs
summary: Entrepreneur First has unveiled its sixth cohort of 19 deep tech startups from Singapore, Bangalore, and Hong Kong. The startups focus on technologies like electric-vehicle battery monitoring and hardware development. Due to COVID-19 concerns, the investor day was cancelled and the startups will pitch to investors directly. Four companies are graduates of a joint programme with HAX, and nine are from Singapore, contributing to Entrepreneur First's 31% of angel and seed deals in Singapore over three years.

site_title: US housing starts fall; building permits near 13-year high
summary: US housing starts fell 3.6% to 1.567 million units in January, beating expectations, while building permits surged to a 13-year high of 1.551 million units, driven by lower mortgage rates. The housing market remains strong, supported by low rates and a solid economy, which could help keep the longest expansion on record going amid risks from the coronavirus.

site_title: Coronavirus: 3 new cases in Singapore, 2 linked to existing church clusters
summary: Three new cases of Covid-19 were confirmed in Singapore on February 19, 2020, bringing the total number infected to 84. Two cases were linked to existing church clusters, while the third case has no known travel history or connections to previous cases.

site_title: LMIRT Q4 DPU up 73%, FY19 DPU rises 9%
summary: Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) reported a 73.3% increase in fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 0.52 Singapore cents, driven by higher gross rental income and lower property operating and maintenance expenses. Full-year DPU rose 8.8% to 2.23 cents. The trust's gearing ratio stood at 35.9% and interest cover at 4.3 times. Despite the Covid-19 outbreak, LMIRT's operations remain unaffected, with shopper traffic increasing by 0.7% in the first two months of 2020.

site_title: Trendlines' fund makes US$1.6m investment in seed-breeding business
summary: Trendlines Group, a Catalist-listed startup incubator, has invested US$1.6 million in seed-breeding technology firm Equinom through its Agrifood fund, its first investment. The fund, set up with US$22 million in commitments from investors, aims to invest 66% of its capital in commercial-stage companies. Equinom's technology optimizes seed functionality, increasing plant yield, nutritional value, and disease resistance. The investment is part of Trendlines' strategy to support sustainable agriculture and plant-based ingredients.

site_title: Euro climbs back above US$1.08, volatility spikes
summary: The euro rose above the US$1.08 on Wednesday, reversing its decline to three-year lows, as improving risk sentiment in global markets offset the dollar's rally. The euro had fallen 3.6% to the dollar this year due to Europe's economic deterioration, but the recent data suggesting the slowing of the COVID-19 outbreak and increased risk appetite boosted the euro. One-month euro-dollar implied volatility rose to its highest in six weeks, while the Japanese yen eased against the dollar to its lowest level in nearly a month.

site_title: CCCS approves Sembcorp unit's acquisition of Veolia ES Singapore
summary: The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) has approved Sembcorp Industries' acquisition of Veolia ES Singapore (Vess) for approximately S$28 million. The deal is subject to remaining conditions precedent, including other regulatory approvals. The CCCS found that the merged entity would continue to face sufficient competition in the market, with barriers to entry and expansion not being high. Customers have alternative suppliers, and the combined market share for general waste collection services is below the CCCS's indicative threshold, reducing competition concerns.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: HYflux received a letter from Longview International Holdings expressing interest in investing in the water treatment firm with a joint venture partner. Prudential Singapore introduced a S$1.5 million relief package for SMEs and individuals affected by Covid-19. Trendlines Group formed a new fund to invest in seed-breeding technology firm Equinom. The COE for cars rebounded, with prices up for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp. Keppel was ranked among the top 11% of industrial conglomerates based on ESG criteria in the MSCI All Country World Index.

site_title: Singapore shares snap 4 sessions of losses, rise 0.5% on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.5% to 3,213.71, snapping a four-session losing streak, following support measures announced in the 2020 budget to aid companies affected by the Covid-19 outbreak. Only two blue-chip index components fell, with the rest gaining.

site_title: IMF warns China virus hitting a fragile global economy
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned that the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak in China will be short-lived, but it comes as the global economy remains fragile. IMF chief Kristalina Georgieva said uncertainty is becoming the new normal, citing the virus as a pressing uncertainty that could threaten a fragile recovery. The fund predicts a sharp decline in China's GDP followed by a sharp recovery, but warns that a prolonged outbreak could worsen global economic conditions.

site_title: Huawei loses legal challenge against US federal purchase ban
summary: A US federal judge has ruled that Washington has the right to block US federal agencies from buying products by Huawei on cybersecurity grounds, dismissing the Chinese telecom giant's legal challenge to a purchase ban. The ban was justified as part of a congressional investigation into a potential threat to the nation's cybersecurity. Huawei has denied the claims and accused the US of trying to put the company out of business through an "unconstitutional" restriction.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks end flat as fast-spreading virus keeps investors wary
summary: South Korean stocks closed flat on Wednesday, ending 1.46 points higher at 2,210.34, as investors remained cautious due to the spread of the coronavirus. Foreigners were net sellers of $196.69 million worth of shares. This marks the 0.58% year-to-date gain, with the previous 30 trading sessions seeing a 1.5% increase.

site_title: India antitrust investigators see no evidence of collusion by IndiGo, SpiceJet and others: sources
summary: India's antitrust investigators found no evidence of collusion by IndiGo, SpiceJet, and four other airlines to fix ticket prices. The Competition Commission of India (CCI) conducted an investigation in 2015 after similar fares were offered on certain routes. The inquiry, which included analyzing airline algorithms, found no direct evidence of cartelization and no communication among executives to fix prices. The investigation's findings may clear the airlines of any wrongdoing, potentially avoiding a fine of up to three times annual profits.

site_title: OUE Lippo Healthcare Q4 net profit doubles on reversal of provision
summary: OUE Lippo Healthcare posted a fourth-quarter net profit of S$2.6 million, more than doubling from S$1.2 million in the same period last year, driven by a reversal of a provision for legal costs. Revenue rose 10% to S$5.1 million, and earnings per share increased to 0.061 Singapore cent. The company attributed the improvement to a slowdown in global economic growth and the escalating COVID-19 outbreak, which may impact healthcare operations in Asia.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise at open
summary: European stock markets opened on a positive note, with the FTSE 100 index rising 0.6% to 7,423.19 points, while the DAX 30 index and CAC 40 index also increased by 0.4%. The gains were attributed to mining and healthcare stocks.

site_title: Their market shut, traders in China's Silicon Valley do business from bags
summary: Traders in China's Silicon Valley, Huaqiangbei, are resuming business despite the coronavirus shutdown. Hundreds of traders gathered outside the market, buying and selling from bags and suitcases, with many reporting a "great atmosphere." Despite the risks, police have not intervened, and traders are uncertain when formal business will resume. The market, which is a major hub for companies worldwide, has been closed since the virus outbreak, with many factories and suppliers unable to return.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon up 0.7% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Wednesday, advancing 0.7% to 3,217.97, driven by support measures for listings affected by the novel coronavirus outbreak and lower global new cases. Volume traded at 866.9 million securities, exceeding 2019 intraday averages.

site_title: Foreign visitors to Japan fall for 4th straight month in January
summary: Foreign visitors to Japan fell 1.1% in January, marking the fourth consecutive month of decline, due to a South Korean boycott and the coronavirus affecting Chinese travelers. Arrivals from South Korea plummeted 59% year-over-year, while mainland Chinese visitors rose 23% in January. A travel ban on Chinese tourists due to the coronavirus is expected to sharply impact Japan's tourist arrivals from February.

site_title: MOM warns employers not to send healthy workers to hospitals for Covid-19 test
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Manpower has warned employers not to send healthy workers to hospitals for COVID-19 tests unless there is a medical emergency, citing hospitals' concerns about being misused. Employers who misused medical facilities may have their work pass privileges suspended. Hospitals will only test individuals who are unwell, and those who are well should be sent to a general practitioner for assessment.

site_title: SoftBank to borrow 500b yen pledging telecom unit stock
summary: SoftBank Group plans to borrow up to 500 billion yen (S$6.3 billion) by using shares of its Japanese telecom unit as collateral, to fund operations and meet demands from activist investor Paul Singer. The two-year loan will have a one-year extension option and is backed by 953 million shares. SoftBank founder Masayoshi Son has acknowledged Singer's stake and is open to buybacks and governance changes, as the company faces challenges including a struggling US$100 billion Vision Fund and significant interest-bearing debt.

site_title: Indonesia proposes to tax sweet drinks, polluting cars, plastic
summary: Indonesia's finance minister, Sri Mulyani Indrawati, proposed levying excise taxes on sweetened drinks, polluting cars, and plastic bags to control consumption and boost revenue. The proposed taxes range from 1,500 rupiah to 2,500 rupiah per liter on sugar- and artificial sugar-sweetened beverages, and would target vehicles emitting high levels of carbon dioxide. The move aims to address a nearly $15 billion revenue shortfall in 2019 and control the country's growing environmental and health concerns.

site_title: Macy's, Renault add to fallen angel fear with downgrades to junk
summary: Macy's Inc and Renault SA have been downgraded to junk status by credit rating agencies, rekindling fears of fallen angels in the US corporate bond market. Macy's lost an investment-grade rating due to failing to adapt to changing consumer habits, while Renault was downgraded to Ba1 after posting its first annual loss in a decade. This move is seen as a warning sign of potential economic downturn and increased debt servicing challenges, with analysts predicting a significant increase in fallen angels this year, potentially exceeding $90 billion.

site_title: Another potential Hyflux investor emerges; Utico says will consider 'soft landing'
summary: Longview International Holdings, a Singapore-based holding company, has expressed interest in investing in Hyflux with a joint venture partner, an undisclosed major Chinese entity. This is the third potential investor for Hyflux, following Aqua Munda and Utico. Utico, a Middle Eastern utility firm, has stated it will consider paying holders of Hyflux's perpetual securities a "soft landing" even if the company lists after two years from its restructuring. The proposed investment terms have not been disclosed, and Hyflux's creditors are set to vote on the scheme by April 2020.

site_title: CSL, Cochlear help Australian shares snap 2 sessions of losses
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% to 7,144.6, ending two sessions of losses, as CSL and Cochlear hit record highs. Cochlear jumped 11% on a rival company's device recall, while CSL gained 3% on a weaker Australian dollar. Expectations of an interest rate cut by the central bank gained ground, driven by tepid wage growth data. Retail-to-chemicals conglomerate Wesfarmers and Fortescue Metals Group also reported strong earnings, while Crown Resorts' profit fell on weak gambling turnover.

images.alt_text: Australian shares closed higher on Wednesday as CSL and Cochlear hit record highs and worries about the coronavirus epidemic waned as the number of new cases fell.

site_title: Coronavirus outbreak dents impact of China's scrap metal tax relief
summary: China granted exemptions on 25% tariffs for US copper scrap and 50% for aluminium scrap amid the coronavirus outbreak, but it's unlikely to increase shipments due to dropped metal demand. The exemptions won't significantly impact as metal processing is impacted by labor flows and economic activities. Copper scrap imports from the US fell 6-fold in 2019, and aluminium scrap declined 38% during the same period, making the exemption too little, too late, according to industry experts.

site_title: Palm oil extends losses on weak demand from top buyers
summary: Malaysian palm oil futures fell 0.64% to 2,622 ringgit (US$630.59) due to weak demand from top buyers India and China, amid concerns over the coronavirus outbreak. Prices have been impacted by slowing demand this month, with exports dropping 6.7-10% from the previous month. The industry is also bracing for additional food safety concerns, including a European Union regulation on mineral oil hydrocarbons in palm oil.

images.alt_text: Malaysian palm oil futures fell for a second straight session on Wednesday, weighed down by losses in rival vegetable oils and slowing demand from top buyers India and China.

site_title: Nomura is finally making money from Asia investment banking
summary: Nomura Holdings Inc's investment banking business in Asia is set to return to profit this fiscal year after over a decade of losses. Revenue is expected to rise by about one-third, driven by private financing and dealmaking in India and Australia, led by financing and capital markets business in India and a sponsor business in Australia. The company's cost cuts, including a US$1 billion reduction, will also contribute to the profit rebound, with the division chief citing growth areas in India and Australia, despite potential impact from the coronavirus outbreak in China.

site_title: Foreign pilots at China airlines return home on unpaid leave as demand plummets
summary: Foreign pilots at Chinese airlines have returned home on unpaid leave due to the coronavirus pandemic, which has severely impacted the industry. About 80% of scheduled airline capacity in and out of China has been cut, and expatriate pilots are more expendable, leading to their layoff. Many pilots are considering other jobs, with some already finding work with other airlines. The situation has left foreign pilots with reduced income and uncertain futures, as China's airline sector faces a long-term demand for pilots.

site_title: Qatar increases stake in British Airways' owner IAG to 25.1%
summary: Qatar Airways Group increased its stake in British Airways-owner IAG to 25.1%, purchasing an additional 465 million pounds worth of shares. This marks a significant expansion of Qatar's holding in IAG, which also owns Iberia, Vueling, and Aer Lingus. The move is described by Qatar as a highly successful strategy, with the company continuing to invest in the airline industry.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on bargain hunting
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.89% on Wednesday, rebounding from four days of declines, driven by bargain hunting amid concerns over the new coronavirus's economic impact. The Nikkei 225 index gained 206.90 points to 23,400.70, while the Topix index rose 6.15 points to 1,671.86. Investors adjusted their positions amid lingering fears about the virus's economic effects, leading to a higher close.

site_title: Vietnam looks to more than double power generation capacity by 2030
summary: Vietnam aims to more than double its power generation capacity to 125-130 gigawatts by 2030, driven by a fast-growing economy. The country plans to raise renewable energy to 15-20% and reduce coal's share from 38% to 10-15%. The government seeks foreign and domestic private investment to develop new power plants and privatize state-owned power companies. To address power shortages, Vietnam will increase electricity generation from coal and oil this year, and develop infrastructure to import 8 billion cubic meters of liquefied natural gas annually by 2030.

site_title: China's virus-hit industrial cities start to ease transport curbs, restore production
summary: China's virus-hit industrial cities are easing transport curbs and restoring production, with the government aiming to strike a balance between containing the coronavirus outbreak and shielding the economy. Major manufacturing hubs, such as Foshan and Zhongshan, have relaxed restrictions, allowing businesses to resume operations without prior approval. Production is expected to reach 60-80% of normal levels by end-February, with normalcy expected by mid-to-late March. The move is seen as a step towards reviving China's economy, which is expected to slow to 4.5% in the first quarter, with car sales projected to decline over 10% due to the epidemic.

site_title: Trump says US working on a 'very big' trade deal with India, but will take time
summary: US President Donald Trump announced that the US and India are working on a major trade deal, but a breakthrough has yet to be reached. The deal aims to increase US access to India's dairy and poultry markets and lower tariffs on other products. Trump stated that the deal will be "very big" but didn't confirm if it would be completed before the US presidential election in November. The US is India's second-largest trade partner, with a record $142.6 billion in goods and services trade in 2018.

site_title: China mulls cash injections, mergers to bail out airlines: sources
summary: China is considering measures to bail out its struggling airline industry, including direct cash infusions and mergers, due to the coronavirus outbreak. The government may allow state-controlled carriers to absorb smaller ones or inject billions of dollars to support the industry. The airline industry has been severely impacted, with flights reduced by 80% in China and local airlines grounding planes to carry 10.4 million passengers. The government has already announced plans to lower taxes and fees for airlines and is exploring loan repayment waivers and more favorable leasing terms.

site_title: Uber says it is closing office in downtown Los Angeles
summary: Uber is closing its downtown Los Angeles office, eliminating approximately 80 jobs, in order to focus on larger "Centres of Excellence" locations. The move was reported by the LA Times earlier, with the company citing a need to concentrate resources on key areas.

site_title: StanChart hires fintech Ripple's ex-executive
summary: Standard Chartered has appointed Kahina van Dyke as global head of digital channels and client data analytics at its corporate, commercial and institutional banking division. She previously held senior roles at Ripple, Facebook, Mastercard, and Citigroup. Van Dyke aims to leverage digital technology and data analytics to deliver real economy impact to clients worldwide, reporting to CCIB CEO Simon Cooper.

site_title: Freeport Indonesia aims for August kick-off of construction on new copper smelter
summary: Freeport Indonesia plans to start construction on a new copper smelter in August, with ground preparation expected to be completed in two to three months. The $3 billion smelter, located in East Java, will produce 500,000-600,000 tonnes of copper cathodes annually, increasing the company's existing smelting output. The project is part of a deal with the Indonesian government to maintain mining rights at Grasberg until 2041, with construction expected to be completed by December 2023. The company is seeking $2.8 billion in loans from nine banks to finance the project.

site_title: Hong Kong reports second coronavirus fatality
summary: A 70-year-old Hong Kong man with a history of the novel coronavirus died at Princess Margaret Hospital on February 19, marking the second fatality from the outbreak in the city. The man had a fever and tested positive for the virus after a fall at home, dying a week later. Hong Kong has confirmed 62 cases of the virus, with two deaths, and local infections have increased among residents with no history of travel to China. The city is on edge due to its history of experiencing deadly diseases, including SARS in 2003.

images.alt_text: In mainland China, where the virus first emerged, more than 2,000 people have been killed and 74,000 infected.

site_title: Keppel rated triple-A in MSCI ESG ranking
summary: Keppel Corporation has been upgraded to a triple-A rating in the Morgan Stanley Capital International (MSCI) environmental, social and governance (ESG) ranking, ranking among the top 11% of industrial conglomerates. The Singapore-based company was rated as an ESG leader in corporate governance, labor management, and clean energy. Keppel's ESG rating reflects its resilience to long-term ESG risks and ability to manage those risks relative to peers. The company's shares rose 0.6% to S$6.74 after the announcement.

images.alt_text: Keppel Corporation has been upgraded this month to a triple-A rating in the Morgan Stanley Capital International (MSCI) environmental, social and governance (ESG) ranking.

site_title: Gold tops US$1,600 as virus fuels growth fears
summary: Gold prices reached a 7-year high of nearly $1,600 an ounce as investors sought safe-haven assets amid growing concerns over the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on global growth. The virus has fueled a rally in gold and palladium, with palladium reaching a record $2,700 an ounce. The Federal Reserve is expected to reassess interest rates in response to the pandemic's economic risks. As a result, gold is up 5.6% this year and palladium prices are expected to widen a multi-year deficit.

site_title: Thai GDP growth seen much lower than forecast this year: central bank minutes
summary: Thailand's central bank revised its economic growth forecast downward, citing a slower-than-expected pace this year due to the coronavirus outbreak, delayed government spending, and a drought. The Bank of Thailand cut interest rates to a record low, aiming to alleviate negative impacts. Analysts predict Thailand's economy will grow less than 2% this year, down from a previously forecast 2.8%. The bank will review monetary policy and provide updated economic projections on March 25.

images.alt_text: Thailand's economy will grow at a much slower pace than previously forecast this year and much further below its potential, the central bank said in minutes of a meeting earlier this month when it cut interest rates to a record low.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars weaken on fears of virus impact on economy
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars weakened on Wednesday due to fears about the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak. The Australian dollar steadied at US$0.6688 after a 0.4% loss, while the New Zealand dollar was a tad firmer at US$0.6393 after an 0.8% decline. The losses came as risk appetite decreased and exporter currencies were sold off, with tech giant Apple warning of lost production and weakening demand in China. The Reserve Bank of Australia predicts wage growth will remain disappointing through 2022.

site_title: SoftBank-backed South Korean ride-hailer Tada gets rare win amid crackdown
summary: South Korea's ride-hailing service Tada has won a rare court victory, being cleared of transport law violations despite operating a service that exploits a loophole allowing the rental of chauffer-driven vehicles. The ruling comes amid increasing regulations and a powerful taxi lobby's threat of protests ahead of the April general election. Tada has won 1.7 million users since its launch in 2018, backed by SoftBank Group Corp, but faces ongoing discussions with regulators and the taxi lobby to co-exist.

site_title: Dell sells RSA cyber-security unit for US$2b
summary: Dell Technologies has agreed to sell its RSA cyber-security unit to a consortium led by Symphony Technology Group for US$2.08 billion. The deal, expected to close by the end of this year, will simplify Dell's business and product portfolio, allowing it to focus on its strategy to build automated and intelligent security into infrastructure, platforms, and devices. RSA, founded in 1982, has over 12,500 customers and hosts the largest cyber-security conference in the industry.

site_title: Passengers leave coronavirus-wracked cruise ship in Japan
summary: Passengers on the coronavirus-wracked Diamond Princess cruise ship in Japan began leaving the ship on Wednesday after testing negative for the disease, with over 500 passengers allowed to disembark after a 14-day quarantine. The ship, which had reported over 542 positive cases, is the largest cluster outside China, where the death toll has surged beyond 2,000 with over 74,000 infected. Critics have raised concerns about Japan's handling of quarantine arrangements, while countries such as the US, South Korea, and the UK have chartered planes to bring back their citizens for further quarantine.

site_title: Prudential offers S$500 cash to those quarantined, defers SME premiums amid outbreak
