summary: Singapore's Prudential offers a S$1.5 million relief package to SMEs and individuals affected by the novel coronavirus outbreak. Employees covered by Prudential's group insurance will continue to receive medical coverage, while SME customers can defer premium payments for up to three months. Individuals quarantined or hospitalized for Covid-19 will receive a one-time S$500 cash benefit and a daily allowance of S$200 for up to three months of hospitalization. The measures aim to help affected businesses and individuals manage cash flow and access medical care.

images.alt_text: Prudential Singapore's chief customer officer Goh Theng Kiat (second from right) with the insurer's employees preparing care kits to be distributed to 1,000 seniors as part of support efforts for the Ang Mo Kio Family Services Centre.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks fall at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.16% at open on Wednesday, tracking global market unease over the new coronavirus. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 27,486.46, while mainland China's Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.26%. The decline was attributed to economic jitters caused by the virus.

site_title: Australia's Caltex receives takeover offer from Britain's EG Group
summary: Britain's EG Group has made an offer to acquire Australia's Caltex for A$3.9 billion in cash and shares, targeting Caltex's convenience retail business and a stake in Ampol, a new company bundling the remaining assets. The deal aims to create a convenience retail powerhouse in Australia. The offer is set to be evaluated by Caltex's board, with a potential listing on the local stock exchange.

site_title: China races to contain job losses as coronavirus batters economy
summary: China is racing to contain job losses amid the coronavirus outbreak, which has killed nearly 1,870 and infected over 72,000, causing businesses to shut and disrupting demand and supply. Many small firms, like Mr. Xia's former employer, face cash crunches, leading to layoffs and reduced salaries. Economists forecast job losses could reach 4.5 million, posing a challenge to China's stability-obsessed leaders. The government has pledged to prevent large-scale layoffs, but experts warn that rapid unemployment could hurt incomes and consumption, reducing the chance of a sharp recovery once the outbreak is contained.

site_title: Grab ties up with air taxi firm to conduct feasibility study in South-east Asia
summary: Grab has partnered with German air mobility startup Volocopter to conduct a feasibility study in South-east Asia for offering airborne rides. The joint study will explore suitable cities and routes, evaluate best-use cases, and consider joint flight tests. Volocopter aims to deploy autonomous electric drones that can carry passengers. This partnership follows the trend of startups and corporations collaborating on deep tech innovation. The study is expected to shed light on the potential of air taxis in South-east Asia.

site_title: Great Eastern Q4 profit more than doubles to S$287m
summary: Great Eastern Holdings reported a net profit of S$287 million for the fourth quarter of 2019, more than doubling from S$136.9 million in the same period last year. Operating profit rose 1% to S$173.7 million, while non-operating profit increased to S$63.2 million. The company attributed the growth to favorable financial market conditions and higher valuation of its investments. The board recommended a final tax-exempt dividend of 50 cents per share, bringing total dividend for fiscal 2019 to 60 cents per share.

site_title: Samsung poised to benefit from China's coronavirus woes afflicting Apple, other rivals
summary: Samsung is poised to benefit from the coronavirus outbreak in China, which has affected Apple and other rivals, as half of its smartphones are made in Vietnam, minimizing the impact. Apple announced it won't meet revenue guidance for the March quarter due to production and sales disruptions in China, while Xiaomi also flagged a hit to its March quarter sales. Samsung, which has largely ceded the China market to its rivals, is better positioned to weather the virus fallout, with analysts and insiders expecting Huawei to also be affected by its reliance on Chinese manufacturing and parts.

site_title: Hong Kong heading for its first back-to-back recessions on record
summary: Hong Kong is poised to experience its first back-to-back annual recessions on record due to the COVID-19 pandemic, which has crippled an already weakened economy. The city's economy is expected to contract by over 1% in 2020, following a 1.2% decline in 2019. Weakened by months of anti-China protests and a decline in mainland tourists, Hong Kong's economic recovery is unlikely to be rapid, with economists forecasting a slow recovery in the fourth quarter.

site_title: ARA H-Trust Q4 DPS misses IPO forecast by 12.9% at 1.08 US cents
summary: ARA H-Trust posted a distribution per stapled security (DPS) of 1.08 US cents for Q4 2019, missing its initial public offering (IPO) forecast of 1.24 US cents by 12.9%. Gross revenue fell 12.2% to US$39.3 million, with occupancy at 69.8% and average daily rate 12.6% lower than forecast. Net property income (NPI) declined 32.9% to US$9.2 million, and distributable income fell 12.9% to S$6.1 million.

site_title: How a Canadian startup used AI to track novel coronavirus
summary: A Canadian startup, BlueDot, used artificial intelligence to detect and track the novel coronavirus in Wuhan, China, raising alarms about the risk posed by the virus days before major public health authorities made official statements. The company's algorithm sifts through hundreds of thousands of news stories and air traffic information to monitor infectious disease outbreaks. BlueDot correctly predicted the countries most at risk of contagion and sent alerts to clients, including airlines and hospitals, on December 31, 2019. The company's algorithm was able to identify key phrases and predict the spread of the virus, ultimately helping to prepare authorities for the worst.

site_title: US dollar shines against euro, riskier peers as virus hit widens
summary: The US dollar strengthened against the euro and other currencies amid the ongoing coronavirus outbreak, with investors seeking safe-haven assets. The euro fell 3.7% and the Australian and New Zealand dollars lost 5% against the dollar this year. The yield curve in the US inverted, a bearish economic signal, and German investor confidence slumped. The US dollar is sitting at a four-month high against a basket of currencies, with gold prices reaching a record high. Investors are closely watching the Federal Reserve's January meeting minutes for insight into the Fed's thinking on virus risks.

site_title: Saudi Aramco's trading arm signs first annual deal with KPC to buy Kuwaiti crude: report
summary: Saudi Aramco's trading arm, Aramco Trading Co, has signed its first annual deal with Kuwait Petroleum Corp (KPC) to buy 2020 Kuwaiti crude for its refineries in Asia. The deal involves lifting Kuwaiti Export Crude (KEC), a medium-sour grade that can be processed at Aramco-owned refineries. The volume of crude to be lifted under the contract is not immediately known. This marks the first time Aramco's trading arm has signed a deal with KPC, highlighting the growing cooperation between Saudi and Kuwaiti oil producers.

site_title: Australian wages growth tepid, public sector drags
summary: Australian wages grew 0.5% in the final quarter of last year, matching expectations, and annual wage growth remained stagnant at 2.2%, below the standard for the country. Public sector wages also grew at 2.2%, the slowest rate since 1997. This subdued wage growth has depressed household consumption, making it a key uncertainty for the Reserve Bank of Australia, which has cut interest rates three times to a record low of 0.75%. The central bank predicts a slow pace of wage growth until mid-2022, and may not achieve its full-employment and inflation objectives.

site_title: Australia: Shares flat as financials drag; New Zealand little changed
summary: Australian shares remained flat on Wednesday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index rising 0.1% to 7,117.9. The financials sub-index fell 1%, driven by losses in Commonwealth Bank of Australia (-2.9%) and Westpac Banking Corp (-0.9%). However, gold stocks rose 3.7% and mining stocks gained 0.7%, with Fortescue Metals Group and Northern Star Resources leading the gains. Consumer stocks also rose, led by Wesfarmers, which hit a record high after posting a 5.7% rise in first-half profit.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Great Eastern, ARA H-Trust, HPL, Wing Tai, China Sunsine, UOB Kay Hian
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several Singaporean companies reported new developments that may impact trading of their shares. Great Eastern Holdings posted a net profit of S$287 million for the fourth quarter, while ARA H-Trust saw a 12.9% decrease in distribution per stapled security. HPL plans to acquire an Italian hotel, and Wing Tai's deputy chairman believes the property market can withstand the Covid-19 spread. China Sunsine Chemical Holdings expects a material decrease in consolidated net profit, but its shares rose 1.09% on Tuesday. UOB Kay Hian's chairman has built up a 29% shareholding, nearing the trigger point for a mandatory general offer.

site_title: China's coronavirus death toll surges past 2,000: government
summary: China's coronavirus death toll surpassed 2,000, with 136 new deaths reported, bringing the total to 2,004. The number of new cases fell for the second consecutive day, reaching 74,185 confirmed cases in mainland China. Most deaths occurred in central Hubei province, where the virus first emerged in December.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.65% and the Topix index up 0.56%, driven by investors adjusting positions amid lingering fears over the new coronavirus' impact on the economy.

site_title: Westpac flags earnings downgrades after lawsuit, bushfires
summary: Westpac Banking Corp has downgraded its 2020 earnings projections due to increased costs related to improving risk management systems in response to a money-laundering scandal and the devastating Australian bushfires. The bank now expects higher costs, with a revised estimate of A$500 million in extra capital required by regulators. Westpac also pegged insurance claims for calamities at A$140 million and expects an additional A$26 million in bushfire relief costs. The bank's revised cost projections will be unveiled when it reports its half-year results in May.

site_title: Oil near flat; virus impact offsets Libya supply disruptions
summary: Oil prices remained near flat on Tuesday, influenced by concerns over the coronavirus outbreak's impact on global demand, despite Libya's reduced supply. Brent crude rose 8 cents to $57.75 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures remained unchanged. The International Energy Agency has cut 2020 oil demand estimates due to the virus, and Opec+ producers are considering further production cuts to support prices, which are expected to fall by 435,000 barrels per day in the first quarter.

site_title: Japan's exports, machinery orders fall as coronavirus risks grow
summary: Japan's machinery orders and exports declined in January, with machinery orders falling 12.5% month-on-month and exports posting a 2.6% year-on-year decline. The decline is attributed to the widening impact of the coronavirus outbreak and a recent sales tax hike. The economy is facing external and domestic pressures, with little room for policy maneuvering, and teeters on the edge of a recession. Analysts expect China-bound shipments to weaken as the outbreak hits demand from February, further exacerbating the economic challenges.

images.alt_text: Japan's machinery orders tumbled at their fastest pace since 2018 while exports posted a 14th straight month of decline as the world's third-largest economy grappled with the widening impact of the coronavirus outbreak and a recent sales tax hike.

site_title: Singapore shares post mild recovery after Budget relief measures; STI up 0.1% at open
summary: Singapore's stocks opened 0.1% higher on Wednesday, reversing losses from the previous day, after the government's Budget 2020 provided S$5.6 billion in relief measures to help firms, workers, and households amid the novel coronavirus outbreak. The Straits Times Index rose to 3,199.8, with gains outnumbering losses 99 to 31. Key sectors such as aviation and insurance saw some recovery, with Singapore Airlines and SATS rising, while Great Eastern posted a fourth-quarter net profit.

site_title: WHO urges calm as China virus death toll nears 1,900
summary: The death toll from the new coronavirus outbreak has reached nearly 1,900 in China, with over 72,000 infected, according to the World Health Organization (WHO). Despite the dire situation, most cases are mild, with 81% of patients experiencing only mild infections, and the mortality rate stands at 2.3%. WHO officials have cautioned that the situation remains serious and could grow, but measures should be taken proportionally to the situation. Global panic-buying and travel restrictions have been reported, with several countries banning travelers from China and suspending flights.

site_title: Facebook faces tax court trial over Ireland offshore deal
summary: Facebook is set to face a tax trial in a San Francisco court, with the Internal Revenue Service seeking to prove the company owes over $9 billion in taxes linked to its decision to shift profits to Ireland. The trial, expected to last three to four weeks, may involve top executives, including Andrew Bosworth and Mike Schroepfer, testifying. The company's witness list includes veterans of Facebook's growth team and chief revenue officer David Fischer. The trial aims to resolve a long-standing dispute over Facebook's tax practices in Ireland.

site_title: New York eyes luxury buildings in search for homeless fix
summary: New York City is requiring luxury rental building developers to convert vacant units into permanent housing for homeless families who can live independently. About 200 units in buildings with designated affordable housing for middle-income tenants will be repurposed. Families in shelters with incomes up to $124,930 will be prioritized for placement, with city-paid rents covering the developer's costs. This move aims to provide high-quality housing to homeless neighbors, but some developers may pull out of the program, citing the unexpected shift from affordable rentals to homeless placements.

site_title: Hong Kong apartment rents sink to lowest in almost 2 years
summary: Hong Kong apartment rents have dropped to the lowest in almost two years, with advertised residential prices per square foot at their lowest since March 2018. The decline is attributed to the COVID-19 pandemic and anti-government protests, with people relocating and landlords offering discounts of up to 12%. The increased supply of homes for rent, with a 10% rise in the northern New Territories, is adding to pressure on rents. Homeowners are instead opting to lease out their properties, expecting the pandemic to end soon.

site_title: EU to unveil plans to boost European firms, rein in US tech giants
summary: The European Commission is set to unveil plans to boost European firms and rein in US tech giants, including Facebook, Google, and Amazon, by creating a single European data market and introducing new rules on data sharing, interoperability, and artificial intelligence. The proposals, to be presented by Margrethe Vestager and Thierry Breton, aim to help European companies compete with US tech giants and Chinese state-aided companies. The EU's data strategy and artificial intelligence discussion papers are part of a larger scheme to address concerns over the power wielded by large online platforms and promote European industry.

site_title: Mediterranean diet boosts good bacteria, curbs harmful ones
summary: A Mediterranean diet has been found to boost good bacteria and curb harmful ones in older adults, according to a clinical trial with 612 volunteers aged 65-79 across five European countries. The study, published in the journal Gut, showed that those who adopted a Mediterranean diet for a year had a net drop in gut flora linked to inflammation and frailty. The results held true regardless of age or weight, and may help curb the advance of physical frailty and cognitive decline in older age.

site_title: Malaysia suspected MH370 downed in murder-suicide: Aussie ex-PM Abbott
summary: Former Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott claims that top-level Malaysian officials believed Flight MH370 was intentionally downed by the captain in a mass murder-suicide. The Malaysia Airlines jet vanished on March 8, 2014, carrying 239 people, with no signs found in a 120,000-sq km Indian Ocean search zone. Abbott's claim contradicts previous statements from Malaysia and the pilot's family, who have rejected such claims as baseless. A final report in 2018 pointed to failings by air traffic control, but no firm conclusions were reached.

site_title: US to tighten rules on China's state media
summary: The US will treat Chinese state media organisations, including Xinhua and China Global Television Network, as foreign missions, tightening rules on them. The outlets will require State Department approval to buy US property and submit employee lists, but journalistic activities inside the US will not be restricted. US officials describe Beijing's media control as propaganda and say it has become stronger and more aggressive since President Xi Jinping took office in 2013.

site_title: Travel restrictions on China fuelling 'panic': ambassador
summary: China's ambassador to the EU warns that travel restrictions over the COVID-19 outbreak are fuelling panic and threatening the Phase One trade deal with the US. The ambassador, Zhang Ming, claims the economic impact from the disease is limited and manageable, and criticizes US decisions, such as banning non-American travellers from China, as unfair. The ambassador also expresses confidence in China's long-term economic prospects and its commitment to reform and opening up, despite the current outbreak.

site_title: Pompeii restoration unearths 'surprise' treasures
summary: Archaeologists at Pompeii have completed a massive restoration project that uncovered "surprise" treasures, including vivid frescoes and never-before-seen inscriptions. The 6-year project, costing $236.4 million, reinforced walls, repaired collapsing structures, and excavated untouched areas of the ancient Roman city. New discoveries include a fresco of a gladiator and an inscription proving the city was destroyed after October 17, 79 AD. The site's general director said that future excavations will be extraordinary, and running repairs will never truly be over.

site_title: US prosecutors accuses ex-Alstom executives of bribery
summary: US federal prosecutors have charged two former Alstom executives and a former Marubeni executive with bribery in connection with a $118 million electricity contract awarded to Marubeni and Alstom's US subsidiaries. The defendants, Reza Moenaf, Eko Sulianto, and Junji Kusunoki, allegedly paid bribes to Indonesian officials to secure the contract. They are accused of violating the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. This latest charge is part of a long-running investigation into corruption by officials working for Alstom and Marubeni, with five others having already pled guilty.

site_title: Asean, China, India to feature more in exposure for tertiary students
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announced a new Asia-Ready Exposure Programme to support Singaporean youth's visits to Asean, China, or India as part of pre-employment training. The aim is to achieve a "70-70" target, where 70% of local graduates have exposure to overseas experience and 70% have exposure to Asean, China, or India. This builds on existing programs like the Global Ready Talent Programme, which aims to build a pipeline of global-ready talent for Singapore enterprises.

site_title: Sectors hit hard by virus outbreak welcome additional support measures
summary: Singapore's government has announced additional support measures to cushion the impact of the Covid-19 outbreak on sectors such as tourism, aviation, retail, and food services. These measures include property tax rebates and rental waivers for hotels, airports, and cruise terminals, as well as a temporary bridging loan programme for tourism firms. The government aims to support over 330,000 local workers in these sectors through the Jobs Support Scheme and the Adapt and Grow initiative, which will now have a six-month funding period for reskilling workers.

site_title: Covid-19: 8-in-10 Singapore-China flights cancelled
summary: More than 80% of flights between Singapore and mainland China have been cancelled since the novel coronavirus outbreak, with passenger traffic from other regions also declining. The number of weekly flights between Singapore and China dropped from over 400 to fewer than 80. Despite this, Singapore Airlines continues to fly to key Chinese cities due to the significant number of Singaporeans working and living there.

site_title: Money FM podcast: The truth about male pattern hair loss
summary: Claressa Monteiro discusses male pattern hair loss on the Money FM podcast "Workday Afternoon". Dr. Kwan Yuan Dong, an aesthetics doctor at S Aesthetics Clinic, shares common causes and available treatments for the condition, including medications, low-level laser therapy, and platelet-rich plasma injections. The conversation aims to educate listeners on the truth about male pattern hair loss and provide them with options for addressing the issue.

site_title: Singapore builders seeking legal advice as outbreak hits ops
summary: Singapore construction firms are seeking advice on invoking force majeure clauses in building contracts due to the COVID-19 outbreak, which has led to curbs on Chinese labor. The government has halted new visa issuance to Chinese nationals, and workers with existing visas must quarantine for 14 days. The construction sector, heavily reliant on foreign labor, could be impacted, potentially pushing the economy into recession with estimated $20-24 billion in projects.

site_title: Euro drops against USD after bleak investor survey
summary: The euro dropped 0.1% against the US dollar to US$1.0830, nearing its three-year low, after a German survey showed a slump in investor confidence. The euro has lost 3.4% of its value against the US dollar this year, with weak manufacturing and GDP data from Germany. The European Central Bank's interest rate cuts are also expected to have a negative impact on the euro.

site_title: SpaceX announces partnership to send four tourists into deep orbit
summary: SpaceX has announced a partnership with Space Adventures to send four tourists into deep orbit, with a mission potentially taking place by 2022 and costing over $100 million. The tourists will be carried on SpaceX's Crew Dragon capsule, which is designed to transport NASA astronauts. The mission's exact altitude will be determined by SpaceX, with the goal of reaching two to three times the height of the International Space Station. The tourists will undergo four weeks of training in the US, and the mission duration will depend on the customers' preferences.

site_title: Private investors eye S$300m additional ammo to fund startups
summary: Singapore's government has announced an additional S$300 million under its Startup SG Equity co-investment scheme to support deep-tech startups, aiming to spur over S$800 million in private funding over the next 10 years. The move is seen as a strategic initiative to strengthen Singapore as a deep-tech startup hub, addressing the challenges deep-tech startups face in raising growth-stage capital. The government's decision to allow the Angel Investors Tax Deduction (AITD) scheme to lapse on March 31 is also expected to have minimal impact on the angel investing scene.

site_title: Europe: Shares slump as Apple warning hammers China-reliant sectors
summary: European shares declined on Tuesday, retreating from record highs, as Apple's revenue warning due to the coronavirus outbreak weighed on China-reliant sectors. Shares of iPhone parts makers and other chipmakers fell, while defensive sectors like utilities and real estate saw gains. Italian banks, however, rose after merger activity, with Intesa Sanpaolo's 4.86 billion euro bid for UBI Banca sparking hopes for consolidation. The Stoxx 600 index closed 0.4% lower, despite a 1.6% jump in Italy's banking index.

site_title: Enhanced support for retirement, inclusivity
summary: The Singapore government has introduced a Matched Retirement Savings Scheme and adjusted the Basic Retirement Sum (BRS) to help lower- to middle-income seniors increase their retirement savings. The new scheme matches every dollar of cash top-up to CPF Retirement Accounts up to S$600 annually from 2021 to 2025. The BRS will also increase by 3% per year for the next two cohorts. Additionally, the government will double spending on the Silver Support Scheme, raise quarterly cash payouts, and expand eligibility criteria.

site_title: Trump commutes corrupt former politician's sentence
summary: President Donald Trump commuted the sentence of former Illinois Governor Rod Blagojevich, who was convicted of corruption and sentenced to 14 years in prison. Trump also pardoned a New York City police chief, a financier, and a former owner of the San Francisco 49ers football team. The moves raised speculation about Trump's willingness to use his power to pardon close associates, including Republican consultant Roger Stone and former campaign aide Paul Manafort.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump on Tuesday commuted the sentence of a former Illinois governor jailed for corruption, as well as pardoning a New York City police chief imprisoned for tax fraud.

site_title: Plans unveiled to help older workers stay employed
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat unveiled measures to boost jobs for mid-career and older workers, aiming to double annual job placements for those in their 40s and 50s to 5,500 by 2025. The government will expand reskilling programs, provide incentives for hiring, and offer credit top-ups and wage offsets to help workers upgrade and lighten employers' costs. A Senior Worker Support Package will also be introduced to support workers beyond their 50s who want to continue working and staying active, with wage offsets and CPF Transition Offset available.

site_title: US: Apple worries send markets lower
summary: US stocks declined on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average losing 0.6% to close at 29,232.19, and the S&P 500 dipping 0.3% to 3,370.29. Apple's share price fell 1.8% to US$319 due to concerns over the impact of the new coronavirus outbreak on its business, leading to a revised March quarter revenue forecast. Other tech stocks like Netflix and Tesla rose, while gold prices jumped 1.2% to US$1,605.5 per-ounce, indicating investors' desire for a financial safe haven.

images.alt_text: Worries over the impact of the new coronavirus outbreak on Apple sent Wall Street to a lower close on Tuesday.

site_title: Transforming enterprises will build a sustainable revenue base
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat's Budget 2020 emphasizes the need for enterprise transformation to address global structural shifts and prepare the economy for a post-COVID-19 world. The budget focuses on catalyzing long-term transformation, including digitalization, internationalization, and workforce upgrading. Targeted measures include the Enterprise Development Grant and a "3+5 protect and grow scheme" to support enterprises in productivity and growth. The goal is to develop Singapore into the Transformation Capital of Asia, enhancing its tax revenue base and lifting worker incomes.

site_title: Viruses, sinophobia and conspiracy theories
summary: The novel coronavirus (Covid-19) outbreak has sparked widespread panic, leading to sinophobia and conspiracy theories. Countries such as South Korea, Japan, and France have seen racist attacks on Chinese nationals. Conspiracy theories emerged, including claims that the virus was created in a lab, but were debunked by researchers comparing genetic sequences. The theories fueled anti-Chinese sentiment, which in turn triggered a nationalistic backlash in China. Experts warn that such theories only exacerbate panic, hinder international cooperation, and hinder the spread of the epidemic.

site_title: Japan plans HIV drug trials to fight Covid-19 infection
summary: Japan plans to start trials of HIV medications to treat coronavirus patients amid a growing threat to the economy and public health. The government's top spokesman, Yoshihide Suga, stated that preparations are underway for clinical trials using HIV medication on the novel coronavirus. However, he could not provide a timeline for approving a drug's use. This move comes as the number of cases in Japan increases, posing a significant challenge to the country's public health and economy.

site_title: What's next after the twin peaks of globalisation and monetary policy?
summary: Globalisation may be reaching its peak, while monetary policy is also nearing its limits. The rise of populism and protectionism is shifting markets towards localisation, creating opportunities in regional/local markets. Trade tensions, particularly between the US and China, continue to affect global markets. The recent Brexit general election and upcoming US elections may also impact markets. As monetary policy becomes less effective, fiscal stimulus is expected to play a larger role in driving growth. Meanwhile, megatrends such as 5G, artificial intelligence, and healthcare are expected to continue disrupting businesses and creating new investment opportunities.

site_title: Britain unveils points-based immigration plan
summary: Britain has unveiled a new points-based immigration system, replacing the free movement policy that ended with Brexit. The scheme prioritizes high-skilled workers, awarding up to 20 points for qualifications, skills, and English language proficiency. The government aims to attract workers earning at least £25,600 to fill labor shortages in key sectors. However, critics argue the policy will create a two-tier workforce and disproportionately affect low-paid workers, such as home nurses. The plan is expected to win parliamentary support, but opposition parties have raised concerns about its effectiveness and fairness.

site_title: Cecil Street's IOB Building up for sale at S$217.7m guide price
summary: The IOB Building, a six-storey office block in Singapore's central business district, has been put up for sale at a guide price of S$217.7 million. The property, with a tenure of 99 years, offers a redevelopment opportunity with a site area of 891.8 sq m and an allowable gross plot ratio of 12.6. The owner expects offers above S$1,800 per square foot per plot ratio, driven by the site's intensified use and lease extension. The tender closes on March 24.

site_title: Wing Tai: Developers unlikely to drop prices despite virus outbreak
summary: Wing Tai's deputy chairman Edmund Cheng believes the Singapore property market is well-positioned to withstand the Covid-19 crisis. He states that developers will not drop prices in a knee-jerk reaction, as they have the financial capacity to wait for the crisis to pass. This suggests that Wing Tai and other developers are unlikely to reduce prices despite the outbreak.

site_title: Pushing back GST hike a right move amid challenging climate
summary: The Singapore government has delayed the increase in the Goods and Services Tax (GST) to between 2022 and 2025, deferring the 7% to 9% hike initially planned for 2021. The move comes amid the challenging economic climate due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The government has set aside a S$6 billion Assurance Package to cushion the impact of the GST increase, with benefits including cash payouts of S$700 to S$1,600 for adults over five years. The delay is seen as a right move to give Singaporeans sufficient lead time and alleviate concerns about the economic impact.

site_title: Keeping calm and carrying on in times of distress
summary: Singapore's government has unveiled the Budget 2020, focusing on long-term goals despite the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The S$800 million package addresses immediate concerns, while the S$4 billion stabilisation package helps workers stay in jobs and the estimated GST rate hike is pushed back to 2022-2025. A S$8.3 billion package supports transformation and growth, positioning Singapore as a Global-Asia Node of Technology, Innovation and Enterprise. The government maintains a sound financial position with an estimated S$17.9 billion surplus, balancing short-term needs and long-term goals.

site_title: Bumitama Agri Q4 profit up 26% to 261b rupiah
summary: Bumitama Agri, an Indonesian palm oil producer, reported a 26.1% increase in net profit to 261.46 billion rupiah in its fourth-quarter earnings, driven by a 6.7% increase in sales revenue from the crude palm oil segment. The average sales price of crude palm oil rose 18.1% to 7,156 rupiah per kilogramme. Revenue grew 4% to 2.29 trillion rupiah, while earnings per share decreased 25.5%. The company recommended a final dividend, but its shares fell 0.73% to S$0.68 after the results were released.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: China Sunsine expects lower net profit in Q4 2019 due to decreased average selling price of products, impacted by slowing Chinese economic growth and lower raw material prices. QAF forecasts 435.5% increase in Q4 2019 net profit, while Singtel's Thai associate AIS may face negative rating pressure due to weakening operating metrics and discretionary spending. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed, and Creative Technology warns of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss.

site_title: Singapore Budget tackles virus-hit economy, gears up for transformation
summary: Singapore's Budget 2020 allocates S$5.6 billion to support firms, workers, and households amid the COVID-19 outbreak, while also focusing on future economic transformation and climate change. The budget includes a S$6 billion support package for the upcoming GST hike, S$5 billion for climate change mitigation, and measures to aid affected sectors such as tourism, aviation, and retail. The government aims to maintain fiscal prudence and has set aside S$5.6 billion in reserves, allowing it to cope with the outbreak. The budget also includes initiatives for workforce transformation and growth, with a focus on deep-tech startups and digitalization.

site_title: A thematic approach to investing in a slowing global economy
summary: The global economy is experiencing slowing growth, with the International Monetary Fund estimating 2.9% growth in 2019 and 3.3-3.4% in 2021. This slowdown is attributed to a shrinking working-age population, overleveraged financial systems, and depleted natural resources. Investors can benefit from a thematic approach to investing, focusing on sustainable and long-term structural growth opportunities, and avoiding negative trends. Bank J. Safra Sarasin's differentiated approach incorporates thematic and sustainable investing, harnessing growth through themes such as digitalization, automation, and climate change.

site_title: Bridging the gap in financial literacy
summary: Singaporeans lack sufficient knowledge of financial management, which hinders their ability to achieve financial security in retirement. Research by Singapore Management University's Professor Benedict Koh found that financially literate Singaporeans have higher average returns, more diversified portfolios, and better retirement savings. However, older Singaporeans' knowledge of financial markets and risk diversification is lacking, and women are less informed than men about stock diversification. To address this, Prof Koh urges the introduction of financial literacy programs in schools and universities, and encourages financial services providers to educate their customers.

site_title: UK will not follow EU-imposed rules as part of free trade deal
summary: The UK will not follow EU-imposed rules as part of a free trade deal after Brexit, according to chief negotiator David Frost. Britain will set its own standards for commerce and state aid, potentially giving up access to the EU single market. Frost stated that London wants a deal similar to the EU's Canada Free Trade Agreement (CETA), which binds Canada to EU legislation. If a deal is not reached, the UK and EU will trade under World Trade Organization (WTO) rules, allowing Britain to set its own laws.

site_title: Care and Support Package worth S$1.6b to help households
summary: Singapore has unveiled a S$1.6 billion Care and Support Package to help households with economic slowdown and Covid-19 uncertainties. The package includes a one-off cash payout of up to S$300 for Singaporeans above 21 years, tiered by personal income levels. The payout ranges from S$300 for those with up to S$28,000 income to S$100 for those with over S$100,000 income or multiple properties. The measure aims to provide support during the economic slowdown and Covid-19 outbreak.

site_title: Some Chinese property developers turning to short-term debt as virus hits cash flow
summary: Chinese property developers are turning to short-term debt due to the coronavirus outbreak, which has stalled home sales and reduced cash flow. At least four developers have borrowed debt with maturities of less than a year, including Guangzhou-based China Aoyuan Group and Central China Real Estate. While short-term notes are cheap, they expose issuers to higher refinancing risks. Developers expect sales to return to normal soon, but some say they will remain cautious in building landbanks this year. Rating agency Moody's notes that most developers have adequate buffers to absorb the impact of the coronavirus.

site_title: Four more in Singapore diagnosed with Covid-19 infection; 3 linked to church cluster
summary: Four more people in Singapore have been diagnosed with Covid-19, bringing the total to 81, with three linked to the Grace Assembly of God Church cluster, accounting for 21 cases. The fourth case is linked to two others, including a Chinese national and an anaesthetist. Most hospitalised patients are doing well, with four in critical condition, while five have been discharged, including a one-year-old boy who was evacuated from Wuhan.

site_title: What should investors make of the novel coronavirus outbreak?
summary: The novel coronavirus outbreak is expected to have a significant impact on global markets, but it is unlikely to derail global economic growth this year. Despite the virus, global economic growth is expected to hold, driven by a cyclical recovery in global manufacturing and positive momentum in leading indicators. The healthcare and e-commerce sectors are expected to benefit from the outbreak, while travel and hospitality sectors are likely to be negatively impacted. Valuations of Asian equities are undemanding, presenting an attractive entry opportunity for investors looking beyond near-term volatility.

site_title: Cash flow help and wage support useful, but SMEs still worry about jobs
summary: Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore welcomed the government's cash flow help and wage support, but remain uncertain about job security. Despite financial support for workers' wages, companies in the red are unlikely to give salary increases or benefit from a corporate tax rebate. SMEs are awaiting more details on relief measures to help them overcome their cash flow needs and save jobs.

site_title: With his UOB Kay Hian deemed stake nearing 30%, will Wee Ee Chao make an offer?
summary: Wee Ee Chao, chairman and managing director of UOB Kay Hian, has built up his stake in the brokerage to nearly 30%, prompting speculation about a potential mandatory general offer. His stake is significant, but below the 30% threshold, which would trigger a takeover obligation. Wee's consistent buying pattern and the brokerage's undervalued price-to-book ratio suggest a possible privatization move, as he has increased his stake in recent years and recently added trading representatives.

site_title: Could the novel coronavirus trigger a recession?
summary: The rapid spread of the novel coronavirus is threatening a global recession, particularly in China, where the world's second-largest economy is coming to a near standstill. Infections and fatalities are mounting, and big urban manufacturing and financial centers are on lockdown, leading to drastic cuts in consumption and a significant hit to service industries. While the Chinese government has taken measures to boost growth, the impact may be limited until commercial activity picks up. The epidemic is likely to have significant ramifications worldwide, including disruptions to global supply chains and a potential hit to the US economy.

site_title: Singapore doubles down on tighter foreign worker quotas
summary: Singapore has tightened its foreign worker quotas, cutting the limit on S Pass holders in the construction, marine, and shipyard industries from 20% to 15% by 2023. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat cited the need to give local workers a fair shake, despite a sharp economic slowdown. The move aims to boost productivity and prevent a labour crunch, with government agencies offering support for businesses to match foreign workers with local talent. The S Pass cap will be adjusted annually, with the goal of increasing local workforce participation in the sector.

site_title: Civmec's completed W Australia facility can boost its bids for jobs
summary: Australian engineering firm Civmec has completed its 53,000 sq meter assembly facility in Western Australia, marking a milestone in its diversification into shipbuilding. The A$85 million facility is expected to boost Civmec's bids for jobs and potentially secure more defence contracts from the Australian government. With a contract value of A$400 million to A$500 million for the Australian navy's offshore patrol vessels project, Civmec aims to generate shipbuilding revenue for about a decade. The company's financial performance will be key in determining the success of its investment.

site_title: Why trusts, why now
summary: Ultra-high net worth individuals are increasingly using trusts to preserve their legacies, drive positive social change, and navigate the evolving wealth management landscape. Trusts have evolved from their historical roots in England to become a key tool for wealth creators, offering tax deferral, management, and protection. As populist sentiments rise and regulatory regimes tighten, families are recognizing the importance of planning and preparing for a changing world order. Growing interest in philanthropy trusts and family offices is driving the use of trusts, which are now seen as a tool for holistic wealth management, encompassing tax transparency, governance, and long-term planning.

site_title: Using tech to boost seniors' wellbeing
summary: A Singapore Management University (SMU) team is collaborating with NTUC Health Co-operative to improve community programmes for the elderly using technology. NTUC Health, a leading health and eldercare provider, aims to enhance its data management and programme development with smart technology. The partnership will leverage data analysis to develop more effective programmes, such as active ageing services and senior day care, and support vulnerable seniors through community centres and volunteer visits.

site_title: Countering Covid-19, future facing
summary: Singapore has established a centre to advance sustainable aviation in Asia-Pacific. The country is also preparing for the impact of COVID-19, with measures such as a new grant of up to S$100,000 for tariff-hit businesses. Graduates are advised to remain calm as early data shows better employment rates. Additionally, Singapore has the potential to become a global hub for advanced chip packaging, according to a study. The government is also supporting workers in future-proofing their careers before a crisis strikes.

site_title: A well thought-through 'UNITY' Budget
summary: Singapore Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance Heng Swee Keat unveiled the "UNITY" Budget, focusing on supporting businesses and workers amidst the COVID-19 outbreak. The S$4 billion Stabilisation and Support Package provides temporary relief measures, including a 25% corporate income tax rebate for companies with tax payable of at least S$60,000. The Budget also includes initiatives to enhance lifelong learning, such as topping up SkillsFuture Credits for Singaporeans aged 25 and above, and a Senior Worker Support Package to help older workers.

site_title: China sees fall in coronavirus deaths
summary: China reported 1,886 new coronavirus cases, the lowest daily figure since January 30, with a total of 72,436 cases. The daily death toll fell to 98, the lowest since February 11, with a total of 1,886 deaths. The World Health Organization urges caution, as data suggests a decline in new cases. Outside China, 827 cases have been reported in 26 countries, with five deaths, mostly on a cruise ship quarantined off Japan.

site_title: Ghana is fast becoming frontier investors' new best friend
summary: Ghana has become a sought-after destination for investors, with its currency, the cedi, being the best-performing in the world in 2020. The country's US$3 billion Eurobond issue was oversubscribed, and its local-currency debt attracted significant foreign investment. Ghana's fiscal discipline, financial reforms, and improved currency management have won investors' confidence, leading to a decline in yields on existing Eurobonds and a 6.6% gain in the cedi since January. Moody's has upgraded Ghana's outlook to positive and affirmed its long-term credit rating, B3.

site_title: Balancing near-term needs with longer-term transformation
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat delivered a two-and-a-half hour speech hinting at an "exceptional budget for exceptional times" in response to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The Singapore Budget focuses on balancing near-term needs with long-term transformation, providing S$4 billion in support for businesses and S$1.6 billion for households. Tax incentives, including corporate and property tax rebates, were also introduced. The budget aims to cushion the impact of the pandemic and sets aside S$6 billion to prepare for the impending GST increase.

site_title: Boustead Projects halts construction work at Seletar coronavirus cluster
summary: Boustead Projects halted construction work at its Seletar Aerospace Heights facility in Singapore after a confirmed Covid-19 case was reported on February 9, 2020. The company stopped activities to clean and disinfect the site.

site_title: Thematic investing: Independent sources of excess growth
summary: Thematic investing, which focuses on non-traditional market categories, has gained popularity as investors seek alternative return sources. These approaches often exploit long-term growth potential in areas such as sustainability, e-commerce, and technological innovation. Key benefits of thematic investing include additional returns, diversification, and long-term growth. However, challenges exist, including accurately identifying high-return investments and managing biases. To succeed, investors must conduct thorough research, establish a pragmatic investment thesis, and maintain a long-term perspective.

site_title: Transformation and growth needed, but SMEs say they must survive first
summary: Singapore's government plans to spend S$8.3 billion over three years to promote transformation and growth among small and medium enterprises (SMEs). The initiative includes funding for partnerships, digitalization, and training programs. However, some SMEs express concern about business survival amid the novel coronavirus outbreak, citing liquidity issues and workforce employment pressures. The government's measures are seen as timely, but some businesses prioritize immediate survival over transformation.

site_title: Companies get more control over training dollars
summary: Singapore's SkillsFuture initiatives have been upgraded with changes allowing companies more control over matching training to workforce needs. The government will give firms a SkillsFuture Enterprise Credit of S$10,000 to cover up to 90% of business transformation, job redesign, and skills training costs. The Productivity Solutions Grant will also cover job redesign consultancy services. The aim is to enhance industry's role in developing staff and support 4,000 SMEs over the next five years.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Whistleblowing and exit interviews - useful tools for good governance
summary: The Singapore Exchange's regulatory arm plans to formalize corporate whistleblowing by writing it into the bourse's Listing Rules, aiming to promote trust and prevent wrongdoing. The move addresses concerns of fear of reprisals and punishment for whistleblowers. Additionally, companies can utilize exit interviews as a tool to gather candid feedback from departing employees, which can help identify ethical issues and potential fraud. Properly conducted exit interviews, with the right mindset and support from the top, can improve a company's performance and strengthen its culture and governance framework.

site_title: Budget 2020: Heng makes a strong statement of confidence
summary: Singapore's Budget 2020 was announced with confidence, marking a stark contrast to the country's economic concerns a year ago due to the US-China trade dispute and Brexit uncertainty. The US-China trade dispute has eased, with some unresolved issues remaining, while the UK has left the EU and entered an 11-month transition period. The government has also set a target of maintaining a stable economy despite global challenges, with a focus on investing in key sectors and supporting businesses.

site_title: Hamilton, Messi share men's title at Laureus sports awards
summary: Lewis Hamilton and Lionel Messi shared the Laureus sportsman of the year award for their achievements in 2019, marking the first time a footballer has won the award and the first tied decision in the event's 20-year history. Simone Biles won her third Laureus sportswoman of the year award, while South Africa was named team of the year. Other winners included Chloe Kim for action sportsperson, Oksana Masters for sportsperson with a disability, and Egan Bernal for breakthrough award.

site_title: London mayor pushes for 'associate' EU citizenship
summary: London Mayor Sadiq Khan proposed an "associate" EU citizenship for Britons after Brexit, aiming to retain the freedom of movement they enjoyed in the EU. This idea was floated last year by Guy Verhofstadt, but it's unlikely to be offered due to the exclusion of such an arrangement in the withdrawal agreement. Khan met with EU officials, including Michel Barnier, to discuss investment and potential associate citizenship. The idea appeals to many Britons who want to continue working, studying, and settling in EU countries, but it faces significant obstacles.

site_title: Dell to sell cybersecurity unit for US$2.08b
summary: Dell Technologies is selling its cybersecurity unit RSA for US$2.08 billion to a consortium led by Symphony Technology Group, Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan Board, and AlpInvest Partners. The deal is expected to close within the next six to nine months. This move comes as Dell focuses on its core business and strategic investments. The sale of RSA marks a significant shift in the cybersecurity landscape, with the consortium poised to expand its capabilities and services in the industry.

site_title: 'Sustained negative impact' from Covid-19 could hurt Japan hotel business: IPC
summary: IPC Corp reports a sustained negative impact from the Covid-19 outbreak on Nest Hotel Japan Corporation, in which IPC owns preference shares. The outbreak has led to a decline in Chinese tourists in Japan, negatively affecting the tourism and hospitality business. IPC's board will continue to monitor the impact on NHJC's business, which may adversely affect the value of IPC's investment.

site_title: Preparing for the future of urban mobility
summary: As the world's population moves to urban areas, cities face unprecedented challenges in transportation systems and planning. Electric vehicles, Connected and Autonomous Vehicles, and Mobility-as-a-Service (MaaS) are driving transformative changes. Electric vehicles can alleviate pollution and congestion, while MaaS could reduce emissions and increase road efficiency. However, CAVs pose challenges in data collection and urban policy development. Despite these challenges, CAVs can reduce accidents, enhance mobility options, and free up public space for other land uses. Urban planners must leverage CAV data to develop policies that encourage private sector involvement and create a safer, cleaner, and more accessible future.

images.alt_text: Cutting-edge research is currently looking at ways for a city's fleet of electric cars to interact with the power provider's grid to help manage the load curve by returning energy to the grid when needed.

site_title: US homebuilder sentiment eases while staying near 20-year high
summary: US homebuilder sentiment eased to 74 in February, near a 20-year high, due to lower borrowing costs and steady growth in residential construction. Mortgage rates are near a three-year low, making home purchases more affordable. Builders remain optimistic despite increasing construction costs, citing steady job growth, rising wages, and low interest rates. The South saw the strongest builder confidence on record, while the Northeast reached a 14-year high.

site_title: Hefty deficit in FY2020
summary: Singapore's FY2020 saw a hefty deficit, but the country is focusing on sustainable growth. The government is setting up a centre to advance sustainable aviation in Asia-Pacific and exploring opportunities to become a global hub for advanced chip packaging. To address workforce challenges, the government and business groups are offering support, including a new grant of up to S$100,000 for tariff-hit businesses and training programs through SBF. Experts also advise graduates to future-proof their careers.

site_title: Johnson bolsters power at home as storm clouds gather overseas
summary: Boris Johnson is consolidating power at home after the UK's landmark election in December, with several major domestic policy announcements made in the past 10 days. Johnson has reshuffled the government, placing Brexiteers in key positions, and is now at the height of his powers as prime minister. With the largest Tory majority in the House of Commons since Margaret Thatcher, Johnson dominates the political scene, having no obvious counterweight in government. This consolidation of power comes amidst UK-US policy spats, including disagreements over Huawei and digital taxes.

site_title: Sonic the Hedgehogimpresses with a mighty US$57m debut
summary: Sonic the Hedgehog, a family film based on the popular video game, debuted with $57 million in North America and $100 million globally, making it the best-performing video game adaptation. The movie's success comes after director Jeff Fowler revised the title character's design following internet backlash, resulting in a CinemaScore of "A". The film unseated Birds of Prey, which had a disappointing debut, and outperformed other movies that opened alongside it, including Fantasy Island and The Photograph.

site_title: Budget relief measures fail to lift stock prices
summary: Singapore Budget 2020 unveiled a special S$4 billion package to help companies with cash flow and jobs, particularly in sectors hit by the Covid-19 crisis. However, the measures had little immediate impact on blue-chip stocks. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat also provided assistance to the tourism, aviation, retail, food services, and point-to-point transport sectors. Despite the budget relief, investors continue to be cautious due to lingering unease over Covid-19, causing SIA shares to slip.

site_title: Covid-19 epidemic slows China's Belt and Road push
summary: China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) is slowing down due to the COVID-19 pandemic, which has caused travel restrictions, factory closures, and supply chain disruptions. Over 1,800 people have died, and over 133 countries have imposed entry restrictions on Chinese citizens or those who have visited China. Chinese workers are unable to reach overseas projects, and factories in China are struggling to operate due to the lack of Chinese imports. The pandemic is expected to have a regional and global impact, with potential delays and cost increases for BRI projects.

site_title: EH-Reit to receive more rent from outperforming properties: EHT
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT), a stapled group comprising EH-Reit and Eagle Hospitality Business Trust, announced that its subsidiary EH-Reit will receive more rent from outperforming properties. 80% of excess cash flow from outperforming properties will be applied to underperforming properties' rent shortfalls. EHT reported lower-than-forecast revenue and net property income for the fourth quarter, due to unfavorable US lodging market fundamentals and construction delays. Despite this, EHT's managers expect incremental market share gains from recent capital expenditures and asset management initiatives.

site_title: Sing Holdings posts 305% jump in 2019 earnings of S$45.4m
summary: Sing Holdings, a property development and investment group, reported a 305% increase in 2019 earnings to S$45.4 million, up from S$11.2 million in 2018. Revenue rose 315% to S$316.4 million. The company attributed the growth to property development activities in Singapore, including the sale of units in Parc Botannia, which has a sale value of S$722.1 million. However, property investment activities in Australia were affected by a drop in occupancy rates. The group recommended a final dividend of 1.85 cents per share and saw its net asset value per share increase to 73.70 cents.

site_title: Smaller deficit of S$1.65b for FY2019
summary: Singapore is expected to register a budget deficit of S$1.65 billion for FY19, 0.3% of its GDP, significantly lower than the estimated S$3.48 billion deficit a year ago. Lower-than-expected military and transport spending, including project delays and reduced Changi East development expenditure, contributed to the smaller deficit. Revenue from motor vehicle taxes and vehicle quota premiums are projected to be lower than estimated, but carbon taxes will contribute S$3.32 billion. Expenditure is expected to total S$78.16 billion, lower than anticipated.

site_title: Profit from Covid-19 profiteers, with the help of regular market forces
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a global shortage of face masks, prompting governments to crack down on profiteers selling them at high prices. However, some argue that restrictive government policies may exacerbate the shortage by stifling market forces that incentivize suppliers to produce more masks. Research suggests that anti-gouging laws can have negative economic consequences, such as prolonging shortages and hurting the very people in need. Instead, allowing market prices to reflect the true value of masks may help ration supplies and prevent hoarding, ultimately benefiting those who need them most.

site_title: AEI Corp expects FY19 loss on impairment, poor business
summary: AEI Corp expects to report a loss for FY19 due to operating and impairment losses from the disposal of its business and a poor business environment. The company, on the SGX Watchlist, is finalizing its results and will provide further details upon announcement.

site_title: Tenants stand to benefit from 15% property tax rebates
summary: Singapore's government has granted a 15% property tax rebate to private commercial properties that support food services and retail establishments, aiming to alleviate the impact of Covid-19 on businesses. Landlords plan to pass on the rebate to their tenants. This move is part of the Stabilisation and Support Package, which was announced in the Budget speech by Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat.

images.alt_text: Analysts note that the rebate can take some pressure off corporates, but add that off-budget measures could also be implemented.

site_title: Franklin Resources to buy Legg Mason for US$4.5b
summary: Franklin Resources has agreed to acquire asset manager Legg Mason for approximately US$4.5 billion in an all-cash deal. The transaction values Legg Mason at US$50 per share, a 23% premium to its share price. The combined companies will have US$1.5 trillion in assets under management, and Franklin will assume US$2 billion in Legg Mason debt. The acquisition is the latest case of consolidation in the industry, driven by falling fees and rising competition from index-tracking funds.

site_title: US: Wall Street slips at open following Apple's sales warning
summary: US stocks declined at the open on Tuesday following Apple's sales warning, which fueled concerns about the coronavirus outbreak's impact on global supply chains. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.39%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.33%, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.54%. The warning led to a sell-off in tech stocks, with Apple's shares leading the decline. The market's focus shifted to the ongoing US-EU trade tensions, which may impact the rally in stocks.

site_title: Observers support government's push for electric vehicles
summary: Singapore's Budget 2020 includes measures to promote electric vehicles, aiming to phase out internal combustion engines in 20 years. The government offers incentives such as a 45% rebate on the Additional Registration Fee for fully electric cars and taxis, and a revised road tax methodology that reduces tax for EVs and hybrids. Experts say the effectiveness of these measures depends on fleet adoption by taxi operators and ride-hailing firms, and the deployment of 28,000 public chargers. The government also plans to incorporate renewable energy into the charging infrastructure, with a goal of decarbonizing the grid by 2030.

images.alt_text: Budget 2020 delivered a pleasant surprise for climate-change watchers, who say measures to spur the adoption of electric vehicles (EV) are a step in the right direction, and that the government's vision to phase out vehicles with internal combustion engines in 20 years is achievable.

site_title: Hong Kong population falls from mid-year amid protests
summary: Hong Kong's population declined for the first time in nearly two decades due to a drop in usual residents, falling 7,900 from mid-year to end-December. The decline was driven by frequent street protests that started in June and led to a recession. Interest in leaving the city has spiked since then, according to Bloomberg. The population drop is attributed to a 97% decrease in usual residents, marking the first time since December 2002.

site_title: Asia sees boom in sustainable investing
summary: Asia is experiencing a boom in sustainable investing amid rising sea levels, with many coastal megacities projected to be submerged by 2050. Research from Climate Central highlights the vulnerability of cities like Bangkok, Shanghai, and Jakarta, which could displace hundreds of millions of people. Policymakers are taking action, with Indonesia planning a $33 billion relocation of its capital and Singapore proposing a $100 billion initiative to mitigate climate change. The Asia Development Bank estimates an annual investment of $1.7 trillion in infrastructure to sustain economic growth, with 16% of that needed to combat climate change.

site_title: Unlocking the untapped opportunity in Asia through impact investing
summary: A significant market opportunity exists in Asia, driven by under-served populations. With over 1 billion people in poverty, they spend over $2 trillion annually on basic goods and services, driving growth and increasing demand for higher quality products. As digitalization in Asia continues to grow, with internet penetration expected to reach 62% by 2025, impact investing is becoming increasingly attractive. This presents a lucrative opportunity for companies and organizations to invest in digital services, improving efficiency and creating new business models, ultimately benefiting the growing middle class in Asia.

site_title: Family businesses need to move on sustainability or be left behind
summary: Family-owned businesses in Southeast Asia, particularly in Singapore, are under pressure to adopt environmental, social, and governance (ESG) strategies to remain competitive in the supply chain. The shift is driven by multinationals and asset managers using ESG criteria to evaluate companies, and 80% of a larger business's environmental impact is now located in its supply chain. To adapt, suppliers need to develop and integrate sustainability strategies, with benefits including increased access to finance and potential funding for capital investment.

site_title: Secura FY19 net profit slumps 80%, warns of loss of major contracts
summary: Secura Group reported a 80% slump in FY19 net profit to S$366,000, down from S$1.83 million in 2018. Revenue declined 6% to S$38.7 million, primarily due to a significant decline in its security guarding segment. The company expects a substantial decline in security guarding contracts and faces industry-wide manpower shortages and increasing costs. However, it anticipates an improvement in remote surveillance and cybersecurity businesses. Secura will focus on business profitability before expanding into new areas.

site_title: Indian industry wants import tax cut to tackle coronavirus disruptions
summary: Indian business leaders are calling for reduced import duties on essential items, such as antibiotic drugs and mobile parts, due to the coronavirus disruption affecting supplies from China. The Confederation of Indian Industries estimates China provides $30 billion worth of intermediate goods annually. Indian Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman plans to announce measures in the coming days to address the issue.

images.alt_text: Indian business leaders are calling for cuts in import duties on antibiotic drugs, mobile parts and other items to help cope with the fallout from the coronavirus outbreak which has disrupted supplies from China, government and industry officials said.

site_title: Despite heightened anxieties, private banking business in good shape
summary: Asia's private banking business remains strong despite economic challenges, with record net new money inflows and assets under management in 2019. Key players, including UBS and BNP Paribas, attribute the sector's resilience to its ability to adapt to changing market conditions and attract new clients. As investors face challenges from global economic slowdown, low interest rates, and trade uncertainties, experts recommend a diversified portfolio strategy to manage risks and capitalize on opportunities. The outlook for 2020 is largely positive, with expected growth across major economies, but volatility and uncertainty remain, particularly related to the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: China Sunsine issues Q4 profit guidance on lower selling prices
summary: China Sunsine Chemical Holdings expects a material decrease in consolidated net profit in Q4 2019 due to lower average selling prices of its rubber chemicals products. The decline is attributed to slowing economic growth in China and lower raw material prices. The company's Q4 2019 results will be released on Feb 28, and shares rose 1.09% to S$0.465 on the news.

site_title: Machine lubricants leave bad taste for palm oil producers, buyers
summary: Palm oil producers and buyers face a new challenge as machinery lubricants seep into the world's most consumed edible oil during processing. European companies, including Nestle, have requested top palm oil producers in Indonesia and Malaysia to lower the amount of mineral oil hydrocarbons in palm oil. Using food-grade lubricants can cost 8-10 times more, potentially hurting profit margins. Industry officials say this is a significant concern, as food safety regulations could heavily impact the palm oil industry, accounting for nearly 70% of its global use.

site_title: Vodafone, Telecom Italia offer rivals access to some sites to ease EU concerns
summary: Vodafone and Telecom Italia have offered rivals access to some of their infrastructure for up to nine years to ease EU concerns over their plan to create Italy's largest mobile tower company. The plan, announced last July, would see Vodafone transfer its Italian mobile masts to INWIT, a TIM subsidiary, with equal governance rights. The move aims to address EU antitrust regulators' tough line on mergers that reduce market competition. The companies will allow rivals access to some infrastructure, reducing concerns over reduced player numbers in the market.

site_title: FY20 Budget gears up to spend big with S$10.9b deficit
summary: Singapore's FY2020 budget deficit is projected at S$10.9 billion, the highest in more than two decades. Despite the high deficit, economists say the budget is a sign of long-term prudent spending and fiscal resilience. Total spending is expected to rise 7% to S$83.61 billion, with a focus on healthcare and infrastructure spending. The government has allocated S$4 billion for a Stabilisation and Support Package to stabilise the economy and support workers and enterprises.

images.alt_text: The expected overall budget deficit of S$10.9 billion for FY2020 is the highest in more than two decades, but economists say the budget plans outlined by the government on Tuesday are a sure sign of long-term prudent spending and fiscal resilience.

site_title: New Qualcomm chips aim to connect phones to disparate 5G networks
summary: Qualcomm has introduced new X60 modem chips designed to connect mobile phones to 5G networks operating on different frequencies worldwide. The chips can handle both sub-6 and millimeter wave frequencies, enabling faster data speeds. Carrier aggregation technology allows multiple bands of wireless spectrum to be sent simultaneously, boosting download speeds. The X60 chip, made using 5-nanometer technology, will be manufactured by Samsung Electronics and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing and is expected to be featured in premium smartphones in early 2021. This move aims to support the growing adoption of 5G networks, with Qualcomm predicting 175-225 million 5G smartphones to be sold in 2020.

site_title: Despite e-commerce, consumers in Asia still prefer online retailers with physical stores: poll
summary: A poll by Zebra Technologies found that nearly 58% of Asian consumers prefer online retailers with physical stores, despite e-commerce's rise. This preference holds across generations, with 73% of millennials and 57% of Gen X shoppers supporting it. However, baby boomers were less likely to prefer this approach. Consumers also expect store associates to have similar knowledge and technology to what they have online, with 62% saying they would have a better experience when using technology in stores. Retailers must balance basic needs with innovation to elevate the shopper experience.

site_title: Budget 2020: Govt aims to phase out all vehicles with internal combustion engines by 2040
summary: Singapore aims to phase out all vehicles with internal combustion engines by 2040, with the government introducing three measures to promote cleaner energy vehicles. The measures include enhanced incentives for drivers to adopt cleaner vehicles, a rebate scheme for electric vehicles and taxis, and an expansion of public charging infrastructure. The government also plans to revise road tax methodology and progressively procure cleaner vehicles. This move aims to reduce pollution and greenhouse gas emissions, following the lead of major cities that have set similar goals.

site_title: Coronavirus: 4 new cases including 3 linked to Grace Assembly of God church
summary: Four new coronavirus cases were reported in Singapore, bringing the total to 81, with three linked to the Grace Assembly of God Church and one to a Chinese national and an anaesthetist. The church cluster now accounts for 21 cases, a quarter of the total cases in Singapore. Most patients are recovering, with four still in critical condition, and five have been discharged.

site_title: Pan-United Q4 net profit soars 167%, raises dividend
summary: Pan-United, Singapore's largest ready-mix concrete producer, reported a 167% surge in Q4 net profit to S$5.4 million, driven by lower raw materials and subcontract costs. Revenue declined 20% to S$169 million. Full-year earnings per share increased 237% to 2.93 cents. A final dividend of 1.1 cents per share is proposed, up from 0.8 cents in 2018. The company forecasts steady demand for ready-mix concrete in 2020 but warns of potential impact from the Covid-19 outbreak on local construction activities.

site_title: Wildfires are just beginning of Australian dollar's climate woes
summary: The Australian dollar may find relief from cyclical downturns if the government prioritizes climate change and environmental policies. ABN Amro Bank expects a shift towards a greener economy could alter the Aussie's performance, making it less driven by global risk sentiment. However, a transition to sustainability would be a tough one in the short term, resulting in lower export revenues and potentially deteriorating fundamentals. The bank notes that even if the economy becomes more environmentally sustainable, the results would only become visible over time, likely weighing on the Australian dollar in the coming years.

site_title: Focus on Budget but S'pore shares extend fall as Covid-19 fears linger
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.5% to 3,196.63, its fourth consecutive decline, amid lingering Covid-19 fears. The STI benchmark index is down 0.8% this year. Despite the government's S$4 billion package to help companies and tourism sectors, shares in aviation-focused listings were mixed, with Singapore Airlines falling 1.7% and SATS trading flat. Index heavyweights like local banks ended lower, with DBS Group Holdings, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank all declining.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Budget 2020 allocates SS$5.6 billion in short-term support amid the Covid-19 outbreak, while maintaining a long-term focus on economic transformation and climate change. The budget aims to support firms, workers, and households. Meanwhile, other news includes Vietnam's surprise at US tariffs, Malaysia's plan to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets, China's slowing GDP growth, and the UK's economy shrinking for the second month in a row.

site_title: QAF expects jump in Q4 earnings on better primary business performance
summary: QAF, a Singapore-based bread manufacturer, expects a significant improvement in FY2019 earnings due to its primary production business. The company forecasts a 435.5% increase in 4th-quarter net profit to S$22.7 million and a 6% rise in full-year revenue to S$863.9 million. Net profit for FY2019 is estimated to be S$28.2 million, up 226.1% from FY2018. QAF shares rose 0.64% to S$0.785 following the announcement. The company will report its FY2019 results later this month.

site_title: Budget 2020: Government sets aside S$1b over 3 years for cyber and data security
summary: Singapore's government has allocated S$1 billion over three years to enhance cyber and data security capabilities. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of safeguarding citizens' data and critical information infrastructure systems. This move comes after a major data breach incident in 2018, where 1.5 million SingHealth patients' personal data was stolen. The government aims to build on its existing cyber security agency, the Cyber Security Agency (CSA), to address emerging threats from advanced technologies like AI, cloud, and the Internet of Things.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close flat on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed flat on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.04 points to 1,537.08. A total of 2.7 billion lots were traded worth RM2.1 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 597 to 251. This follows a broader market trend, as stocks in Europe were down due to bank and healthcare sector drag, and US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats.

site_title: Budget 2020: CAAS to roll out regulatory fee rebate to Singapore carriers
summary: The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) will provide a 50% rebate on regulatory fees for new and renewed certificates of airworthiness, saving Singapore carriers S$6 million. This measure is part of the Stabilisation and Support Package (SSP) announced by Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat during the Budget speech. The assistance aims to help the aviation community offset business costs and protect jobs, safeguarding Singapore's air connectivity amid the Covid-19 outbreak.

site_title: Budget 2020: Expected overall budget deficit of S$10.9b; no draw on past reserves for FY2020
summary: Singapore's government expects an overall budget deficit of S$10.9 billion for FY2020, but will not draw on past reserves due to a sufficient accumulated fiscal surplus. The deficit is lower than forecasted a year ago, primarily due to lower-than-expected expenditures from unforeseen project delays. The government's fiscal surplus will be used to fund the deficit, with the overall deficit accounting for 0.3% of Singapore's GDP for FY2019.

images.alt_text: Finance minister Heng Swee Keat said the government is expecting an overall budget deficit of S$1.7 billion, or 0.3% of Singapore's GDP for FY2019.

site_title: Budget 2020: Initial S$5b injection for new fund to guard against rising sea levels
summary: The Singapore government announced an initial S$5 billion injection for a Coastal and Flood Protection Fund to safeguard against rising sea levels. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat made the announcement in the 2020 Budget speech, citing the existential threat of rising sea levels and the need to protect the island for future generations. This major fiscal outlay is seen as a prudent step to address the potential S$100 billion cost of climate change adaptation over 100 years.

images.alt_text: "This is a major fiscal outlay in the coming years, so it is right and prudent that we set aside resources for this."

site_title: Budget 2020: Lump-sum tax built into road tax for electric vehicles
summary: Singapore will introduce a lump-sum tax on electric vehicles (EVs) starting from January 2021, to partly compensate for lost fuel excise duties. The tax will be phased in over three years, with the full amount implemented by January 2023. Total road tax for some EV models will be higher, but EV buyers can still enjoy significant cost savings due to the Early Adoption Incentive. The government aims to implement a usage-based tax on EVs in the future, but the technology is not yet available.
