site_title: British metals tycoon Gupta buys bankrupt steel plant in India
summary: British metals tycoon Sanjeev Gupta's GFG Alliance has acquired a bankrupt steel plant in India, Adhunik Metaliks and Zion Steel, for $60 million. The steel plant, with annual capacity of 500,000 tonnes, will be integrated into GFG's Liberty Steel Group, which aims to become carbon neutral by 2030. Gupta said the takeover will revive the plant and bring employment back. This is GFG's latest acquisition in the steel and aluminium sector, following a string of purchases worldwide.

site_title: Budget 2020: Government to match retirement savings top-ups by up to S$3,000 over 5 years
summary: Singapore's government will introduce a 5-year programme to match retirement savings top-ups made by lower- to middle-income Singaporeans, with the goal of encouraging and augmenting family support for seniors. The Matched Retirement Savings Scheme will match every dollar of cash top-up made to CPF Retirement Accounts, up to an annual cap of S$600, from 2021 to 2025. This means that individuals who make a top-up of S$3,000 will receive a dollar-for-dollar top-up of S$3,000, bringing the total to S$6,000. About 435,000 Singaporeans will be eligible for the scheme.

site_title: Budget 2020: S$31m in annual spend allotted to support employers of PwDs
summary: Singapore's government has introduced the Enabling Employment Credit (EEC) scheme to support employers of persons with disabilities (PwDs). The EEC will replace the Special Employment Credit and Additional SEC schemes, providing wage offsets for hiring PwDs earning below S$4,000 per month. The 5-year scheme will cost approximately S$31 million annually, with reviews to be conducted after two years. The government also announced top-ups to funds supporting the elderly and lower-income individuals.

site_title: Budget 2020: Singaporeans above 21 to get one-off cash payout of up to S$300
summary: Singaporeans above 21 will receive a one-off cash payout of up to S$300 as part of the government's S$1.6 billion Care and Support Package for households. The payout amounts vary based on income, with those earning up to S$28,000 receiving S$300, while those earning between S$28,001 and S$100,000 will get S$200. Additional payouts include S$100 for every adult with a child under 20, S$100 top-up for seniors, and a one-off GST Voucher for eligible households.

site_title: Hotel Properties, Ong Beng Seng to acquire hotel in Italian Dolomites
summary: Hotel Properties Ltd, a subsidiary of Ong Beng Seng, plans to acquire 90% of the corporate capital and voting rights in Alpina Dolomites SRL for €40.6 million (S$61 million). The acquisition includes a 5-star luxury hotel in Italy's Dolomites region. The deal will be funded by internal funds and bank borrowings. Following the acquisition, HPL shares rose 5.34% to S$3.75. The purchase consideration was negotiated at arm's length and takes into consideration the trading performance of the business and hotel activities.

site_title: Interra Resources JV completes development well in Myanmar
summary: Interra Resources' joint-venture entity, Goldpetrol Joint Operating Company, has completed the development well CHK 1220 in the Chauk oil field in Myanmar as an oil producer. Interra holds a 60% interest in the Improved Petroleum Recovery Contract and owns 60% of Goldpetrol, the operator. The well was drilled using a low-cost rig, with drilling costs funded from existing funds. This milestone marks a significant achievement for the company in Myanmar's oil exploration and production sector.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed 1.5% lower on Tuesday, following a decline in corporate earnings and economic growth due to the deadly new coronavirus. The Hang Seng Index fell to 27,530.20, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.1%. The Shenzhen Composite Index increased 1.12%. The decline was attributed to the impact of the coronavirus on the global economy.

site_title: Gyms in China livestream routines as coronavirus keeps patrons away
summary: Gyms in China have resorted to livestreaming workouts as the coronavirus epidemic keeps patrons away. Many gyms have started offering free online classes to maintain customer engagement and protect existing clients. However, the lack of income from these classes has raised concerns among gym owners. Some are exploring alternative revenue streams, such as renting out gym equipment, while others are bracing for a prolonged suspension of business. The situation is expected to continue until at least the end of the month.

site_title: Budget 2020: S Pass sub-DRC tightened for construction, marine shipyard and process sectors
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced that the S Pass sub-Dependency Ratio Ceiling (DRC) for the construction, marine shipyard, and process sectors will be reduced from 20% to 15% by 2023. This change aims to encourage local recruitment and skill development. The manufacturing sector will be exempt from this tightening, with plans to introduce similar measures in the future. The changes are intended to adapt to growing S Pass holders in these sectors, which are expected to increase in the coming years.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks end lower on worries over economic impact from virus
summary: South Korean stocks closed 1.5% lower on Tuesday, their lowest close since February 10, amid worries over the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak in China. Apple's revenue warning contributed to the decline. The KOSPI has risen 0.51% so far this year, but the decline marks a reversal from previous gains.

site_title: Budget 2020: Government to set up new trust for social service sector
summary: The Singapore government plans to set up a Community Capability Trust, a new trust to fundraise and support social service agencies, with a commitment of up to S$350 million. The trust, to be established by the Ministry of Social and Family Development and the National Council of Social Service, aims to enhance social service agencies' capabilities and capacities to serve the community. The government and Tote Board will provide S$200 million in FY2020, with a match of up to S$150 million in funds raised over the next 10 years.

site_title: Budget 2020: Billions in short-term support, while keeping long-term focus for Singapore
summary: Singapore's Budget 2020 allocates billions in short-term support to help firms, workers, and households amid the Covid-19 outbreak. The budget sets aside S$5.6 billion for support, including an 8% wage offset for local workers and a 25% corporate income tax rebate. The government also aims to raise recurrent revenue to finance long-term economic transformation and address future challenges such as climate change and fiscal sustainability. The budget retains a focus on the future, with S$8.3 billion allocated for transformation and growth over the next three years.

site_title: Hong Kong protests hurt Holiday Inn-owner IHG, sees pain from virus outbreak
summary: InterContinental Hotels Group (IHG), owner of Holiday Inn, reported a slight dip in annual room revenue due to Hong Kong protests and the impact of the Chinese virus outbreak. Comparable revenue per available room fell 0.3% globally and 4.5% in Greater China. The company closed or partially closed 160 out of its 470 hotels in China, and allowed customers to change or cancel stays in affected areas at no additional cost. Total revenue rose 6.7% to $4.63 billion for the year ended December 31.

site_title: Budget 2020: Basic Retirement Sum set at S$93,000 for those turning 55 next year
summary: The Basic Retirement Sum (BRS) in Singapore will increase by 3% annually for two cohorts, setting a target of S$93,000 for those turning 55 in 2021 and S$96,000 for those turning 55 in 2022. The current BRS for those turning 55 this year is S$90,500. The government aims to ensure the BRS keeps up with basic retirement expenses, with the expectation that seven in 10 actively employed persons from the two cohorts will be able to set aside the sum.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets slide at open
summary: European stock markets slid at the start of trading on Tuesday, with the FTSE 100 index falling 0.9% to 7,368.25 points. The DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices also declined, losing 0.8% and 0.7% respectively. The decline was attributed to bank and healthcare stocks, with US-EU trade tensions also a focus.

images.alt_text: Frankfurt's DAX 30 index lost 0.8 per cent to 13,667.80 points.

site_title: Australia: Energy, tech stocks drag down shares on coronavirus impact
summary: Australian shares closed 0.2% lower on Tuesday, led by losses in energy and tech stocks due to concerns over the coronavirus' impact on China's economy and global supply chains. Apple's revenue forecast warning and Altium Ltd's weak outlook partly due to the virus dragged the market lower. Energy stocks, including Woodside Petroleum, declined due to declining oil prices. Despite BHP Group's higher profit, the market ended the session lower, with Coles Group's shares 1% lower due to underpaid store managers.

site_title: Budget 2020: S$500 top-up for SkillsFuture Credit, expires by 2025
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced in the 2020 Budget Speech that all Singaporeans aged 25 and above will receive a one-off S$500 top-up for their SkillsFuture Credit, set to expire by 2025. This move aims to encourage Singaporeans to take action early to learn new skills during the economic slowdown. The SkillsFuture Credit has helped over half a million Singaporeans develop new skills and interests since its launch in 2015.

site_title: Budget 2020: Deep-tech startups to get more support under Startup SG Equity
summary: The Singapore government will allocate an additional S$300 million under the Startup SG Equity co-investment scheme to support deep-tech startups, aiming to draw over S$800 million of private funding over the next decade. This move aims to provide better access to capital, expertise, and industry networks for these startups, which face higher risks and require larger investments and longer gestation periods. The allocation is part of the government's Transformation and Growth strategy, valued at S$8.3 billion over the next three years.

site_title: Budget 2020: Enterprise Grow Package to help companies digitalise and enter new markets
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced the Enterprise Grow Package, a new initiative to support companies in growing and entering new markets through digitalization. The package includes the expansion of the GoBusiness platform, Industry Digital Plans, and the Market Readiness Assistance grant, aiming to enhance digital adoption and facilitate market entry. Funding support and free trade agreement consultancy will be expanded to support companies. The goal is to help enterprises identify business needs, adopt digital technologies, and take the first steps to enter new markets.

site_title: Budget 2020: Senior employment credit, CPF offset among new measures for those hiring older workers
summary: Singapore will introduce a Senior Worker Support Package with four measures to support enterprises that employ older staff. The Senior Employment Credit will provide wage offsets for those hiring Singaporeans aged 55 and above, starting from 2021. Employers will also receive a CPF Transition Offset for the 2021 increase in CPF contribution rates. A Senior Worker Early Adopter Grant will support enterprises raising retirement and re-employment ages ahead of legislated changes. Additionally, a S$500 SkillsFuture Credit top-up will support seniors who choose to retire but wish to continue learning and staying active.

site_title: Budget 2020: Training, mentorship for 900 SME leaders over next 3 years
summary: Singapore's government plans to train and mentor 900 SME leaders over the next three years through the Enterprise Leadership for Transformation Programme. The programme, launched by Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat, aims to boost business transformation and leadership capabilities. The government will also expand the Enterprise Development Grant to support more projects, increasing its support by over 10% in FY2020. The programme is part of the Enterprise Transform Package, aimed at strengthening leadership and management capabilities, and is seen as a key initiative to enhance Singapore's global competitiveness.

site_title: Budget 2020: New SkillsFuture Mid-Career Support Package for workers in 40s and 50s
summary: Singapore's government is introducing a SkillsFuture Mid-Career Support Package to help workers in their 40s and 50s stay employable. The package aims to double job placements for this age group to around 5,500 by 2025. The initiative includes increased capacity for reskilling programs, hiring incentives for local jobseekers, and a special SkillsFuture Credit top-up of S$500 for those aged 40-60. The government also encourages employers to recruit, retain, and retrain mid-career workers, promising support for those who do so.

site_title: Budget 2020: Self-help groups to get S$10m grant to support needy families amid virus outbreak
summary: Singapore's government has allocated S$10 million over two years to self-help groups to support needy families amid the COVID-19 outbreak. The grant is part of the S$1.6 billion Care and Support Package, which also includes S$20 million for Community Development Councils to implement local initiatives. The measures aim to help Singaporeans with household expenses during this period of uncertainty and strengthen community bonds. The government's comprehensive package also aims to address the needs of vulnerable groups.

site_title: S&P sees Singtel associate Advanced Info Service losing rating headroom with spectrum win
summary: S&P Global Ratings warns Advanced Info Service (AIS), a Singtel associate, that its rating of BBB+ with a stable outlook may face negative pressure due to weakening operating metrics or rising discretionary spending. AIS's spectrum wins in Thailand have diminished its financial headroom, and the credit agency expects the company to fund spectrum licence payments and 5G capital expenditure using debt and internally generated cash flow. AIS's 5G capex is expected to rise, averaging 30-32 billion baht annually, with no significant payback expected over the next two years.

site_title: Budget 2020: New SkillsFuture Enterprise Credit to defray 90% of training, job redesign costs
summary: Singapore's government introduces a new SkillsFuture Enterprise Credit to encourage workforce transformation and enterprise growth. The credit allows employers to defray up to 90% of training and job redesign costs, benefiting over 35,000 enterprises, mostly small and medium-sized enterprises. The government also expands the Productivity Solutions Grant and partners with large anchor enterprises to support training for SMEs and their value-chain partners. By 2025, the government aims to double the capacity of SkillsFuture Work-Study Programmes and deepen workplace learning capabilities.

site_title: Thousands of frozen meat containers piling up at China ports: sources
summary: Thousands of frozen meat containers are piling up at Chinese ports, including Tianjin, Shanghai, and Ningbo, due to transport disruptions and labor shortages caused by coronavirus travel curbs. The shortage affects deliveries of pork, chicken, and beef, which China imports from South America, Europe, and the US. Port operations remain uncertain, with truck drivers quarantined for 14 days and other transport restrictions in place. This disruption comes as China boosts meat imports to ease shortages caused by African swine fever.

site_title: Budget 2020: Boost in bursaries, other financial assistance for students
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced in the 2020 Budget speech that students from lower-income families will receive increased financial assistance. The annual bursary for pre-university students will rise to S$1,000, while primary to pre-university students will receive greater transport subsidies, and secondary school students will get increased subsidies for school meals.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei down for fourth straight session on virus fears
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei 225 index dropped 1.40% to 23,193.80, marking its fourth consecutive decline due to concerns over the new virus outbreak's impact on major global companies. The broader Topix index also fell 1.31% to 1,665.71. The market holiday in the US contributed to the thin trade.

site_title: Budget 2020: Government to pump S$6.4b into virus support measures
summary: Singapore's government has allocated S$6.4 billion for measures related to the novel coronavirus (Covid-19) outbreak. The majority of the funds will go to the Ministry of Health, with S$800 million supporting frontline agencies. Two special packages will also be introduced: the Stabilisation and Support Package (S$4 billion) to help workers and enterprises, and the Care and Support Package (S$1.6 billion) for households, providing additional help with living expenses. The government aims to alleviate the impact of the virus on businesses and jobs amid the global economic slowdown.

site_title: Budget 2020: S$2.4b to help firms defray wage costs
summary: Singapore's government has introduced a S$4 billion Stabilisation and Support Package to help companies defray wage costs. The Jobs Support Scheme will offset 8% of wages for local workers, up to S$3,600 per month, for three months. The Wage Credit Scheme will also be enhanced with a top-up of S$1.1 billion, raising the monthly wage ceiling to S$5,000 for qualifying wage increases in 2019 and 2020. The measures aim to support 1.9 million local workers and approximately 90,000 enterprises.

site_title: Cochlear says demand for implants may struggle to pick-up in virus-hit China
summary: Cochlear Ltd, an Australian hearing implant maker, warns that demand for hearing implants in China may struggle to recover from the coronavirus crisis, which is delaying surgeries. The company expects a drop in demand for March, traditionally its biggest month in China, and has cut its full-year profit forecast. Underlying profit for the six months ended December 31 was slightly above last year's, but revenue from implant sales climbed 14%. Cochlear's shares fell 3.4% due to the forecast cut. The company expects underlying profit for fiscal 2020 to be between A$270 million and A$290 million.

site_title: China to waive tariffs on US medical imports amid virus outbreak
summary: China announced it will waive tariffs on US medical equipment imports starting March 2, amid the ongoing coronavirus epidemic. The exemptions include patient monitors, blood transfusion equipment, and blood pressure instruments. The move is aimed at boosting cooperation between the two countries in combating the outbreak, which has infected over 72,000 people and claimed over 1,800 lives. The decision follows a surge in global demand for medical supplies.

site_title: Some Chinese property developers turning to short-term debt as virus hits cashflow
summary: Chinese property developers are turning to short-term debt to cope with reduced cash flow due to the coronavirus outbreak. Several developers, including China Aoyuan Group and Central China Real Estate, have sold notes maturing in less than a year. This shift is a stark contrast to last month's sales of long-tenor notes. While short-term notes are cheap, they expose issuers to higher refinancing risks if markets turn volatile. Rating agency Moody's says most developers have adequate buffers, but small and financially weak firms face higher refinancing risks.

site_title: Cecil Street's IOB Building up for sale at S$217.7m guide price
summary: The IOB Building, a six-storey office block in Singapore's central business district, has been put up for sale at a guide price of S$217.7 million. The property, with a tenure of 99 years, features 891.8 square metres of site area and is zoned "commercial" according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority's 2019 Master Plan. The sale is expected to attract interest from developers and investors, although the current market conditions and demand for prime projects in Singapore remain uncertain.

site_title: Singapore builders seek force majeure advice as coronavirus causes labour crunch
summary: Singapore construction firms are seeking advice on invoking force majeure clauses due to the coronavirus, which has caused a labour crunch and halted the issuance of new visas to Chinese nationals. With an estimated US$20-US$24 billion of building projects in the works, a large impact on the sector could push the economy into recession. Several contractors have already invoked force majeure, and the government has urged private sector developers to give extensions to contractors. The labour shortage issue has been raised with authorities by the Singapore Contractors Association.

site_title: Dutch court set to rule in US$50b Yukos appeal
summary: A Dutch appeals court is set to rule on a US$50 billion appeal by former shareholders of Russian oil giant Yukos, who claim the company was forced into bankruptcy by excessive tax claims and then sold off to state-owned companies. The case, which dates back to 2004, stems from the break-up of Yukos after its former owner, Mikhail Khodorkovsky, was arrested in 2003. The court's decision may not be final, as the parties may still appeal to the Dutch Supreme Court.

site_title: Budget 2020: Enterprise Singapore launches 2 programmes to support trade and merchant associations
summary: The Singapore government has launched two programmes to support trade and merchant associations. The Executive-in-Residence programme will fund over 10 trade associations to hire experienced executives and procure expert advice for enterprises. The Heartland Enterprise Upgrading Programme will support merchants' associations in transforming heartland enterprises. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat said these programmes will strengthen industry partnerships and deepen industry-wide capabilities, helping sustain the country's good progress.

site_title: Budget 2020: More help for 5 sectors directly hit by Covid-19
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced a special S$4 billion Stabilisation and Support Package to alleviate the impact of the novel coronavirus (Covid-19) on five directly affected sectors in Singapore: tourism, aviation, retail, food services, and point-to-point transport services. The package includes property tax rebates, rental waivers, and loans for these sectors, with the aim of supporting businesses and workers amid the outbreak. The government will also enhance support through redeployment programs and the Jobs Support Scheme to retain and reskill over 330,000 local workers.

site_title: HSBC 2019 pre-tax profits drop by a third to US$13.3b
summary: HSBC reported a 33% drop in 2019 pre-tax profits to US$13.3 billion, citing a US$7.3 billion goodwill impairment in Europe. Interim CEO Noel Quinn warned that the bank is not delivering acceptable returns and plans to overhaul underperforming areas, including reducing jobs in the US and Europe. The bank also announced plans to reduce its branch network, consolidate activities, and lower expenses by 10-15%. Quinn stated that parts of the business are not delivering acceptable returns, amid uncertainties from the US-China trade war, Brexit, and the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Joo Chiat conservation shophouse put on market with S$4.5m guide price
summary: A conservation shophouse at 452 Joo Chiat Road in Singapore is up for sale with an indicative price of S$4.5 million, translating to S$2,140 per square foot. The two-storey shophouse, built on a 1,100 sq ft freehold site, is fully tenanted and expected to provide an immediate rental income. The sale is via an expression of interest exercise, with interested parties invited to submit their offers by March 18, and no additional buyer's or seller's stamp duty will be imposed.

site_title: Funding ASEAN's trade engine: Technology and collaboration
summary: ASEAN's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) face significant challenges in accessing financing due to a global trade finance gap estimated at $1.5 trillion. Banks are under increasing regulatory scrutiny, leading to a disparity between their needs and those of their corporate clients. However, technology and collaboration are changing the landscape, with fintechs offering innovative products and improved features. Banks are recognizing the importance of partnering with fintechs to offer a greater range of products, and a three-pronged partnership model between corporates, banks, and fintechs is emerging. Cloud-based solutions are also expected to play a key role in providing scalable, secure, and agile financing solutions.

site_title: Dawn Mello, who revived Bergdorf Goodman and Gucci, dies at 88
summary: Dawn Mello, a renowned fashion retailer, has passed away at 88. She revitalized Bergdorf Goodman and helped restore Gucci's luxury image in the 1980s and 1990s. As vice president and fashion director at Bergdorf, Mello nurtured emerging designers, including Donna Karan, Giorgio Armani, and Tom Ford. Her keen eye and nurturing personality transformed the store into a temple of high-end consumption. Mello's influence extended beyond Bergdorf, with her hiring decisions and merchandising strategies shaping the fashion industry.

site_title: A giant milk industry merger moves closer with a US$425m deal
summary: Dairy Farmers of America, the US's largest milk cooperative, has reached a $425 million deal to acquire a "substantial portion" of bankrupt milk company Dean Foods. The deal aims to guarantee buyers for farmers' milk amidst declining national consumption and the trade war with China. Critics argue that the merger would reduce competition and suppress milk prices, while executives say it will keep the market stable and secure markets for their members' milk. The deal must be approved by the bankruptcy court and regulators.

site_title: Furious shareholders blast Nissan bosses
summary: Nissan shareholders heavily criticized the company's performance, particularly its plummeting stock price, at an extraordinary meeting. The company posted a 87% drop in net profit for the nine months to December, and failed to issue a dividend. Shareholders also questioned executive pay, with some calling for executives to have their compensation reduced. Former boss Carlos Ghosn's escape from financial misconduct charges was also mentioned. New CEO Makoto Uchida sought to placate shareholders, promising a strategic review in May to turn around the company's fortunes.

site_title: Budget 2020: Corporates to enjoy 25% income tax rebate, enhanced tax treatments
summary: Singapore's government has introduced a corporate income tax rebate of 25% with a cap of S$15,000 for the 2020 financial year to support enterprises affected by the Covid-19 outbreak. The rebate is part of a S$4 billion Stabilisation and Support Package, which also includes enhanced tax treatments for companies, such as faster write-down of investments and renovation costs. The package aims to provide working capital support through enhanced loan schemes and flexible rental payments for government-managed properties. The measures are expected to benefit all tax-paying companies and cost the government approximately S$400 million.

images.alt_text: The rebate will benefit all tax-paying companies and cost the government about S$400 million.

site_title: Asia: Markets fall as coronavirus hits earnings, growth
summary: Asian markets plummeted on Tuesday as the coronavirus outbreak hit earnings and growth, with the virus killing over 1,800 and infecting nearly 72,500 people, mostly in China. Apple warned of production disruptions, and investors feared a prolonged impact on corporate earnings. Markets in Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Singapore fell, with the Nikkei 225 index down 1.2%, and the Shanghai Composite Index slipping 0.2%. The World Health Organization and International Monetary Fund expressed caution about the economic impact, while European markets rose after a prediction of a "temporary" impact.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon down 0.6% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) resumed trading on Tuesday, down 0.6% at 3,194.38 points, amid concerns over the Covid-19 outbreak and Apple's lower profit guidance. Volume and turnover were lower than 2019 averages.

site_title: China's aviation market shrinks to smaller than Portugal's
summary: China's aviation market has shrunk to 25th globally due to the coronavirus outbreak, falling from third in 2019. Airlines have significantly reduced capacity, with global carriers cutting 1.7 million seats from China services and Chinese airlines slashing 10.4 million domestic seats. The market's decline highlights the industry's dependence on China, with capacity reduced by 80-90% on international flights and a quarter of a million seats dropped from China to Hong Kong and Taiwan in five weeks. The impact may linger beyond the virus, with some airlines facing long-term damage to their growth.

site_title: Budget 2020: S$6b package to cushion impact of upcoming GST increase
summary: Singapore's government has announced a S$6 billion package to cushion the impact of a 2% GST increase to 9% by 2025. The Assurance Package will provide offsets to households, with lower-income households receiving more, and a cash payout of S$700 to S$1,600 over five years for every adult Singaporean. The package aims to offset at least five years' worth of additional GST expenses incurred. The government has also committed to enhancing the permanent GST Voucher Scheme to defray GST for lower- to middle-income Singaporeans.

site_title: Singapore Airlines to reduce flights across network due to virus impact
summary: Singapore Airlines will temporarily reduce flights across its global network in March, April, and May due to weaker demand caused by the coronavirus epidemic. Destinations affected include Los Angeles, Frankfurt, Paris, Tokyo, Seoul, Jakarta, Sydney, and Mumbai. This is in addition to previously announced major cuts to flights to mainland China and Hong Kong. The airline aims to mitigate the impact of the virus on its operations and revenue.

site_title: Mexico's Pemex signs contracts for new oil projects -CEO
summary: Mexico's state-owned oil company Pemex has signed contracts with oilfield service firms for new exploration and production projects, aiming to discover and develop 20 new oil and gas fields this year. CEO Octavio Romero said the closed bidding process offers cost savings and expects all related contracting to be finalized by mid-2020. This move comes as Pemex targets 20 new projects, with only three of the 20 priority projects selected last year reporting crude production as of December. Negotiations with US-based Talos Energy over the Zama offshore discovery are ongoing.

site_title: Apple jars investors into coronavirus realities
summary: Apple has warned that its quarterly revenue will fall short of expectations due to supply and demand issues caused by the coronavirus outbreak in China. The company's manufacturing partners have reopened plants, but staffing them is proving difficult due to workers being trapped at home. This could have ripple effects on the global economy, particularly in industries that rely heavily on Chinese components, such as pharmaceuticals. Apple's announcement marks a significant concern, as it's the first major US company to sound the alarm, and its impact may be felt beyond the tech industry.

site_title: Canada's Trudeau stresses the need for peaceful end to pipeline protests
summary: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau called for a peaceful resolution to the rail blockades by indigenous rights groups protesting the Coastal GasLink pipeline in British Columbia. The blockades, which began nearly two weeks ago, have forced Canadian National Railway Co to shut operations in eastern Canada. Trudeau has been in touch with indigenous communities and premiers about the situation, but declined to disclose measures discussed to diffuse the situation. The pipeline, worth $6.6 billion, would transport natural gas from northeastern British Columbia to the Pacific Coast, posing a threat to essential goods and shipping vessels.

site_title: US considering new wave of China tech restrictions
summary: The US is considering new restrictions on exports of cutting-edge technology to China, including a potential ban on the sale of jet engines to China's C919 passenger jet and measures to broaden export controls related to tech giant Huawei. The move aims to limit China's technological progress and contain national security threats, but faces debate within the administration. The restrictions could have long-term consequences for US export industries like aviation and semiconductors, and may not be implemented due to internal divisions.

images.alt_text: The Trump administration is considering new restrictions on exports of cutting-edge technology to China in a push aimed at limiting Chinese progress in developing its own passenger jets and clamping down further on tech giant Huawei's access to vital semiconductors, according to four people familiar with the discussions.

site_title: Coronavirus casts shadow on China's big screen ambitions
summary: China's coronavirus outbreak has cast a shadow on the country's big screen ambitions, with entertainment venues closed for nearly a month and blockbuster films postponed. The closures could have a devastating impact on China's film industry, which was expected to overtake the US as the biggest box office in the world this year. Sales at the box office have been decimated, with takings down by 87% on the first day of the new year, and film groups are only beginning to count the cost. The outbreak has also affected the global film industry, with streaming giants seeing a surge in popularity and US entertainment giants facing losses from closing their parks in China.

site_title: Virus outbreak in China threatens global antibiotics supply: European business group
summary: A coronavirus outbreak in China threatens the global antibiotics supply, according to European Union Chamber of Commerce president Joerg Wuttke. The industry's supply problems are due to the outbreak, surging inventories, and regulatory uncertainties. Companies in China are experiencing challenges with packaging material and face potential shortages. Wuttke warned that if the issues cannot be resolved soon, the world could face a shortage of antibiotics.

site_title: Budget 2020: No GST hike in 2021, but increase will take place by 2025
summary: Singapore's government will not raise the Goods and Services Tax (GST) in 2021, but will delay the increase to between 2022 and 2025, Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announced in his Budget speech. The decision comes amid a downgraded GDP growth forecast for 2020, which was reduced to -0.5 to 1.5%. The GST increase, initially planned for 2021-2025, will still be necessary by 2025 to fund the country's spending needs. The government will assess the timing carefully, providing sufficient lead time for Singaporeans.

site_title: China regulator says coronavirus impact on industries to show in Feb
summary: China's vice-chairman of the state assets regulator, Ren Hongbin, stated that the impact of the coronavirus outbreak on industries will be apparent in February. Over 95% of central government-controlled companies in key sectors such as oil refining, communication, and transport are currently operational. This suggests that the economic disruption caused by the virus is being gradually absorbed by the industries. However, the statement does not provide a clear timeline for when the full impact of the outbreak will be felt.

images.alt_text: The impact of the coronavirus outbreak on China's various industries will mainly show up in February, a vice-chairman of the country's state assets regulator said on Tuesday.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars swoon as economic costs of epidemic mount
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars fell 0.4% against the US dollar, reaching decade lows, amid concerns over the economic impact of the coronavirus. Apple's production warning and weaker demand in China from the outbreak spooked investors, leading to a decline in stocks and a rise in safe-haven bonds. The Reserve Bank of Australia kept interest rates steady at 0.75%, but analysts warned of a possible rate cut in June, citing a potential rise in unemployment and economic disruption.

site_title: Boustead Projects halts construction works after Seletar virus case
summary: Boustead Projects halted construction works at Seletar Aerospace Heights and a neighboring facility after a confirmed COVID-19 case was reported. The company has carried out cleaning and disinfection of both sites. There are five confirmed cases related to the cluster, with workers identified as cases 42, 47, 52, 56, and 69. The company had already implemented preventative measures prior to the detection of the cases, but further assessment and updates on the project's impact are pending.

site_title: India's poultry sales decline after coronavirus rumours linked to chickens
summary: India's poultry industry has lost 13 billion rupees in three weeks due to speculation on social media that chickens can spread coronavirus, leading to a 13% decline in sales and nearly halving prices. The industry's losses have affected small poultry farmers and soybean/corn producers, with prices falling up to 8% in the last three weeks. Authorities have issued statements assuring the safety of eating chicken, but sales have not fully recovered, with the industry expected to continue losing money.

site_title: Brazil's soybean crop 'exceptional' as harvesting progresses - AgRural
summary: Brazil's soybean crop is expected to reach a record 125.6 million tonnes for the 2019/2020 cycle, according to agribusiness consultancy AgRural. Over 21% of the planted area has been harvested, with yields forecasted to be higher in states such as Mato Grosso, Goiás, and São Paulo, making up for losses in Rio Grande do Sul due to dry weather. This would add over 10 million tonnes to last year's production, the world's largest exporter and producer.

site_title: Bushfire crisis affected 75% of Australians: survey
summary: A survey of 3,000 Australians found that 75% of the population, or nearly 18 million people, were affected by the 5-month bushfire crisis, with 14% directly impacted and 15 million having indirect exposure. The crisis resulted in over 30 deaths and thousands of destroyed homes. The survey also showed plummeting support for the government and coal projects, with 27% of respondents lacking confidence in the government and support for coal mines decreasing from 72% to 57%. Scientists attribute the fires to climate change, exacerbating drought and unfavourable weather conditions.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Tuesday, down 0.59 points or 0.04% to 1,536.53. The market saw 75.17 million lots traded worth RM25.45 million, with 103 gainers and 78 losers. The lower opening follows global market trends, including a decline in European stocks and US records edged down amid tariff threats.

site_title: Is coffee good for you?
summary: Moderate coffee consumption (3-5 cups, 400mg of caffeine) is associated with lower mortality rates and various health benefits, including a reduced risk of cardiovascular disease, Type 2 diabetes, Parkinson's disease, and liver conditions. Polyphenols in coffee, particularly chlorogenic acid, are believed to be the key to these benefits. However, coffee is not suitable for everyone, particularly expecting mothers, due to the unclear safety of caffeine during pregnancy. Preparation methods, such as brewing, can affect the amount of compounds in coffee, and some studies suggest that adding milk or sugar may not cancel out the benefits of moderate coffee consumption.

images.alt_text: We've come a long way from the cans of Folgers that filled our grandparents' cupboards, with our oat milk lattes, cold brews and Frappuccinos.

site_title: BHP warns coronavirus could impact demand
summary: BHP, the world's largest miner, warned that the novel coronavirus outbreak in China could impact demand for resources, particularly oil, copper, and steel, unless contained by the end of March. The company expects a decline in demand unless the epidemic is well contained. Despite this, BHP chief executive Mike Henry remains optimistic about the company's long-term outlook. The company posted a $4.8 billion profit for the six months to December 31, up from $3.7 billion in the same period in 2018.

site_title: Broker's take: RHB downgrades Valuetronics to 'neutral' on production delay due to Covid-19 outbreak
summary: RHB Research downgraded Valuetronics Holdings to 'neutral' due to production delays caused by the Covid-19 outbreak in China, with expected factory downtime of 1-1.5 months. The research team lowered its FY2020 forecast by 8% and target price to S$0.76. Valuetronics reported a 26.3% rise in bottom line for Q2 FY2020, but top-line dipped. The company aims to meet original shipment schedules despite the delays, but faces downside risks from foreign exchange, raw material price fluctuations, and escalating trade tensions.

site_title: Nissan CEO sees earnings, cashflow under pressure this business year
summary: Nissan CEO Makoto Uchida expects weak global car sales to pressure the company's earnings and cash flow through March, citing a 11-year low full-year profit forecast and lowest dividend outlook since 2011. The automaker's recent quarterly net loss was its first in nearly a decade, driven by dwindling car sales following the arrest of former chairman Carlos Ghosn in 2018. Nissan's earnings and cash flow are under pressure as the company struggles to recover from the corporate shake-up and weak global sales.

images.alt_text: Nissan Motor chief executive Makoto Uchida on Tuesday said he expects weak global car sales to keep the Japanese automaker's earnings and cashflow under pressure through the end of the financial year in March.

site_title: Australia: Techs drag shares lower as Apple outlook weighs; New Zealand at record high
summary: Australian shares fell 0.2% on Tuesday, weighed down by heavy losses in technology stocks after Apple Inc. flagged a revenue miss due to weakening demand and production in China from the coronavirus outbreak. The Australian tech sub-index declined 3.3% to its worst session in over four months. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index reached a record high of 11,938.31, rising 0.5%.

site_title: Hottest fossil fuel market catches a chill as gas prices drop
summary: The liquefied natural gas (LNG) market, once the hottest part of the energy industry, is cooling down due to a drop in prices. Major utilities such as Orsted, Iberdrola, Naturgy, and Vattenfall are exiting the business, citing volatility concerns. This shift drains momentum from the push to trade LNG, which has been driven by companies in the energy industry over the past decade. The drop in prices is attributed to various factors, including market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions, which have led to a decrease in investor confidence.

site_title: Virus travel ban keeps thousands of maids from Hong Kong jobs
summary: Thousands of migrant workers, mostly women from the Philippines, who work as maids and nannies in Hong Kong, are stuck in the Philippines due to the coronavirus travel ban. The ban, which affects Hong Kong, Macau, and mainland China, has left thousands of workers stranded, worried about losing their jobs and income. Many families in Hong Kong are struggling to manage childcare, with schools and community centers closed for at least four weeks. The Philippine government has offered financial assistance and temporary housing to affected workers, and is set to reconsider the travel ban in two weeks.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Tuesday's open, STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.3% to 3,202.26 at Tuesday's open, following muted regional activity. Banking stocks, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC Bank, opened lower. The US financial markets were closed for Presidents Day, while Europe saw shares hit a record high due to Italian banks and China's stimulus measures.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks fall at Tuesday's open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Tuesday, falling 0.69% to 27,766.50, following Apple's warning of a revenue miss due to the new coronavirus. Mainland China's Shanghai Composite Index also declined 0.1%. The decline was attributed to economic jitters sparked by the virus.

site_title: Bumitama Agri's Q4 profit up 26% on higher palm oil prices
summary: Bumitama Agri, an Indonesian palm oil producer, reported a 26.1% increase in net profit to 261.46 billion rupiah in Q4 2020, driven by higher palm oil prices. Revenue grew 4% to 2.29 trillion rupiah, with the average sales price of crude palm oil rising 18.1% to 7,156 rupiah per kilogram. The company's full-year net profit sank 37.4% to 686.31 billion rupiah, and directors recommended a final dividend, subject to shareholder approval.

site_title: Gojek buys US$30m stake in Indonesia taxi operator Blue Bird: sources
summary: Indonesia's on-demand services app Gojek acquired a 4.3% stake in local taxi operator Blue Bird for $30 million. The deal confirms a partnership between the companies, which already offers taxi reservations for Blue Bird's taxis on its app. The move aims to counter competition from Singapore-based Grab Holdings Inc. and expand Gojek's services into areas like food delivery and digital payments. The partnership is seen as a strategic move to strengthen Gojek's presence in the Indonesian market.

site_title: Hong Kong increases funds to tackle coronavirus outbreak to HK$28b
summary: Hong Kong's leader Carrie Lam announced an increase in funds to tackle the coronavirus outbreak to HK$28 billion, up from the previously pledged HK$25 billion, to ease the economic impact. The government will provide one-off payments to businesses and the Hospital Authority. The move aims to support the city's battered economy amidst the outbreak.

site_title: Strikes, protests in Greece over latest pension reform
summary: Greeks are protesting against a new pension reform, the third major overhaul in a decade, that aims to make the troubled pension system viable until 2070. The reform, set to be voted on Friday, includes measures to reduce penalties for working pensioners and contain pension increases. Protests are planned in Athens, including a 24-hour standstill of public transport and disruptions to ferry services. The move comes as Greece continues to recover from a decade-long debt crisis.

site_title: Hong Kong virtual bank with 6.8% deposits cools price war talk
summary: ZA Bank Ltd, one of Hong Kong's new virtual banks, has kicked off offering deposit rates of almost 7% despite initial interest from 20,000 people. The bank's CEO, Rockson Hsu, stated that the rate is reasonable for new funds and aims not to disrupt the market. ZA's initial offer is capped at HK$100,000 and will pay rates in line with the market. The bank has no plans to raise capital and will accept 2,000 initial customers, including 100 with the highest three-month rate.

site_title: China's coronavirus death toll passes 1,800: government
summary: China's coronavirus death toll surpassed 1,800 after 93 more people died in Hubei province, with over 72,300 affected nationwide. The province reported 1,807 new cases, a smaller increase than Monday. Outside Hubei, new cases have been slowing, but the World Health Organization warned that trends can change as new populations are affected.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, Genting, Singtel, StarHub, Bumitama Agri, Boustead Projects
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) announced a management shuffle, promoting potential frontrunners for the top job. Genting Singapore backed out of a bid for an integrated resort licence in Osaka, Japan. Singtel shares fell 0.9% after bidding for 5G network licences closed, while StarHub shares dropped 0.7%. Bumitama Agri's earnings rose 26.1% due to higher palm oil prices. Boustead Projects halted construction due to a confirmed Covid-19 case, and Eagle Hospitality Trust's fourth-quarter earnings were lower than forecast.

site_title: Japan to start trials using HIV treatment for coronavirus: Suga
summary: Japan is set to start trials using an HIV treatment for the coronavirus, according to Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga. The government is preparing to begin clinical trials using HIV medication on the novel coronavirus, although the approval process timeline is unclear.

site_title: DBS says second employee infected with Covid-19, works at satellite office
summary: DBS, a Singaporean bank, reports its second employee infected with Covid-19, a 35-year-old man who works at the Ngee Ann City office on Orchard Road. The employee, Case 77, is a first-degree contact of Case 50, a 62-year-old DBS employee who tested positive for the virus. The bank's satellite office has been deep cleaned, and affected employees are receiving support, including basic grocery packs and medical resources. DBS is monitoring the situation closely and prioritizing the health and well-being of its employees and customers.

site_title: France confirms first case of ruinous tomato virus
summary: France has confirmed its first case of the destructive Tomato Brown Rugose Fruit Virus (ToBRFV), also known as ToBRFV, which can lead to whole crops being wasted. The virus was first reported in 2014 in Israel and has since spread to Europe, America, and other countries. A farm in France's Finistere region has been isolated, and greenhouses with contaminated tomatoes will be destroyed due to the lack of a known treatment. This confirms the virus's spread to the EU's biggest tomato producers, including Spain and Italy.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 0.55% or 128.66 points to 23,394.58. The decline was attributed to concerns over the economic impact of the new virus outbreak from China.

site_title: 'Ghost ship' washes ashore in Ireland after Storm Dennis
summary: A 77-metre cargo ship, MV Alta, washed ashore in Ireland's south coast after drifting without a crew for over a year due to Storm Dennis. The ship, which was disabled in the mid-Atlantic in September 2018 en route from Greece to Haiti, ran aground on rocks outside the village of Ballycotton near Cork. The incident marks the end of the ship's months-long voyage, which was abandoned due to its disabled state. The Republic's coast guard has confirmed the incident.

site_title: Coronavirus could be knockout blow for Hong Kong's once-thriving tourism, retail sectors
summary: Hong Kong's tourism and retail sectors are severely impacted by the coronavirus, with tourist arrivals plummeting to under 3,000 a day in February and retail sales expected to post their steepest fall on record in January at around 30%. The city's economy has contracted for three consecutive quarters, and over 100 restaurants have closed. Business owners, including those in the hospitality and retail industries, fear a knockout blow to their livelihoods, with some considering leaving the city or taking drastic measures such as cutting staff or closing operations.

site_title: SIA makes changes to top posts; seen as grooming next-gen leaders
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) announced a management shuffle, promoting two airline veterans, Mak Swee Wah and Lee Lik Hsin, to executive vice-president (EVP) positions. Mak will oversee operations, while Lee will lead commercial and cargo divisions. Senior vice-president Tan Kai Ping will become EVP (finance and strategy), and Campbell Wilson will return to Scoot as CEO. The changes, effective April 1, aim at succession planning and strengthening the management team. Analysts see the moves as a step towards grooming potential future leaders, with CEO Goh Choon Phong expected to stay at least three more years.

site_title: Queen Elizabeth II's nephew in latest royal marriage split
summary: Queen Elizabeth II's nephew, David Armstrong-Jones, 58, is divorcing his wife, Serena, after 27 years of marriage. The couple, known as the Earl and Countess of Snowdon, have two children and have agreed to a divorce with mutual respect for their privacy. This follows a week of marital splits in the royal family, including Queen Elizabeth's grandson Peter Phillips and his wife Autumn, and Prince Harry and Meghan Markle's decision to step back from royal duties.

site_title: China asks recovered patients to donate plasma for virus treatment
summary: Chinese health officials are urging recovered patients to donate plasma to treat others critically ill from the coronavirus. Plasma from recovered patients contains antibodies that can help reduce the virus load in critically ill patients. Eleven patients in Wuhan received plasma infusions, with one already discharged and others recovering. The World Health Organization says exploring plasma as a treatment is important but notes the need for safety protocols. Clinical studies have shown that plasma infusions are safe and effective.

site_title: EHT posts Q4 DPS of 1.179 US cents, 24.4% below IPO forecast
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) posted a Q4 distribution per stapled security (DPS) of 1.179 US cents, 24.4% below its IPO forecast of 1.56 US cents. Revenue fell 13.1% to US$20.5 million, and net property income (NPI) declined 14.7% to US$14.7 million. Despite this, EHT's managers expressed optimism about incremental market share gains from recent capital expenditures. The company's portfolio remains relatively insulated from the COVID-19 pandemic, and a recent amendment to the master lease agreements may benefit stapled security holders.

site_title: Oil edges up as output cut hopes offset coronavirus concern
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday, with Brent crude up 27 cents to $57.59 a barrel, driven by expectations of potential production cuts from major producers and China's economic stimulus measures. The International Energy Agency predicted a 435,000 barrel-per-day decline in oil demand due to the coronavirus, but investors are optimistic about a supply response from Opec+. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries has an agreement to cut oil output by 1.7 million barrels per day until the end of March.

site_title: Americans arrive home from virus-infected cruise ship
summary: More than 300 Americans arrived back in the US from a cruise ship quarantined off Japan due to the new coronavirus, with 454 diagnosed cases reported. The US government has ordered a two-week quarantine period for all repatriated passengers. Concerns over global transmission and the virus's impact on the economy continue, with the WHO urging caution against "blanket measures" despite a decline in new cases outside China's epicentre region. The virus has infected over 70,500 in China, with 1,770 deaths, and has sparked panic buying, economic jitters, and the cancellation of high-profile events.

site_title: Australia's Coles posts flat half-year earnings hurt by underpayment costs
summary: Coles Group, Australia's second-largest grocery chain, reported near-flat half-year earnings of A$725 million, beating its range of A$710-730 million. The company attributed the earnings to a A$20 million cost provision for underpaid salaried employees and a 1.7% rise in net profit to A$498 million. Total sales revenue rose 3.3% to A$18.85 billion. Coles declared an interim dividend of 30 Australian cents per share, its first half-year dividend since it was spun off from Wesfarmers in 2018.

site_title: Cybersecurity should be a priority when building Smart Cities
summary: Civic leaders worldwide are building smart cities with automation and connectivity, but cybersecurity is a major concern. The UN projects 66% of South-east Asia's population will live in urban areas by 2050, and many cities are vulnerable to cyber threats due to IoT-connected devices with significant vulnerabilities. A single cyber attack can cause catastrophic events, putting citizens' lives at risk. To mitigate these risks, civic managers must prioritize cybersecurity, train staff to be "cyber aware," and invest in technology that provides detailed oversight of IT and OT networks.

site_title: Creating good job opportunities
summary: Singapore's Future Economy Council is exploring ways to improve healthcare and education services while keeping them accessible and affordable. Senior Minister of State Chee Hong Tat emphasizes the need for job redesign, career progression opportunities, and training to create good job opportunities for workers. Technology can aid in efficiency, such as telemedicine and digital student records, but the human touch remains crucial in industries like healthcare and education. The government is working with private sector partners to develop innovative models and services, and Singapore's strong reputation in both sectors can help firms expand abroad.

site_title: China's home-price growth near two-year low as virus spreads
summary: China's new home prices grew at their weakest pace in nearly two years in January, rising 0.2% from the previous month, marking a 6.3% year-on-year increase, an 18-month low. The slowdown is attributed to the spread of the coronavirus, which has brought the property market to a standstill, with home sales plummeting and developers offering discounts. Analysts expect widespread price-cutting in the coming months, with some speculating that local governments and banks may relax restrictions on buyers and developers to stimulate the market.

site_title: US furnishings store Pier 1 files for bankruptcy
summary: US furnishings store Pier 1 filed for bankruptcy, citing years of weakening sales and a struggle to establish itself online. The Texas-based company plans to sell the business after closing 450 stores and cutting costs. A commitment of $256 million in financing from Bank of America and others has been secured. The remaining stores and website will remain open for business as the company seeks a buyer.

site_title: Brexit negotiator says Britain will make own rules
summary: Britain's chief Brexit negotiator, David Frost, stated that the country will set its own rules for commerce and state aid, even if it means giving up privileged access to the EU single market. This contradicts EU demands for supervision on "level playing field" issues. Frost emphasized that Britain wants a free trade deal similar to the Canada-EU CETA agreement, which removes tariffs but binds Canada to follow EU legislation. Britain will trade under WTO rules if a deal cannot be reached by the end of the year.

site_title: UK government adviser quits over race comments
summary: UK government adviser Andrew Sabisky resigned after online comments resurfaced, linking intellect to race and suggesting eugenics policies. Sabisky previously stated that black Americans had lower average intelligence and advocated for forced contraception to prevent unplanned pregnancies. He claimed he was stepping down due to a "giant character assassination" and not wanting to be a distraction. The main opposition Labour Party called for his sacking, and Downing Street refused to comment on whether Prime Minister Boris Johnson supported Sabisky's views.

site_title: Unit business cost rising for services; easing for manufacturing
summary: Unit business costs rose 5.2% for services in the first three quarters of 2020, contrasting with a 3% decline for manufacturing. The divergence is attributed to different unit labour cost trends, with manufacturing experiencing productivity gains and services seeing remuneration growth outpacing labour productivity. The overall unit business cost (UBC) is expected to continue rising in 2020, driven by stable wage growth and easing labour productivity, while other cost components remain stable.

site_title: Thai economy grows at weakest pace in 5 years
summary: Thailand's economy grew at its weakest pace in five years in 2019, expanding 2.4% as exports and public investments slowed. The slowdown was attributed to the Sino-US trade war, soft domestic demand, and drought. Tourism remained a bright spot. Analysts expect the Bank of Thailand to cut rates further to bolster growth this year, with some predicting a contraction in the first quarter before recovery in the second quarter. The central bank's policy rate has been at record lows since its last cut.

site_title: Victoria Beckham's gentle rebellion
summary: Victoria Beckham showcased her autumn/winter 2020/21 collection at London Fashion Week, embracing a "gentle rebellion" that honors tradition while challenging convention. The collection featured fluid black dresses and bold accessories, with the designer stating her goal was to "stay true to ourselves and our woman, but still surprising her." Beckham's show marked her return to London Fashion Week after a decade in New York, and she was joined by her family in the front row, including husband David and daughter Harper. The collection's message of subtle rebellion resonated with the audience.

site_title: China Evergrande gives 25% discount off its properties
summary: China Evergrande, the country's third-largest developer, is offering a 25% discount on its properties for sale from February 18 to 29, and a 22% discount for its China properties, as part of "routine marketing" amid the coronavirus outbreak. The move aims to boost sales and counteract the impact of the epidemic on the property market. Evergrande has sold nearly 50,000 properties online since its online sales began three days ago. Experts predict the outbreak could lead to a significant decline in property investment and economic growth.

site_title: EU to unveil plans challenging US, China tech might
summary: The European Union plans to unveil a strategy to challenge US and Chinese tech dominance, focusing on fundamental EU rights such as strict privacy and non-discrimination rules. EU tech czar Margrethe Vestager aims to reassure Europeans that the bloc can compete on its own terms. The plan includes new AI rules, gate-keeping legislation, carbon-neutral data centers, and incentives for data sharing to boost innovation. The EU will start a 12-week consultation and propose legislation by the end of the year, aiming to set an example for ethical AI development.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Mark Powell and his cycle of Tinder dates
summary: Mark Powell, a Singaporean, shared his experience on a podcast about his cycle of Tinder dates. He discussed how he went on multiple dates, but none of them led to a serious relationship. Powell revealed that he had been on over 100 Tinder dates, with most of them being superficial and not leading to anything meaningful. He concluded that Tinder can be a platform for socializing, but it's not a reliable way to find a serious partner.

site_title: Local startup Whizpace's IoT solution picked for Microsoft platform
summary: Singapore-based startup Whizpace's IoT solution has been certified by Microsoft and inducted into the Microsoft Azure Certified for Internet of Things (IoT) programme. The certification reduces time-to-market for customers adopting its solution, allowing them to quickly select and connect compatible devices and platforms. Whizpace's solution repurposes unused TV white space to transport data for IoT applications, offering a cost-effective and efficient alternative to traditional Wi-Fi. This certification is the result of Whizpace's participation in the Microsoft ScaleUp programme, which provided access to technology, mentorship, and support.

site_title: US firms in China say Covid-19 outbreak has hit global operations: survey
summary: Nearly half of US companies in China report a global operations impact due to the coronavirus epidemic, citing business shutdowns and staff shortages. 78% of respondents lack sufficient staff to resume full production, and 48% say plant shutdowns have already impacted global supply chains, with nearly all expecting an impact within the next month.

site_title: Cruise passengers scatter, take Cambodia bus tours despite virus fears
summary: A US cruise liner, the Westerdam, docked in Cambodia despite health concerns, allowing passengers to disembark and take bus tours of Phnom Penh. One passenger later tested positive for COVID-19, prompting fears that others may have been infected. Cambodia prioritized tourism over health risks, despite the ship being barred from other ports due to virus fears. The move has raised concerns about the spread of the virus globally, with the US and other countries imposing travel restrictions.

images.alt_text: A scramble intensified on Monday to trace passengers from a US cruise liner allowed to disembark in Cambodia despite at least one traveller later being diagnosed with the deadly coronavirus.

site_title: Euro struggles near 3-year lows on economic worries
summary: The euro struggled near three-year lows on Monday due to economic worries, particularly in Germany, where data showed weakened growth. Investors also looked to Chinese efforts to limit the damage from the Covid-19 outbreak, which calmed markets and boosted the yuan and Australian dollar. The euro traded at US$1.0845, its weakest since mid-2017, while the yen traded down 0.1% at 109.84 yen per dollar. Market players expect the US to maintain stronger growth, despite mixed data.

site_title: Europe: China measures, Italian banks lift shares to record close
summary: European shares hit a record high close on Monday, driven by a rally in Italian banks and China's stimulus measures to limit the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index rose 0.3% despite US holiday dulling market activity. Italian bank UBI Banca jumped 5.5% after aiming to nearly double net profit, while China's interest rate cut lifted investor spirits. Despite economists cutting growth forecasts due to the coronavirus, China's stimulus efforts kept markets upbeat, with automobile stocks leading the gains.

site_title: Czech tycoon sees Warsaw real estate as next big thing
summary: Czech tycoon Radovan Vitek's CPI Property Group SA is betting big on Warsaw's booming real estate market, purchasing five buildings and a stake in Globalworth Real Estate Investments Ltd. The company aims to become number one in Warsaw, driven by the city's high returns and growth in the European Union's eastern flank. CPI is expanding its presence in the city, seeking to dilute its retail space and improve its credit ratings, despite facing legal challenges. The company expects its assets to reach over $15 billion.

site_title: Creditors fear illiquid equity in new honestbee entity
summary: Honestbee's creditors are concerned about the liquidity of the new entity, which could leave them in a worse situation if the company fails. The startup has delayed the last tranche of salary repayment to ex-employees and is re-evaluating its habitat supermarket's reopening date amid the COVID-19 outbreak. Honestbee has proposed repaying creditors 3 cents on the dollar in cash and shares, but many are anxious about the value of their shares if the new entity faces similar distress. The company is seeking investors to monetize the shares, but a clear timeline is uncertain.

site_title: UK mansion tax could be Conservative winner
summary: The UK Conservative Party is considering a mansion tax, a move that has sparked surprise and outrage in the conservative press. However, reports suggest that Prime Minister Boris Johnson has shelved the plan. The idea was seen as a potential point of friction that may have contributed to Sajid Javid's recent resignation as Chancellor of the Exchequer.

site_title: Amazon boss Bezos launches US$10b fund to combat climate change
summary: Jeff Bezos, founder and CEO of Amazon, announced a $10 billion fund to combat climate change, dubbed the Bezos Earth Fund. The fund will support projects aimed at preserving and protecting the natural world, with grants to be issued this summer. Bezos stated that climate change is the biggest threat to the planet and expressed his desire to work alongside others to address the issue. This move comes after Amazon pledged to become carbon neutral by 2040 and ordered 100,000 electric delivery trucks.

site_title: PBOC cuts interest rate for one-year loans to support banks
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China, cut the interest rate on one-year loans to 3.15% from 3.25%, the lowest since 2017, to support banks and cushion the economy from the virus epidemic. A 200 billion yuan injection was provided via medium-term loans and 7-day reverse repurchase agreements, totaling 700 billion yuan. Analysts expect additional funding in March, and the rate reduction may influence the loan prime rate.

site_title: Prague seeks to rein in Airbnb to avoid ghost city scenario
summary: Prague is pushing to regulate short-term rentals through legislative changes, aiming to counter the negative effects of platforms like Airbnb on the housing market. The city has approved a plan allowing local authorities to restrict short leases, improve tax collection, and force platforms to share user information. Prague has battled a housing crisis and complaints from citizens about noise, damage, and rising rents. Airbnb disputes the claim that its system overloads the housing market, but the company is willing to work with the city to find a common solution.

site_title: Fast-food companies in China step up 'contactless' pick-up, delivery services amid coronavirus outbreak
summary: Fast-food companies in China, including McDonald's and Starbucks, are stepping up "contactless" pickup and delivery services amid the coronavirus outbreak. To minimize human contact, companies are using remote ordering, sealed meals, and frequent hand washing among employees. Delivery drivers are also being screened for body temperature and required to disinfect their bags and wash hands frequently. The measures aim to keep workers and customers safe while continuing to sell prepared food, with some companies experiencing a surge in demand for delivery services.

site_title: Next recession may see merger of fiscal and monetary policy
summary: Advanced economies are likely to grow near trend rates in 2020, reducing recession risks. However, economists worry that the next recession will expose problems with monetary policy, which is now severely circumscribed. The concept of "helicopter money" may be less effective due to its similarity to fiscal policy, and policymakers are questioning how to co-operate internationally and domestically to produce a better policy response. A merging of fiscal and monetary policy is possible, with the central bank or treasury leading the design of an effective policy response.

site_title: Analysts cut earnings forecasts for ComfortDelGro
summary: Analysts have cut ComfortDelGro's earnings forecast for FY2020 by 12% to S$271 million due to the Covid-19 outbreak's impact and weak taxi earnings. This is also reflected in a dropped proposed final dividend for FY2019, a disappointment for investors. The transport operator faces headwinds for the year ahead.

site_title: Genting Singapore ditches bid for Osaka casino
summary: Genting Singapore has unexpectedly withdrawn its bid for an integrated resort licence in Osaka, Japan, despite shareholders' approval for an investment of up to $10 billion. The company will instead focus on Yokohama, continuing to engage in the city's Request-for-Concept process. Genting cited no specific reasons for the decision, but analysts speculate that the tight timeline for the Osaka project, coinciding with the World Expo in 2025, may have contributed to the change of heart.

site_title: Covid-19: Under new notice, China returnees cannot leave home for 14 days
summary: Singapore has introduced a new "Stay-Home Notice" for residents and long-term pass holders returning from mainland China, requiring them to remain at home for 14 days. This replaces the current Leave of Absence (LOA) scheme, with penalties for non-compliance. The move comes as Singapore struggles with 75 confirmed cases of Covid-19, with 53 locally transmitted. The government has assured strict compliance and has already begun recovering from the economic impact of the outbreak.

site_title: Bernie is leading, but it's making his party unhappy
summary: Bernie Sanders is leading the Democratic presidential race, despite being unpopular with the party establishment. He is winning in much the same way that Donald Trump won the Republican primary in 2016. Sanders' popularity is largely among young, left-leaning voters, but he struggles to win over African American Democrats and older, white blue-collar workers. The Democratic primaries use a proportional voting system, allowing other candidates to accumulate delegates and potentially sabotage Sanders' nomination. Former VP Joe Biden and billionaire Mike Bloomberg are also in the running, with Bloomberg expected to enter the race soon.

site_title: Pricier property markets in Australia most sensitive to rates, says RBA report
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has found that expensive property markets in Australia are most sensitive to interest rate changes, according to a research paper. The RBA's monetary policy adjustments have the greatest impact on areas with high land costs, high household debt, and investor concentration. Low interest rates can temporarily exacerbate housing wealth inequality, while higher rates do the opposite. This suggests that the RBA's actions can influence housing prices and contribute to economic growth.

site_title: What made Genting Singapore forgo its Osaka IR bid at the eleventh hour?
summary: Genting Singapore has abandoned its bid to build an integrated casino complex in Osaka, Japan, after a shareholder vote in favor of the investment opportunity was narrowly outweighed by concerns. The company, which had previously announced plans to pursue both Osaka and Yokohama, now plans to focus on the Yokohama bid, citing strong market sentiment and a robust cash position. Genting's decision comes despite a consortium led by MGM Resorts International having submitted a request for proposal for the Osaka IR concession, suggesting that other contenders may also have dropped out of the race.

site_title: Virus' impact on new home sales expected to be short-term; demand could pick up in H2
summary: Singapore's private home sales surged in January, with 618 units sold, a 14.9% increase from the previous month and a 41.4% rise from January 2019. Despite concerns over the Covid-19 outbreak's impact on the economy, property consultants expect a short-term moderation in sales volume, but a resurgence in buying activity from pent-up demand when the threat abates. Developers are cautious, with some delaying launches, but prices are not expected to be immediately negatively affected. Experts predict a potential surge in transactions in the second half of 2020.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Singapore cuts 2020 growth forecast amid virus outbreak
summary: Singapore's official 2020 growth forecast has been downgraded to -0.5 to 1.5% due to the novel coronavirus outbreak, with a contraction possible if the outbreak is more severe than anticipated. Economists expect further monetary easing if growth prospects deteriorate, citing a V-shape recovery in the past for SARS and the current situation. Despite a gloomy outlook, economists believe Singapore may experience slow growth rather than a recession, with government support measures expected to cushion the blow.

images.alt_text: Sharon See

site_title: Local SME to mass-produce Sars-CoV-2 diagnostic test kits
summary: MiRXES, a Singaporean medtech firm, will mass-produce locally-developed diagnostic test kits for SARS-CoV-2, meeting high demand both domestically and internationally. The test kit, developed by A*Star and Tan Tock Seng Hospital, uses the polymerase chain reaction (PCR) method and has received provisional authorisation from the Health Sciences Authority. MiRXES, which currently produces 100,000 tests a week, will ramp up capacity to 250,000 a week, enabling the local production of 10,000 tests sent to China and 5,000 to local public hospitals.

images.alt_text: Dr Sidney Yee, CEO of Diagnostics Development Hub (left), and Dr Zhou Lihan, CEO and co-founder of MiRXES, with the SARS-CoV-2 diagnostic test kit developed by A*Star.

site_title: Asking prices for UK homes jump to near record high
summary: Asking prices for UK homes rose to a near record high in February, increasing 0.8% to an average of £309,399, according to Rightmove. The increase was driven by Prime Minister Boris Johnson's Brexit breakthrough, lifting confidence in the market. Visits to the website also jumped to a record, with buyer activity reviving after three and a half years of Brexit uncertainty. Experts note that while the housing market remains supported by low interest rates and a shortage of homes, a trade deal with the EU must be completed by the end of the year.

site_title: Growth of green financing as China takes the lead
summary: China is taking the lead in green financing, with the country issuing over $42.8 billion in green bonds in 2018. The UN's Emissions Gap report warns that current initiatives are not enough to meet the 1.5-2 degree Celsius temperature goal, requiring significant financing of up to $3.6 trillion per year. China has established a thriving green bond market and is relying on private sector investment to achieve its sustainability goals, with an estimated $1 trillion in environmental opportunities. The country's growth in green finance is expected to drive demand for green technologies and attract investors looking for sustainable investments.

site_title: STI dips ahead of Singapore Budget reading
summary: The Singapore Straits Times Index (STI) dipped 0.2% to 3,213 points on Monday ahead of the country's budget reading, amid concerns over the ongoing COVID-19 outbreak and its economic impact. The index trended down throughout the session, with the blue-chip index having 18 of its 30 components close in the red. Investors remained cautious, with benchmark indexes in other Asia-Pacific countries also ending lower, while China and Hong Kong were higher due to expected government stimulus efforts.

site_title: No surprises behind move to end Philippines-US military pact
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has ended the Visiting Forces Agreement (VFA) with the US, which was criticized for allowing US troops to operate with impunity in the country. The move has sparked warnings about the potential impact on the military balance in the South China Sea, as the US Navy may struggle to conduct Freedom of Navigation Operations without a foothold in the Philippines. The decision was long overdue, as Duterte had been publicly opposed to the agreement since 2016, citing concerns about sovereignty and extraterritoriality.
