site_title: Japan on brink of recession as economy contracts, virus heightens risk
summary: Japan's economy shrank 6.3% in the October-December quarter, the first decline in five quarters, due to a sales tax hike and the novel coronavirus outbreak. This contraction raises the risk of a recession, with analysts predicting another drop in the first quarter. The epidemic's impact on inbound tourism, exports, and domestic consumption is expected to worsen the economic situation, with the Bank of Japan considering additional easing measures if necessary.

site_title: US financial markets closed on Monday in observance of Presidents Day
summary: US financial markets closed on Presidents Day, observing the holiday. On the economic front, stocks in Europe declined due to bank and healthcare sector downturns, with US-EU tariffs remaining a focus. In the US, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite ongoing tariff threats.

site_title: Facebook warns of risks to innovation, freedom of expression ahead of EU rules
summary: Facebook has warned the European Union that new rules aimed at regulating US tech giants and Chinese companies could stifle innovation and freedom of expression. The social media giant, in a white paper, expressed concerns about the possibility of holding internet companies responsible for hate speech and other illegal content. Facebook proposed new frameworks that should be proportionate and necessary. The EU is set to announce proposals on Wednesday, which will include rules to govern artificial intelligence and challenge the dominance of Facebook, Google, and Amazon.

site_title: Trax acquires Paris-based startup Qopius
summary: TRAX, a computer vision tech firm backed by GIC, has acquired Paris-based startup Qopius for an undisclosed amount. Qopius' platform helps European retailers monitor inventory and streamline operations using computer vision and retail data integration. The acquisition strengthens TRAX's global footprint, with existing customers including Carrefour, Casino, and MediaMarktSaturn Retail Group. This deal marks the latest in TRAX's string of acquisitions, as the unicorn expands its presence in the European market.

site_title: Construction, infocomm to drive 2020 growth amid Covid-19 virus impact
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to grow in 2020 despite the Covid-19 outbreak, driven by sectors such as construction and information and communications. Construction is projected to post steady growth, while information and communications is expected to be resilient with sustained demand for IT solutions. The government has announced a support package, including wage support, tax rebates, and rental waivers, to help mitigate the impact of the virus on the economy. However, manufacturing growth is expected to be delayed due to the outbreak's impact on supply chains and final demand markets, with some economists predicting a manufacturing recovery by the middle of the year.

site_title: Indonesian authorities call for calm after radiation found at housing complex near Jakarta
summary: Indonesian authorities have called for calm after radioactive contamination was found in a housing complex near Jakarta. A patch of land in Serpong was contaminated with Caesium-137, causing alarm among locals. Radiation levels were initially 680 microSv per hour, but have since fallen to 20-30 microSv per hour after a decontamination process. Authorities plan to investigate the source of the contamination, with possible industrial use or improper disposal of waste suspected.

site_title: OCBC sends food and drinks to show appreciation to healthcare workers
summary: OCBC Bank is sending 20,000 bottles of bird's nest drinks, 14,000 cups of bubble tea, and over 45,000 packets of snacks to healthcare workers at Tan Tock Seng Hospital and the National Centre for Infectious Diseases in Singapore as a gesture of appreciation for their hard work during the Covid-19 outbreak. The bank, in collaboration with partners, has raised S$140,000 and delivered the items over two weeks, with a goal to brighten the day of hospital staff. The initiative is part of OCBC's #OCBCCares campaign.

site_title: Trendlines, Agriline to invest US$6.1m in portfolio companies
summary: Agriline, an investment vehicle of Trendlines' controlling shareholder Vincent Tchenguiz, plans to invest US$6.1 million in seven Trendlines' portfolio companies. The investments include US$5 million in seven companies and US$1.1 million in six companies, with some transactions in the form of share-purchase agreements and others as Simple Agreement for Future Equity (SAFE) transactions. The transactions are contingent on the execution of definitive agreements and necessary approvals from the portfolio companies' boards of directors.

site_title: Virus outbreak derails Singapore exporters' hopes of recovery
summary: Singapore's exporters, who had been expected to recover from a 2019 downturn, are facing a prolonged period of decline due to the COVID-19 outbreak. The country's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) outlook has been cut to a range of -0.5% to 1.5% growth, down a half-point from an earlier projection. The electronics sector, a key contributor to Singapore's exports, is expected to be particularly affected, with some analysts predicting a modest increase in exports. The outbreak's impact on global supply chains and energy demand is also expected to weigh on the economy.

site_title: Neon streetwear goes sustainable for Tommy Hilfiger's London show
summary: Tommy Hilfiger's London show featured a sustainable neon streetwear collection in collaboration with Lewis Hamilton and H E R. The unisex designs, including high-topped trainers and glowing yellow laces, were showcased at the Tate Modern gallery, emphasizing environmental sustainability. Hilfiger aims to become a more sustainable company, and Hamilton hopes to inspire other luxury brands to follow suit, creating a "ripple effect" in the fashion industry. The "see now, buy now" event made the outfits available for immediate purchase.

site_title: Scotch whisky facing £100m losses on US tariffs: industry body
summary: Scotland's whisky industry is facing £100 million in losses due to a 25% tariff on single malt Scotch imports into the US, which began in October. The tariff, imposed in retaliation for EU subsidies to Airbus, is hitting small distilleries hard, with exports already seeing a significant drop. Industry leaders are urging the EU, US, and UK to resolve the trade dispute to restore tariff-free trade. The Scotch Whisky Association is seeking to mitigate losses by cutting excise duties on spirits in the upcoming UK budget.

images.alt_text: Scotland's whisky industry is facing a £100 million (S$180.7 million) fall in exports as a 25-per cent tariff on imports of single malt Scotch into the United States starts to "hit hard", according to an industry body.

site_title: JEP unit reaches settlement with Korea-domiciled plaintiff YG-1 Co
summary: JEP Holdings' unit JEP Industrades has reached a settlement agreement with Korea-domiciled plaintiff YG-1 Co over claims of outstanding payables for 2016 shipments, valued at US$219,284.25. The settlement has no impact on JEP's financial position, and no admission of liability is made. YG-1 Co has withdrawn its claims without an order as to costs, and the High Court of Singapore has accepted the discontinuance.

site_title: 1-year-old boy evacuated from Wuhan on Feb 9 among 2 new coronavirus cases in S'pore
summary: Singapore reported two new coronavirus cases, bringing the total to 77, on February 17, 2020. A 1-year-old boy, evacuated from Wuhan on February 9, tested positive for the virus after showing no symptoms upon departure. He is currently in stable condition at KK Women's and Children's Hospital. The other new case is a 35-year-old Singaporean man with no recent travel history to China, who is being treated at the National Centre for Infectious Diseases.

site_title: Changing hands
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary:

Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook and global tensions. European stocks fell due to bank and healthcare sector concerns, while US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss. London's Heathrow airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. In other news, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case related to 285 trillion rupiah. US President Trump also launched a fresh tariff salvo on Canada, affecting global markets.

site_title: Thai army to transfer control of land after mass shooting
summary: Thailand's army agreed to transfer management control of 160,000 hectares of commercial land to the finance ministry, following a mass shooting incident that killed 29 people and exposed the army's involvement in business activities. The transfer aims to reform the army's business practices and bring transparency to its operations, which generate an annual income of nearly $44.5 million. The move will see the businesses' revenues go directly to the state, with some earnings going towards army personnel welfare. The army will hand over projects to the Treasury Department for consideration.

site_title: StanChart opens international banking, priority private centre in Singapore
summary: Standard Chartered Bank has opened its first international banking and priority private centre in Singapore at Ngee Ann City. The centre caters to high-net-worth individuals with at least S$1.5 million in assets under management, offering bespoke solutions, wealth privileges, and exclusive access to a highly experienced relationship management team. The centre aims to provide a hub for international banking clients, with about one-third of StanChart's priority private clients also being international banking clients. The bank plans to double its relationship manager headcount to support the expected increase in international banking clients.

images.alt_text: The new centre will allow StanChart's affluent clients to catch up on their financial needs whenever they're in Singapore.

site_title: Macau casinos to resume operations from Feb 20 after suspension over virus fear
summary: Macau's casinos will resume operations on February 20 after a two-week suspension to curb the spread of the coronavirus. The suspension ended on February 19, with no new cases reported since February 4. Casino operators have been given 30 days to return to full business, but business is expected to be limited due to strict visitor controls and curtailed transport links. Nearly 30 hotels have been shuttered during the suspension, and it's unclear when non-gaming amenities will resume.

site_title: Extreme weather to overload urban power grids, study shows
summary: Scientists warn that extreme hot spells fueled by climate change could overload urban power grids, causing blackouts, as cities continue to grow. By 2050, over half of humanity is expected to live in cities, putting strain on existing fossil fuel-based infrastructure. To mitigate this, researchers suggest cities adopt renewable power sources and plan for frequent temperature swings. The growing use of air conditioning in urban areas will exacerbate the issue, making it crucial to develop more efficient solutions to meet increasing energy demands.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index falling 7.34 points to 1,537.12. The market saw 2.9 billion lots traded worth RM1.9 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 444 to 413. The decline comes amidst global market fluctuations, including US-EU trade tensions and recent stock performance in other regions.

site_title: Slump in global goods trade to deepen with coronavirus, WTO says
summary: The World Trade Organisation (WTO) predicts a slump in global goods trade will deepen due to coronavirus disruptions, alongside existing tariffs and uncertainty. The latest Goods Trade Barometer stands at 95.5, indicating weak trade growth in the coming months. The WTO notes that recent developments, including global health threats, may further dampen the slow start, with year-on-year trade growth potentially falling again in the first quarter of 2020. The barometer's reading suggests no indication of a sustained recovery, with trade growth expected to remain below medium-term trends.

site_title: Corporate experience valuable for the job: Lim Kee's next-gen leader
summary: Lim Kee Food Manufacturing's next-generation leader, Ang Khim Wee, credits his corporate experience for helping him become a humble and realistic leader. Having worked in government agency Spring Singapore, Ang developed essential skills, including product knowledge, operations optimization, and people engagement. He believes that these skills are crucial for his role and as a next-generation leader. Ang aims to spread Lim Kee's love for pau while ensuring its quality remains relevant in the fast-changing business landscape.

images.alt_text: Mr Ang says limited resources is a challenge for SMEs, but one way to overcome this is through partnership, through open innovation and working with like-minded partners with the objective of creating greater value for all stakeholders.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Banyan Tree to introduce its first property in the Bahamas, Illa Bimini, under a partnership with Island Developers, featuring eco-conscious luxury residences and overwater bungalows. Meanwhile, global oil prices rose over 2% as investors weigh market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. In business news, NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed, while Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for its £10b upgrade, and Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case.

site_title: Dubai's DP World to delist, return to full state ownership
summary: Dubai's DP World, a leading port operator, announced it will delist from the Nasdaq Dubai exchange after its parent company, Port and Free Zone World, acquired 19.55% of its listed shares. This move will result in DP World being fully owned by the state investment vehicle Dubai World. The delisting is part of the parent company's efforts to regain full control over its subsidiary.

site_title: Talkmed Q4 net profit rises 19%, declares S$0.013 per share dividend
summary: Talkmed Group reported a 19% increase in Q4 net profit to S$10.9 million, driven by higher patient visits. Revenue rose 16.6% to S$22.1 million. The company declared a final dividend of S$0.013 per share, up from S$0.01065 in the previous year. Full-year profit and revenue also increased, with earnings per share rising to 2.72 cents. Net asset value per share increased to 6.32 cents.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Trade and Industry downgraded its 2020 GDP growth forecast to between -0.5% and 1.5% due to the COVID-19 outbreak. Non-oil domestic exports are expected to range from a 0.5% drop to a 1.5% rise. The country also saw a 41.4% increase in private home sales in January, while insurers are offering free COVID-19 coverage. The Singapore Stock Index (STI) finished 0.2% lower.

site_title: 5G call for proposal closes with 3 bids received: IMDA
summary: The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) has closed the 5G call for proposal with three bids received from Singtel, TPG Telecom, and a joint submission from StarHub and M1. The regulator will evaluate the submissions and award spectrum to two network operators to deploy nationwide public 5G networks by mid-2020. The winners must cover at least half the island by end-2022 and lease network at a wholesale price to other mobile operators. Interested operators can also bid for localized 5G networks using millimetre-wave spectrum packages.

site_title: Money Hacks podcast: The basics of loyalty programmes (Ep 65)
summary: The Money Hacks podcast discusses loyalty programmes in the online brokerage industry. Adam Reynolds, CEO of Saxo Markets, explains that loyalty programmes can work for investors and that Saxo Rewards is one such programme. The programme allows investors to earn rewards points for trading with Saxo Markets. The podcast touches on the commonality of loyalty programmes in the industry, potential competitors, and strategies for maximizing rewards points. Investors can benefit from these programmes, but should consult a financial adviser before making any investment decisions.

site_title: Singapore shares dip 0.2% ahead of Budget 2020
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.2% to 3,213.00 on Monday, amid concerns over the economic impact of the COVID-19 outbreak and a downgrade of Singapore's economic forecast for 2020. However, financial markets are expecting significant deficit spending from the government to offset the slowdown. In contrast, China and Hong Kong rose as investors priced in more stimulus efforts to counter the pandemic's impact. Trading volume in Singapore was 1.61 billion securities, 36% higher than the 2019 daily average.

site_title: Virus turns Thai firm into world's top asset manager stock
summary: Thailand's Bangkok Commercial Asset Management Pcl (BAM) has become the world's top performer among asset management companies this year, with shares surging 74% due to the novel coronavirus outbreak's impact on the nation's economy. The firm has delivered the highest total return among companies with a market value of at least $1 billion. Analysts believe BAM's business model, which focuses on distressed assets, will benefit from the economic slowdown, with opportunities for buying assets at a cheaper cost. The firm's shares have nearly doubled since its listing in December.

site_title: China Everbright Water secures upgrading project for Suzhou plant
summary: China Everbright Water has secured an effluent upgrading project for the Jiangsu Suzhou Wuzhong Chengnan Waste Water Treatment Plant, investing 109 million yuan (S$21.7 million) under a Build-Operate-Transfer model. The concession period will expire concurrently with the plant's 150,000 cubic meter capacity. This project will upgrade the plant's waste water treatment capabilities.

site_title: Indian FM defends citizenship law as he promotes EU ties
summary: India's Foreign Minister Subrahmanyam Jaishankar defended his country's citizenship law and Kashmir crackdown as he promoted EU ties in Brussels. Jaishankar, the guest of honor, met with EU foreign ministers to renew relations and boost trade. The EU hopes to host a March summit with Prime Minister Narendra Modi, who would give Brussels a more "geopolitical role." Jaishankar's defense of the citizenship law came amid international criticism, but he emphasized the need for India's strategic ties with Europe. The EU Commission aims to strengthen its role in global affairs, including with India.

site_title: Malaysia urged to cut down on plastic packaging for cleaner seas
summary: Malaysia is urged to reduce plastic packaging to clean its seas. A WWF report found Malaysians are the largest consumers of plastic packaging, accounting for 27 million tonnes in 2016. The country, along with other Asia nations, contributes 60% of the estimated 8 million tonnes of plastic entering the world's oceans annually. The WWF calls for the government to limit single-use plastics and fund recycling efforts, working with companies to address the issue.

site_title: South Korea: Shares end flat as China's stimulus offsets economic damage worries
summary: South Korea's stock market closed flat on Monday, with the KOSPI down 1.42 points, or 0.06%, at 2,242.17. China's interest rate cut, aimed at calming economic concerns, offset worries about the coronavirus outbreak. The death toll in mainland China reached 1,770, and 2,048 new cases were reported. Foreigners sold US$194.07 million worth of shares, despite the KOSPI's 2.02% year-to-date gain.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets climb at open
summary: European stock markets rebounded at the start of trading on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 index gaining 0.3% to 7,428.50 points. Frankfurt's DAX 30 index and Paris CAC 40 also rose 0.2% to 13,767.72 and 6,079.85 points, respectively. This follows losses on Friday. The gains were driven by mining and healthcare stocks, with US-EU trade talks also in focus.

site_title: SIA unveils changes to senior management in succession-planning moves
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has made several senior management appointments as part of succession planning. Mak Swee Wah will assume EVP (operations) from April 1, overseeing cabin crew, customer services, and operations. Lee Lik Hsin will return to SIA as EVP (commercial) and Tan Kai Ping will be promoted to EVP (finance and strategy). The new appointments will report directly to CEO Goh Choon Phong, strengthening the management team and positioning the group for the future. Ng Chin Hwee will retire and join SIA Engineering Company as CEO on April 1.

site_title: Banyan Tree to debut overwater bungalows at its first Bahamas resort
summary: Banyan Tree Hotels & Resorts will debut its first property in the Bahamas, Illa Bimini, under a partnership with Island Developers. The 40-acre eco-conscious resort will feature 50 hotel keys, 54 luxury residences, and Maldives-style overwater bungalows. Located 48 nautical miles from Miami, the property will offer private terraces, plunge pools, and unique culinary and music experiences. Designed by world-renowned architect Chad Oppenheim, Illa Bimini aims to bring luxury to the Bahamas while taking an environmentally sensitive approach.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. European stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector concerns, while US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss. London's Heathrow airport considered increasing fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Meanwhile, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case.

site_title: F&B trade show postponed on Covid-19 fears after initial plans to go ahead
summary: The FHA-Food & Beverage trade show in Singapore has been postponed due to "global travel concerns" and the "spillover effects" of the Covid-19 outbreak on the food and beverage industry. The event, initially set to take place from March 31 to April 3, will now be held at a later date. ProWine Asia (Singapore) 2020, a co-organized event, has also been postponed. The decision was made in the best interests of attendees, partners, and staff, with the organizer working closely with government authorities and taking measures to support exhibitors and visitors.

site_title: Facing uptick in virus infections, Japan moves to limit public crowds
summary: Japan has limited public crowds in Tokyo to prevent the spread of the coronavirus, cancelling the emperor's birthday celebrations and closing the Tokyo Marathon to all but elite runners. The country is experiencing a widening outbreak, with over 400 infected cases, and a further spread could undermine growth and potentially push Japan into recession. The government has also ordered companies to limit gatherings and work from home, with major companies like NTT urging employees to do so.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks hit near 4-week high as China steps up support
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose to a near 4-week high on Monday, driven by China's policy stimulus to combat the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak. The Hang Seng index closed 0.5% higher at 27,959.60, erasing losses from the previous two weeks. China's Shanghai Composite index and CSI300 also rallied, marking a reversal of losses. The gains come as Beijing steps up support to cushion the economic blow from the outbreak.

images.alt_text: Flags of the Hong Kong Stock Exchange (C) and Hong Kong (R) are seen at Exchange Square. The Hang Seng index closed up 0.5 per cent at 27,959.60, after touching its highest level since Jan 22.

site_title: Nintendo is likely to suffer global switch shortages from virus
summary: Nintendo is likely to face global Switch shortages due to a production bottleneck caused by the coronavirus outbreak, affecting its supply chain. Component shortages in China are impacting output at a factory in Vietnam, where consoles are primarily built for the US and European markets. This may lead to a shortage of Switch units scheduled for arrival in April, affecting sales momentum of the console's popular first-party titles, including the upcoming Animal Crossing game.

site_title: PBOC cuts interest rate for one year loans to support banks
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China, cut the interest rate it charges for one-year loans to 3.15% from 3.25%, the lowest since 2017, to support banks amid the coronavirus outbreak. The move provided 200 billion yuan in medium-term loans and injected 100 billion yuan into the market through 7-day reverse repurchase agreements, totaling 700 billion yuan. Analysts expect additional funding in March, and the rate reduction is seen as a small step to calm financial markets and support companies.

images.alt_text: China's central bank provided medium-term funding to commercial lenders and cut the interest rate it charges for the money, a move widely anticipated by analysts to cushion the economy from the virus epidemic.

site_title: Fast-food companies in China step up 'contactless' pickup, delivery as coronavirus rages
summary: Fast-food companies in China, including McDonald's and Starbucks, are ramping up "contactless" pickup and delivery services to minimize human contact amid the coronavirus outbreak. Customers can order remotely and have meals sealed in bags for pickup without human contact, while delivery drivers wear ID cards and have their temperatures scanned. The measures aim to keep workers and customers safe as the outbreak continues to spread globally, infecting over 68,500 people and killing 1,665.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower as virus worries linger
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Monday, slipping 0.69% to 23,523.24 due to worries over the spread of the new coronavirus and the economy's worst quarterly contraction in over five years. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 164.35 points. The broader Topix index also declined 0.89% to 1,687.77. The economic concerns follow a previous decline in January.

site_title: Australia: Shares close lower as banks weigh
summary: Australian shares closed 0.1% lower on Monday, weighed down by losses in the country's leading four banks. Despite strong corporate earnings, investors were cautious about the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak. The benchmark S&P/ASX 200 index ended at 7,125.1, with Commonwealth Bank of Australia and National Australia Bank experiencing significant declines. However, a 4% rise in QBE Insurance and a 3.9% gain in Brambles Ltd helped limit losses.

site_title: Thai economic growth slips to 5-year low, rate cuts likely
summary: Thailand's economy contracted to its weakest pace in five years in 2019, driven by slowing exports and public investments. The central bank is expected to cut rates at record lows to boost growth amid the coronavirus epidemic. The trade-dependent economy has faced challenges from the Sino-US trade war, soft domestic demand, and drought, but tourism remained a bright spot. Analysts predict further rate cuts to bolster growth this year.

images.alt_text: Port of Bangkok. Thailand's economy grew at its weakest pace in five years in 2019 as exports and public investments slowed, adding pressure on the central bank to cut rates to shield Southeast Asia's second-largest economy from the coronavirus epidemic.

site_title: Alstom confirms talks underway to buy Bombardier Transportation
summary: Alstom, a French transport infrastructure company, confirmed talks are underway for a possible acquisition of Bombardier Transportation's train business, valued at US$7 billion. Discussions are ongoing, with no final decision made. The acquisition would give Alstom a significant boost in the global rail market, potentially expanding its presence and competitiveness.

site_title: Neon streetwear goes sustainable for Tommy Hilfiger's London show
summary: Tommy Hilfiger's London show featured a sustainable neon streetwear collection with high-topped trainers and glowing yellow laces, in collaboration with Lewis Hamilton and H E R. The unisex designs and formal Hilfiger clothes prioritized environmental sustainability, with a "see now, buy now" event allowing consumers to purchase the displayed outfits immediately. The show was part of Hilfiger's efforts to become more sustainable, with Hamilton hoping to create a ripple effect in the fashion industry to improve luxury brands' sustainability profiles.

site_title: Indonesia posts larger than expected Jan trade deficit
summary: Indonesia's trade gap widened to US$870 million in January, exceeding expectations. Exports fell 3.71% to US$13.41 billion, largely due to declining metals prices. This marked a significant reversal from the revised US$61.70 million deficit in December. The unexpected deficit was attributed to a forecasted 1.19% increase in exports instead of a decline.

site_title: Major Thai coffee brand vows to repay 200 debt-ridden farmers
summary: A major Thai coffee brand, Doi Chaang Coffee, has vowed to repay approximately 7 million baht (S$311,330) to 200 debt-ridden farmers who were left with spiraling debts after nearly three years of non-payment. The company, which claims to be a social enterprise, had used to pay its suppliers within four days but has struggled with declining sales due to the economic downturn. Labour rights experts warn that such debts can lead to debt bondage, a form of modern slavery, and put farmers at risk of being exploited.

site_title: Amazon, Flipkart seek rollback of new Indian tax on online sellers
summary: Amazon and Flipkart are urging India to reconsider a proposed 1% tax on third-party sellers on their platforms, citing concerns over increased compliance costs and reduced trading activity. The tax, part of a broader plan to boost tax revenues, could harm the country's fledgling e-commerce sector. Industry groups are pushing for a deferral of the tax's implementation, with some sellers arguing it will negatively impact their working capital and make the model "unviable".

site_title: Asia: Coronavirus jitters weigh on markets
summary: Asian markets were weighed down by concerns over the economic impact of the new coronavirus, with Japan's economy contracting for the first time in five years and Singapore cutting its growth forecast. The death toll in China rose to over 70,500, and investors remain cautious despite a slowdown in new infections. The World Health Organization warned it's impossible to predict the epidemic's direction, while China's central bank is expected to take action to counter the economic impact, potentially benefiting emerging markets.

site_title: Singapore developers sell 618 private homes excluding ECs in Jan, up 14.9% from Dec
summary: Singapore developers sold 618 private homes in January, a 14.9% increase from December and 41.4% higher than the same month last year. Including executive condominium units, the total sales reached 638 units, a 15.8% rise from December and 45.7% higher than January last year. The sales figures suggest a strong housing market in Singapore.

site_title: China approves imports of all US poultry, poultry products
summary: China has approved the import of all US poultry and poultry products, ending a 5-year ban due to avian influenza outbreaks. The move allows US companies like Aviagen and Cobb-Vantress to sell breeding stock and live birds to China, benefiting the US poultry industry. China's decision comes as the country ramps up poultry production to fill a meat shortage after a disease epidemic decimated its pig herd.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts lower forecasts on ComfortDelGro due to earnings headwinds
summary: Analysts have lowered their earnings forecasts for ComfortDelGro due to headwinds from the Covid-19 outbreak and weak taxi earnings. Research houses have trimmed their earnings outlook by 5.5-12.2% for the current financial year, citing the impact on the company's taxi business and potential for higher idle rates. Despite this, analysts believe ComfortDelGro's ability to generate strong free cash flow and healthy dividend yield will support share prices.

site_title: UK property asking prices rise again, close to new high: Rightmove
summary: UK property asking prices rose by 0.8% in February, reaching near-record highs, according to Rightmove. This marks a slower increase than the previous month but still indicates a return of seller confidence. The number of sales agreed also rose by 12.3% nationally and 26.4% in London. The housing market has shown signs of recovery since the December election, with other reports indicating a surge in house prices and sales.

site_title: General Motors to exit Australia, New Zealand in US$1.1b overhaul
summary: General Motors will exit Australia, New Zealand, and Thailand by year-end, taking a $1.1 billion charge to cover costs. The company will retire the Holden brand, withdraw the Chevrolet brand from Thailand, and sell its Rayong plant to China's Great Wall Motor Co. This move is part of GM's strategy to focus on new technologies like self-driving cars and electric vehicles, with CEO Mary Barra prioritizing global investments for future growth. GM has been downsizing since its bankruptcy in 2009, with previous exits from Europe and Russia.

site_title: ComfortDelGro appoints new chief digital officer
summary: ComfortDelGro appoints Siew Yim Cheng as its new group chief digital officer, overseeing digital transformation initiatives and leveraging technology to strengthen operations and improve customer service. The company aims to explore new areas such as AI and autonomous driving, requiring necessary skills and talent. This move follows ComfortDelGro's recruitment of over 20 C-suite executives in the last two years, bringing diverse skills in areas like finance, IT, and artificial intelligence.

images.alt_text: Before joining ComfortDelGro, Ms Siew was the global vice-president for the smart city domain at Envision Digital.

site_title: Victoria Beckham's 'gentle rebellion' at London Fashion Week
summary: Victoria Beckham made a statement at London Fashion Week with her "gentle rebellion" collection, blending tradition and convention. The designer aimed to "honour tradition but challenge convention" while staying true to her brand's codes. The sophisticated yet wearable collection featured a mix of surprising elements, showcasing Beckham's approach to subverting expectations without sacrificing elegance. This collection marked a clarion call for a more inclusive and thought-provoking approach to fashion.

site_title: UK digital bank Monzo plans to hire 500 and relaunch paid accounts
summary: UK digital bank Monzo plans to hire up to 500 people and relaunch paid accounts, aiming to reach 5.5 million users this year. The bank has burned through cash to fuel growth and has had no problems raising capital, valuing it at over $3.6 billion. Monzo's CEO Tom Blomfield expects the firm to be profitable within three to four years and plans to float in the same timeframe. The bank has learned from past mistakes, including the cancellation of a premium paid-for account, and aims to implement transparent and fair monetization strategies.

site_title: More Singapore insurers enhancing coverage with free Covid-19 protection
summary: Singaporean insurers are offering free Covid-19 insurance coverage to their customers, including diagnosis benefits, hospitalization coverage, and death benefits. DBS partnered with Chubb to offer a 30-day complimentary policy, while Manulife and AIA also provided additional coverage. NTUC Income extended its personal accident plans to include infectious disease cover, and HSBC Life Singapore offered complimentary benefits to its life insurance customers. Gojek, an e-commerce platform, also provided earnings protection coverage for private-hire drivers quarantined due to the virus. These measures aim to support customers and individuals affected by the pandemic.

site_title: Brokers' take: Maybank KE downgrades Far East H-Trust to 'hold' amid virus outbreak
summary: Maybank KE downgraded Far East Hospitality Trust's (Far East H-Trust) call to "hold" amid the Covid-19 outbreak, citing weaker income visibility and reduced demand for hospitality services in Singapore. The trust's distribution per stapled security fell 5% to 0.95 Singapore cent for the fourth quarter. Analysts prefer other hospitality trusts, such as CDL Hospitality Trusts and Frasers Hospitality Trust, due to their diversified portfolios.

site_title: Miners welcome South Africa's plans to open up power generation
summary: South Africa's President Cyril Ramaphosa announced plans to open up electricity generation to other players, effectively breaking Eskom's monopoly, in an effort to rapidly shore up electricity generation. The move has been welcomed by the mining industry, which has been clamoring for legislative changes to ease licensing for firms to produce their own electricity. The mining industry is expected to produce 1.5 gigawatts of electricity in the next 36 months, and companies will be able to sell excess power into the national grid.

images.alt_text: Large businesses facing difficulties securing retail contracts amid "unprecedented volatility" in the electricity market will be able to get 1-month fixed price plans for January 2022 under a temporary scheme launched by the Energy Market Authority (EMA).

site_title: Pricier property markets most sensitive to rates, RBA paper says
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has found that expensive property markets are most sensitive to interest rate changes, with low rates exacerbating housing wealth inequality. A research paper by RBA economists Calvin He and Gianni La Cava found that prices in areas with high incomes, indebted households, and investor concentration respond more to monetary policy. This has led to higher housing prices in Sydney and Melbourne, and the RBA's decision to cut interest rates has temporarily boosted the economy. However, the effects are expected to be temporary, with housing wealth inequality likely to decrease with higher interest rates.

site_title: Japanese manufacturers remain pessimistic as coronavirus fears grow
summary: Japanese manufacturers remain pessimistic due to growing coronavirus fears and uncertainty over the global economy. A Reuters poll found business confidence to remain weak over the next three months, with the virus affecting supply chains and Chinese shoppers in Japan. The virus has killed over 1,700 people in China, causing economic harm and contributing to weak business confidence.

site_title: Virus could spur buyout appetite for Chinese food
summary: A coronavirus outbreak in China may prompt private equity firms to invest in the country's dining sector, which has been hit hard by the virus. Yum China, McDonald's, and Haidilao have closed stores, with Yum China reporting a 40-50% decline in sales. Independent chains, such as Xibei, are more vulnerable due to weaker balance sheets. With ample cash, buyout funds may view these chains as attractive investment opportunities, particularly those looking to expand abroad.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.58 points or 0.04% to 1,543.88. The market saw a slight volume of 76.09 million lots worth RM26.49 million, with 141 gainers outpacing 50 losers.

site_title: Natas, SHA and STGS issue guidelines to protect tourists amid virus outbreak
summary: Singapore's National Association of Travel Agents, Hotel Association, and Society of Tourists Guides have issued guidelines to protect tourists amid the novel coronavirus outbreak. The guidelines include cleaning air-conditioning filters in coaches, rescheduling itineraries to avoid overcrowded areas, and separating tourists showing signs of the disease. Hoteliers are also going above and beyond to safeguard guests' well-being. The associations will continue to work closely with government agencies during this period, with the International Tourist Guide Day at Capitol Singapore scheduled for February 22.

site_title: Australia should ease travel ban on foreigners from China: ambassador
summary: Australia's Ambassador to China, Cheng Jingye, has urged the government to ease travel restrictions on foreign nationals from mainland China due to the steady number of cases in Australia. The current ban, implemented on Feb 1, has prevented non-citizens and permanent residents from entering the country directly from China. Cheng expressed hope that the Australian government will review the policy and consider relaxing the restrictions, citing the World Health Organization's recommendations. The ban is set to be reviewed on Feb 22.

site_title: Japan ready to take steps vs coronavirus impact on tourism: economy minister
summary: Japan's Economy Minister Yasutoshi Nishimura stated the government is prepared to take necessary steps against the impact of the coronavirus on the economy and tourism. This comes after the release of October-December GDP data, which showed a moderate recovery. Nishimura emphasized the need for vigilance against the virus's effect on domestic and overseas economies.

site_title: Oil prices slip ahead of data pointers on impact of coronavirus on demand
summary: Oil prices slipped ahead of data on the impact of the coronavirus on demand. Brent crude fell 33 cents to US$56.99 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude dropped 13 cents to US$51.92 a barrel. The International Energy Agency (IEA) predicted a 435,000-barrel-per-day decline in oil demand in the first quarter due to the virus. Analysts await data on manufacturing PMIs for February, which may indicate the virus's effect on global supply chains. Opec+ is expected to approve deeper production cuts to support oil prices.

site_title: Australia: Shares halt four-session winning streak; New Zealand flat
summary: Australian shares fell 0.2% on Monday, snapping a four-session winning streak, as investors booked profits from the previous week's rally in the banking sector. The S&P/ASX 200 index was down 0.2% at 7,115.6, with financial sub-index falling 0.8% after a 3.6% rise last week. China's coronavirus outbreak continued to weigh on markets, with over 5,000 new cases reported. New Zealand's benchmark index was flat after falling for two consecutive sessions.

site_title: South-east Asia feels the burn as coronavirus keeps Chinese tourists at home
summary: South-east Asia is experiencing significant losses due to the collapse of Chinese tourism following the coronavirus outbreak. Billions of dollars in revenue are at stake as Chinese travelers are restricted at home and abroad. In Thailand, tourism arrivals from China have plummeted by 90% in February, with some businesses facing debt and job losses. The Thai government has offered visa on arrival for Chinese tourists, despite having one of the highest numbers of confirmed infections. Cambodian tourism is also taking a hit, with ticket sales at the Angkor temple complex and tourist takings in Sihanoukville decreasing significantly.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks fall at Monday's open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Monday, February 17, 2020, due to concerns over the death toll from China's new coronavirus and potential economic fallout. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.18% to 27,766.71, while mainland China's Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.27%.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon down 0.16% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) resumed trading on Monday, down 0.16% at 3,214.94, amid concerns over the COVID-19 outbreak and its economic impact. The Ministry of Trade and Industry downgraded Singapore's 2020 growth forecast to between -0.5% and 1.5%. Non-oil domestic exports (NODX) for January dropped 3.3%, while the official full-year NODX forecast was also cut. The STI's bluechip index saw 19 of 30 counters in the red, with Thai Beverage being the top gainer.

site_title: Singapore shares dip after GDP, NODX forecasts slashed; STI falls 0.18% at open
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.18% at Monday's open following the downgrade of Singapore's official growth forecast for 2020 and a lower export forecast. The Straits Times Index dropped 5.67 points to 3,214.36, with losers outnumbering gainers 62 to 59. Banking stocks started the morning trade in the red, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC Bank falling 0.4%, 0.9%, and 0.3%, respectively. The Ministry of Trade and Industry lowered its GDP growth forecast to 0.5% and cut its export forecasts due to the novel coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: China's Evergrande to offer discount for all properties on sale in Feb, March
summary: China Evergrande Group, the third-largest developer, will offer 25% discounts on all properties for sale from February 18 to 29. The company also plans to offer 22% discounts on properties in March. The move aims to boost sales amid concerns about the coronavirus outbreak. China's property market has been impacted, with expected losses of up to 1.44 trillion yuan and a potential 37.5% drop in property investment. This could affect the country's full-year economic growth rate and employment.

site_title: US farmer wins damages over Bayer AG, BASF herbicide
summary: A US jury has awarded Missouri farmer Bill Bader $265 million in damages, blaming Bayer AG and BASF's Dicamba herbicide for destroying his peach orchards. The case is the first US trial over the chemical, which is alleged to have caused widespread crop damage by drifting onto nearby plants. The ruling is part of 140 lawsuits filed against the companies, who have argued that Dicamba is safe for crops when used properly. Bayer plans to appeal the decision, while BASF has not commented.

site_title: Singapore exports, the canary in the coal mine for Covid-19 impact, fall by 3.3% in January
summary: Singapore's exports fell 3.3% in January, dragged down by a 13% drop in electronic shipments. Non-electronic exports rose 0.1%, while exports to six of Singapore's top 10 markets declined year-over-year. The decline was attributed to an unfavourable base effect and softer demand from Hong Kong, the European Union, and Indonesia. Economists predict the impact of Covid-19 on trade will worsen in February, with a gradual reopening of China's factories expected to lead to more downside in trade flows.

site_title: Challenges and contingencies
summary: Key lessons from the novel coronavirus epidemic include the importance of calm decision-making, accurate information, and individual responsibility for good hygiene. Businesses must be prepared for disruptions and have contingency plans in place. The interdependence of the world highlights the need for global cooperation and information sharing. Effective communication by governments, businesses, and media can help combat misinformation and maintain public trust. The role of science, innovation, and partnerships in developing vaccines and healthcare solutions is crucial in addressing the risks posed by infectious diseases.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower as virus worries linger
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on February 17, 2020, due to concerns over the global spread of the new coronavirus. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.81% or 191.88 points to 23,495.71, while the Topix index slipped 0.85% or 14.46 points to 1,688.41.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday due to worries over the global spread of the new coronavirus.

site_title: Japan's economy shrinks at fastest pace in 6 years, virus clouds outlook
summary: Japan's economy shrank at the fastest pace in 6 years, with a 6.3% annualized contraction in the December quarter, driven by a sales tax hike and soft global demand. Private consumption dropped 2.9%, while capital expenditure fell 3.7%. The contraction translates to a 1.6% quarter-on-quarter decline, sparking fears of a recession. Policymakers are under pressure to prop up growth with additional stimulus, amid concerns about the coronavirus's impact on the economy.

images.alt_text: Japan's economy shrank at the fastest pace in six years in the December quarter as a sales tax hike and soft global demand hurt consumption and capital expenditure, keeping policymakers under pressure to prop up growth with additional stimulus.

site_title: Armed gang steals toilet rolls in panic-buying hit Hong Kong
summary: Armed robbers in Hong Kong have stolen hundreds of toilet rolls amid the city's coronavirus panic-buying, highlighting the severity of shortages. Despite government assurances, supermarkets struggle to restock quickly, leading to lengthy queues and bare shelves. The incident has sparked concerns over the desperation of residents seeking essential items. Authorities are hunting the thieves, who are believed to have taken the toilet rolls in a panic-buying frenzy.

site_title: China's coronavirus toll reaches 1,765: government
summary: China's coronavirus death toll surpassed 1,765, with 100 new fatalities reported in Hubei province, the epicentre of the outbreak. The province also reported 1,933 new cases, bringing the nationwide total to 70,400 infected. While the number of new cases has been declining, the World Health Organization warns it's impossible to predict the epidemic's direction. International experts have arrived in Beijing to meet with Chinese counterparts.

site_title: America's factories actually have something in their favour now
summary: US manufacturing is experiencing a welcome turn in stockpiles, alleviating concerns that had been weighing on the industry for two years. Recent economic data show a decrease in inventory cloud, which was caused by lacklustre export markets, trade-policy uncertainty, and corporate investment cutbacks. This improvement could help undergird manufacturing and provide a positive outlook for America's factories.

site_title: Binance applied for Singapore's new crypto licence, says CEO
summary: Binance, the world's largest crypto exchange operator, has applied for an operating licence in Singapore under the country's new Payment Services Act. The licence, which is the first comprehensive regulation for crypto firms, aims to bring companies handling digital payments and token trading into the regulatory fold. Binance co-founder and CEO CZ Zhao Changpeng stated that the company submitted the application quickly and has been in close touch with local regulators. Other crypto exchanges, Liquid Group and Luno, also plan to apply for the licence.

site_title: Masayoshi Son's other big property bet has some real problems
summary: Japanese billionaire Masayoshi Son's SoftBank Group Corp has faced challenges with its investment in Oyo, a startup from India that aims to disrupt the hotel business. Despite Son's enthusiasm for the company's ambitious goals, including a target of one million rooms within a year, the company has struggled to meet its targets, with only 7,500 rooms currently available. The startup's business model, which was successful in India, has not translated well to Japan and other overseas markets. SoftBank's aggressive expansion strategy has also led to conflicts with hotel owners and alienated workers, further exacerbating the company's woes. The setback has raised concerns about SoftBank's investment strategy and the reputation of its founder, Son, who is now facing pressure to rebuild his reputation and secure funding for his successor to the $100 billion Vision Fund.

site_title: China's home price growth hits near 2-year low as coronavirus spreads
summary: China's new home prices grew at their weakest pace in nearly two years in January, rising 0.2% from the previous month, as the coronavirus outbreak slows the country's property market. This marks an 18-month-low on a year-on-year basis. Analysts warn that the worst is yet to come, predicting widespread price-cutting and business disruption in coming months. Home sales have plummeted due to the virus outbreak, with nearly 1,800 people dying and over 70,000 infected in China. The spread of the disease is expected to have a devastating impact on China's economy.

images.alt_text: New home prices in China grew at their weakest pace in nearly two years in January, as the economy slows and a fast-spreading coronavirus outbreak brings the country's property market to a standstill.

site_title: Budget and Q4 results to take centre stage
summary: Singapore's Q4 GDP growth is expected to be 0.1% quarter-on-quarter, with year-on-year growth at 0.8%. The novel coronavirus outbreak has led to downward revisions in economic forecasts, with DBS revising its 2020 growth forecast from 1.4% to 0.9% and ING from 1.6% to 1%. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has warned of a recession in Singapore due to the virus outbreak, and traders are looking to the upcoming 2020 Singapore Budget statement for support measures to aid affected sectors.

site_title: Clock's ticking for Nissan boss Uchida to show he has a plan: sources
summary: Nissan's new CEO Makoto Uchida faces intense pressure to revive the struggling automaker, with a matter of months to prove he can accelerate cost-cutting and rebuild profits. The company posted its first quarterly net loss in nearly a decade, and Uchida's future is uncertain, with some board members reportedly dissatisfied with his work. Uchida has only been in the top job for two months and must act swiftly to counter a slide in sales, particularly in key markets like the US and China. The board may assess his efforts and make a decision on his future by mid-year.

site_title: 40 US nationals infected with coronavirus on Japan ship as others fly home
summary: Forty US nationals are among hundreds infected with coronavirus on a Japanese cruise ship, with 40 infected Americans choosing to leave the ship on chartered flights home after being offered the option. The ship, the Diamond Princess, was placed in a 14-day quarantine in early February after a former passenger tested positive for the virus. Over 3,500 people on board have been tested, with 1,665 deaths reported in mainland China. Japanese authorities have urged citizens to avoid crowds and non-essential gatherings as the country enters a new phase of the outbreak.

site_title: New York drops fight against T-Mobile-Sprint merger
summary: New York has dropped its fight against the $40 billion merger of T-Mobile and Sprint, following a US federal judge's approval of the deal. The state will no longer appeal the decision, instead focusing on ensuring consumers get the best pricing and service, and that networks are built throughout New York. The move comes after other states, including Colorado and Mississippi, have also dropped their challenges, with some striking agreements on job commitments and 5G deployment.

site_title: Man dies as Storm Dennis slams UK, power cuts hit France
summary: Storm Dennis brought heavy flooding and high winds to the UK and France, resulting in a man's fatal fall into a river in south Wales. Over 60,000 people in France suffered power cuts, and 594 flood warnings were issued across the UK. The storm also caused landslides and road closures, with the army assisting in relief efforts. Winds of over 150 km/h were recorded, and the government issued a rare red warning for south Wales due to the risk of "significant impacts from flooding."

site_title: UK's Intertek temporarily shuts Hong Kong garment office over coronavirus case
summary: Intertek Group temporarily shut its Hong Kong garment centre for two weeks after an employee contracted the new coronavirus. The employee is under observation in hospital. Operations had resumed on January 29 after the Lunar New Year holiday. Intertek's operations in mainland China and Taiwan resumed on February 10 and January 30, respectively. The company aims to minimize the impact on customers' business operations and has communicated new temporary work arrangements.

site_title: 8M Real Estate poised to ride wave of CBD living
summary: Singapore-based property investment company 8M Real Estate is shifting its focus from short-term hotel-style stays to longer-term serviced apartments. The company currently operates 109 rooms in three properties but plans to expand its accommodation portfolio to focus on longer-term stays. Founder and CEO Ashish Manchharam cites labor-intensive hotel operations and growing demand for serviced apartments in the Central Business District as reasons for the change. The company aims to increase its accommodation share to 60% of its business in the next two to three years, while reducing office space.

site_title: German far-right group planned Christchurch-style mosque attacks: reports
summary: German authorities have arrested 12 members of a far-right group planning Christchurch-style mosque attacks, similar to the 2019 New Zealand shootings that killed 51 people. The group, known to authorities, had planned to attack Muslim places of worship during prayers using semi-automatic weapons. The alleged leader detailed his plans at a meeting last week, and investigators learned of the plot from an infiltrated member. This comes after increased attention to Germany's underground extreme right scene following recent attacks and the murder of a conservative politician.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ThaiBev, Singapore Airlines, SIA Engg, F&N, Chip Eng Seng, Centurion
summary: ThaiBev reported a 14% jump in net profit to 8.4 billion baht (S$380 million) due to improvements in spirits and non-alcoholic beverage businesses. Singapore Airlines posted a 10.9% rise in Q3 net profit, warning of significant challenges from the Covid-19 outbreak. SIA Engineering entered into an agreement to form a line maintenance joint venture with Air Innovation Korea. Fraser and Neave will offer corporate guarantees to third-party lenders, while Chip Eng Seng Corp's fourth-quarter earnings were hit by a double-digit drop in property development contributions.

site_title: Global experts begin meetings in China over coronavirus: WHO
summary: Global health experts are meeting with Chinese officials to discuss the rapidly spreading coronavirus, with the number of new cases declining for a third consecutive day. The death toll has risen to 1,665 in mainland China, while over 68,000 people have been infected. The World Health Organization warns that the epidemic's future path is "impossible to predict," and the US has reported a cluster of infections on a quarantined cruise ship off Japan. Chinese authorities have introduced strict quarantine measures, including sealing off residential compounds and closing public spaces, in an effort to contain the virus.

site_title: Parc Canberra sells 64% of its 496 units
summary: Parc Canberra, a 496-unit executive condominium in Singapore, has sold 64% of its units, with 316 apartments sold at an average price of S$1,085 per square foot. The sales were launched amid the COVID-19 outbreak, with precautionary measures in place, including temperature checks and social distancing. The remaining units are available for viewing at the showflat, which is open daily from 11am to 7pm.

site_title: Singapore lowers export forecast for 2020 on Covid-19, oil price fears
summary: Singapore has cut its export forecast for 2020 due to the impact of the novel coronavirus outbreak and lower oil prices. The country's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) are expected to range between a 0.5% drop and a 1.5% rise this year, down from its earlier projection of zero to 2% growth. Lower oil prices and supply chain disruptions are also expected to weigh on the country's total trade in 2020, with exports to key markets such as Japan and the European Union declining in 2019.

site_title: EU in 'frank' talks with Balkan nations seeking membership
summary: European Union leaders held 'frank' talks with leaders of six Western Balkan nations seeking membership, ahead of a key summit in Zagreb in May. The EU aims to maintain credibility in the Balkans after delaying membership talks with Albania and North Macedonia last October. France has led a small group vetoing the move, while Germany is working to get the accession process back on track. The EU Commission has proposed a more rigorous route to membership, focusing on "fundamental reforms" before opening talks.

images.alt_text: European Council president Charles Michel on Sunday met with leaders of the six Western Balkan nations seeking to join the EU, for 'frank' talks ahead of a key summit in Zagreb in May.

site_title: God save the pub: Britons rally to rescue local watering holes
summary: In the UK, a group of 7,500 locals banded together to save their favorite pub, Ye Olde Cross, from closure due to competition from supermarkets and online retailers. The pub, with a history dating back to the 1800s, was forced to close two years ago but was saved through community ownership, where 300 local people invested £150,000 in the business. This effort is part of a growing trend of individual investors taking over iconic British pubs, with around 100 now owned by private investors.

site_title: Momentum and an accommodative Fed seen keeping 2020 rally going
summary: US stocks rose last week, with momentum and accommodative comments from the US Federal Reserve expected to keep the 2020 rally going. Despite a revised estimate of over 60,000 coronavirus cases in China, investors remained optimistic due to low mortality rates and limited outside spread. Strategists, including Lorenzo Di Mattia and Jim Paulsen, anticipate the stock market to continue its upward trend as central bankers step in to counter any economic impact from the virus.

site_title: Macy's New York skyscraper project in midtown Manhattan faces tough challenges
summary: Macy's plans to build a 1.5 million square foot skyscraper in midtown Manhattan faces challenges as it requires zoning changes approved by the city. The process could be delayed or quashed due to potential political issues, with city officials and stakeholders expressing concerns. Macy's is seeking to generate cash from the project, which comes as the company navigates a difficult retail climate and has closed 125 stores and slashed 2,000 jobs. Approval may require concessions, such as transit upgrades, and the process could take years to complete.

site_title: British Airways COO and director of people to leave
summary: British Airways has announced the departure of its COO, Klaus Goersch, and Director of People, Angela Williams. Goersch will move back to North America, while Williams plans to leave in the next few months. Jason Mahoney, former director of engineering, will take over as COO, and Stuart Kennedy, previously director of people at IAG Cargo, will replace Williams. The changes are effective immediately.

images.alt_text: British Airways said on Sunday its chief operating officer, Klaus Goersch, and its Director of People, Angela Williams, were leaving the company.

site_title: Neo Group founder acquires 5.2m shares in a married deal
summary: Neo Group founder Neo Kah Kiat acquired 5.2 million shares in a married deal, increasing his stake to 77.625% with a consideration of S$1.56 million. The acquisition was also accompanied by his spouse, executive director Liew Oi Peng, who increased her deemed interest in the stock, maintaining a 77.625% total interest. This move comes amidst a relatively stable market, with the Straits Times Index declining 0.4% over the past five trading sessions.

site_title: Cloud computing: invisible, versatile and highly profitable
summary: Cloud computing has become a vital backbone of daily life, with Amazon, Microsoft, and Google setting records and driving its growth. The market is expected to reach $266 billion in 2020, with a near-doubling to $500 billion by 2023. Cloud services now offer various options, including public and private cloud access, and hybrid models combining both. Key players, such as AWS and Azure, compete for market share, with AWS holding a 30-50% share and Azure controlling around 15%. The industry emphasizes cybersecurity and the use of artificial intelligence to analyze and optimize vast amounts of data.

site_title: Upward trend on horizon for USD/SGD pair
summary: The USD/SGD pair is expected to trend upwards, with a "golden cross" candlestick pattern and breaking away from a downtrend line, signaling a bullish signal. The Fed's decision to keep interest rates unchanged in 2020, coupled with the US economy's healthy state, supports the USD's strength. Meanwhile, the ongoing Covid-19 outbreak may result in a weaker SGD, but the Monetary Authority of Singapore's potential easing of monetary policy and Singapore's close economic ties with China may mitigate this impact.

site_title: Singapore Budget's focus expected to be on manpower issues
summary: Singapore's upcoming Budget is expected to focus on addressing the country's long-term manpower needs, particularly for professionals, managers, executives, and technicians (PMETs), amid the COVID-19 outbreak. The government plans to announce wage support to help companies retain local workers and has proposed measures such as job redesign, upskilling, and re-employment incentives. The Budget also aims to support viable companies and help workers stay in their jobs, with some hoping for relief from tightened foreign worker quotas and increased funding for sector-specific job redesign efforts.

site_title: Johnson's Treasury coup could shift UK budget goalposts again
summary: Boris Johnson's new Chancellor Rishi Sunak is expected to shift the UK's budget goals, potentially ditching the surplus goal and increasing spending. This move could be a departure from the fiscal discipline of the Conservative party, which has prided itself on prudent budgeting. The new Chancellor may need to introduce new fiscal rules to foster credibility among investors, a challenge that comes as the UK's budget deficit is projected to be around £40 billion this year.

site_title: Dollar defies detractors with its strongest start in five years
summary: The US dollar is experiencing its strongest start to a year since 2015, defying expectations of many forecasters. The Bloomberg dollar index has climbed 1.9% since December, driven by demand for dollar havens amid global Covid-19 uncertainties and stable US economic data. A stronger dollar could contribute to global recovery, but its chances are low. This reverses forecasts that US growth would trail other parts of the world, and may hinder the European Central Bank's ability to raise interest rates, supporting the dollar against the euro.

site_title: Singapore downgrades 2020 growth forecast on virus outbreak; 2019 GDP slows to 0.7%
summary: Singapore's official growth forecast for 2020 has been downgraded to between -0.5% and 1.5% due to the novel coronavirus outbreak, with authorities bracing for the possibility of negative growth. The 2019 full-year growth came in at 0.7%, the slowest since the global financial crisis in 2009. Outward-oriented sectors like manufacturing and wholesale trade are expected to be affected, while pockets of relative strength include the construction and information and communications sectors.

images.alt_text: Singapore's official growth forecast for 2020 has been downgraded as the authorities are bracing for the possibility of negative growth as a result of the novel coronavirus outbreak, even as 2019 full-year growth came in consistent with earlier flash estimates.

site_title: Google in talks with publishers to pay for displaying news
summary: Google is in early-stage talks with French and European publishers to pay licensing fees for displaying news excerpts in Google News search results. The discussions, if successful, would apply only to news products, not general web content queries. This comes after Google sparked controversy in France by showing stripped-down news search results in response to a new copyright law. Google's vice-president of news, Richard Gingras, said the company is looking at ways to expand its work with publishers to support a sustainable news industry.

site_title: Euro washout exposes deep fault lines in single-currency system
summary: The euro is experiencing its worst annual start since 2015, with a decline of over 3% this year, amid concerns over the economic shock of the coronavirus outbreak, political risks from Germany to Ireland, and unresolved Brexit risks. The currency's vulnerability has led hedge funds to add to short positions, while options traders boost bearish bets. Analysts attribute the euro's decline to its design flaws, including divergent economies and a lack of fiscal transfers, with some predicting a potential long-term recovery at the expense of severe structural adjustments and internal devaluation.

site_title: SIA Engineering, Korean firm set up line maintenance JV
summary: SIA Engineering has entered into an agreement with Air Innovation Korea to form a line maintenance joint venture based in South Korea, with SIA holding a 51% stake. The partnership aims to support Aero-K Airlines' A320 fleet inventory technical management programme, providing component pooling and repair services for six years. The joint venture, expected to operate four A320 aircraft by end-2020, is planned to be operational in March. This partnership is not expected to impact SIA Engineering's earnings per share or net tangible assets.

site_title: Wage support, tax rebates, rental waivers and more in Budget's Covid-19 relief measures
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced measures to counter the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak, including wage support for local workers, tax rebates, and rental waivers for companies. The government will also provide targeted support for sectors hit hard by the outbreak, such as food and beverage, retail, and tourism. Additionally, households will receive relief to help with their cost of living. The measures aim to address concerns and support workers and companies affected by the global health crisis.

site_title: Ships are skipping China and it's causing turmoil for trade
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic is causing significant disruption to global trade, with dozens of export sailings to China being canceled, affecting the shipment of goods such as handbags, TVs, and toys. China, a major source of cargo for global shipping, is experiencing a surge in cases, leading to output squeezes and forcing exporters to diversify their supply chains. This has resulted in blank sailings, idle vessels, and empty containers, with losses estimated to be over $600 million. The impact is not limited to finished goods, with energy and commodity markets also being affected, including oil, gas, and bulk commodities.

site_title: Quarterly reporting, dividends and growth at listed companies
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has implemented a risk-based approach to quarterly reporting requirements for listed companies, allowing most to report semi-annually while maintaining the option to provide voluntary updates. This shift aims to encourage long-term growth and reduce focus on short-term profits. Dividend distributions can also be made quarterly, with 30 companies currently doing so. The new approach is seen as a positive development for investors, with Singapore maintaining the highest dividend yield across the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Flight of fancy? Aviation industry tries to go green
summary: The aviation industry is ramping up efforts to reduce its carbon emissions, with manufacturers and airlines pledging to become more sustainable. The industry aims to cut its net carbon emissions by 50% by 2050 and some have unveiled futuristic models, such as Airbus's Maveric jet, which could reduce fuel consumption by up to 20%. Electric planes are also being developed, with several companies working on hybrid-electric aircraft. However, environmentalists say technological solutions will take decades to implement and that the industry is moving too slowly to address the devastating impacts of climate change.

site_title: HSBC braces for massive overhaul
summary: HSBC Holdings Plc is set to unveil a massive overhaul, its third major restructuring in a decade, amid declining profits and rising challenges. The bank is expected to announce billion-dollar writedowns, cuts at trading desks, and a reduction in exposure to countries such as Turkey and Greece. Interim head Noel Quinn is battling uncertainty about his own future, and potential successors include Stephen Bird, Citigroup's former top executive in Asia, and external candidates. The bank's chairman, Mark Tucker, is seeking a CEO with broad experience, and the overhaul may include a new strategy for its underperforming US business.

site_title: Budget journey
summary: Singapore's Budget 2020 focuses on addressing manpower issues, with a key emphasis on addressing the country's labor shortages. The government aims to provide support for workers who need to upskill or reskill to remain employable. The Budget also allocates funds for various initiatives, including trade talks with the US and support for businesses affected by tariffs. Additionally, the government is exploring opportunities to establish Singapore as a global hub for advanced chip packaging and sustainable aviation. The goal is to position Singapore as a leader in emerging industries.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report provides a weekly roundup of the tanker and dry bulk market. Middle East rates remained unmoved, while the US Gulf and China markets saw slight improvements. Aframax rates rose across all routes, with the Northern European and Atlantic voyages gaining 37 and 25 points respectively. The Capesize market softened due to volatility in bunker prices, but the Transatlantic C8 bucked the trend with demand for time-charter vessels lifting. Panamax rates increased, particularly in East coast South America, while the Handy index fell below 300 points.

site_title: Funds facing trillion-dollar hit on negative-yielding debt pile
summary: Investors could lose up to $1 trillion this year due to negative-yielding debt, with pension funds particularly exposed. Traders must pay to lend on $13 trillion of debt, and investors are living longer and spending more on healthcare, increasing the need for returns. Negative-yielding debt has shaken the conventional wisdom of investors being compensated for lending, and portfolio managers may be stuck with assets they can't sell. The phenomenon is forcing investors into riskier assets, which could impact pension funds and insurance companies' solvency and increase risks.

site_title: Parc Canberra condominium sells 64% of its 496 units
summary: Parc Canberra, a 496-unit executive condominium, has sold 64% of its units, with 316 apartments sold at an average price of S$1,085 per square foot. The launch, which began on Saturday, was conducted amid the Covid-19 outbreak, with precautionary measures in place, including temperature checks and social distancing. The remaining units are available for viewing at the showflat, which is open daily from 11am to 7pm.

site_title: SGX RegCo seeks to hardcode whistleblowing policy into Listing Rules
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) plans to hardcode a whistleblowing policy into its Listing Rules, ensuring confidentiality and protection against retaliation for complainants. The policy aims to encourage whistleblowers to come forward and report concerns without fear of reprisal. SGX RegCo's CEO, Tan Boon Gin, believes listed companies must play a role in adhering to the policy, with audit committees responsible for ensuring compliance. The move aims to create a healthy whistleblowing culture across the market, with SGX RegCo seeking consultation from the market by June and aiming to institutionalize the policy by year-end.

site_title: Three new cases of coronavirus in Singapore, two linked to Grace Assembly church
summary: Three new cases of coronavirus infections have been confirmed in Singapore, bringing the total to 75, with two linked to the Grace Assembly of God cluster and a third linked to a previous case, including a regular serviceman in the Republic of Singapore Air Force. One patient has been discharged, and 19 have fully recovered. The Ministry of Health has reactivated its network of clinics, offering subsidized treatment for patients with symptoms.

images.alt_text: The Grace Assembly of God's Bukit Batok branch. With 18 confirmed cases, the church remains the largest coronavirus cluster.

site_title: ASL Marine halves Q2 losses to S$4.16m due to cost reduction
summary: ASL Marine, a mainboard-listed company, reported a 54.6% decrease in Q2 losses to S$4.16 million due to cost reduction. Revenue dropped 17.7% to S$78.27 million, but the company's ship-chartering segment reported higher revenue due to infrastructure projects. Despite oil prices being higher than in 2016, ASL Marine is optimistic about its mid-to-long-term prospects, citing increased infrastructure spending in select Asian regions and urbanization in emerging markets.

site_title: Five S-E Asia cities, including Singapore, listed in JLL's Premium Office Rent Tracker
summary: Singapore ranks 14th in the world's top 86 most expensive premium office rental markets with net effective rents at US$117 per year per square foot, according to JLL's Premium Office Rent Tracker. Other S-E Asia cities, including Ho Chi Minh City, Jakarta, Manila, Bangkok, and Kuala Lumpur, also feature in the top 100. The banking and financial industry sectors drive demand for premium office space, with tech firms, particularly online platforms, contributing to the growth of the sector. Other Southeast Asian cities, such as Jakarta and Ho Chi Minh City, are challenging Singapore's position as Asia's investment and innovation hub.

site_title: WHO says not advising on whether to hold Tokyo Olympics
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has stated that it is not advising on whether to hold the Tokyo Olympics this year amid the novel coronavirus outbreak, as its role is not to call off or cancel events. WHO head of health emergencies Michael Ryan said the agency can offer technical advice on handling possible risks, but the decision is up to hosting countries and the International Olympic Committee (IOC). Despite concerns, IOC officials have insisted there is no danger of the Olympics being cancelled or moved.

site_title: SIA Engineering inks Korean JV agreement for line maintenance
summary: SIA Engineering has entered into a 51-49 joint-venture agreement with Air Innovation Korea to form a line maintenance JV based in South Korea. The JV will provide component pooling and repair services for A320 aircraft, starting from March.
