Global oil demand is expected to suffer its first quarterly drop in a decade due to the epidemic's impact on China's economy.

site_title: Japan vows to step up efforts on coronavirus testing, containment after first fatality
summary: Japan has vowed to step up coronavirus testing and containment efforts after suffering its first death and confirming new cases, including a doctor and taxi driver. A 79-year-old woman in Kanagawa prefecture died after being transferred between hospitals, and several others in the Tokyo area and western Japan have also tested positive. The government has announced increased testing and containment measures to prevent further spread of the virus.

site_title: Wells Fargo to eliminate about 700 jobs in Manila
summary: Wells Fargo is planning to eliminate approximately 700 jobs in Manila, Philippines, and transfer some roles to India. This move follows the bank's earlier layoff of over 200 US lending division employees in 2019. The company reported a 55% slump in fourth-quarter profit, with new CEO Charles Scharf setting aside $1.5 billion for legal costs related to its sales scandal. The job cuts are part of the bank's restructuring efforts.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday due to lingering concerns over the new coronavirus's impact on the global and Japanese economy. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.51% and the Topix index declined 0.54%. This marks the latest decline in Asian markets amid ongoing economic worries.

site_title: Japan to begin moving some off quarantined cruise ship
summary: Japanese authorities are preparing to move some older passengers off the quarantined Diamond Princess cruise ship, with the first group set to depart later on Friday. The ship, which has over 3,700 passengers and crew on board, has seen 218 cases of COVID-19 diagnosed, with 10 in serious condition. The government is testing all passengers aged 80 or over for the virus, with those who test negative allowed to disembark and stay in government-provided accommodations. The quarantine is set to end on February 19.

site_title: African Development Bank says World Bank chief's criticism 'misleading'
summary: The African Development Bank (AfDB) has pushed back against World Bank President David Malpass' criticism, calling it "misleading and inaccurate." Malpass stated that the AfDB and similar regional development banks contribute to emerging market debt problems by lending quickly without a strong program to sustain it. The AfDB disputed this, citing its strong governance program and efforts to mitigate foreign exchange risks, improve tax collection, and direct pension assets into infrastructure development. The bank also emphasized its coordination with the World Bank and IMF on debt sustainability analyses.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks fall at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.11% at open on Friday, following a decline on Wall Street amid concerns over China's coronavirus epidemic. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 27,698.56, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.21%. The decline was attributed to growing fears over the epidemic, which has near 1,500 deaths.

site_title: US offers to help coronavirus efforts in North Korea
summary: The US has offered to support aid efforts in North Korea to combat the coronavirus, citing concerns over the country's vulnerability. State Department spokeswoman Morgan Ortagus stated the US is ready to facilitate the approval of assistance from aid groups, despite US and UN sanctions. North Korea has banned foreign tour groups and imposed a 30-day quarantine on foreigners. This offer comes amid a stalled diplomatic relationship between the US and North Korea, following failed meetings between the two leaders.

site_title: China's coronavirus toll revised downward after deaths double-counted
summary: China's death toll from the new coronavirus epidemic has been revised downward to 1,380 after officials discovered "duplicate statistics" in Hubei province. The National Health Commission removed 108 deaths and 1,043 confirmed infections. The revised death toll and total number of cases now stand at 1,380 and 63,851, respectively. Authorities in Hubei started counting patients diagnosed through lung imaging, adding nearly 15,000 patients to the count in a single day.

site_title: China's coronavirus death toll nears 1,500 but new cases fall
summary: China's coronavirus death toll reached 1,483, with a decline in new cases in hard-hit Hubei province. The province reported 116 new deaths and 4,823 new cases, following a change in case definitions that previously inflated numbers. Over 64,600 people are now infected nationwide, with health officials prioritizing early treatment for "clinically diagnosed" patients. The change has raised concerns about the severity of the crisis, despite Chinese authorities' reported numbers.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, OCBC, Keppel, Sats, Hi-P, Far East H-Trust, SBS Transit
summary: Several Singapore stocks were affected by the novel coronavirus outbreak. DBS Group and OCBC Bank announced relief packages for businesses, while Sats warned of potential short-term impact from the outbreak. Hi-P International saw its fourth-quarter earnings halve, and Far East Hospitality Trust's distribution per stapled security fell 5%. In contrast, SBS Transit posted a 1.5% increase in full-year net profit, and Accordia Golf Trust's distribution per unit rose 1.5%. Other stocks, including Keppel Corp, First Sponsor, and UnUsUaL, also reported earnings or announcements.

site_title: Australia: Shares set to end week firmer as earnings offset virus scare
summary: Australian shares are set to end the week firmer, with the S&P/ASX 200 index up 0.06% at 7,107.60, driven by strong earnings from top lender Commonwealth Bank of Australia. The bank is set to post its biggest weekly gain since last May and is considering a fresh share sale. The financial sector is expected to gain 3% weekly, while mining stocks decline 0.4%. The energy sector is on track for its fifth consecutive weekly loss.

site_title: Proposed S$1.58b merger between Frasers' Reits on 'normal commercial terms': IFA
summary: Frasers Logistics Trust (FLT) and Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) are set to merge in a proposed S$1.58 billion deal. The independent directors of both Reits have recommended unitholders vote in favor, with their respective IFA advising the independent directors to give the recommendation. Meetings to seek approval from both Reits' unitholders will be held on March 11 at the Suntec Singapore Convention & Exhibition Centre.

site_title: Cruise passengers land after two weeks at sea over coronavirus fears
summary: A cruise ship, the Westerdam, carrying 2,257 passengers and crew, docked in Cambodia on February 14, 2020, after being turned away from several Asian ports due to concerns over the new coronavirus. The ship was initially denied entry in Japan, Guam, the Philippines, Taiwan, and Thailand. After no cases of the virus were found on board, passengers were welcomed ashore by Cambodian Premier Hun Sen, who praised the country's human rights record. All passengers will be allowed to disembark, with flights home provided by Holland America.

images.alt_text: Passengers on a cruise ship that was turned away from ports around Asia over fears they could be carrying the new coronavirus finally began disembarking in Cambodia on Friday.

site_title: Japan's policymakers brace for Q4 GDP slump, growing coronavirus risks
summary: Japan's policymakers anticipate a sharp contraction in Q4 GDP due to sluggish overseas demand and the impact of the coronavirus outbreak, which may lead to a "big contraction" in the final quarter of last year. Analysts expect an annualized 3.7% decline, the fastest pace since 2014. The government has decided to spend 10.3 billion yen from budget reserves to respond to the outbreak, and the Bank of Japan is prepared to maintain its stimulus program but may consider additional support if the impact is significant.

site_title: CPF interest rates to remain unchanged for second quarter this year
summary: The Central Provident Fund (CPF) interest rates for the second quarter will remain unchanged, with the Ordinary Account (OA) interest rate at 2.5% per annum and the concessionary interest rate for HDB mortgage loans at 2.6% per annum. This decision will apply from April 1 to June 30.

site_title: Russia's Don Agro debuts at S$0.25 on SGX, 13.6% higher than IPO price
summary: Russian agri and dairy firm Don Agro International debuted on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist at S$0.25, 13.6% higher than its IPO price of S$0.22. The company, which operates farms in southern Russia, raised S$5.1 million through its IPO. Don Agro's listing is the first by a Russian firm on the Singapore bourse, fueling its growth and capturing opportunities in the Russian agricultural industry. The listing also reinforces SGX's position as Asia's most international exchange, with over 40% of international listings.

site_title: Britain's Johnson feels the heat over luxury holiday funding
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson faced pressure to reveal who funded his £15,000 luxury holiday in the Caribbean, with the opposition Labour Party demanding a parliamentary investigation. Johnson claimed the trip was provided by David Ross, a Conservative donor, but Ross's spokesman disputed this, stating Ross facilitated accommodation but did not pay for it. The opposition argued transparency is crucial, citing the code of conduct requiring members to provide the name of the person or organisation that actually funded a donation.

site_title: Court rules Apple must pay California workers during bag checks
summary: The California Supreme Court ruled that Apple must pay hourly workers for time spent waiting for bag and personal device searches upon leaving work. The decision affects over 12,000 retail store employees, who are required to clock out before the searches, which can take 5-20 minutes. Apple will pay millions of dollars to these workers under the mandatory bag-search policy.

site_title: Capital World sinks into the red in Q2, proposes scheme of arrangement
summary: Capital World, a Singapore-listed property developer, has proposed a scheme of arrangement to restructure its debt due to its current net liability position of RM53.5 million. The company reported a net loss of RM14.8 million in Q2, with revenue plummeting 98% to RM986,000. Capital World cited a lack of visibility in cash flow to repay creditors within the next 12 months and unsuccessful efforts to raise further financing. The company's share price has fallen, making a proposed share subscription by two private investors unlikely.

site_title: Tesla shifts gears with plans to issue more shares
summary: Tesla plans to issue 2.65 million shares of common stock, raising over $2 billion, to strengthen its balance sheet and for company operations. The move comes after the company's Shanghai factory was temporarily closed due to the coronavirus outbreak. Tesla shares rose 5% on the news, with CEO Elon Musk planning to buy $10 million worth of the newly minted shares. The company will use the funds to offset a decline in sales in China, where it has its first factory outside the US. The offering is seen as a smart move by analysts.

site_title: How to make the kindest cuts
summary: There is no article content related to the topic "How to make the kindest cuts" provided.

site_title: Japan's Q4 GDP likely weaker than in Q3: economy minister
summary: Japan's economy minister, Yasutoshi Nishimura, stated that the country's Q4 GDP is likely weaker than in Q3 due to the impact of the sales tax hike and a typhoon. The economy is expected to pick up, but the coronavirus outbreak poses a risk to growth.

images.alt_text: Japan's gross domestic product in October-December was likely weaker than in the previous quarter due to the impact of the sales tax hike and a typhoon, economy minister Yasutoshi Nishimura said on Friday.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.88 points or 0.19% to 1,536.28. The index saw a trading volume of 42.86 million lots worth RM23.17 million, with 104 gainers and 75 losers. The market's performance was influenced by global economic concerns, including US-EU tariffs and the ongoing S&P 500 and Nasdaq records.

site_title: Pentagon shifts US$3.8b to Mexico border wall construction
summary: The US Pentagon has shifted an additional $3.8 billion towards the construction of the US-Mexico border wall, bringing the total to $9.9 billion. The funds were reallocated from procurement and other operations to support the Department of Homeland Security's counter-drug activities. This move follows President Donald Trump's national emergency declaration last year and a court ruling allowing the diversion of federal budget funds. The wall's construction has been a contentious issue, with opposition from Congress and a recent decline in border apprehension numbers.

site_title: Accordia Golf Trust posts Q3 DPU of 2.22 S cents
summary: Accordia Golf Trust reported a Q3 DPU of 2.22 Singapore cents, up from 1.57 yen in the previous year, driven by a 2 billion yen increase in income available for distribution. However, the trust's net profit dropped 14.2% to 2.8 billion yen and revenue declined 3.1% to 13.9 billion yen. Operating income also fell 3.8% to 14.1 billion yen due to a decline in the number of players. No distribution was declared for the current financial period, as Accordia Golf Trust makes semi-annual distributions.

site_title: US: Wall Street ends in the red as virus fears spook investors
summary: US stocks declined on Thursday, closing at record levels due to concerns over the COVID-19 outbreak in China, with the Dow Jones falling 0.4% to 29,423.31 points. Japan reported its first death and Vietnam placed 10,000 people under quarantine. The Nasdaq slipped 0.1% and the S&P 500 declined 0.2%. Investors were also affected by weak earnings from companies like Cisco and American Airlines. Despite this, Tesla's shares rose 5% after announcing a $2 billion stock offering.

site_title: Trump says peace deal with Taleban 'very close'
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that a peace deal with the Taleban guerrillas in Afghanistan is "very close" and a deal could be reached within the next two weeks.

site_title: Singapore stocks decline on Friday morning; STI opens 0.15% lower
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.15% to 3,215.28 on Friday morning, following weaker US and regional performances amid Covid-19 concerns. Losers and gainers were evenly matched at 55, with Medtecs International rising 0.9% and ESR-Reit holding steady. Banking stocks DBS, UOB, and OCBC Bank declined, while Hi-P International and Sats fell 3.1% and 1.8% respectively. The decline follows Wall Street's retreat overnight, with the Nasdaq and S&P 500 also falling.

site_title: Antarctica registers record temperature of over 20 deg C
summary: Scientists in Antarctica recorded a new record temperature of 20.75°C, breaking the 20°C barrier for the first time on the continent. The reading was taken on February 9 at Seymour Island, part of Argentina's Marambio research base. Brazilian researcher Carlos Schaefer cautioned that the reading is a one-off temperature and not part of a long-term data set, but it highlights the warming of the planet and accelerating melt-off from glaciers and ice sheets, driving sea level rises. This is not the first record-breaking temperature in Antarctica, as a previous record was set in the 19s.

site_title: Trump, Bloomberg trade barbs as ex-New York mayor rises in polls
summary: US President Donald Trump and former New York Mayor Mike Bloomberg exchanged barbs on Twitter, with Trump calling Bloomberg a "loser" and "circus barking clown" and Bloomberg firing back, saying Trump is a "carnival barking clown." The exchange comes as Bloomberg rises in the polls, with an average of recent nationwide surveys placing him in third place, ahead of Bernie Sanders and Joe Biden. Trump is taking note, with rivals accusing him of trying to buy the election with his vast fortune.

site_title: US attorney general says Trump making it 'impossible' to do job
summary: US Attorney General Bill Barr accused President Donald Trump of hindering his ability to do his job due to Trump's tweets, stating they are "making my job impossible." Barr expressed frustration over Trump's constant commentary on Department of Justice cases, specifically in the Roger Stone case, where prosecutors resigned amid allegations of political interference. Barr will testify to Congress next month, amid concerns he may face repercussions for speaking out against Trump.

site_title: Amazon wins suspension of US$10b 'Jedi' contract to Microsoft
summary: A federal judge temporarily blocked the US military from awarding a $10 billion cloud computing contract to Microsoft, citing alleged politics in the process. Amazon claimed it was shut out of the deal due to President Donald Trump's vendetta against the company. Amazon is seeking testimony from the president and other top officials on the reasons for awarding the contract to Microsoft, which was chosen over Amazon Web Services (AWS). The 10-year contract for the Joint Enterprise Defence Infrastructure (JEdi) programme will share military information in a cloud-based system boosted by artificial intelligence.

site_title: Far East H-Trust posts 5% drop in Q4 DPS to 0.95 S cent
summary: Far East H-Trust reported a 5% drop in Q4 distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 0.95 Singapore cents due to an enlarged base from implementing a distribution reinvestment plan. Gross revenue rose 0.1% to S$28.95 million, while net property income (NPI) fell 1% to S$26.1 million. The full-year DPS declined 4.8% to 3.81 Singapore cents, with income available for distribution falling 2% to S$73.9 million. The trust attributes the decline to the impact of the Covid-19 virus outbreak on demand.

site_title: White House 'disappointed' in China's coronavirus transparency
summary: The US is disappointed with China's lack of transparency regarding the coronavirus crisis, according to a senior White House official. Despite President Trump praising China's response, unanswered questions and a lack of promised cooperation are mounting. Director Larry Kudlow expressed concerns over the economic impact and the uncertainty caused by the crisis, questioning China's motives and the sincerity of its top leadership. The US is willing to work with international organizations on the crisis but is waiting for more information from China.

site_title: Get carbon border taxes right for fairer distribution
summary: A carbon border tax could efficiently move the world towards sustainability by equalizing the cost of carbon use from domestic and foreign sources, preventing "carbon leakage." However, concerns about distributional fairness arise, particularly for developing countries. Implementing carbon border taxes without exceptions for developing countries and with resource transfers could depart from the traditional "separability" narrative, which separates efficiency from distributional priorities. Policymakers must address these issues upfront to create a consensual multilateral approach, as the future debate is likely to focus on within-country redistribution rather than international distribution.

site_title: Oil prices climb on prospects for deeper Opec+ output cuts
summary: Oil prices rose on Thursday as investors anticipated deeper Opec+ output cuts amid a coronavirus outbreak in top oil importer China. Brent crude ended up 1% at $56.34 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate settled up 0.5% at $51.42 a barrel. Opec+ producers are expected to cut output further, with the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries lowering its 2020 demand forecast by 200,000 bpd. Oil demand in China has plummeted due to travel restrictions and quarantines.

site_title: Interview - James and Tamara Lohan
summary: James and Tamara Lohan, founders of Mr & Mrs Smith, discuss the evolving concept of romance in travel, citing changing societal expectations and technological advancements as drivers. Their report, "Modern Love," explores innovative, sensual, and meaningful experiences in romantic travel. Key takeaways include the rise of experiential travel, the blurring of lines between romance and friendship, and the importance of shared purpose and co-romantic breaks. The couple suggests hotels and travel operators adapt by showcasing unique, eco-friendly, and community-driven experiences, and embracing the idea of untethered living and situationships.

site_title: Europe: Linde surge helps shares end flat amid rising coronavirus fears
summary: European shares ended flat on Thursday, despite a surge in new coronavirus cases in China, as Linde's record high helped offset losses. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index finished flat, with London's blue chip index underperforming 1.1% due to a rallying pound. Utility Centrica plummeted 15% after reporting a 35% drop in 2019 profit. Despite calmings from the World Health Organization, HSBC lowered its first-quarter forecast for mainland China's economic growth.

site_title: $77m in aid for cabbies, private-hire drivers during outbreak
summary: Singapore's government is providing $77 million in aid to taxi and private-hire drivers affected by the coronavirus crisis, with $45 million from the government and the rest from taxi and private-hire companies. The aid package includes $20 per day for 40,000 drivers for three months. Main taxi hirers and active private-hire drivers who completed at least 200 trips per month from October to December 2019 will be eligible. The government and taxi companies have also set up a $2.7 million fund for those who don't qualify.

site_title: Washington gives Huawei 45-day reprieve to operate in US
summary: The US Commerce Department granted Huawei a 45-day reprieve to sell to American companies, allowing existing telecommunications providers to continue operating existing networks. This decision comes hours after the US hit Huawei with criminal charges alleging a "decades-long" effort to steal trade secrets from American companies. The extension is seen as a temporary measure to give the US time to search for alternatives to Huawei.

site_title: Planting one trillion trees won't save the world
summary: A study's claim that planting one trillion trees is the most effective climate change solution is being disputed by scientists. While trees can absorb carbon dioxide, it's not enough to offset the enormous amounts of fossil carbon emitted from industrial societies. Focusing on tree planting diverts attention from those responsible for carbon emissions and ignores the need for rapid reductions in fossil fuel use. Experts argue that regulating carbon pollution and making clean energy cheap are the only solutions to combat climate change, which will require significant investments and policy changes.

site_title: Transforming Singapore enterprises
summary: Singapore's government aims to support local enterprises, particularly small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), by transforming their businesses to adapt to a dynamic and uncertain future economy. The government proposes a "3+5 Protect and Grow" scheme, which offers tax measures and grants to boost productivity, innovation, and internationalization. The scheme has two phases, with the first three years focusing on productivity and the next five years on growth and value creation. Additionally, the government plans to accelerate tech adoption, including cloud-based services, and provide incentives for talent development and upskilling.

site_title: Analysts expect provisions to be made in Budget for social spending
summary: Singapore's upcoming Budget 2020 is expected to include significant allocations for social spending, despite the economic impact of the Covid-19 virus. Analysts predict a 15-20% increase in social expenses, driven by the country's ageing population and the need to boost safety nets for the poor and vulnerable. The government's huge surpluses, estimated to be around S$15-20 billion, provide substantial fiscal space to finance social spending and combat the pandemic. Key thrusts are expected to include increased healthcare and education spending, as well as measures to support the elderly and vulnerable.

site_title: Berlin's 5-year rent freeze is cold comfort for Lisbon
summary: Portugal's Prime Minister Antonio Costa has expressed skepticism about Berlin's 5-year rent freeze, citing Lisbon's own experience with the policy. Lisbon's home prices have doubled since 2012, discouraging property owners from renovations. Costa believes the freeze will lead to speculative movements and is ending "golden visas" for foreign property purchases. In contrast, Berlin's measures aim to ease the burden on tenants amid a shortage of affordable homes. Costa suggests alternative solutions to manage the market, noting the difference between a 4-year and 40-year freeze.

site_title: Money FM podcast: String - the next evolutionary step in travel planning
summary: The Money FM podcast "Weekend Mornings" featured an interview with Albert Tan, founder of String Travel, an app designed to simplify travel planning through a shared portal of user-generated itineraries. String aims to ease travel planning by allowing users to reference and share their itineraries. The app aims to revolutionize the travel planning process by providing a platform for users to collaborate and share their travel experiences.

site_title: Fed chief says 'all is not well' in otherwise healthy US economy
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell stated that despite a near-50-year low unemployment rate, the US economy is not entirely healthy. He noted that over 5% of workers hold multiple jobs, wages are rising at a 3% annual rate, just ahead of inflation, and Americans lag behind other advanced economies in education and skills. Powell emphasized the need for Congress to address these issues, which the Fed cannot directly address, and urged lawmakers to support the independence of the Federal Reserve.

site_title: Towkays Of Yore
summary: A revamped gallery at the Sun Yat Sen Nanyang Memorial Hall showcases the contributions of early Chinese business pioneers in Singapore. The gallery features over 300 historical images and artefacts, including a rare franking machine and a Magic Brain calculator. The exhibit aims to instill values such as integrity, loyalty, and innovation in visitors, providing relatable role models for younger generations and encouraging Singaporeans to adopt these values. The gallery highlights the achievements of pioneers like Tan Lark Sye, Tan Kah Kee, and Lee Kong Chian, who set the stage for Singapore's growth into a vibrant business hub.

site_title: Unpretentious fare hits the spot at Torasho
summary: Torasho Ramen & Charcoal Bar, a Singaporean restaurant, offers an unassuming yet polished dining experience. Chef-partner Sho Naganuma's impressive resume and modern menu featuring all-you-want boiled eggs, ikan bilis, and spicy cabbage elevate the restaurant beyond its competitors. The menu showcases a variety of dishes, including tonkotsu and tsukemen ramen, chicken karaage, and gyoza, all made with high-quality ingredients. The restaurant's extensive selection of small bites and big plates, including wagyu donabe, make it a standout. With its thoughtful and reasonably-priced cooking, Torasho earns a 7-star rating.

site_title: Uber plans move to bigger Amsterdam office to hold new hires
summary: Uber is set to move to a larger office in Amsterdam, renting two-thirds of the 148,000 sq ft Tripolis complex, starting from 2022. The company is expanding its workforce, with employee numbers growing from 400 to 1,500 since 2017. Uber aims to accommodate new hires, including staff for its electric bikes and freight services, which are part of its growing operations in the city. The move is part of the company's expansion plans, despite overall spending reductions, with the US tech company having 27,000 employees globally.

site_title: China firms tap 'virus bonds' but use funds for other purposes
summary: Chinese companies are tapping into cheap funds via "virus bonds" to capitalize on Beijing's efforts to boost the economy, but most funds will be used for other purposes. Only a third of the raised 14 billion yuan will be used for virus-related investments, with companies allocating just 10% of the funds to such causes. State-controlled banks are encouraged to buy these instruments, offering lower yields. Companies like Fuyao Glass Industry Group and Huafa Group are using the funds to repay loans and replenish liquidity, rather than solely for virus prevention and control.

site_title: HK property developers cut retail rents amid war on virus
summary: Hong Kong property developers are cutting retail rents by up to 60% in February to help tenants cope with the effects of the novel coronavirus outbreak. Major landlords, including Henderson Land, Sun Hung Kai Properties, and New World Development, are offering rent reductions to small- to medium-size tenants in retail, food and beverage, and education businesses. The moves come as the city's retail sector suffers from months of anti-government protests and the outbreak in mainland China has emptied shopping centers and closed tourist attractions.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng, two other firms bag Jurong Regional Line deals worth S$596m
summary: Chip Eng Seng, along with two other firms, Sembcorp Design and Construction and China Communications Construction, have secured contracts worth S$596 million to design and construct four Jurong Region Line (JRL) stations and associated viaducts in Singapore. The largest contract, valued at S$226.6 million, was awarded to Sembcorp Design and Construction. The stations are expected to be completed by 2026 and 2027, with the projects contributing positively to Chip Eng Seng's net tangible assets and earnings per share.

site_title: Yen and Swiss franc gain as Covid-19 cases jump
summary: Investors sought safe havens as China's Hubei province reported a sharp rise in novel coronavirus cases, with the euro falling to a 41/2-year low against the Swiss franc and the yen strengthening. The euro dropped to 1.0622 francs, while the yen gained 0.3% against the dollar, reaching a four-month high. The Swiss franc's gains are attributed to its low correlation with risky assets, potentially paving the way for further gains.

site_title: Dhaka Art Summit Joins The Dots
summary: The Dhaka Art Summit, now in its fifth edition, has solidified its position as a prominent art platform, showcasing the diverse and authentic perspectives of South Asian artists. The event, which runs until February 15, 2020, features works by notable artists such as Adrián Villar Rojas, Nilima Sheikh, and Otobong Nkanga, highlighting the region's rich cultural heritage and the struggles of women in Kashmir. Curator Diana Campbell Betancourt's theme, "Seismic Movements," aims to challenge traditional notions of borders and art worlds, with the event attracting over 300,000 visitors.

site_title: Working Relationships
summary: Five couples, including the Chuas, Ting and Chew, and Yip and Yeo, share their experiences of thriving in both their personal and professional relationships. The couples, who often work together and have similar work styles, attribute their success to trust, open communication, and a willingness to compromise. They prioritize spending quality time together and make an effort to maintain a work-life balance. Their partners often work long hours, but they understand and support each other's needs. The couples also emphasize the importance of having a strong foundation in their relationship, which enables them to navigate the challenges of running a business together.

site_title: Bezos pays record US$165m for Beverly Hills home
summary: Jeff Bezos has agreed to pay a record US$165 million for a Beverly Hills mansion on nine acres, setting a record for a Los Angeles-area home. The property, designed in the 1930s for Jack Warner, features expansive terraces and a nine-hole golf course. This purchase comes after Bezos recently cashed out US$4.1 billion of Amazon shares and made significant art purchases, including a record-breaking US$52.5 million purchase of Ed Ruscha's "Hurting the Word Radio #2."

site_title: Singapore SMEs seize opportunities in growing aerospace sector
summary: Singaporean small- and mid-sized enterprises (SMEs) are seizing opportunities in the growing aerospace sector, with the help of government agencies and trade associations. Companies such as logistics firm CK Shipping and composite cluster Singapore are leveraging their existing capabilities to serve aerospace needs, while others are developing purpose-built solutions. With grants from Enterprise Singapore, these SMEs are reskilling their workforce, investing in new assets, and gaining access to overseas markets. Despite high barriers to entry, SMEs that persevere can achieve significant rewards, including specialized products and global market access.

site_title: Covid-19 spread clouds recovery of Singapore retail, industrial sectors
summary: Singapore's retail and industrial sectors are facing near-term downside pressure due to the escalating Covid-19 outbreak, which has killed over 1,300 people and infected over 60,000 worldwide. According to Colliers International, both sectors showed signs of bottoming and will likely stabilize into 2020, but any recovery will be marginal, particularly for the retail property market. Retail sales remain fragile, with a 1.2% decline in 2019, and rents are expected to stabilize and recover gradually, driven by new supply pipelines.

site_title: Genting's earnings to take hit, but analysts bet on bright side
summary: Genting Singapore's Q1 earnings are expected to take a hit due to the Covid-19 outbreak, with analysts forecasting a 10-20% drop in FY2020 forecasts. However, analysts recommend adding positions in the casino operator, citing attractive valuations and potential re-rating catalysts. Aid and relief packages in the upcoming Budget, Genting's net cash position, and its bid for an Osaka IR licence are seen as positives. Analysts expect the negative impact to be short-lived, with upside potential for Genting Singapore if it wins a bid for the Osaka integrated resort project.

site_title: NUS don and two Bangladeshi workers among 8 new cases
summary: Singapore reported 8 new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total to 58, with 5 linked to the Grace Assembly of God church and a 54-year-old NUS professor among them. Two Bangladeshi work pass holders, aged 30 and 37, are also infected, linked to a worksite in Seletar Aerospace Heights. All new cases are currently in isolation, with none having recent travel history to China. The Ministry of Health will continue to rely on laboratory tests to confirm cases, despite China adopting new diagnostic guidelines.

site_title: SGX asks Vividthree to explain why company is raising more funds
summary: Vividthree Holdings, a visual effects studio listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX), has announced a new fundraising exercise to raise up to S$1.88 million for working capital. Despite unused IPO proceeds of S$1.15 million, the company plans to use the fresh funds to develop new projects, with S$1.3 million earmarked for this purpose. The remaining working capital portion will be used for ongoing projects. The SGX has raised queries about the company's decision to raise funds, citing unused IPO proceeds and lack of specific plans for the funds.

site_title: He's in a cabernet franc state of mind
summary: Bruce Schneider, a lesser-known figure in the wine industry, has spent 25 years making Cabernet Franc wines in New York state, primarily on the North Fork of Long Island and in the Finger Lakes. Schneider, who started with limited financial assets, has demonstrated the potential of the grape, evolving American wine styles, and pioneering eco-friendly methods of selling and transporting wine. His journey, from an internship in Burgundy to founding his own wineries, showcases his resourcefulness and expertise in farming, production, marketing, and innovation.

site_title: Trump's re-election will have huge worldwide significance
summary: US President Donald Trump is likely to win re-election, with the economy and passionate supporters being key factors in his victory. His re-election could have significant worldwide implications, potentially eroding liberal democracy in the US and undermining the global trading system. Trump's nationalist and authoritarian tendencies, as well as his hostility towards the EU and the rules-based order, could lead to a decline in international cooperation and a rise in tensions with China and Russia. The consequences of his re-election could be far-reaching, with potential destabilization of the global economy and a decline in moral leadership.

site_title: Restoring inclusive and sustainable growth in India
summary: India's federal budget, presented on February 1, aims to restore inclusive and sustainable growth amidst a slowdown in economic growth. The budget focuses on boosting consumer demand, lifting investment, expanding infrastructure, and easing credit to revive economic growth. Key measures include a 21% increase in government capital spending, reduced personal income tax rates, and corporate tax cuts to 22% and 15%. The budget also emphasizes wealth creation, inclusive development, and empowering marginalized communities, with a focus on digital infrastructure and innovation.

site_title: Malaysia to renew Lynas' rare earths plant licence: sources
summary: Malaysia has agreed to renew Lynas Corp Ltd's licence to operate its rare earths processing plant for three more years, following a cabinet meeting chaired by Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad. The decision resolves a dispute over low-level radioactive waste and comes after Lynas fulfilled conditions to store waste and relocate a facility. Shares in the company rose over 8% following the announcement. The renewal was made despite some Malaysians protesting against the plant due to health concerns from radioactivity.

site_title: Mergers and acquisitions game not for the faint of heart
summary: A good merger or acquisition requires attention, preparation, and a clear understanding of the target business. It's essential to know your partner, not just the numbers, and to consider the culture and people involved. Rigid procedures can lead to failure, while treating the acquired business as a valued guest can foster success. Timing is crucial, and acquirers should be immersed in both their own and the acquired business to ensure a smooth integration. With the right approach, a merger can be a beautiful and beneficial partnership, but it's not a treat to be slowly consumed.

site_title: Singtel's India woes easing, but Australia market poses new challenge
summary: Singtel reported a 24% decline in earnings for the third quarter, citing losses from its Indian associate Airtel. However, management believes these issues are temporary, with growing user demand and a strong balance sheet. The telco faces new challenges in the Australian market, where it operates. Despite this, Singtel's balance sheet remains strong, and management is confident in its ability to overcome current difficulties.

images.alt_text: Mainboard-listed Singtel on Thursday announced 24 per cent lower earnings for the third quarter and noted new threats to margins and revenue.

site_title: Seven measures to expect from Budget 2020
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance Heng Swee Keat is expected to unveil a strong expansionary Budget 2020, focusing on growing the economy, helping Singapore face external challenges, and ensuring long-term success. Key measures include a 20% corporate income tax rebate for struggling companies, a special relief package for companies affected by the coronavirus outbreak, and initiatives to support workers, particularly those aged 40 and above, in upskilling and reskilling. The Budget may also introduce a higher income tax rate for ultra-rich individuals and increase tax revenue collection through scaling down personal reliefs.

site_title: Centerbridge seeks up to US$5b for fourth debt fund
summary: Centerbridge Partners, a US private equity firm, is seeking to raise up to $5 billion for its fourth private credit fund. The fund will target corporate debt trading at a discount, potentially snapping up distressed debt as the US economy enters a recession. Despite a relatively healthy economic cycle, Centerbridge's fundraising aims to capitalize on potential opportunities for distressed debt purchases. The firm's assets under management total $27 billion, and its previous debt fund raised over $4 billion.

site_title: Sats Q3 profit down 14%; warns of hit from Covid-19 epidemic
summary: SATS, a Singapore-listed aviation services provider, reported a 13.9% decline in third-quarter net profit to S$59.3 million, despite a 17.6% increase in revenue to S$545.6 million. The company attributed the fall in earnings to higher costs from expansion-related activities and the Covid-19 epidemic, which has impacted Chinese air traffic and passenger volumes. Sats warned of a potential hit to its short-term financial performance due to the epidemic, but expressed confidence in its ability to weather the disruption.

site_title: SBS Transit full-year net profit up 1.5% to S$81.3 million
summary: SBS Transit, a Singapore transport operator, reported a full-year net profit of S$81.3 million, a 1.5% increase from the previous year. Revenue rose 4.5% to S$1.45 billion, driven by higher bus service fees, increased rail ridership, and higher train fares.

site_title: Investors oppose delisting of Dubai real estate fund amid property slump
summary: Dubai real estate investment trust ENBD Reit faces opposition from investors who oppose going private due to concerns about the potential erosion of its value. The move comes as the city's property market is hit by oversupply and sluggish growth. Investors, including UAE's National Bonds and Saudi insurer Tawuniya, believe the trust's fee structure rewards managers without fully accounting for the sector's condition. ENBD Reit plans to delist due to low trading liquidity and a 50% discount on its shares versus net asset value, but investors argue delisting won't solve the problem and may further devalue the trust.

site_title: DBS outperforms in Q4; hunkers down to tackle impact from virus outbreak
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest bank, reported a strong Q4 performance, outperforming its peers. The bank's CEO, Piyush Gupta, expects lower revenue of 1-2% in 2020 due to the impact of the novel coronavirus on industries like tourism and hospitality. Permanent demand displacement is anticipated, with travel, hospitality, and aviation sectors likely to be affected. DBS is preparing to tackle the virus outbreak's impact on its earnings.

site_title: UK finance minister resigns, upsetting Johnson's reshuffle plans
summary: UK Finance Minister Sajid Javid resigned on Thursday, upending Prime Minister Boris Johnson's reshuffle plans. Javid had reportedly disagreed with Johnson's team over his advisers, leading to his resignation as Chancellor of the Exchequer. Rishi Sunak, Chief Secretary to the Treasury, has been appointed to replace him. The pound rallied after Javid's resignation, with some speculating that the UK may move towards more fiscal stimulus.

site_title: STI dips as Covid-19 cases surge in Hubei
summary: The Singapore Stock Exchange experienced a downturn due to a surge in Covid-19 cases in Hubei province, China. A new diagnosis method revealed a sharp increase in infected cases and fatalities, denting investor sentiment. This development, a major concern for markets, led to a decline in investor confidence, with AxiCorp's chief market strategist Stephen Innes stating that the update was a "ton of bricks" to the market.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Singapore companies reported varied quarterly results, with Prime US Reit seeing better-than-expected results and Lum Chang Holdings' net profit rising 34.3% year-on-year. Hi-P International's fourth-quarter net profit halved to S$22.4 million, while UG Healthcare Corp's half-year net profit declined 35.9% due to the Covid-19 epidemic. The Hour Glass' third-quarter net profit rose 1.5% year-on-year. Market fluctuations also affected other companies, including Creative Technology, which warned of potentially lower second-half revenue.

site_title: Developers explore new ideas to market projects safely amid outbreak
summary: Developers in Singapore are exploring digital solutions to market residential projects safely amid the Covid-19 outbreak. They are using 3D video walkthroughs, online marketing, and digital balloting to minimize risks. Some developers have reduced gallery visiting hours, while others are offering virtual showflats and digital signing of documents. However, most buyers still prefer to visit showflats before making a purchase, and some projects, like OLÁ Residences, are going ahead with full-scale launches, including interactive sales galleries and carnival-like atmospheres.

site_title: New party boss in China's Hubei pledges to contain coronavirus
summary: China's new Communist Party chief in Hubei province, Ying Yong, pledges to contain the coronavirus outbreak, despite the situation remaining severe. Ying, who took over after the dismissal of previous officials, vowed to defend Wuhan and Hubei, and prevent and control the disease. The central government has set up a special task force to handle the crisis, and Ying's appointment suggests greater control by senior leaders. The virus has killed over 1,000 and infected tens of thousands across China, with analysts criticizing the initial delay in raising the alarm.

site_title: British finance minister quits in reshuffle upset
summary: British Finance Minister Sajid Javid resigned on Thursday, in a surprise move amid a Cabinet reshuffle just weeks after Brexit. Javid stood down after Prime Minister Boris Johnson tried to remove some of his aides, a source said. Javid was replaced by Treasury official Rishi Sunak. The move comes at a turbulent time for Britain, with an uncertain future after leaving the EU. Johnson's decision has been seen as a blow to his government, with other senior ministers also being removed from their positions.

site_title: What's Up This Week
summary: Hollywood's critically-acclaimed film "Nina Wu," a #metoo drama about a Taiwanese actress's personal experience in the film industry, is set to get a general theatrical release on Feb 20. Meanwhile, pianist Kun-Woo Paik performs romantic Schumann pieces at the Victoria Concert Hall on Feb 14, while Kenny G returns to Singapore for a one-night-only concert on Feb 18. Valentine's Day is also marked by a special gift from Roku Gin, featuring a floral bouquet and bottle of Japanese gin, and a dinner date with chef Kishon Chong at Cookyn Inc on Feb 22.

site_title: SIAEC to acquire 49% stake in Malaysian firm PAES for RM10m
summary: SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) is acquiring a 49% stake in Pos Aviation Engineering Services (PAES) in Malaysia for RM10.1 million (S$3.4 million). The acquisition will expand SIAEC's network to 46 airports in nine countries, offering a complete MRO solution to customers in the region. The deal is not expected to impact SIAEC's earnings per share or net tangible assets per share for the financial year ending March 31, 2020.

site_title: The M braves virus outbreak with preview
summary: Wing Tai Asia has opened a public preview for its latest development, The M condominium in Bugis, Singapore, with indicative pricing ranging from S$2,200 to S$2,400 per sq ft. The 522-unit project, set to be completed in 2024, offers studio, one- and two-bedroom units, as well as three-bedroom dual-key apartments. The developer has introduced health and safety measures due to the COVID-19 outbreak, and expects to gauge buyers' response before announcing the sales launch date and unit allocation. The project's location in the Ophir-Rochor Corridor is considered a key selling point.

site_title: Battling Covid-19 - Stay healthy, keep calm, and carry on spending at home
summary: The COVID-19 outbreak is affecting Singapore's economy, with potential damages including a 25-30% decline in international visitor arrivals and disruptions to manufacturing supply chains. To mitigate the impact, residents are encouraged to stay healthy, keep calm, and continue spending at home. Domestic consumption can support local businesses, particularly those in the hospitality, food and beverage, and retail sectors. The government and healthcare community are urging residents to take staycations and support local eateries, while also considering online shopping with local retailers to reduce the economic toll.

site_title: SBS Transit posts 1.5% rise in full-year net profit of S$81.3m
summary: SBS Transit reported a 1.5% rise in full-year net profit to S$81.3 million, driven by a 4.5% increase in revenue to S$1.45 billion. Operating costs rose 4.3% due to higher repairs and maintenance costs. Revenue from public transport services and other commercial services also increased. However, the company expects lower ridership due to the novel coronavirus outbreak, which may impact future earnings.

site_title: Special Feature: Natural Beauty Through Science
summary: Illumia Therapeutics offers customized beauty solutions in luxurious surroundings, focusing on natural beauty through science-based therapies and medical-grade protocols. The company's personalized approach combines different technologies, such as Dual Ultrasound FACE and Collagen Induction RF, to target various skin concerns. Illumia also provides body sculpting treatments, including TESLAForte and ACCENTForte, and feminine care solutions, like FioreCARE, which addresses vaginal health issues. With its state-of-the-art facilities and experienced consultants, Illumia aims to deliver rejuvenated skin, a sculpted body, and optimal feminine care.

site_title: Pound rallies as Javid resignation prompts fiscal speculation
summary: The British pound rallied 0.6% to a new high of $1.3040 after Chancellor Sajid Javid resigned, sparking speculation of increased fiscal stimulus under new Chancellor Rishi Sunak. The yield on UK 10-year government bonds rose 4 basis points to 0.65%. Analysts note the long-term implications of changes to British government spending remain unclear, and the move in UK government bonds may be overly hasty.

site_title: A Home to Grow Into
summary: A couple commissioned Goy Architects to design their two-bedroom apartment in Bukit Batok, prioritizing flexibility for future needs, such as a growing family. The result is a "soft" and comfortable space with curved archways, vault-like ceilings, and a mix of materials like teak wood and rattan. The home's layout accommodates their current lifestyle while allowing for potential changes. The couple praises the space, particularly the living area and bedroom, where they can relax and be close together. The design creates a sense of comfort, texture, and volume, making it a home that can "grow" with them.

images.alt_text: Light is thrown upwards and downwards to make the space feel bigger.
The vault-like feel of the common spaces.
In the common spaces are a series of curved ceilings.
Olive green cabinets add colour.
This shelf with plants doubles as a screen.
View of the living room.
The terrazzo bar counter.
The archway looking out onto the living room.

site_title: Alibaba warns of drop in e-commerce revenues due to coronavirus
summary: Alibaba warned of a drop in e-commerce revenues due to the coronavirus outbreak in China, citing supply chain disruptions and delayed deliveries. Despite beating analyst estimates, the company expects a decline in revenues from its physical goods businesses. However, CEO Daniel Zhang noted a surge in demand for goods from Hema supermarkets and a rebound in logistics networks. Alibaba's cloud computing business is expected to lead the company to a more positive outlook.

site_title: First Sponsor launches, prices S$100m in 3.29% notes due 2025
summary: First Sponsor Group launched and priced S$100 million in 3.29% notes due 2025, with Wells Spring Pte Ltd subscribing to 13% of the issuance. Net proceeds will be used for general corporate purposes, including refinancing and financing investments. The notes are direct, unconditional, and unsecured obligations ranking pari passu with other unsecured obligations. The offering is expected to be issued on Feb 20 and listed on the next market day, with DBS Bank appointed as sole dealer.

site_title: Experts fear China reluctant to accept WHO ground mission
summary: China is delaying the deployment of a full international team to investigate the origin and spread of the COVID-19 virus, despite a pledge from Chinese President Xi Jinping two weeks ago. The WHO's advance team arrived in Beijing four days ago, but no details have been released on the composition or scope of the full mission. Experts are concerned that Chinese authorities may not accept international experts, potentially limiting their ability to verify crucial information about the epidemic's trajectory.

site_title: F&B players seek rebates as some face imminent closure from outbreak
summary: The Restaurant Association of Singapore (RAS) has urged major landlords to offer 50% rental rebates to F&B tenants until April due to a 80% decline in takings following the Covid-19 outbreak. With 200,000 jobs at risk, RAS president Vincent Tan has approached 24 landlords, including CapitaLand and Frasers, for assistance. Some landlords, such as Jewel Changi Airport, have already offered 50% rent rebates. Analysts predict high-end restaurants will be the most affected, with mass-market options and food courts likely to be more resilient.

site_title: US: Wall St slips from record levels at open on fears over new coronavirus case count
summary: US stocks slipped from record highs at the open on February 13, 2020, due to concerns over the growing coronavirus outbreak in China. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 115.39 points, the S&P 500 opened 13.55 points lower, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 68.92 points. Investors sought safe-haven assets amid the sharp increase in deaths and cases related to the outbreak.

site_title: IReit Global explores ways to raise Spanish portfolio's occupancy rate
summary: IReit Global plans to boost the occupancy rate of its Spanish portfolio by leveraging the network and local presence of its joint venture partner Tikehau Capital. The goal is to bring under-rented properties to market levels through active asset management. This move aims to increase the portfolio's occupancy rate, without providing specific targets or timelines for the initiative.

site_title: GrabWheels raises US$30m in ongoing Series A round
summary: GrabWheels, the mobility arm of ride-hailing giant Grab, has raised US$30 million in a Series A round led by Taiwan's electric vehicle leader Kwang Yang Motor Co (KYMCO). The partnership aims to accelerate the adoption of electric vehicles in South-east Asia, deploying KYMCO's Ionex electric bikes and charging platforms in Grab-operating cities. The collaboration will also focus on developing a shared two-wheeler EV service and building electric charging infrastructure.

site_title: Chasen moves to buy out Malaysian warehouse firm's other shareholder
summary: Chasen Holdings has agreed to buy the remaining 30% stake in Malaysian warehouse company City Zone Express Bonded Warehouse Sdn Bhd for RM375,000 (S$125,600). The deal is part of Chasen's strategic plan to enhance its long-term growth in the Malaysian warehousing market. The transaction is expected to have minimal impact on Chasen's financials, with no material effect on net tangible assets and earnings per share.

site_title: Lessons in rebuilding reputation for Boeing
summary: Boeing expects a $19 billion economic cost from its two fatal plane crashes, its first annual loss in 20 years, and has confirmed the departure of its president and CEO, Dennis Muilenburg. The company's new CEO, Dave Calhoun, faces a daunting task in rebuilding the company's reputation. To succeed, Calhoun must conduct a thorough review and overhaul of Boeing's operations, restore internal pride, and restore confidence with regulators, customers, and shareholders. The new CEO should be seen to be proactive, humble, and independent, with a commitment to partnership and culture change.

site_title: Rents lift US core inflation
summary: US underlying consumer prices rose 0.2% in January, driven by increases in accommodation, apparel, and healthcare costs. The core CPI, excluding volatile food and energy components, increased 2.3% for the 12th consecutive month, meeting the Federal Reserve's 2% inflation target. Unemployment claims rose 2,000 to 205,000 for the week ended Feb 8, with the four-week moving average remaining unchanged. The Fed is expected to keep interest rates on hold this year, citing a stable economy.

site_title: Overseas Education posts 16% rise in FY2019 net profit of S$8m
summary: Overseas Education Ltd reported a 16% increase in FY2019 net profit to S$8 million, driven by amortisation of intangible assets. Revenue declined 0.9% to S$79.6 million due to lower student enrolment in the first half of 2019. The company recommended a final dividend of S$0.0275 per share, unchanged from the previous year. Despite this, the company's shares rose by 1.43% to S$0.355 following the announcement.

site_title: Traveloka-backed PouchNATION extends Series B round to TIX ID
summary: Traveloka-backed PouchNATION has extended its Series B round to TIX ID, an Indonesian online cinema tickets platform, with partners including Singapore Press Holdings' venture arm SPH Ventures. The partnership aims to offer event tickets on TIX ID's platform starting March 2020. PouchNATION will utilize TIX ID's 5 million monthly active users to expand its presence in the events space and venue business, solidifying its leadership position in the region.

site_title: In Norway, bottles made of plastic are still fantastic
summary: Norway has achieved a 97% recycling rate of plastic bottles, 10 years ahead of the EU's 2029 target of 90%. The country's success is attributed to a deposit system, where customers pay a few extra cents for plastic bottles and receive a refund when returning empties. This system has led to over 1.1 billion plastic bottles and cans being returned in 2018. The Norwegian recycling industry aims to increase the use of recycled plastic, promoting a "clean loop" recycling process where waste becomes a valuable resource.

site_title: Endless Time
summary: Blancpain's Saint-Valentin watch, inspired by Marilyn Monroe, is a 14-piece limited edition featuring 84 diamonds and a mother-of-pearl dial. Swatch's Valentine's Special is a whimsical red watch with emojis on its calendar wheel. Franck Muller's Vanguard Lady Heart Skeleton and Master Banker Skeleton timepieces are designed for unconventional couples, featuring hand-painted red hearts and skeletonised mechanical movements. Tissot's T-Wave Bicolour is a stylish quartz watch for women, while Piaget's Possession is a diamond-set timepiece representing love. Chopard's L'Heure du Diamant and Breguet's Classique 9065 Tahitian Mother-of-Pearl Tender Dreams are also featured, along with a limited edition Harry Winston watch.

images.alt_text: BLANCPAIN: SAINT-VALENTIN 2020 (left). CHOPARD: L'HEURE DU DIAMANT (right).
SWATCH: VALENTINE'S SPECIAL
FRANCK MULLER: VANGUARD LADY HEART SKELETON AND MASTER BANKER SKELETON
TISSOT: T-WAVE BICOLOUR
PIAGET: POSSESSION (left). BREGUET: CLASSIQUE 9065 TAHITIAN MOTHER-OF-PEARL TENDER DREAMS (right).
HARRY WINSTON: PRECIOUS VALENTINE'S DAY

site_title: Chaswood Resources to hold scheme of arrangement vote by Apr 30
summary: Chaswood Resources Holdings, a food and beverage operator, has received permission from the High Court to hold a creditors' vote on its scheme of arrangement by April 30. The company must notify creditors at least four weeks in advance and pay the costs of the meeting from its assets. Businessman Ng Teck Wah has been required to stay out of decisions on the scheme until he resigns from Tremendous Asia Management Inc's board. The court's order prevents legal action against the company until the scheme is approved.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: DBS reported a 14% net profit boost to S$1.51 billion in Q4 2020, surpassing market expectations. Singtel's Q3 profit fell 23.8% to S$627.2m due to weaker enterprise performance. Colliers warns of near-term downside risks to Singapore's retail and industrial markets, but stabilisation is expected. The Singapore F&B industry group seeks rental rebates to cope with the Covid-19 outbreak. CapitaLand rolls out a S$10m marketing plan to support retailers.

site_title: UnUsUaL posts 15.5% rise in Q3 net profit of S$3.52m
summary: UnUsUaL Ltd, a concert promotion and event production spin-off of mm2 Asia, reported a 15.5% increase in Q3 net profit to S$3.52 million, driven by a 66.4% surge in revenue. However, the company's earnings were partially eroded by increased costs. Despite this, net asset value rose to 6.07 Singapore cents, and the company warned that the ongoing Covid-19 outbreak may impact its performance. No dividend was recommended, as the company continues to grow its businesses.

site_title: Singapore banks roll out relief assistance for SMEs, retail customers
summary: Singapore banks OCBC, DBS, and UOB have introduced relief measures to support SMEs and retail customers affected by the Covid-19 outbreak. These measures include loan restructuring, principal repayment moratoriums, and extended due dates for trade finance bills. DBS will also partner with ComfortDelGro to encourage commuters to use its cards for street hail fares. UOB has set aside S$3 billion for relief assistance, while OCBC will offer targeted support to customers in Singapore, Malaysia, China, Hong Kong, and Macau.

site_title: Singapore banks roll out virus relief measures for SMEs, retail customers
summary: Singapore banks DBS, OCBC, and Standard Chartered have rolled out virus relief measures for SMEs and retail customers, including loan restructurings, principal moratoriums, and extensions of loan tenors. These measures aim to help businesses and individuals manage cash flow during the Covid-19 outbreak. DBS will provide a six-month principal repayment moratorium for SME property loans, while OCBC will offer targeted support to customers across affected markets. Standard Chartered will consider loan tenor extensions and principal moratoria for affected clients.

images.alt_text: As the Covid-19 outbreak continues to rattle the region, Singapore banks have stepped in with relief measures to help businesses and retail customers.

site_title: ISOTeam posts 24% rise in Q2 net profit of S$1.65m
summary: ISOTeam, a CATALIST-LISTED building solutions company, reported a 24.1% year-on-year increase in Q2 net profit to S$1.65 million, driven by government grants and a 31.7% rise in half-year net profit to S$2.8 million. Revenue slid 22.6% to S$35.5 million, while earnings per share rose to 0.58 Singapore cents. The company's order book stood at S$133.3 million for the next two years, and CEO Anthony Koh expressed optimism about future growth plans.

site_title: Japan reports its first death from coronavirus
summary: Japan reported its first death from the novel coronavirus, a woman in her 80s, with no travel records to Wuhan, China. The death marks the third fatality outside mainland China. There are at least 247 confirmed cases in Japan, primarily on the Diamond Princess cruise ship. Authorities are investigating how the woman contracted the virus.

site_title: The Hour Glass posts 1.5% rise in Q3 net profit of S$18.6m
summary: The Hour Glass, a luxury watch dealer, reported a 1.5% year-on-year rise in Q3 net profit to S$18.6 million, driven by a 4.7% increase in revenue to S$197.8 million. The company expects to be profitable for the full year despite the Covid-19 outbreak worsening global uncertainties. Net asset value rose to 84 cents per share, and no dividend was recommended. The company's shares closed at S$0.78, up 1.3% before the results were released.

site_title: KOP narrows Q3 losses to S$513,000 on 33.6% revenue rise
summary: KOP, a Catalist-listed hotel and resort developer, reported narrowed losses of S$513,000 in Q3 2020, up 84.5% from Q3 2019, despite a 33.6% revenue increase to S$6.28 million. The company attributed the improvement to consultancy income and better performance of Montigo Resorts. For the nine months, KOP recorded a net profit of S$30,000, up from a loss of S$5.48 million in the same period last year. The company's shares rose 11.36% to S$0.049.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close the day lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed lower on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index dipping 0.34% due to investor fears about the coronavirus outbreak in China. China reported a rise in deaths and infections, affecting the Shanghai Composite Index, which fell 0.71%. The Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 0.77%. The decline was attributed to concerns about the impact of the outbreak on the global economy.

site_title: Coronavirus: 8 new cases in Singapore, including 5 more linked to Grace Assembly church
summary: Singapore reported 8 new coronavirus cases, bringing the total to 58, with 5 linked to the Grace Assembly of God church, including a NUS professor. The cases include 2 previously announced ones and 4 new cases linked to the church and a Seletar Aerospace Heights worksite. None of the new cases has recent travel history to China, and all are currently in isolation. The Ministry of Health will continue to rely on laboratory tests to confirm cases, despite changes in China's diagnostic guidelines.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower with markets nervous on virus impact
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on February 13, 2020, due to concerns over the impact of the new coronavirus on the economy. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.14% and the Topix index dropped 0.34%. Chinese authorities reported a spike in fatalities and new cases, weighing on market sentiment. Japanese investors are more sensitive to short-term economic impacts, worrying about supply chain disruptions, according to analysts.

site_title: Silverlake Axis posts 21.8% drop in Q2 net profit to RM52.8m
summary: Silverlake Axis reported a 21.8% drop in Q2 net profit to RM52.8 million, despite a 12.8% increase in revenue to RM190.7 million. The company attributed the decline to higher costs, including finance costs and selling and distribution expenses. However, it won four contracts worth RM60 million with banking customers, expected to contribute positively to its results. The company remains cautious about the business environment but expects recurring revenue to continue growing.

site_title: Challenger Tech posts 11.6% fall in Q4 net profit of S$5.07m
summary: Challenger Technologies, a consumer electronics retailer, reported a 11.6% year-on-year decline in Q4 net profit to S$5.07 million, driven by a 1.1% drop in revenue to S$83 million. The company attributed the decline to lower contributions from retail operations, despite growth in corporate, trade show, and online sales. For the full year, net profit fell 9.4% to S$17.6 million. The board recommended a final dividend of 1.5 Singapore cents a share, down from 3.1 cents in the previous year, citing uncertainty in the market outlook and global economic slowdown.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 3.78 points to 1,539.16. Volume reached 2.7 billion lots worth RM2.3 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 452 to 361.

site_title: As China needs virus masks, phone and diaper makers fill void
summary: China is rapidly converting manufacturers to produce face masks amid a deadly virus epidemic, with companies like New Yifa Group and BYD producing up to 600,000 and five million masks daily, respectively. The shortage of medical equipment has prompted authorities to urge factories to chip in, with some manufacturers postponing orders to focus on mask production. Despite efforts, a serious shortage of masks and protective supplies remains, with doctors on the front line resorting to reusing equipment.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks finish lower as surge in virus cases hits sentiment
summary: South Korean stocks ended lower on Thursday due to a surge in virus cases in China's Hubei province, which reported a record 242 deaths and 14,840 new cases. The KOSPI closed 5.42 points lower, or 0.24%, at 2,232.96. The won weakened, while the benchmark bond yield remained unchanged. Foreigners were net buyers of $233.59 million worth of shares, despite the decline in the local market.

site_title: Sats posts 14% fall in Q3 net profit of S$59.3m
summary: SATS, a mainboard-listed aviation services provider, reported a 13.9% year-on-year decline in third-quarter net profit to S$59.3 million, despite a 17.6% revenue growth to S$545.6 million. The decline was attributed to higher staff and raw material costs, while the company warned that the Covid-19 outbreak may impact its short-term financial performance. The company also noted that it has enhanced its revenue base with recent investments in overseas kitchens and ground handling investments in Asia.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets slide at open
summary: European stock markets slid at the open on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.8%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 down 0.3%, and Paris's CAC 40 down 0.5%. The decline was attributed to bank and healthcare sector losses. The US-EU trade tensions remained a focus, with investors watching for updates on the ongoing trade talks. Despite this, other markets, such as Singapore, saw gains, with stocks rallying for a fifth consecutive day.

site_title: UG Healthcare posts 36% fall in H1 net profit despite revenue rise
summary: UG Healthcare Corp reported a 35.9% year-on-year decline in net profit to S$846,000 for the six months to Dec 31, 2019, despite a 28.5% revenue rise to S$53.2 million. The decline was due to increased administrative expenses and higher finance costs. Production line upgrades, initially planned for 2019, have been delayed by the Covid-19 epidemic. The company remains on track to achieve its annual production capacity goal and plans to expand its marketing and distribution infrastructure.

site_title: Edtech accelerator EduSpaze picks 9 startups as its first cohort
summary: EduSpaze, an edtech accelerator, has selected 9 startups from 25 countries for its inaugural cohort. Seven are from Singapore, while two are from Australia and Malaysia. The selected startups will receive up to S$500,000 in funding and a customized accelerator program, mentor support, and a live sandbox environment. The 100-day program will focus on market fit, product development, and scalability. Evaluations will be conducted by Education Alliance Finland, providing startups with evidence-based suggestions to improve their products.

site_title: Wing Tai to preview The M condo this weekend
summary: Wing Tai Asia will open The M condominium in Singapore's Ophir-Rochor Corridor for public preview this weekend. The 522-unit project, set to be completed in 2024, features studio, one- and two-bedroom units with prices starting from "just below" S$1 million. The development boasts a retail component, a "novel home/work concept" for studios and one-bedrooms, and is close to major MRT stations and hubs. The M is expected to appeal to investors and homebuyers, including creative professionals and gig workers.

site_title: Hi-P International posts 50% slide in Q4 net profit of S$22.4m
summary: Hi-P International, a contract manufacturer, reported a 50% slide in Q4 net profit to S$22.4m, down from S$44.8m in the same period last year. Revenue fell 10.2% to S$396.9m due to price pressures and lower sales volume. The company's earnings per share and net asset value also declined. Hi-P attributed the decline to the impact of the Covid-19 outbreak on its Chinese manufacturing plants and a shift in customer demand. The company has guided for higher revenue but lower profit in FY2020.

site_title: Outbreak poses near-term downside risks to Singapore's retail, industrial markets: Colliers
summary: Singapore's retail and industrial property markets face near-term downside risks due to the escalating Covid-19 outbreak. Research by Colliers International suggests both markets are showing signs of stabilizing but vulnerable, with retail sales remaining fragile. Rents are expected to stabilize and recover gradually, but consumer sentiment may be dampened by the outbreak. The industrial market is also under pressure, with factory rents falling 1.8% year-on-year, and the virus could disrupt the global supply chain.

site_title: Lum Chang posts 34.3% rise in Q2 net profit of S$4.04m
summary: Lum Chang Holdings reported a 34.3% year-on-year increase in Q2 net profit to S$4.04 million, driven by more construction work, bank interest income, and currency gains. Revenue more than doubled to S$92.9 million. The company's half-year net profit jumped 77.4% to S$7.04 million. Lum Chang warned of uncertainty due to the global Covid-19 outbreak affecting its full-year financial results, recommending an unchanged interim dividend of 0.3 Singapore cents per share.

site_title: Singapore shares slip as Covid-19 cases surge in Hubei province
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) slipped 0.1% to 3,220.09, despite a 3.28-point gain in the morning session, following a surge in Covid-19 cases in Hubei province. Markets in Asia-Pacific were mixed, with China, Japan, and Hong Kong ending lower, while Australia and Taiwan gained. The increase in Hubei cases led to concerns about a bigger-than-expected crisis, affecting investor sentiment.

site_title: Trip.com seeking US$1.2b loan in funding test amid outbreak
summary: Trip.com Group Ltd, China's largest online travel service provider, is seeking a US$1.2 billion loan to refinance and boost working capital amid the coronavirus outbreak. The company is in talks with international and Chinese lenders, following its last loan of US$2 billion in 2019. The loan comes as the leisure industry faces challenges, with over 50 countries imposing travel restrictions and tightened visa requirements.

site_title: Twitter's upcoming engineering centre in Singapore to create 65 technical roles
summary: Twitter is building its first engineering centre in Asia-Pacific, based in Singapore, and will hire 65 technical roles, including product engineering, software engineering, and data science. The centre aims to boost global engineering capabilities and improve service availability for Twitter users worldwide. This marks another milestone in Twitter's partnership with Digital Industry Singapore, following the company's establishment of its international data science team in Singapore in 2016.

site_title: Credit Suisse CEO Thiam sees investment bank loss weigh on results
summary: Credit Suisse CEO Tidjane Thiam's final results as CEO show a pretax loss of about $61 million at the investment bank, worse than expected, while the global markets business saw a profit rebound that fell short of forecasts. This marks a pattern of unpredictable earnings during Thiam's tenure, overshadowing gains in the private banking unit. Thiam's restructuring efforts have shown signs of success, but recent scandals have raised concerns. Despite this, Thiam remains confident about the bank's start to the year, citing improved results and a "flying start."

site_title: SIAEC to acquire 49% stake in aviation engineering company for RM10m
summary: SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) is acquiring a 49% stake in Pos Aviation Engineering Services (PAES) for RM10.1 million. PAES, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Pos Malaysia Berhad, will retain the remaining 51% stake. The acquisition expands SIAEC's network to 46 airports in nine countries, offering a complete MRO solution to international airline customers in Malaysia. The investment is expected to contribute to future growth and revenue expansion, but is not expected to have a material impact on SIAEC's earnings.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher on financials; virus concerns weigh
summary: Australian shares ended higher on Thursday, driven by gains in financial stocks, despite concerns over the new coronavirus cases in China. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed 0.2% higher at 7,103.2, after National Australia Bank rose 1.4% on a potential share sale and revamped strategy. However, the index pulled back from a record peak, with New Zealand's benchmark slightly lower. The coronavirus is a major market consideration, with every major market in the region experiencing losses.

site_title: US$45b cruise industry faces big challenge amid outbreak
summary: The US$45.6 billion global cruise industry faces significant challenges amid the COVID-19 outbreak, with ships quarantined in Japan and the US, and travelers being turned away from ports. The industry's biggest lines, including Norwegian Cruise Lines and Carnival Corp, have seen bookings decline by 10-15% in the US. Cruise companies are prioritizing passenger safety, but uncommunicative and unhelpful customer service is causing frustration among passengers. The outbreak could affect customer confidence in China towards cruises for a long time, with China being one of the travel industry's biggest growth markets.

site_title: Singapore F&B industry group seeks rental rebates to ride out Covid-19 storm
summary: The Restaurant Association of Singapore (RAS) has requested rental rebates from major landlords to help its members cope with the 80% drop in sales amid the Covid-19 outbreak. The association, representing 450 members and 700 brands, has sent written requests to 24 landlords, with Jewel Changi offering a 50% rental rebate for February and March. Without immediate help, RAS fears closures of outlets will be imminent, prompting the association to also discuss labor cost assistance with the government.

site_title: Impact of coronavirus epidemic to have widespread spillovers to the region and rest of the world
summary: The coronavirus epidemic is expected to have widespread spillovers to the region and rest of the world, with the ASEAN+3 growth forecast to be deducted 0.2 percentage points. The regional economy will be impacted by a sharp drop in Chinese outbound travel and tourism, a decline in regional travel and tourism, and transmission of the virus to regional economies. Financial markets saw significant falls in yields, with tourism-related and energy stocks weakening the most, while healthcare stocks gained. The materials sector also responded negatively, with countries like Hong Kong, Korea, and Thailand among the worst hit.

site_title: Hong Kong extends suspension of schools till at least March 16
