summary: Hong Kong has extended the suspension of schools until at least March 16 to contain the spread of the coronavirus, with 50 confirmed cases in the city. The suspension, initially set to end on March 2, will now keep students away from lessons until mid-March.

site_title: Broker's take: Maybank KE ups Prime US Reit's target price, reiterates 'buy'
summary: Maybank KE has raised its target price for Prime US Reit to US$1.10, reiterating a "buy" call following the Reit's better-than-expected quarterly and yearly results. The move also comes after Prime US Reit announced its maiden proposed acquisition of Park Towers in Sacramento, California. As of 1:14pm on Thursday, Prime US Reit units were trading at US$1.03, up one US cent or 1 per cent on a cum-dividend basis.

site_title: LTA awards 3 contracts worth S$596m for future Jurong Region Line
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) awarded three civil contracts worth S$596 million to design and construct four Jurong Region Line (JRL) stations and associated viaducts. Chip Eng Seng Corporation, a Mainboard-listed company, secured the largest contract valued at S$226.6 million. The contracts are expected to contribute positively to Chip Eng Seng's net tangible assets and earnings per share for the current financial year.

site_title: PSA Marine acquires Peru port services firm
summary: PSA Marine, a subsidiary of Singapore's PSA International, has acquired the entire stake in Tramarsa Flota, a Peruvian port services firm. Tramarsa Flota provides towage, pilotage, and other services in 10 Peruvian ports, owning 45 vessels. This acquisition strengthens PSA Marine's international towage and pilotage network, expanding its operations to 70 tugs in Peru, Bangladesh, and other regions. The deal does not disclose the acquisition value.

site_title: Google's US$2.6b Looker deal cleared by UK regulator
summary: Google's US$2.6 billion acquisition of Looker Data Sciences has been cleared by the UK's antitrust authority. The Competition and Markets Authority deemed the deal unlikely to weaken competition, as Google would not stifle its rivals. The purchase aims to boost Google's cloud offering, which lags behind Amazon and Microsoft. The deal was initially intended for last year but has been pushed forward to expand Google's data management tools. The UK's decision joins US regulators in declining an in-depth review of the acquisition.

images.alt_text: The UK's antitrust authority cleared Google's US$2.6 billion takeover of Looker Data Sciences, joining US regulators in declining to open an in-depth review.

site_title: China replaces head of its Hong Kong and Macau affairs office
summary: China has replaced the head of its Hong Kong and Macau affairs office, Zhang Xiaoming, with Xia Baolong, following months of anti-government protests in Hong Kong. The move aims to address the unrest, which has seen mass marches, vandalism, and disruptions to the city's transport networks. The protests, which began in June, led to the withdrawal of a highly unpopular extradition bill and pressure on the local government. The change is seen as a significant move by China to assert control over the territory.

site_title: The matchmaker of Beijing: Grandfather plays cupid for generations
summary: In Beijing, 75-year-old matchmaker Zhu Fang has been uniting lonely hearts for nearly 50 years, despite a decline in marriage rates and a patriarchal society. With hundreds of headshots of hopeful singles on his walls, Zhu charges a one-off 200 yuan membership fee to connect middle-aged parents with suitable spouses for their adult children. His clients, mainly elderly people, seek face-to-face connections, as Zhu believes online dating lacks trust. With over 1,700 couples matched, Zhu remains in demand, despite the changing social landscape and rising expectations of his clients.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon down 0.29% after virus tally spikes
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index declined 9.23 points, or 0.29%, to 3,214.14 at 1:02pm, as investors reacted to a spike in Covid-19 cases in China's Hubei province. The market saw 757.3 million securities worth S$556.5 million trade, with losers outnumbering gainers 175 to 155. The decline follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, which may provide further insights into the market's performance.

site_title: CapitaLand rolls out S$10m marketing plan, shorter hours to help retailers amid outbreak
summary: CapitaLand has rolled out a S$10 million marketing plan and adjusted mall hours to support retailers affected by the Covid-19 outbreak in Singapore. Stores will operate from 11am to 8pm, while a marketing assistance program will provide funding for promotions and mall-wide initiatives. The company has also pledged S$300,000 to support patients and healthcare workers affected by the outbreak.

site_title: Broker's take: UOB Kay Hian re-initiates coverage on Wing Tai with 'buy'
summary: UOB Kay Hian has re-initiated coverage on Wing Tai Holdings with a "buy" recommendation, setting a target price of S$2.54. The property developer reported a 61% increase in Q2 net profit despite a 10.2% drop in revenue. Analysts praise Wing Tai's strong balance sheet, low risk, and resilient earnings, citing its joint ventures with Uniqlo and improving margins. They also expect the Singapore residential property business to improve due to pent-up demand and foreign investment.

site_title: 44 more coronavirus cases on Japan ship: health minister
summary: Japan's health minister announced 44 more coronavirus cases on the Diamond Princess cruise ship, bringing the total to 218, including a quarantine officer. Authorities plan to move elderly passengers off the ship if they test negative for the virus, offering government lodging.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed after spike in coronavirus cases
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Thursday following a spike in coronavirus cases in mainland China, with the nationwide death toll reaching 1,355 and infection count nearing 60,000. Despite this, some markets, such as Sydney and Seoul, rose, while others, like Tokyo, remained steady. The jump in China's numbers "has initially hit like a ton of bricks," but experts suggest it may be due to a testing backlog being cleared. The World Health Organization has praised China's handling of the outbreak, but concerns about the scale of the problem persist.

images.alt_text: Asian markets were mixed on Thursday after a dramatic spike in the number of coronavirus deaths and cases in mainland China, with traders concerned about the scale of the epidemic.

site_title: Audit slams safety US oversight of Southwest Airlines
summary: A new audit has found the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) allowed Southwest Airlines to operate planes in an "unknown airworthiness state," putting 17.2 million passengers at risk. The FAA cleared 88 planes acquired from international airlines between 2014 and 2018 without ensuring they met US safety standards. The airline has since addressed the issue, but the FAA's oversight was criticized for relying on summary data provided by Southwest rather than conducting an independent analysis. The audit comes amid scrutiny of the FAA's certification of the grounded Boeing 737 MAX.

site_title: China removes party chief of virus epicentre province: state media
summary: China has removed Jiang Chaoliang, the party chief of virus-stricken Hubei province, amid growing criticism of local officials' handling of the crisis. Jiang will be replaced by Shanghai mayor Ying Yong. The move comes after two top health officials were sacked earlier in the week. Hubei reported a spike in confirmed cases, raising the nationwide infection total to nearly 60,000. The province's handling of the crisis has been under scrutiny, particularly after the death of a doctor who was punished for raising the alarm about the new virus.

images.alt_text: Jiang Chaoliang, Hubei's party secretary, will be replaced by Shanghai mayor Ying Yong, according to the official Xinhua news agency.

site_title: Amazon's Bezos buys estate for US$165m: report
summary: Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos has purchased a Los Angeles-area estate, the Warner Estate, for $165 million, setting a new record for the region. The 3.6-hectare estate, built in the 1930s, features a Georgian-style compound with a floor once owned by Napoleon, guest houses, a tennis court, and a golf course. The sale tops a previous record of $150 million set by Lachlan Murdoch for a Bel-Air estate. Bezos' purchase is the latest in his vast real estate holdings, which also include The Washington Post and a significant stake in cloud computing giant Amazon.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.47% at open on Thursday, following a positive Wall Street cue, despite a rise in mainland China coronavirus deaths and infections. The Hang Seng Index opened at 27,953.65, while mainland China's Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.06%. The Shenzhen Composite Index also edged down. Investors appeared to shrug off the news, indicating a lack of concern about the outbreak's impact on the markets.

site_title: Australia: Shares pull back from record high as virus tally surges; New Zealand down
summary: Australian shares fell from a record high due to concerns over the coronavirus outbreak, with the S&P/ASX 200 index down 0.2% at 7,098.20. The death toll in China's Hubei province rose to a record, while a forecast that the outbreak may end by April dampened investor sentiment. However, solid corporate results from lenders lifted the index, with National Australia Bank rising 3.5%. The New Zealand benchmark also fell 0.3% after a decline in dairy firm Synlait Milk's forecast.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars burdened by coronavirus confusion
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars experienced volatility on Thursday following China's report of a surge in new coronavirus cases and deaths, sparking concerns about the economic impact of the outbreak. The Aussie initially dropped 20 ticks before steadying, while the kiwi dollar fell 30 ticks before stabilizing. Reserve Bank officials emphasized the need for caution, with the RBNZ switching to a neutral interest rate bias and the RBA Governor expressing concerns about fueling an unwelcome borrowing binge. Markets now price in a 44% probability of a rate cut by year-end.

site_title: Vividthree proposes S$1.9m placement
summary: Vividthree Holdings is proposing a S$1.9 million placement of up to 15.9 million new ordinary shares at a price of at least 12.6 Singapore cents each to strengthen its financial and working capital position.

site_title: China sees hope in coronavirus 'war' as deaths top 1,100
summary: China's coronavirus death toll surpassed 1,100, with 97 new deaths reported on Wednesday, as the country's leadership expressed "positive results" from efforts to contain the outbreak. However, the epidemic is still considered a "large-scale war" and a "big test" for the country, with tens of millions under lockdown. The World Health Organization warned against premature conclusions on the data, citing the need for caution as the outbreak could go in any direction.

site_title: Bank of Singapore appoints chief data and innovation officer
summary: Bank of Singapore has appointed Celine Le Cotonnec as its chief data and innovation officer to boost digital transformation efforts. Le Cotonnec, with over 15 years of experience in business transformation and data analytics, will lead the bank's data strategy and innovation unit. She joins from AXA Insurance Singapore and will report to Bank of Singapore chief executive Bahren Shaari. The appointment aims to unlock new opportunities and deliver actionable insights for clients and business functions, aligning with the bank's digital transformation programme.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower despite US rallies
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday, despite US rallies, as the benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 0.14% to 23,828.31. The death toll from China's new coronavirus surged by 242 in a single day in Hubei province, contributing to the decline. The Topix index also dropped 0.25%.

site_title: Argentina sees 'deep debt restructuring' ahead, rejects fiscal austerity
summary: Argentina is set for a "deep debt restructuring" worth $100 billion, Economy Minister Martin Guzman said, as the country rejects fiscal austerity policies. The government, led by Guzman, will rebuff IMF recommendations, citing an unsustainable debt load inherited from the previous administration. With $44 billion owed to the IMF, bondholders are expected to face frustration. Guzman warned of a difficult path ahead, but expressed a "growing mutual understanding" with the IMF about handling the debt crisis.

site_title: Exit of Indonesia's tech whiz kid is a warning to startups
summary: Achmad Zaky, the 33-year-old CEO of Indonesia's e-commerce startup Bukalapak, has stepped down after losing the board's confidence in his ability to lead the company. Zaky's departure marks a significant shift in South-east Asia's tech scene, where founder-driven startups have dominated growth but often struggled with profitability. The exit is seen as a warning to startups to prioritize sustainability over hyper-growth, with industry observers predicting more CEO exits in the coming years. Zaky's successor, Rachmat Kaimuddin, will focus on turning a profit and expanding the company's operations.

site_title: Australian central bank says not obsessed with getting inflation back to target in a hurry
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) Governor Philip Lowe stated that the central bank is not "obsessed" with achieving its 2-3% inflation target quickly, instead focusing on using record-low interest rates to encourage investment. The RBA cut rates three times last year to 0.75% to stimulate growth and inflation. Lowe emphasized the need for the government and business to invest during this period of low interest rates.

site_title: Trump 'fine' with end of Philippines military pact
summary: US President Donald Trump has expressed acceptance of the Philippines' decision to cancel the 1998 Visiting Forces Agreement (VFA), citing potential cost savings for the US. The agreement, which allowed US troops to be stationed in the Philippines, was set to expire in six months. Trump stated that his "very good relationship" with President Rodrigo Duterte would not be impacted by the decision, despite Duterte's previous threats to end the alliance. The VFA's cancellation has sparked controversy in the Philippines, with critics arguing it would compromise the country's defense capabilities.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher after Wall Street rally; STI up 0.28%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Thursday, following a rally in US markets overnight, with the Straits Times Index gaining 0.28% to 3,232.37. Gainers outnumbered losers 67 to 53, driven by gains from banking stocks like DBS, UOB, and OCBC Bank, as well as Ley Choon Group and OEL (Holdings). The rally follows easing investor worries over the virus outbreak, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.9% and the Nasdaq and S&P 500 also gaining.

site_title: Empty LNG ships at biggest producer show how virus grips market
summary: At least 12 empty liquefied natural gas (LNG) vessels are idle off the coast of Qatar due to the coronavirus outbreak, coinciding with reduced demand in Asia and ship diversions. The vessels, which have returned after delivering cargoes to countries such as India and South Korea, are expected to face potential delays in loading due to record-low Asian spot LNG prices. Analysts have cut their projections for China's LNG demand growth, citing the virus's impact on the region. The situation highlights the market's vulnerability to global events.

site_title: Coronavirus death toll in hard-hit Hubei surges by 242 in a day: government
summary: China's Hubei province reported a surge of 242 coronavirus-related deaths and 14,840 new cases, bringing the nationwide toll to over 1,350. The jump in fatalities was attributed to a broader definition of Covid-19 cases. This increase marks a significant escalation in the outbreak, which emerged in the province in December.

site_title: Australian court backs A$15b Vodafone-TPG merger, overruling regulator
summary: An Australian court approved a $15 billion merger between Vodafone's local arm and TPG Telecom, overruling an earlier regulator's decision to block the deal. The Federal Court ruled that the tie-up would not harm competition, allowing the deal to proceed and challenging the dominance of Telstra and Optus in the Australian market. The decision revives a plan to challenge the market leaders and gives Vodafone's local arm, Hutchison Telecommunications (Australia), a boost.

site_title: US health authority shipped faulty coronavirus test kits across country
summary: US health authorities have shipped faulty coronavirus test kits to labs nationwide, resulting in inconclusive results. The Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) shipped 200 test kits on February 5, but labs reported issues with the kits' reagent. The CDC has remanufactured the reagent and will continue testing at its headquarters in Atlanta. The faulty kits, which can be used 700-800 times, were shipped to 36 countries.

site_title: UK house prices jump by most since 2017 in post-election bounce: RICS
summary: UK house prices surged to a +17 reading in January, the highest since May 2017, driven by a turnaround in London and southeast England. The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors' (RICS) index surpassed economists' forecasts. A majority of surveyors now believe prices in London are rising, and a six-month high in homebuyer demand has been reported. The rebound in consumer sentiment is attributed to the end of Brexit uncertainty and a shift in government policy. Experts caution that this momentum may be short-lived, but for now, they remain optimistic about the market.

site_title: IMF chief sees 'mild' virus impact on global economy
summary: IMF chief Kristalina Georgieva expects the economic impact of the virus outbreak in China to be "mild" with a "V-shaped impact," a sharp decline followed by a recovery. The global economy is still relatively strong compared to the 2003 Sars outbreak, and China's economy is projected to grow 6.0% this year, down from 10% in 2003. US officials, including Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell, also express confidence in a short-term impact on the American economy.

site_title: DBS sees 1-2% revenue impact in 2020 on Covid-19 outbreak
summary: DBS Group expects a 1-2% revenue impact in 2020 due to the Covid-19 outbreak, with provisions potentially rising by a few basis points of loans. The bank's CEO, Piyush Gupta, believes the virus may be controlled by summer, similar to the 2003 Sars crisis. Despite a confirmed case of Covid-19 at one of its offices, DBS reported a 14% boost in net profit to S$1.51 billion in the fourth quarter, with a recommended final quarterly dividend of 33 cents per share. The bank also announced support measures for customers, including a six-month moratorium on principal repayment for SME property loans and mortgage loans.

site_title: Trudeau calls for end to protests crippling Canada railways
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau called for an end to protests disrupting Canada's railways, which have forced the cancellation of hundreds of trains. The protests, led by indigenous hereditary chiefs, are against a natural gas pipeline through their traditional lands. Trudeau urged dialogue to resolve the situation, while opposition leader Jagmeet Singh called for Trudeau to meet with the chiefs. The disruptions have impacted over 24,000 passengers and threatened to shut down significant parts of the Canadian rail network.

site_title: Netherlands says it rejected Moscow offer for MH17 prosecution
summary: The Netherlands has rejected an offer from Russia to prosecute three men suspected of involvement in the 2014 downing of Malaysia Airlines flight MH17. The Dutch justice minister stated that Russia's request for the transfer of the criminal prosecution to Russia was not considered. The trial of the four suspects, three of whom are Russian, is set to take place in absentia on March 9 in the Netherlands. The suspects face charges of murder for their alleged role in the downing of the Boeing 777, which killed all 298 on board.

site_title: US: Stocks close at records, brushing off virus fears
summary: US stocks closed at record highs on Wednesday, despite concerns over the COVID-19 virus outbreak in China. The death toll surpassed 1,100, but new cases fell for a second day, raising hopes the outbreak may peak later this month. Analysts say it will take time for China to get consumers and businesses back to full operating mode.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, Singtel, UOB, Genting, Sembcorp, SIA, SIA Engg, Thomson Medical
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

Several Singaporean companies reported financial results, with DBS Group posting a 14% increase in net profit to S$1.51 billion for the fourth quarter. Singtel saw a 23.8% decline in net profit to S$627.2 million, while UOB set aside S$3 billion to assist Singapore companies affected by the Covid-19 outbreak. Genting Singapore reported a 4% increase in net profit to S$156 million, and Sembcorp Industries announced plans to build 20,000 solar panels for SIA and SIAEC. Thomson Medical Group narrowed its losses in the fourth quarter, and Thomson Medical shares fell 1.67% to S$0.059.

site_title: EU seeks better coordination to tackle coronavirus
summary: The European Union is set to discuss ways to increase cooperation in tackling the coronavirus threat, following the virus's spread to several EU member states. The draft text proposes strengthening coordination between member states and the EU Commission to enhance protection of public health. The EU will also stress the importance of sharing information on individuals at increased risk of carrying the virus while ensuring free movement within the EU. Cases have been identified in eight EU nations, with the biggest number in Germany, and the EU urges the dissemination of up-to-date information to counter misinformation.

site_title: Singtel Q3 profit down 23.8% to S$627.2m
summary: Singtel reported a 23.8% decline in Q3 net profit to S$627.2 million, due to weaker enterprise performance and lower equipment sales. Operating revenue fell 5% to S$4.38 billion, mainly attributed to lower equipment sales and price erosion in carriage services. Regional associates' pre-tax profit contributions increased 15% to S$393 million, driven by improved performances of Airtel and Globe. The company revised its forecast for the current year, expecting stable group revenue and a low single-digit decrease in Ebitda.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 2.18 points or 0.14% to 1,545.12. Volume reached 61.03 million lots worth RM30.62 million, with gainers beating losers 134 to 58. The increase followed a global trend, as US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats and European stocks rose despite bank and healthcare sector declines.

site_title: Despite US$1t deficits, Trump tax cuts will still 'pay for themselves': Mnuchin
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said President Donald Trump's tax cuts will pay for themselves over 10 years despite near-term deficits of nearly $1 trillion. Mnuchin attributed the deficits to increased spending, not lower revenues. The Congressional Budget Office predicts $1.3 trillion in annual deficits over the next decade, which Mnuchin believes will be offset by the tax cuts. The administration forecasts $4.6 trillion in deficit reduction over 10 years, based on an assumption that Trump's policies will be enacted.

images.alt_text: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin insisted on Wednesday that President Donald Trump's tax cuts will still pay for themselves over 10 years, even as the administration forecasts near-term deficits close to US$1 trillion.

site_title: Oil rises over 3% as demand worries ease amid fewer new coronavirus cases
summary: Oil prices rose over 3% on Wednesday, driven by China's lowest daily new coronavirus cases, sparking hopes for recovering fuel demand. Brent futures gained $1.78, settling at $55.79 per barrel, while US WTI crude rose $1.23, settling at $51.17. This was the highest settle since January, despite a larger-than-expected crude inventory build and a decline in fuel stocks.

site_title: Former Democratic frontrunner Warren hangs on thread after primary rout
summary: Former Democratic presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren trails in the polls after placing fourth in the New Hampshire primary, trailing Bernie Sanders by over 10 percentage points. Warren's chances of securing the nomination are slim, with a one-in-30 chance according to FiveThirtyEight. Despite still having the third-largest haul of delegates, Warren's campaign is facing increasing scrutiny, and her campaign manager predicts she will finish in the top two in eight of the 14 states that vote on Super Tuesday.

site_title: IMF says new Lebanon government requested advice
summary: Lebanon's new government, led by Prime Minister Hassan Diab, has requested advice from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) on its economic plan, despite a vote of confidence from parliament the previous day. The IMF will provide "advice and technical expertise" on macroeconomic challenges, but has made no mention of financial assistance. Lebanon is on the brink of defaulting on its sovereign debt, with a $1.2 billion payment due next month, and the international community has pledged over $11 billion in financial aid conditional on economic reforms.

site_title: Budget measures can help SMEs raise their game
summary: Singapore small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are struggling to stay profitable and competitive due to global economic slowdown and uncertainties from the novel coronavirus outbreak. To help SMEs, the government can provide timely support through business cost reliefs, such as extending the Wage Credit Scheme. The government should also exercise flexibility in granting schemes, with a better balance struck between prescribing supportable input factors and progression of the company. SMEs need to adopt an agile mindset and proactively examine how to tap the assistance available to tackle immediate concerns and create a longer-term competitive edge.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Adapting business operations to the coronavirus epidemic
summary: A Money FM podcast discusses adapting business operations to the coronavirus epidemic, with experts emphasizing the need for flexibility and resilience. The outbreak's ongoing impact on global economies is expected to continue, and businesses must adapt to changing circumstances. Key takeaways include the importance of systems leadership in managing complexity during M&As, and authentic leadership as a key factor in thriving in uncertain times. Companies are also advised to reevaluate their executive structures and consider alternative leadership models.

site_title: Welcome use of AI as force of good to combat the novel coronavirus
summary: China's use of artificial intelligence (AI) and technology in combating the novel coronavirus, now named Covid-19, is being hailed as a force for good. AI-powered tools, including drones, robots, and analytics, are being used to remotely deliver services, track the spread of the virus, and identify infected individuals. Chinese technology giants Alibaba and Baidu are offering gene-sequencing AI tools to researchers worldwide. However, concerns have been raised about the potential misuse of AI-driven mass surveillance capabilities, highlighting the need for universal rules and regulation governing the ethical use of AI.

site_title: China Life Insurance seeks backdoor listing in Hong Kong
summary: China Life Insurance (Group) Co, the parent company of the nation's largest life insurer, plans to list its key businesses in Hong Kong through a backdoor listing this year. The move aims to speed up market-oriented reforms and focus on business value rather than size. Chairman Wang Bin's plan involves injecting main assets into the listed China Life Insurance Co, which will issue new shares to the parent. This would enable China Life Group to widen its access to capital markets without a separate initial public offering. A final decision has not been made.

site_title: Xi vows China will beat virus - as economists slash forecasts
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping expressed optimism about the country's economy despite the ongoing coronavirus outbreak, saying China will overcome the epidemic and achieve its economic targets. However, economists have cut their forecasts for growth, with S&P Global Ratings predicting 5% growth this year, down from previous estimates. The outbreak has killed over 1,000 people and has disrupted production and productivity, with some officials shifting focus towards containing the epidemic while ensuring the economy operates.

images.alt_text: President Xi believes China will be more prosperous after overcoming this epidemic.

site_title: Federal Reserve chief describes chinks in otherwise healthy US economy
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell testified to Congress that the US economy, experiencing a record 11th year of growth, has some underlying issues. Despite steady job gains and a near 50-year low unemployment rate, wage gains have remained sluggish, and Americans lag behind other advanced economies in education and skills. The number of people working multiple jobs is high, and earnings are rising at a rate just ahead of inflation. Powell urged Congress to address these issues, which are not within the Fed's authority, and emphasized the need for additional education and training to boost earnings and reduce inequality.

images.alt_text: The US has seen steady job gains that have beat expectations and lasted longer than expected, but Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell acknowledged on Wednesday that all is not well.

site_title: Europe: Kering, slowing coronavirus cases in China lift shares to new highs
summary: Luxury stocks surged in Europe, with Kering's 6.3% jump driving the rally, as optimism over fewer new coronavirus cases in China lifted shares to new highs. The German benchmark also reached new heights. Other luxury stocks, including LVMH, Christian Dior, Hugo Boss, and Burberry, rose between 1-3% on the news. Despite virus fears, Kering remained upbeat about its long-term prospects and halted spending in China.

images.alt_text: A rally in luxury stocks led by Gucci-owner Kering and optimism over fewer new coronavirus cases in China pushed an index of European shares and the German benchmark to new highs on Wednesday.

site_title: Airbnb extends Beijing suspension to May
summary: Airbnb has extended its suspension of business in Beijing to April 30, following tightened local regulations aimed at curbing the coronavirus epidemic. The company is offering refunds to affected users and has suspended check-ins at all its listings in the Chinese capital. This move comes as health authorities in China try to gauge the effectiveness of the quarantine effort in containing the virus. Other home-sharing companies, such as Trip.com Group-backed Tujia, have also suspended bookings in Beijing.

site_title: Singapore luxury co-living comes with steep prices and no apologies
summary: Singapore's luxury co-living concept, Figment, offers heritage shophouses with unique interior designs and local flavors, starting at around S$2,000 a month. The company, founded by 32-year-old CEO Fang Wei Low, aims to differentiate itself from competitors with its boutique homes and curated experiences, including bi-monthly private dinners with renowned Singapore chefs. Despite steep prices, Figment's shophouses have gained popularity among expats and local millennials seeking alternative living options, with plans to expand to Hong Kong and Sydney.

site_title: Tax jab against the novel coronavirus
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister has announced measures to manage the novel coronavirus (Covid-19) situation, including property tax rebates for hotels and reduced foreign worker levies. The government also plans to support businesses by allowing employees to work remotely, providing grants for flexible-work arrangements, and considering tax credits for businesses and deductions for medical expenses. These measures aim to alleviate the economic impact of the pandemic on businesses and Singaporeans, with the goal of containing the spread of the virus and minimizing disruptions to supply chains.

site_title: When disorientation is the new normal
summary: New York Fashion Week has become disoriented, reflecting the chaotic state of the world. Designers are struggling to create meaningful fashion amidst disruption and dystopianism. Carolina Herrera's show featured optimistic, party-inspired outfits, while Oscar de la Renta's collection was criticized for being oblivious and over-the-top. In contrast, The Row's designs offered a soothing, muted calm, while Proenza Schouler's collection was aggressively off-center, confronting the chaos head-on. The fashion industry is left to navigate this new normal, where sense and urgency are in short supply.

site_title: Fear distorts our thinking when risk is involved
summary: Fear distorts decision-making when risk is involved, and experts' trust is key. A 2020 study, inspired by the Asian disease problem, showed that people prefer options with guaranteed outcomes over uncertain ones, even when the outcomes are mathematically equivalent. Fear, fueled by real or perceived threats, further biases decisions, leading to irrational behavior. Emotions can lead to miscalibrated predictions and reinforce fear, creating a cycle of irrational behavior. The solution lies in trusting data-informed expertise, not trying to think more carefully, as most people lack the necessary knowledge to make informed decisions.

site_title: From Russia's Don Agro to SGX's Catalist with love
summary: Don Agro International, a Russian wheat and raw milk producer, is set to debut on Singapore Exchange's Catalist on February 14, 2020, with a S$5.1 million initial public offering. The company plans to use IPO proceeds to expand its land bank and has a controlled land bank of 53,000 hectares. Don Agro's listing marks the first time a Russian firm will list on the Singapore bourse. The company's CEO notes that the SGX is a conservative and transparent bourse, and he is unfazed by market volatility, stating that becoming a public company requires strategic thinking and a focus on growth.

site_title: Condo, HDB rents rise in January on lower volume
summary: Singapore's housing rental market saw a temporary slowdown in activity due to the novel coronavirus outbreak. Despite this, rents for private apartments and condominiums rose 0.9% month-on-month in January, while HDB flat rents increased 0.8%. Leasing volume for private non-landed homes fell for a sixth consecutive month, and HDB rental volumes dropped 22.5% year-on-year. Experts predict a slowdown in the rental market, citing the impact of the virus on sectors like tourism and MICE, but expect demand to rebound when the situation stabilizes.

site_title: Australia's CBA posts better than expected half-year profit
summary: Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA) reported a better-than-expected half-year profit, with shares rising to a near five-year peak. The bank's results suggest it is leaving scandals behind and solidifying its dominance in the saturated home loan market. CBA is also considering returning capital to shareholders. The bank's performance is seen as a positive sign for the Australian banking sector, which has been impacted by scandals and regulatory challenges.

site_title: Virus outbreak to buffet retail further after 2.8% fall in 2019
summary: Singapore's retail sales are expected to be weak this year due to novel coronavirus pressures, following a 2.8% fall in 2019, the steepest decline in six years. This marks the first consecutive annual contraction since the post-Global Financial Crisis period in 2009-2010. OCBC Bank predicts a possible contraction in Q1 GDP, raising concerns about the official 2020 forecast being cut.

site_title: Prime US Reit to buy first property post-IPO, Q4 DPU up 9% against forecast
summary: Prime US Reit has acquired its first property post-initial public offering (IPO) in July 2019 for US$165.5 million in Sacramento, California. The 24-storey office tower has a 92.2% occupancy rate and a weighted average lease expiry of 5.6 years. The acquisition is expected to enhance yields and distribution per unit (DPU) accretion of 2.7% and net asset value per unit accretion of 0.1%. The deal is financed by a combination of loans and new unit issuance, with gross proceeds of US$120 million raised through a private placement.

site_title: Singtel's regional associates remain good value despite setbacks
summary: Singtel, a Singaporean telco, faces setbacks from its regional associates Bharti Airtel and Telkomsel, which have struggled with losses and financial issues. Despite this, Singtel's regional associates remain a good value for the company, providing significant dividend payouts. Analysts expect Singtel's associates to recover in the long term, with Bharti Airtel expected to return to profitability in FY2022. Singtel's focus on diversifying into faster-growing markets and creating a digital platform across its subsidiaries also suggests a long-term strategy for the company.

site_title: SoftBank stock surges 14% after Sprint sale wins approval
summary: SoftBank's founder Masayoshi Son won approval for the sale of his US telecommunications firm Sprint to T-Mobile, extracting the Japanese billionaire from a cash-draining US wireless business and removing $40 billion in net debt. SoftBank shares surged 14% after a federal court approved the deal, which will allow Son to regain financial flexibility and potentially raise capital for a share buyback or new investments. The sale marks a positive turn for Son after a punishing year, following setbacks at portfolio companies and the failed initial public offering of WeWork.

site_title: In brief
summary: Airbus and the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore signed a memorandum of understanding to enable urban air mobility in Singapore, aiming to set up services and platforms to enhance industry productivity and improve regional connectivity. ST Engineering agreed to provide maintenance support for CFM International's LEAP-1B engine, while ATR said Singapore-based Avation plc converted its purchase rights for two ATR 72-600 aircraft into firm orders. The partnership between Airbus and CAAS will foster public acceptance of UAM operations and study feasibility for further services.

site_title: Corporates rally to thank healthcare workers with food, transport vouchers
summary: Corporates in Singapore are rallying to show appreciation for healthcare workers battling Covid-19 by delivering food, transport vouchers, and drinks to hospitals. Companies such as Mapletree, Far East Organization, and ComfortDelgro are participating in the initiative, which aims to boost the morale of doctors, nurses, and other frontline staff. The effort has been met with gratitude from hospitals, with some staff members expressing appreciation for the gestures. The Community Foundation of Singapore has also set up a fund to provide support for frontline healthcare workers and vulnerable communities.

site_title: Why 'Westlessness' is a worry for the world
summary: Key leaders are gathering at the Munich Security Conference to discuss "Westlessness," a widespread feeling of unease about the West's purpose in a rapidly changing world. The phenomenon is fueled by the Brexit referendum, Donald Trump's presidency, and rising global tensions. The conference aims to address questions about the West's future, including its relevance in the face of great power competition and the potential for a new era of Western-led global governance. Experts stress that the West's rejuvenation requires acknowledging its limitations and embracing a more pragmatic approach, rather than attempting to restore the old liberal order.

site_title: Retail woes hit high-end malls, leading to major landlord deal
summary: High-end malls in the US are facing pressure due to the retail apocalypse, with bankruptcies and store closures among brick-and-mortar retailers causing concern for mall operators. Investors are increasingly worried, leading to major landlord deals. The trend is a result of the decline of traditional retail and the shift towards online shopping.

site_title: Vicom proposes share split; FY19 net profit down by 18.1%
summary: Vicom, a Singapore-based vehicle inspection company, plans to split its shares into four, aiming to improve trading liquidity and broaden the shareholder base. The move, effective from FY20, will increase the total number of shares from 88.6 million to 354.6 million, reducing the share price. This decision comes after the company reported a 18.1% drop in FY19 net profit. The board believes the share split will benefit the company in the long run, despite the initial reduction in share price.

site_title: RHTLaw Asia LLP clarifies that it operates independently
summary: RHTLaw Asia LLP, a Singapore law firm, clarified that it operates independently from RHT Capital and other entities in the RHT Group of Companies. The firm's decision to move towards a collaborative relationship with Taylor Wessing in 2019 was driven by long-term business objectives and not related to the Notice of Compliance issued to RHT Capital. The firm adheres to strict rules governing conflicts of interest and has operated independently throughout. Managing Partner AZMAN JAAFAR reiterated the firm's independence in response to concerns raised in an article.

site_title: Valentine's is not just for one day
summary: Couples are proving that Valentine's Day is not just a one-day celebration, but a way of life. Five husband-and-wife teams in various sectors share their experiences of patience, give-and-take, and unity, demonstrating that being partners both in love and business can be a winning combination. From romance getaways to luxury watches and art exhibitions, Valentine's Day is offering a range of ideas and inspiration for couples to strengthen their bond. As societal perceptions of love and coupledom continue to evolve, the concept of partnership is becoming increasingly valued.

site_title: Cruise ship heads to Cambodia after Thailand bars entry
summary: A cruise ship, Westerdam, is headed to Cambodia after being barred from entry in Thailand due to coronavirus concerns. The 2,257 passengers and crew will disembark in Sihanoukville, Cambodia, and the ship will remain in port for several days. Thailand had previously offered to provide medical aid, food, and water, but ultimately decided to bar entry. The Westerdam had been rejected by Taiwan, Japan, the Philippines, and Guam, and was running low on supplies. The ship's operator, Holland America Line, denies any coronavirus cases on board.

images.alt_text: Passengers on board the Westerdam cruise ship. Carnival Corp's Holland America Line, the operator of the ship, has said there's no reason to believe there are any coronavirus cases on board.

site_title: Three new cases confirmed; a 'small number may succumb'
summary: Singapore has confirmed three new cases of Covid-19, bringing the total to 50 infected individuals, with 15 recovered. Panic buying has stabilized, with retailers expected to return to normal stocking levels within a day or two due to manpower and logistics issues. The government remains prepared for the worst, with Health Minister Gan Kim Yong stating that a small number of those infected may succumb to the virus.

site_title: Risks in Reits are not what they once were
summary: The Reit market has shifted from being considered defensive plays, with risks decreasing due to lower interest rates and economic growth expectations. However, resilience varies across sub-sectors, with hotel Reits being the most cyclical and retail Reits facing structural headwinds from e-commerce. Investors now face lower margin of safety against capital losses, with compressed dividend yields and increased volatility in the market. The proposed mergers and acquisitions in retail Reits may indicate anticipation of greater fluctuations in income.

site_title: Malaysia's central bank sees room to cut rates as GDP growth hits 10-yr low
summary: Malaysia's central bank sees room to cut interest rates as the country's GDP growth slowed to its weakest pace in over a decade, hitting 3.6% in the fourth quarter of 2019. The full-year growth figure for 2019 was 4.3%, below the government's initial projection of 4.7%. Bank Negara Malaysia Governor Nor Shamsiah Mohd Yunus stated that the bank has "ample room" to adjust interest rates, citing low inflation. The move comes as the nation braces for the impact of the coronavirus on tourism and trade.

site_title: Siba the standard poodle wins Westminster Dog Show
summary: Siba, a black standard poodle, won the 144th Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show, defeating a final group of contenders including a golden retriever and two repeat best in show contestants. Siba, 5, is the fifth standard to win the show's top prize since 1991, and her handler, Chrystal Murray, attributes her win to her hypo-allergenic coat and her family dog demeanor. Siba, who prefers chicken, won over the crowd's favorite, Daniel the golden retriever, and took home the top prize.

site_title: ABN Amro Q4 profit hurt by low interest rates, rising impairments
summary: ABN Amro reported a flat fourth-quarter net income of 316 million euros, missing analysts' estimates due to lower interest income and higher impairments. Impairments jumped 51% to 314 million euros, mainly from corporate loan write-offs in the offshore energy sector. The bank also scrapped interest payments on retail deposits and plans to charge interest on deposits over 2.5 million euros. CEO Kees van Dijkhuizen cited uncertainties surrounding the bank, including a money laundering investigation, as reasons for not increasing the dividend.

site_title: Cambodia to allow cruise ship shunned over coronavirus fears to dock
summary: Cambodia has agreed to let the Holland America Line's cruise ship MS Westerdam, turned away by five countries over coronavirus fears, dock and disembark its 1,455 passengers and 802 crew. The ship had been denied entry to Japan, Taiwan, Guam, the Philippines, and Thailand due to concerns about a potential outbreak. After nearly two weeks of sailing, the ship is expected to arrive in Cambodia on Thursday for a brief health inspection before passengers can disembark. Despite no reported cases of the coronavirus on board, passengers have been subjected to regular health checks.

site_title: Singapore Shopping Centre back on en bloc market with S$255m price tag
summary: Singapore Shopping Centre is back on the collective-sale market with a reserve price of S$255 million, unchanged from its previous attempt in 2019. The seven-storey building, with a 2,449.8 sqm site, has been given provisional approval to re-zone for hotel use. This offers flexibility for the purchaser to redevelop the site into various uses, subject to approval. The tender closes on March 18, and no additional buyer's stamp duty or seller's stamp duty will be payable for foreign and local buyers.

site_title: 200 DBS staff vacate MBFC after case confirmed
summary: DBS bank in Singapore sent home 200 employees from its Marina Bay Financial Centre office after a staff member tested positive for the novel coronavirus. The individual was tested on Tuesday and the diagnosis was confirmed on Wednesday. The bank took the precautionary measure as a precautionary measure to prevent the spread of the virus.

site_title: Nissan sues Ghosn in Japan, seeks 10b yen in damages
summary: Nissan Motor Co. has filed a lawsuit in Japan's Yokohama District Court against former chairman Carlos Ghosn, seeking 10 billion yen (S$126 million) in damages. The lawsuit claims Ghosn's misconduct and fraudulent activity led to financial losses for the company. Ghosn has denied the charges, but the lawsuit may impact his net worth, estimated to be around $70 million. Nissan is also seeking to hold Ghosn accountable for the harm caused by his actions, while Ghosn is pursuing claims against Nissan for wrongful dismissal.

site_title: Harnessing technology to create a 'super-smart' society
summary: Singapore is expected to announce policies in its Budget 2020 to help companies invest in automation technology, as the country's economy faces a slowdown. The government has already taken steps to advance automation, including deploying Robotic Process Automation within its own departments. Singapore can learn from countries like Germany and Japan, which have enacted policies to encourage the use of automation technologies. The US government has also deployed automation technologies across 30 government agencies.

site_title: Tech deal review puts VCs in regulatory purgatory
summary: The US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has issued new orders requiring tech giants such as Alphabet, Amazon, and Facebook to report small acquisitions to the agency. The orders, which apply to deals valued below $90 million, aim to scrutinize transformative deals and prevent anti-competitive behavior. The move could hinder venture capital firms seeking to exit investments, as 60% of startups rely on asset sales for funding. Regulators worry that early-stage acquisitions are helping tech companies achieve dominance, and the FTC's focus on smaller deals may lead to increased scrutiny and potential penalties.

site_title: Virus outbreak shuts North Korea's best route around US sanctions
summary: North Korea has shut its border with China to avoid the coronavirus, hindering its economic recovery and potentially renewing pressure on leader Kim Jong-un to negotiate with US President Donald Trump. The closure will cut off foreign tourism and limit trade, affecting the cash-strapped state's hard currency earnings. The decision follows a 36% jump in diesel prices and diminished port activity, with reports of the first virus case in North Korea. The closure may make it tougher for Kim to push back against Trump's demands, and the economic blow may accelerate an impending economic crisis.

site_title: Genting Singapore pessimistic about H1 amid virus threat
summary: Genting Singapore is pessimistic about the first half of 2020 due to the novel coronavirus scare, which has disrupted the travel and tourism industries. Despite a 4% jump in net profit for the fourth quarter, revenue dipped 9% to S$607 million, with gaming revenue falling 13% to S$388 million. The company plans to refresh its offerings and embark on a stronger productivity drive to counter the uncertainty. Genting Singapore reported a 10th anniversary for Resorts World Sentosa in March, with a S$4.5 billion mega expansion planned.

site_title: Banks, telco, property firms help businesses hit by Covid-19 outbreak
summary: Singaporean banks and telco firms have launched initiatives to aid businesses affected by the Covid-19 outbreak. United Overseas Bank (UOB) has set aside S$3 billion to provide relief assistance to small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). Other firms, including property companies, are also offering support to help businesses overcome near- to short-term financial disruptions. These measures aim to mitigate the negative impact of the pandemic on local businesses.

site_title: David Hockney's The Splash sells for £23m
summary: David Hockney's 1966 painting "The Splash" sold for £23.1 million at a London auction, exceeding the pre-sale estimate of £20 million to £30 million. The acrylic work depicts a swimming pool moment and is the second in a series of three splash paintings. This sale follows Hockney's 2018 record-breaking sale of "Portrait of an Artist (Pool with Two Figures)" for US$90.3 million, and marks the first time the artist's work has sold for over £20 million.

site_title: Real-estate fund redemptions in US, Europe, surge on alarm over malls
summary: Real-estate funds in the US and Europe are facing a surge in investor requests to withdraw their cash, driven by concerns about the viability of retail properties in the e-commerce era. UBS Group's flagship fund, Trumbull Property Fund, is struggling to meet a $7 billion redemption request, while similar issues are emerging in Europe. The funds may be forced to unload mall properties at a time when buyers are scarce, highlighting the pressure on retail properties. Investors are reassessing their investments tied to malls, citing store closures and bankruptcies.

site_title: Samsung unveils foldable phone and 5G Galaxy S
summary: Samsung unveiled a foldable phone and 5G capabilities for its flagship devices, aiming to retain its position as the world's largest smartphone company. The company's second attempt at a folding phone follows last year's delayed rollout. This move comes as Samsung faces competition from Apple and Chinese brands like Huawei, which has gained market share in China and Europe. The 5G-enabled devices will be available in the market soon, as Samsung continues to innovate and adapt to the changing smartphone landscape.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Dow hit all-time highs as coronavirus spread slows
summary: US stocks hit all-time highs as the coronavirus outbreak in China appears to be slowing down. The Dow Jones Industrials rose 0.45% to 29,406.75, while the S&P 500 gained 0.38% to 3,370.50. The Nasdaq Composite also reached a record high, up 0.52% to 9,688.60. These gains come as investors become more optimistic about the economic outlook.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Singaporean companies reported varying financial performances. ST Engineering's aerospace arm secured two multi-year maintenance contracts, while Pratt & Whitney developed an industrialized 3D-printed aero-engine process in collaboration with ST Engineering. SEMBCORP Industries will build solar panels for Singapore Airlines, and Neo Group's third-quarter net profit nearly doubled. Thomson Medical Group's fourth-quarter net loss decreased, while United Overseas Insurance's full-year earnings surged 69.5%. Other companies, including Ley Choon Group and Tai Sin Electric, also reported improved financial results.

site_title: Wing Tai Holdings posts 61% jump in Q2 net profit of S$26m
summary: Wing Tai Holdings, a Singapore-based company, reported a 61% jump in Q2 net profit to S$26 million, driven by higher gross profit, other gains, and contributions from associates and joint ventures. Revenue slipped 10.2% to S$104.2 million. The company attributed the growth to increased sales at its Le Nouvel Ardmore condominium and higher contributions from associates and joint ventures. However, no dividend was recommended for the half-year.

site_title: Facebook-owned WhatsApp says it has 2 billion users
summary: WhatsApp, a Facebook-owned messaging service, announced it now has over 2 billion users worldwide. The service, acquired by Facebook in 2014, has reaffirmed its stance on strong encryption to protect user privacy. WhatsApp emphasizes the need to protect users as it grows in connectivity, stating "the more we connect, the more we have to protect." The platform has become one of the most-used services in the Facebook "family" of apps.

site_title: Britain starts setting up 'first internet watchdog'
summary: The British government plans to appoint the Office of Communications (Ofcom) as the country's first internet watchdog, allowing it to issue substantial fines to social media companies that fail to remove harmful content. The new agency will have the power to issue warnings and notices, but not take down content or block platforms. The move comes after a 14-year-old girl killed herself after being cyberbullied online, with two-thirds of adults in the UK expressing concern about online content. The government aims to balance freedom of expression with online safety, with plans to draft legislation in the coming months.

site_title: Rolls-Royce to add more jobs in Singapore this year
summary: British engineering giant Rolls-Royce plans to hire 230 more people in Singapore this year, a 10% increase, to boost plane engine production capacity. The company currently employs 2,500 staff in Singapore and aims to increase production to 250 engines annually. Rolls-Royce is expanding its presence in South-east Asia, driven by the Singapore government's support for the aerospace sector. The company has also committed to a zero greenhouse gas emission target by 2030 and is working towards sustainability efforts.

site_title: OEL (Holdings) plans to take on new investors amid diversification moves
summary: OEL (Holdings), a Catalist-listed property management company, plans to diversify into early childhood childcare and health education in Singapore, as well as the healthcare industry, through a share placement led by controlling shareholder Zhang Jian. The move aims to generate long-term sustainable growth across diverse economic conditions. The placement will yield S$7.64 million in net proceeds, with 16 investors, including Healthcare Co executives, subscribing for shares and warrants. OEL will call an extraordinary general meeting to seek shareholders' approval for the placement and diversification plans, with the company's name potentially changing to reflect its new businesses.

site_title: European Parliament ratifies EU-Vietnam trade pact
summary: The European Parliament has ratified an EU-Vietnam free trade accord, with 401 lawmakers voting in favor, despite some objecting due to Vietnam's human rights record. The accord, signed last year, will phase out tariff barriers over a decade for Vietnam and seven years for the EU. EU Trade Commissioner Phil Hogan hailed the deal's "huge economic potential" and Vietnam's labor rights improvements, while the Greens expressed skepticism about the pact's real impact. The deal will take effect after final approval by the European Council and Vietnam's ratification, with annual exchanges between the EU and Vietnam totaling nearly 48 billion euros.

site_title: Swee Hong gets 3-month extension to AGM deadline till Apr 30
summary: Swee Hong, a Mainboard-listed company, has received a three-month extension to its annual general meeting (AGM) deadline until April 30. The extension comes after the company negotiated with its external auditors and paid the audit fees, allowing them to commence the audit of its FY2019 accounts. Trading in Swee Hong shares has been suspended since May 2019, and the company must confirm in writing that it is not aware of any unannounced information that will impact investor decisions.

site_title: Samsung's galaxy of partnerships
summary: Samsung has formed partnerships with Netflix and Microsoft to deepen integration of their services into its Galaxy S20 devices. The new devices will allow users to search for movies by voice queries and feature Spotify music streaming through Bixby's morning routines. These partnerships aim to elevate Samsung beyond hardware, diversify revenue, and level the playing field with Apple. Analysts believe this strategy is a better approach than competing in content and enterprise apps, and that it leverages Samsung's strengths in hardware while allowing partners to contribute to the ecosystem.

site_title: Hedge funds step up purchase of USD
summary: Hedge funds have increased their purchases of the US dollar amid hopes that the spread of the novel coronavirus has slowed. The dollar holds near a four-month high as trend-following investors seek yields, driven by the relatively high interest rates. Despite skepticism about the dollar's outlook, market watchers note that the US economy remains superior to others and the growth gap with the rest of the world remains substantial. The dollar edged 0.1% higher to 98.77 against a basket of major currencies.

site_title: Ley Choon back in black, posts Q3 net profit of S$218,000
summary: Ley Choon Group Holdings, a construction company, reported a net profit of S$218,000 for the third quarter of 2019, reversing a net loss of S$914,000 in the same period the previous year. Revenue fell 10% year-on-year to S$23.6 million due to lower pre-mix sales. Gross profits increased due to lower material costs. The company's unfulfilled order book is S$123.8 million, and it plans to bid for public sector projects. No dividend was recommended, and shares shed 0.1 Singapore cent or 6.67% to S$0.016.

site_title: Businesses look to targeted help measures in Budget
summary: Singapore businesses are seeking targeted support measures in the upcoming Budget to address the Covid-19 outbreak's impact on the economy. With past schemes such as the Productivity and Innovation Credit (PIC) and SkillsFuture Credit being abused, the government is likely to introduce more tailored measures to promote digital transformation, innovation, and manpower development. Experts expect income tax rebates, targeted productivity grants, and R&D incentives, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and industries such as electronics.

images.alt_text: Coming out of 2019's slowdown, companies here have been looking to the upcoming Budget for support - a hope that has intensified as the Covid-19 outbreak threatens to hammer the Singapore economy.

site_title: STI recoups losses as virus fears recede
summary: Singapore's equities bounced back from early-week losses as investors focused on Wall Street's lead and concerns about the novel coronavirus (Covid-19) faded. The Straits Times Index rose 1.5% to 3,223.37, its best single-day jump all year, driven by hopes of further stimulus and a decline in fresh cases and deaths related to the virus. Local banks and property developers also performed well, with DBS, OCBC, and City Developments advancing. Oil prices rose as concerns over falling Chinese demand faded.

site_title: Thomson Medical Group narrows Q4 net loss to S$1.16m
summary: Thomson Medical Group reported a narrowed Q4 net loss of S$1.16 million, down from S$4.46 million in the same period last year. Despite higher income tax expenses, the company attributed its 4.3% year-over-year increase in turnover to more in-patients and higher average bill sizes. The group's full-year net loss was S$1.67 million, with revenue rising 6.6% to S$229.8 million. Thomson Medical expects to stay in the black in the year ahead, barring unforeseen circumstances related to the Covid-19 epidemic.

site_title: EU slashes Cambodia trade benefits over rights violations
summary: The European Union has partially suspended duty-free trade benefits for Cambodia, a move aimed at addressing the country's human rights record. The decision affects about 20% of Cambodia's yearly exports, worth around $1.5 billion, and comes after repeated calls from the EU to drop charges against opposition leader Kem Sokha. The EU has expressed concerns over Cambodia's erosion of democracy, curtailment of human rights, and suppression of free debate. The move is seen as a significant blow to Cambodia's garment industry, which employs over 700,000 workers and generates billions of dollars in revenue.

site_title: Genting Singapore pessimistic about 1H2020 on 'massive disruption' of coronavirus
summary: Genting Singapore expresses pessimism over the first half of 2020 due to the novel coronavirus' massive disruption to the travel and tourism industries. The company reported a 4% rise in net profit to S$156 million for the fourth quarter, with revenue falling 9% to S$607 million. Genting Singapore will focus on productivity and refresh its offerings, and its non-gaming businesses continue to perform well. The company's shares rose 1.7% to 87.5 cents.

site_title: Property sales lift Wing Tai Q2 profits
summary: Wing Tai Holdings reported a 61% increase in net profit to S$26 million for the second quarter, driven by higher gross profit and gains from associates and joint ventures. Revenue slipped 10.2% to S$104.2 million. The company attributed the growth to contributions from luxury condominiums and increased unit sales. Net asset value stood at S$4.17 per share, while earnings per share grew to 2.96 cents. Wing Tai noted a slower pace of growth in Singapore private home prices and will monitor the property markets amid the Covid-19 outbreak.

site_title: UOI posts 69.5% jump in FY2019 net profit of S$40.4m
summary: UOI, a subsidiary of UOB, reported a 69.5% year-on-year jump in FY2019 net profit to S$40.4 million, driven by investment dividends and interest income. Gross premium income rose 2.6% to S$105.9 million. Earnings per share increased to 66.05 Singapore cents and net asset value grew to S$6.84 per share.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets climb at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.2%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 index up 0.4%, and Paris's CAC 40 up 0.3%. The gains were driven by mining and healthcare stocks.

site_title: Crisis talks on fate of Spain mobile fair over coronavirus fears
summary: Organisers of the World Mobile Congress (MWC 2020) are considering cancelling the event due to coronavirus fears, following the withdrawal of several industry heavyweights. The GSMA, the mobile trade association, had originally planned the event for February 24-27 but brought it forward in response to the growing number of cancellations. Several major companies, including Vodafone, Nokia, and Deutsche Telekom, have pulled out, citing concerns for employee and customer safety. The decision could have significant economic implications for Barcelona, Spain, where the event is held.

site_title: Opec says coronavirus to trim 2020 oil demand as it weighs deeper cut
summary: Opec reduced its forecast for global oil demand in 2020 due to the coronavirus outbreak, citing a 200,000 barrel-per-day decrease. The organization also reported a sharp decline in oil production in January, with output falling short of the average 2020 requirement. This decrease is attributed to planned cuts and involuntary losses. Opec's new forecast for 2020 oil demand averages 29.30 million barrels per day, down from a previous estimate. The reduced demand is expected to continue for the next four years.

site_title: Coronavirus: 3 new cases in Singapore - 2 from Grace Assembly of God church, 1 from DBS
summary: Singapore reported 3 new confirmed cases of coronavirus, bringing the total to 50. Two cases, both Singaporeans with no travel history to China, were linked to the Grace Assembly of God Church. The third case, also a Singaporean with no recent travel history to China, was a DBS bank employee. The church had earlier asked some staff to work from home. The cases highlight the ongoing spread of the virus in Singapore despite the country's efforts to contain it.

site_title: Singapore shares jump 1.5% as novel coronavirus fears ease
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index surged 1.5% to a year-high, driven by investor optimism as fears about the novel coronavirus eased. The local market was boosted by hopes of further stimulus and strong performances from local banks, ST Engineering, and property developers. The benchmark index finished with gains across 29 of its 30 counters, while trading volume and turnover reached record highs. The rally follows a similar trend in other Asia-Pacific markets, with Taiwan's Taiex Index also rising 0.9%.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 8.54 points to 1,542.94. Volume reached 2.8 billion lots worth RM2.8 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 419 to 405, indicating a mixed market.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore retail sales fell 3.4% in December, with motor vehicle sales dropping significantly. GIC purchased the LG Twin Towers in Beijing for over 8 billion yuan. To support SMEs, UOB set aside S$3 billion for relief assistance, while ARA and Straits Trading offered S$5 million in loans. Condo and HDB rents rose 0.9% in January, and Singapore shares jumped 1.5% due to decreasing coronavirus fears.

site_title: Ryobi Kiso's judicial managers get court approval to pay some creditors
summary: Ryobi Kiso Holdings and its Ryobi Kiso (S) subsidiary have received court approval to make interim distributions of up to S$7 million and S$20 million to creditors, respectively. The judicial managers, Goh Thien Phong and Chan Kheng Tek, will make further announcements and notify creditors regarding the filing of proofs of debt. The court orders allow for distributions to creditors upon request, subject to certain terms.

site_title: Neo Group Q3 net profit nearly doubles to S$3.79m
summary: Neo Group, a CATALIST-listed caterer, reported a nearly doubling of its third-quarter net profit to S$3.79 million, driven by reduced operating lease expenses. Revenue increased by 2.7% year-on-year to S$50.8 million. The company's net profit for the nine months jumped to S$6.09 million, with earnings per share rising to 3.92 Singapore cents. Despite a net current liability of S$19 million, the board expects the group to overcome its negative working capital position in the longer term through synergies between businesses.

site_title: Vicom posts 18% fall in FY2019 net profit of S$28.4m despite revenue rise
summary: Vicom, a vehicle inspection company, reported an 18.1% year-on-year drop in net profit to S$28.4 million in FY2019, despite a 3.6% revenue growth to S$103.7 million. Higher operating costs and lower "other income" contributed to the decline. The company expects its vehicle-testing business to remain stable, but its non-vehicle testing business to remain challenging due to economic uncertainties. A final dividend of 24.29 cents per share was recommended, and Vicom shares ended higher by 0.77% at S$7.82.

site_title: Singapore-based Avation exercises purchase rights for two ATR aircraft
summary: Singapore-based Avation plc has converted purchase rights for two ATR 72-600 aircraft into firm orders, with the aircraft to be leased to Bangladeshi airline US-Bangla. This expansion increases the airline's turboprop fleet to eight, allowing for more frequent flights on trunk routes. The ATR 72-600 is considered an attractive asset due to its economics, wide customer base, and environmental credentials. This deal highlights the growing demand for regional aircraft and the importance of ATR in meeting this demand.

site_title: Condo and HDB rents rise in January on lower volume; virus outbreak may hit leasings
summary: Singapore's housing rental market saw a temporary slowdown in January due to the coronavirus outbreak, with rents for private apartments and HDB flats rising 0.9% and 0.8% month-on-month, respectively. Leasing volumes for private non-landed homes dropped 4.9% month-on-month, while HDB flats took up 1,653 units, a 5.1% decline from December. Experts expect a slowdown in the rental market, with potential long-term effects from the virus outbreak on sectors like tourism and hospitality.

site_title: Nissan sues Ghosn in Japan, seeks 10b yen in damages
summary: Nissan Motor is suing former Chairman Carlos Ghosn in Japan for 10 billion yen (S$126 million) in damages, claiming he under-reported his income and used company money for personal gain. The lawsuit seeks to recover monetary damages inflicted on the company as a result of Ghosn's misconduct. If successful, the damages could represent a significant part of Ghosn's net worth, estimated to be around $70 million. Nissan claims Ghosn's actions caused financial losses to the company, while Ghosn is pursuing claims against Nissan, alleging wrongful dismissal and lost income.

site_title: Coronavirus cases fall, experts disagree over whether peak is near
summary: China reported its lowest number of new coronavirus cases since late January, with a total of 2,015 new confirmed cases, bringing the total to 44,653. Dr. Zhong Nanshan, China's foremost medical adviser, predicts the epidemic could be over by April, but international experts remain concerned about the global spread of the virus. The World Health Organization warns the epidemic poses a global threat, and hundreds of cases have been reported in dozens of countries, including a fatality in Hong Kong and another in the Philippines.

site_title: Tai Sin Electric nearly doubles H1 earnings to S$8.11 million
summary: Tai Sin Electric's first-half earnings nearly doubled to S$8.11 million, driven by a spike in other operating income. Revenue slipped 3.7% to S$165.1 million, mainly due to a decline in cable and wire sales. Gross profit rose despite lower deliveries for older infrastructure projects. The company plans to focus on developing industrial and infrastructure sector businesses, citing ongoing global uncertainties and volatile copper prices. An interim dividend of 0.75 cents per share is recommended, unchanged from the previous year.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei closes up on Wall St gains, SoftBank rally
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index rose 0.74% or 175.23 points to 23,861.21 on Wednesday, driven by Wall Street gains and a 11.7% rally in SoftBank Group. The rally was attributed to hopes that SoftBank's US mobile business will improve. In contrast, the broader Topix index closed down 0.04% or 0.72 point at 1,718.92.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on solid corporate earnings; NZ rises
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% to 7,088.2, driven by gains in top two companies, Commonwealth Bank of Australia and BHP, after strong half-year results. The decline in new coronavirus cases in China also boosted sentiment.

images.alt_text: Australian shares ended higher on Wednesday, powered by gains in top two companies by market value on the benchmark after their strong half-year results, with a drop in new coronavirus cases in China adding to sentiment.

site_title: Aoxin Q & M asks for more time for FY2019 results, AGM amid Covid-19 outbreak
summary: Aoxin Q & M Dental Group, a Singapore-listed dental services provider, has asked the Singapore Exchange (SGX) for an extension of its fiscal year 2019 financial results and annual general meeting (AGM) due to the COVID-19 outbreak in China. The company cited travel restrictions and limited access to auditors as the reason for the delay. The board is now seeking an extension until April 30, 2020, and the AGM until June 30, 2020.

site_title: Startups get access to NIUM's tech infrastructure through developer lab BOLT
summary: NIUM, a fintech startup, has launched a 26-week programme called BOLT, allowing startups to access its tech infrastructure at a monthly fee of S$99. Through BOLT, startups can build their own fintech products without needing licenses or creating a compliant network. NIUM will provide assistance, training, and link-ups with venture capitalists. The company aims to expand its reach by building a fintech hub, with plans to make the programme virtual in the future, allowing it to extend its reach globally.

site_title: Anchor Resources' Malaysian mining sites face delayed return of China staff
summary: Anchor Resources' Malaysian mining sites face delays in the return of Chinese staff due to COVID-19 travel restrictions. While all Chinese workers for gold mining reached Malaysia, some underground tunnelling workers and granite mining contractors were unable to enter the country. This has delayed deliveries of granite dimension stones to local and overseas customers, as well as quarry aggregate sales to a Brunei company, now scheduled for June 2020. Anchor Resources will monitor the financial impact of the delays and deliver backlog orders as soon as possible when contractors return to work.

site_title: Tiny Korean hedge fund hits jackpot with 'Parasite' deal
summary: A South Korean hedge fund, Ryukyung PSG Asset Management, has seen significant returns after investing in the Oscar-winning film "Parasite". The fund, which focuses on Korean cinema, has returned 72.1% since its launch in 2018 and profited from other Korean hits. The film's Oscar win has boosted ticket sales and is expected to continue. The fund's success highlights the growing demand for alternative investments, such as film-financing funds, in a low-interest-rate environment.

site_title: UOB sets aside S$3b as relief assistance to SMEs
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has set aside S$3 billion to provide relief assistance to small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore affected by the Covid-19 outbreak. The bank's measures include flexible cash flow management, extended working capital financing, and financing liquidity against mortgage security. SMEs will have the option to rework principal repayments and service only loan interest for up to one year. The bank will assess retail customers on a case-by-case basis, and the cost of relief measures will be disclosed after its FY19 results on February 21.

site_title: Tencent, Alibaba apps find fans in virus-affected schools
summary: China's schools, shut or delayed due to the coronavirus outbreak, are turning to virtual office tools from Alibaba Group and Tencent Holdings to facilitate online teaching. The companies' apps, such as DingTalk and WeChat Work, have seen a surge in demand as educators adapt the tools for instruction purposes. At least 50 million students have signed up for online teaching programs using DingTalk, with features like live-streaming lessons and online testing. The use of these tools is expected to become more widespread as the education sector faces a prolonged winter break.

site_title: ST Engineering inks maintenance agreement with CFM International
summary: ST Engineering signed a maintenance agreement with CFM International to provide MRO support for its LEAP-1B engine, used on the Boeing 737 MAX. The agreement allows ST Engineering to use technical data for MRO work and expands its CFM engine offerings. ST Engineering's MRO infrastructure for LEAP-1B engines is expected to be ready by the end of 2020, with a Singapore facility set to handle the work.

site_title: Foxconn aims to resume half of China production by end-February: source
summary: Foxconn, a Taiwan-based electronics manufacturer, aims to resume 50% of its production in China by the end of February and 80% by March, according to a source. The company's reopening was delayed due to the coronavirus outbreak in China, which has killed over 1,100 people. Foxconn's chairman, Liu Young-Way, set these internal targets.

site_title: Sembcorp inks solar panel deal with Singapore Airlines, SIA Engineering
summary: Sembcorp Industries signed a deal with Singapore Airlines and SIA Engineering to build over 20,000 solar panels with a capacity of 8.2 megawatt-peak (MWp) for their facilities. The deal is part of SIA's commitment to renewable energy sources and is expected to contribute to the national grid and Changi Airport Group's electrical grid.
