The contract is not expected to impact the companies' earnings, with Sembcorp adding 2.49% to its stock price and SIA increasing by 1.29%. The deal increases Sembcorp's solar capacity pipeline to approximately 250MWp.

site_title: Virus hits China's gold jewellery demand as shoppers stay away
summary: China's gold jewellery demand is expected to plummet this year due to the economic damage from the coronavirus crisis. Sales are projected to drop 6% in China, extending a 7% decline in 2019 to a seven-year low. The crisis has led to shoppers limiting spending to basic necessities and retailers shortening business hours to prevent the disease from spreading. The decline in gold sales could have a significant impact on global markets, potentially boosting gold prices if the outbreak continues to accelerate or develops into a pandemic.

site_title: Shophouses in Neil Road, Jasmine Road up for sale
summary: Two conservation shophouses in Neil Road and three others in Jasmine Road are up for sale, with indicative prices ranging from S$15.57 million to S$22.88 million. The shophouses offer potential for redevelopment, including conversion into serviced apartments or co-living spaces, and are situated near Tanjong Pagar and Outram Park MRT stations. The sale of the properties is expected to attract "healthy interest" from local and foreign investors, driven by Singapore's strong fundamentals and long-term growth potential.

site_title: SMEs to get free StarHub softphone service for remote working during outbreak
summary: StarHub is offering free softphone service to small and medium enterprises (SMEs) for remote working during the novel coronavirus outbreak, starting Feb 13, 2020, until Sept 1, 2020. The service, called SmartUC Mobile, allows SME employees to make and receive landline calls from remote locations using their mobile phones and/or laptops. This initiative aims to help SME customers manage business risks and maintain operations amidst the outbreak, according to StarHub's chief of enterprise business group, Charlie Chan.

site_title: Singapore retail takings fall 3.4% in December with drop in motor vehicle sales
summary: Singapore retail sales fell 3.4% year-on-year in December, largely due to a 24.1% drop in motor vehicle sales. Excluding motor vehicles, sales were up 0.1%. Sales declined for furniture and household equipment, computer and telecommunications equipment, department stores, and food retailers, but rose for watches and jewellery, petrol service stations, and other categories. Food and beverage services saw a 2.7% year-on-year increase, while fast food outlets and cafes experienced significant gains.

site_title: Airbus, CAAS sign MOU to work on urban air mobility
summary: Airbus and the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) signed a memorandum of understanding to enable urban air mobility in Singapore. The collaboration aims to set up UAM services and platforms to enhance industry productivity and improve regional connectivity. Airbus and CAAS will work together to define and develop an initial UAM service with an unmanned aircraft system, creating an unmanned traffic management system and fostering public acceptance. This partnership builds on their previous collaboration on a 2016 UAS proof-of-concept trial and aims to develop safe and reliable transportation solutions for urban environments.

site_title: SoftBank Vision Fund loses US$2b on portfolio struggles
summary: SoftBank Group Corp's Vision Fund reported a 225.1 billion yen ($2.84 billion) loss for the three months ended in December, marking the second consecutive quarterly loss. The loss is attributed to struggles with startup investments, following a record quarterly loss in the September quarter. Despite a slim operating profit of 2.6 billion yen, the Vision Fund's performance has been a concern for SoftBank and founder Masayoshi Son, who has faced challenges in the past year, including the meltdown of WeWork and the disappointing public debut of Uber.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index opens higher, tracking gains in US
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index opened 0.28% higher, tracking gains in US stocks, as concerns about the China virus outbreak decreased. The index rose 66.14 points to 23,752.12. Meanwhile, US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats.

site_title: ST Engineering inks 2 maintenance contracts with T'way Air
summary: ST Engineering's aerospace arm has signed two multi-year maintenance, repair and overhaul (MRO) contracts with South Korean airline T'way Air, effective from March 2020. The contracts cover component and engine MRO for T'way Air's 28 Boeing 737-800 aircraft, including 25 Boeing 737 MAX aircraft. This extends their decade-long partnership, with ST Engineering providing reliable and comprehensive maintenance services.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks hit 3-week high on falling new coronavirus cases
summary: South Korean stocks reached a near three-week high on February 12, 2020, after China reported its lowest number of new coronavirus cases since late January, suggesting the outbreak could be over by April. The Seoul stock market's main KOSPI index closed at 2,238.38, a 0.69% gain.

site_title: Asia: Markets rise as coronavirus concerns ease
summary: Asia-Pacific markets rose on Wednesday as investor sentiment improved following cautious comments from US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell on the coronavirus outbreak. The virus has killed over 1,100 people and infected tens of thousands, but Powell's comments suggested the Fed is closely monitoring the situation. Markets in Tokyo, Hong Kong, Sydney, and Singapore rose, with Shanghai also up. Despite concerns about China's economy and the impact on multinational firms, crude prices recovered, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records.

images.alt_text: Markets in Asia-Pacific rose on Wednesday following another positive lead from Wall Street with investor sentiment mixed about the immediate and long-term impact of the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Under 200 DBS staff sent home after MBFC employee found to have Covid-19
summary: DBS confirmed one employee at its Marina Bay Financial Centre office has been infected with the novel coronavirus. As a precautionary measure, over 200 staff members on the affected floor have been sent home, with 20 employees requiring a 14-day leave of absence. The bank is deep cleaning and disinfecting the premises, providing support to the infected employee and his family, and offering personal hygiene packs to all employees. This is the second confirmed case at MBFC, following a confirmed case at Standard Chartered's office in Tower 1.

site_title: China's aviation regulator hopes countries will lift virus-related travel curbs soon
summary: China's aviation regulator hopes countries will lift virus-related travel curbs soon, in line with WHO and ICAO guidance. The regulator will continue to lobby authorities for subsidies to aid airlines impacted by travel restrictions due to the coronavirus. This move aims to support the aviation industry affected by the travel curbs, which have been in place since the outbreak of the virus in China.

site_title: Malaysia's Q4 economic growth slumps to decade-low, virus to hit Q1
summary: Malaysia's economy grew 3.6% in Q4, the lowest pace in a decade, due to lower palm oil, crude oil, and natural gas output, as well as a fall in exports amid the US-China trade war. The coronavirus outbreak in China is expected to put further pressure on the economy, particularly in Q1. The central bank has forecast the economy to grow at 4.8% this year, but the government is working on a stimulus package to support aviation, retailing, and tourism. Full-year growth came in at 4.3%, below forecasts.

site_title: Australia's 'black summer' provides glimmer of hope for climate policy action
summary: Australia's devastating bushfires, dubbed the "Black Summer," have created a window of opportunity for the country to break its decade-long climate policy impasse. Independent politician Zali Steggall has proposed legislation to achieve zero carbon emissions by 2050, which could gain traction if the Liberal Party and Labor agree to a conscience vote. However, Prime Minister Scott Morrison's government is under pressure from conservative MPs to fund new coal-fired power stations, making the bill's passage uncertain. The country's failure to meet its Paris Climate Accord target and its significant carbon emissions per person have sparked global criticism.

site_title: Pratt & Whitney, ST Engineering develop 3D-printing process for metal engine parts
summary: Pratt & Whitney, a division of United Technologies Corp, has developed an industrialized process for 3D-printing metal engine parts in collaboration with ST Engineering. The process, a first in the maintenance, repair and overhaul (MRO) scene for commercial engines, will produce a fuel system component on one of Pratt & Whitney's engine models. The use of 3D printing is expected to reduce dependency on conventional fabrication processes and improve repair efficiency. The technology is part of Pratt & Whitney's digital transformation roadmap, which aims to integrate artificial intelligence, robotics, and automation across operations.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed higher on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.87% to 27,823.66, following a second consecutive day of gains amid easing concerns about the coronavirus outbreak in China. Mainland China's benchmark Shanghai Composite Index also rose 0.87%. The gains came despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions and a decline in European stocks, which were dragged down by mining and healthcare sectors.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng Index rose 0.87 per cent, or 239.78 points, to 27,823.66.

site_title: Indonesia says won't repatriate hundreds of IS recruits
summary: Indonesia will not repatriate nearly 700 IS recruits due to security concerns, but will consider repatriating children under 10 years old on a case-by-case basis. The decision was made after a meeting between the Security Affairs Minister and President Joko Widodo, citing the risk of these fighters becoming a "dangerous new virus" upon return. Critics argue that repatriation and rehabilitation would be a better option, while experts warn that further radicalization is possible if not managed well by the government.

site_title: Singtel, SPH Magazines and others fined S$66,000 for data protection breaches
summary: Seven organizations, including Singtel, SPH Magazines, and Royal Caribbean Cruises (Asia), have been fined a total of S$66,000 for data breaches under Singapore's Personal Data Protection Act. The breaches, which occurred between 2015 and 2019, involved the exposure of personal data of 750 mobile subscribers, 685,393 user profiles, and 6,000 customer records. The fines, which total S$2.12 million since April 2016, highlight the growing number of organizations being held accountable for data protection breaches in Singapore.

site_title: Coronavirus wreaking havoc on global mail delivery
summary: The coronavirus outbreak is disrupting global mail delivery, particularly in the shipping industry, where paper documents are relied upon. Traders are facing challenges in receiving critical documents, such as bills of lading and letters of indemnity, from mainland China, leading to cargo delays. As the extended Chinese New Year holiday ends, logistical issues persist, with some shipping companies suspending services in affected areas. Industry experts suggest a shift towards paperless trade could help mitigate these issues, but technological and regulatory complexities remain a barrier.

site_title: Five SEA cities rank in JLL's Premium Office Rent tracker but rents remain reasonable: JLL
summary: Five Southeast Asian cities, including Singapore, Ho Chi Minh City, Jakarta, Manila, and Kuala Lumpur, rank in the world's top 86 most expensive premium office rental markets, according to JLL's Premium Office Rent Tracker. Singapore's net effective rents are at US$117 per year per square foot, while global tech firms, particularly online platforms, drive demand for premium office space. Other Southeast Asian cities, such as Jakarta and Ho Chi Minh City, are competing with Singapore to become the next Silicon Valley, diverting attention from Singapore as Asia's investment and innovation hub.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon up 1.31% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Wednesday afternoon, up 1.31% or 41.65 points, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,217.22. Banking stocks led the gain, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC Bank rising 1.3%, 1.4%, and 1.9% respectively. The news of a possible peak in the novel coronavirus outbreak in China this month and a potential end by April contributed to the market's optimism, with other Asia-Pacific markets also trading stronger.

site_title: Australian consumer sentiment brightens as bushfires recede
summary: Australian consumer sentiment improved slightly in February, rising 2.3% from January, driven by easing concerns over bushfires. However, concerns over the coronavirus outbreak in China and globally remain a headwind. The index still indicates pessimists outnumber optimists, and consumer spending remains subdued. The economic outlook for the next 12 months and five-year outlook also showed slight improvements, but the outlook for family finances and overall consumer spending remains below long-term averages.

site_title: John Lim's family office, ARA, Straits Trading to offer S$5m in loans to help SMEs amid outbreak
summary: Singaporean property tycoon John Lim's family office, ARA Asset Management, and Straits Trading Company have launched a S$5 million fund to provide short-term loans to SMEs in Singapore affected by the COVID-19 outbreak. The loans, up to S$50,000 for six months, will have an interest rate of 0.5% per month and a 2% processing fee. The fund aims to support viable businesses with good credit history, and applications can be approved within 48 hours. The initiative is seen as a practical and fast way to help businesses, rather than grants or funds with no terms.

site_title: Asiana Airlines asks cabin crew to take unpaid leave amid China flight reduction
summary: Asiana Airlines has asked cabin crew members to take unpaid leave due to reduced China flights amid coronavirus concerns. The airline is accepting applications for unpaid leave from Feb 15-29 and may consider more leave in March. Yonhap reported 80% of flights between China and South Korea have been suspended or reduced. The move aims to minimize staff presence on flights.

site_title: GIC buys LG Twin Towers in Beijing for more than 8b yuan
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC has acquired LG Twin Towers in Beijing for over 8 billion yuan (S$1.59 billion). The integrated development, comprising two Grade-A office towers and a retail podium, has a total gross floor area of 140,680 square meters. GIC expects the investment to benefit from strong demand for offices in central Beijing and generate resilient returns over the long term, solidifying its commitment to investing in China.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher on Wednesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.48% at the open on Wednesday, tracking positive cues from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index reached 27,717.22, while mainland China's Shanghai Composite Index dipped 0.21%. The Shenzhen Composite Index also fell 0.35%.

site_title: Australia: Shares up on financials, slowing virus, New Zealand hits record high
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% to a nearly three-week high, driven by Commonwealth Bank of Australia's smaller-than-expected earnings drop and relief over a slowing coronavirus outbreak in China, which may be over by April. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 7,086.1. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index hit a record high as the Reserve Bank of New Zealand held interest rates steady.

site_title: New Zealand central bank keeps rates unchanged at 1.0%
summary: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) maintained its official cash rate at 1.0% in its first policy meeting for the year, defying expectations of a rate cut. The decision was influenced by receding domestic risks, leading to a 0.8% increase in the New Zealand dollar. The move was in contrast to global economic concerns, including China's slowing GDP growth and the UK's economic contraction.

site_title: In Brief
summary: Collins Aerospace Systems opened its 10,000 square foot Singapore Innovation Hub to develop and standardize advanced digital and automation technologies for maintenance, repair and overhaul operations. The company has committed to delivering over 40 proof-of-concepts over the next five years. Collins Aerospace also entered into a 12-year agreement with Singapore Airlines to support the carrier's B787 aircraft fleet. Meanwhile, Satys will operate two new paint hangars at the Bombardier Singapore Service Center, and Airbus unveiled a new demonstrator model for a fuel-efficient, twin-engine jet.

site_title: Coronavirus death toll passes 1,110: Chinese government
summary: China's coronavirus death toll has surpassed 1,113, with 2,000 new cases reported on Wednesday. The number of infected people has risen to 44,600, with 1,638 in the hard-hit province of Hubei. The virus is believed to have emerged in a market selling wild animals in Wuhan, China's capital. The World Health Organization (WHO) has urged countries to share data to further research the disease, citing a "grave threat" for the rest of the world.

site_title: US households add US$601b of debt in 2019: NY Federal Reserve
summary: US households added $601 billion in debt in 2019, the largest yearly gain since 2007, bringing total household debt to a record high of $14.15 trillion. The increase was fueled by rising mortgage debt, with new home loans reaching their highest volume since 2005. However, the debt load is taking a toll on some households, with younger credit card borrowers falling behind on payments. The New York Fed warned that this trend may continue, with student loans also rising to $1.51 trillion and 9.21% past due by 90 days or more.

site_title: Australian bank CBA weighs capital return, shares soar to 5-year high
summary: Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA) posted a better-than-expected half-year profit of A$4.48 billion, driving its shares to a near five-year peak. The bank is considering returning capital to shareholders. This move comes as the lender appears to be recovering from scandals and solidifying its dominance in the saturated Australian home loan market, despite record-low interest rates.

images.alt_text: Commonwealth Bank of Australia posted a better than expected half-year profit and said it was actively considering returning capital to shareholders, driving its shares higher to a near five-year peak.

site_title: 2 new novel coronavirus cases in Singapore
summary: Two new novel coronavirus cases have been confirmed in Singapore, bringing the total to 47. The new cases are a 39-year-old Bangladeshi worker at Seletar Aerospace Heights and a 35-year-old Singaporean permanent resident working at Resorts World Sentosa. Seven patients remain in critical condition, while two have been discharged. The Ministry of Health has identified 1,124 close contacts, with 989 being quarantined or isolated.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.82 points or 0.05% to 1,550.66. Volume was 54.6 million lots worth RM28.16 million. The market saw 99 gainers compared to 66 losers.

site_title: Prime US Reit Q4 DPU of 1.77 US cents, 9% above IPO forecast
summary: Prime US Reit reported a 9% increase in fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.77 US cents, beating the initial public offering forecast of 1.62 US cents. Gross revenue rose 2% to US$33.5 million, driven by higher rental income and recoveries income. The company also announced a plan to acquire a US$165.5 million property in Sacramento, California, and raised at least US$100 million in gross proceeds through a private placement.

site_title: Europe: German shares hit record highs as coronavirus fears ease
summary: German shares hit a record high on Tuesday, leading Europe's DAX to a record close amid easing coronavirus fears. The DAX rose 1% to 13,627.84, driven by gains in Deutsche Telekom, Nokia, and Ericsson after the US approved a $26 billion merger. The rally was fueled by slowing new coronavirus cases in China, but some analysts warn it may be premature and vulnerable to negative news.

site_title: Britain and EU split over financial market access
summary: Britain and the European Union are at odds over financial market access, with Britain seeking a stable relationship for "decades to come." Finance Minister Sajid Javid urged the EU to consider Britain's financial sector equivalent to its own, but EU chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier said there would be no general equivalence with Britain. The two sides have agreed to assess equivalence by the end of June, with actual access linked to broader trade issues. The UK's financial stability and competitiveness are at risk if it doesn't participate in EU rule development.

site_title: Singapore shares edge up at Wednesday's open; STI up 0.18%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.18% to 3,181.22 at the open, tracking Wall Street gains overnight. Gainers outnumbered losers 56 to 31, with heavy trading in GSS Energy and Trendlines. Financials were mostly up, including United Overseas Bank and OCBC Bank. The US tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index closed at a record high, while the S&P 500 rose 0.2%. The Singapore market is expected to continue its 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: IMF says China can top up stimulus but must focus on reform
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has stated that China can implement fiscal stimulus measures if its economy slows further, but must focus on structural reforms and address rapid credit growth. Director Changyong Rhee warned that the coronavirus outbreak adds to the risks to the region's growth outlook, particularly for countries closely tied to China. It is too early to assess the impact of the outbreak, but the IMF emphasizes the need for China to prioritize reforms to mitigate potential economic risks.

site_title: Oil prices rise about 1%, up from 13-month low as virus cases slow
summary: Oil prices rose about 1% on Tuesday, rebounding from 13-month lows, as the number of new coronavirus cases slowed in China, easing concerns over demand destruction. Brent crude settled at $54.01 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose to $49.94 a barrel. Analysts say the market is trying to bottom and look beyond the virus, but investors remain wary of potential further hits to China's oil demand and oversupply concerns.

site_title: 'Time for targeted SkillsFuture top-ups' in Budget
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat hinted at plans to enhance SkillsFuture amid the economic hit from the coronavirus outbreak. Analysts propose refining the criteria for recipients, courses, and funding to make the scheme more targeted and effective. Suggestions include earmarking funds for specific in-demand capabilities, such as digital literacy, and granting top-up amounts based on age. Experts also propose tying up with industry groups and companies for "mass reskilling programmes" to support workers, particularly older Singaporeans and freelancers.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Jardine C&C, Singtel, OKH, First Sponsor, Civmec, Tiong Seng
summary: Stocks to watch on Wednesday included Jardine C&C, Singtel, OKH, First Sponsor, Civmec, and Tiong Seng, following various developments. Jardine C&C's bid to privatize Cycle & Carriage Bintang was rejected by shareholders. Singtel won an arbitration against TOT Public Company over roaming revenue share, but TOT can still file a petition. OKH's net profit declined in the second quarter. First Sponsor's fourth-quarter net profit jumped 63% and group revenue rose 13.5%. Civmec posted a tripling in net earnings for the second quarter. Tiong Seng announced contracts for two private-home projects worth S$123.9 million.

site_title: Samsung joins the fold with Galaxy Z Flip smartphone
summary: Samsung unveiled its second folding smartphone, the Galaxy Z Flip, with a 6.7-inch screen that can be folded and unfolded over 200,000 times. The device will be available starting at $1,380 and is aimed at "trendsetters" and "trailblazers." The company also introduced a new Galaxy S 20 Ultra flagship model with 5G capabilities, starting at $999. Additionally, Samsung announced partnerships with Netflix and Xbox for exclusive content and gaming experiences.

site_title: Trump under fire for intervening in Roger Stone case
summary: US President Donald Trump faced accusations of abuse of power after the Justice Department moved to override prosecutors' recommendations for a 7-9 year sentence for Roger Stone, a longtime Trump cohort. The proposed reduction appeared to be a response to Trump's tweet attacking the recommended sentence. The Justice Department's intervention sparked the resignation of four prosecutors, with senior House Democrat Adam Schiff calling it a "blatant abuse of power" that threatened the rule of law.

site_title: US: Nasdaq, S&P edge to closing records as virus fears ebb
summary: US stocks closed at record highs on Tuesday, with the Nasdaq Composite Index and S&P 500 edging up 0.1% and 0.2% respectively. The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished flat at 29,276.34. Fears of the viral outbreak in China's economic disruption eased, contributing to the gains.

site_title: Draft US law to make plastic industry responsible for recycling
summary: The US Congress has introduced the "Break Free From Plastic Pollution Act," a bill that would hold the plastic industry responsible for recycling. The proposed law would require producers to collect and recycle their own waste, create a nationwide drink container refund scheme, and phase out certain single-use plastic items. The bill also aims to pause new plastic production for up to three years and create a 10-cent national refund program for beverage containers. However, its passage is unlikely due to a Republican majority opposing curbs on the industry, which generates $400 billion in sales.

site_title: First Sponsor Q4 profit up 63% to S$94.9m
summary: First Sponsor Group reported a 63% increase in net profit to S$94.9 million for its Q4, driven by revenue growth from hotel operations, property financing, and property sales. Earnings per share rose to 11.75 Singapore cents. The company also reported a 47.9% increase in full-year net profit to S$167.1 million. A final tax-exempt dividend of 1.6 Singapore cents per share is recommended, subject to shareholder approval.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Chasing Cars: Going car-less
summary: A Money FM podcast, "Chasing Cars: Going Car-less," discussed the option of abandoning car ownership. The episode explored alternatives such as private hire, car-sharing, and short-term lease options. Claressa Monteiro, the podcast's producer, delved into the pros and cons of this lifestyle choice. The conversation centered around practicality, affordability, and the environmental impact of reduced car usage.

site_title: Big Tech acquisitions over past decade to face fresh US review
summary: The US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) announced a review of acquisitions made by five major tech firms - Amazon, Apple, Facebook, Microsoft, and Alphabet (Google) - between 2010 and 2019. The review aims to assess potential antitrust concerns, with FTC Chairman Joe Simons stating that it could lead to "unwinding" of past deals. The move comes amid growing concerns about the dominance of these tech giants and potential anticompetitive actions, although experts downplay the likelihood of major action resulting from the review.

site_title: Federal Reserve 'closely monitoring' global risks from coronavirus: Powell
summary: US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell stated that the central bank is closely monitoring global risks from the coronavirus outbreak in China, which could impact the global economy. The death toll has surpassed 1,000, and transportation disruptions are affecting shipments to foreign manufacturers. Powell's comments come as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: The US central bank is keeping watch for any impact from the virus outbreak in China that could spread beyond its borders, Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell said on Tuesday.

site_title: New coronavirus outbreak threatens green shoots of global recovery
summary: A novel coronavirus outbreak threatens the global economy's recovery, as the virus has killed over 1,000 people and spread globally, impacting trade, tourism, and manufacturing. The outbreak's uncertainty has led to a decrease in business sentiment, and the global economy may face supply shocks and reduced domestic demand. Central banks in Asia have responded with rate cuts, while China is expected to implement more stimulus measures to prop up growth. The US Federal Reserve is also expected to cut borrowing costs further if the global economy weakens.

site_title: High stakes as New Hampshire holds key White House primary
summary: In New Hampshire's high-stakes primary, Democratic hopefuls Bernie Sanders and Pete Buttigieg battled for pole position to challenge President Donald Trump. Joe Biden conceded he expects to do badly, but still hopes to right the ship in Nevada and South Carolina. Sanders, a senator from Vermont, is the strong favorite, with 28.7% support, followed by Buttigieg at 21.3%. The primary outcome is seen as crucial in shaping the Democratic nomination and ultimately the nation's future, with the winner aiming to defeat Trump in November.

site_title: 39 more on board Japan cruise ship have new coronavirus: minister
summary: Japanese Health Minister Katsunobu Kato announced 39 new coronavirus cases on the Diamond Princess cruise ship, bringing the total to 174. Out of 53 new test results, 39 people tested positive, and a quarantine official also contracted the virus. The ship remains off the Japan coast, and the situation is being closely monitored.

images.alt_text: An additional 39 people on board the Diamond Princess cruise ship off the Japan coast have tested positive for the new coronavirus, Japanese Health Minister Katsunobu Kato said on Wednesday, bringing the total to 174.

site_title: Intel, Vivo, LG drop out of key mobile fair
summary: US chip giant Intel and Chinese phonemaker Vivo withdrew from the Mobile World Congress (MWC) due to coronavirus fears. This adds to the list of industry heavyweights pulling out, including Sony, Ericsson, LG, and NTT DoCoMo. Vivo postponed its mobile presentation, while Huawei and ZTE remain set to attend, with executives and staff undergoing a self-imposed quarantine. The event, scheduled for Feb 24-27, has seen significant participation decline due to the outbreak, which has claimed over 1,000 lives.

site_title: Jan condo resale prices inch up; Feb data likely to show virus impact
summary: Singapore's non-landed private residential property resale prices rose 2.3% year-on-year in January, with a 0.5% increase from December. Sales volume grew 15.9% year-on-year, with 684 units resold in January. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, resale prices have been less affected, with experts predicting a 25-30% drop in the first quarter. Condominium resale prices in the core central region (CCR) fell 0.8%, while prices in the rest of central region (RCR) rose 1.5%.

site_title: ST Engineering clinches 5-year Qantas maintenance deal
summary: ST Engineering's aerospace arm secured a 5-year nacelle maintenance contract with Qantas Airways, starting in 2020. The deal covers Boeing 737-800 and Airbus A330 fleet maintenance services. This marks the company's expansion into nacelle maintenance, repair, and overhaul (MRO) services. Additionally, ST Engineering secured two new aircraft conversion orders and a 3-year airframe heavy maintenance contract with a North American airline. The company's shares closed at S$4.20, up 1% on the news.

site_title: Shipping must be prepared for wider spread of virus
summary: The novel coronavirus has spread to Singapore, with a confirmed case reported on January 29, prompting the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore to urge shipping companies to take precautions. The industry is gearing up to cope with the implications of the disease, with shipping companies and seafarers advised to adopt good hygiene practices. The global shipping industry is already feeling the impact, with certain sectors, such as the cruise industry, being particularly vulnerable. Operations have been impacted, with some ships being refused entry to ports and cargo delivery being delayed due to transportation restrictions.

site_title: WHO head sees chance to stop virus which poses 'grave' threat
summary: WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus says countries have a chance to stop the global spread of the new coronavirus, urging cooperation and data sharing. The virus has killed over 1,000, infected over 42,000, and reached 25 countries, with 99% of cases in China. Despite low mortality rate, the virus poses a "grave threat" to the rest of the world, with cases abroad linked to infected individuals who had not traveled to China. The WHO is holding a conference to combat the virus, while countries impose travel bans and restrictions to contain its spread.

site_title: Germany must take the lead in Europe's innovation move
summary: Germany is at risk of falling behind in the digital innovation era, with the country's economy struggling to adapt to the increasing importance of software and data. The recent surge in US technology giant Apple's worth compared to Germany's DAX index has deepened the economic slowdown. To survive, German firms must collaborate with software companies and invest in new digital technologies, such as the Internet of Things and artificial intelligence. The German government should establish a European research agency, similar to the US DARPA, to provide technological backing and support innovation, ultimately driving Germany's industrial revival and staying competitive globally.

site_title: World Bank: New China loans not needed to fight coronavirus given ample reserves
summary: The World Bank is offering technical assistance to China to combat the coronavirus, but no new loans will be provided due to China's ample international reserves. World Bank President David Malpass stated that China has sufficient resources to address the crisis, citing its $3.115 trillion in foreign exchange reserves. The bank is instead providing advice on health, sanitation, and disease policies, and experts are in discussions with Chinese authorities to provide immediate assistance.

site_title: Party of India PM Modi stung in New Delhi election
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's right-wing party, the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), suffered a crushing defeat in the New Delhi election, with the Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) winning 62 of 70 assembly seats. The AAP's leader, Arvind Kejriwal, easily won a second term, and Modi congratulated him on Twitter. The BJP's aggressive campaign, which focused on defending a contentious nationality law, backfired and was criticized for its "politics of hate." The defeat is the latest in a string of setbacks for Modi's party in regional elections over the past two years.

images.alt_text: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's right wing party suffered a crushing defeat on Tuesday in an election for control of the capital New Delhi after a vitriolic campaign in which it concentrated on defending a controversial new nationality law.

site_title: It's not end of the road for taxi business: Trans-cab boss
summary: Trans-cab Holdings CEO Teo Kiang Ang believes the taxi industry will not disappear despite the threat from ride-hailing startups, citing government support and Singapore's tourist market. The company has a strong financial position with S$17.7 million in cash and S$107.4 million in unused credit facilities. Trans-cab has adapted to the changing market by collaborating with ride-hailing apps and has a growing leasing-services business. The company expects to expand its fleet if the cost of certification of entitlement (COEs) stays low, and its taxi operator licence will expire in 2023.

site_title: Equity trading on SGX still strong in January despite growing fears over virus
summary: Singapore's stock trading remained strong in January, despite the Chinese New Year festivities and concerns over the novel coronavirus. Total securities market turnover rose 27% to S$25.6 billion, with equity and debt fundraising increasing 49% to S$50.4 billion. Market turnover for exchange-traded funds and structured warrants also surged, with record volumes seen in January. The US-China Phase One trade agreement boosted institutional investor optimism, driving growth in equity derivatives. However, commodity prices took a hit due to the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: USD at 4-month high, yield-seeking tactics pay off
summary: The US dollar reached a four-month high against its rivals, closing within striking distance of its 2019 peak, as subdued price swings encouraged hedge funds to invest in the relatively high-yielding currency. This trend, known as a carry trade, has historically been rewarding, with returns of nearly 5% in 2018-2019. Low market volatility, partly driven by central banks, has fueled the dollar's rise, with implied market volatility for the euro/dollar pair briefly plummeting to a record low.

site_title: HDB launches over 3,000 BTO flats in first exercise for 2020
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) launched 3,095 Build-To-Order (BTO) flats in Singapore, across two projects in Toa Payoh and one in Sembawang. The flats are priced from S$89,000 for a two-room flexi flat to S$395,000 for a four-room flat. This is the first BTO launch for Toa Payoh in 2018, and the Sembawang project is near the upcoming Bukit Canberra integrated sports hub. Applications close on Feb 17.

site_title: STI takes breather from virus worries
summary: Asian equities rebounded on Tuesday, with Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closing 0.4% higher after a strong showing on Wall Street. The Shanghai Composite Index also rose 0.4%, with investors taking heart from falling new coronavirus cases in China. However, strategists caution against complacency, warning that the risk of secondary infections remains. Trading volume in Singapore was 27% above the 2019 daily average, with most medical plays closing lower except for Clearbridge Health, which rose 3.8%.

site_title: Macquarie sticks to lower profit guidance, preps for low-carbon projects
summary: Macquarie Group has stuck to its profit guidance for 2020, citing a decline in investment banking earnings. The bank reported higher fee income from its asset management and lending businesses, and flagged opportunities in low-carbon projects. Its energy trading unit had a "strong" performance, with potential to grow into adjacent areas. Macquarie's asset management business saw assets under management rise 5% to A$587.5 billion, driven by higher fund-management fees and investment gains.

site_title: 3 lessons from owning Reits for 15 years
summary: A 15-year investor in Real Estate Investment Trusts (Reits) shares three key traits to look for in Reit investments: the sustainability of a Reit, the location of properties, and having a multinational sponsor. Reits have grown in popularity, with abundant choices available across the globe. However, investors must be aware of the risks, including the need for Reits to pay out 90% of income and the potential for credit crunches to impact refinancing of debt. With patience and a long-term perspective, investors can benefit from growing distributions and the stability of physical properties.

site_title: Virus fears, US-China diplomacy loom over Singapore Airshow
summary: The Singapore Airshow began under heightened scrutiny due to novel coronavirus fears, with attendance scaled down to 40,000 from 45,000. Over 70 companies pulled out, citing fears over the outbreak. Despite this, several major deals were announced, including a deal between ATR and PNG Air for short take-off and landing aircraft. Boeing also secured a deal to convert passenger jets to freighters, while Korean Air Lines ordered Pratt & Whitney engines for Airbus A321neo jets. The airshow also featured a rare display of US and Chinese fighters, amid tensions between the two nations in Asia.

site_title: Thailand bars entry to cruise ship with no known virus cases aboard
summary: Thailand has barred passengers from Holland America's cruise ship, the Westerdam, from disembarking despite no confirmed virus cases on board. The ship, carrying 1,455 passengers and 802 crew, was initially set to dock in Bangkok but was denied permission. Thailand will provide fuel, medicine, and food to the ship instead. The move follows other countries such as Japan and the Philippines in turning away the vessel due to fears of the novel coronavirus. The ship had introduced extra health screening measures, including temperature checks and cleaning, before being turned away.

site_title: OCBC downgrades SIAEC to 'sell' as virus weighs on travel demand
summary: OCBC Investment Research downgraded SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) to 'sell' due to the impact of the novel coronavirus on air travel demand. The downgrade lowers the fair value estimate from S$2.86 to S$2.41. This follows a similar trend seen during the Sars epidemic in 2003, where visitor arrivals and incoming flights declined, weighing heavily on SIAEC's airframe business and resulting in a 21% y-o-y drop in FY2003 revenue.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Eu Yan Sang has denied media reports of a potential sale, stating they are "rumours" and will focus on executing strategies and enhancing shareholder value. Hatten Land posted a net profit of RM285,000 for its second quarter, reversing a net loss from the previous year. Singtel's Thai associate, AIS, won an arbitration against TOT Public Company, while Jardine Cycle & Carriage's bid to privatise Cycle & Carriage Bintang was rejected by shareholders. BM Mobility applied to go under judicial management, citing suspension of trading since July 2019.

site_title: Singapore incumbent banks should launch digital offensive in Asean
summary: Singapore's incumbent banks are poised to launch a digital offensive in ASEAN, capitalizing on the region's growing demand for digital banking services. Despite the presence of non-bank players, Singapore's banking incumbents have a significant market share and can leverage their local presence to set up digital entities in ASEAN. DBS and UOB have already made strides in the region, and OCBC is also exploring digital banking opportunities. The banks can tap into global fintech firms and e-commerce platforms to offer a technology edge and tap into the region's large and growing e-commerce market.

site_title: IT Show among major events postponed
summary: The organiser of Singapore's IT Show, Food & Beverage Fair, BuildTech Asia, and CARGONOW has postponed the four events until further notice due to safety and health concerns related to the novel coronavirus outbreak. The events, originally scheduled for March, will be delayed after exhibitors and local exhibitors considered pulling out. Two suspected cases of the virus emerged in Suntec City and OUE Downtown, prompting the postponement. New event dates will be announced when available.

images.alt_text: In light of uncertainties from the novel coronavirus outbreak, the organiser of Singapore's IT Show, Food & Beverage Fair and BuildTech Asia/Cargonow has postponed the three events until further notice.

site_title: China's home sales plunge 90% in first week of February
summary: China's home sales plummeted 90% in the first week of February, with new apartment sales dropping 90% and existing home sales plummeting 91% in eight cities. The sector is bracing for a worse impact than the 2003 SARS pandemic, with property developers facing a liquidity crisis due to restricted sales and potential decline in incomes. Experts predict demand may start picking up in April, but the downturn will challenge developers with poor liquidity.

site_title: Asia must lead in tackling the plastic waste crisis
summary: Asia, home to over half of the world's plastic debris in oceans, must lead in tackling the plastic waste crisis. Poor waste collection and recycling systems, driven by high plastic consumption and urbanization, contribute to the problem. Less than 10% of global plastic waste is recycled, with the majority ending up in landfills or improperly discarded. To solve the crisis, a multi-stakeholder effort is needed, including government policies, private sector intervention, and consumer engagement. Asia's diverse communities require tailored solutions, and financial institutions are ready to unlock capital for recycling and plastic value-chain solutions.

site_title: AI for the new decade in Singapore
summary: Singapore unveils AI initiatives to elevate consumer trust and governance, aiming to stay technologically competitive. The country's focus on innovation and collaboration will be crucial in bridging concerns over AI's presence and use among communities. Digital assistants, leveraging AI and machine learning, will gain a greater understanding of user needs, anticipating demands and recommending next steps. Industry-specific templates will also emerge, enabling easier use and deployment of AI in key sectors such as manufacturing and retail. With stronger government and regulatory support, Singapore is poised to establish itself as an AI powerhouse.

site_title: White House race: battle of the billionaires?
summary: The Democratic Party's chances of defeating President Trump in the 2020 election are dwindling due to internal divisions and the country's electoral deadlock. Despite a diverse slate of candidates, the party remains unable to unite behind a single electable candidate. The Iowa caucuses' technical fiasco and subsequent infighting have further weakened the party. With no clear candidate emerging, billionaire Mike Bloomberg, a centrist Democrat, is seen as the only one who can bring together moderate Democrats and independents to potentially beat Trump in November.

images.alt_text: Mr Bloomberg, a former New York mayor, ex-Republican and successful businessman, has embraced the positions that helped the Democrats take over the House in 2018.

site_title: Ten years on, Singapore's Asia Genesis hedge fund plans comeback
summary: Singaporean hedge fund manager Chua Soon Hock is reviving his Asia Genesis Macro Fund after a 10-year hiatus, with the goal of achieving a net return of over 10% annually. The fund, backed by Chua and two former executives, will start trading with $50-100 million in assets. Chua, a legendary trader, has a proven track record, delivering an 18.7% annual return over the previous fund's 10-year life. He aims to train world-class Singaporean traders and has a unique approach, focusing on "many good risk-reward trades" rather than trying to beat algorithms.

site_title: Axcelasia to sell key unit in Malaysia, considering 'various options available'
summary: CATALIST-LISTED firm Axcelasia Inc is selling its Malaysian subsidiary Axcelasia Taxand to Hong Kong's Tricor Group for RM69.7 million (S$23.4 million). The sale will leave Axcelasia with just its holding company and subsidiaries in Singapore, Lao, and Vietnam. The deal is expected to result in a gain of RM64.9 million for the company. Axcelasia will consider various options after the sale, including distributing the proceeds in a dividend, and will update shareholders in due course.

site_title: EU rejects calls for permanent access for London financial firms
summary: The European Union has rejected the UK government's request for permanent equivalence for London's financial services firms, even if the UK breaks away from EU rules after Brexit. Chancellor Sajid Javid had included the demand in a draft of the UK's opening positions for trade negotiations. EU chief Barnier stated that the EU will not grant open-ended access, and instead will require the UK to meet specific rules. This decision is seen as a significant blow to the UK's financial sector, which had hoped to maintain its access to the EU's single market.

site_title: Job openings in US fall to two-year low, capping annual drop
summary: US job openings fell to a two-year low of 6.42 million in December, down 364,000 from the previous month, according to the Labor Department's Job Openings and Labour Turnover Survey. This marks the first annual decline since 2009. The number of available positions decreased despite forecasts of a modest gain, and the quits rate remained at 2.3% for a fourth consecutive month. The decline caps the annual drop, which may reflect weaker demand for hiring as more people join the workforce.

site_title: Ex-billionaire Mallya fights extradition from UK for fraud
summary: Former Indian billionaire Vijay Mallya is fighting extradition from the UK to face fraud and money laundering charges in India. Mallya's lawyers claim a previous ruling to send him back to India was based on incorrect evidence and misunderstandings about the collapse of Kingfisher Airlines in 2012. Mallya's lawyers argue that he is not a fly-by-night figure, but a wealthy businessman who is contesting the extradition order, saying the magistrate "didn't look at all the evidence" and made errors in her ruling.

site_title: Focus on animal welfare guides 2 vegan funds
summary: Two new investment funds, the US Vegan Climate ETF and the Karner Blue Animal Impact Fund, focus on promoting animal welfare through their investment strategies. The US Vegan Climate ETF excludes companies involved in animal testing and fossil fuel extraction, while the Karner Blue fund employs positive screening to identify companies with good animal welfare practices. Both funds come with higher fees compared to traditional index funds, with the Karner Blue fund potentially costing up to $1,000 more per year. Despite this, they aim to promote a more sustainable and humane approach to investing.

site_title: BM Mobility files application for judicial management
summary: BM Mobility, a Singaporean company, has filed an application for judicial management due to its "deteriorating financial position". The firm cited loss-making and cash-flow insolvent nature, as well as unpaid debts, as reasons for seeking judicial management. Deloitte & Touche will be appointed as judicial managers. A court hearing date has not been set, and the company will make further announcements when developments occur. This move aims to provide the company with "breathing space" to draw up a restructuring or rescue plan.

site_title: Jokowi urges Cabinet to step up spending to shield economy from virus
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo urged the Cabinet to accelerate fiscal stimulus to shield the economy from the coronavirus crisis, citing China as Indonesia's biggest trading partner and top export destination. Despite no confirmed cases in Indonesia, officials are concerned about the economic impact, with growth projected at 5.3% for this year. The government plans to implement several omnibus laws to boost investment and counter global headwinds. Indonesia has taken measures to prevent the spread of the virus, including barring entry to visitors from China and stopping flights to and from the country.

site_title: HK banks unveil relief measures for mortgage borrowers hit by coronavirus
summary: Hong Kong banks, Bank of China (Hong Kong) and Standard Chartered, have introduced relief measures for mortgage borrowers affected by the coronavirus outbreak. Customers can apply to pay only interest for up to 6 months, with an option to extend for another 6 months. This move aims to alleviate pressure on monthly repayments for those in industries severely impacted by the outbreak, including retail, tourism, and hospitality. The measures are seen as a way to prevent foreclosures, which could worsen the already recession-hit Hong Kong economy.

site_title: 'Some IFIs are deepening poor countries' debt crisis'
summary: World Bank President David Malpass criticized other development banks for lending too quickly to heavily indebted countries, contributing to worsening debt situations. The Asian Development Bank, African Development Bank, and European Bank for Reconstruction and Development were among those singled out. Malpass called for more coordination and transparency among international financial institutions to address the issue.

site_title: US judge approves Sprint-T-Mobile merger
summary: A US federal judge approved the merger of Sprint and T-Mobile, allowing the number three and four US mobile phone companies to combine. The deal, backed by Federal Communications Commission Chairman Ajit Pai, will create a strong third US wireless carrier with resources to invest in 5G networks, potentially closing the digital divide and securing US leadership in 5G. Critics had expressed concerns over higher prices, but Pai said the merger will help achieve these goals.

site_title: ThaiBev puts off Feb 28 shareholder meeting in S'pore on coronavirus worries
summary: Thai Beverage Public Co (ThaiBev) has cancelled its annual information meeting scheduled for February 28 due to coronavirus concerns in Singapore. The meeting, intended for Singapore shareholders, has been postponed to a later date for safety reasons. The company cited the growing global spread of the virus, which has claimed over 1,000 lives in China, and the Singapore government's downgrade to Disease Outbreak Response System Condition level "Orange." ThaiBev will keep investors informed of any updates and has instructed investors not to attend the meeting.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq hit new highs at open on coronavirus optimism
summary: The US stock market opened at all-time highs on February 11, 2020, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq rising 0.41% and 0.55% respectively, driven by optimism over the potential peak of the coronavirus outbreak. The Dow Jones Industrial Average also rose 0.39%. Additionally, Sprint's shares surged after winning approval for its merger with T-Mobile.

site_title: JTC signs record S$500m of deals at airshow
summary: JTC Corporation signed a record S$500 million worth of deals at the Singapore Airshow 2020 with aerospace companies expanding their operations in Singapore over the next five years. This represents a 66% increase over the S$300 million signed at the 2018 event. Deals include new facilities, business expansions, and strengthening Singapore's position as a global aerospace hub.

images.alt_text: JTC Corporation signed a record S$500 million worth of deals at the Singapore Airshow 2020 on Tuesday with aerospace companies that will be expanding their operations in Singapore over the next five years.

site_title: Asean needs to consider its response to US-China conflict
summary: Southeast Asia must consider its response to the escalating US-China conflict, which has disrupted the region's order. Despite the recent Phase One trade agreement, tensions remain, with the US refusing to lift tariffs on Chinese imports. Asean countries, including Vietnam, are taking a hardline stance against China's expansion in the South China Sea. The US and Asean are seeking to repair their relationship, with a special summit planned in March, but Asean nations cannot rely solely on the US for support. Meanwhile, China is strengthening ties with resource-rich countries, including Myanmar, and is pushing for a closer relationship with the country.

site_title: Boeing scores no January orders for first time since 1962
summary: Boeing scored no new orders for airplanes last month, marking the first time since 1962 without a January order, due to the grounding of its 737 MAX following fatal crashes. The lack of orders leaves Boeing trailing Airbus SE and results in significant monthly financial losses. Boeing booked 296 aircraft orders in January, but 274 were net orders after cancellations. Most airline customers are avoiding fresh orders for the 737 MAX until it is cleared by regulators to fly again.

site_title: Outbreak may slash visitor arrivals 25-30%; STB not counting on V-shaped recovery
summary: Singapore's tourism sector is bracing for a 25-30% decline in visitor arrivals this year due to the novel coronavirus outbreak, according to the Singapore Tourism Board (STB). The decline is expected to be "roughly in line" with the decline in arrivals, with a rough estimate of 18,000 to 20,000 international visitor arrivals lost each day. The STB is urging locals to boost consumption in tourism, hospitality, and lifestyle services to support the recovery. The board has formed a Tourism Recovery Action Task Force to develop strategies and plans for recovery, with a focus on attracting more local visitors and managing costs.

site_title: Tiong Seng units bag S$124m worth of contracts for en bloc sites
summary: Tiong Seng Holdings' subsidiaries secured contracts worth S$124m for two private-home projects, taking the group's construction order book to S$1 billion until 2023. The deals include a S$99.6m project for six 12-storey apartment blocks in Holland Road and a S$24.3m project for a 15-storey apartment block at the former Cairnhill Heights. The contracts are expected to be completed by February 2020, with minimal impact on the group's net tangible assets and earnings per share.

site_title: World's happiest people seek road to financial smarts
summary: Finland, ranked the world's happiest country, is developing a financial-literacy strategy to help its citizens manage their finances. The central bank aims to improve financial literacy, which is key to unlocking wealth creation and productivity gains. This initiative is part of a broader effort to support the well-being of its citizens, who are known for their high level of happiness and financial stability. The strategy's implementation is expected to promote financial inclusion and reduce financial stress among Finns.

site_title: Vividthree to buy rights to horror-themed comic for S$1.5m
summary: Vividthree, a Singaporean visual effects studio, has agreed to buy the rights to the horror-themed comic "Silent Horror" for S$1.5 million. The deal includes the intellectual property rights and goodwill to the business name of the creator, Darkbox Studios. Vividthree plans to utilize its post-production and content production capabilities to expand the comic's reach through its comic video platform. The acquisition is part of Vividthree's strategy to grow its IP ownership in the comic video mass market.

site_title: Powell says economy 'resilient,' but warns on coronavirus, productivity
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell expressed optimism about the US economy, citing its resilience despite global headwinds. The economy, now in its 11th year, has continued to expand, with increased economic activity and a strengthening labor market. However, Powell warned about potential threats from the coronavirus in China and expressed concerns about long-term productivity gains, which have been subpar throughout the expansion. He also emphasized the need to boost labor participation and productivity to support the economy's health.

site_title: OKH Global Q2 net profit slumps to S$54,000 on flat revenue
summary: OKH Global's Q2 net profit decreased to S$54,000, down from S$3.99 million in the same period last year, due to a negative contribution from associates. Revenue remained flat at S$4.2 million. The construction services segment experienced a slight decrease in turnover.

site_title: Electric serenade
summary: Durapower Technology Group, a leading lithium battery technology firm, is revolutionizing the electric vehicle industry with its innovative solutions. The company, which has been researching advanced battery technology for over a decade, has developed fast-charging batteries that can charge in 10-15 minutes, making electric vehicles more practical for daily use. Its batteries are also lightweight, allowing for more efficient use of space in buses and other vehicles. Durapower has successfully expanded its operations globally, with 80% of its revenue coming from international markets. The company has also established research and development centers in various countries, including Singapore, Japan, and the US. As the industry continues to grow, Durapower is poised to play a significant role in making electric vehicles more accessible and affordable.

site_title: Axcelasia Inc to sell off key Malaysian unit to HK's Tricor Group
summary: Axcelasia Inc, a Catalist-listed professional services firm, is selling its Malaysian operating subsidiary Axcelasia Taxand to Hong Kong's Tricor Group for RM69.7 million. The sale will leave Axcelasia with a holding company and three other subsidiaries, which have not contributed significantly to revenue. The transaction must be approved by shareholders through an extraordinary general meeting. Axcelasia expects a gain of RM64.9 million from the sale and is considering distributing the proceeds as a dividend, pending assessment of cash flow needs and future plans. The sale must comply with Catalist rules.

site_title: 2 new cases of coronavirus including man who works at RWS casino
summary: Singapore reported two new coronavirus cases, bringing the total to 47. A 39-year-old Bangladeshi worker at Seletar Aerospace Heights and a 35-year-old Singaporean permanent resident who works at Resorts World Sentosa casino were confirmed to have the virus. Neither case had been to China recently, and they did not live in the same premises. The cases were announced on February 11, 2020.

site_title: M&S picks CFO from supplier as executive suite's door turns
summary: Marks & Spencer (M&S) has named Eoin Tonge, CFO from food supplier Greencore Group Plc, as its new chief financial officer, replacing Humphrey Singer. This move follows a series of executive departures as the retailer seeks to turn around its business. M&S has been struggling with declining clothing sales, but its grocery arm has performed better. The company's turnaround programme aims to reverse a decade of decline, with Tonge overseeing the efforts. The shares rose 0.7% after the announcement.

site_title: Reports on company going on sale are 'rumours': Eu Yan Sang
summary: Eu Yan Sang, a Singaporean company, has denied reports of a possible sale, labeling them as "rumours". CEO Aaron Boey stated the company will focus on executing its strategies and enhancing shareholder value amidst the novel coronavirus outbreak. The company had aimed to be valued at over US$500 million, primarily targeting Chinese buyers. Eu Yan Sang has not delisted from the Singapore bourse since 2016, with majority ownership resting with a consortium consisting of the Eu family, Temasek, and private equity firm Tower Capital.

site_title: EU warns UK not to kid itself on 'equivalence' for finance
summary: The European Union has warned the UK not to expect "general, global or permanent equivalence" for its financial services, citing concerns over regulatory differences. EU Chief Brexit Negotiator Michel Barnier stated that the UK's bid for broad equivalence was not acceptable, while European Commission Chief Ursula von der Leyen said the EU is "fine" with Britain walking away without a deal if it chooses. The EU demands a "level playing field" and oversight on UK state aid decisions, complicating UK efforts to secure access to the EU market.

site_title: Novel coronavirus named 'Covid-19': UN health agency
summary: The World Health Organisation (WHO) has officially named the deadly coronavirus 'Covid-19', following its first identification in China on December 31. The name, chosen by WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, avoids references to specific locations or groups to prevent stigmatisation. The WHO had previously referred to the virus as "2019-nCoV acute respiratory disease" and China's National Health Commission as "novel coronavirus pneumonia". Tedros expressed optimism about stopping the outbreak, stating there is a "realistic chance" of controlling it.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific takes 49% stake in Tokyo retail building
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings has acquired a 49% stake in a Tokyo retail building for approximately S$65.7 million. The company injected US$10 million into investment company Vivel SG to purchase the building. The deal is expected to have a minimal impact on Roxy-Pacific's consolidated earnings and net tangible assets per share for the year to December 31, 2020.

site_title: Singtel's Thai unit AIS wins arbitration case over roaming revenue spat
summary: Singtel's Thai unit AIS has won an arbitration case against TOT Public Company, dismissing a claim for extra roaming revenue share worth 16.25 billion baht (S$721 million). The decision follows a dispute over a concession agreement from 1990, with AIS ordered to pay 31.07 billion baht to TOT in January. AIS still faces a three-month deadline to file a petition over the arbitration ruling, which may impact Singtel's third-quarter results.

site_title: Civmec Q2 earnings triple, upside from major projects expected
summary: Civmec, a construction and engineering group, reported a significant increase in net earnings for its second quarter, tripling to A$4.26 million (S$3.96 million) from A$1.42 million in the same period last year. The company attributed the growth to reduced administrative costs and finance expenses. Its net profit margin improved to 5% from 1.7% in FY2019. Earnings per share increased to 0.85 Australian cents from 0.25 cents a year ago, driven by the nature of the projects undertaken.

site_title: Envictus to sell loss-making sports nutrition unit to NZ food company
summary: Envictus International Holdings has agreed to sell its loss-making sports nutrition unit, Naturalac Nutrition, to Hansells Masterton of New Zealand for NZ$400,000. The sale comes after Envictus planned to shut down the business, which had a book value of RM6.93 million but was expected to result in a loss of RM2.47 million. The deal will be completed within 30 days, subject to shareholder approval. Envictus will use the net proceeds for working capital purposes, with the company agreeing not to compete in New Zealand and Australia for three years after the sale.

site_title: Britain gives 'green signal' to major rail project HS2
summary: Britain's Prime Minister Boris Johnson has given the green light for the high-speed rail project HS2, connecting London to northern England. The project, initially estimated at £106 billion, will slash journey times and add capacity to Britain's network, aiming to catch up with countries like France and Spain. Johnson vows to restore discipline to the project, which has been behind schedule and over budget, and will be part of a wider transport infrastructure revamp. Physical work has already started, with £7.4 billion spent so far, before splitting into two lines to Manchester and Leeds.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore tourist arrivals may fall 25-30% due to the novel coronavirus outbreak. The Singapore Tourism Board (STB) expects a decline in receipts to be "roughly in line" with the decline in arrivals. Meanwhile, JTC Corporation signed S$500 million worth of agreements at the Singapore Airshow 2020. The IT Show, three other events in Singapore, have been postponed due to the outbreak. The Straits Times Index rebounded 0.4% higher at 3,175.57 after a strong session on Wall St.

images.alt_text: Visitor arrivals to Singapore may fall by 25 to 30 per cent this year due to the novel coronavirus outbreak, after four straight years of growth in arrivals and receipts, said the Singapore Tourism Board (STB) at its annual year-in-review on Tuesday.

site_title: Mastercard wins approval to enter China's US$27t market
summary: Mastercard has received approval to establish a bank card clearing business in China, gaining access to the country's $27 trillion payments market. The joint venture must complete preparation work within a year. China is opening up its financial markets to foreign firms, allowing them to set up fully owned operations in insurance, asset management, and investment banking. This move follows China UnionPay's monopoly being lifted in 2015, allowing foreign providers to obtain licenses by setting up units or acquiring local companies.

site_title: Singapore shares rebound after strong session overnight on Wall St
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 12.42 points or 0.4% higher at 3,175.57 after a strong showing on Wall Street, where main benchmarks hit record highs. Other Asia-Pacific markets, including Australia, China, Hong Kong, Malaysia, South Korea, and Taiwan, also notched gains. Investors took heart from falling new cases of the novel coronavirus outbreak, but caution was expressed about the risk of secondary infections. Trading volume in Singapore was 1.50 billion securities, with most medical plays closing lower except for Clearbridge Health, which rose 3.8%.

site_title: Have no fear, Indonesia's Spider-Man will clean up your trash
summary: Indonesian cafe worker Rudi Hartono used a Spider-Man costume to encourage residents in his coastal community to pick up trash, resulting in an extraordinary public response. Prior to wearing the costume, Hartono struggled to get residents to join him in cleaning up the streets and beaches. The Spider-Man costume drew attention and inspired others to participate, ultimately leading to a successful community clean-up effort.

site_title: SoftBank-backed Brandless shutters less than 2 years after investment
summary: Brandless, a direct-to-consumer personal care and packaged goods company backed by SoftBank's Vision Fund, is shutting down less than two years after receiving a $240 million investment. The company will cut 70 employees and stop taking orders, citing the competitive direct-to-consumer market as unsustainable. SoftBank's failure to deliver on its investment marks an embarrassing setback for the conglomerate, which is struggling with other investments, including WeWork and Uber. The company will fulfill outstanding orders and provide customer service until its website is no longer accessible.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks end 1% higher on battery makers; virus worries persist
summary: South Korean stocks ended 1% higher on Tuesday, driven by gains in battery makers Samsung SDI and LG Chem. The KOSPI index rose 22.05 points, or 1%, to 2,223.12. Despite the rally, concerns about the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak in China persisted.

site_title: Samsung to unveil square-shaped foldable phones to challenge Apple
summary: Samsung is set to unveil square-shaped foldable phones, including the Galaxy Z Flip, which folds like a flip phone and has a lower price point than the Galaxy Fold, a book-like foldable phone. The new handsets aim to revive sales after ceding smartphone market share to Apple. Analysts expect limited mass-market production and sales of around 5 million units this year, with the new handsets driving profits and the Samsung brand. The launch marks the first public debut of Samsung's new mobile chief Roh Tae-moon.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.26% on Tuesday, closing at 27,583.88, following a cautious start to the week amid the coronavirus outbreak in China. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains, while US and European markets were affected by bank and healthcare sector declines. Investors remained cautious despite recent stock rallies, with US-EU trade talks and tariff threats adding to market uncertainty.

site_title: Acromec unit inks pact to build second waste-to-energy plant for industry
summary: Acromec's subsidiary Acropower has signed a six-month memorandum of understanding (MOU) to build a waste-to-energy plant at a wood chip processing farm in Singapore. The plant aims to generate electricity for a landscaping company using wood chips, producing biogas. This project is similar to another ongoing project with poultry farmer Chew's Agriculture. Acromec's shares fell 0.8 Singapore cent after the announcement, with no guarantee on the project's materialization.

site_title: Jardine Cycle & Carriage loses Cycle & Carriage Bintang privatisation bid
summary: Regional automotive dealer Jardine Cycle & Carriage lost its bid to privatize Malaysian arm Cycle & Carriage Bintang (CCB) after a shareholder vote. The plan, valued at RM90.6 million, failed to pass muster as 13.18% of disinterested shareholders voted against it. The resolution required at least half of disinterested shareholders by number and 75% by value to approve, which was not met. As a result, Jardine C&C will not proceed with the privatization bid.

site_title: 2 Yishun industrial properties up for sale via EOI: Edmund Tie
summary: Two industrial properties in Yishun, Singapore, are up for sale via expression of interest (EOI) with indicative prices of S$29 million. The properties, 539 and 543 Yishun Industrial Park A, have a combined site area of 13,326.2 sq m and existing gross floor areas of 14,318.9 sq m. Potential buyers can submit offers for either or both properties, with vacant possession and lease terms ranging from 32 to 34 years. The sites are zoned for "Business 1" use and have a plot ratio of 2.5, making them suitable for companies looking to expand or consolidate operations in the Yishun area.

site_title: WHO says coronavirus emergency 'holds a very grave threat' for world
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has declared China's coronavirus outbreak a "very grave threat for the rest of the world." WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus emphasized the need for sharing virus samples and speeding up research into drugs and vaccines. As of Tuesday, China reported 42,708 confirmed cases, including 1,017 deaths. The WHO is calling for solidarity and equitable sharing of samples and sequences to defeat the outbreak, citing the need for an agreed roadmap for research.

site_title: The continuing impact of the novel coronavirus
summary: The novel coronavirus continues to impact Singapore's economy, with visitor arrivals expected to fall 25-30% this year due to the outbreak. Several Singapore-listed companies have reported disruptions to their China operations, and businesses in the financial district have heightened their monitoring efforts. Ride-hailing and taxi firms have also stepped up precautionary measures. The outbreak has also affected various events, including the IT Show, which has been postponed until further notice. The government is working to mitigate the impact, with some initiatives focused on promoting sustainable aviation and supporting affected businesses.

site_title: China home sales plunged 90 per cent in first week of February
summary: China's home sales plummeted 90% in the first week of February, with new apartment sales dropping 90% and existing home sales plummeting 91% in some cities, amid the coronavirus outbreak. The sector is bracing for a worse impact than the 2003 SARS pandemic, with property developers largely closed for business and restricted from selling apartments. Demand may start picking up in April, but if incomes decline, home-buying plans may be put on hold, challenging developers with poor liquidity.

site_title: S'pore-listed firms warn of supply, shipment delays amid virus outbreak
summary: Singapore-listed companies in China are facing supply and shipment delays due to the ongoing coronavirus outbreak. Valuetronics Holdings and Luzhou Bio-Chem Technology have notified customers of potential delays, citing disruptions to raw materials and factory closures. Both companies are assessing the financial impact of the crisis on their operations. Valuetronics is applying to resume production, but Luzhou Bio-Chem Technology has yet to determine when it can reopen its factories, citing the uncertainty of raw material supply.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rally at open
summary: European stock markets surged at the start of trading on Tuesday, driven by overnight gains on Wall Street and in Asia. London's FTSE 100 rose 1.0% to 7,523.57 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 also increased by 1.1% and 0.7%, respectively. The rally was fueled by gains in mining and healthcare sectors.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher on broad-based gains; NZ up over 1%
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.6% to 7,055.3, driven by broad-based gains, with tech stocks leading the pack. US stocks also closed higher, boosted by tech giants, and their Australian peers followed suit. Despite concerns over the coronavirus, markets globally are tracking higher. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index surged more than 1% higher, driven by financial and utility stocks.

site_title: China home sales plunged 90% in first week of February
summary: China's home sales plummeted 90% in the first week of February, with new apartment sales dropping 90% and existing home sales falling 91% in eight cities. The sector is bracing for a worse impact than the 2003 Sars pandemic, with property developers largely closed for business due to the coronavirus outbreak. Demand may pick up in April, but if incomes decline, home-buying plans may be put on hold, challenging developers with poor liquidity.

site_title: Fu Lu Shou Complex strata offices up for sale with S$1,400 psf guide price
summary: Three strata office units at Fu Lu Shou Complex in Singapore are up for sale with a guide price of S$7.2 million (S$1,400 psf). The 99-year leasehold units, spanning 936-2,174 sq ft, will be sold on a vacant possession basis and are expected to garner interest from end-users and investors seeking long-term operational costs and capital appreciation. The sale price is attractive, considering a similar 1,464 sq ft unit sold at S$1,435 psf in 2019.

site_title: Clamour for masks can't save Asian plastic makers from virus
summary: China's plastics makers face a severe economic impact from the coronavirus, with absent workers and plummeting demand for non-face mask products. Despite a surge in demand for face masks, the production of masks accounts for only 0.1% of polypropylene demand, making it negligible in mitigating the economic impact. Polyester demand, particularly for durable plastics used in automobiles and home appliances, is expected to take the biggest hit, with polypropylene futures falling 9.5% since January.

site_title: Bankers in Asia brace for a virus-related deal drought
summary: Bankers in Asia are bracing for a potential deal drought due to the coronavirus epidemic, with auctions and IPO preparations facing delays or re-assessments. Several asset sales are on hold, and initial public offerings from China are slowing. A Hong Kong-based senior investment banker stated that "nothing is happening" in capital markets or mergers and acquisitions. The delay is expected to impact the region's economy, particularly in China, where GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.
