site_title: Queen Elizabeth's grandson splits from wife
summary: Peter Phillips, the grandson of Queen Elizabeth, has separated from his Canadian wife Autumn after 12 years of marriage. The couple has two children, Savannah, 9, and Isla, 7. Buckingham Palace declined to comment on the private matter. This marks the latest high-profile split involving a member of the British royal family, following Prince Andrew's separation from Sarah, Duchess of York in 1992. The exact reasons for the separation are not specified, but it is reported that Autumn wanted to split up, leaving Peter devastated.

site_title: Singapore commercial properties affected by the novel coronavirus
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article:

The novel coronavirus has affected several commercial properties in Singapore, including office buildings, malls, and retail spaces. As of March 11, over 40 confirmed cases have been linked to a Chinese New Year private dinner function at Safra Jurong. Other affected areas include Marina One, where a Facebook employee tested positive, and Marina Bay Financial Centre, where a DBS employee was confirmed with the virus. The government has raised the risk alert level to Orange and advised people to take precautions to prevent transmission. Cleaning and sanitization efforts are underway at affected properties.

site_title: Fed chief Powell likely to give Congress largely positive economic update
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell is expected to deliver a largely positive economic update to Congress, echoing the central bank's formal report that the current interest rate target range is "appropriate" to keep the expansion on track. Powell will likely reiterate that the US economy is inherently healthy and that rate cuts will only be made in response to global disruptions associated with the coronavirus. Investors will be watching for new details on the Fed's balance sheet and short-term funding markets.

site_title: Equity, debt fundraising on SGX climbs 49% in January
summary: Singapore's securities market turnover rose 27% in January, reaching S$25.6 billion, despite Chinese New Year festivities and regional market closures. Total equity and debt fundraising increased 49% to S$50.4 billion, driven by the listing of debut international sovereign bonds by Laos and the year's first initial public offering by Resources Global Development. Market turnover for exchange-traded funds and structured warrants also surged, with a 73% and 94% increase respectively, driven by institutional investor optimism on emerging Asia's growth prospects.

site_title: HK banks unveil relief measures for mortgage borrowers hit by coronavirus
summary: Hong Kong banks, Bank of China (Hong Kong) and Standard Chartered, have introduced relief measures for mortgage borrowers affected by the coronavirus outbreak, allowing them to pay only interest for up to six months. This move aims to prevent foreclosures and ease pressure on customers in industries severely impacted by the outbreak. The measures come as Hong Kong's economy faces a recession and travel curbs further exacerbate the situation, with the financial secretary warning of a potentially worse impact than the 2003 SARS outbreak.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 8.68 points to 1,551.48, driven by a volume of 2.8 billion lots worth RM2.3 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 462 to 372.

site_title: World Bank chief: some development banks worsening poor country debt burdens
summary: World Bank President David Malpass criticized other development banks for lending too quickly to heavily indebted countries, exacerbating debt burdens. The Asian Development Bank, African Development Bank, and European Bank for Reconstruction and Development were singled out for contributing to debt problems. Malpass stated that these institutions lend too quickly, adding to the debt issues of countries.

site_title: Ancient Jewish dish becomes melting pot of Israeli cuisine
summary: In Israel, a traditional ancient Jewish dish called hamin, also known as cholent, is experiencing a renaissance, with its popularity transcending religious boundaries. Originating from the early oral interpretation of the Torah, hamin is a rich stew cooked for at least 12 hours, typically served on Saturdays. The dish has evolved across Jewish diaspora communities, with variations made in different climates and ingredients. Today, it's enjoyed by people of all backgrounds, including secular and ultra-Orthodox Israelis, who celebrate its nostalgic and cultural significance.

site_title: Daimler slashes its dividend following profit warning
summary: Daimler slashes its dividend to 0.90 euros per share following a profit warning, marking the third profit warning under new CEO Ola Kaellenius. The company's net profit fell to 2.7 billion euros, down from 7.6 billion euros in the previous year, despite record Mercedes car deliveries. Despite this, the brand retained its title as the world's top-selling premium automaker. The dividend cut is a result of restructuring and charges weighing down earnings.

site_title: Recent sell-offs on AEM and UMS an opportunity to buy on the dip: Maybank Kim Eng
summary: Maybank Kim Eng advises clients to buy AEM Holdings and UMS Holdings on the dip amid the novel coronavirus outbreak, citing intact FY2020 earnings for the semiconductor-related companies. AEM earns 90% of its revenue from Intel, with production underway for Intel's 10nm processors. UMS is riding the global semiconductor recovery, with a "buy" recommendation and price targets of S$2.58 for AEM and S$1.13 for UMS.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher on Tuesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Tuesday, rebounding from coronavirus-linked losses at the start of the week. The Hang Seng Index rose 1.0% to 27,514.25, while mainland China's Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains. The rebound comes as traders brush off new US threats to extend the stocks rally, with investors focusing on the ongoing US-EU trade talks.

site_title: JTC signs S$500m in deals at Singapore Airshow 2020
summary: JTC Corporation signed S$500 million in deals with aerospace companies at the Singapore Airshow 2020, including GE Aviation, SIA Engineering Company, and Rolls-Royce, to expand their operations in Singapore over the next five years. The agreements include new facilities and expansions of existing operations, strengthening Singapore's position as a global aerospace hub. The deals are expected to enhance productivity and support the growth of the aerospace ecosystem in the country.

site_title: Taiwan says advises against Hong Kong, Macau travel
summary: Taiwan's government has raised its travel warning for the new coronavirus, advising against non-essential travel to Hong Kong and Macau, and taking precautions for Singapore and Thailand. The move comes as China's death toll from the epidemic surpasses 1,000. The warning is part of a broader effort to mitigate the spread of the virus, with Taiwan seeking to protect its citizens from potential outbreaks.

site_title: Broker's take: OCBC downgrades SIA Engineering to 'sell' as virus weighs on travel demand
summary: OCBC Investment Research has downgraded SIA Engineering Company to "sell" due to the impact of the novel coronavirus on air travel demand, citing a potential 10-15% drop in revenue forecasts for the company's airframe and line maintenance segments. The downgrade comes after the company reported a 63.1% rise in third-quarter net profit, beating forecasts. SIA Engineering shares were trading 0.4% lower at S$2.58, following the downgrade.

site_title: Hong Kong fishing village stays calm, uses sea water to keep virus at bay
summary: Residents in Hong Kong's remote fishing village of Tai O remain calm about the coronavirus outbreak, with many choosing not to wear face masks. Locals, including fisherman Chan Lui Fok, claim that the abundance of seawater provides a sufficient sanitizer, allowing them to go mask-free for now. Despite the outbreak affecting the rest of Hong Kong, Tai O's residents appear to be taking a more relaxed approach to the situation.

site_title: Hong Kong housing block evacuated after double coronavirus find
summary: More than 100 residents of a 35-storey Hong Kong housing block were evacuated after two residents tested positive for the new coronavirus. The evacuation was a precautionary measure after a 62-year-old woman on the third floor was found to have the virus, potentially linked to another man on the same floor through faulty drainage pipes. Four residents have since shown flu-like symptoms and are being taken to a hospital isolation ward. The incident highlights Hong Kong's high alert for "super spreader" events in densely populated areas.

site_title: Trading giants seek oil storage at sea as virus creates glut
summary: Three major oil traders, Vitol SA, Royal Dutch Shell Plc, and Litasco SA, are seeking to store crude on tankers at sea due to a glut in the market caused by the coronavirus outbreak in China. The sharp drop in Chinese demand prompts requests for cargo deferments, leading firms to consider alternative storage options. This move shows the scale of buying weakness in the Asian country, despite the potential higher costs associated with storing barrels at sea.

site_title: Asia: markets rebound after fresh Wall Street records
summary: Asian markets rebounded on Tuesday, driven by fresh Wall Street records, but investors remain cautious about the global economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak in China. Asian bourses bounced back after a nervous start, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index up 1.2%, Shanghai up 0.4%, and Seoul jumped 1.4%. Chinese authorities are expected to make policy interventions to ease the economic hit, boosting market confidence. Investors will also monitor US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's testimony and earnings reports from companies affected by the outbreak.

site_title: China says overall jobs situation stable amid coronavirus outbreak
summary: China's overall long-term jobs situation remains stable despite the coronavirus outbreak, according to an official at the Human Resources and Social Security. The government has taken specific measures to stabilize jobs, particularly supporting small and medium-sized enterprises in employment.

site_title: IT Show, three other events in Singapore postponed amid virus outbreak
summary: Singapore's IT Show, Food & Beverage Fair, BuildTech Asia, and CARGONOW have been postponed until further notice due to the novel coronavirus outbreak. The events, originally scheduled for March, were cancelled after exhibitors and partners expressed concerns over safety and health. The organiser, Sphere Exhibits, cited the growing uncertainty and loss of Chinese exhibitors as factors in the decision. The new event dates have yet to be announced.

site_title: Airbus unveils 'blended wing body' plane design after secret flight tests
summary: Airbus unveiled a 'blended wing body' plane design, which blends the wing and body of an aircraft, aiming to reduce carbon emissions by 20%. The design, called Maveric, has been tested in secret since last year and was revealed at the Singapore Airshow. This concept, first explored in the 1940s, has also influenced the US B-2 bomber and Boeing's X-48 project. Airbus plans to use this design to slash emissions in future aircraft, marking a significant step forward in sustainable aviation.

site_title: More than 3,000 HDB flats launched for sale in Toa Payoh, Sembawang in first BTO exercise for this year
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) has launched 3,095 Build-To-Order (BTO) flats in two projects in Toa Payoh and one in Sembawang, marking the first BTO exercise for 2020. The flats are available for sale with prices starting from S$90,000 for a two-room flexi flat in Toa Payoh and S$89,000 for a two-room flexi flat in Sembawang. Applications for the flats close on Feb 17, with more BTO launches planned for May and August.

site_title: Indonesia Dec retail sales fall 0.5% y-o-y
summary: Indonesia's retail sales contracted 0.5% in December from a year earlier, according to a central bank survey, despite year-end festivities. The estimated annual drop in January sales is 3.1% due to weak sales of clothes, food, and beverages. The decline is attributed to a slowdown in the country's economy, which may persist due to falling sales.

images.alt_text: Retail sales in Indonesia contracted 0.5 per cent in December from a year earlier, despite year-end festivities, according to a central bank survey released on Tuesday.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon up 0.66% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.66% to 3,183.96 points, with 197 gainers outpacing 136 losers, as trading resumed on Tuesday afternoon. Key gainers included Clearbridge Health, Medtecs International, and the trio of banks, with DBS, United Overseas Bank, and OCBC Bank advancing 0.4%, 1.1%, and 1.1% respectively. The gains followed a rebound in the Asia-Pacific region, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index and China's Shanghai Composite also rising.

site_title: Philippines' trade deficit narrows to six-month low in Dec
summary: The Philippines' trade deficit narrowed to its lowest level in six months in December, reaching $2.48 billion, due to a 21.4% surge in exports and a 7.6% decline in imports. This marks a significant improvement from the previous year's $4.2 billion deficit. The data suggests a positive trend in the country's trade balance, indicating a stronger economy.

site_title: Storm Ciara wreaks destruction across Europe
summary: Storm Ciara wreaked destruction across northern Europe, claiming at least six lives and causing widespread disruption. Fierce winds and heavy rains flooded roads, grounded hundreds of flights, and left millions without power. Extensive damage was reported in several countries, including England, France, Germany, and the Netherlands. The storm also forced the cancellation of top-flight football fixtures and disrupted air, rail, and road travel. Despite the destruction, some flights were able to take advantage of tailwinds, including a British Airways flight that set a new sub-sonic flight record.

site_title: China pork prices head toward record high on supply concerns
summary: China's pork prices are nearing a record high due to supply concerns, surging 116% from last year and boosted by African swine fever and transport restrictions. Wholesale prices are just 4% below their record high in November. The coronavirus outbreak has also affected poultry supplies, with road blockades killing chicks and restocking delayed. This could lead to a drop in domestic poultry output, potentially supporting pork prices. Analysts expect pork prices to remain robust in the first half of the year.

images.alt_text: The rapid spread of the coronavirus in China has failed to dampen a scorching pork rally, with prices heading toward a record high on supply concerns in the world's biggest meat consumer.

site_title: ST Engineering secures nacelle maintenance contract from Qantas
summary: ST Engineering's aerospace arm has secured a five-year nacelle maintenance contract from Qantas Airways, starting this year. The company will provide maintenance services for Qantas' Boeing 737-800 and Airbus A330 fleets. This is part of ST Engineering's aerospace sector, which offers comprehensive MRO solutions, including nacelle design and manufacturing. The contract is expected to contribute to the company's growth and value for its customers.

site_title: Coronavirus case confirmed in California, takes US total to 13
summary: A 13th case of coronavirus has been confirmed in the US, bringing the total to 13, in a person under federal quarantine in California after returning from Wuhan, China. The patient, an adult, is being observed and isolated at the University of California San Diego Medical Center. The US has imposed quarantines and travel restrictions with China to slow the spread of the virus, with over 800 US nationals evacuated from Wuhan and flown to military bases for quarantine.

site_title: Singapore tourist arrivals may fall 25-30% due to virus outbreak: STB
summary: Singapore's tourism sector is expected to decline 25-30% in 2020 due to the novel coronavirus outbreak, with visitor arrivals potentially falling by 19%. The decline in receipts is likely to be "roughly in line" with the decline in arrivals. The tourism sector aims for a strong recovery, with a public-private task force to be formed. Locals are urged to support the sector, with Sentosa Development Corporation offering incentives to attract visitors. The decline in business travel and meetings, incentive travel, conventions, and exhibitions (BTMICE) sector is also expected, with receipts down 7% from January to September 2019.

site_title: Collins Aerospace opens Singapore Innovation Hub, inks 12-year agreement with SIA
summary: Collins Aerospace has opened its 10,000 square foot Singapore Innovation Hub, focusing on developing advanced digital and automation technologies for maintenance, repair, and overhaul (MRO) operations. The hub will add 40 new jobs and deliver over 40 proof-of-concepts (POCs) in the next five years. Collins Aerospace has also signed a 12-year agreement with Singapore Airlines (SIA) to support its Boeing B787 aircraft through the Dispatch flight hour programme, providing on-site spares, maintenance services, and technical assistance.

site_title: Hopes crisis nearly over as rains forecast to douse more Australia wildfires
summary: Torrential rain is forecast to douse Australia's remaining bushfires by the end of the week, raising hopes the national crisis is almost over. The country has battled hundreds of blazes since September, fueled by three years of drought attributed to climate change. Heavy rain and storms have swept across New South Wales state, which bore the brunt of the crisis. Authorities believe the rain could extinguish all remaining fires, ending a deadly national crisis that engulfed several states and territories. The prolonged summer wildfire season has had a devastating impact on Australia.

images.alt_text: Torrential rain across Australia's east could extinguish all remaining bushfires in the country's most populous state by the end of the week, authorities said on Tuesday, raising hopes a deadly national crisis is almost over.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.71 points or 0.11% to 1,544.51 on Tuesday, driven by gains. Volume was 53.85 million lots worth RM33.71 million. Gainers outpaced losers 112 to 47.

site_title: Google HR chief stepping aside as worker activism rises
summary: Google confirmed Eileen Naughton, vice-president of people operations, is stepping away from her role amid rising worker activism. During her six-year tenure, Google added over 70,000 employees. Naughton cited a desire to return home to her family in New York. The move comes as Google faces controversies, including employee opposition to contracts with the US military and unionization efforts. The company has faced recent tensions, including the firing of four employees accused of violating data security policies and protesting against the US customs and border patrol agency.

site_title: Singapore condo resale prices edge up in January: SRX
summary: Singapore condo resale prices rose 0.5% in January, up 2.3% year-over-year, according to SRX Property. Sales volume increased 4% to 684 units, with the OCR accounting for half of all resales. The highest transacted price was S$18.2 million for a luxury condo, while median TOX worsened to negative S$2,500 in January, down from December.

site_title: Thailand bars cruise passengers amid coronavirus fears
summary: Thailand has refused permission for passengers from Holland America's cruise ship MS Westerdam to disembark, citing coronavirus fears. The ship, owned by Carnival Corp, had planned to dock in Bangkok on February 13, but Public Health Minister Anutin Charnvirakul issued orders to deny permission. This decision comes amid growing concerns about the spread of the virus, despite the cruise line's assurance that there was no reason to believe anyone on board had the virus.

site_title: Hatten Land swings back into the black in Q2
summary: Hatten Land, a Catalist-listed developer, posted a net profit of RM285,000 (S$95,498) for its Q2 ended Dec 31, reversing a net loss of RM8.3 million in the year-ago period. Revenue fell 6.5% to RM52.2 million. The company's earnings per share rose to 0.02 sen from a loss per share of 0.6 sen last year.

site_title: China says Taiwan drills are meant to hone combat capabilities
summary: China conducted military drills near Taiwan, aiming to improve combat capabilities, after Taiwan's air force scrambled to intercept Chinese jets. The drills follow a pattern of increased tensions since Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen took office in 2016, with China viewing her as a threat to its claim of Taiwan as its territory. China claims Taiwan's formal independence as a red line, while Taiwan asserts its sovereignty. The drills have been denounced by Taiwan as a threat to regional peace, with Tsai calling on China to focus on the COVID-19 outbreak instead.

images.alt_text: A second day of drills by China's military close to Taiwan were aimed at improving combat capabilities, the People's Liberation Army said, after Taiwan's air force scrambled to intercept Chinese jets that briefly crossed the Taiwan Strait's mid-line.

site_title: Tokyo: Markets closed on Tuesday for holiday
summary: Financial markets in Japan are closed on Tuesday for a public holiday. In other markets, stocks in Europe declined due to bank and healthcare sector losses, while US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats. Asia's markets rallied despite Trump's new threats, with Singapore stocks experiencing a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Singapore O&G and Katrina Group warn of FY19 losses
summary: Two Catalist-listed firms, Singapore O&G and Katrina Group, have warned of losses for the fiscal year ended Dec 31, 2019. Singapore O&G expects a net loss due to significant impairment of goodwill, while Katrina Group expects a loss mainly due to startup costs and gestation period of new outlets. Both companies will release their FY2019 financial results on or before Feb 29. The companies advised shareholders to exercise caution when dealing in their shares.

site_title: World emissions kept in check as rich nations kick coal habit
summary: Global energy-related carbon dioxide emissions remained steady at 33.3 billion tons in 2019, the first time in three years, as developed nations shifted away from coal power. The US, EU, and Japan led declines, with Germany reducing emissions to levels not seen since the 1950s. Asia, however, saw a rise in emissions due to robust coal demand. Despite stagnation, the halt in emissions growth is seen as grounds for optimism, with the International Energy Agency calling for continued efforts to make 2019 a definitive peak in global emissions.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Mortgage Master wants to help you pick the best mortgage loan
summary: Mortgage Master, a mortgage brokering platform, aims to help individuals pick the best mortgage loan tailored to their needs. David Baey, co-founder and CEO, shares his expertise on selecting mortgage loans without regret. This is particularly important for those making a significant financial decision like buying a home. Baey's guidance can help individuals navigate the complex process of choosing a mortgage loan and avoid potential pitfalls.

site_title: China reports 108 new coronavirus deaths on Feb 10, total at 1,016
summary: China reported 108 new coronavirus deaths on February 10, bringing the total to 1,016, according to the National Health Commission. The total number of mainland cases increased to 42,638, with 2,478 new confirmed cases. The country's COVID-19 situation remains a concern.

images.alt_text: China reported 108 new coronavirus deaths on the mainland on Feb 10, up from 97 on the previous day, the country's health authority said on Tuesday.

site_title: UK shoppers still wary about spending in January: BRC
summary: UK shoppers maintained cautious spending habits in January, with total retail sales edging up 0.4% annually, the lowest increase since 1995. Like-for-like sales remained flat, with consumer confidence slowly returning post-general election. A separate survey by Barclaycard showed a 3.9% annual increase in spending, boosted by fuel and supermarket purchases, and consumer confidence in the British economy reached its highest level since September 2016 at 42%.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise led by IT, financials; New Zealand up nearly 1%
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% to 7,049.5, driven by gains in technology and financial sectors, following a similar rally on Wall Street. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq closed at record highs, boosted by Amazon, Microsoft, and Alphabet.

images.alt_text: Australian shares rose up to half a percent on Tuesday as technology stocks took a cue from their Wall Street peers amid worries about the growth impact from the coronavirus outbreak on China.

site_title: UK warns of post-Brexit controls on EU trade
summary: The UK government has warned businesses to prepare for stricter controls on goods coming from the European Union after the post-Brexit transition period ends in December. EU imports will face the same checks as those from the rest of the world, with traders required to submit customs declarations and accept checks on their goods. The UK aims to negotiate new trade deals with the US, Japan, and other nations alongside an agreement with the EU, but is expected to leave the EU's single market and customs union.

site_title: Singapore shares recover following Wall Street rally; STI up 0.31%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) gained 0.31% to 3,173.07 points on Tuesday, recovering from previous day's losses. The gains were driven by overnight record highs on Wall Street. The index saw 82 gainers and 42 losers, with S$51.9 million worth of securities changing hands. The rally follows a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: US opens coronavirus push with aid to Laos
summary: The US has begun its global coronavirus aid effort, starting with a delivery of health supplies to Laos, bordering China. The US Agency for International Development handed over 1,500 surgical gowns and 440 protective goggles. This is part of a pledged $100 million in assistance to combat the virus, which has killed over 900 people.

site_title: US district judge expected to rule in favour of Sprint-T-Mobile merger: WSJ
summary: A US district judge is expected to rule in favor of the Sprint-T-Mobile merger, worth $26.5 billion, after multiple states sued to block the deal citing anticompetitive concerns. The decision is expected to be made public on Tuesday. Shares of both companies rose after the news, with Sprint's shares increasing 50% and T-Mobile's rising 6.5%. The merger would make Sprint the third-largest US wireless carrier by subscribers.

site_title: US adds hacktivists, social media manipulators to top intel threats
summary: The US has added hacktivists, social media manipulators, and anti-secrecy organizations to its top intel threats, alongside Russia and other countries. The National Counterintelligence Strategy report notes that advances in cyber and surveillance technology have multiplied the intelligence threat, making it possible for anyone to pose a threat. The report highlights the risks of online manipulation, malicious influence campaigns, and the theft of sensitive data, with WikiLeaks cited as a contributing factor to the shift in threat perception.

site_title: Digital telco startup Circles.Life bags funding from Warburg Pincus
summary: Circles.Life, a Singapore-based digital telco startup, has secured funding from global private equity firm Warburg Pincus to further fund growth and expansion in new markets. The exact investment amount was not disclosed, but Warburg Pincus typically invests a few hundred million US dollars in startups. Circles.Life plans to use the funds to enter two new markets by the end of 2020 and strengthen its position in existing markets Singapore, Taiwan, and Australia. The company aims to launch non-telco related digital services, such as personalized content discovery and financial services.

site_title: APTT eyes 5G tie-up with Taiwan firm after proposed 65% stake sale
summary: Asian Pay Television Trust (APTT) is considering a 65% stake sale to Da Da Digital Convergence Co, a Taiwan-listed firm, in a deal worth an undisclosed sum. The buyer is controlled by Dafeng TV's founder Dai Yung Huei, which operates cable television systems and broadband services in Taiwan. The proposed deal will see Da Da Digital acquire a majority stake in Dynami Vision, APTT's trustee-manager.

site_title: Harker says Federal Reserve may need to act if coronavirus takes toll on US economy, but not yet
summary: US Federal Reserve Bank President Patrick Harker stated the central bank is monitoring the coronavirus' impact on the US economy but doesn't think immediate action is necessary. He noted that the Fed's interest rate reduction tool won't provide significant relief for companies affected by supply chain shutdowns. Harker warned that if the situation worsens and significantly impacts the economy, the Fed will consider accommodating. However, he doesn't believe the US economy is at that point yet.

site_title: US indicts four Chinese military 'hackers' for Equifax breach
summary: The US Justice Department has indicted four Chinese military hackers for their alleged involvement in the 2017 Equifax data breach, which exposed sensitive information of 145 million Americans. The hackers, from China's People's Liberation Army, are accused of stealing personal data, including social security numbers and addresses, and are charged with multiple counts of hacking, computer fraud, and wire fraud. The indictment comes amid concerns that China's military and security service are collecting personal data on Americans for intelligence purposes, and US officials warn that the data could be used for malicious activities.

site_title: Pele depressed, reclusive because of poor health: son
summary: Brazilian football legend Pele, 79, is experiencing depression and reclusiveness due to poor health, according to his son Edinho. Pele, a three-time World Cup winner, has struggled with mobility issues since a hip operation left him dependent on a walker. He has been hospitalized several times for various health problems, including kidney issues and a severe urinary infection. Despite physical improvements, Pele rarely leaves home, feeling "shy and embarrassed" about his mobility. His health issues have taken a toll on his mental well-being, leading to a "kind of depression."

site_title: Europe: Shares end flat, Irish stocks battered after election
summary: European shares ended flat on Monday, with the pan-European Stoxx 600 index rising 0.07% after a rebound from earlier virus-driven sell-offs. Irish stocks fell 1.2% as investors feared negative impacts from left-wing Sinn Fein's policies, including an end to tax breaks for banks. Oil stocks and commodity-linked stocks were the worst performers, while defensive sectors like healthcare and real estate rose. The virus has raised concerns over weaker Chinese demand, but some analysts believe Germany's economy could benefit from China's stimulus efforts.

site_title: Trump announces visit to India February 24-25
summary: US President Donald Trump will visit India from February 24-25, with stops in New Delhi and Gujarat, to strengthen the US-India strategic partnership. Trump and Prime Minister Narendra Modi had a phone call over the weekend, following Modi's visit to the US in September and a rally in Houston, Texas. The visit aims to further their close relationship, with Gujarat being Modi's home state and the birthplace of Mahatma Gandhi.

site_title: Ghosn demands Nissan-Mitsubishi documents: lawyers
summary: Former Nissan chief Carlos Ghosn is seeking 15 million euros in compensation from Nissan-Mitsubishi, which he claims was an illegal dismissal under Dutch labour laws. Ghosn's lawyers want access to internal documents to determine how and why he was fired before his arrest for financial misconduct. The Dutch court will hear arguments on March 26, with Nissan accusing Ghosn's team of "going fishing" without knowing what documents they are looking for. Ghosn fled Japan after being jailed and placed under house arrest, and is currently in Lebanon.

site_title: Coronavirus could trim 1 percentage point from China GDP growth: government researcher
summary: A Chinese government researcher, Zeng Gang, predicts the coronavirus outbreak could trim China's full-year economic growth rate by 1 percentage point in 2020. This estimate compares to the 2 percentage point decline in China's growth rate in 2003 during the Sars epidemic. The impact is expected to be comparable in the first quarter, putting pressure on policymakers to address the economic slowdown.

site_title: From Singapore to UK via the Alps: how one man spread coronavirus
summary: A British man, who contracted the coronavirus while attending a conference in Singapore, spread the virus to at least 11 others in three countries, including France, the UK, and Spain, without ever setting foot in China. The man attended a conference in Singapore, then traveled to the French Alps, where he infected several British citizens, before being diagnosed in the UK. The rapid spread of the virus highlights the potential for a global pandemic, with experts warning that transmission is no longer restricted to China.

site_title: Data centres are niche no longer
summary: More than $100 billion has flowed into the data centre ecosystem in the past decade, driven by capital from various organisations. This influx has enabled the industry to expand at a lower cost, with funds taking ownership positions in new companies rather than acquiring data centres asset by asset. As a result, the industry is no longer niche, and funds are looking to deploy similar amounts of capital in attractive opportunities.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq end at records as rally resumes
summary: US stocks closed at records on Monday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index rising 0.7% and 1.1% respectively. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.6% to 29,276.82. Investors largely shrugged off concerns about the coronavirus, citing government efforts to contain it. Data releases on retail sales and consumer pricing, as well as Federal Reserve testimony, will be closely watched.

site_title: Digital banks unlikely to replace existing bank accounts: study
summary: A study by PwC found that digital banks in Singapore are unlikely to replace existing primary banking relationships, with 99% of customers planning to keep their existing account. Only 40% of respondents would consider opening a digital bank account if it's "popular and successful". Younger, affluent customers are more likely to be interested in digital banking, but trust and human interaction remain concerns. Digital banks should focus on displacing secondary accounts and offering attractive rates, promotions, and personalized services to attract and retain customers.

site_title: Trump to take an India pre-election 'victory lap'
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to embark on a two-day trip to India, aiming to finalize a trade agreement and strengthen bilateral ties. The trip, scheduled for later this month, will also allow Trump to showcase his revamped Indo-Pacific strategy in the face of China's growing strength. The proposed trade deal would see India cut duties on over 40 US exports in exchange for Washington allowing Indian manufacturers duty-free trade facilities. The agreement would build on progress made on the security front, with the two countries having signed several defense cooperation agreements in recent years.

site_title: Oil drops to 13-month low on weak Chinese demand, traders eye Opec+ cuts
summary: Oil prices dropped to a 13-month low due to weaker Chinese demand amid the coronavirus outbreak, with Brent futures falling 2.2% to $53.27 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude falling 1.5% to $49.57 a barrel. The decline follows a 25% drop from its peak in January, as traders wait for Opec+ to decide on further production cuts, which Russia has delayed. Analysts say the crisis has brought China's transport and manufacturing sectors to a standstill, leading to a significant decrease in crude oil and natural gas imports.

site_title: Coronavirus forces cancellation, delay of trade shows, conferences
summary: Multiple trade shows and conferences worldwide have been postponed or cancelled due to the coronavirus outbreak, potentially disrupting billions of dollars worth of deals. Events affected include the Taipei International Book Exhibition, League of Legends Pro League, Singapore Airshow, and major industry conferences in China, such as the China Commodity Markets Insight Forum and SEMICON/FPD China. The cancellations and postponements are a result of travel restrictions and concerns about the spread of the virus.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: ST Engineering secured two new orders for A321 aircraft conversion and a deal with Wilhelmsen Ships Service for unmanned aircraft system operations. Sembcorp Industries won a 25-year floating solar farm deal on Tengeh Reservoir, while RE&S Holdings reported a second-quarter net loss. Oil prices rose over 2% due to market uncertainty, while US stocks edged down amid tariff threats. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed, and Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case.

site_title: US dollar strengthens as traders see resilient economy
summary: The US dollar strengthened against the euro, reaching its lowest level in months, as investors remained optimistic about the US economy's resilience to the coronavirus pandemic. The euro's decline was attributed to market participants' positive outlook on riskier currencies, with hints that the virus's spread might be slowing down. The US payroll data from last week reinforced traders' expectations of a resilient US economy, contributing to the dollar's growth.

site_title: From foreign talent to Singapore talent
summary: Singapore's Budget 2020 aims to support businesses in raising productivity by retraining existing employees in essential future technological skills, amid Industry 4.0 and global trade tensions. The government will continue to focus on supporting businesses in attracting and retaining local talent, including the "Tech@SG" initiative, and address social barriers that prevent Singaporeans from relocating overseas for work. The budget will also focus on improving productivity through education and training of employees, with a emphasis on coding, data analytics, and robotics.

images.alt_text: Singapore has started to shift its focus from attracting foreign talent to grooming local talent. As a result, many tax breaks previously available to foreigners to attract them to relocate and be based in Singapore are being removed or phased out.

site_title: Ride-hailing and taxi firms step up measures to guard against coronavirus
summary: Ride-hailing and taxi companies in Singapore have increased precautions to combat the coronavirus, including temperature checks, service suspensions, and quarantined driver support. Grab suspended its carpooling service and advised against picking up multiple riders per trip. Other measures include limiting contact between individuals and providing support for quarantined drivers. These precautions come as the novel coronavirus continues to spread globally.

site_title: Amazon wants Trump testimony about huge Pentagon contract
summary: Amazon is seeking testimony from US President Donald Trump and other top officials about the US$10 billion military cloud computing contract. The tech giant is appealing the awarding of the "JEDI" contract to upgrade the US military's computing networks. Amazon's filing states that Trump has unique knowledge about his involvement in the bid process, including private conversations with others about the award. The company is seeking depositions of Trump, Defence Secretary Mark Esper, and his predecessor, James Mattis, as part of an evidence gathering phase for the appeal.

images.alt_text: Amazon is seeking testimony from US President Donald Trump and other top officials about how the tech giant was shut out of a US$10 billion US military cloud computing contract, according to court documents made public on Monday.

site_title: NetLink posts 9.6% rise in Q3 net profit to S$21.5m
summary: NetLink NBN Trust reported a 9.6% year-over-year increase in Q3 net profit to S$21.5 million, driven by rising home broadband connections. The company saw 1.42 million residential connections as of Dec 31, up from 1.28 million in 2018. Revenue grew 2.9% to S$91.6 million, with higher residential revenue offset by lower contributions from non-residential connections. For the nine months, net profit rose 14.5% to S$65.6 million, with the company expecting higher revenues from key connection services in FY2020.

site_title: California homebuilders rush to avoid solar mandate
summary: California homebuilders issued 5,526 permits for new single-family homes in December 2019, a 56% increase from the previous year, ahead of a state mandate requiring solar power in all new homes starting this year. The surge is likely due to homebuilders submitting permits before the deadline to avoid upfront costs. The solar mandate aims to increase California's electricity from carbon-free resources by 2045, but critics argue it adds a significant expense for homebuyers, estimated at $9,500 on average.

site_title: Virus spread continues to weigh on sentiment
summary: Asian markets slid to start the week, with Singapore's Straits Times Index closing at 3,163.15, down 18.33 points or 0.6%. However, China's Shanghai Composite Index bucked the trend, rising 14.52 points or 0.5% to 2,890.49, following Chinese authorities lifting some work and travel restrictions. Investors remain cautious about the novel coronavirus, with analysts predicting further economic damage.

site_title: Will Trump be the master survivor on the back of a buoyant economy?
summary: US President Donald Trump's re-election prospects are uncertain, despite a strong economy and high approval rating. After impeachment, Trump's approval rating rose to 49%, and the economy showed historic lows in unemployment and inflation rates. The Democrats' presidential contest is in disarray, with a potentially long and bitter battle between centrist and left-leaning candidates. The outcome of the election will be determined by a few thousand voters in key electoral states, and Trump's ability to maintain his electoral base will be crucial in securing a second term.

site_title: Two new cases in Singapore; one is a Cisco officer involved in quarantine orders
summary: Singapore reports two new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total to 45, with 7 in critical condition and 7 discharged. A 37-year-old Cisco officer and a 2-year-old girl are the new cases, with the officer having served quarantine orders on Wuhan individuals before developing symptoms. The Ministry of Health has identified 1,026 close contacts, with 896 quarantined or isolated. The disease outbreak response system has been raised to orange, with extra measures in place to reduce public health impact.

site_title: China president in rare visit to virus patients, medics
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping made a rare public appearance to visit medical workers and patients affected by the deadly coronavirus, donning a face mask and having his temperature checked. Xi called the situation "still very grave" and urged "more decisive measures" to contain the spread of the epidemic. The visit came amid the outbreak, which has killed over 900 people.

images.alt_text: Chinese President Xi Jinping donned a face mask and had his temperature checked on Monday while visiting medical workers and patients affected by the deadly coronavirus that has killed more than 900 people.

site_title: Stocks to watch: HPHT, Oxley, OUE, NetLink, Sembcorp, RE&S, Soilbuild Construction
summary:
Several Singapore companies released their financial results, with notable developments including:

- Hutchison Port Holdings Trust trimming its fourth-quarter distribution by 41% due to a drop in underlying earnings.
- Oxley Holdings seeing its second-quarter earnings plummet 89.9% due to a revaluation of an investment property.
- OUE Limited acquiring a majority stake in Indonesian coffee company Maxx Coffee Prima.
- NetLink NBN Trust's third-quarter earnings lifted by rising home broadband connections.
- Sembcorp Industries' wholly-owned subsidiary winning a bid for a national water agency's planned floating solar farm.
- RE&S Holdings sinking into the red in its second quarter due to temporary store closures.
- Soilbuild Construction Group winning a S$48.3 million contract to build an apartment block.
- Asian Pay Television Trust proposing to sell a 65% stake to a Taiwanese firm.
- Hatten Land reversing its second-quarter net loss, while Singapore O&G and Katrina Group warned of losses in FY2019.

site_title: Olam to post one-time Q4 net gain of S$72m from restructuring initiatives
summary: Olam International, a Singapore-based agri-food giant, expects to record a net one-time post-tax gain of about S$72 million for its fourth quarter ended Dec 31, driven by restructuring initiatives. The company sold various assets, generating a one-time post-tax capital gain of around S$372 million, while also recognizing S$300 million in one-off exits costs. Olam will release its Q4 results on Feb 28, as part of its 2019-2024 strategic plan, which includes reorganizing businesses into two operating groups.

site_title: Singapore's aerospace sector set to fly higher despite setback
summary: Singapore's aerospace sector is expected to continue growing despite a setback from the Singapore Airshow 2020, where over 70 firms pulled out due to the novel coronavirus. The industry is poised to capitalize on increasing demand for air travel and aircraft in the region. The Singapore Economic Development Board expects the sector to experience an impact on air travel, business, and consumer confidence, but overall prospects remain bright. The sector is expected to benefit from growing air travel demand and the increasing presence of companies like Tesla and FedEx in the region.

site_title: Samsung unveils more compact foldable phone
summary: Samsung unveiled its compact foldable phone, the Galaxy Z Flip, during the Academy Awards ceremony. The device features a square folded shape, a tiny notification panel, and a large widescreen display. Scheduled for a launch event on February 11, the phone is expected to be available in black and purple colors. This new device is smaller and more compact than Samsung's original foldable phone, the Galaxy Fold, and is part of the company's effort to "define a new era" in the mobile industry.

site_title: Humility, managing skills key to his role, says Mothercare's Pang Fu Wei
summary: Pang Fu Wei, 31, managing director of Mothercare Singapore, attributes his success to humility and effective people management. As the chairman's son, he overcame the challenge by working in various departments, including accounts and warehousing, and putting in extra effort to prove he was capable of handling any task. He credits his approach for his current role, which he took without shortcuts.

site_title: Numerous Singapore listcos report disrupted operations in China
summary: Several Singapore-listed companies have reported disruptions to their China operations due to the ongoing coronavirus epidemic. Powermatic and Luxking Group Holdings have closed or curtailed their factories, while BHG Retail Real Estate Investment Trust has temporarily closed its stores. Aoxin Q & M Dental Group has also suspended dental treatments in the province of Liaoning. The companies cited global travel curbs and local authorities' requests to close facilities as reasons for the disruptions, which may impact their performance for the year 2020.

site_title: Seeing around the corner
summary: The Future Economy Council's modern services subcommittee explores technology's role in sectors that rely on human expertise. Technology can reduce tedious work, such as auditing and contract review, and enable high-value-added services. Law firms like Rajah & Tann are adopting subscription-based models and partnering with tech firms to provide tools and solutions to clients. The industry is shifting towards a more client-centric approach, with firms focusing on anticipating future problems and providing proactive services. Successful firms will "see round the corner" and adapt to changing market expectations. The government is also supporting the development of ecosystems and collaboration among firms to help small and medium enterprises tap opportunities.

site_title: China gradually getting back to work after outbreak measures eased
summary: China began gradually returning to work after easing outbreak measures, with workers trickling back to offices and factories on Monday. The country has borne the brunt of the novel coronavirus epidemic, with the vast majority of confirmed cases and all but two deaths linked to the outbreak. The World Health Organization has sent experts to assess the situation, and the virus has spread to at least 27 countries, infecting over 330 people. The government has taken steps to support the economy, including providing special funds for banks to re-lend to businesses, and some industries, such as manufacturing and automotive, have resumed production.

site_title: Oxley's Q2 earnings dive 90%
summary: Oxley Holdings' Q2 earnings plummeted 90% to S$3.56m, despite a 12.5% decline in turnover to S$311.2m. Other gains decreased 59.8% to S$20.7m, and administrative expenses tripled to S$22.6m. The group's net asset value remains at 34.05 cents per share. Oxley expects real estate sales to be impacted by supply and unsold inventory, and the novel coronavirus outbreak's effects on the market are uncertain.

site_title: Chinese military aircraft cross into Taiwan airspace: Taipei
summary: Taiwan's defense ministry reported that Chinese H-6 bombers and accompanying aircraft briefly crossed into Taiwanese airspace, marking the first major incursion since President Tsai Ing-wen's re-election in January. The incursion occurred as China grapples with a deadly coronavirus outbreak, with Tsai criticizing Beijing for taking "meaningless and unnecessary" military moves. Taiwanese fighter jets intercepted the aircraft, and they returned to Chinese airspace after warnings were broadcast. This is the second time Chinese aircraft have crossed the median line dividing the two sides in the Taiwan Strait since March last year.

site_title: WongP's Simon Tay quits Hyflux board as independent director
summary: Singapore-based water treatment firm Hyflux announced the resignation of non-executive independent director Simon Tay, effective last Friday, due to "unresolved differences in opinion" with his law firm WongPartnership over Hyflux's decision to discharge itself. Tay had previously recused himself from discussions about WongP but was criticized by lawyers Clifford Chance and Cavenagh Law for discussing the matter publicly. Tay had hoped to continue serving on Hyflux's board to assist with the company's restructuring, but he cited a breakdown in the working relationship between the board and him as the reason for his resignation.

site_title: HPHT slashes Q4 DPU by 41% to 5 HK cents on underlying profit drop
summary: Hutchison Port Holdings Trust (HPHT) slashed its Q4 distribution per unit (DPU) by 41% to 5 HK cents due to a drop in underlying earnings, primarily caused by a decline in transshipment cargo and higher operating expenses. The trust reported a net profit of HK$528.2 million, down 28.4% year-over-year, and attributed the decline to a trade war between the US and China, as well as the impact of the novel coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Singapore's financial district on high alert as infections surface there
summary: Singapore's financial district is on high alert as cases of the novel coronavirus surface, prompting companies to step up temperature screening and sanitization efforts. Two confirmed cases have been reported, one at Marina Bay Financial Centre and another at Clifford Centre. Companies such as Standard Chartered, DBS, and UOB have activated their business continuity plans, restricting large-scale meetings and public gatherings, and restricting overseas travel. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has advised financial institutions to prepare for increased demand and remain vigilant on cyber security.

images.alt_text: Businesses clustered in Singapore's financial district have heightened their monitoring efforts amid the novel coronavirus outbreak, reflecting the realities of Singapore being a large financial centre where banks and other large corporations dot Shenton Way and the Marina Bay.

site_title: Lendlease Global Reit posts DPU of 1.29 S cents, 3.1% above IPO forecast
summary: Lendlease Global Reit reported a distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.29 Singapore cents for its second quarter, exceeding its initial public offering (IPO) forecast of 1.25 cents by 3.1%. The DPU will be paid on March 16. This positive result suggests the company's performance is exceeding expectations, indicating a strong start to its operations.

site_title: Frasers Property unit buys AsiaMalls Management
summary: Frasers Property unit Frasers Property Retail has agreed to acquire AsiaMalls Management for an undisclosed sum. AsiaMalls manages five malls in Singapore, and the acquisition will make it a subsidiary of Frasers Property Retail Management. The move aims to unlock operational synergies and compete more effectively in the retail landscape. This is part of Frasers Property Retail's expansion efforts, which include suburban retail malls and asset management.

site_title: Google drops plan to buy into largest African wind farm
summary: Google has cancelled plans to buy a 12.5% stake in Africa's largest wind farm, the 310 megawatt Lake Turkana wind farm in Kenya, due to delays in the project. The project was initially set for completion in 2017, but the delay led to Google cancelling its agreement with Danish wind turbine maker Vestas in 2019. Vestas is now in talks with other potential buyers of the stake.

site_title: Why adopting circular economy practices can lead to growth
summary: Climate change poses significant risks to the economy, with the World Health Organization predicting 250,000 additional deaths annually by 2030-2050. The Association of South East Asian Nations (Asean) is prioritizing sustainability efforts, with some cities like Jakarta and Manila facing extreme financial risk due to climate change. Adopting circular economy practices can lead to growth, reducing waste and pollution. The circular economy model can save 80-99% of materials and reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and its adoption could result in $324 billion in economic growth and 1.5 million jobs across Asia over the next two decades.

site_title: 'Should we leave?' Life in China under the coronavirus lockdown
summary: A couple in Shanghai, over 800 km from Wuhan, China, where a coronavirus lockdown has been in place for two weeks, are weighing their decision on whether to leave. Despite having access to food and medical supplies, they are hesitant to travel due to concerns about the virus and the risks of getting packed together with strangers on flights. They consider themselves young and healthy, but also acknowledge the risks and the fact that the Chinese government's measures may not be entirely transparent. The couple struggles with their own fears and doubts, questioning whether they are entitled to flee while others in Hubei province are dealing with the crisis.

site_title: Airbnb freezes Beijing check-ins until March to curb spread of virus
summary: Airbnb has suspended all check-ins at its Beijing listings until March to comply with local regulations aimed at curbing the spread of the novel coronavirus. The company will offer refunds to affected guests and hosts. Local rival Xiaozhu has also shut down rentals in Beijing for February and issued full refunds, while waiving landlord commission fees. The move follows guidance from local authorities for the short-term rental industry during the public health emergency.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Oil prices surged over 2% as investors weighed market outlook and global trade tensions. US stocks edged down from record highs amid tariff threats, while Europe's stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector concerns. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss. Meanwhile, Heathrow Airport is considering higher fees for its £10 billion upgrade and Indonesia detained an employee in a graft case involving Trafigura.

site_title: Sembcorp unit clinches Tengeh Reservoir solar farm project
summary: Sembcorp Industries has won the project to build a 60 megawatt-peak floating solar farm on Tengeh Reservoir by 2021. The 25-year award will increase Sembcorp's solar capacity in Singapore to 240MWp, powering 7% of the Republic's energy needs. Sembcorp Solar beat out three other bidders, including Sunseap and Terrenus Energy, and will operate the system under a "design, build, own and operate" contract.

site_title: Virus outbreak seen hitting Asian semicon recovery
summary: A virus outbreak in China is expected to disrupt the Asian semiconductor industry's recovery, citing lockdowns and restricted labor movements. Citi Research forecasts a delay in China's semiconductor import demand to Q2, which could impact South Korea and Taiwan's Q1 sales. The outbreak may also lead to a shortage of intermediate goods, such as batteries and LCD screens, and delay inventory restocking of electronics goods. This could result in a fall in demand for components, weakening consumer disposable income and impacting the overall electronics market.

site_title: Virus outbreak to take centre stage at local banks' FY19 results briefings
summary: Singapore banks' FY19 results will focus on the impact of the novel coronavirus outbreak, with global growth expected to slow due to China's economic downturn. The banks' loan exposure to Greater China has grown, with DBS having the largest exposure at 30%. Analysts expect weaker loan growth and more volatile earnings, with a possible downward revision to Singapore's GDP. The banks are likely to increase dividends due to high capital ratios, and analysts will closely watch for additional cautionary provisioning. DBS will release its Q4 and full-year 2019 results on Feb 13, while OCBC and UOB will report on Feb 21.

site_title: Oscars 2020 winners
summary: The 92nd Academy Awards, also known as the Oscars 2020, took place on February 9, 2020. "Parasite" made history by becoming the first non-English language film to win Best Picture, marking a significant milestone for international cinema. The South Korean film also took home awards for Best Director and Best Original Screenplay. "Parasite" director Bong Joon-ho became the first person of Korean descent to win Best Director. The ceremony also honored other notable winners, including Joaquin Phoenix for Best Actor and Renée Zellweger for Best Actress.

site_title: Chinese New Year, coronavirus push up China's consumer prices in January
summary: China's consumer prices rose 5.4% in January, the fastest monthly gain in over eight years, driven by the Chinese New Year holiday and supply chain disruptions from the coronavirus outbreak. Food prices, particularly pork, surged due to supply disruptions and African swine flu. Analysts expect inflationary pressures to continue into the first half of 2020, with the coronavirus impacting the economy. The central bank has announced measures to support demand and small enterprises, but may loosen monetary policy further to address economic headwinds.

site_title: Virus outbreak to take centre stage at local banks' FY19 results briefings Continued from Page 1
summary: Singapore banks are expected to face challenges in FY19 results briefings due to a worse-than-expected virus outbreak affecting tourism and retail businesses. This may lead to risks in credit cost and non-performing loan (NPL) declines, posing a threat to bank earnings. Ongoing trends, including margin compression and flattish loan growth, are likely to continue, impacting Q4 earnings.

site_title: Telcos offer defensive buys when market is down
summary: Telcos offer a defensive investment strategy when the market is down, particularly in a digital age where more Singaporeans are staying home due to the novel coronavirus. DBS analysts recommend investing in defensive counters such as fibre broadband provider Netlink NBN Trust and mainboard-listed telco Singtel, which are expected to recover once the virus is brought under control.

site_title: IMF warns of coronavirus hit to Japan's economy via tourism, trade
summary: A senior IMF official warned that a prolonged coronavirus outbreak could negatively impact Japan's economy, affecting tourism, retail, and exports. The spread of the disease poses an emerging downside risk, with potential effects on tourist arrivals and spending from China, as well as trade and investment. Japanese companies rely heavily on China for parts and exports, and the outbreak could disrupt supply chains. The IMF did not provide an estimate of the impact on Japan's growth, but it will be taken into account when updating global forecasts in April.

site_title: Parasite makes Oscar history
summary: Parasite, a South Korean thriller, made Oscar history by winning Best Picture, the first non-English language film to do so, and collecting three other trophies, including Best Director for Bong Joon Ho. The win marked a historic moment for diversity in the Academy, following years of outcry over the #OscarsSoWhite protests. The film's victory highlighted the importance of inclusion and paved the way for a more diverse Hollywood. Netflix, which had entered the ceremony with a field-leading 24 nominations, won only two prizes, including Best Documentary for American Factory.

site_title: Oxley Holdings posts 90% slide in Q2 net profit of S$3.56m
summary: Oxley Holdings, a mainboard-listed developer, reported a 90% slide in its Q2 net profit to S$3.56 million, down from S$34.2 million in the same period last year. The decline was attributed to a sharp decrease in other gains and administrative expenses. Despite a 13% rise in revenue to S$594 million, the company's earnings per share fell to 0.09 Singapore cent. The group expects real estate sales in 2020 to be impacted by supply and unsold inventory, with the novel coronavirus outbreak also affecting market conditions.

site_title: Kick off the decade with a cybersecurity upgrade
summary: Cybersecurity threats are increasing, with 11 vulnerabilities publicly reported in January alone. Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are particularly vulnerable, with 66% reporting a cyberattack in 2019, resulting in an average loss of $1.2 million in damages and $1.9 million in disruption costs. The most common attack method is phishing emails, often using simple tactics like "Nigerian Prince" scams. SMEs can improve their defenses by focusing on employee training and education, introducing multi-factor authentication, and implementing robust security measures to protect against targeted attacks.

site_title: Sponsors' conflicts symptomatic of a bigger issue
summary: A Singapore Exchange (SGX) Notice of Compliance (NOC) was issued to RHT Capital (RHTC), a full sponsor on the Catalist board, due to possible conflicts of interest related to share registrar and investor relations services provided by RHT Corporate Advisory Pte Ltd (RCA) and RHT Communications and Investor Relations Pte Ltd (RCIR) at four Catalist companies. The NOC noted that RHT Group shares common directors and/or shareholders with RHTLaw Taylor Wessing LLP, which provides certain legal and other services to certain sponsored issuers. This is the first NOC to be issued to a sponsor.

site_title: China's Xi promises to prevent major layoffs amid coronavirus outbreak
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping has pledged to prevent major layoffs amid the coronavirus outbreak, stating the government will take decisive measures to curb the virus' spread. Xi inspected efforts to contain the virus in Beijing and visited a local hospital, wearing a surgical mask. He emphasized China's determination to meet its economic and social targets for the year, despite the outbreak's impact on the world's second-largest economy. China aims to mitigate the virus' effects through economic adjustments and is confident it will win the battle against the outbreak.

site_title: India readying US$2.6b US naval helicopter deal ahead of Trump trip
summary: India is set to approve a $2.6 billion deal for US naval helicopters from Lockheed Martin ahead of US President Donald Trump's visit in February, as part of efforts to strengthen strategic ties with the US. The 24 MH-60R Seahawk helicopters will be used by the Indian navy to track submarines in the Indian Ocean. The deal is part of India's efforts to modernize its military and counter China's growing presence in the region. The US has also offered India the armed version of Guardian drones, but the deal is unlikely due to lack of funds.

site_title: RE&S posts Q2 net loss of S$263,000 on temporary store closures
summary: RE&S Holdings, a CATALIST-listed restaurateur, reported a Q2 net loss of S$263,000 due to temporary store closures at Great World City and Jurong Point, resulting in a 7.1% decline in revenue to S$34 million. The company attributed the losses to the impact of the 2019 coronavirus outbreak and rising demand for online food delivery services. RE&S plans to explore new service channels and technology solutions to mitigate the effects of the pandemic and potential headwinds.

site_title: Ghosn used Nissan-Mitsubishi venture to inflate pay
summary: Former Nissan-Mitsubishi chairman Carlos Ghosn allegedly inflated his pay by using a joint venture to offset a cut in his declared earnings and cover a personal tax debt. Ghosn granted himself a salary and bonus worth 7.3 million euros without the knowledge of Nissan and Mitsubishi boards. He has denied wrongdoing, but lawyers for the companies claim the payments were made through the joint venture to offset the cut and avoid paying taxes. Ghosn is seeking 15 million euros in damages from the carmakers, alleging they violated Dutch labor laws.

site_title: Ride-hailing firms in Singapore step up measures to guard against virus outbreak
summary: Ride-hailing firms in Singapore have increased precautions amid the novel coronavirus outbreak. Grab suspended its carpooling service and advised drivers against picking up multiple riders, while Gojek strengthened its educational outreach to drivers. The government has also set up temperature-taking stations and provided surgical masks to drivers. To support affected drivers, both companies offer financial assistance and rental waivers during quarantine periods.

site_title: Healthcare plays back in favour; Sheng Siong up 4%
summary: Healthcare-related stocks in Singapore saw a surge in interest as the risk assessment for the novel coronavirus was raised to Orange, a moderate to high public health impact level. Sheng Siong, a local supermarket operator, rose 4.1% after being favored as a defensive play. Other healthcare companies, such as Medtecs International and Clearbridge Health, also saw significant gains. Meanwhile, glove makers like Riverstone Holdings and Top Glove climbed as investors anticipate increased demand for laboratory testing and protective equipment.

site_title: Xerox raises takeover offer for HP
summary: Xerox has raised its takeover offer for HP to $24 per share, consisting of $18.40 in cash and 0.149 Xerox shares, valuing the company at $35 billion. The new offer comes after several rejections of its previous bid and follows a plan to nominate 11 independent candidates to HP's board. The financing for the offer has been secured at $24 billion.

site_title: UK coronavirus cases double to 8, government declares 'imminent threat'
summary: The UK has reported 8 confirmed coronavirus cases, doubling from 4 previously, with all new cases linked to a Briton who had returned from Singapore and stayed at a French ski resort. The government has declared the virus a serious and imminent threat, giving doctors more powers to isolate those suspected of being infected. The UK has designated two isolation facilities and is quarantining British nationals who have been flown back from Wuhan. The risk to the public remains moderate, according to health minister Matt Hancock.

site_title: LifeBrandz touts new plan to give 282 shareholders 1 consolidated share each
summary: LifeBrandz, a Catalist-listed lifestyle investor, has revised its plan to give 282 shareholders one consolidated share each, after initially deciding to disregard their fractional entitlements. The board considered alternatives such as a share buyback mandate, but determined it was not a meaningful exercise given the small amounts involved. The new plan aims to balance safeguarding minority shareholders' interests with business and commercial considerations, and has been deemed "fair and appropriate" by the board.

site_title: OUE to buy 88.43% stake in Indonesian coffee chain for 229b rupiah
summary: OUE has agreed to buy an 88.43% stake in Indonesian coffee chain Maxx Coffee Prima for 229 billion rupiah (S$23.2 million). The acquisition, made by OUE's Oddish Ventures unit, was reached due to high barriers of entry in the Indonesian food and beverage market and access to prime retail locations. The deal is expected to augment OUE's food and beverage portfolio without significantly affecting its net tangible assets or earnings per share. The acquisition was finalized after two of OUE's controlling shareholders recused themselves from the decision-making process.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as coronavirus fears may hit Apple sales
summary: US stocks opened lower on Monday as concerns over the coronavirus outbreak in China may impact Apple sales, leading to losses in the company. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.37%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.28%, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.28%. Analysts predict a decline in quarterly smartphone sales in China due to retail store closures and production suspensions.

site_title: Soilbuild Construction bags S$48.3m contract from chairman's company
summary: Soilbuild Construction Group won an S$48.3 million contract from a company owned by executive chairman Lim Chap Huat, who is also the sole shareholder of the project owner. The contract, approved by shareholders in 2019, falls under an interested-person transaction mandate. Lim Cheng Hwa, a non-executive director of Soilbuild, also sits on the project owner's board.

site_title: honestbee suspends habitat business as traffic dives 60%
summary: honestbee has temporarily suspended operations at its supermarket, habitat, due to a 60% decline in walk-in traffic following Singapore's risk assessment for the novel coronavirus being raised to Orange, the second-highest level. The suspension, which started on Monday, will last until February 23 and may be extended. The company is undergoing a court-supervised restructuring process, with a proposed scheme of arrangement that includes repaying creditors with 3% cash and 97% shares in a new entity. Online grocery delivery service will continue to operate.

images.alt_text: habitat is a tech-enabled supermarket and dine-in concept located in Pasir Panjang.

site_title: Singapore scientists aim to test coronavirus vaccine in as soon as 3 months
summary: Singapore scientists are developing a coronavirus vaccine, with plans to test it in as soon as three months. The vaccine will be tested on healthy volunteers to monitor side effects and observe its effects on the immune system. Meanwhile, anti-viral drugs such as those used to treat HIV are being repurposed to treat patients with severe cases. The trial aims to speed up the development of vaccines and identify key periods for treatment and intervention. The research is part of efforts to combat the novel coronavirus, which has infected over 40,000 people globally.

site_title: Solar is beating out coal in Australia, pushing down emissions
summary: Australia's electricity landscape is transforming, with record-high renewables growth pushing out coal plants and lowering emissions. The Australian Energy Market Operator reported a 39% increase in solar and wind output in the fourth quarter, cutting power-generation emissions 5% and slashing wholesale prices by almost a fifth. This growth is expected to continue into 2020, with extreme heat and bushfires testing the power system in 2019. The move is seen as a shift away from coal, which has faced criticism from the government over its lack of a coherent climate policy.

site_title: Hong Kong tycoon Li Ka-shing gives HK$100m to Wuhan
summary: Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing's foundation donated HK$100 million (approximately S$17.88 million) to Wuhan, the epicentre of the new coronavirus that has killed over 900 people. This donation aims to support the city's healthcare efforts during the pandemic.

site_title: 2 new coronavirus cases in Singapore, including Certis Cisco staff who had served quarantine orders
summary: Two new coronavirus cases were reported in Singapore, bringing the total number of cases to 45. Seven patients are in critical condition, while seven have been discharged. The cases include a Certis Cisco staff member who had served quarantine orders.

site_title: 2 in 5 will only consider 'popular and successful' digibanks in Singapore: PwC poll
summary: A PwC poll found that 2 in 5 Singaporeans would consider opening a digital bank account only if it's "popular and successful". Younger customers and those with higher incomes are more interested in digital banking, but most will keep their existing bank account. The top feature for customers is better rates on deposits and lending, followed by quick online customer service and a better mobile experience. Digital banks need to create ongoing engagement and personalized financial and non-financial products to be successful in the long run.

site_title: Airlines face growth warning as virus curtails Singapore Airshow
summary: Asian airlines face drastic cuts in planned growth due to the coronavirus crisis, according to the International Air Transport Association. The Singapore Airshow, which began on Monday, is proceeding despite a depleted exhibitor list and new safety measures, with few deals expected. The crisis has triggered a 50-70% reduction in operations within China, and the air show's organisers are limiting public attendance. The event's expected revenue of tens of millions of dollars could be at risk if the show is cancelled.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) closed two banking outlets in China and a commercial banking centre in Hong Kong due to the novel coronavirus outbreak. Airlines face growth warnings due to the crisis, and ride-hailing firms in Singapore have stepped up measures to guard against the virus. ST Engineering secured new orders for aircraft conversion, while a PwC poll found that 2 in 5 Singaporeans prefer 'popular and successful' digibanks. Singapore shares dropped 1% as the virus spread, with the STI closing at 3,231.55.

site_title: Singapore shares continue drop as virus spread weighs on sentiment
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index dropped 1.3% at the start of the week, influenced by concerns over the novel coronavirus's spread, particularly outside of China. Despite a partial recovery, the index ended the day at 3,163.15, down 18.33 points or 0.6%. Investors remain cautious, with market strategist Stephen Innes describing the situation as "extremely concerned."

site_title: Volvo cars may go public in deal with Geely auto unit
summary: Volvo Cars, owned by Geely Group, is considering a merger with its Hong Kong-listed automobile unit to create a unified company valued at around $30 billion. The deal would unify Volvo with other automotive brands under billionaire Li Shufu's control, who also owns Daimler AG. The joint listing would be in Stockholm and Hong Kong, and the proposal follows Volvo's delayed initial public offering (IPO) in 2018. The move aims to pool resources for electrification and automated driving initiatives.

site_title: Discontent grows among HSBC workers as business review looms
summary: HSBC's European arm sees a 21-point drop in confidence among employees, with only 38% feeling confident about the company's future, a 15-point decline. The bank is set to release a strategic review on Feb. 18, amid uncertainty from the coronavirus and pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong. The review is expected to include job cuts, with businesses and countries expected to bear the brunt. The bank has attempted to calm fears with a letter to staff, warning of media speculation, but the survey highlights a "wait-and-see" approach to the strategy.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 11.69 points to 1,542.80, closing lower on Monday. The market saw a significant drop in volume, with 2.4 billion lots traded at RM1.9 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 597 to 285, indicating a bearish trend.

site_title: Wind giants in Germany are not so keen on market rates after all
summary: German offshore wind developers, including Orsted and Vattenfall, are pushing for new auction rules that would ensure they receive a guaranteed income for their power, regardless of wholesale prices. This comes after the government's muddled climate policy made investments in the technology riskier. The companies are seeking contracts-for-difference (CfDs), similar to those used in the UK, to secure financial stability. The Economy and Energy Ministry is evaluating its auction system and considering industry pressure to adopt CfDs, which would provide necessary financial security while promoting continued development of offshore wind.

site_title: Japanese e-commerce giant Rakuten raided by anti-monopoly officials
summary: Japanese antitrust officials raided Rakuten's offices over complaints from online merchants about the company's free shipping policies, which they claim is an abuse of its dominant position. Rakuten plans to make shipping free for orders above 3,980 yen starting March 18. The company's shares fell 1.4% after the raid. Rakuten is cooperating with the investigation, which aims to address pressure on merchants to shoulder shipping costs.
