site_title: S'pore manufacturers, service providers shut some China ops amid virus spread
summary: S'pore manufacturers and service providers have shut some operations in China amid the spread of the novel coronavirus, including InnoTek's Mansfield Group and Powermatic Data Systems. InnoTek closed some factories in mainland China, while Powermatic has suspended operations at two Suzhou-based subsidiaries. Other companies, such as Aoxin Q & M Dental Group and Zhongmin Baihui Retail Group, have also closed their operations or reduced trading hours. The closures are expected to disrupt supply chains and impact the companies' financial performance.

site_title: Philippines moves to cancel top broadcaster's franchise
summary: The Philippine government is moving to cancel the franchise of ABS-CBN, the country's largest media group, citing a violation of the constitution's restriction on foreign ownership. The move is seen as an attack on press freedom by campaigners, who claim it will silence a major voice in the country. The petition alleges that ABS-CBN allowed overseas investors to join the company, despite the constitution's ban. The franchise is set to expire on March 30, and the government has repeatedly vowed to block any new license.

site_title: Hot stocks: Healthcare-related plays back in vogue, supermarket operators see strong interest
summary: Singapore-listed healthcare-related stocks saw a surge in interest after the country raised its risk assessment of the novel coronavirus from Yellow to Orange. Medtecs International advanced 15.5% to 11.9 cents after a strong trading session, while another local supermarket operator joined the healthcare-related plays. The Orange alert level indicates a moderate to high public health impact, fueling concerns and bets on these counters as beneficiaries of the outbreak.

site_title: Airbnb suspends bookings in Beijing for rest of February
summary: Airbnb has suspended bookings in Beijing until February 29 due to the coronavirus outbreak, citing guidance from local authorities. The decision affects bookings from February 7 to February 29. This is a city-specific measure, with Airbnb evaluating the situation and working to comply with local guidance.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end the day lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the day lower, with the Hang Seng Index sliding 0.59% to close at 27,241.34. The decline was attributed to concerns over the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak in China. In contrast, mainland China's Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.5%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 1.2%.

site_title: NetLink NBN Trust posts 9.6% rise in Q3 net profit of S$21.5m
summary: NetLink NBN Trust reported a 9.6% increase in Q3 net profit to S$21.5 million, driven by rising home broadband connections. Revenue rose 2.9% to S$91.6 million, with residential connections reaching 1.42 million. However, installation-related revenue declined due to StarHub's fibre migration. The trust expects higher revenues in FY2020 from key connection services despite increased capital expenditure.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks end lower on virus worries
summary: South Korean shares ended lower on Monday due to growing concerns over the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak in China. The KOSPI closed down 0.49% at 2,201.07, with foreigners selling US$255.43 million worth of shares. This marks a 0.15% gain for the year so far, and a 0.4% increase in the previous 30 trading sessions.

site_title: Who won at the Oscars?
summary: The 97th Academy Awards ceremony was held on March 2, 2025, with 'Anora' emerging as the big winner, taking home five Oscars including best picture, best director, best actress, best film editing, and best original screenplay. Sean Baker won the awards for his work on 'Anora'. Adrien Brody won the Best Actor award for his role in 'The Brutalist', and Mikey Madison took home the Best Actress award for her role in 'Anora'.

images.alt_text: Brody has been dating fashion designer Georgina Chapman – the woman behind the Marchesa label and the ex-wife of disgraced producer Harvey Weinstein – since 2020.

Director Sean Baker accepts the Oscar for Best Picture for "Anora" as producers Samantha Quan, Alex Coco, and Best Actress in a Leading Role winner Mikey Madison look on at the 97th Academy Awards in Los Angeles, California, March 2, 2025.
Actress Demi Moore attends the 97th Annual Academy Awards at the Dolby Theatre in Hollywood, California, March 2, 2025.

site_title: Asia: Stocks slip, yuan fluctuates on virus news
summary: Asian stocks declined on Monday as investors awaited the economic impact of the novel coronavirus. The yen rose, and the yuan also increased, while the Australian dollar climbed. The People's Bank of China kept liquidity ample, but economists warn the hit to growth will be longer. The US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's semi-annual testimony is set for Tuesday and Wednesday, and China and the US are expected to lower tariffs on billions of dollars of imports on Friday.

site_title: Palm oil falls as coronavirus death toll climbs
summary: Malaysian palm oil futures declined 0.53% to RM2,798 per tonne on Monday due to concerns over the coronavirus epidemic in China, the country's second-largest buyer. The death toll in China's Hubei province surpassed 900, increasing worries about the impact on palm oil demand. Despite a 12.7% drop in January inventories, prices may retest a support level of RM2,795 per tonne, according to Reuters technical analyst Wang Tao.

site_title: Samsung debuts more compact foldable phone during Oscars ad
summary: Samsung unveiled a compact foldable smartphone, the Galaxy Z Flip, during the Oscars ceremony. The device features a square folded shape, a tiny notification panel, and a large widescreen display. It is smaller and more compact than Samsung's original foldable, Galaxy Fold. The phone will be available in black and purple colors and will be part of the Galaxy S20 lineup, which also includes three new flagship phones. The device is set to launch on February 11 in San Francisco.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand shares end lower ahead of corporate earnings
summary: Australian shares ended 0.1% lower on Monday ahead of corporate earnings, with investors awaiting the impact of the coronavirus outbreak in China. Index heavyweights Commonwealth Bank, CSL, and Maquarie Group will report earnings this week. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed lower due to losses in the financial sector and miners, but gained in safe haven gold stocks. New Zealand's benchmark index also fell 0.5%. The market's uncertainty led to risk aversion, with investors reducing exposure to wait for the reporting season's impact.

site_title: China stutters back to work as coronavirus deaths soar
summary: Millions of people in China returned to work Monday after a holiday aimed at slowing the spread of the new coronavirus, which has killed over 900 people and infected at least 40,000. The World Health Organisation warned that the overseas cases may be just the tip of the iceberg. China's economic situation is under pressure, with its GDP growth set to slow, raising concerns for policymakers.

site_title: South Koreans celebrate as "Parasite" snags historic wins at Oscars
summary: South Korean film "Parasite" made history at the Oscars, becoming the first non-English language movie to win Best Picture. Director Bong Joon-ho won Best Original Screenplay, Best Director, and International Feature Film, while the film also took home Best Picture. The win marked a historic first for South Korea's film industry, with the country's film industry being one of the largest in the world. The film's success demonstrated the global appeal of Korean cinema, with many praising its portrayal of social inequality.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks down with investors vigilant on virus
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 0.60% and the Topix index down 0.72%, amid concerns over the novel coronavirus outbreak. Investors locked in profits following a strong US jobs report and the death toll from the outbreak surged past 900 in mainland China. Markets are assessing the economic impact of containment measures and the pace of new infections closely, with many investors on the sidelines due to uncertainties.

site_title: UOB shuts select bank locations in China amid virus outbreak; Singapore financial centre on alert
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has closed select locations in Shanghai, Beijing, and Hong Kong as a precautionary measure against the novel coronavirus outbreak. The bank has shut its commercial banking centre in Kwun Tong, Hong Kong until February 14, while a small number of staff remain in mainland China to support critical business and customer services. This move follows other banks in suspending branches or services in Hong Kong and Macau since January.

site_title: ST Engineering wins new orders for aircraft conversion
summary: ST Engineering secured two new orders for the A321 passenger-to-freighter (P2F) aircraft conversion from US-based BBAM. The first unit was inducted in January, with the second conversion set to start in March. Additionally, ST Engineering's aircraft-leasing joint venture, Keystone Holdings, signed a letter of intent to convert and lease an aircraft under the A321P2F programme for Qantas Airways. The company also announced successful flight tests and plans to obtain the supplemental type certificate by the end of Q1 2020.

site_title: Forecasting the weather: Asean financial services industry taking balanced approach to cloud
summary: ASEAN financial institutions are adopting a balanced approach to cloud technology, moving non-critical applications to the cloud while keeping mission-critical applications on-premise. This approach allows them to better understand the risks and benefits of cloud adoption before fully committing to it. The region's banks are focusing on delivering a better customer experience, partnering with fintechs, and adopting a cost-effective operating model. While there are concerns about security, the majority of respondents in ACI Worldwide's Culture of Innovation Index plan to move mission-critical workloads to public cloud infrastructure this year, indicating a strong vote of confidence in cloud adoption.

site_title: Shipping is getting smashed by coronavirus in more ways than one
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic is significantly impacting the global shipping industry, with Chinese demand and supply chains severely disrupted. Shipping owners are facing reduced earnings due to lower cargo demand, with giant carriers earning just $2,660 per day, 93% below 2019 levels. The pandemic is also causing delays in installing scrubbers, which allow ships to burn fuel that was previously restricted by sulfur oxide emissions regulations, resulting in lost revenue and idle vessels.

site_title: Britain 'reasonably confident' of US trade deal despite Huawei concerns
summary: Britain's foreign secretary, Dominic Raab, expressed confidence in securing a US trade deal despite US concerns over Huawei's involvement in the UK's 5G mobile network. The UK granted Huawei a limited role in its 5G network last month, frustrating US efforts to exclude the firm. Raab acknowledged US concerns, saying they were taken seriously, but emphasized the UK's commitment to a trade deal. A trade deal is expected to be among the UK's first post-Brexit agreements.

site_title: China's producer prices break deflation spell but coronavirus heightens risks
summary: China's producer prices rose 0.1% in January, snapping a six-month decline, but the positive momentum is expected to be short-lived due to the coronavirus outbreak. The virus has driven consumer inflation to a 7-year high, with food prices surging 20.6% and pork prices rising 116%. The outbreak has also disrupted supply chains, prompting economists to lower GDP growth estimates for the first quarter and full year. Beijing is considering slashing its 2020 growth target and implementing fiscal and monetary stimulus to counter the effects of the outbreak.

site_title: Indonesia Q4 current account deficit widens to 2.84%
summary: Indonesia's current account deficit widened to 2.84% in the fourth quarter, reaching a US$8.1 billion gap, from 2.7% in the previous quarter. The country's balance of payments showed a US$4.3 billion surplus in the fourth quarter, compared to a US$46 million deficit in the previous three months. This brings the full-year current account deficit to 2.72% of GDP, with a US$4.7 billion surplus for the full-year balance of payments.

site_title: Sommeliers on the march as Trump tariffs threaten Chianti, Rosé
summary: Sommeliers, wine importers, and restaurateurs are protesting potential US tariffs on European wine, cheese, and olive oil, which could lead to prices doubling for American consumers. The US Trade Representative has threatened to impose tariffs as high as 100% on these products in retaliation for European subsidies to Airbus. The move could devastate the market for these products, causing job losses and decimating sales. The wine industry fears the tariffs will effectively kill the market for French and other European wines in the US, with some predicting prices could rise by as much as $70 for a US$9 glass of wine.

site_title: Aussie dollar rallies, Asian currencies lift as China heads back to work
summary: Asian currencies rose on Monday as China began to recover from the coronavirus outbreak, with the Australian dollar gaining 0.5% to US$0.6706. The New Zealand dollar also bounced 0.2% to US$0.6410. The Chinese yuan rose 0.2% to 6.9897, lifting Asian currencies, while the US dollar softened to 109.75 yen. Positive news included Taiwan's Foxconn receiving approval to resume production in China and Tesla's Shanghai factory resuming production. However, concerns remain about the impact on the local labor market and potential rate cuts.

site_title: China inflation rises as coronavirus disrupts supply chains
summary: China's consumer prices rose 5.4% in January, the highest rate in over eight years, driven by Lunar New Year demand and the disruption caused by the coronavirus outbreak. Food prices spiked 20.6%, with pork and fresh vegetables contributing to the increase. The National Bureau of Statistics attributed the rise to both Spring Festival-related factors and the new coronavirus, which has claimed over 900 lives in China. Analysts expect the virus to keep prices higher than usual due to supply chain disruptions and hoarding.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon down 0.8% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Monday afternoon, down 0.8% on the day, amid concerns over the novel coronavirus. The Straits Times Index fell 25.40 points to 3,156.08. Banking stocks declined, with DBS, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank losing 1.1%, 1.3%, and 1.2% respectively. Other stocks, such as Ascott Residence Trust and CDL Hospitality Trusts, also fell. The decline was part of a broader Asia-wide downturn, with Japan's Topix and South Korea's Kospi also falling 0.6%.

site_title: Australia cartel investigator says no impropriety in exchanges with JPMorgan lawyers
summary: Australian antitrust investigator Michael Taylor denied impropriety in exchanges with JPMorgan lawyers during the investigation into a $2.5 billion share sale in 2015. JPMorgan and its staff had agreed to act as informants with the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) in exchange for immunity from prosecution. Taylor testified that he had taken steps to ensure the integrity of the investigation, including reviewing email communications between the ACCC and JPMorgan lawyers. The case, which alleges the banks colluded to keep ANZ stock prices high, remains ongoing.

site_title: Virus outbreak to hit Asia's semiconductor industry in Feb and March: Citi
summary: A novel coronavirus outbreak in Asia is expected to disrupt the region's semiconductor industry in February and March, according to Citi Research. The outbreak has led to lockdowns in Chinese cities, a labor shortage, and disruptions in freight logistics, resulting in a delay in China's demand for semiconductor imports. This could negatively impact South Korea and Taiwan, which rely heavily on China for chip sales, and lead to a shortage of intermediate goods used in electronics production, affecting consumer electronics and household appliances.

site_title: Malaysia's economy to grow 4.5% in 2020: Mahathir
summary: Malaysia's economy is expected to grow 4.5% in 2020, down from the initial 4.8% forecast, according to Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad. This revision is attributed to "challenging times." Mahathir cited good fiscal discipline in reducing the budget deficit to 3.2% and a commitment to providing a stable business environment for investors.

site_title: Kia Motors says suspending production at South Korean plants due to parts shortages
summary: Kia Motors has suspended production at its three South Korean car plants due to a shortage of auto parts. Production at the Gwangju and Sohari factories will be halted on Monday and Tuesday, while the Hwaseong factory resumed production on Tuesday after a one-day halt. Kia will monitor the availability of parts to determine if production will resume after the suspension.

site_title: China reports first H5N6 bird flu in Sichuan poultry farm: Ministry
summary: China's agriculture ministry reported the first H5N6 bird flu case in a poultry farm in Sichuan province, resulting in the death of 1,840 out of 2,497 birds. This is the first avian flu detected from a poultry farm after four cases found in swans this year. The remaining birds have been culled to prevent the spread of the disease.

site_title: Brad Pitt back on top with Oscar win
summary: Brad Pitt won the Oscar for his role in Quentin Tarantino's "Once Upon a Time... in Hollywood," marking his first acting Academy Award after 30 years in showbiz. Pitt, 56, thanked his children and referenced the impeachment trial, delivering a witty and heartfelt speech. His win comes after a low-profile period following his divorce and custody battle with Angelina Jolie. Pitt has shifted focus to producing, stating he'll appear in fewer films to pursue other projects.

site_title: Australia, Indonesia move to implement trade deal
summary: Australia and Indonesia announced a 100-day plan to implement a long-awaited trade deal worth $12 billion annually, aiming to deepen trade and counter China's growing economic and military influence. The agreement will eliminate Australian tariffs and 94% of Indonesian duties, boosting exports of automotive, textile, and medicinal goods. The deal, hailed as a "new beginning" for the two nations, also aims to improve access for Australian universities, health providers, and miners in Indonesia's vast market of 260 million people.

site_title: Gold extends gain after WHO chief's 'tip of the iceberg' warning
summary: Gold prices rose for a fourth consecutive day as investors assessed the impact of the coronavirus outbreak on global growth and appetite for risk. The WHO's Director-General warned of a "tip of the iceberg" scenario, citing concerns over the spread of the disease. The global death toll surpassed 900, and Beijing pledged at least $10 billion to combat the outbreak. Despite weaker physical demand in China, gold trading reached its highest level since 2013, with investors weighing the virus's effects on the outlook. The Federal Reserve considers the issue a "new risk."

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp, Olam, SIA Engg, Frasers Prop, Micro-Mechanics, Koufu
summary: Sembcorp Industries concluded multi-million-dollar legal proceedings over pollution offences in China, impacting its shares. Olam International announced a one-time net gain of S$72 million for its fiscal fourth quarter. SIA Engineering reported a 63.1% surge in net profit to S$54 million. Frasers Property acquired property manager AsiaMalls Management. Micro-Mechanics posted a 14.4% increase in net profit. Koufu Group plans to expand its domestic footprint.

site_title: Canada's top manufacturer Bombardier at a crossroads
summary: Canada's top manufacturer Bombardier is facing financial difficulties, with the company heavily indebted and considering selling off major divisions to stay afloat. Rumors of potential sales to Alstom or Textron have been circulating, and Bombardier has announced it is actively pursuing alternatives to accelerate debt paydown. The company has also revised downward its preliminary 2019 revenues. This move comes after a painful restructuring process, leaving Bombardier at a crossroads to secure its future.

site_title: Lendlease Global Reit posts DPU of 1.29 S cents, 3.1% above IPO forecast
summary: Lendlease Global Reit reported a DPU of 1.29 Singapore cents, 3.1% above its IPO forecast, for its second quarter. The distributable income was S$15 million, 2.4% higher than the forecast, and gross revenue was S$21.4 million, 1% above the forecast. Net property income exceeded the forecast by 3.2%. The company's gearing ratio was 34.9% as of Dec 31. The unit price ended its first day of trading 4.5% above its IPO price.

site_title: Oil prices fall on oversupply worries as virus hits China demand
summary: Oil prices declined due to concerns over oversupply and the impact of the coronavirus outbreak on China's demand. Brent crude fell to a low of $53.63 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate dropped to $49.94 a barrel. Russia's decision to delay a proposed OPEC production cut of 600,000 barrels per day further reduced market pressure, with oil traders expressing concerns that the proposed reduction would not be sufficient to tighten global markets.

site_title: Hong Kong, China: Stocks open lower on virus fears
summary: Hong Kong stocks dropped 1.1% at the open on Monday, February 10, 2020, amid concerns over the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak in mainland China, which has killed over 900 people. The Hang Seng Index fell to 27,092.15, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also declined. The decline follows a broader global market trend, with US and European stocks also experiencing losses.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks dropped at the open on Monday as concerns lingered about the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak that has killed more than 900 people in mainland China.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 6.50 points or 0.42% to 1,547.99. The market saw a higher volume of 76.72 million lots worth RM39.33 million, with losers beating gainers 165 to 95. This is the latest update on the Malaysian stock market, with no specific cause mentioned for the decline.

site_title: HSBC Women's golf in Singapore cancelled because of coronavirus
summary: The 2020 HSBC Women's World Championship in Singapore and the LPGA Thailand tournament have been cancelled due to the coronavirus pandemic. The decision was made by the LPGA Tour and its partners, citing continued health concerns and advisories in some Asian countries to cancel or postpone large-scale events. The tournaments, which would have featured top players including world number one Ko Jin-young and defending champion Park Sung-hyun, will not take place this season. The cancellation affects the US women's Tour's early-season events in Asia.

site_title: Australia: Shares weighed by miners, energy stocks, New Zealand falls
summary: Australian shares fell 0.5% to 6,988.1, weighed down by energy and mining stocks amid coronavirus concerns. Deaths from the outbreak have surpassed 900, with China's tourism and businesses hit hard. Mining stocks like BHP Group and Fortescue Metals Group lost 1.9% and 2.5%, respectively. Meanwhile, gold stocks rose 2% as investors sought safe-haven assets. New Zealand's benchmark index also fell 0.7% to 11,675.710, with utilities and industrial sectors losing the most.

site_title: Coronavirus deaths jump to 902 on Monday: official
summary: China reported 902 coronavirus deaths nationwide on Monday, with 91 new fatalities in hard-hit Hubei province. The province also confirmed 2,618 new cases. This surge in cases highlights the growing severity of the outbreak.

site_title: Britain, Ireland hit as Storm Ciara whips over northwest Europe
summary: Storm Ciara brought strong winds and heavy rain to northwest Europe, affecting Britain, Ireland, and several other countries. Over 30,000 homes in Britain lost power, and more than 150mm of rain fell in some areas. The storm caused widespread disruptions, including the cancellation of sports events, flights, and travel. The English Premier League and Women's Super League football fixtures were postponed, and the Women's Six Nations rugby tournament was also affected. The storm's impact was felt across northern Europe, with multiple countries experiencing power outages, flight cancellations, and travel disruptions.

site_title: Deal reached to cut bankrupt Puerto Rico's debt by US$24b
summary: Puerto Rico has reached a deal with bondholders to cut its debt by $24 billion, shedding $35 billion of bonds and claims. The agreement also increases the ranks of general obligation and Public Buildings Authority bondholders. The restructuring plan aims to restructure core government debt and pension obligations. The deal moves Puerto Rico closer to exiting bankruptcy.

site_title: Singapore stocks decline on sustained virus jitters; STI opens 1.3% lower
summary: Singapore stocks declined 1.3% on Monday, with the Straits Times Index falling 41.54 points to 3,139.94. Investors remained cautious due to sustained concerns over the novel coronavirus. Decliners outnumbered advancers 125 to 35, with banking stocks taking a hit, including DBS, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank. The decline was part of a broader Asia-Pacific downturn, with Japan's Topix and South Korea's Kospi also falling.

site_title: Hyflux director Simon Tay quits after commenting on WongP's discharge
summary: Hyflux director Simon Tay has resigned as non-executive independent director after commenting on WongPartnership's discharge from representing the water treatment firm. Tay cited "unresolved differences in opinion" and had previously recused himself from discussions on the matter but continued to comment publicly. Clifford Chance and Cavenagh Law expressed concern that Tay's actions breached his duty as an independent director, prompting his resignation.

site_title: BHG Retail Reit closes stores at two China malls to contain virus spread
summary: BHG Retail Reit temporarily closed stores at two malls in China to contain the spread of the novel coronavirus. The closures, effective Feb 6, include all stores except supermarkets and delivery services at Hefei Mengchenglu Mall and Hefei Changjianxilu Mall. The move follows a notice from local authorities requiring the closure of non-essential venues. The Reit's manager aims to reopen stores as soon as possible. This is part of the Reit's portfolio, which includes four other malls in China and a 60% stake in a mall in Beijing.

site_title: Turkish banking watchdog limits banks' forex swap transactions
summary: Turkey's banking watchdog, BDDK, has limited banks' foreign exchange transactions to 10% of their equity, down from 25% in August 2018. The new limit will be calculated daily and will apply to forex swaps, spot, and forward transactions with foreign entities. The move aims to curb excessive foreign exchange exposure and stabilize the financial system.

site_title: Amazon pulls out of major Barcelona telecoms conference over coronavirus
summary: Amazon has pulled out of Mobile World Congress in Barcelona due to the coronavirus outbreak, citing concerns about the new coronavirus. The company had planned a significant presence through its cloud computing arm AWS, but will withdraw from exhibiting and participating in the event. This move is another blow to the telecom industry's biggest gathering, which attracts over 100,000 visitors. Amazon's decision comes as the company prioritizes safety amid the growing coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Olam to post one-time net gain of S$72m for Q4 from restructuring initiatives
summary: Olam International expects to record a net one-time post-tax gain of S$72 million for its Q4 2020, resulting from restructuring initiatives under its 2019-2024 strategic plan. The company has sold assets, including real estate and permanent water rights, generating a one-time post-tax capital gain of around S$372 million. However, Olam will also recognize S$300 million in one-off exits costs, losses on disposal, and/or impairment on deprioritized assets. The company will release its Q4 results on Feb 28.

site_title: honestbee suspends habitat business due to coronavirus outbreak
summary: honestbee has suspended operations at its supermarket, habitat, in Pasir Panjang, Singapore, until Feb 23 due to the novel coronavirus outbreak, which has raised the risk assessment to Orange, the second-highest level. The company will continue to provide online grocery delivery services while undergoing a court-supervised restructuring process.

site_title: Thousands from cruise ship in Hong Kong freed after virus tests
summary: Thousands of people stranded on a Hong Kong cruise ship were released from quarantine after its crew tested negative for the new coronavirus. The World Dream, carrying 1,800 crew and passengers, had previously had three Chinese passengers who tested positive for the virus on a voyage to Vietnam. The passengers and crew were released after five days in quarantine due to concerns they may have contracted the virus. The release comes after health authorities confirmed the crew and passengers had tested negative for the virus.

site_title: Downside risk looms for Nikkei 225
summary: The Nikkei 225 index, Japan's stock market, faces downside risk due to underlying economic conditions and global geopolitical risks. A sales tax hike and the yen's appreciation as a safe-haven currency are contributing factors. The index rebounded from a low in 2020 but failed to sustain its rally, and recent headwinds from the coronavirus outbreak and tourism outlook are expected to continue. Technical analysis suggests a potential double-three formation, which could lead to a significant decline in the index, potentially below 20,000 points.

site_title: India bus hits power line, 10 dead: officials
summary: At least 10 people were killed in India when a bus carrying about 40 passengers caught fire after making contact with a roadside power line in the eastern state of Odisha. Initial investigations suggest the luggage carrier of the bus touched the power line when the driver tried to give way to a two-wheeled vehicle. Five others were in critical condition. The accident occurred near Mandarajpur, and authorities are continuing to investigate the cause.

site_title: JetBlue founder files to launch new airline by end of 2020
summary: JetBlue founder David Neeleman filed an application with the Department of Transportation to launch a new airline, Breeze Airways, with initial flights possible by the end of 2020. The leisure-focused, low-cost airline aims to serve mid-sized US cities, focusing on routes "abandoned by our current air transportation network." Breeze will initially use Embraer 195 planes and later Airbus A220s. The airline seeks to become "the world's nicest airline" and compete in a highly concentrated US air transport sector. Neeleman plans to fly about 500 city pairs, bypassing connection hubs.

site_title: Nine members of Hong Kong family get virus after 'hotpot': officials
summary: Nine members of a Hong Kong family have been infected with the new coronavirus after sharing a hotpot meal, officials confirmed. The family, consisting of a 24-year-old man, his grandmother (91), and seven relatives, contracted the virus after a Lunar New Year gathering in January. This brings the total number of infected cases in Hong Kong to at least 36. The semi-autonomous city has enforced a 14-day quarantine period for all people arriving from mainland China, with over 470 people ordered to stay at home or in quarantine camps.

site_title: Trump to propose US$4.8t US budget with large cuts in safety nets: WSJ
summary: US President Donald Trump will release a $4.8 trillion budget proposal on Monday, which includes steep cuts to social safety net programs and foreign aid. The budget will raise military spending by 0.3% to $740.5 billion for fiscal year 2021, while increasing outlays for defense and veterans.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump will release a US$4.8 trillion budget on Monday that will propose steep cuts to social safety net programmes and foreign aid, the Wall Street Journal reported on Sunday.

site_title: MAS advises banks on extra measures amid virus outbreak
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) advises banks to implement extra measures and precautions amid the coronavirus outbreak. The MAS urges financial institutions to manage increased demand for services, maintain internal controls, and monitor staff morale. The advisory comes after Singapore raised its coronavirus alert level from yellow to orange and reported more cases. The MAS also reminds banks to remain vigilant on cybersecurity and be cautious of scams and phishing attacks.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 0.77% to 23,645.09. Investors locked in profits while monitoring the novel coronavirus. The broader Topix index also fell 0.81%.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday as investors continued to lock in profits while keeping a close watch on new infections from the novel coronavirus.

site_title: Britain plans to create 10 free ports
summary: Britain plans to create up to 10 free ports to stimulate the economy after Brexit, with a 10-week consultation launched to name locations by the end of the year. The free ports will not require a full customs declaration for goods entering, and London aims to have them operational by 2021. The move is part of the UK's mission to promote global free trade and regenerate communities.

site_title: Data protection - taking the 'It will happen to us' approach
summary: A recent shift in data protection has highlighted the importance of personal data protection, following high-profile breaches in 2018, including the misuse of Cambridge Analytica's data and the theft of SingHealth patients' records. Fines for data breaches in Singapore have increased, with the Personal Data Protection Commission (PDPC) imposing fines totaling S$1.54 million in 2019. The PDPC has also introduced an "accountability obligation" for organizations, requiring them to demonstrate responsibility for personal data protection. Boards of directors are urged to take a proactive approach to data protection, as failure to do so can result in reputational damage, loss of customer trust, and decreased shareholder value.

site_title: Virus may steal limelight from earnings results
summary: The spread of the novel coronavirus continues to dictate investor sentiment, despite a series of earnings releases from Singapore's largest corporates. Asian equities have been sold off since late January, with the Straits Times Index sliding 1.6% on Friday. The Singapore government raised its risk assessment to orange, citing moderate to high public health impact, and economists have downgraded growth forecasts for China and Singapore. Standard Chartered Bank projects China's growth to 5.8% and United Overseas Bank predicts a 1.5% growth for Singapore in 2020, with potential negative effects of 0.5-1 percentage points if the outbreak lasts six months.

site_title: New York's real estate groups to challenge ban on broker fees for renters
summary: New York real estate groups are challenging the state's ban on broker fees for renters, claiming the Department of State overstepped its authority. The Real Estate Board of New York and the New York State Association of Realtors filed a lawsuit, accusing the agency of failing to follow proper procedures before issuing the rule. The groups argue the rule will severely impact the incomes of real estate professionals, while tenant advocates say the guidance was valid and predict the lawsuit will fail.

site_title: Coronavirus deaths rise past 800, overtaking Sars toll
summary: The death toll from the novel coronavirus in mainland China has surpassed 800, overtaking the global fatalities from the 2002-03 Sars epidemic. With 89 additional deaths reported, the total infected stands at 37,200. The World Health Organization says the outbreak appears to be stabilizing, but warns of potential "shoot up" in cases. The Chinese government has implemented lockdowns and measures to control the spread, with some cities ordering residents to wear masks in public. The WHO praises China's response, but concerns remain over the handling of the crisis, particularly after a whistleblowing doctor died from the virus.

site_title: The humble urban garbage truck gets a high-tech battery makeover
summary: Volvo is set to start producing electric garbage trucks in Europe, with cities such as Hamburg and Gothenburg already signed up to buy. The trucks, weighing 16-27 tonnes, offer advantages for electrification due to their regular routes and frequent stops that return energy to batteries. Despite higher upfront costs, Volvo predicts that the total cost of ownership will be comparable to diesel equivalents by the middle of the decade. The company's move is driven by growing competition from rivals and cities increasingly hostile to combustion vehicles, with many introducing limited bans on older diesel cars.

site_title: Sea's digital banking move offers edge over Grab-led bid: report
summary: Sea Ltd, the parent company of shopping platform Shopee, may have an edge over the Grab-Singtel consortium in Singapore's digital banking bid, according to a fresh report by S&P. Both Sea and the Grab-led consortium appear to meet regulators' expectations for having a significant capital base and offering financial services to underbanked segments. Sea's e-commerce business presents greater lending opportunities, and its ability to issue cards without financial institution support could drive down checkout abandonment rates. The report suggests Sea's digital banking move could be a key differentiator in the battle for Singapore's two new digital full bank licences.

site_title: Frasers Property unit acquires manager of Singapore malls, office building
summary: Frasers Property unit Frasers Property Retail acquired property manager AsiaMalls Management for an undisclosed sum. AsiaMalls manages five malls and a 20-storey office tower in Singapore. The acquisition aims to unlock operational synergies and compete effectively in the retail landscape. Frasers Property Retail oversees 14 malls in Singapore and reported a 9.5% rise in first-quarter net profit to S$159.4 million.

images.alt_text: The six properties, including the Century Square mall (pictured) in Tampines, are held by PGIM Real Estate AsiaRetail Fund.

site_title: Companies will be hit harder by supply chains disruption than during Sars outbreak
summary: China's factory closures and transport disruptions due to the novel coronavirus outbreak will have a more significant impact on global supply chains than the 2003 SARS epidemic, according to market watchers. China is now a crucial part of global supply chains, with 30-40% of the world's textiles and footwear exports originating from the country. The shutdown of key manufacturing hubs and transport links will affect sectors such as textiles, electronics, and automotive industries, with Taiwan, South Korea, and Vietnam likely to be the hardest hit.

site_title: Carmakers can't turn out EVs cheap enough to convert Indians
summary: India's electric vehicle market is hindered by high upfront costs, with most models priced above $8,000, making them inaccessible to budget-conscious buyers. Carmakers, including Mahindra & Mahindra and Hyundai Motor India, are working to bring prices down, with some expecting a decline in cell prices and increased local manufacturing over the next three to five years. However, a lack of charging infrastructure and rapidly evolving technology also pose challenges to mass adoption. The Indian government aims to increase the share of electric vehicles on the road to 15% by 2023, but the current muted demand for EVs is a significant obstacle.

site_title: China to support debt financing for virus-related projects
summary: China will support debt financing for companies working on virus-related projects, encouraging firms with good credit to provide liquidity support for affected SMEs. The National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) will help companies raise funds for medical services, scientific research, and other virus-related projects. This move aims to stimulate economic growth and support affected industries amid the ongoing coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Coronavirus: Singapore bans 4 work pass holders
summary: Singapore has banned four work pass holders and suspended privileges of six employers for breaching leave of absence requirements due to the coronavirus. The four workers were found to have worked during their leave period, while the six employers were penalized for hiring work pass holders during this time. The Ministry of Manpower also announced stricter measures, requiring employers to obtain approval for work pass holders who traveled to mainland China within the last 14 days.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The global tanker and dry bulk market has experienced another dismal week, with rates plummeting due to reduced demand and supply chain disruptions. In the Capesize market, Brazilian iron ore flows were severely impacted by poor weather, leading to a 12% drop in C3 rates to $13.575. The Pacific region was also affected by tropical cyclone Damien, which halted activity out of West Australia. In contrast, the US Gulf saw some improvement in rates, with a 28,000dwt vessel fixed for a grain trip to Morocco at $6,500.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Budget 2020 preview
summary: Singaporeans expect Budget 2020 to bring relief amid the challenging economic outlook and novel coronavirus outbreak. Minister Indranee Rajah will outline the government's plans, including potential tax relief for businesses. The podcast discusses the economic challenges and expected measures to mitigate their impact.

site_title: When Chinese consumers stay home, world's retailers take hit
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic is affecting global retailers, particularly those reliant on Chinese consumers, with shopping streets emptying out and stores closing. Companies such as Burberry, Nike, and Shiseido are feeling the impact, with Burberry warning of an 80% loss of sales in China. Luxury brands are especially hard hit, with Burberry generating 40% of its sales from Chinese consumers. The Lunar New Year travel and shopping season coinciding with the outbreak has exacerbated the issue, with many executives expecting a short-term hit.

site_title: Dollar advances to four-month high after upbeat US jobs data
summary: The US dollar reached a four-month high against a basket of major currencies after a strong US non-farm payrolls report, with 225,000 jobs added last month. The dollar index posted its largest weekly percentage gain in over two years, while the dollar rose against sterling, the Canadian dollar, and the Swiss franc. However, it fell against the yen due to concerns over the coronavirus outbreak in China. Economists expect the Federal Reserve to keep interest rates steady, citing a strong US job market and expanding economy.

site_title: Singapore Airshow hit by virus fears as some 70 companies pull out
summary: Over 70 companies, including US aerospace giant Lockheed Martin, have pulled out of the Singapore Airshow due to concerns over the coronavirus outbreak. Despite this, the event, which begins on Tuesday, will still proceed with over 930 participating companies. Organizers maintain that the event will go ahead as planned, down from the original 1,000 companies.

site_title: Panic buying hits Singapore after virus alert raised
summary: Singapore shoppers formed long lines at grocery stores after the city-state raised its alert level to "orange" over China's coronavirus outbreak. The alert, which indicates the virus is severe and passes easily between people, prompted panic buying of essential items such as rice, noodles, and toilet paper. Despite government assurances that there's no risk of shortages, empty shelves and long lines were reported. The city-state has reported 33 cases of the virus, with over 700 deaths in China and more than 34,000 infected globally.

site_title: Towards a secure, digitally-ready and low carbon aviation future for all
summary: The aviation industry is shifting towards a secure, digitally-ready, and low-carbon future. With exponential demand for air travel and a need for efficiency, technology such as artificial intelligence (AI) and robotics is being harnessed to improve safety, security, and sustainability. The International Air Transport Association (IATA) estimates a 4.7% annual growth rate in air traffic in the Asia-Pacific region by 2035. To maintain momentum, industry players must prioritize secure technology, sustainable innovations, and building capacity, including collaborations between governments and private sectors.

site_title: A gateway to Asia-Pac's booming air travel industry
summary: The Singapore Airshow 2020 will take place from February 11-16, focusing on technology, innovation, and Asia-Pacific's strong growth outlook for air travel. The event aims to connect industry players, startups, and investors, with a focus on sustainable technologies and environmentally friendly solutions. Boeing expects the region's rising appetite for air travel to drive demand for 40% of new airplane deliveries globally and services valued at $3.4 trillion over the next 20 years. The airshow will feature business forums, startup pitches, and innovation sessions, showcasing the latest advancements in AI, blockchain, and more.

site_title: Budget 2020: A need to tackle long-term transformation, sustainability issues
summary: Singapore's Budget 2020 aims to address long-term transformation, sustainability, and ageing population issues, in addition to providing short-term relief from the novel coronavirus. Business leaders called for more support and incentives for digitalisation, talent development, and sustainability. Key measures suggested include incentivising low-carbon technologies, promoting green buildings, and investing in preventive healthcare. The budget is seen as crucial for tackling economic transformation, digitalisation, and environmental concerns, as well as addressing the ageing population and ageism in the workforce.

site_title: Home furnishing players face potential supply disruptions
summary: Singapore's furniture and lighting industry is concerned about potential supply chain disruptions due to China's response to the coronavirus outbreak. Companies worry that components may not be shipped on time, affecting production. Mark Yong, president of the Singapore Furniture Council, expressed these concerns. The industry is largely unaffected for now, but the situation may change if the outbreak persists and China's borders remain sealed.

site_title: STI rebounds 2%; Elite Commercial Reit makes its debut
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rebounded 1.9% over the five trading sessions from Jan 31 to Feb 6, with the Nikkei 225 Index, Hang Seng Index, and S&P/ASX 200 Index averaging a 4.2% gain. This brings the STI's 2020 total return to 0.4%. Share buybacks totaled S$2.2 million, with Singapore Press Holdings and Stamford Land Corporation leading the consideration tally. Elite Commercial Reit, the first UK-focused Singapore Reit, made its debut on Feb 6 with an initial portfolio of 97 commercial buildings in the UK.

site_title: An open response to SGX's open consultation
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has proposed enhancements to its regulatory regime for property valuation and auditors. The proposals include requiring listed companies to appoint an additional auditor to provide a second independent opinion on their financial statements under certain circumstances. This could be a catalyst for change in the auditing field, promoting a more investor-centric approach. The proposals also include standards for valuers, such as requiring them to have at least five years of experience and be independent of the companies they serve. Critics argue that these measures may be used as a shield against valid criticism, but proponents see them as necessary to boost investor confidence and protect against potential scandals like Enron.

site_title: Build for the future
summary: Singapore's 2020 Budget should address longer-term issues such as an aging population, housing affordability, and skills development. The government aims to boost economic growth and productivity, while also addressing social and environmental concerns. Key areas include increasing support for low-income households, enhancing healthcare services, and promoting sustainable development. The budget also needs to balance fiscal prudence with the need to invest in key sectors, such as education and infrastructure.

site_title: Fear and panic can do more harm than the coronavirus, says PM Lee Hsien Loong
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong warns that fear and panic can be more detrimental than the coronavirus, urging citizens to remain calm and take sensible precautions. The country has stockpiled masks and medical supplies, upgraded facilities, and trained healthcare workers to combat the outbreak. Despite the virus being more infectious, it is less deadly than SARS, with a death rate of 0.2% compared to 0.1% for seasonal influenza. Measures are being taken to contain the spread, but the government is preparing for a potential shift in strategy if the virus becomes widespread.

site_title: Mega-landlord deal in Germany faces mounting investor resistance
summary: German landlord ADO Properties faces resistance from investors over a proposed three-way deal to create one of the country's largest landlords. The deal involves acquiring stakes in Adler Real Estate and Consus Real Estate, with investors questioning the rationale behind the acquisition. Shareholders are concerned that the deal would destroy value and increase risk, with one fund manager stating that the deal "should never have happened." ADO's shares have plummeted 18% since the deal was announced, while Consus has gained 21%. The deal is set to be finalized on March 6.

site_title: Coronavirus toll hits 722, with first foreign victim
summary: The death toll from China's coronavirus outbreak has reached 722, including the first foreign victim, a 60-year-old US citizen. The US embassy confirmed the death, and a Japanese man also died in Wuhan. Nearly 35,000 people have been infected globally, with Hong Kong imposing a mandatory quarantine on mainland arrivals. The crisis has prompted drastic measures, including a "wartime" approach, and researchers are racing to develop a treatment and vaccine. The government has also faced criticism over its handling of the crisis, particularly after a whistleblowing doctor, Li Wenliang, died from the virus.

site_title: Coronavirus may hit building projects using pre-fab work too
summary: Singapore's construction industry faces disruptions due to the novel coronavirus outbreak, affecting pre-fabricated pre-finished volumetric construction (PPVC) projects. Builders rely heavily on Chinese suppliers, with 70-80% of materials sourced from China, leading to delays and potential monetary losses. The Building & Construction Authority (BCA) has informed contractors of the possibility of submitting claims for extension of time due to the impact of the virus. Contractors are exploring alternative sources, such as Malaysia and Indonesia, and may renegotiate prices and deadlines. The industry is bracing for varying levels of difficulties, with those near project completion in a better position.

site_title: OCBC contributes S$300k to set up first community shop
summary: OCBC Bank donates S$300,000 over 5 years to establish the first community shop in Singapore, providing food to nearly 5,000 eligible households. The shop, set up by Food from the Heart, aims to minimize food waste by offering preferred food items to those in need, rather than standard packages from charities. The donation will fund shop setup, operations, and food supplies, with OCBC staff volunteering to analyze data on consumption patterns to guide food item provision.

site_title: Controversial Nobel Center finds new home in Stockholm
summary: The Nobel Foundation has found a new location for its controversial center in Stockholm, after a Swedish court rejected the original plan due to concerns over the building's impact on the city's historical development. The new site is in the Slussen area, about 1 km from the original location, and will feature a new design. The foundation aims to launch work on the project in 2025 or 2026, and will initiate the process of seeking funding and appointing an architect. The center will house a museum and serve as a site for outreach activities, including the Nobel prize ceremony.

site_title: Coronavirus: 3 new cases, 4 more recovered, 6 in critical condition in ICU
summary: Three new coronavirus cases were confirmed in Singapore on February 9, 2020, including a 71-year-old grandfather and a Bangladeshi worker, with no known links to previous cases or travel history to China. Four more individuals have recovered from the virus, and six remain in critical condition in the ICU.

site_title: Food-share apps seeking to help environment
summary: Food-share apps like Karma and Too Good To Go are helping reduce food waste by offering discounted prices on surplus food from restaurants. The apps, which have gained popularity amid the climate emergency, can source daily meals for around £3.50. Industry estimates suggest one-third of all food is thrown away, contributing to greenhouse gas emissions. Experts say while the apps raise awareness, they don't address the root cause of food waste, which is still a significant issue in the UK, with 10 billion meals ending up in the bin each year.

site_title: Factories feeling the strain from supply and labour shortages
summary: Manufacturing companies in Singapore are feeling strain from supply chain disruptions and labour shortages due to the novel coronavirus outbreak in China. Hubei and Henan provinces, major manufacturing hubs, are particularly affected, impacting steel, automobile, and electronics sectors. Chemical manufacturers, however, report limited impact, indicating varying effects across industries.

site_title: Twitter says Facebook, Messenger accounts hacked
summary: Twitter confirmed that the official Facebook and Messenger accounts were hacked through a third-party platform. The compromised accounts were locked and restored with the help of Facebook. This incident comes after Twitter's CEO Jack Dorsey's account was hacked in August, allowing an unauthorized person to send public tweets with racial slurs and curse words.

site_title: ST Engineering to showcase wide range of capabilities
summary: ST Engineering will showcase its wide range of aviation, defence, and smart city solutions at the Singapore Airshow 2020. The company will display new conceptual designs, including a lightweight economy class seat and an expandable lavatory, as well as models of engine nacelles and smart city technologies. Its defence cluster will feature the Hunter Armoured Fighting Vehicle and the MAK One Synthetic Training Environment, while its smart city cluster will highlight its CitySense suite of smart mobility solutions.

site_title: China turns to AI, data in fight against virus
summary: China is utilizing artificial intelligence (AI) and data tracking to combat the spread of the coronavirus, with several tech firms developing apps to identify travelers who have taken the same flights or trains as confirmed cases. Local authorities are also using flight and train data to track individuals, and robots have been deployed in public plazas to enforce mask-wearing. Fever detection systems using AI and infrared cameras are being trialled at public transport hubs, and some neighborhoods are prompting residents to scan QR codes to register their travel history and contact information.

site_title: World's happiest people seeking road to financial intelligence
summary: Finland, ranked as the world's happiest country, is launching a financial literacy strategy to help citizens manage their finances. The central bank aims to reduce household debt, which has doubled in the past two decades, by educating Finns on responsible spending and borrowing. The strategy will include digital tools and personal cash flow predictions to help individuals estimate their finances and make informed decisions. The goal is to improve financial discipline and reduce the number of people unable to pay their bills, currently at a record 7% of the population.

site_title: Cyclone nears Australia's west with heavy winds, risk of storm tide
summary: A tropical cyclone, Damien, is expected to make landfall in Western Australia's west coast near Port Hedland on Saturday, bringing heavy winds and a potentially hazardous storm tide. Category 3 storm Damien is forecast to bring winds of up to 220km/h, with residents in coastal areas urged to seek shelter. The cyclone's arrival coincides with severe fire warnings in Western Australia and torrential rains in eastern states, including New South Wales, which has seen heavy rainfall in nearly 20 years.

site_title: Army officer who testified at Trump impeachment loses White House job
summary: A US Army officer, Lieutenant Colonel Alexander Vindman, who testified at the House of Representatives impeachment hearings against President Donald Trump, was ousted from his job at the White House, according to his lawyer. The move was seen as an act of revenge by President Trump, who had previously stated he wanted Vindman removed. Vindman, who worked on the National Security Council, was escorted out of the White House on Friday.

site_title: UK's Raab wants 'ambitious' Japan trade deal, Tokyo seeks end to Fukushima restrictions
summary: UK Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab discussed an "ambitious" trade deal with Japan, aiming to match the EU-Japan Economic Partnership agreement. Japan wants Britain to lift import restrictions on Japanese food and products imposed after the Fukushima nuclear disaster. Raab also sought to ease Japanese concerns about trade friction with the rest of Europe. The meeting comes as Britain negotiates its future relationship with the EU and begins free trade talks with other major economies.

site_title: Japan confirms 3 more coronavirus cases on cruise liner; total now 64
summary: Japan has confirmed 64 cases of coronavirus on a cruise liner, with 41 new cases reported on Friday. The infected individuals are being transferred to hospitals on land. The ship, the Diamond Princess, has been placed on a two-week quarantine since its arrival in Yokohama on February 3. The total number of cases from the ship is now 64, bringing the total infections in mainland China to over 34,000.

site_title: Coronavirus: S'pore bans 4 work pass holders, suspends privileges of 6 employers over LOA breach
summary: Singapore has banned four work pass holders and suspended privileges of six employers for breaching the leave of absence (LOA) requirements due to the coronavirus. The work pass holders were permanently banned from working in Singapore, while the employers had their privileges suspended for two years. The Ministry of Manpower had introduced the mandatory 14-day LOA for work pass holders with recent travel history to mainland China.

site_title: US offers US$100m to China, others to fight coronavirus
summary: The US is offering up to $100 million to China and other countries to combat the coronavirus, according to Secretary of State Mike Pompeo. This commitment, combined with private sector donations, demonstrates strong US leadership in response to the outbreak.

site_title: Three new coronavirus cases confirmed in Singapore
summary: Singapore has confirmed three new coronavirus cases, bringing the total number of infected individuals to 43. Six people are now in critical condition, up from four previously, with four having recovered. The new cases include a 71-year-old grandfather, a 39-year-old Bangladeshi worker, and a 54-year-old Singaporean man with no known links to previous cases or recent travel to China.

site_title: Hard work key to Koufu CEO's success
summary: Entrepreneur Pang Lim, CEO of SGX-listed food and beverage operator Koufu Group Ltd, attributes his success to hard work and continuous evolution. Dropping out of school at 13, he worked as a hawker and progressed to operating coffee shops and food courts. In the late 1980s, he capitalized on the trend of air-conditioned food courts and expanded Koufu Group, which now has a presence in Singapore, Macau, Malaysia, and Indonesia. With a focus on efficiency, technology, and talent development, Pang aims to maintain Koufu's competitive edge and drive growth, with plans to expand its domestic footprint and enter new markets.

site_title: China allocates 71.9b yuan to fight coronavirus
summary: China has allocated 71.85 billion yuan (S$14.3 billion) to fight the coronavirus, with funds to be used for diagnosis and treatment, as well as to support small and medium-sized firms affected by the outbreak. The Hubei province will offer subsidies and cut costs for local firms, while the northern province of Hebei will keep schools shut until at least March 1. The State Council has also ordered workers in key industries to return to work in batches to minimize the risk of transmission, and to resume the production of vital food and medical supplies.

site_title: Global economy could catch cold from China's virus problems
summary: US stocks may experience more volatility this week as Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell testifies to Congress about the economic threat from the novel coronavirus. Despite a surge in stocks last week, investors' fear of a global pandemic has not dissipated, with the US economy at risk of a slowdown. The Fed warned that an epidemic could have "spillover effects" on the global economy, and shares of companies with direct exposure to China, such as airlines and luxury brands, were initially hit hard. However, the market's euphoria has turned to caution, with investors waiting for Powell's testimony to gauge the economic impact of the virus.

site_title: Japanese with suspected coronavirus infection dies in China
summary: A 60-year-old Japanese man with a suspected coronavirus infection died in a hospital in Wuhan, China. The cause of death was given as viral pneumonia, and Chinese authorities believe he was likely infected with the new coronavirus. If confirmed, this would be Japan's first victim of the outbreak.

site_title: Micro-Mechanics posts 14.4% rise in Q2 net profit of S$3.6m
summary: Micro-Mechanics Ltd, a semiconductor industry tool and parts manufacturer, posted a 14.4% increase in Q2 net profit to S$3.6 million, driven by higher revenue and improved gross profit margin. Revenue rose 7.4% to S$16.3 million, with sales in China, Singapore, Japan, and Taiwan offsetting lower sales in the Philippines, Malaysia, and European markets. The company attributed the growth to operational strategies, including automation and smart-factory initiatives, and a stabilizing global semiconductor industry.

site_title: Hong Kong starts quarantine for mainland China arrivals
summary: Hong Kong has implemented a mandatory two-week quarantine for anyone arriving from mainland China, with the majority expected to self-quarantine. Those without pre-arranged accommodation will be taken to temporary facilities. The quarantine aims to halt cross-border traffic while ensuring food and goods supplies remain available. Exemptions will be made for key jobs, and officials will conduct daily phone calls and spot checks. The measure is a drastic escalation of the city's efforts to contain the deadly new coronavirus, which has killed over 700 people in mainland China and infected over 34,000.

site_title: 'Game On' for Sentosa Golf Club to go green
summary: Sentosa Golf Club, voted the World's Best Golf Club, is launching a toolkit called "Game On" to promote sustainable practices in golf club and course operations. The model, developed by the club's general manager, aims to reduce golf's carbon footprint and combat climate change. The club has already implemented various eco-friendly initiatives, such as removing plastic bottles from golf carts, using energy-efficient air-conditioning, and introducing bee-keeping practices. The "Game On" toolkit will be available for free download in March and targets the global golf community to adopt sustainable practices.

images.alt_text: SGC is taking the lead in becoming one of the most recognised eco-friendly golf facilities, and soon it will produce a toolkit - named "Game On" - for other clubs to follow suit using best practices for environmental sustainability in golf club and golf course operations.

site_title: Nations may bicker, but green investments are turning into greenbacks for firms
summary: Green investments are yielding financial returns for firms, with some hoping this can help save the planet. A transformation in green finance is underway, with banks and trading houses investing in environmentally friendly projects. This shift is expected to bring profitable opportunities for companies and governments. The article does not provide a specific date for the transformation but highlights the growing importance of green investments in the financial sector.

site_title: Renault to halt output at South Korean unit due to China supply disruptions
summary: Renault's South Korean subsidiary RSM will suspend production at its Busan site for four days starting February 11 due to supply chain disruptions in China caused by the coronavirus outbreak. The Busan unit produces the Nissan Rogue SUV, and Renault is working closely with Nissan to address the issue. This decision follows Renault's extension of a shutdown at its factory in Wuhan, China until February 13. The disruptions also impact Fiat Chrysler's European plants, with potential production threats within two to four weeks.

site_title: Lockheed Martin drops out of Singapore Airshow over coronavirus concerns
summary: Lockheed Martin has dropped out of the upcoming Singapore Airshow due to coronavirus concerns. The US weapons maker decided not to participate in the event after consulting with the US government and medical teams, citing the best interest of its employees. This decision aligns with the US Department of Defense's decision to reduce its presence at the airshow. The Singapore Ministry of Health had declared a Code Orange health alert on February 7, prompting Lockheed Martin's decision.

site_title: China turns to AI, data in fight against virus
summary: China is utilizing data tracking and artificial intelligence to combat the spread of the coronavirus, with authorities using flight and train data to identify potential cases. Apps and robots have been developed to track individuals' travel history, and fever detection systems using AI and infrared cameras are being trialed at public transport hubs. The National Health Commission has urged local governments to share data on train, flight, and medical records to enhance epidemic control efforts, with some neighborhoods requiring residents to scan a QR code to fill out personal details and track their travel history.

site_title: Treasury's Mnuchin sees US GDP growth less than 3% in 2020
summary: Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin expects US GDP growth to be less than 3% in 2020, citing issues at Boeing, which has halted production of its 737 MAX planes. This is partly due to the impact on exports, making the US the largest exporter. Mnuchin's revised projection is attributed to Boeing's problems and other factors.

site_title: Europe: Shares end best week since 2018 on weak footing
summary: European shares ended the week on a weak note, falling 0.26% on Friday after underwhelming earnings reports and concerns over the coronavirus outbreak. Despite a strong week, the Stoxx 600 index recorded its best weekly gain since November 2018, driven by China's efforts to limit the outbreak's impact. Key sectors such as mining, healthcare, and luxury were among the biggest decliners, while some companies like L'Oreal and Yara International posted better-than-expected earnings.

site_title: Have multi-currency account, will travel?: How far will new multi-currency players go in the payments game?
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The rise of multi-currency e-wallets is transforming the payments landscape, offering travelers and shoppers lower fees and greater transparency. Players like Revolut, Transferwise, and YouTrip have gained popularity, with Revolut amassing over 50,000 users in Singapore and Transferwise processing S$1.7 billion in transactions annually. Despite the growth, banks are unlikely to compete intensely, as the retail payment business is low-margin. Fintechs must achieve scale and presence in major remittance corridors to sustain profitability, with Transferwise being the exception by generating profits from its international digital remittance arm.

site_title: Global warming to blame for hottest day in Argentine Antarctica
summary: Argentina's research station Esperanza base in Antarctica recorded its hottest day since 1961, with a temperature of 18.3°C, attributed to global warming. The previous record stood at 17.5°C in 2015. The extreme weather is part of a decade of record temperatures globally, with 2020 being the second-hottest year on record. The effects of global warming include rising ocean levels, with the Thwaites glacier, one of the largest in Antarctica, contributing to a potential 65cm sea-level rise if it melts.

site_title: Fed faces housing conundrum
summary: The US Federal Reserve faces a housing conundrum as housing permits and pending home sales have dipped, raising concerns about affordability. Despite a strong fourth-quarter GDP, the decline in building permits and pending home sales, and rising mortgage rates, pose challenges for the Fed. Affordability, which was artificially repressed by low interest rates, is a major issue, and a slowing economy could exacerbate the problem. The Fed may need to consider a rate cut to boost the housing market, but a rising jobless rate could have the opposite effect.

site_title: Oil falls 1% as Russia needs time to mull more Opec+ supply cuts
summary: Oil prices fell 1% on Friday as Russia said it needed more time to assess the possibility of output cuts sought by other Opec+ producers. The coronavirus outbreak has led to weaker consumption figures and lower demand expectations, with forecasters predicting a contraction in oil demand in China of up to 3 million bpd in the first quarter. Despite a panel advising Opec+ to cut 600,000 barrels per day, Russia Energy Minister Alexander Novak expressed uncertainty, contributing to the decline in oil prices.

site_title: From Disneyland to Christmas Island: Unlikely but possible quarantine sites
summary: Governments worldwide are exploring unconventional quarantine sites to combat the novel coronavirus outbreak, including Disneyland, Christmas Island, cruise ships, training centres, public housing, military bases, and sanatoriums. As the virus continues to spread globally, with over 28,000 infected and 563 deaths in mainland China, these sites aim to provide secure and remote isolation for suspected carriers. The use of such unusual locations highlights the unprecedented measures being taken to contain the outbreak.

site_title: Construction costs of Canada pipeline to Pacific soar
summary: Canada's Trans Mountain pipeline project has seen its construction costs jump 70% to US$9.5 billion due to design changes, regulatory processes, and environmental activist protests. The project, which would transport 890,000 barrels of oil daily from Alberta to the Pacific coast, was initially estimated at US$5.6 billion. Finance Minister Bill Morneau says the project remains commercially viable, but Greenpeace and indigenous tribes dispute the cost and environmental impact. A federal court recently denied their bid to block construction, but they plan to appeal to the Supreme Court.

images.alt_text: The cost of constructing a government-owned pipeline to the Pacific coast that would open new overseas markets for Canadian oil has jumped 70 per cent, the management company announced Friday.

site_title: Harry, Meghan in first joint event since leaving royal fold
summary: Prince Harry and his wife Meghan, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, attended a JPMorgan Chase event in Miami, marking their first joint public engagement since leaving the British royal family. The couple stepped back from royal duties last month to pursue financial independence.

site_title: France's Total rejects force majeure notice from Chinese LNG buyer
summary: French oil major Total has rejected a force majeure notice from a Chinese LNG buyer, becoming the first global energy supplier to publicly push back against firms backing out of deals amid the coronavirus outbreak. Total's head, Philippe Sauquet, stated that some Chinese customers are trying to use the coronavirus to claim force majeure, but the company has rejected at least one such notice. This move is seen as a sign that Total is committed to meeting its contractual obligations despite the challenges posed by the pandemic.

site_title: Shares slide 6% after Sembcorp flags S$245m impairment
summary: Sembcorp Industries (SCI) announced a S$245 million impairment, mainly due to a write-down of its UK Power Reserve (UKPR) assets. The impairment is attributed to increased energy capacity in the UK and reduced demand. Despite this, the energy business is expected to be profitable for the full year, but the conglomerate will report a net loss for the fourth quarter. Analysts have mixed reactions, with some downgrading their forecasts and others maintaining a "hold" call.

site_title: Reits (February 8-9, 2020)
summary: Realtors and investors are tracking the real estate market, with key events including record-high Manhattan rents, a rebound in UK homebuyer demand, and a Q3 wave of condo launches in Singapore. Notable transactions include Goldman's acquisition of Seoul hotel and retail assets, and New World's sale of China property assets. Additionally, US mortgage rates have started to climb after five weeks of declines, and WeWork has secured new tenants at 21 Collyer Quay. These developments indicate a shift in market trends and investor sentiment in the global real estate sector.

site_title: Coronavirus death toll soars to 717: official
summary: China's coronavirus death toll has risen to 717, surpassing the 2002-2003 Sars outbreak that killed nearly 650 people. Hubei province reported 81 new fatalities and 2,841 new cases, marking a significant increase. This development highlights the growing severity of the outbreak, which emerged in December.

images.alt_text: The number of deaths from China's new coronavirus epidemic jumped to 717 on Saturday after hard-hit Hubei province reported 81 new fatalities.

site_title: Family or job? Tough decisions for Hong Kong border commuters
summary: Hong Kong authorities have implemented a 14-day mandatory quarantine for anyone crossing from mainland China due to the spread of a deadly coronavirus, significantly reducing cross-border travel. Tens of thousands of people, including Hong Kongers living in mainland China, are facing tough decisions on whether to stay with family or return to work. The quarantine has brought economic and social uncertainty, with many fearing job losses and separation from loved ones, as the border, once a hub for daily commutes, is now largely closed.

site_title: Firms with large China operations can apply to SGX to defer audited results
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has granted a two-month extension for listed firms with significant China operations to defer audited results due to the novel coronavirus outbreak. Companies with a Dec 31, 2019, financial year-end and affected by travel restrictions can apply for the extension, which allows them to hold annual general meetings (AGMs) by June 30, 2020. Issuers must still release unaudited financial statements by Feb 29, 2020, and obtain approval from the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) or other relevant authorities.

site_title: Trump's election trump card: a healthy economy
summary: US President Donald Trump's re-election bid is bolstered by the country's strong economy, which has continued to expand despite his first three years in office. The unemployment rate stands at 3.6%, with job growth averaging 175,000 jobs per month, and average hourly earnings increasing 2.9%. However, the economy has fallen short of Trump's promises, and growth slowed to 2.3% last year due to the trade war with China. The IMF predicts further slowdown this year, and the budget deficit is projected to breach $1 trillion by the end of September.

site_title: New coronavirus infected 40 staff in single Wuhan hospital: study
summary: A new study found that 40 staff at a Wuhan hospital were infected with the novel coronavirus by patients in January, with one patient presumed to have infected 10 healthcare workers. Seventeen patients and 138 total cases were infected, with hospital-associated transmission accounting for 41% of cases. The study highlights the risks to healthcare workers and underscores the need for better protective gear. The findings come as a Chinese doctor who raised alarm about the virus died from the pathogen, sparking grief and anger over the worsening crisis.

images.alt_text: Forty healthcare workers were infected with the novel coronavirus by patients at a single Wuhan hospital in January, a new study has found, underscoring the risks to those at the frontlines of the growing epidemic.

site_title: Credit Suisse CEO Thiam exits in shock reversal after scandal
summary: Credit Suisse CEO Tidjane Thiam is resigning after a damaging spying scandal, despite being backed by key shareholders. Thiam, who led the bank's turnaround efforts, will be replaced by Thomas Gottstein, a 20-year veteran of the bank. Chairman Urs Rohner has the board's unanimous backing to complete his term until April 2021. The scandal led to Thiam's departure in a shocking reversal, with top shareholders urging Rohner to back Thiam or step down.

site_title: Virus anxiety returns on Friday but STI ends 0.9% up on week
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 50.07 points or 1.6% on Friday, its second-largest single-day drop this year, as investors returned to worrying about the implications of the fast-spreading coronavirus.
