summary: Global companies are responding to the coronavirus outbreak by implementing various measures to mitigate its impact. Airlines such as Air Canada, Air France, and Delta have cancelled flights to China, while travel and tourism sectors have been severely affected. Electronics companies like Apple and LG Electronics have also been impacted, with Foxconn's Chinese factories closed until mid-February. Automakers like Hyundai Motor and Tesla have suspended production due to supply chain disruptions. Meanwhile, some companies like 3M are taking advantage of the situation by increasing production of protective face masks.

site_title: Trump impeachment a 'colossal' mistake by Democrats: top Republican
summary: Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell says the Democratic Party's failed impeachment effort against President Donald Trump was a "colossal political mistake" that will benefit Republicans. The Senate voted along party lines to acquit Trump of abuse of power and obstruction of Congress. McConnell believes the Democrats' move will harm their chances in the 2020 election and give Republicans an advantage in the short term.

images.alt_text: The Democratic Party's failed effort to impeach and remove President Donald Trump was a major political miscalculation likely to benefit Republicans, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said Wednesday.

site_title: Money FM podcast: How data will be the competitive advantage for SMEs
summary: A Money FM podcast discusses how data will be a competitive advantage for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in the digital economy. Managing director of Xero Asia, Kevin Fitzgerald, shares insights on how SMEs can leverage data to gain a competitive edge. The conversation highlights the importance of data-driven decision-making and analytics in driving business growth.

site_title: British commercial property back on the investment map
summary: Investors expect to invest billions of pounds in UK commercial real estate this year, citing improved Brexit clarity after the Conservative party's election victory in December. Companies such as LaSalle Investment Management and Madison International Realty plan to spend £1 billion and pursue several transactions, respectively. Overseas investors, including Dutch developer Breevast and US duo CA Ventures and Invesco Real Estate, see opportunities in Britain. However, uncertainties over trade deal negotiations and global economic factors may weigh on UK property.

site_title: Europe: Shares boosted by earnings, progress on coronavirus treatment
summary: European shares rose 1.2% on Wednesday, driven by upbeat earnings from companies like Novo Nordisk, Valmet, and Infineon. The Stoxx 600 index is now just 0.3% shy of record highs. The rally follows a recent virus outbreak in China, which had sent markets into a tailspin. Investors are cautiously optimistic about the potential for a coronavirus treatment, boosting shares in the region.

site_title: HNWIs in IPOs can turn from cornerstone to Tower of Babel
summary: High net worth individuals (HNWIs) are increasingly taking on a larger role in cornerstone investments for real estate investment trusts (Reits) in initial public offerings (IPOs), surpassing traditional institutional investors. This shift is attributed to HNWIs' ability to provide liquidity and their willingness to invest in foreign Reits. To mitigate the risks associated with this trend, regulators may consider implementing lock-up periods for cornerstone investors, including private banking and wealth management clients, to ensure more disciplined investing behaviors and protect retail investors' interests.

site_title: Singapore shares edge up at open tracking Wall Street rally; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Thursday, tracking a Wall Street rally, with the Straits Times Index gaining 0.47% to 3,215.24. Gainers outnumbered losers 82 to 23, with BlackGold Natural Resources and Rex International leading the gains. Banking stocks also rose, with DBS, United Overseas Bank, and OCBC Bank increasing 0.9%, 0.2%, and 0.7% respectively. The rally followed strong US jobs data and waning fears on the coronavirus outbreak, with the S&P 500 closing at a record high.

site_title: Brazil central bank cuts interest rate to record low
summary: Brazil's central bank cut its benchmark interest rate to a record low of 4.25% to boost the country's economy, which is experiencing a "gradual recovery." This is the fifth consecutive decrease in the interest rate, following a loosening cycle that started in July 2020. The decision aims to stimulate economic growth in the largest economy in Latin America.

site_title: Malaysian journalist charged over coronavirus posts
summary: A Malaysian journalist, Wan Noor Hayati Wan Alias, was charged with causing public alarm with Facebook posts about the coronavirus outbreak in China. The posts allegedly spread misinformation about a cruise ship arriving in Malaysia, despite officials having assured passengers had undergone medical examinations. The journalist faces up to two years in prison if found guilty. Attorney-General Tommy Thomas warned against "rumour-mongering" and said lies about the virus could endanger public safety, as Malaysia has a sensitive multi-ethnic population.

site_title: Ex-OCBC consumer finance head takes CEO spot at Prudential Singapore
summary: Dennis Tan, a 51-year-old banking veteran, has been appointed CEO of Prudential Singapore, expanding the club of Singaporeans leading major financial institutions. Tan joins from OCBC, where he was head of consumer finance services and executive vice-president before resigning late last year. He will take over once regulatory approvals are obtained. Tan's appointment comes as Prudential Singapore invests in technology and artificial intelligence to boost preventative healthcare, and follows recent appointments of Singaporean leaders at AIA and Ping An Insurance.

site_title: iPhone maker Hon Hai cuts 2020 outlook following virus outbreak
summary: Hon Hai Precision Industry Co, Apple's main production partner, cut its 2020 revenue growth outlook to 1-3% due to the potential impact of a deadly coronavirus outbreak. The company's chairman, Liu Young, made the announcement following the assessment of the outbreak's effect on production and consumer demand. This reduction in forecast lags the 5.4% average of analysts' projections. The outbreak is expected to disrupt Apple's production chain, dampen consumer demand, and overall economic growth, particularly in China.

site_title: Pompeo to pay first visit to Africa
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo will visit sub-Saharan Africa from February 15-19, focusing on security and economic partnerships with Senegal, Angola, and Ethiopia. He will meet with President Macky Sall in Senegal, support democracy and anti-corruption efforts in Angola, and discuss Ethiopia's reform agenda with Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed. The trip comes two years after his predecessor, Rex Tillerson, and follows Pompeo's talks in Saudi Arabia and Oman after a US-ordered strike.

site_title: Trump considers withdrawing from WTO's US$1.7t purchasing pact
summary: The US is considering withdrawing from the World Trade Organization's Government Procurement Agreement, a pact worth $1.7 trillion, unless it is reformed to align with American views. This move would create chaos for foreign companies bidding on US government contracts and complicate trade talks with the UK and EU. A US withdrawal would also affect Canada, which is still ratifying the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement. The decision fits President Trump's pattern of using threats to increase leverage in negotiations, despite close ties with allies.

site_title: Ford posts Q4 loss, gives disappointing 2020 outlook
summary: Ford Motor Co posted a Q4 loss of $1.7 billion, or 42 cents a share, despite a 5% revenue increase to $39.7 billion. The company lowered its 2020 forecast, citing higher warranty costs, lower profits at its credit arm, and investments in future technology. Ford's CEO, Jim Hackett, emphasized the need for the company to change and adapt to the changing market, while maintaining a quarterly dividend of 15 cents. The disappointing forecast is a blow to Hackett, who has been asking investors to be patient with the company's restructuring efforts.

site_title: More Baby Yoda? The Mandalorian's back in October with spin-offs in the works
summary: Disney plans to release the second season of The Mandalorian in October, with potential spin-offs in the works, according to Disney CEO Bob Iger. The live-action Star Wars series was a hit on Disney+, thanks to its character Baby Yoda, who has become a viral sensation. Iger hinted at more Baby Yoda content and the possibility of standalone series featuring the character. The priority for Star Wars in the next few years is television, with previously announced shows including the return of Ewan McGregor as Obi-Wan Kenobi and a Rogue One prequel.

site_title: Australia could intervene to loosen Visa, Mastercard grip on tap-and-go payments
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) is considering intervening to stop banks from directing "tap-and-go" card payments through Visa and Mastercard, instead using cheaper EFTPOS options. Governor Philip Lowe stated that banks must give retailers the option to use EFTPOS, reducing costs. This move aims to promote competition and reduce fees for consumers.

site_title: The end of Iowa as the bellwether state?
summary: The Iowa Democratic caucuses have raised questions about the state's disproportionate influence in presidential nominations. For decades, Iowa's caucus results have been a crucial indicator of a candidate's viability, with only those finishing first, second, or third in the caucuses winning the nomination. However, the 2020 Iowa caucuses were marred by technical issues and chaos, potentially undermining the state's significance. The outcome suggests a long and contentious primary season, with no clear frontrunner, and may lead to a "Stop Bernie" movement, potentially supporting alternative candidates like Michael Bloomberg.

images.alt_text: The mess in Iowa would probably reinforce Americans' declining confidence in the integrity of their elections and the legitimacy of the winners.

site_title: In political triumph, Trump acquitted of all impeachment charges
summary: US President Donald Trump was acquitted by the Senate on impeachment charges of abuse of power and obstruction of Congress, winning 52-48 and 53-47 votes respectively. Despite strong evidence, Republicans stayed loyal, falling short of the two-thirds supermajority required for conviction. Trump's acquittal clears a major hurdle for his re-election campaign in November, with many Democrats dejected but not surprised by the outcome.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump drew on staunch Republican support on Wednesday to defeat the gravest threat yet to his three-year-old presidency, winning acquittal in the Senate on impeachment charges of abuse of power and obstruction of Congress.

site_title: Singapore confirms 4 new cases, including 6-month-old baby
summary: Singapore confirmed 4 new cases of the coronavirus, including a 6-month-old baby, bringing the total to 28. The cases are linked to local transmission and an imported case from Wuhan. The World Health Organization (WHO) has downplayed reports of breakthrough treatments, stating that no effective therapeutics exist and further testing is needed. The earliest human trials of a new coronavirus vaccine are expected by June this year.

site_title: US political season opens, and tribal warfare continues in Washington
summary: US President Donald Trump's impeachment trial is set to conclude, potentially leading to a temporary ceasefire between Republicans and Democrats. However, the start of the 2024 presidential race may reignite tribal warfare, with intense ideological and social divisions likely to continue and worsen. The country's political polarization, intensified under Trump, has paralyzed legislation and policy-making in Washington, with deep divisions between Democrats and Republicans now resembling a "cold civil war."

site_title: Newly-emboldened Trump gives Democrats reason to fret
summary: US President Donald Trump delivered a State of the Union speech with approval ratings on the upswing, making an acquittal in impeachment proceedings likely. His approval ratings have reached 49%, the highest since taking office. Trump appealed to suburban voters, highlighting bipartisan accomplishments and pledging to protect entitlement programs. He also warned of free healthcare for undocumented immigrants and reinforced his stance on immigration. Despite the impeachment trial, Trump remained confident, with some Democrats fretting that he may be peaking at the right time.

site_title: Prolonged China factory closures to weigh on Singapore firms' earnings
summary: Singapore-listed companies with manufacturing plants in China are expected to be negatively impacted by the prolonged closures due to the novel coronavirus outbreak. Analysts predict earnings to drop by 10% for companies like Hi-P and Fu Yu, which have at least half their facilities in China, while firms with smaller proportions may see a 3-5% decline. The closures are likely to strain supply chains, but companies with diversified businesses are better equipped to weather the crisis.

site_title: Singapore factories simply can't afford to let their lights go out
summary: Singapore's semiconductor manufacturing sector has gained recognition, with two multinationals' sites receiving World Economic Forum's exemplary factory status. The industry is seen as crucial to Singapore's manufacturing sector, and there is hope for homegrown companies to follow suit.

images.alt_text: The Singapore premises of American chipmaker Micron and Munich-based Infineon joined the ranks of the 44 factories in the WEF's Global Lighthouse Network earlier this year.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: GS Holdings has not received 120 million yuan (S$23.5 million) in outstanding gross service fees from 14 Chinese food and beverage outlets due to ongoing tax consultations. The fees were due on Dec 31, 2019. The company's subsidiary Wish Hospitality Holdings provides branding and procurement services for the outlets, with an aggregate quarterly service fee of 50 million yuan. The delay is expected to impact GS Holdings' third quarter financial results, particularly from its China operations.

site_title: Infineon's digitalisation cuts labour costs, raises capital efficiency
summary: Infineon Technologies, a German electronics company, has successfully implemented its digital transformation plan in Singapore, resulting in a 30% reduction in direct labor costs and a 15% improvement in capital efficiency. The company achieved this through investments in a digital backbone and people development, according to the World Economic Forum's Global Lighthouse Network.

site_title: San Francisco's Transamerica tower to be sold to New York developer
summary: The Transamerica Pyramid in San Francisco is set to be sold to a group led by New York developer Michael Shvo for approximately $700 million. The deal comes after the building's owner, Transamerica, failed to attract buyers due to European accounting standards and ultimately decided to pursue an outright sale. The sale will be Michael Shvo's latest landmark property, expanding his portfolio of high-end properties worth over $3 billion.

site_title: Car COE prices tumble as virus outbreak takes toll
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) prices for cars and motorcycles have dropped due to the coronavirus crisis. The latest tender saw declines in COE prices for all categories, with the sharpest falls in recent memory. The car COE price for up to 1,600cc and 130bhp finished at S$30,010, down from S$35,010 two weeks ago. Motor industry watchers predict prices will remain dampened in the near term, but some see a potential increase in car sales as fears of contamination grow.

site_title: What Libra means for central banks, commercial banks and the economy
summary: Central banks have expressed concerns over Facebook's Libra digital currency, citing its potential to disrupt the creation of money and threaten the role of commercial banks in modern economies. Libra's digital nature could force banks to reduce loans and overdrafts, leading to a major credit squeeze and economic damage. Central banks have no easy solution, as relaxing reserve requirements or issuing loans themselves could weaken banks and risk bank insolvencies. Additionally, Libra's revenue model, potentially based on usage charges, raises questions about efficiency and value for money, and whether it would be cheaper and more beneficial to the society than the existing bank-based system.

site_title: Credit Suisse joins others in scrapping events
summary: Credit Suisse scrapped its annual Asia investment conference due to the ongoing coronavirus outbreak, joining a string of cancellations or delays in Hong Kong and China. The Zurich-based private bank had planned the event for March 25-27 at Hong Kong's Conrad Hotel. The decision marks the biggest cancellation in Hong Kong's financial industry since the outbreak. Several other conferences have been postponed or cancelled, including the AVCJ China Forum and Fitch Ratings' Credit Outlook 2020 Conference.

site_title: Faster, better with smart factory tools at Micron
summary: Micron Technology, a US-based chipmaker, has successfully implemented smart factory tools in its Singapore operations, resulting in twice the production speed and a 10% increase in staff productivity. The company utilizes automated wafer testing, image screening, and joint data analysis to optimize processes. This move is part of Micron's Industry 4.0 strategy to boost unit-cost competitiveness and bring new products to market faster. The Singapore fab, recognized by the World Economic Forum's Global Lighthouse Network, will continue to play a key role in Micron's operations.

site_title: 282 shareholders to receive nothing under LifeBrandz's 50:1 share consolidation
summary: LifeBrandz, a Singapore-based company, will consolidate its shares 50-to-1, resulting in 282 shareholders holding fewer than 50 shares being left with nothing. The move aims to reduce volatility and fluctuations in the company's market capitalization. LifeBrandz will also raise funds through a rights issue to repay advances from two major shareholders. The company's executive chairman and CEO, Saito Hiroyuki, will not abstain from voting at the upcoming extraordinary general meeting, citing similar arrangements in the market.

site_title: Building an EU-UK special relationship
summary: The European Union has lost a significant member state with the UK's departure, but it will still remain a premier economic power. Negotiating a trade agreement is crucial, but the outcome will not determine the UK's economic fate. The EU has more pressing issues, such as the European Green Deal, and the UK's participation in this area could be beneficial. The EU's efforts to complete the euro zone and Schengen area may put it and the UK on diverging paths. The UK could establish a special relationship with the EU, leveraging its strengths in security and intelligence, but this will require a good-faith effort from both parties.

site_title: 11 freehold commercial units at Balestier Point for sale at S$68m
summary: A portfolio of 11 freehold commercial units at Balestier Point in Singapore is up for sale at S$68 million. The units range from 269 to 5,609 sq ft and can be bought individually or collectively. The portfolio represents 31.7% of the share value within Balestier Point and offers potential uses such as restaurants, cafes, and showrooms. Foreigners and companies are eligible to purchase, with no buyer's or seller's stamp duty applicable. The expression of interest exercise will close on March 17.

site_title: Manulife US Reit Q4 DPU slips 5.9% to 1.44 US cents on enlarged unit base
summary: Manulife US Reit reported a 5.9% decline in its fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.44 US cents due to an enlarged unit base following a placement and preferential offering to fund its US$198.8 million acquisition of 400 Capitol Mall. Gross revenue increased 20.4% to US$48.8 million, driven by contributions from newly acquired properties. Net property income (NPI) grew 18.9% to US$30.3 million, while distributable income climbed 15.5% to US$22.6 million.

site_title: Troubled Ezra Holdings files for judicial management
summary: Ezra Holdings, a troubled offshore and marine group, has filed an application for judicial management in Singapore's High Court. The move comes after the company received a statutory demand from creditors and its subsidiaries have been placed under judicial management or liquidated. A moratorium will be in place until the application is granted or dismissed, preventing any steps to enforce security over its property. This follows Ezra's Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection filing in the US in 2017.

site_title: When innovation in space boosts development on earth
summary: Innovation in space is driving development on Earth, particularly in addressing global concerns such as climate change, personal mobility, and healthcare. Satellites provide global, uniform, and sustained data, enabling monitoring of environmental changes, tracking of greenhouse gases, and mitigation of natural disasters. Space technology is also fueling the development of various services, including satellite navigation, tele-epidemiology, and augmented medical solutions. International cooperation, such as the Space Climate Observatory and partnerships between space agencies and businesses, is key to harnessing the potential of NewSpace and promoting sustainable development.

site_title: China stimulus boosts market sentiment
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,200.13, up 43.56 points or 1.4%, boosted by China's central bank stimulus efforts to combat the economic effects of the coronavirus. Regional bourses also saw gains, with Asia's manufacturing and services data indicating economic resilience. However, uncertainty remains over the virus, with investors weighing the potential for "peak virus" or "peak optimism".

site_title: More MICE events, including hotel-F&B trade show, postponed
summary: Several events in Singapore's MICE sector have been postponed due to the evolving novel coronavirus situation. FHA-HoReCa, a hotel-F&B trade show, has been rescheduled from March 3-6 to July 13-16. The Bloomberg Intelligence Singapore Outlook 2020 event and the Sustainable Business Summit Singapore 2020 have also been postponed or cancelled. Meanwhile, healthcare event CAREhab 2020 has been rescheduled to July 10-11, while the National Association of Travel Agents Singapore's annual travel fair has been postponed to May. Movie theatres are also feeling the impact, with attendance declining in the days following the Chinese New Year period.

site_title: BNP Paribas chalks up 63% rise in Q4 trading revenue
summary: BNP Paribas reported a 63% increase in Q4 trading revenue to €820 million, surpassing European rivals and matching US banks such as Goldman Sachs. The French bank's fixed-income trading revenue rebounded from a year earlier, with equity and prime services revenue also increasing. Despite net income missing analyst estimates, the bank's revenue rose 11.5% and common equity Tier 1 ratio increased by 10 basis points. The bank is targeting business growth across its divisions and cost reductions, with a 10% return on tangible equity target for 2020.

site_title: US service sector growth picks up in January
summary: US services sector activity increased to a reading of 55.5 in January, the highest level since August, indicating moderate economic growth. The index, which accounts for over two-thirds of the economy, rose from 54.9 in December. A rebound in manufacturing, driven by easing trade tensions, is expected to continue, but Boeing's 737 MAX production suspension and the coronavirus outbreak may disrupt supply chains. The economy grew 2.3% last year, the slowest since 2016.

site_title: Cathay Pacific asks employees to take unpaid leave as virus hits demand
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways has asked its 27,000 employees to take three weeks of unpaid leave due to the novel coronavirus outbreak, citing grave conditions similar to the 2009 financial crisis. The airline is also implementing measures to preserve cash, including hiring freezes, price reductions with suppliers, and stopping non-critical spending. Chief executive Augustus Tang made the announcement in a video message to staff.

site_title: Twitter moves to target fake videos, photos
summary: Twitter will more aggressively scrutinize fake or altered photos and videos, starting in March. The company will add labels or take down tweets carrying manipulated images and videos, balancing parody and disinformation removal. To determine removal or labeling, Twitter will apply tests on the content's intent and impact. Tweets likely to harm public safety or cause serious harm will be taken down, while others will receive warnings or limited reach. Twitter developed its rules after surveying over 6,500 users, with 70% believing manipulated content should be removed or labeled.

site_title: Hospitality S-Reits, integrated resorts most exposed to fallout from outbreak: Moody's
summary: Moody's Investors Service predicts Singapore's gaming sector and hospitality Reits will be severely impacted by the novel coronavirus outbreak, as they generate most of their revenue from foreign visitors. Tourist arrivals are expected to fall significantly, leading to declines in gaming revenues at integrated resorts like Marina Bay Sands and Resorts World Sentosa. Hospitality Reits such as Frasers Hospitality Trust and Ascott Residence Trust are expected to have sufficient liquidity to weather the downturn, but analysts have downgraded their calls on other Reits.

site_title: India guards against virus at coming car show dominated by China firms
summary: India is hosting the Motor Show 2020, dominated by Chinese carmakers showcasing electric vehicles and connected cars. However, no Chinese officials will attend, with booths staffed only by Indian employees and representatives. Chinese companies SAIC Motor Corp, Great Wall Motor Co, and FAW Haima will showcase their cars, while over 300 Chinese car-parts companies participate. The event comes as India identifies a third positive case of the virus, with Siam and Acma taking precautions to ensure visitor safety.

site_title: Shadow CEO apologises for app glitch
summary: Shadow CEO Gerard Niemira apologized for a technical glitch in the company's app used for the Iowa Democratic Party's primary, which delayed the transmission of results data into the party's data warehouse. The bug caused problems with the app's transmission to the data warehouse, leading to delays and confusion. The Iowa Democratic Party's chairman confirmed that the underlying data collected via the app was sound, but the reporting system had a coding issue. The issue was fixed, and partial results were released. The incident raised questions about the role of technology in vote tabulation and whether Shadow's technology was suitable for election-related work.

site_title: Singdollar can ease without any off-cycle action by MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has indicated that there is room for the Singdollar to ease without an off-cycle move, citing economic weakness from the 2019 novel coronavirus outbreak. The central bank reaffirmed its monetary policy stance, but noted that the Singdollar has been trading in the top half of its policy band and may need to weaken to provide offset to the economic impact. Analysts now expect the Singdollar to reposition at a more neutral level, potentially weakening to 1.40 against the US dollar by end-March.

site_title: The way forward for GST hike in Singapore as funding needs rise
summary: Singapore plans to hike its Goods and Services Tax (GST) by two percentage points from 7% to 9% between 2021 and 2025, raising additional revenues of almost 0.7% of the country's GDP per year. The government aims to enhance the permanent GST Voucher scheme to support Singaporeans coping with the rate change, with details to be shared in the upcoming Budget announcement on Feb 18. The new support package is expected to include measures similar to the 2007 GST Offset Package, which cost S$4 billion over five years.

site_title: There's no place like Kangaroo Island. Can it survive Australia's wildfires?
summary: Kangaroo Island, a wildlife haven and tourism hub in Australia, has been devastated by weeks-long wildfires that consumed half of the island, killing two people and destroying homes and wildlife habitats. The fires, which raged from December to January, have left the island's economy and community reeling, with tourism operators and farmers struggling to recover. The island's revenue, split between tourism and agriculture, is expected to take a significant hit, with concerns about the long-term viability of the community. Despite the challenges, residents are determined to rebuild, but many fear the loss of people and the devastating impact on the island's unique ecosystem.

site_title: The future of food hangs on Asian innovation
summary: The future of food is poised to be shaped by Asian innovation, driven by the region's growing population, economic growth, and openness to technology. The global plant-based market is expected to triple from $10 billion in 2018 to $31 billion in 2026, with Asia leading the growth. Companies must leverage Asian consumers' high digital potential and openness to innovation to develop sustainable food solutions. Food-tech innovation can address existential challenges such as the carbon and water footprint of livestock agriculture and antibiotic resistance. By partnering with local food delivery and cloud kitchen operators, companies can gain insights into consumer preferences and iterate their products to meet the needs of the Asian market.

site_title: US private hiring surges to 291,000 in January: ADP
summary: US private companies hired 291,000 new employees in January, surpassing the consensus forecast and the largest gain since December 2014. The majority of the increase was in the services sector, while manufacturing also saw a relatively healthy gain. Economists expect the government employment data to be revised downward, citing mild winter weather as a factor in the January surge. The job growth is expected to cool, with economists predicting around 125,000 new hires per month for low and stable unemployment.

site_title: Hotel deals heat up across eastern Europe
summary: Hoteliers in eastern Europe are shifting focus to secondary cities outside saturated hubs like Prague and Warsaw, seeking higher returns. Major cities in Romania, Hungary, and Serbia are attracting developers and investors, with yields dropping close to levels in Germany. The region saw 4.2 billion euros in hotel deals in the past five years, with Poland and Romania being key markets due to strong domestic demand. International brands have ample room to expand, with the share of hotel chains currently at just 15% in Hungary and 6% in Serbia.

site_title: GM forecasts flat 2020 profit after a rough 2019
summary: General Motors (GM) forecasts flat profits for 2020, ranging from $5.75 to $6.25 per share, excluding one-time items. The company reported a better-than-expected fourth quarter result, despite a $3.6 billion hit from a 40-day United Auto Workers strike. Profits fell 20% in China due to slower adoption of new fuel-efficient technology. GM will restart idled operations in China "plant by plant" and expects the Chinese market to be volatile this year.

site_title: SGX RegCo expects timely, adequate disclosure of significant litigation
summary: Singapore's frontline market regulator, SGX RegCo, is serving notice to listed companies to make timely and adequate disclosure of significant litigation. The regulator emphasizes that companies must provide sufficient details to help investors understand the risks associated with the litigation. The disclosure must be made in a timely manner and avoid omitting or downplaying unfavorable facts. Companies are expected to assess whether the litigation is material enough to warrant disclosure, considering factors such as business operations, reputation, and financial performance.

site_title: Air cargo carriers not adding China flights as demand weak
summary: Major air cargo carriers have no immediate plans to add China flights due to weak demand amid the coronavirus. Over 25,000 fewer flights are expected to operate to, from, and within China this week compared to two weeks ago. Thirty airlines have halted services, with many factories remaining shut down after the Chinese New Year. This reduction in capacity is expected to impact the global air cargo industry, with half of belly cargo facing huge freight capacity cuts. The cuts are attributed to the decline in passenger travel and the resulting decrease in belly cargo demand.

images.alt_text: Air cargo represents less than one per cent of global trade by tonnage. Carriers report rising demand for medical supplies such as surgical masks although shipments of other goods had been delayed.

site_title: Alarm over BBC's future as UK proposes dropping compulsory subscription fee
summary: The UK government proposes dropping the compulsory subscription fee for the BBC, sparking concerns about the broadcaster's funding. Culture Secretary Nicky Morgan says removing prosecution for non-payment would "almost certainly" lead to a £200 million funding cut. The BBC had previously estimated this reduction. The move comes amidst tensions between the BBC and Prime Minister Boris Johnson's Conservative Party, with accusations of political bias. The BBC's licence fee model is set to remain until 2027, but the government is exploring alternative funding methods.

site_title: FSL swings back into black in Q4, proposes 1.5 US cents full-year DPU
summary: FIRST Ship Lease (FSL) Trust reported a net profit of US$3.5 million for Q4 2020, reversing a US$18.5 million loss in the same period last year, driven by improved charter rates. Revenue rose 19.8% to US$22.2 million, and net distributable amount stood at US$26.5 million. FSL proposed a full-year distribution of 1.5 US cents per unit, its first since 2012, with a focus on operating performance and vessel portfolio management in 2020.

site_title: 2-storey commercial podium at Oxley Rise condo for sale with S$62.5m indicative price
summary: A 2-storey commercial podium at 71 Oxley Rise in Singapore's Orchard Road shopping belt is up for sale with an indicative price of S$62.5 million. The podium, with 16,459 sq ft of strata area, has a 28% share value and 14 basement car park lots. It offers potential signage rights and a 4% gross yield in the first year to the buyer. The sale allows for repositioning and curating a tenant mix, and the property is expected to benefit from the authorities' rejuvenation efforts in the Dhoby Ghaut precinct.

site_title: Intel lures Israeli tech talent with smart buildings
summary: Intel is investing $11 billion in a manufacturing facility in Israel, aiming to compete for the country's top tech talent amid a shortage of skilled workers. The company's new development center in Petah Tikva features smart buildings with perks such as environmentally-friendly systems, a smart gym, and 14,000 sensors to monitor employee comfort. The move is seen as a bid to outdo rival companies like Apple and Google, and Intel's CEO says the tracking of data collected is on an opt-in basis, fostering a relationship based on output.

site_title: OCBC, UOB extend US$44m green loan to Myanmar conglomerate
summary: OCBC Bank and United Overseas Bank (UOB) have extended a US$44 million green loan to Myanmar's Shwe Taung Group, with close to US$30 million from OCBC and the balance from UOB. The loan will refinance an earlier loan taken out for Junction City Shopping Centre, a mixed-use development with green features such as energy-efficient systems and rooftop solar panels. The loan is part of a green loan framework developed by OCBC and Shwe Taung, and signals an important shift towards sustainability in Myanmar.

site_title: London City leader makes case for selective ditching of EU rules
summary: London's insurance sector official, Julian Adams, suggests selectively ditching EU rules to boost the city's appeal as a global financial hub. With Britain's departure from the EU, the sector can write its own rules once a transition period ends on December 31. Adams proposes amending wholesale market rules, which could promote international competitiveness, but may face trade-offs with investor protection. The City of London financial district's leader, Catherine McGuiness, says there's no demand to row back on regulation, while other officials warn of potential EU backlash if rules diverge too far.

site_title: US: Nasdaq opens at record high on private jobs data, virus treatment talks
summary: US stocks opened at record highs on Wednesday, driven by strong domestic private jobs data and reports of treatments for the coronavirus. The Nasdaq Composite reached a record high, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also opened higher, with gains of 0.84% and 0.83% respectively.

site_title: WHO issues appeal for US$675m to fight novel coronavirus
summary: The World Health Organisation (WHO) has issued an appeal for US$675 million in donations to fight the novel coronavirus, mainly through investments in countries at high risk. The funds will be used for preparedness and response efforts, including 500,000 masks and 40,000 respirators being sent to 24 countries. A US$100 million donation from the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation has also been announced for virus testing, treatment, and vaccine research. WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus urged the international community to invest now to avoid costly measures later.

site_title: Singapore confirms 4 new cases of coronavirus, including 6-month-old child
summary: Singapore confirmed four new cases of the coronavirus, including a 6-month-old baby, bringing the total number of confirmed cases to 28. Three of the new cases are linked to a local transmission cluster, while one is an imported case from Wuhan. Despite this, the government reiterated that there is no evidence of widespread community transmission in Singapore. The country has the second-highest number of confirmed cases outside of China, with Japan having the most.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets ahead at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Wednesday, with gains driven by advances in mining and healthcare sectors. London's FTSE 100 rose 0.3%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 climbed 0.4%, and Paris's CAC 40 won 0.5%. The gains came despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions and tariff threats.

site_title: Airbus closes China plant due to coronavirus
summary: Airbus has closed its aircraft production facility in Tianjin, China, due to the coronavirus outbreak, citing logistical challenges. The facility, which produces single-aisle A320 aircraft, will remain closed indefinitely. This decision follows similar closures by French aeronautics and defense contractor Safran. The move is part of a global response to the pandemic, which has prompted travel restrictions, flight suspensions, and a global health emergency declaration by the World Health Organisation. Airbus will continue to monitor the situation and explore alternative plans to mitigate production and delivery disruptions.

site_title: Modi promises 'grand' Hindu temple at flashpoint site
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced the establishment of a trust to oversee the construction of a grand Hindu temple at the disputed holy site of Ayodhya, which was the site of a 1992 mosque demolition that led to widespread violence. The temple will be built on 27 hectares, while a separate area will be given to a Muslim body for a mosque. The move has sparked concerns of a Hindu nationalist agenda, with critics accusing Modi of trying to remould the country as a Hindu nation. The project has been a decades-long campaign pledge of Modi's BJP party.

images.alt_text: A model of a proposed Ram Hindu temple displayed at Karsevakpuram campus in Ayodhya. The construction of the temple at holy site bitterly contested with Muslims moved a step closer Wednesday when Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi said a trust had been finalised to oversee the project.

site_title: Debao seeks more time for results release as travel curbs hit finance team
summary: Debao Property Development has applied for an extension to release its FY2019 financial results, initially due by Feb 29, to March 31, due to travel restrictions affecting its finance team. The company's employees who returned from the Lunar New Year celebrations in Wuhan and other parts of Hubei province will face a 14-day quarantine period, limiting their access to financial data. Debao cited a shortage of manpower as the reason for the request, requiring more time to review accounts, liaise with auditors, and seek board approval.

site_title: Elite Commercial Reit IPO's public offer oversubscribed
summary: Elite Commercial Reit's initial public offering (IPO) in Singapore was oversubscribed 8.3 times, with 47.85 million units applied for out of 5.73 million units offered. The retail tranche was 5% of the overall offering, and the placement tranche was 3.2 times subscribed by institutional investors. The IPO is expected to raise £130.9 million, with trading of the units set to begin on Thursday.

site_title: ECB's Lagarde warns coronavirus adds to economic uncertainty
summary: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde warned that the coronavirus outbreak adds to economic uncertainty, citing its impact on global trade and the need for close monitoring. The ECB is prepared to add monetary support if necessary, while also highlighting longer-term risks such as climate change. Lagarde emphasized the potential for a short-term economic effect but no long-lasting impact, drawing parallels to previous pandemics.

images.alt_text: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde said her institution is on watch as the coronavirus outbreak provides a new threat to the economic outlook.

site_title: Sailing the high seas in luxury
summary: The Singapore Yacht Show is set to celebrate its 10th anniversary in March, featuring over 100 boats and 15,000 visitors. Despite the novel coronavirus impacting visitor numbers, the show will proceed. The article also explores various lifestyle topics, including a driving holiday in Hokkaido, a new concept restaurant, retro architecture, luxury streetwear, and love-related literature. Additionally, it highlights several recent news articles on topics such as corporate purpose, zero-waste living, and financial literacy for women.

site_title: Thailand's largest IPO braves market, priced near top of range
summary: Thailand's largest retailer, Central Retail Corp, priced its initial public offering (IPO) near the top end of its indicative range at 42 baht (S$1.87) per share, worth about US$2.6 billion. The IPO was launched despite global market concerns over the coronavirus outbreak in China, which has weakened Thailand's stocks index and the baht. Analysts say the IPO price justifies Central Retail's asset base, and the company's listing plans include delisting a retail unit and offering a share swap to existing shareholders.

site_title: Co-living firm Hmlet adds Tiong Bahru properties to collection
summary: Hmlet, a Singapore-based co-living company, has added seven properties in Tiong Bahru to its collection, bringing the total number of properties managed in Singapore to 48. The new properties feature studios, one-bedroom, and two-bedroom apartments with communal areas and will provide greater flexibility and housing options for members. This latest venture is expected to play a crucial role in Hmlet's community growth, following successful launches of other Tiong Bahru properties and a recent Series B funding round.

site_title: US trade deficit falls in 2019 for the first time in six years
summary: The US trade deficit fell 1.7% to $616.8 billion in 2019, marking the first drop in six years, as the White House's trade war with China curbed imports. Goods imports and exports both decreased 1.7% and 1.3% respectively, with the goods trade deficit with China falling 17.6% to $345.6 billion. The trade deficit contributed to the economy's moderate growth in the fourth quarter, with GDP growth at 2.1% annualized.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index increasing 0.99 points to 1,536.79. A total of 3.1 billion lots worth RM2.7 billion were traded, with 514 gainers outnumbering 344 losers.

site_title: Singapore shares extend gains as Chinese stimulus lifts sentiment
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 1.4% to 3,200.13, driven by Chinese stimulus efforts to combat the coronavirus. Asia's manufacturing and services data showed economic resilience, despite investor confidence shaken by virus fears. The Singapore banks, including DBS, OCBC, and United Overseas Bank, ended higher, while Genting Singapore and Manulife US Reit also gained. The rally follows a similar trend in other Asian markets, with the Shanghai Composite Index advancing 1.3%.

site_title: Former OCBC head of consumer finance Dennis Tan appointed Prudential Singapore CEO
summary: Former OCBC head of consumer finance Dennis Tan, 51, has been appointed CEO of Prudential Singapore. He replaces Wilfred Blackburn, who will become regional CEO, Insurance Growth Markets, based in Hong Kong. Tan previously held executive roles at OCBC and Citibank Singapore, and resigned from OCBC late last year. He is expected to take over as Prudential Singapore CEO once regulatory approvals are obtained.

site_title: WHO says no known effective treatments for new coronavirus
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has clarified that there are no known effective treatments for the new coronavirus, contrary to media reports of breakthrough drugs. Researchers are working on developing a vaccine, with initial human trials expected to begin by June this year. Doctors may try antiviral medicines licensed for other viral infections to treat patients, and the US drugmaker Gilead is conducting clinical trials of an experimental drug called remdesivir. The WHO recommends enrolling patients in randomized controlled trials to test efficacy and safety.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) has stated there is room within its current policy band to accommodate another easing if economic conditions weaken due to the coronavirus outbreak. COE prices for cars in Singapore have fallen, with prices for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp dropping to S$30,010. Dennis Tan, former head of consumer finance at OCBC, has been appointed CEO of Prudential Singapore, while 11 freehold commercial units at Balestier Point are up for sale at S$68 million.

site_title: German car sales plunge as new pollution rules bite
summary: German car sales plummeted 7.3% in January to 246,300 new vehicles, marking the first decline in five months. The drop is attributed to new EU pollution rules that triggered a buying frenzy in the final months of 2019. Despite a 4.5% decrease in CO2 emissions, the majority of cars sold still emit high levels of pollution. Electric car sales rose 61% and plug-in hybrids 300%, but they account for only 6.5% of the market. Analysts expect the trend to strengthen as more electric models hit the market and climate awareness grows.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks end firmer on hopes of China stimulus boost
summary: South Korean stocks rose for a second session on Wednesday, up 0.36% at 2,165.63, as investors bet on Chinese stimulus measures to counter the economic impact of a coronavirus outbreak. The death toll in China passed 490, and two US airlines suspended flights to Hong Kong following a fatality. The KOSPI dropped 1.46% so far this year, but the recent gains suggest investors are optimistic about the potential economic boost from Chinese stimulus.

site_title: COE prices tumble following coronavirus outbreak
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) prices for cars and motorcycles fell at the latest tender, with car premiums down by the sharpest in recent memory due to the coronavirus crisis. The car premium for up to 1,600cc and 130bhp ended at S$30,010, down from S$35,010. The commercial vehicle COE price was the only exception, closing at S$25,013. Industry watchers expect prices to remain dampened in the near term, while some see a potential increase in car sales as fears of contamination elsewhere increase.

images.alt_text: Certificate of entitlement (COE) premiums for cars and motorcycles ended lower at the latest tender Wednesday (Feb 5) as consumer sentiment weakened in light of the developing coronavirus crisis.

site_title: 282 shareholders to get nothing under LifeBrandz' 50:1 share consolidation
summary: 282 LifeBrandz shareholders holding fewer than 50 shares will lose their shares in a proposed 50-to-1 share consolidation. The move aims to reduce volatility and fluctuations in the company's market capitalization. Up to 305.8 million new shares will be issued through a rights issue to repay advances from two shareholders, Bounty Blue Capital and Capital Square Co. The company's executive chairman and CEO, Saito Hiroyuki, will not abstain from voting at the upcoming EGM due to similar arrangements in the market.

site_title: How have industries been affected by the virus outbreak?
summary: The novel coronavirus outbreak has significantly impacted various industries in Singapore and globally. Hospitality S-Reits and integrated resorts are expected to see a decline in earnings due to the outbreak. Construction projects may face delays, while food delivery and e-commerce players are bracing for a surge in sales. MICE events have been canceled or postponed, and travel restrictions have affected the tourism industry. Globally, the outbreak has raised concerns about economic growth, with China's GDP growth expected to slow, and the UK economy shrinking for the second month in a row.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose on Wednesday, tracking a strong lead from Wall Street, as concerns over the coronavirus's impact on the economy eased. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.42%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index rose 1.25% and 2.48%, respectively. These gains followed a strong lead from US stocks, which edged towards fresh records despite ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon up 1% on day
summary: Singapore stocks rose 1% on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,188.23, as trading resumed in the afternoon. Medtecs International fell 14.2% after losing S$0.017 on 75.1 million shares traded, while Rex International lost S$0.002 on 55 million shares. The market saw a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with gains outnumbering losses 174 to 147.

site_title: BlackGold seeks to raise up to S$25m in bond issue to 3 investors
summary: BlackGold Natural Resources is seeking to raise up to S$25 million through interest-free convertible bonds to three investors. The bonds can be converted into new shares at a price of S$0.015 apiece, representing a 16.28% premium to the volume-weighted average price of BlackGold shares. The conversion shares would account for 166.05% of existing share capital and 58.75% of enlarged issued share capital. The funds will be used to finance new plans, including an offtake agreement for thermal coal and exclusive agreements to manage coal concessions in Indonesia and obtain mining licenses.

site_title: Australia, NZ shares rise on China stimulus hopes
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% to 6,976.1 on Wednesday, following broader Asia gains on hopes of Chinese stimulus measures to combat the coronavirus outbreak. China's central bank is expected to lower its lending rate on February 20 and cut reserve requirements in the coming weeks. The S&P/ASX 200 index is now on track for a second consecutive day of gains.

site_title: Memstar's transfer of listing status to TBN hits roadblock
summary: Memstar Technology's bid to transfer its listing status on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to TBN Property Co has hit a roadblock after the SGX rejected its request to extend deadlines related to the transfer. The deal, first proposed in 2018, aims to transfer Memstar's listing status to TBN in exchange for S$6 million worth of shares. The SGX cited concerns over Memstar's ability to comply with Catalist admission requirements and whether TBN is suitable for listing after a restructuring exercise. Memstar will continue to evaluate other alternatives.

site_title: Indonesia investigates deaths of hundreds of pigs in Bali
summary: Indonesian authorities are investigating the deaths of approximately 880 pigs on the island of Bali, with the cause potentially linked to African swine fever (ASF). The deaths occurred between December and January, and there have been no confirmed outbreaks on Bali. This incident is part of the global ASF outbreak that has affected China and led to a ban on imports from Indonesia. The Indonesian government is working to determine the cause of the deaths and implement operational standards for infectious animal diseases.

site_title: Google says glitch sent people's videos to strangers
summary: A software glitch at Google's Photo app resulted in some users' videos being sent to the wrong people, with an estimated 0.01% of those who used the "Takeout" tool affected between November 21 and November 25, 2020. The glitch delivered videos, not photos, to unauthorized recipients. Google apologized and stated that the issue has been fixed, with an in-depth analysis conducted to prevent similar incidents in the future.

site_title: ICA to stop accepting Malaysian 'group passport' from January next year
summary: The Immigration and Checkpoints Authority (ICA) of Singapore announced that it will stop accepting the Malaysian Collective Travel Document (MCTD) from January 1, 2021, due to security concerns. The document, issued to groups of 5-20 Malaysians, requires manual data entry and causes longer clearance times. Malaysian travelers using the MCTD must apply for individual passports to visit Singapore from January 1, 2021. This change aims to strengthen security and efficiency at Singapore's checkpoints.

site_title: Sim Leisure to bring Escape theme parks to Sri Lanka
summary: Sim Leisure Group, a Malaysian theme park developer, has signed a memorandum of understanding with Sri Lanka-listed Elpitiya Plantations to bring its Escape theme parks to Sri Lanka. The project will be located halfway between Colombo city and Galle, with construction expected to start in March. Sim Leisure aims to expand to China and other South-east Asian cities, citing Sri Lanka's growing tourism industry and low business costs. The joint venture partnership is expected to be finalized later this month.

site_title: CAREhab 2020 postponed to July due to virus outbreak
summary: The CAREhab 2020 event has been postponed to July 10-11 due to the novel coronavirus outbreak, originally scheduled for February 14-15 in Singapore. The event, expected to attract 1,500 industry professionals from 25 countries, will prioritize health and safety. Other events affected by the virus include the National Association of Travel Agents Singapore's annual travel fair and the Singapore Airshow Aviation Leadership Summit, which have been postponed or cancelled, respectively.

site_title: Broker's take: UOB Kay Hian initiates coverage on Food Empire with 'buy', S$0.89 target price
summary: UOB Kay Hian has initiated coverage on Food Empire Holdings, a manufacturer of instant coffee and snacks, with a "buy" call and a target price of S$0.89. The brokerage firm cites Food Empire's global footprint and relatively low valuation as attractive, with shares trading at a 25% discount from the target price. The company's forward price-to-earnings ratio is 9.2 times, lower than peers trading at an average of 22 times.

site_title: Commercial podium at Oxley Rise condo up for sale with S$62.5m indicative price
summary: A two-story commercial podium at Oxley Rise in Singapore is up for sale via expression of interest with an indicative price of S$62.5 million, or around S$3,800 per square foot. The podium, which fronts onto Oxley Rise and Clemenceau Avenue, has 29 strata units, including space for food and beverage establishments, and 14 basement car park lots. The sale comes as part of the larger mixed-use development, which includes 120 residential units sold. The seller is offering a 4% gross yield in the first year to the successful buyer.

site_title: Spotify's Sunita Kaur joins game-streaming platform Twitch as APAC head
summary: Twitch, an Amazon subsidiary, has hired Sunita Kaur as its first Asia-Pacific (APAC) managing director. Based in Singapore, Kaur will focus on growing the live-streaming platform's operations and community in the APAC region. With experience at Spotify and other companies, Kaur will leverage her expertise in digital advertising and online communities to deepen Twitch's investments in the region. This move is seen as a strategic move to tap into the growing demand for user-generated live content and gaming in Asia.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares advance on weakening virus fears, lower yen
summary: Tokyo shares rose 1.02% on Wednesday, driven by easing global worries about the coronavirus outbreak and a weaker yen. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index closed at 23,319.56, while the Topix index rose 1.04%. Investors cheered news of potential economic stimulus from China and optimistic projections from S&P Global Ratings, which predicted the crisis would stabilize globally in April 2020. The dollar stood at 109.39 yen, and major shares such as Toyota, Nintendo, and Komatsu gained, while Sony fell 0.53%.

site_title: Subaru checking with Chinese suppliers for possible coronavirus impact
summary: Subaru is checking with Chinese suppliers for potential disruptions to parts deliveries due to the coronavirus outbreak. Senior vice-president Fumiaki Hayata noted that communication with Chinese partners is difficult due to the lunar new year holiday, but parts supply has not been affected so far. However, the company acknowledges that disruptions are possible and is monitoring the situation. As of now, no alternative suppliers have been sought.

site_title: Siemens on track for 2020 despite slow start
summary: Siemens reported a 3% year-on-year decline in net earnings for its October-December first quarter, to approximately 1.1 billion euros, due to a slump in its wind power division and severance costs. Despite this, the company remains on track to spin off its energy businesses into Siemens Energy in September. Operating profits declined at its factory automation and gas and power divisions, but its wind turbine arm boosted revenues 82%. Siemens forecasts "moderate growth" in comparable revenue and earnings per share for the full year.

site_title: Hong Kong medical staff strike for third day as locally transmitted virus cases rise
summary: Medical staff in Hong Kong began their third day of strike action on Wednesday, demanding the border with mainland China be sealed as locally transmitted cases of a new coronavirus increased to 18, including at least four locally infected cases. The city's chief executive, Carrie Lam, has suspended some links with the mainland but left three border crossings open. The strike is part of a broader health scare in Hong Kong, where the city's public hospital network was already suffering from staff shortages and limited hospital beds.

site_title: Top Democrat Pelosi rips up Trump speech
summary: Top US Democrat Nancy Pelosi ripped up a copy of President Donald Trump's State of the Union address after listening to his speech, breaking with custom. Trump had not shaken hands with Pelosi upon arrival, further straining their relationship. Pelosi said her gesture was "the courteous thing to do" after Trump made claims she deemed unbelievable. The incident occurred a month after Pelosi oversaw Trump's impeachment.

site_title: OCBC, UOB provide US$44m green loan to Myanmar conglomerate
summary: OCBC Bank and United Overseas Bank (UOB) have provided a US$44 million green loan to Myanmar's Shwe Taung Group, with close to US$30 million from OCBC and the balance from UOB. The loan will be used to refinance a previous loan taken out by Shwe Taung's subsidiary, City Square Commercial Company, for its Junction City Shopping Centre, which has green features such as energy-efficient systems and a self-sustaining waste treatment system. The loan signals an important shift towards sustainability in Myanmar, according to OCBC.

site_title: Rise of Malaysia's middle class presents opportunities at our doorstep
summary: Malaysia's middle class is expanding rapidly, presenting opportunities for Singaporean businesses in the consumer industry, digital economy, and manufacturing sector. The country's proximity to Singapore and cultural similarities make it an attractive location for investment and expansion. The government's 4.7-4.8% economic growth in 2019 and 2020, and the growing demand for retail, food and beverage, healthcare, education, and e-commerce, create a favorable business environment. However, businesses must adapt to lower bureaucratic efficiency and regulatory requirements. With 36% of the population being young, e-commerce is experiencing rapid development, and companies like Ninja Van, Shopback, and Shopee are expanding their operations in Malaysia.

site_title: Singapore shares edge up at Wednesday's open; STI up 0.03%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.03% to 3,157.50 on Wednesday, driven by a decline in investor concern over the novel coronavirus and strong US and European market performances. Gainers outnumbered losers 83 to 44, with Addvalue Technologies and Ntegrator International among the top gainers. Banking stocks, however, fell, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC losing points. The gains follow Wall Street's rally overnight and a boost in Asian markets, with Tokyo stocks opening higher and fears over the coronavirus outbreak easing.

site_title: Major US airlines add Hong Kong to China flight suspensions
summary: Major US airlines United and American Airlines have suspended flights to Hong Kong until February 20, citing a sharp drop in passengers due to the deadly new coronavirus outbreak. The airlines had previously halted flights to mainland China, where the virus has killed nearly 500 people and infected over 24,000. Hong Kong's airport is a major transit point for China, and the city is struggling with its own outbreak, with 18 people testing positive for the disease. The move comes as health officials warn of growing evidence of local transmissions in Hong Kong.

site_title: Credit Suisse scraps Hong Kong conference on coronavirus outbreak
summary: Credit Suisse scrapped its annual Asia investment conference in Hong Kong due to the ongoing coronavirus outbreak. The event, originally set for March 25-27, was canceled in view of continued health and safety risks. This marks the biggest cancellation in Hong Kong's financial industry since the outbreak. Several other conferences in China and Hong Kong have also been postponed or canceled, including the AVCJ China Forum and Fitch Ratings' Credit Outlook 2020 Conference. The virus has shown no signs of abating, prompting further cancellations and rescheduling of events.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand: Shares rise on hopes of more China stimulus
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% on Wednesday as investors hoped for more Chinese economic stimulus to mitigate the impact of the coronavirus outbreak. China is preparing additional measures, including rate trimming and injecting hundreds of billions of dollars into the financial system. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 6,975.60.

site_title: Asia: Markets build on global rally, virus fears ease
summary: Asian markets continued their global rally on Wednesday, extending gains despite concerns over the deadly China virus. The spread of the virus outside China has eased, and Chinese authorities' support for mainland stocks has boosted markets. Shanghai rose 1.9%, while Hong Kong and Tokyo also gained ground. Safe havens retreated, with gold shedding 1% and the Japanese yen at its weakest since January 24. Oil prices fell to one-year lows due to concerns over demand in China.

site_title: 11 freehold commercial units at Balestier Point up for sale at S$68m
summary: A portfolio of 11 freehold commercial units at Balestier Point is up for sale at S$68 million. The units, ranging from 269 to 5,609 sq ft, can be bought individually or collectively. Located on the ground floor and second storey, they have shop frontage and main road frontage. Foreigners and companies can purchase the units, with a significant stake in the management corporation strata title. The expression of interest exercise will close on March 17. The units can be used as restaurants, cafes, fitness centres, or showrooms, subject to approval from relevant authorities.

images.alt_text: The portfolio of 11 freehold commercial units comprises a total of about 31.7 per cent of share value within Balestier Point, and the prospective buyer will command a significant stake in the management corporation strata title, said Savills.

site_title: Broker's take: RHB downgrades UOB as coronavirus may dampen forward earnings
summary: RHB Securities has downgraded United Overseas Bank (UOB) to "neutral" with a target price of S$25.80 due to potential economic disruption from the coronavirus outbreak. Analyst Leng Seng Choon lowered UOB's expected return on equity to 11.6% from 12.7% previously, citing lower loan growth and higher provisions. Despite this downgrade, RHB considers UOB its preferred bank pick due to its lower loan exposure to Greater China. UOB's full-year results are set to be released on February 21.

site_title: Hospitality S-Reits, integrated resorts most exposed to fall in earnings from outbreak: Moody's
summary: Moody's reports that Singapore's hospitality and gaming sectors will be significantly impacted by the novel coronavirus outbreak, with revenue from foreign visitors expected to drop due to travel restrictions and cancellations. Integrated resorts like Marina Bay Sands and Resorts World Sentosa are particularly vulnerable, but have sufficient cash reserves to meet committed capital spending. Analysts have downgraded their calls on two Singapore-listed hospitality Reits, Frasers Hospitality Trust and Ascott Residence Trust, citing the virus outbreak.

images.alt_text: Marina Bay Sands, Resorts World Sentosa and Singapore-listed hospitality Reits will be the most exposed to revenue declines amid the travel restrictions, as they are in tourism-reliant industries.

site_title: 'Sufficient room' for Singdollar to ease amid virus outbreak: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has stated that there is "sufficient room" within its current monetary policy band to accommodate another easing if the Singapore economy weakens due to the coronavirus outbreak. This comes after the MAS reduced the Singapore dollar's nominal effective exchange rate (S$NEER) policy band in October, which has been fluctuating near the upper bound since then. The next half-yearly monetary policy review remains scheduled for April this year.

site_title: Philippines' Jan annual inflation quickens to 2.9%
summary: The Philippines' consumer price index (CPI) rose 2.9% in January, exceeding expectations and surpassing the previous month's 2.5% increase. This is the country's fastest inflation rate in a year. The central bank's forecast range for January was 2.5-3.3%.

site_title: Space programme to start commercial operations in 2020: Addvalue Tech
summary: Addvalue Technologies, a mainboard-listed company, announced that its space programme with Capella Space will start commercial operations in 2020. The inter-satellite data relay system (IDRS) terminal is expected to contribute significantly to the group's revenue and performance, with sales growth anticipated at an accelerated pace from early 2020. The company's IDRS hardware sales and associated airtime revenue are expected to drive progress in the last quarter of fiscal 2020 and the following financial year.

site_title: Japan services sector returns to growth in Jan as sales tax hike impact fades
summary: Japan's services sector returned to growth in January, with the Jibun Bank Japan Services Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 51.0, the fastest pace since last September. This uptick comes as consumers may be adjusting to a sales tax hike, and is a welcome sign for the Bank of Japan's hopes for a domestic demand-led economic recovery. However, business confidence dropped to a 29-month low, and backlogs of work remained in contraction, suggesting the economy may remain under pressure.

site_title: China's services sector growth hits 3-month low in Jan: Caixin PMI
summary: China's services sector growth slowed to a three-month low in January, with a Caixin PMI of 51.8, down from 52.5 in December. Companies cut prices and new orders dipped due to limited demand and higher fuel and labor costs. Despite this, firms' expectations for business activity improved, driven by the US-China trade deal. However, the coronavirus crisis, which began in late January, is expected to further darken the economic outlook, with analysts warning of significant disruption to economic activities and a potential hit to growth.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 5.92 points or 0.39% to 1,529.88. Volume reached 112.31 million lots worth RM56.78 million. Gainers beat losers 197 to 52. The decline follows a broader global trend, with European and US stocks also experiencing downward momentum due to concerns over US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Trump administration to meet on Huawei export curbs after Pentagon pushback: sources
summary: The US Trump administration is set to meet on February 28 to discuss limiting exports to China and its flagship telecoms company Huawei, following a Pentagon pushback on a Commerce Department rule. The meeting aims to resolve disagreements on how to approach Huawei, amid a deepening tech war between the US and China. The Commerce Department withdrew the rule in May, but it was stymied by opposition from the Pentagon and the Treasury Department. The gathering is part of the administration's efforts to keep sensitive technologies out of China's hands and limit Chinese investment in key US sectors.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher as virus worries recede
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.36% on Wednesday, driven by Wall Street rallies and a cheaper yen, easing fears of the coronavirus' economic impact. The Nikkei 225 index reached 23,398.23, while the Topix index rose 1.25%. Investors took heart from the US market's gains, which edged towards records despite ongoing tariff tensions. The rally was seen as a positive sign, with fears of the virus outbreak receding.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks extend gains at open
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks rose on Wednesday, following a strong lead from Wall Street, as fears over the impact of China's coronavirus on the global economy began to ease. The Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.33%, and the Hang Seng Index added 0.72% in Hong Kong. The gains were attributed to investors' confidence in the markets' resilience.

site_title: UK foreign minister to visit Australia, Singapore in post-Brexit trade drive
summary: UK Foreign Minister Dominic Raab is visiting Australia, Singapore, and Malaysia to secure free trade deals post-Brexit. Raab will meet with counterparts and business executives to promote Britain as a great place to invest. The trip follows Britain's departure from the European Union and aims to establish new trade relationships with major economies. Raab emphasized the opportunities in the Asia-Pacific region and the UK's openness to business. The visit is part of Britain's efforts to negotiate its future relationship with Brussels and the US.

site_title: Trump in State of Union speech: 'I keep my promises'
summary: President Donald Trump delivered a State of the Union speech, boasting of "I keep my promises" as he faces near-certain acquittal in his impeachment trial. Trump said the US has achieved an "incredible result" since he launched the "great American comeback" three years ago. The speech comes as the Democratic party faces divisions and a chaotic start to the primaries. Trump's re-election bid is set to gain momentum with the acquittal, which is expected to happen soon.

site_title: 'I do': Tiffany shareholders back LVMH bid after long courtship
summary: Tiffany shareholders have approved the acquisition by luxury firm LVMH for $16.2 billion, with LVMH paying $135 per share. The deal, announced in November, adds Tiffany to LVMH's portfolio of luxury brands, strengthening its presence in the US and tapping into a different type of luxury demand. The acquisition is expected to close mid-2020, subject to regulatory approvals, and will make LVMH the largest luxury group globally.

site_title: London's financial district sees few signs of Brexodus
summary: The City of London financial district reported few signs of a "Brexodus" on the first day of Brexit, with job relocations to the EU estimated to be between 2,000 and 7,000. Leader Catherine McGuinness stated that there were no major calls for radical divergence from EU rules to threaten equivalence-based access to the bloc. McGuinness urged Britain to remain open to EU financial market access, saying that New York is the big potential competitor to London and it will remain Europe's only global financial center.

site_title: Bank of Japan deputy governor says vigilant against coronavirus impact on global trade
summary: Bank of Japan Deputy Governor Masazumi Wakatabe expressed vigilance over the potential impact of the coronavirus outbreak on global trade and capital expenditure. He stated that the central bank will scrutinize the economic effects and be prepared to ease monetary policy if the economy's momentum is threatened. Risks surrounding Japan's economy and prices remain high, with the BOJ targeting a 2% inflation rate. Wakatabe emphasized the need for caution, highlighting the uncertainties surrounding the coronavirus's global economic impact.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Manulife US Reit, Japfa, GS Holdings, CSE Global, Sim Leisure, Hwa Hong, Ntegrator
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several Singapore stocks experienced new developments on Wednesday, including Manulife US Reit's 5.9% decline in fourth-quarter distribution per unit, Japfa's S$92.6 million raised from a rights issue, and CSE Global's S$230 million worth of new orders. Other notable developments include Sim Leisure's non-binding agreement to set up theme parks in Sri Lanka, Hwa Hong's fourth-quarter earnings rise, and Ntegrator's S$6.6 million contract secured. GS Holdings reported outstanding gross service fees due to tax consultations, while its shares remained flat. The companies' shares closed with varying gains or losses on Tuesday.

site_title: GS Holdings yet to receive 120m yuan in fees from China F&B outlets
summary: GS Holdings, a Catalist-listed company, has not received 120 million yuan (S$23.5 million) in outstanding gross service fees from 14 Chinese food and beverage outlets due to ongoing tax consultations. The delay is related to corporate income tax and withholding tax payable by the outlets before remitting the outstanding fees. GS Holdings hopes the issue will be resolved by mid-March, and its provision of BOP services may be affected. The company expects a "significant increase" in revenue and net profit for fiscal 2019, subject to the finalisation of the tax consultation.

site_title: Manulife US Reit lowers Q4 DPU on enlarged unit base
summary: Manulife US Reit reported a 5.9% decrease in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.44 US cents for its Q4 2019, primarily due to an enlarged unit base following a recent acquisition. Gross revenue increased 20.4% to US$48.8 million, driven by contributions from newly acquired properties.

site_title: Australian central bank governor says jobs key for further rate cuts
summary: Australian Reserve Bank Governor Philip Lowe stated that a strong case exists for further rate cuts if the unemployment rate increases and inflation doesn't rise. The unemployment rate eased to 5.1% in December, while inflation ticked higher, making a rate cut unnecessary. Lowe emphasized that lower rates would support private consumption and jobs, but also risk asset price inflation and increased borrowing. The RBA left interest rates at 0.75% for the first meeting of the year, with expectations of a potential rate cut in June.

images.alt_text: Australia's central bank would see a strong case for cutting its benchmark interest rate from current record lows if the unemployment rate moved higher and there was no progress in lifting inflation, Governor Philip Lowe said on Wednesday.

site_title: Macy's closing 125 stores, cutting 2,000 jobs
summary: Macy's plans to close 125 stores and cut 2,000 jobs over three years as part of a plan to shore up its financial position. The company expects to generate $1.5 billion in annual gross savings by the end of 2022. This move comes as the department store chain struggles with declining mall sales and competition from online retailers like Amazon.

images.alt_text: Iconic American department store chain Macy's will shutter 125 stores and slash 2,000 jobs over the next three years as part of a plan to shore up its financial position, the company announced on Tuesday.

site_title: Walt Disney results lifted by 'Star Wars,' 'Frozen'
summary: Walt Disney delivered better-than-expected results in the past quarter, driven by box office hits from 'Star Wars: The Rise Of Skywalker' and 'Frozen II', and a strong consumer response to its new Disney+ streaming service. Profits dropped 24% to $2.1 billion, while revenues surged 36% to $21 billion. Disney+ has signed 28.6 million subscribers since its launch in November, exceeding expectations. The company's studio entertainment segment saw a significant boost, with revenues increasing to $3.8 billion.

site_title: At least 10 on Japan cruise ship have new coronavirus: minister
summary: Japan has quarantined a cruise ship with 3,711 passengers after at least 10 tested positive for the new coronavirus. The health minister reported over 200 specimens were collected, with 10 confirmed cases. The infected passengers were removed and sent to medical organizations for treatment.
