The outbreak has prompted global health concerns, with the World Health Organization declaring a global health emergency and travel restrictions imposed by several governments.

site_title: Coronavirus deaths rise as WHO says 'opportunity' to halt spread
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has declared a global health emergency due to the rapid spread of the 2019-nCoV virus, with over 24,000 cases in China and 176 cases worldwide. Despite China's efforts to contain the outbreak, the WHO believes there is a "window of opportunity" to halt transmission. The virus has spread to more than 20 countries, with new cases reported in Singapore, Malaysia, and Thailand. The WHO's chief, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, urged wealthy countries to share data, as the mortality rate stands at 2.1%.

images.alt_text: The world has a "window of opportunity" to halt the spread of a deadly new virus, global health experts said, as the number of people infected in China jumped to 24,000 and millions more were ordered to stay indoors.

site_title: Iconoclastic Musk basks as Tesla shares soar
summary: Elon Musk's Tesla has seen its market value surge over 300% in the past five months, reaching $165 billion, making it more valuable than several major automakers combined. The company's shares rose 23% to $962, driven by Musk's ability to build the brand and maintain its mystique despite production challenges. Experts credit Musk's charismatic leadership and focus on environmental concerns, which resonates with younger consumers. However, concerns have been raised about Tesla's reliance on its CEO and potential risks to the company's long-term success.

site_title: Italy sees fashion sales hit due to China virus, Pandora warns of business freeze
summary: Italy's fashion industry expects a 1.8% revenue decline in the first half of 2020 due to the coronavirus outbreak. The Italian national fashion chamber CNMI attributed this decline to the impact of the virus on sales. Several high-end brands have also closed their stores in China, the world's largest luxury goods market, raising concerns about significant damage to sales if the virus is not contained quickly. Jewelry maker Pandora warned of a business freeze in China.

site_title: More Baby Yoda? 'Mandalorian' back in October as spin-offs mooted
summary: Disney is set to release the second season of "The Mandalorian" in October, with potential spinoffs also in the works. Chief Bob Iger announced the news during an earnings call, citing the show's success and the character of Baby Yoda, who has become a viral sensation. Iger hinted at the possibility of more Baby Yoda content, including spinoffs, and prioritized television over film for "Star Wars" in the coming years. The live-action series, which follows a bounty hunter and his unlikely bond with Baby Yoda, has been a hit on Disney+.

site_title: Brazil to evacuate citizens stuck in Wuhan
summary: Brazil is evacuating its 40 citizens stuck in Wuhan, China, due to the deadly new coronavirus outbreak. The decision comes after President Jair Bolsonaro's initial reluctance to evacuate, citing diplomatic, budgetary, and legal obstacles. Two presidential planes will bring the Brazilians home on Wednesday, who will be placed in a 18-day quarantine at a military base. The move follows emotional appeals from citizens, including professional footballer Millene Fernandes, who had been stuck in Wuhan for days.

site_title: Huawei promises 'Made in Europe' 5G for EU
summary: Huawei has announced plans to set up manufacturing hubs in Europe, aiming to produce 'Made in Europe' 5G networks. The move comes amid US pressure on EU nations to ban the Chinese telecom giant due to security concerns. The European Commission has recommended a middle ground, allowing Huawei to operate in critical 5G infrastructure while limiting its role. Huawei's top executive Abraham Liu emphasized the company's commitment to Europe, saying it wants to "truly have 5G for Europe made in Europe." The decision is seen as a bid to persuade EU countries to resist US pleas for a ban.

site_title: Twitter moves to curb manipulated content including 'deepfakes'
summary: Twitter has announced a plan to curb the spread of manipulated content, including "deepfakes," as part of its efforts to fight misinformation that could result in violence or harm. The policy, set to begin on March 5, will include warning labels for tweets with manipulated images or video, and removal of the tweets if deemed likely to cause harm. The decision will be based on factors such as the likelihood and severity of harm, and the policy will apply to politicians and their campaigns.

site_title: Millions in China banish virus blues with online games, video apps
summary: In response to China's virus outbreak, millions of people have turned to online games and video apps for entertainment, with millions of views and downloads reported. Companies like Tesla and Mercedes-Benz have also promoted products online, while investors have seen shares of Chinese game publishers and video platforms rise. Weekly downloads of ByteDance's Xigua video app jumped 77% and health and fitness apps saw significant revenue growth. The trend is expected to continue as people stay at home during the Lunar New Year holiday.

site_title: Europe: BP and Glencore drive best day in four months for shares
summary: European shares rose 1.6% on Tuesday, their biggest gain in nearly four months, driven by upbeat earnings updates from BP and Glencore, and China's stimulus efforts to stabilize markets. China's central bank injected $333 billion to support its markets, lifting sentiment. The basic resources sector, led by mining companies focused on China, surged 3.5%. Oil company BP also rose after raising its dividend and reporting better-than-expected profits. However, poor earnings from Micro Focus International and Ferrari kept gains in check.

site_title: '90210' star Shannen Doherty suffers cancer relapse
summary: Shannen Doherty, a 48-year-old actress known for her roles in "Beverly Hills, 90210" and "Charmed," has been diagnosed with stage-four breast cancer. This is her second cancer diagnosis, as she was previously in remission for three years. Doherty expressed her emotional struggle with the news, stating she hasn't fully processed the recurrence.

site_title: Hyundai suspending South Korea production as parts supply hit
summary: Hyundai Motor has suspended production in South Korea due to a disruption in parts supply resulting from the coronavirus outbreak. This is the first major carmaker to do so outside China. The suspension, which affects most factories, is expected to delay Hyundai's recovery from a sales slump, following its best quarterly profit in over two years. The shortage of wiring harnesses, mostly made in China, is the cause of the idling, with production lines expected to restart on February 11 or 12.

site_title: EU set to modify member acccession method to placate France
summary: The European Union is set to propose modifications to the accession process for countries entering the bloc, aiming to placate France, which blocked the opening of membership negotiations with Northern Macedonia and Albania. The proposals will make the process "more predictable" and "dynamic" without altering the rules or conditions for accession, as stated by EU spokeswoman Ana Pisonero. France had sought a more "gradual process" and a reversible system, but the EU is ruling out major changes, with German European Affairs Minister Michael Roth emphasizing that the EU has already significantly changed the accession procedure.

site_title: New Zealand loggers, US food exporters suffer from China's virus clampdown
summary: China's coronavirus lockdown is affecting global exporters, particularly New Zealand loggers and US food exporters, with supply line backups stretching to the US and beyond. China's Lunar New Year holiday and lockdowns have restricted the movement of millions, causing delays and potential shipment cancellations. New Zealand's log exports to China, worth NZ$300 million annually, have been halted, and lobster sales have been severely impacted. US agricultural exporters, such as Tyson Foods and Sanderson Farms, are also facing supply chain disruptions, with refrigerated poultry containers stuck in transit.

site_title: Lesotho first lady charged with 'murder' over killing of PM's ex-wife
summary: Lesotho's first lady, Maesaiah Thabane, was charged with murder over the 2017 killing of Prime Minister Thomas Thabane's ex-wife, Lipolelo Thabane. Thabane, 42, turned herself in to police and will spend the night in custody. Eight others are also accused and will be summoned. The charge comes after new evidence emerged, including a letter alleging communication records linked the prime minister's mobile number to the crime. The prime minister has been questioned and faces pressure to resign amid opposition demands.

site_title: Construction workers' leave of absence raises fears of project delays
summary: Construction workers in Singapore face potential delays due to a leave of absence policy, with 60% of workers from mainland China, a key supplier of labor. The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) has allowed public-sector project contractors to submit claims for more time, while private-sector firms may request extensions through contract extensions. However, not all projects will receive extensions, and contractors must demonstrate they took mitigating measures to minimize delays. The industry is bracing itself for possible missed deadlines, with some firms employing workers from approved non-China markets.

site_title: Oil falls 1% as demand fears outweigh hopes for bigger Opec+ cuts
summary: Oil prices dropped 1% on Tuesday as fears of long-term demand destruction from the coronavirus outbreak outweighed hopes for Opec+ production cuts. Brent crude fell to $53.96 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude slid to $49.61 a barrel, their lowest levels since January 2019. Opec+ considered further output cuts but faces uncertainty over the virus's duration and economic impact, which may limit their ability to respond.

site_title: iSTOX's novel approach to private markets needs time to gain acceptance
summary: iSTOX, a capital markets platform using blockchain and smart contract technology, has graduated from Singapore's FinTech Regulatory Sandbox and is fully licensed operational. The platform aims to increase transparency in private markets by facilitating transactions for secondaries and issuances. However, investors and experts express concerns that the technology may take time to gain acceptance, with some citing the need for fundamental changes to shareholder arrangements. Despite this, iSTOX offers flexibility and potential benefits for unlisted companies seeking to raise capital.

site_title: Alphabet shares fall as Google's Q4 revenue growth slows
summary: Alphabet shares fell 5% as the company's Q4 revenue growth slowed, despite a 53% quarterly revenue growth for Google's cloud services. YouTube's ad revenue was also underwhelming, at $15 billion annually, below estimates of $25 billion. The company's overall sales rose 17% to $46.08 billion, but expenses increased 18.5% due to hiring and infrastructure spending. Analysts questioned executives for the second time in four quarters about revenue growth, citing concerns about the company's dominance in the advertising market.

site_title: China's Hubei province, epicentre of coronavirus outbreak, reports 65 new deaths on Feb 4
summary: China's Hubei province reported 65 new deaths from a coronavirus outbreak, bringing the total to 479 deaths and 16,678 cases as of Feb 4, 2020. The province also saw a 3,156 new cases, increasing the total to 16,678. The outbreak remains a major concern in the country.

images.alt_text: The number of deaths in China's central Hubei province from a coronavirus outbreak had risen by 65 to 479 as of Tuesday, Chinese state television reported on Wednesday.

site_title: Federal Reserve permanently bars Goldman banker over 1MDB
summary: The Federal Reserve permanently barred Goldman Sachs executive Andrea Vella from the banking industry over the 1MDB scandal. The Fed found Vella engaged in unsafe and unsound practices by failing to act on Low Taek Jho's involvement in bond offerings in 2012 and 2013. This action comes after two former Goldman bankers, Tim Leissner and Roger Ng, were also barred from the industry. Goldman Sachs has set aside $1.1 billion in legal costs for 1MDB settlements.

site_title: Latinos are building businesses, but lack connections to access investors
summary: Latino-owned businesses, such as vegan pet food startup Wild Earth, contribute over $700 billion to the US economy annually. However, despite growing in number and size, these businesses face significant challenges accessing capital, with a projected $410 billion annual revenue gap and one million job losses. Latinos lack connections to secure outside funding, instead relying on individual investors and credit card debt. Experts warn that the US is missing a key driver of growth, and investors should be more conscientious about the demographic changes, with Hispanics projected to make up 29% of the US population by 2060.

site_title: Church of England devises index for eco-friendly investing
summary: The Church of England's pension board has introduced an eco-friendly investing index, rewarding companies that curb carbon-dioxide emissions in line with the 2015 Paris agreement and excluding those perceived as environmental laggards. The index, managed by the Church of England Pensions Board with FTSE Russell, invests £600 million in companies that meet environmental standards, including Royal Dutch Shell and Repsol. Companies that fail to meet targets, such as Exxon Mobil and Chevron, are excluded. The move aims to influence corporate behavior and align investments with long-term societal interests.

site_title: SIAS asks Utico, Hyflux to clarify scheme terms for PnP investors
summary: The Securities Investors Association (Singapore) is seeking clarification on several terms of Utico's proposed rescue deal for Hyflux's perpetual securities and preference shares (PnP). SIAS founder David Gerald requested confirmation on six points made by Utico's team during a Jan 20 town hall meeting, which SIAS believes require clarification. SIAS also requested detailed financial information to assess Utico's ability to meet its obligations under the proposed scheme, as Utico had previously provided only snippets of financial information.

site_title: Money FM podcast: The NUS Bizad Charity Run
summary: The NUS Bizad Charity Run, a fundraising event for the NUS Business School, aims to support those less privileged within the student community and elderly in society. Hosted by Claressa Monteiro, the podcast features Chua Hung Meng, vice-president of NUS Business School Alumni Association, and Kavin Seow, senior director of Elderly Group, TOUCH Community Services. The run raises funds for various charitable causes, with the funds going towards supporting the elderly and disadvantaged students. The event highlights the importance of corporate social responsibility and giving back to the community.

site_title: Nike warns of financial impact from coronavirus outbreak
summary: Nike warns of financial impact from the coronavirus outbreak in China, citing a 3% decline in its shares. The company has temporarily shut half of its Nike-owned stores and reduced hours at the remaining ones. China has been a key growth market for Nike, but the outbreak's financial impact is expected to be significant, with the company set to provide an update on its operational and financial impact during its third-quarter earnings call. The outbreak has killed over 400 people and infected more than 20,000 in mainland China, affecting the company's reliance on Chinese consumers.

site_title: China car sales likely to see record plunge in first two months of 2020
summary: China's car sales are expected to plummet 25-30% in the first two months of 2020 due to the coronavirus outbreak, with full-year sales potentially falling by 5%. The virus has already led to an unprecedented third straight annual decline in car sales before lockdowns were enforced. Companies, including Tesla and Volkswagen, are warning of production disruptions and potential supply chain issues. Economic activity is expected to take months to return to normal, and people's purchasing power will be undermined by falling incomes.

site_title: GuocoLand unit to issue S$200m 3.4% notes
summary: GuocoLand's subsidiary, GLL IHT, will issue S$200 million worth of new 3.4% notes maturing on Aug 10, 2025. The notes will be used to finance general working capital and corporate requirements, and will be guaranteed by GuocoLand. The re-offer yield is 205.9 basis points above the prevailing 5.5-year Singapore dollar swap offer rate. The new notes are part of GLL IHT's S$3 billion multicurrency medium-term note program, which also includes S$400 million in subordinated perpetual securities.

site_title: Australia's central bank keeps rates on hold at record low 0.75%
summary: Australia's central bank, the Reserve Bank of Australia, kept interest rates unchanged at a record low 0.75% as the labour and property markets remain strong despite the economic impact of China's slump. Governor Philip Lowe stated that the coronavirus' effect on the Chinese economy is too early to determine and the board will continue to monitor developments, prepared to ease monetary policy further if needed.

site_title: US: Tesla continues surge as stocks gain
summary: US stocks rose for a second consecutive session, gaining over 1% due to eased fears over the coronavirus outbreak in China. Major indices, including the Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite, advanced. Despite World Bank President David Malpass' forecast of a global growth slowdown, tech stocks surged, with Tesla reaching new records and gaining 13.7% on the day. Other leading tech companies, including Apple, Amazon, and Netflix, also rose.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks jumped on Tuesday, gaining for a second straight session as fears eased over an economic hit from the coronavirus outbreak in China.

site_title: HK reports first death from coronavirus; Macau shuts casinos to curb spread
summary: Hong Kong reported its first death from the coronavirus, bringing the global death toll to 427, with 20,438 cases in mainland China and nearly 200 cases in 24 countries. Macau shut down its casinos for two weeks to curb the spread. The World Health Organisation declared the virus a global emergency, citing unknown mortality rates and transmission routes. Hong Kong's public hospital network struggles to cope with the surge in patients, with thousands of medical workers on strike to press for border closure.

site_title: First local transmissions among six new infections
summary: Singapore reported six new Coronavirus cases, bringing the total to 24, with the first cases of transmission in the country. The six new cases include four women infected through human-to-human transmission and two individuals who recently arrived from Wuhan. The Ministry of Health urges employers to step up precautions. The total number of infected cases is now 24, with the first local transmissions among six new infections.

site_title: Japan quarantines 3,711 on cruise ship over novel coronavirus
summary: Japan has quarantined a cruise ship carrying 3,711 people after an 80-year-old passenger who recently disembarked in Hong Kong tested positive for the novel coronavirus. The ship, the Diamond Princess, had already been through a quarantine procedure in Japan's Okinawa, but a second quarantine was organized after the passenger's case emerged. Passengers and crew are being tested for the virus, as well as other infectious diseases, and the ship's departure from Yokohama has been delayed by at least 24 hours.

site_title: Virus throws China's economic plans into disarray
summary: China's economic plans are in disarray due to the coronavirus outbreak, forcing leaders to balance doubling per-person GDP and taming high debt levels. The country's economic growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. The trade war with the US has deepened, but policy restraint held last year, and economists were surprised by the lack of big-bang stimulus. With the coronavirus shutting down the economy, it appears one of China's key economic goals may have to be sacrificed. The country's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising concerns for the future.

site_title: UK-EU dissonance disguises fact that they are really singing from same song sheet
summary: The European Union and the United Kingdom are closer to achieving a trade deal than initially thought, with initial documents showing they're not too far apart. Contrary to negative media reports, the EU's 33-page outline doesn't suggest a hard Brexit, with both sides needing each other. Realpolitik is driving the negotiations, and a satisfactory deal is possible by the end of 2020, despite potential snags and disagreements.

site_title: Grab ventures into retail wealth management with Bento buy
summary: Grab, a digital bank contender, has acquired Singapore-based robo-advisory startup Bento for an undisclosed sum, expanding its retail wealth management capabilities. GrabInvest, the new entity, will offer cash management and portfolio-based financial solutions, operating under a retail wealth management capital markets services licence. The acquisition aims to make investments accessible to customers, regardless of their wallet size, and follows a market expected to reach $75 billion by 2025. GrabInvest will launch products on the Grab app in Singapore in the first half of the year, with plans to expand to other South-east Asian markets.

site_title: Spreading cheer with bags of 'blessings'
summary: Staff from Standard Chartered Bank in Singapore, along with over 1,300 volunteers, packed and delivered over 6,000 "bags of blessings" to seniors and families in need during the Chinese New Year. The event, themed "Home: For The Community, By The Community," was organized by Community Chest and aimed to provide essential items such as food and snacks to those in need. The initiative has been a long-time supporter of the event since 2009, with the bank encouraging its staff to participate through volunteer leave.

site_title: Inequality and economic growth can no longer be separated
summary: The article "Inequality and economic growth can no longer be separated" by Heather Boushey argues that economic policymakers must address inequality as a key factor in sustaining economic growth. The US tax system has become less progressive, and the wealthy have accumulated more wealth, leading to increased inequality. This, in turn, undermines economic growth by limiting market entry, allowing powerful incumbents to stifle competition and create barriers to new businesses. To address these issues, Boushey suggests implementing a modest wealth tax, updating antitrust policies to reduce barriers to market entry, and changing campaign-finance and lobbying rules to reduce the influence of the wealthy.

site_title: Outbreak adds to demand surge for food delivery plays
summary: Food delivery and e-commerce players in Singapore are experiencing a surge in sales volumes due to the novel coronavirus outbreak, with four out of seven tech companies reporting a 30% increase in sales over the past week. Companies like Deliveroo, foodpanda, and GrabFood have seen an uptick in orders, with some attributing the increase to Lunar New Year promotions. E-commerce platforms are also experiencing increased demand for healthcare products, with Qoo10 listing surgical masks as its top searched item.

site_title: Firms should have a contingency plan in place - even to thwart short sellers
summary: The novel coronavirus outbreak has created opportunities for short sellers, who aim to capitalize on fear and falling prices. Companies should have a contingency plan in place to minimize the impact of a short selling attack, which can cause significant share price volatility. A prompt and transparent response is crucial, and halting trading temporarily can help mitigate damage. Companies should focus on debunking specific concerns and provide clear information to shareholders, rather than issuing generic statements. Having a plan in place can help companies survive such attacks and preserve shareholder wealth.

site_title: Mindful Wealth re-domiciles CLO fund to Singapore after VCC pilot
summary: Boutique wealth management firm Mindful Wealth has completed the Variable Capital Companies (VCC) pilot program and re-domiciled its Avenida CLO Equity Fund from the Bahamas to Singapore. The fund, which manages $80 million in assets, focuses on the equity tranche of collateralized loan obligations (CLOs). The move is part of Singapore's efforts to attract fund managers, following the launch of the VCC structure and grant scheme in January.

site_title: Manufacturers' group says delayed return of China workers affect 1-in-10 staff
summary: Singapore manufacturers are feeling the impact of the delayed return of Chinese workers due to the coronavirus, affecting about 1-in-10 staff. The Ministry of Manpower reported 30,000 Chinese work pass holders are outside the country, with the manufacturing sector hit harder than other industries. While some companies are concerned about space constraints, others are exploring alternatives such as automation and productivity measures. The industry is also considering hiring Singaporean or Malaysian temporary staff to fill the gap, and experts warn that Singapore's attractiveness as a destination for Chinese labor may have faded due to rising wages in China.

site_title: Apple suppliers aim to resume full China production on Feb 10
summary: Apple's major suppliers in China, including Hon Hai Precision Industry Co, plan to resume full-scale production on February 10, despite the ongoing coronavirus outbreak. The move comes despite growing doubts about the timing due to rising virus death tolls, worker lockdowns, and transportation disruptions. Suppliers such as Quanta Computer Inc and LG Display Co also plan to restart production next week. Apple has already closed its corporate offices and stores in mainland China due to the outbreak, and its shares have been impacted by the uncertainty.

site_title: Aussie dollar rises as risk appetite picks up
summary: The Australian dollar rose 0.5% to US$0.6725, while the offshore Chinese yuan gained 0.4% to US$6.879 per dollar, as risk appetite increased despite a novel coronavirus outbreak in China. The Reserve Bank of Australia left its main cash rate unchanged at 0.75%. Chinese stocks rose, and the central bank vowed to stabilize the market. The death toll in China from the outbreak rose to 425, with 20,438 cases reported.

site_title: Coronavirus curbs leave Hubei poultry farmers helpless
summary: Poultry farmers in Hubei province, where the coronavirus originated, are struggling due to a ban on live animal transport, feed supply, and slaughterhouses. The ban has forced farmers to euthanize young birds, halve rations, or dispose of them, with some producing only 7,000 eggs a day. The restrictions have also impacted hatcheries and slaughterhouses, leading to reduced capacity and labor shortages. The situation is expected to worsen unless the measures are extended, with supplies of fast-growing meat chickens potentially plummeting in about two months.

site_title: Cyber security must not be overlooked
summary: Respectable and well-protected corporations remain vulnerable to cyber attacks, despite their resources. Large corporations, especially those in Asia-Pacific, are targeted due to their valuable data and financial information. The article cites Toyota's data breaches in Japan, exposing 3.1 million clients' personal information. Public organisations in Singapore, with their strategic business plans and financial reports, are also at risk. To mitigate these threats, public organisations must ensure strict compliance with external vendors before engaging them, highlighting the need for vigilance in protecting sensitive data.

images.alt_text: Once large organisations have identified gaps in their current cyber security strategy, they are in a better position to bounce back from a cyber attack and learn from their mistakes.

site_title: STI gains as relief rally lifts Asian markets
summary: Asian markets experienced a relief rally on Tuesday, following a bloodbath on Monday, as investors were encouraged by China's slower rate of new coronavirus cases and the central bank's injection of $230 billion into its financial markets. The US also reported strong January manufacturing data. Despite this, the spread of the virus remains a key concern.

site_title: The big takeaway from Australia: men's and women's tennis are in very different places
summary: The men's and women's tennis scenes are vastly different, with the men's tour dominated by a duopoly of Novak Djokovic and Rafael Nadal, while the women's tour has seen a surge of new winners in recent years. Since 2006, seven men have won major singles titles, while 25 women have achieved the feat. Djokovic's focus and visualization have contributed to his success, and he is now in his 276th week at No. 1, chasing Federer's record. Meanwhile, young stars like Dominic Thiem and Coco Gauff are pushing the boundaries of what's possible, but still face an uphill battle to break through the dominance of the Big Three.

site_title: Liquidity still aplenty for Singapore, with investors in the hunt for real estate yield
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to be short-livedly impacted by the novel coronavirus outbreak, with the government's multiple defense lines preventing the spread of the virus. As of Tuesday, Singapore has 24 confirmed cases, with no deaths reported. The impact will mainly be felt in the hospitality, retail, and F&B sectors, with limited effect on office and industrial sectors. Liquidity remains high, and investors are seeking yield in the real estate sector, with well-managed assets expected to recover over time.

site_title: MICE events shelved due to virus outbreak fears
summary: Singapore's meetings, incentive travel, conferences and exhibitions (MICE) scene is being affected by the coronavirus outbreak, with several events being cancelled or postponed. The National Association of Travel Agents Singapore postponed its annual travel fair to May, and the Singapore Airshow Aviation Leadership Summit has been cancelled due to concerns over turnout. Other events, including the BuildTech Asia and IT Show, have also seen exhibitor withdrawals and venue uncertainty. Organisers are assessing the situation and considering postponement or cancellation options to ensure attendee safety.

site_title: Developers likely to proceed with launches amid virus outbreak
summary: Singapore's property developers are likely to proceed with launches despite the coronavirus outbreak, with analysts predicting a decrease in visitorship to showflats and transaction volumes. Developers are taking precautions, such as temperature checks and sanitizers, to minimize the risk of transmission. While sentiment is dampened, high-end luxury properties may face slower take-up rates, and the resale market may perform better in relative terms. Sales volumes for units in the primary and resale markets are expected to fall in the first quarter, but developers are unlikely to cut prices or drastically change their pipeline launches.

site_title: Kenya's former president Daniel arap Moi dies at 95
summary: Kenya's former president Daniel arap Moi, 95, died Tuesday, according to the office of the president. Moi, who served as president from 1978-2002, kept the country relatively stable but struggled to address poverty and corruption. The cause of his death is not immediately known, but he had been in and out of hospital with breathing problems.

site_title: US factory orders post largest increase in nearly 18 months
summary: US factory orders surged 1.8% in December, the largest gain in nearly 18 months, driven by strong demand for defense aircraft. However, weak business spending on equipment and limited scope for a sharp rebound in manufacturing remain concerns. The Commerce Department reported a 0.6% decline in factory orders for 2019, despite a 1.8% increase in December shipments of manufactured goods. Risks persist due to ongoing trade tensions, the coronavirus, and Boeing's suspended 737 MAX production.

site_title: 'Superbond' cools the world's hottest real estate market
summary: Hungary's "superbond" initiative, a state-backed debt instrument offering 5% annual returns, has cooled the world's hottest real estate market. Since its launch last June, $10.5 billion has been invested in MAP+, diverting funds from real estate and reducing prices. The move, aimed at reducing reliance on foreign creditors, has led to a 56% drop in retail-property transactions and a quarterly drop in housing prices. Experts predict the market will stagnate in 2020, with the government describing the market as "bubble-like."

site_title: WWF launches online tool to encourage sustainable investing
summary: The World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF) launched an online tool called "Respond" to help asset managers align their portfolios with a low-carbon, sustainable future. The tool provides a foundation of basic questions and best-practice providers for ESG-conscious investors, covering 22 European-based firms with Asian operations managing $12.7 trillion. The tool is initially available to family offices, private banks, and institutional investors, but WWF aims to expand it to the general public and other markets within a year. The goal is to support asset managers in implementing sustainability into their overall strategy.

site_title: EU climate ambition comes under scrutiny
summary: The European Union is reviewing its climate ambition, with lawmakers expressing concerns about the economic impact of more ambitious targets. EU Parliamentarian Peter Liese calls for a step-by-step approach, recommending assessments of lower emissions before setting intermediary targets for 2030. The EU's Green Deal, aiming to make the continent carbon neutral by mid-century, faces complexity in its shift affecting various sectors. The European Commission plans to present a law to enshrine the climate neutrality objective into existing legislation, followed by an impact assessment this summer.

site_title: Rich Capital, related parties facing legal suit by Batam project partner
summary: Rich Capital and its related parties are being sued by Karya Indo Batam (KIB) for alleged conspiracy and project mismanagement in a property development project in Batam. KIB claims damages for conspiracy and breach of the shareholder's agreement, seeking S$20 million in compensation. The lawsuit follows two previous letters served by KIB, which demanded full control of the joint venture and compensation. Rich Capital has formally rejected and denied the allegations and is seeking legal advice to resist the claims.

site_title: WHO working on recommendations for resuming flights to China
summary: The World Health Organisation (WHO) is holding a teleconference with travel and tourism industry representatives to develop recommendations on protecting flight crews to resume flights to China. WHO Director Sylvie Briand emphasized the need for specific guidelines to ensure crew safety, as they have close contact with passengers. She noted that masks will not provide 100% protection for healthy individuals, and frequent hand-washing and hygiene measures are crucial. The WHO is also seeking clarifications from countries on their measures and restrictions, and hopes for a realignment of policies on evacuations from China.

site_title: US, Japan to cooperate on energy, infrastructure investment
summary: The US and Japan signed a memorandum of cooperation to encourage private investment in energy and infrastructure projects, addressing regulatory barriers and developing innovative solutions for regional debt markets. The effort aims to compete with China's Belt and Road initiative and boost bilateral investment. The agreement seeks to "crowd-in institutional investors," enhance liquefied natural gas markets, and promote commodity trading. The initiative is part of the Trump administration's private-sector led solutions to counter China's infrastructure drive.

site_title: Ex-Indonesian Cabinet minister joins VC firm East Ventures
summary: East Ventures, an Indonesia-focused venture capital firm, has appointed former Indonesian Cabinet minister Triawan Munaf as its first venture adviser. Munaf will help Indonesian startups scale their impact at a regional level, leveraging his government and entrepreneurial experience. East Ventures plans to bolster its portfolio and focus on generating impact for Indonesia's startup space. Munaf, currently the president commissioner of Garuda Indonesia and honorary adviser of the Tourism and Creative Economy Ministry, shares East Ventures' values and aims to develop Indonesia's digital economy.

site_title: All eyes on next marine fuel deadline
summary: The International Maritime Organization's (IMO) 0.50% sulphur limit in fuel has been in effect for a month, with the global shipping industry generally complying with the regulations. Shipowners who installed scrubbers to burn high sulphur fuel oil (HSFO) are reportedly seeing financial benefits, while those using very low sulphur fuel oil (VLSFO) face higher prices due to increased demand and limited supply. However, issues with sulphur content and sediment in some fuels are causing concerns, and the industry must ensure compliance by the March 1 deadline.

site_title: Virus to delay US 'export boom' from China deal, Kudlow says
summary: The US trade deal with China is expected to delay the country's "export boom" due to the coronavirus outbreak. White House economic adviser Larry Kudlow stated the economic impact will be minimal, despite over 20,600 reported cases. Economists have cut forecasts for Chinese economic growth, but Kudlow said the US won't use the outbreak as leverage in trade talks. The administration will instead focus on tax cuts, with plans to announce "tax cut 2.0" proposals during President Trump's re-election campaign. The economic impact is expected to be minimal, according to Kudlow.

site_title: Tech employees optimistic about Singapore's prospects: SGInnovate study
summary: Tech employees in Singapore remain optimistic about the country's prospects as a global science and technology hub, with 88% believing it will remain competitive over the next decade. The study, conducted by SGInnovate, found that respondents value the government's clear direction and the ecosystem created in Singapore. However, there is a need for improvement in soft skill sets and entrepreneurial spirit. The industry is expected to focus on emerging technologies like AI and cybersecurity, leading to new job opportunities such as geospatial experts and clinician-scientists.

images.alt_text: Tech employees in Singapore are optimistic about their prospects here as they believe the Republic's science and technology industry will remain competitive for the next decade, a study by SGInnovate has found.

site_title: Tech staff optimistic about Singapore's prospects: SGInnovate study
summary: Tech staff in Singapore remain optimistic about the country's prospects as a global science and technology hub, with 88% believing it will remain competitive in the next decade. The majority (84%) find pursuing an R&D or technical role rewarding in terms of career prospects and remuneration. The government's clear direction is cited as the top reason for this optimism. However, respondents also highlighted the need for improvement in soft skill sets and entrepreneurial spirit among tech professionals, with a focus on emerging roles such as geospatial experts and clinician-scientists.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Acromec secured a S$19.5 million sub-contract to supply air-conditioning systems at a new medical building in Singapore General Hospital. Keppel Infrastructure Trust's subsidiary, Ixom Watercare, acquired Medora Environmental for an undisclosed sum, expanding its source water management services. Ntegrator International secured a S$6.6 million contract from a repeat customer for pipeline and cable installation in Singapore. Sim Leisure Group signed a non-binding agreement to develop theme parks in Sri Lanka.

site_title: Novel coronavirus - China needs less politics, more science
summary: China's response to the novel coronavirus outbreak has been marked by a lack of scientific approach, instead relying on the government's ability to mobilize resources. The public's attitudes are divisive, with some blaming the system and others extolling its virtues. A scientific approach is crucial in understanding the origin and spread of the virus, and the government should prioritize science over politics. The country's history of relying on politics to solve problems has led to a culture of obedience, excluding science from daily life. A national science movement is needed to bring science into the lives of the Chinese people and promote a scientific culture.

site_title: UK threatens 'Australian Brexit' if Canada deal rejected
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson has threatened to pursue a "no-deal" Brexit, akin to an Australian model, if the EU refuses a Canadian-style trade agreement. This move comes after Johnson declared that a Canadian-style deal is the best way to achieve a post-Brexit "global Britain." A Canadian-style deal would allow the UK to diverge from EU rules, but would also come with significant costs, including loss of preferential access to 50 markets outside Europe. Johnson's threat has raised the stakes, with many fearing a hard, disorderly Brexit.

site_title: Retail rents up but not much cheer for landlords
summary: Singapore retail rents have shown a 2.9% rise in the Central Region in 2019, reversing a 1% decline in 2018. The Orchard Road shopping belt saw a 5.9% increase, driven by high-end fashion brands that continue to attract customers. In contrast, demand for retail space in secondary locations remains lacklustre. The industry faces challenges from e-commerce, labour shortages, and high rents, leading landlords to pressure tenants to fill space in less performing malls. A coronavirus outbreak may further impact retail rents, but a lack of catalysts for a significant rental recovery is expected.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 13.85 points to 1,535.80, closing higher on Tuesday. The index gained 552-351 in favor of gainers over losers, with a total volume of 3 billion lots worth RM2.6 billion.

site_title: Banks have a key weakness in preparing for Brexit: Their clients
summary: Germany's top financial regulator, BaFin President Felix Hufeld, warns that banks' clients are a key weakness in preparing for Brexit. Despite banks having set up units in the EU to retain access to UK markets, they are not moving client business to these hubs at the required pace. On average, banks have only completed less than a third of the work needed to move client business to EU hubs, which could lead to financial centers like New York and Singapore gaining an advantage. This could result in lost business for banks and the UK.

site_title: Altrium PE fund of funds a hit among high net worth clients
summary: Azalea Investment Management, a Temasek subsidiary, successfully raised US$650 million for its first fund of funds, Altrium Private Equity Fund I, targeting accredited investors. The fund aims to provide a low-to-mid-teens internal rate of return through a diversified portfolio of private equity funds across the US, Europe, and Asia. Azalea's innovative structure, which includes investible bonds listed on the Singapore Exchange, offers liquidity and reduces the 10- to 15-year lock-in period. This marks a significant milestone for Azalea, which has been working to democratize private equity for retail investors.

site_title: Former Kenyan president Daniel arap Moi dead at 95
summary: Former Kenyan president Daniel arap Moi has died at 95, according to President Uhuru Kenyatta. Moi's 24-year rule was marked by authoritarianism, corruption, and tribal divisions. Despite this, he is remembered for his efforts to consolidate peace in the Horn of Africa and his role in Kenya's transition to multiparty politics. Moi's legacy is complex, with both praise and criticism for his rule. A period of national mourning has been declared, and a state funeral is planned.

site_title: Disney bans hugs and China cleans cash in virus-sparked hygiene
summary: Disney has restricted hugs with its mascots at Tokyo Disney, while McDonald's in Shanghai requires customers to register and sterilize their hands before picking up food. The People's Bank of China has begun disinfecting cash with ultraviolet light and replacing old notes with new bills. In other efforts to combat the coronavirus, banks are requiring employees to wear gloves, and some companies are allowing remote work or restricting employee interactions. These measures aim to protect staff and customers from the rapidly spreading virus.

site_title: Commodities to take bigger hit from coronavirus than from Sars: analysts
summary: The novel coronavirus is expected to have a longer and larger impact on global commodity markets than the Sars outbreak in 2003. China's growing share of the world's GDP, from 4.2% in 2003 to 16.3% now, and its increased global economic footprint, are contributing factors. Analysts predict a more significant decline in metal prices, particularly copper and steel, with oil prices also expected to take a hit. However, gold and silver prices are expected to rise due to favourable investment sentiment and low interest rates.

site_title: CSE Global secures S$230m worth of new orders in Q4 2019
summary: CSE Global secured S$230 million in new orders for the fourth quarter of 2019, exceeding its order book of S$300 million. The new orders include S$190 million for the oil and gas sector, S$25 million for the infrastructure sector, and S$16 million for the mining sector. The developments are expected to have minimal impact on the group's consolidated net tangible assets per share or earnings per share for the year ended December 31, 2019.

site_title: Russian govt pulled 1.6t roubles from banks in Dec as Putin revives stimulus plan
summary: Russia's finance ministry withdrew 1.6 trillion roubles ($34.7 billion) from banks in December, doubling the outflow from the same period in 2018, as part of President Vladimir Putin's stimulus plan. The plan, initially valued at $400 billion, aims to lift the economy into the world's top five by 2024. Following a new government appointment, budget spending rose to 3.3 trillion roubles in December, ahead of the year-end. The outflow is attributed to the need to speed up strategic spending.

site_title: SGX, IPOS tie up to promote intangible asset disclosures
summary: The Intellectual Property Office of Singapore (IPOS) and Singapore Exchange (SGX) have partnered to launch the Intangible Disclosure Evaluation and Audit Scheme (IDEAS) to promote intangible asset (IA) disclosures among SGX-listed companies and those preparing for a listing. The pilot programme will run until the end of 2020 and provides government support for IA evaluations and audits to help companies identify key IA information. Companies such as Revez Corporation and Hyphens Pharma International have joined the programme, with IPOS and SGX aiming to raise awareness and encourage IA disclosures.

site_title: Corporate turnaround whizz will need luck as WeWork's new CEO
summary: WeWork appoints 57-year-old corporate turnaround expert Sandeep Mathrani as its new CEO, replacing Adam Neumann. Mathrani, known for his success in leading General Growth Properties out of bankruptcy, will report to Marcelo Claure, WeWork's executive chairman and SoftBank Group's operating chief. He aims to refocus the company on office rentals and shed passion projects, with a goal of achieving positive cash flow by 2023. Mathrani's appointment comes after WeWork's IPO plan collapsed last year, and the company agreed to sever ties with Neumann, who received an exit package worth over $1 billion.

site_title: Japfa raises S$92.6m from oversubscribed rights issue
summary: Japfa, a mainboard-listed agri-food firm, raised S$92.6 million from its oversubscribed rights issue, with 186.3 million rights shares available for subscription. The issue closed 36.4% oversubscribed. The net proceeds will be used to repay debt, with S$16.9 million for a revolving facility, S$13 million for a term facility, and S$62.7 million for a syndicated facilities agreement. The shareholder, controlled by Rangi Management, will hold 51.8% of the enlarged share capital after the issue.

site_title: Oil rebounds on potential for further Opec+ supply cuts
summary: Oil prices rebounded on Tuesday as investors hoped for further Opec+ supply cuts to offset potential demand drops from the coronavirus outbreak. Brent crude rose 1.7% to $55.38 a barrel and WTI crude rose 2.4% to $51.31 a barrel. The gains followed a two-week slide on concerns over the global economic impact of the coronavirus.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: A major international aviation summit in Singapore was cancelled due to coronavirus fears, casting doubt on the Asia's largest aerospace event. Grab acquired robo-advisory firm Bento, rebranding it as GrabInvest. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) and the International Private Securities (IPOS) tied up to promote intangible asset disclosures. Meanwhile, Singapore shares rose 1.3% as relief rallies supported markets, with the Straits Times Index (STI) ending at 3,156.57.

site_title: Hwa Hong posts higher Q4 earnings of S$2.1m, proposes dividend
summary: Hwa Hong Corporation posted higher Q4 earnings of S$2.1 million, driven by increased rental income and investment dividends. Revenue more than doubled to S$5.9 million. The company proposes a dividend of one cent per share, to be paid on May 15, 2020. Despite stabilizing London residential market, the group expects the coronavirus outbreak to negatively impact business sentiment and the equity markets.

site_title: Batam project partner sues Rich Capital, other parties
summary: Rich Capital and its associates are being sued by Karya Indo Batam (KIB) for alleged conspiracy and project mismanagement in a property development project in Batam. KIB claims damages for an alleged breach of the shareholders agreement and conspiracy, seeking S$20 million in compensation. The dispute began in September when KIB served legal letters demanding full control of the joint venture and compensation. Rich Capital has formally rejected and denied the allegations. The parties are now seeking legal advice to resist the allegations and consider counterclaims.

site_title: US: Wall Street jumps 1% at open as China stimulus calms investor nerves
summary: Wall Street experienced a 1% gain at the open on Tuesday, marking a second day of recovery from a coronavirus-driven sell-off. China's central bank intervened with fresh stimulus measures, calming investor nerves. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 296.93 points, the S&P 500 gained 31.69 points, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 124.99 points. This recovery follows a sell-off last week and amid ongoing US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Analysts downgrade Thailand growth forecast due to virus
summary: Analysts have downgraded Thailand's 2020 growth forecast due to the novel coronavirus, with Citi economist Nalin Chutchotitham revising her forecast to 2.2% and Oxford Economics economist Sian Fenner to 2%. The virus is expected to impact tourism, with a potential 1 percentage point reduction in growth, but could be offset by reduced outbound travel by Thai residents. A drought is also expected to shave off 0.1 percentage point from growth. Both economists expect some bounce-back in tourism in the second half of the year.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks rally as investors bet on more China stimulus
summary: South Korean stocks surged 1.84% on Tuesday, their largest gain since January 2019, as investors bet on more Chinese stimulus to counter the economic impact of coronavirus. China's central bank injected $242.74 billion into the market, and analysts expect additional measures to boost liquidity and consumption. Foreigners were net buyers of $410.06 million worth of shares, with the KOSPI index closing at 2,157.90.

images.alt_text: The Seoul stock market's main Kospi ended up 39.02 points, or 1.84 per cent, at 2,157.90, posting its steepest daily gain since Jan 9, 2019.

site_title: No longer niche: Oscar contenders embraced beyond the art house
summary: This year's Oscar best-picture nominees feature six films that have grossed over $100 million worldwide, a trend that bucks the previous year's focus on independent films. Blockbusters like "Joker" ($1.07 billion) and Quentin Tarantino's "Once Upon a Time in Hollywood" ($389.3 million) are among the contenders, as well as World War One epic "1917" and racing drama "Ford v Ferrari". The shift in focus has been welcomed by critics, who argue that it shows the Academy is more in touch with movie audiences, and that popular films can be just as impactful as art house ones.

site_title: Manpower affected by leave of absence: Singapore Hotel Association
summary: Singapore hotels face manpower disruption due to leave of absence policies. The Singapore Hotel Association notes that most housekeeping employees and outsourced partners are from China, affected by the 14-day leave policy for returning residents and long-term pass holders. Travel restrictions have been implemented to combat the ongoing virus outbreak. This may impact hotels' operations, exacerbating existing reduced travel demand.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets extend recovery at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Tuesday, extending a recovery after last week's slide triggered by coronavirus fears. London's FTSE 100 rallied 1.1% to 7,408.08 points, while the eurozone's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 climbed 0.7% and 0.6% respectively. The recovery is attributed to gains in the mining and healthcare sectors.

site_title: Ralph Lauren jumps on sales gains even amid China virus fears
summary: Ralph Lauren reported a 2% increase in same-store sales worldwide and a 4% increase in same-store sales in North America, beating projections. Despite a volatile economic environment and issues in Asia, including a viral outbreak, the company expects a 2-3% increase in net revenue for the full year. CEO Patrice Louvet attributed the results to investments in reinvigorating the brand, which are expected to raise the average price of its goods. The company's Asian sales fell 1% in the quarter, but Louvet expressed confidence in the company's gameplan.

images.alt_text: Ralph Lauren surged in early trading after posting sales that topped estimates globally and in North America, even as the apparel seller navigates a tumultuous environment for luxury goods in Asia.

site_title: 46 Singapore F&B companies take their fare to the Middle East
summary: 46 Singapore food and beverage companies are participating in the Gulfood 2020 trade show in Dubai, showcasing over 20 food prototypes and local products such as steamed glutinous rice and meat-free satay. This comes amid growing demand for affordable and high-quality Asian food in the Middle East, with food exports from Singapore to the region increasing steadily over the past three years. The Singapore Food Manufacturers' Association is leading the delegation, which includes 11 first-time participants, and will also engage in business networking sessions with Middle East investors and traders.

site_title: BP bucks oil industry gloom
summary: BP has reported a fourth-quarter profit of $2.57 billion, beating analyst estimates, and increased its dividend by 2.4% to 10.5 cents a share. The company's output increased 2.7% to 3.781 million barrels of oil equivalent a day, driven by a strong upstream performance and lower petrochemical exposure. Despite high debt levels, BP's gearing remains above its target, and the company plans to reduce its debt burden through asset sales and capital spending cuts. New CEO Bernard Looney will focus on tackling climate change, with a major de-leveraging of the balance sheet expected this year.

site_title: Singapore shares gain 1.3% as relief rally supports markets
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 1.3% on Tuesday, driven by a relief rally in Asian markets following the reopening of Chinese markets from the Lunar New Year break. The rally was fueled by slower rate of new coronavirus cases and strong US manufacturing data. Shares in Medtecs International fell 4.8% despite high trading volume, while tourism- and travel-related industries continued to take a hit due to virus concerns. Analysts expect the market to shift from fear to data-driven decisions as the economic impact of the virus becomes more apparent.

site_title: China opens coronavirus hospital built from scratch in under two weeks
summary: China has opened a 1,000-bed coronavirus hospital in Wuhan, built from scratch in under two weeks. The facility was constructed to alleviate hospital congestion and is a response to the national health emergency. Fifty patients arrived at the military-run facility, marking the beginning of operations. The hospital's construction was a national social media sensation, demonstrating China's rapid response to the outbreak.

site_title: China car sales to see historic plunge in first months of 2020
summary: China's car sales are expected to slump by 25-30% in the first two months of 2020 due to the coronavirus outbreak, according to a preliminary forecast by China Passenger Car Association. The virus has already caused China's economy to close two-thirds of its operations, leading to potential supply-chain issues and parts shortages. Automakers such as Tesla and Volkswagen are warning of disruptions in their operations, with possible production cuts of 15% in China this quarter. If sales fall 20% from last year's 21.4 million units, it could threaten China's status as the world's largest auto market.

site_title: Jewellery maker Pandora sees sales decline in 2020
summary: Pandora, a Danish jewellery maker, reported an improvement in fourth-quarter sales, but expects only a 3-6% organic sales growth for 2020, down from a 2019 drop of 8%. The company attributed this to significant changes made in a short time frame, with consumers responding positively to commercial initiatives. Pandora's operating profit margin is expected to be 23%, down from 26.8% in 2019. The forecast does not account for the impact of the coronavirus in China, where the company has closed 53 shops.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end the day higher
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rose 1.21% to 26,675.98, following modest gains on Monday, as investors tracked developments in the outbreak with little major reaction to the first virus-linked death. Shanghai stocks rallied, with the Shanghai Composite Index jumping 1.34%, boosted by a huge injection of cash into the financial system by China's central bank. The Chinese government pumped $173 billion into the economy on Monday and almost $60 billion more on Tuesday to help stabilize markets.

site_title: SIAS asks Utico, Hyflux to clarify scheme terms for PnP investors
summary: The Securities Investors Association (SIAS) in Singapore is seeking clarification from Utico and Hyflux on several terms of Utico's proposed rescue deal for Hyflux's perpetual securities and preference shares (PnP). SIAS has identified six areas of uncertainty, including the payment structure for investors with multiple accounts, the interest rate on deferred amounts, and the potential for a "soft landing" payment even after the two-year listing period. SIAS is requesting confirmation from Utico and Hyflux to ensure transparency and fairness for PnP investors.

site_title: Australia: Shares close higher on banks, healthcare stocks; NZ down
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% to 6,948.7 points, recouping losses from the previous session, driven by financial and healthcare stocks. The Reserve Bank of Australia maintained its cash rate at record lows, boosting financial sector gains. Healthcare stocks rose 0.6% on CSL Ltd's approval for an influenza vaccine. However, the coronavirus outbreak in China capped gains, with economists predicting an interest rate cut by the RBA in April. New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.34% due to losses in energy and healthcare stocks.

site_title: Coronavirus crisis upends global commodity trade flows
summary: Global commodities trade is being severely impacted by China's coronavirus crisis, with demand for raw materials plummeting 20% and refineries curtailing operations. This has led to a surge in commodity price volatility, with copper smelters considering output cuts and crop shipments stuck at ports. Major companies such as Anglo American and Rio Tinto have restricted travel, and OPEC is considering an emergency meeting to address the crisis. The crisis has already caused chaos in the commodities world, with Chinese refiners looking to offload unwanted crude cargoes and demand for Latin American oil stalled.

site_title: Macau asks casinos to suspend operations to curb coronavirus spread
summary: Macau's casinos have been asked to temporarily close due to the coronavirus outbreak, with at least 10 confirmed cases in the territory. This move is the longest-ever halt and second instance, following a 2018 typhoon shutdown. The closure is the latest blow to Macau's struggling gambling industry, which is facing its worst annual revenue decline since 2015. The Bloomberg Intelligence index of Macau operators fell 3.7% on the news, with MGM China Holdings Ltd and Galaxy Entertainment Group Ltd being the worst performers.

site_title: Coronavirus: Singapore reports first cases of local transmission
summary: Singapore has reported its first cases of local coronavirus transmission, with four women infected who had not traveled to Wuhan, the epicenter of the outbreak. The cases are linked to a Chinese health products shop and a tour group that returned from Wuhan. The country has 24 confirmed cases and is taking measures to contain the spread, including cleaning public areas, suspending school activities, and restricting travel to China. Health Minister Gan Kim Yong warned that if community transmission spreads, Singapore will consider additional measures to reduce human-to-human interactions.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close higher on rebound in Shanghai stocks
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Tuesday as investors breathed relief over a recovery in Shanghai shares, which were hit by the coronavirus. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.49% to 22,084.59, while the Topix index gained 0.69%. Panasonic surged 10.04% after maintaining its earnings forecast, and Toyota rose 0.77% on bargain-hunting. Despite this, some China-related shares were lower, and Sony edged down 0.03%. The rebound in Shanghai shares alleviated selling pressure, with investors feeling comfortable buying back shares.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon up 1.29% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 1.29% on Tuesday, reaching 3,156.43, driven by gains in banking stocks. DBS, UOB, and OCBC led the rally, while Asiatic gained 12.5% and Medtecs International lost 6.4%. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index also rose 1.0%, led by South Korea and Australia.

site_title: For China virus insurance, check the small print
summary: Insurance companies may not cover the global disruption caused by the China virus epidemic, with basic travel policies unlikely to provide coverage. Individuals are advised to consult their credit card or travel providers for refunds and medical costs. Companies, such as airlines, may also face challenges in getting recourse from their insurers if they cancel plans due to the epidemic.

site_title: Carlsberg says coronavirus to curb beer sales
summary: Carlsberg forecasts slower earnings growth for 2020 due to the coronavirus outbreak in China, which threatens beer consumption in Asia. Adjusted earnings rose 10.5% in 2019, and the company expects mid-single-digit growth this year. The Danish brewer cites competition in Russia and a new drunk-driving law in Vietnam as additional challenges. Carlsberg's conservative forecast sets a subdued tone for rivals Anheuser-Busch InBev and Heineken, which have prioritized Asia as a key growth engine.

site_title: Hong Kong reports first coronavirus death as hospital workers escalate strike
summary: Hong Kong reported its first coronavirus death, a 39-year-old male who had visited Wuhan, China, as hospital workers escalated a strike to force the government to close the city's borders with mainland China. The death toll in China rose to over 420, with at least 151 cases in 23 countries. Hong Kong has 15 confirmed cases, including one transmitted locally. Medical workers, including nurses, are on strike, calling for better protection and border closure. The government has rejected calls to shut the border, citing impracticality and discrimination.

site_title: Workplace app Asana files to go public, may opt for direct listing
summary: Asana, a San Francisco-based workplace app, confidentially filed paperwork with the US Securities and Exchange Commission to go public through a direct listing. This move is expected to save millions in underwriting fees and avoid diluting ownership stakes. Founded in 2008 by Dustin Moskovitz and Justin Rosenstein, Asana is valued at around $1.5 billion. The direct listing is the latest trend in the tech industry, following companies like Spotify Technology and Slack Technologies. Asana's listing is pending SEC review and is expected to take place after completion.

site_title: Chinese cities locked down far from coronavirus epicentre
summary: Chinese cities Taizhou and three districts in Hangzhou have restricted residents' movement due to coronavirus concerns, with one person allowed to leave every two days for necessities. The cities, home to over 9 million people, are far from the epicentre of the outbreak. This move is part of China's efforts to contain the spread of the virus.

images.alt_text: Two more cities in China's eastern province of Zhejiang have restricted the movement of residents over fears of the spread of the coronavirus, far from the epicentre of the health emergency.

site_title: The Business of Sustainability: Why Adopting Circular Economy Practices Can Lead to Growth
summary: Malaysia and other Southeast Asian countries are facing significant climate change risks, with potential losses of 3% of regional GDP by 2050. To mitigate these effects, adopting circular economy practices is crucial. The circular economy model, which aims to extend the life of goods and materials, can help reduce waste and pollution. Many companies are already embracing this approach, with 98% of surveyed executives familiar with circular economy principles. However, more needs to be done to instill sustainability practices, and governments, businesses, and consumers must work together to prioritize sustainability.

site_title: Two shophouses off Serangoon Road up for sale with S$6.6m guide price
summary: Two freehold shophouses at 24 and 26 Moonstone Lane in Singapore are up for sale with a guide price of S$6.6 million. The properties occupy 2,877 sq ft and have a combined existing built-up area of 4,628 sq ft. They are zoned for residential use with commercial space on the first floor and could be redeveloped into a mixed-use development with a total gross floor area of 8,632 sq ft, subject to authorities' approval. The sale is expected to benefit from the URA's vision to transform areas along the Kallang River into a lifestyle hub.

site_title: Japan quarantines 3,700 on cruise ship over new coronavirus
summary: Japan has quarantined a cruise ship carrying 3,711 people after a former passenger was diagnosed with the new coronavirus in Hong Kong. Eight people on board have symptoms such as fever, and the vessel's departure from Yokohama will be delayed by at least 24 hours. Passengers and crew underwent a previous quarantine in Okinawa, but a second quarantine was organized after the Hong Kong case emerged. The health ministry is testing those with symptoms and other infectious diseases, and a decision on docking the vessel will be made at the quarantine station.

site_title: Hiap Seng to provide plant maintenance services for SRC refinery
summary: HIAP Seng Engineering has secured a three-year contract with Singapore Refining Company (SRC) to provide plant maintenance services for the SRC refinery on Jurong Island, effective from Jan 1, 2020, to Dec 31, 2022. The contract is valued at S$75 million, with an option to extend for two more years. Hiap Seng expects a positive contribution to its earnings but does not anticipate a significant impact on its net tangible assets or earnings per share.

site_title: Yoma Strategic tie-up extends online payment services in Myanmar
summary: MAINBOARD-LISTED Yoma Strategic Holdings' Myanmar-based joint venture Wave Money has partnered with 2C2P to enable 17 million WavePay users to make payments to merchants without a bank account. The partnership will initially allow users to pay for ticket purchases on regional airlines, with plans to roll out to other merchants in the coming months. This expansion aims to increase online payment services in Myanmar.

site_title: SGX, IPOS tie up to promote intangible asset disclosures
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) and Intellectual Property Office of Singapore (IPOS) have partnered to launch the Intangible Disclosure Evaluation and Audit Scheme (IDEAS), a pilot program aimed at promoting intangible asset (IA) disclosures among SGX-listed companies. The program provides government support for IA evaluations and audits, helping companies identify key IA information. Companies such as Revez Corporation and Hyphens Pharma International have joined the program, with feedback from pilot phase companies to shape future support for IA disclosures.

site_title: Starbucks closes store at Fullerton Waterboat House as lease ends
summary: Starbucks Singapore has closed its store at the Fullerton Waterboat House due to the end of its lease, nearly six years after opening. The store, which partnered with the Autism Resource Centre to employ staff with special needs, has transitioned its employees to other locations. The closure is unrelated to the ongoing virus outbreak, but the company is in touch with local health authorities. This marks the end of a 1919 Waterboat House landmark, which will be occupied by other businesses.

site_title: Have a good cry but no boozing: expert tips for virus-stressed China
summary: China is urging citizens to cope with the mental strain of the deadly coronavirus by having a good cry, exercising, or singing. Health experts, including Yang Fude of the Beijing Huilongguan Hospital, suggest punching a sandbag or installing one in the office to relax. Meanwhile, the government is promoting responsible behavior, such as wearing masks and staying calm, through various media channels. Experts warn against excessive drinking and gaming to alleviate stress, instead recommending indoor exercises and other stress-relieving activities.

site_title: Malaysia bets instant noodles will sustain palm oil demand in virus-hit China
summary: Malaysia expects palm oil demand in China to remain strong despite the coronavirus epidemic, with instant noodles being a key driver of increased demand. As people stay indoors, they are eating more packaged foods that use palm oil, offsetting reduced consumption at restaurants. Despite forecasts of falling palm oil prices, Malaysia's minister in charge of palm oil believes demand will remain due to the country's historical reliance on Chinese imports. Malaysia has not seen any delays in shipments to China, and palm oil production continues to be a vital export.

images.alt_text: Malaysia expects palm oil demand in China to remain strong despite the coronavirus epidemic as people forced to stay indoors eat more packaged foods, such as instant noodles, that use a lot of the edible oil, the industry regulator said.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks extend losses on virus fear
summary: Mainland Chinese stocks fell more than two percent at the start of trade Tuesday, extending losses from the previous day due to fears over the coronavirus. The Shanghai Composite Index dropped 2.23% and the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 3.48%. The number of coronavirus deaths exceeded 400, and those infected broke 20,000.

site_title: Natas postpones travel fair to May on concerns over turnout
summary: Natas, the National Association of Travel Agents Singapore, has postponed its annual travel fair from February to May due to concerns over the coronavirus outbreak affecting turnout. The fair, initially scheduled for February 21-23, will now take place from May 1-3. Over 70 exhibitors, including travel agencies and hotels, had expressed concerns about the expected turnout. Some exhibitors have asked for a smaller fair in February, which Natas is still considering. The decision comes as Singapore reports cancellations and lower occupancy due to the virus outbreak.

site_title: Mindful Wealth re-domiciles CLO fund to Singapore after VCC pilot programme
summary: Boutique wealth management firm Mindful Wealth has completed the Variable Capital Companies (VCC) pilot programme and re-domiciled one of its funds, the Avenida CLO Equity Fund, from the Bahamas to Singapore. The fund, which has US$80 million in assets under management, invests in senior secured bank loans to sub-investment grade corporates. The move is part of a larger effort to relocate offshore funds to Singapore, which has a fully regulated jurisdiction. The company's re-domiciliation is facilitated by the VCC pilot programme launched by the Monetary Authority of Singapore and the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority.

site_title: Hyundai suspends production line over China outbreak
summary: Hyundai Motor suspended operations at one of its assembly lines in South Korea due to a lack of parts from China, where the coronavirus outbreak has disrupted wiring component procurement. The production line for Genesis sedans at the Number 5 plant in Ulsan was temporarily halted, with the company reviewing possible wider suspensions. The move comes as the global car industry faces supply chain disruptions and concerns about the virus's impact on the economy.

site_title: Australia's central bank keeps interest rates on hold
summary: Australia's central bank, the Reserve Bank of Australia, kept interest rates on hold at a record low of 0.75% despite the country's devastating bushfire crisis and the coronavirus outbreak in China. Governor Philip Lowe cited improved jobs figures and an uptick in housing markets as factors in the decision, but acknowledged "uncertainty" in the global economy. The RBA left its economic growth forecast unchanged at 2.75% for 2020 and 3% for 2021, and warned that an extended period of low interest rates may be needed to support sustainable growth and achieve the inflation target.

site_title: Apple suppliers aim to resume full China production Feb 10
summary: Apple's major suppliers in China, including Hon Hai Precision Industry Co, plan to resume full-scale production in the country on February 10, despite the ongoing coronavirus outbreak. The resumption of production is expected to be unaffected by the virus death toll and labor shortages. Suppliers such as Quanta Computer Inc, Inventec Corp, and LG Display Co also plan to resume work next week. Apple has roughly 10,000 direct employees in China and a supply chain of over a million workers manufacturing products like iPhones and iPads.

site_title: The big takeaway from Australia: men's and women's tennis are in very different places
summary: Men's tennis is dominated by a triopoly of Novak Djokovic, Rafael Nadal, and Roger Federer, with Djokovic seeking to surpass Federer's record for total time at No. 1. The women's game, on the other hand, has seen eight first-time major singles champions in the past 12 Grand Slam tournaments, with Sofia Kenin's win at the Australian Open. Despite the men's age advantage, younger stars like Dominic Thiem have shown promise, but the "blockade of Grand Slam ports" remains a significant challenge for new blood.

site_title: Patient infected with coronavirus has died in Hong Kong: authorities
summary: A 39-year-old Hong Kong resident, infected with the novel coronavirus, has died, marking the first fatality in the financial hub and the second outside mainland China. The victim, who traveled to Wuhan on January 21, returned to Hong Kong two days later. Authorities confirmed the death on Tuesday, following treatment at a hospital. This development raises concerns about the spread of the virus in Hong Kong and the global impact of the outbreak.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 7.61 points to 1,529.56, a 0.50% gain. The market saw 164 gainers for every 54 losers, with a trading volume of 72.09 million lots worth RM34.65 million.

site_title: J Lo and the power of 50
summary: Jennifer Lopez made a statement at the Super Bowl halftime performance, showcasing her 50th birthday in a series of daring Versace outfits. The performance featured 75,000 Swarovski crystals and took over 700 hours to create. Lopez's bold display of physicality and confidence has sparked a conversation about age and fashion, with some critics labeling her outfits as "silly" and "racy." However, Lopez's impact on the industry suggests it may be time to rethink the phrase "Dress your age."

site_title: US finalises rule to slap duties on countries that undervalue currencies
summary: The US Commerce Department finalized a rule to impose anti-subsidy duties on products from countries undervaluing their currencies against the US dollar, including potentially China. The move could lead to higher tariffs on goods from countries like Germany, Ireland, and Japan. The rule aims to "level the playing field" for American businesses and workers, but critics argue it may be inconsistent with World Trade Organization rules and could alienate countries worldwide.

site_title: Shares of AirAsia, AirAsia X fall after CEO, chairman step aside
summary: Shares of AirAsia Group and AirAsia X fell 5% and 8% respectively after CEO Tony Fernandes and Chairman Kamarudin Meranun stepped aside amid an investigation into allegations of a $50 million bribe paid by Airbus to win plane orders from AirAsia. The move comes as authorities investigate the bribery claims.

images.alt_text: Shares of budget airline AirAsia Group and its long-haul subsidiary, AirAsia X, fell in early trade on Tuesday after the group's CEO Tony Fernandes and Chairman Kamarudin Meranun said they would step aside for two months.
