site_title: China's biggest LNG buyers mulling force majeure amid virus fight: sources
summary: China's largest state-owned liquefied natural gas (LNG) importers, including CNOOC, PetroChina, and Sinopec, are considering force majeure declarations amid the novel coronavirus outbreak, which threatens China's economic growth and energy demand. The nation's oil consumption has dropped by 20%, forcing fuel makers to cut production and delay shipments. If declared, force majeure would impact contracted cargo deliveries and put pressure on Asian spot LNG prices, already at a decade-low due to a global glut. China has announced support for companies seeking to declare force majeure.

site_title: Chinese abandon food delivery fearing drivers will spread virus
summary: China's food delivery industry is severely impacted by the coronavirus outbreak, with millions of customers and 3 million delivery drivers affected. Due to concerns over drivers potentially spreading the virus, many restaurants have halted food delivery services, and consumers are scrambling for alternatives. Companies like Meituan Dianping and Alibaba Group are racing to address health concerns, introducing measures to protect drivers and customers, including secure pickup stations and mask-wearing requirements. The outbreak is expected to hurt the industry in the short term but may accelerate its growth in the long term, according to analysts.

site_title: Mortgage Master raises S$522,500 in oversubscribed seed round
summary: Mortgage Master, a Singapore-based mortgage brokering platform, has raised S$522,500 in an oversubscribed seed round, exceeding its initial target of S$400,000. The investment was made through FundedHere and includes investors Bala Swaminathan and Andy Lim. The startup plans to use the fresh capital to build technology capabilities, increase headcount, and enter new markets. Mortgage Master aims to provide unbiased personalized advice to homeowners and eliminate inefficiencies in the mortgage process, benefiting both homeowners and banks.

site_title: Commodities to take bigger hit from coronavirus than from Sars: DBS
summary: DBS Group Research predicts the novel coronavirus will have a larger negative impact on commodity demand and prices than the 2003 Sars epidemic, due to China's increased contribution to global metal consumption. The brokerage expects metal prices to decline 2-3% and has revised forecasts down. However, gold and silver prices are expected to rise as safe-haven assets, with forecasts revised up by 2%. The outbreak's peak may occur within the next one to two months, with bargain hunting opportunities emerging during this time.

site_title: Australia: Shares edge higher ahead of rate decision; New Zealand flat
summary: Australian shares rose 0.1% to 6,932.80, driven by financial stocks ahead of the Reserve Bank of Australia's rate decision, despite concerns over the coronavirus outbreak. The central bank is expected to keep interest rates on hold, but economists anticipate a rate cut this year. Healthcare stocks rose near 1%, while energy stocks fell 1.5% due to weaker oil prices.

images.alt_text: Australian shares inched up on Tuesday, buoyed by financials ahead of the central bank's rate decision, although persisting worries over the economic impact from the coronavirus capped gains.

site_title: Chinese cities to lose crucial Emirates flights as virus spreads
summary: China's cities will lose crucial Emirates flights as the coronavirus outbreak spreads, drastically reducing the nation's links to the outside world. The UAE's civil aviation authority ordered a halt to flights to all Chinese cities except Beijing, starting on Wednesday. Passengers flying out of Beijing will undergo comprehensive medical screening before boarding. The suspension affects over 25,000 flights this week and reduces international capacity by 4.4 million seats a week.

images.alt_text: Gulf carriers Emirates and Etihad Airways were told to halt flights to all Chinese cities apart from Beijing as the coronavirus outbreak spreads, drastically reducing the Asian nation's links to the outside world.

site_title: Australia eyes second flight from Wuhan as evacuees arrive on Christmas Island
summary: Australia is considering a second flight from Wuhan, China, after 241 evacuees arrived on Christmas Island. The initial flight, operated by Qantas, was quarantined for two weeks to prevent the spread of the new flu-like coronavirus. Australia plans to keep evacuees on Christmas Island for the maximum incubation period of the virus. The country is also working with New Zealand to share seats on a plane and has barred entry to foreign nationals from mainland China.

site_title: Hong Kong's striking hospital workers pose new threat to Beijing
summary: Hong Kong hospital workers went on strike, demanding the closure of the border with mainland China to prevent the spread of the coronavirus. The strike, which drew criticism from the government, revealed a growing threat to Beijing's administration and the city's pro-democracy unions. The Hospital Authority Employees Alliance, formed in December, has attracted over 18,000 members and is seeking stronger measures to stop the outbreak. The strike tests the ability of protesters to turn street numbers into organized collective action, and could potentially shift power dynamics in the city's legislature.

site_title: China's massive economic power shapes global response to coronavirus outbreak
summary: Countries worldwide are responding to the coronavirus outbreak in China, balancing public health concerns with economic and diplomatic considerations. Wealthier nations like the US and Australia have imposed travel restrictions, while less developed countries reliant on China are taking a softer approach to avoid economic fallout and domestic political consequences. China has criticized the US response, calling it "beggar-thy-neighbour practices." Several South-east Asian countries have taken more stringent precautions, including Singapore and the Philippines, to protect public health. The potential for restrictive measures to be difficult to reverse and cause economic damage has raised concerns.

site_title: Retirement savings may best real estate returns in Singapore
summary: In Singapore, research by UrbanZoom found that private apartment investments have yielded lower returns since 2011, with median annualised capital gains reaching 2.2% last year. This is lower than the minimum fixed rate of return of 2.5% offered by the Central Provident Fund (CPF), and in some cases, even lower. The study attributed this to government cooling measures, which have dampened both property prices and sentiment, leading owners to hold onto their properties for longer, waiting for price increases to offset initial expenses.

site_title: 'Open bar' for rats as Paris pension strikes hit waste collection
summary: A waste collection strike in Paris, France, has resulted in overflowing trash bins and public health concerns due to rodent infestations. The strike, sparked by the government's pension reforms, has brought six of seven incinerators to a halt, leaving rubbish uncollected for days. Residents and tourists have expressed frustration and disgust at the situation, which has raised concerns about the city's livability. The strike, now in its 10th day, is part of broader discontent over the government's pension reforms, which critics argue will force most French people to work longer for reduced payouts.

site_title: Asia: Markets rise, Shanghai swings as investors track virus
summary: Asian markets rose on Tuesday, with Shanghai fluctuating between positive and negative gains as investors tracked the US and European markets after a previous day's rout. The deadly virus in China, now infecting over 20,000 and killing more than the Sars epidemic in 2003, remains a major concern. China's GDP forecasts are being reconsidered due to the crisis, and the World Health Organization has declared a global health emergency. Oil and currency markets also stabilized, with the pound regaining ground after a Monday drop.

site_title: Grab moves into retail wealth management with acquisition of robo-advisory
summary: Grab has acquired Bento Invest, a Singapore-based robo-advisory startup, to expand its retail wealth management offerings. GrabInvest will offer cash management and portfolio-based financial solutions via its app, aiming to democratize access to affordable financial solutions for users in South-east Asia. Led by Bento's founder and CEO Chandrima Das, GrabInvest will operate under a retail wealth management capital markets services licence by the Monetary Authority of Singapore, with products expected to be launched in the first half of 2020.

site_title: Asian LNG price plunges to record low as virus crimps demand
summary: Asia's liquefied natural gas (LNG) price plummeted to a record low due to concerns over the novel coronavirus outbreak's impact on China's energy demand. The Platts Japan/Korea marker fell to $3.512 per million British thermal units, half the October spot market rate. China's weaker economic growth and supply chain disruptions are expected to hurt energy demand, contributing to the price drop. The benchmark price is half of its October value, highlighting the virus's significant impact on the energy market.

site_title: Tee International sells Tee Land stake to Malaysia's Amcorp
summary: Tee International has sold its 63.3% stake in Tee Land to Amcorp Group for S$50.6 million, or S$0.179 per share, with Tee International's former CEO Phua Chian Kin also selling his 5.5% stake. The deal, first announced on January 13, 2020, will help Tee International focus on its core engineering business and use the proceeds to repay loan or bank borrowings. Tee Land will dispose of its stake in Tee Industrial for a nominal amount of S$1, and Amcorp plans to maintain Tee Land's listing on the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Stocks to watch: GuocoLand, KIT, Tee Intl, Tee Land, DBS, OCBC, Nico Steel
summary: Key developments in the stock market include GuocoLand issuing S$200 million in new notes with a 3.4% coupon, Keppel Infrastructure Trust acquiring a US-based water management solutions provider, and Tee International selling its 63.3% stake in Tee Land to a Malaysian company for S$50.6 million. Banks DBS and OCBC have temporarily closed branches in Hong Kong and Macau due to the virus outbreak, while Nico Steel Holdings has closed its operations in China until Feb 9. Acromec secured a S$19.5 million sub-contract for a new medical building.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher following US market gains; STI up 0.79%
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Tuesday, gaining 0.79% to 3,140.95, following a rebound in US markets overnight. The Straits Times Index rose 24.64 points, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC leading the gains. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also rose, driven by tech giants and manufacturing data. European shares closed higher, despite a weak Nikkei 225 index, amid a merger and encouraging manufacturing data.

site_title: Sub-standard mask donations hamper China virus response: Red Cross
summary: The International Red Cross warned that sub-standard mask donations are hindering China's response to the novel coronavirus outbreak, which has killed over 360 people and infected over 17,000. The Red Cross urged donors to ensure masks meet quality standards, as lower-quality masks can cause more problems than help. The organization also criticized misinformation about the virus, which diverts resources away from addressing needs. China has acknowledged its need for medical supplies, including high-quality surgical masks, to battle the outbreak.

site_title: Air Canada plane makes emergency landing in Madrid
summary: An Air Canada flight made an emergency landing in Madrid on February 3, 2020, after experiencing technical problems shortly after takeoff. The plane, model AC837, had an engine issue and a blown tire, forcing it to turn back and circle the skies to burn off fuel. The aircraft safely landed back at Madrid's Barajas airport. No injuries or fatalities were reported. The incident occurred just hours after the flight took off from Madrid, and Air Canada attributed the issue to a problem with one of its engines.

site_title: Two AirAsia chiefs step aside amid Airbus bribery probe
summary: Two AirAsia executives, Tony Fernandes and Kamarudin Meranun, will step aside for at least two months amid an Airbus bribery probe. The probe, launched by authorities in France, Britain, and the US, alleges Airbus paid AirAsia $50 million to secure a plane order. The airline's board formed a committee to review the allegations, with Fernandes and Meranun to be kept as company advisors. Both executives denied any wrongdoing, stating they would not harm the companies they built up. An investigation by Malaysia's anti-corruption commission is underway.

site_title: Italy 2020 public finances make good start with Jan surplus
summary: Italy posted a state sector budget surplus of 3 billion euros in January, more than doubling the surplus from the same month last year. The annual improvement in state accounts was largely due to an increase in tax revenues. This marks a good start for Italy's 2020 public finances.

site_title: G-7 health ministers agree on coordinated approach to coronavirus: Germany
summary: G7 health ministers agreed to coordinate their response to the coronavirus, including travel regulations, research, and cooperation with the World Health Organization. German Health Minister Jens Spahn emphasized the need for international and European-level coordination. The agreement was made during a conference call and will be followed by meetings with British and French health ministers.

site_title: China's Hubei province reports 64 new coronavirus deaths on Feb 3: state TV
summary: China's Hubei province reported 64 new coronavirus deaths, bringing the total to 414, as of February 3. The province also saw 2,345 new cases, with Wuhan, the epicenter of the outbreak, reporting 48 new deaths and 1,242 new cases. With travel restrictions in place, fears of economic disruption are growing. The province's death toll has risen to 313 in Wuhan.

site_title: KIT unit buys US water management solutions provider
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust's (KIT) subsidiary, Ixom Watercare Inc, has acquired US-based Medora Environmental for an undisclosed amount. Medora provides source water treatment services to over 110,000 municipal water sources across North America. The acquisition strengthens Ixom Watercare's position in the water management sector, expanding its global reach and capabilities.

site_title: UK journalists walk out in government briefing protest
summary: British journalists walked out of a government briefing in protest after being excluded from a meeting on Britain's post-Brexit trade strategy. The briefing was attended by select journalists invited by Prime Minister Boris Johnson's team, with others being told to leave when they arrived. The National Union of Journalists described the incident as "very alarming" and called for the government to engage with all the press, not just favorites. The move has heightened tensions between the government and the media, with concerns raised about potential restrictions on access to information.

site_title: GuocoLand prices S$200m 5.5-year senior notes at 3.4%
summary: GuocoLand's wholly-owned subsidiary, GLL IHT, priced S$200 million 5.5-year senior notes at 3.4% coupon, with proceeds financing general working capital and corporate requirements. The notes, guaranteed by GuocoLand, will be listed on the Singapore Exchange under GLL IHT's S$3 billion multicurrency medium-term note programme. The deal was led by DBS Bank, OCBC Bank, Standard Chartered Bank, and United Overseas Bank. GuocoLand's shares fell S$0.04 to close at S$1.79 on Monday following the announcement.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday, down 0.28% or 63.92 points at 22,908.02, amid concerns over the new coronavirus. Investors also watched the Chinese market, which dropped sharply a day earlier. The broader Topix index fell 0.15% or 2.58 points at 1,670.08. The decline follows a global trend, with US stocks also edging down from records amid tariff threats.

site_title: British aviation industry outlines plans for net-zero emissions by 2050
summary: Britain's aviation industry has set a goal to achieve net-zero carbon emissions by 2050, despite plans to build a third runway at Heathrow airport. The Sustainable Aviation coalition, comprising companies like Rolls Royce, easyJet, and Airbus, aims to reduce emissions through more efficient aircraft and increased use of sustainable aviation biofuels. Meeting the target will require significant changes in the industry.

site_title: Singapore as Asia's transformation capital
summary: Singapore can emerge as Asia's Transformation Capital, driving digitalization and economic growth. The city-state can leverage its financial and political stability, infrastructure, and skilled labor to support businesses in the region. To achieve this, Singapore needs to embark on a digital transformation journey, using technology to maximize resources, adapt to change, and succeed. The government can support this by introducing tax incentives, such as a Digital Transformation Package, and investing in 5G networks, which will create demand for innovations and new revenue sources. This will help build a transformation ecosystem, lift income levels, and balance the budget.

site_title: Britain's GSK joins race to develop coronavirus vaccine
summary: GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) is joining the global effort to develop a vaccine for the new strain of coronavirus, with the UK government pledging £20 million in funding. GSK's vaccine adjuvant technology will complement existing projects, aiming to develop a vaccine within 16 weeks. The World Health Organization has declared a global virus emergency, but not a pandemic. The UK has also released its sequencing data for the viral genome, which suggests the virus has not evolved in the last month.

site_title: Nigeria to receive US$308m stolen by ex-dictator: US
summary: Nigeria is set to receive $308 million seized from former military dictator Sani Abacha, according to a US Department of Justice statement. The funds, laundered through US financial institutions and purchased bonds, were recovered from accounts in Jersey, a deal backed by the US and Jersey. The repatriation follows a 2014 US court ruling allowing the seizure of $500 million from Abacha's accounts worldwide. The money will be spent on three major road projects in Nigeria, ensuring transparency and accountability. This is the latest in a series of recovered funds linked to Abacha.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Thriving through mobile global sales teams
summary: Konsyg's CEO William Gilchrist shares insights on thriving through mobile global sales teams. The company assigns sales representatives to target any region, sharing key strategies for success. Gilchrist, a former Google regional sales manager, emphasizes the importance of adaptability and effective communication in today's sales landscape.

site_title: Oil hits 13-month lows as coronavirus cuts demand
summary: Oil prices hit 13-month lows due to the coronavirus outbreak, which has cut demand in China, the world's largest crude oil importer. Brent crude fell 3.8% to $54.45 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude dropped 3.6% to $50.12 a barrel. Opec and its allies are considering a 500,000 barrel-per-day cut to oil output to balance supply and demand. The outbreak could push the global oil market into surplus, with Fitch ratings agency predicting a potential surplus if the outbreak lasts for several months.

site_title: Disappointing growth hits Google parent Alphabet shares
summary: Alphabet, the parent company of Google, reported a 19% increase in profits to nearly $10.7 billion in the fourth quarter, driven by growth in digital advertising and cloud computing. However, revenue growth was disappointing, with a 17% increase to $46 billion. Shares fell 4% due to weaker-than-forecast revenue. The company's cloud computing services generated $2.6 billion in revenue in the quarter, while its YouTube advertising and cloud computing revenues showed sharp gains. Despite this, Alphabet's "other bets" segment reported an operating loss of over $2 billion.

site_title: Major summit on eve of Singapore Airshow cancelled on coronavirus fears
summary: A meeting of international aviation officials scheduled for February 10 in Singapore, just before the Asia's largest aerospace event, has been cancelled due to coronavirus fears. The ICAO and three industry sources confirmed the cancellation, adding to concerns about the broader Singapore Airshow, which is set to begin on February 11. This is the latest pullout by companies from the main event, which is taking place under the shadow of the fast-spreading virus. The summit's cancellation raises doubts about the airshow's future.

site_title: China admits 'shortcomings' in virus response
summary: China's top leadership admitted "shortcomings and difficulties" in its response to the coronavirus outbreak, with 57 new deaths confirmed on Monday, bringing the total to 361. The government criticized the US for sparking "panic" with its response, including a ban on foreigners who have recently been to China. The World Health Organization declared the crisis a global health emergency, and several countries have instituted similar rules. China is racing to build new hospitals and improve its emergency management system to combat the outbreak.

site_title: Antiviral cocktail a possible cure for novel coronavirus
summary: A Thai health official reports that a combination of antiviral drugs, including lopinavir and ritonavir, and the anti-flu medication oseltamivir, appears effective in treating a patient with the novel coronavirus. The treatment, administered to three patients, resulted in two continuing to receive the medications, with one testing negative for the virus. The Thai doctors' use of the unique three-drug therapy is part of a global effort to combat the outbreak, which has spread to Thailand with 19 confirmed cases.

site_title: Acromec wins S$19.5m contract for works at Singapore General Hospital
summary: Acromec, a specialist engineering firm, has secured a S$19.5 million sub-contract to supply, deliver, and install air-conditioning and mechanical ventilation systems at a new medical building in the Singapore General Hospital campus. The 12-storey health and medical care building will feature acute care facilities, including an accident and emergency department. The project is expected to commence in the second half of 2020 and complete by December 2022, contributing positively to Acromec's earnings per share and net tangible assets per share.

site_title: Europe: Shares recover from dismal week, FTSE weathers Johnson's tough Brexit terms
summary: European shares recovered from their worst week in six months, closing 0.6% higher on Monday. The FTSE 100 benefited from tough Brexit terms, while international-focused companies on London's blue-chip index gained. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.3% as manufacturing data showed a shallow contraction, and shares of Ingenico Group surged 17.2% after a merger announcement. Oil and gas stocks were the worst performers, and basic resources stocks also dropped.

site_title: STI falls 1.2%; losses led by financial and property stocks
summary: Singapore stocks fell 1.2% on Monday, following a sharp sell-off in China, which plunged over 7% amid the novel coronavirus outbreak. The decline is attributed to the extended New Year break and China's pledge to inject liquidity. Market strategist Pan Jingyi expects further volatility unless the support fails to arrest it.

site_title: The coronavirus outbreak will hit global growth
summary: A coronavirus outbreak is expected to hit global growth, potentially leading to a slowdown. The article cites the empty hotel rooms in Istanbul as a sign of the impact on tourism. China, which accounts for about one-third of global growth, is a key factor in this potential slowdown, as the US has traditionally triggered global recessions. The shift in global economic power from the US to China could lead to a new pattern of global recessions.

site_title: Making sense of Industry 4.0
summary: The Future Economy Council's manufacturing subcommittee aims to boost productivity and efficiency through Industry 4.0, a concept combining digitalisation, data, and automation. Senior Minister of State Koh Poh Koon notes that while manufacturers were initially hesitant to change, they now understand the need for transformation. The subcommittee oversees five industries and seeks to create opportunities for new products and services, addressing the shift from "why transform" to "what to do" and "how" to transform.

site_title: Modi opening bond market wider to foreigners to woo index funds
summary: India's government plans to allow foreign investors greater access to short-term and long-term government securities, aiming to tap into global bond indexes and attract US$50-125 billion of new investment. The move is seen as a precursor to India's inclusion in global bond indexes, which could give foreign investors access to a high-yielding market and allow India to tap overseas savings. The government will take a decision within a month on which securities to offer, and is discussing with the central bank on the matter.

site_title: Pamela Anderson and new husband split after just 12 days
summary: Pamela Anderson and her new husband Jon Peters, a movie mogul, have split just 12 days after their wedding in Malibu. Anderson cited a need to re-evaluate their relationship and take time apart, stating that the wedding was not formalized. The pair, who were previously married four times each, reportedly met at the Playboy Mansion in the 1980s. Peters expressed his desire to be with Anderson for 35 years, but it appears their union was short-lived.

site_title: US defends ban on Chinese travellers, more evacuations planned
summary: The US has defended its ban on Chinese travelers amid the coronavirus outbreak, citing the best available science. The ban, which excludes Hong Kong and Macau, aims to slow the spread of the virus. Eleven US cases have been confirmed, including two cases of person-to-person transmission. More evacuations of Americans from Wuhan are planned, with 195 currently in quarantine in California. The US CDC director, Nancy Messonnier, stated that science should trump other factors in containing the outbreak.

images.alt_text: The US said on Monday a ban on travellers from China meant to contain the deadly coronavirus outbreak was based on the best science, adding there would be more evacuations of Americans.

site_title: Why Brexit is about much more than Britain
summary: The EU has begun its first full week without the UK as a member, marking a crucial period in the bloc's future. A two-year conference, starting in May, aims to reform the EU to "reach out to the silent majority of Europeans" and address key policy ambitions. Domestic debates focus on internal rebalancing, reform, and restructuring EU budgets. The UK's withdrawal has created a new non-EU power in Western Europe, changing the EU's relationship with other non-EU countries, and raises questions about the future of the EU's institutional architecture and its place in a multipolar world.

site_title: US: Stocks bounce back after rout
summary: US stocks rebounded on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 0.5% to 28,399.54, the S&P 500 advancing 0.7% to 3,248.90, and the Nasdaq Composite Index jumping 1.3% to 9,273.40. The gains followed a better-than-expected manufacturing industry report and a strong earnings report from Tesla, which saw its shares soar 20% and more than triple since October. However, concerns about the coronavirus remained, with the Shanghai stock market dropping 8% and Gilead Sciences' stock surging 5% following news of an antiviral drug being tested in China.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks finished solidly higher on Monday led by Tesla and other tech giants as investors started buying again following Friday's rout.

site_title: Banks suspend branches, services in HK, Macau
summary: Banks in Hong Kong and Macau, including DBS, OCBC, and HSBC, have temporarily suspended or reduced services at various branches due to the worsening novel coronavirus outbreak. Many are advising customers to use digital channels for banking activities. Branch closures include OCBC's three Hong Kong branches and three Macau branches, while HSBC has closed 24 branches in Hong Kong and one in Macau. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has urged banks to maintain access to basic banking services and inform customers of any closures.

site_title: Honda to close Wuhan plants till Feb 13
summary: Honda has extended the closure period for its Wuhan car plants until February 13, following local government policy to contain the coronavirus outbreak. Initially, production was set to resume on February 14, but the company will now wait for further guidance. The Wuhan plants, based in Hubei province, have been closed since January due to the outbreak, which is centered in the city. The extended closure will impact Honda's production and delivery schedule.

site_title: China stocks suffer mauling; central bank injects 1.2t yuan to calm markets
summary: China's stock markets suffered a massive sell-down on Monday, with the Shanghai Composite index plummeting nearly 9% due to the spread of the novel coronavirus. The sell-off was largely expected as investors had been unable to unload their shares during the Lunar New Year holidays. China's central bank injected 1.2 trillion yuan into the market to calm nerves, while economists predict a return to calm markets in the coming days. The impact on regional markets was also significant, with Singapore's Straits Times Index and Japan's Nikkei 225 falling, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index bucked the trend.

site_title: Jennifer Lopez, Shakira restore sparkle to Super Bowl halftime show
summary: Jennifer Lopez and Shakira restored the Super Bowl halftime show's sparkle with a Latin-themed performance, a year after Maroon 5's underwhelming set. Lopez, 50, showcased her 21-year pop career with hits like Jenny From the Block and On the Floor, while Shakira, 43, performed classic tracks like Empire and Hips Don't Lie. The performance marked a return to female-led extravaganzas at the Super Bowl, following past headliners like Lady Gaga and Beyoncé. The event also highlighted the NFL's partnership with Roc Nation, which aims to increase inclusivity and activism.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% amid market uncertainty, with investors weighing tariffs, sanctions, and market outlook. European stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector concerns, while US stocks edged down from record highs despite no official tariff announcements. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Companies like Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss targets. Meanwhile, Heathrow airport considered increasing fees for a £10 billion upgrade, and an Indonesian employee was detained in a graft case involving Trafigura.

site_title: 2 local SMEs partner Rolls-Royce, A*Star
summary: Rolls-Royce, the Agency for Science, Technology and Research (A*Star), and two local SMEs, Zincode Technologies and Sysmatic Global, have jointly developed a new technology to automate part of the inspection process in jet engine manufacturing. The solution uses cameras and specialized lighting to capture detailed images of fan blades, eliminating subjectivity and creating a thread of digital data for future reference. The technology improves traceability, encourages upskilling for Rolls-Royce's workforce, and paves the way for lights-out manufacturing. The partnership is a key factor in helping local SMEs leverage A*Star's science and technology capabilities.

site_title: Does your pet really need cat TV or a dog playlist?
summary: A growing trend in pet entertainment involves streaming services like Amazon Prime and Spotify offering videos and playlists to calm or engage dogs and cats. The services, dubbed "cat TV" and "dog playlists," have gained popularity, with many pet owners reporting a positive response from their pets. A survey of 5,000 pet owners found that over 70% play music for their pets, with 40% believing it helps relieve stress. While the science behind these recommendations is anecdotal, many pet owners swear by their effectiveness, with some even using them as a form of therapy.

site_title: Market value of listed firms dips 1.8% in Jan
summary: The Singapore stock market experienced a 1.8% dip in January, with the total market capitalisation falling to S$871.5 billion from S$887.8 billion at the end of December. Blue chip stocks saw a larger contraction, with healthcare stocks being the biggest gainers, driven by medical plays and the novel coronavirus outbreak. ThaiBev's market cap fell the most, losing S$2.4 billion, while local banks, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC, also saw significant losses.

site_title: Next big challenge: Combating slate of animal-borne viruses
summary: China's public health system failed to contain the 2019-nCoV outbreak, despite scientists' warnings of a potential bat-borne virus re-emerging. The country's trade in wild meat, particularly bats, is also being criticized for contributing to the spread of the virus. Beijing has imposed temporary bans on selling wild animals, but experts warn that the virus could have been contained earlier with more proactive measures. As the world grapples with the crisis, the Global Virome Project estimates that there are nearly 1.7 million undiscovered viruses in the animal kingdom, highlighting the need for global preparedness for future pandemics.

site_title: Ireland's housing crisis derails Leo Varadkar's re-election bid
summary: Ireland's housing crisis is derailing Prime Minister Leo Varadkar's re-election bid, with the rapid property recovery leaving a generation unable to afford higher rents and prices. The crisis has led to a scarcity of housing, with daily stories of low-income families stuck in temporary accommodation and workers in their 30s living with their parents. Fine Gael's centre-right party has trailed in opinion polls, with its main rival Fianna Fáil and left-wing party Sinn Fein gaining ground on the issue.

site_title: Dollar-yuan overbought at top of channel
summary: The dollar-yuan (USDCNH) market has formed a channel, indicating a possible downtrend. The pair peaked at 7.1967 in September but has been in a consistent downtrend since then. It is currently hovering at the top of the channel, suggesting a possible downturn. The stochastics oscillator has surpassed the 80 level, turning downwards, and the MACD indicator is lying far below the 0 line, indicating strong bearish momentum. Expectations include support at 6.8232 and a potential fall to 6.6738 before buying pressure.

site_title: Travel curbs likely to crimp hospitality Reits' distributions
summary: Singapore's entry ban on travelers with recent history of visiting China is likely to negatively impact hospitality Reits' distributions, with potential cuts of up to double digits. The ban has already led to a 7% decline in hospitality Reits since alarm was raised over the novel coronavirus outbreak. Analysts expect at least a 4-8% occupancy drop in the near term, with some Reits downgraded, including CDLHT, FEHT, and Ascott Residence Trust. The impact is expected to be worse for hotels due to shorter stay lengths and higher proportion of leisure travelers.

site_title: Bad Boys stays on top of the box office in its third weekend
summary: Bad Boys for Life topped the box office for its third weekend, earning an estimated US$17.7 million in domestic ticket sales, bringing its cumulative domestic sales to around US$148.1 million. The film's overseas earnings stand at US$142.7 million. Newcomers Gretel & Hansel and The Rhythm Section underperformed, with Gretel & Hansel in fourth place and The Rhythm Section earning just US$2.8 million. Holdovers 1917, Dolittle, and The Gentlemen rounded out the top five.

site_title: WeWork hires new boss
summary: WeWork hires Sandeep Mathrani as its new CEO, replacing interim CEOs Artie Minson and Sebastian Gunningham, who took over after Adam Neumann's departure in September. Mathrani, a real estate industry veteran, aims to relaunch the company, which had faced significant losses and investors' mistrust after its failed IPO. He will report to Marcelo Claure, chairman of the board and a close associate of Japanese billionaire Masayoshi Son, who invested billions into WeWork to save it from bankruptcy. Mathrani's task is to revive the company, which had previously announced the elimination of 2,400 jobs worldwide.

site_title: Hit to China property likely to be temporary
summary: China's property market may experience a temporary hit due to the coronavirus outbreak, but latent demand is expected to drive sales later. Analysts note that people will delay purchases rather than cancel plans, similar to the 2003 Sars outbreak. Transactions in the second quarter of that year saw a 33% increase. As the epidemic subsides, demand is likely to return, with developers like China Evergrande Group benefiting from easing liquidity policies. The impact on the market is expected to be limited for the whole year, with some short-term delay in property sales.

site_title: Australian home prices start year on strong note
summary: Australian home prices started the year on a strong note, with annual growth accelerating to 4.1% in January, the fastest pace since 2017. Major cities such as Sydney and Melbourne saw significant gains, with values reaching all-time highs. The rebound in home prices is seen as a boost to consumer wealth and confidence, despite bushfires and the coronavirus scare. Analysts expect the Reserve Bank of Australia to cut interest rates, with a 20% chance of a quarter-point cut in the cash rate, and a further move to 0.25% by year-end.

site_title: China regulator 'urges fund managers not to offload shares'
summary: China's securities regulator has urged mutual fund managers not to sell shares unless investor redemptions occur, citing a growing virus outbreak. Despite this, Chinese stocks plummeted over 8% on Monday, the first trading day after a 10-day break. The regulator has also limited shortselling activities and injected 1.2 trillion yuan into the banking system to calm market anxiety. The measures are seen as a response to a potential massive investor redemption, which could lead to forced sales by mutual fund managers.

site_title: Minister paints 3 scenarios Singapore must prepare for
summary: Singapore's government is preparing for three scenarios related to the novel coronavirus, including a severe outbreak, a slowdown in affected sectors, and a broader-based economic slowdown. The government has already implemented measures such as border controls, detection and isolation, and quarantine allowance. Interim support will be provided to affected firms, and a Budget package is expected to be announced to support the economy. The government is also considering measures to address irresponsible behavior, such as landlords evicting Chinese tenants on leave.

site_title: Holland Village freehold shophouse, land parcels up for sale at S$13.8m
summary: A freehold shophouse in Singapore's Holland Village, including two retail units and adjacent land parcels, has been launched for sale at an indicative price of S$13.8 million. The properties, spanning 1,840 sq ft, have been approved for restaurant and patio dining use. The sale is seen as an opportunity for investors to capitalize on the area's growth plans, with the Urban Redevelopment Authority earmarking Holland Village as a growth precinct. The expression of interest closes on March 5, with no additional buyer's stamp duty applicable for foreigners.

site_title: Singapore firms leveraging adtech will command higher valuations in 2020
summary: Singaporean firms leveraging adtech innovations can command higher valuations in 2020 by selling their audience data directly to advertisers, resulting in a 500% increase in ad revenue. This shift allows publishers and app owners to set their own prices, take back control of their data, and add substantial new revenue streams. As a result, growth-stage startups and established companies can benefit from increased valuations, with the regional digital advertising market in South-east Asia expected to reach $15.35 billion by 2026.

site_title: Toyota's Lexus brand surges globally, despite stalling demand in US
summary: Lexus posted a 10% global sales gain in 2019, reaching 765,330 vehicles, driven by strong sales in China (25% increase) and Europe (14% increase). However, US sales fell 0.1% to 298,114 vehicles, marking a fourth consecutive year of decline. Lexus aims to boost US sales with new vehicles, despite trailing behind German rivals Mercedes-Benz and BMW. The brand sold its 10 millionth vehicle last year, solidifying its position as a leading luxury brand.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Pacific Star Development's construction project in Bangkok halted due to payment and construction progress disputes with China Railway Construction. The company seeks "constructive solutions" to resolve the issues. Sarine Technologies files lawsuits in India against manufacturers of alleged intellectual property infringement. M Development acquires Antai Mining International's stake, potentially leading to a reverse takeover. Swissco Holdings transfers its listing status to Tech Onshore MEP-Prefabricators in a deal worth S$3.5 million to shareholders and creditors.

site_title: Citibank Singapore's retail banking head leaves after over 20 years
summary: Citibank Singapore's retail banking head Charles Wong has resigned after more than 20 years with the US bank. Wong led the unit to deliver "consistent double-digit growth" and was credited by CEO Brendan Carney for a strong turnaround. Chan San-San will take over as interim head of retail banking until a permanent successor is found. Wong's departure follows the recent resignation of Citibank Singapore CEO Han Kwee Juan, who joined DBS after nearly three decades with the bank.

images.alt_text: Citibank Singapore's head of retail banking Charles Wong has resigned after more than 20 years at the US bank.

site_title: AirAsia, SembMarine react to remote law enforcement action
summary: AirAsia and SembMarine have been hit with allegations of corruption. Airbus agreed to pay $4 billion in fines over a long-running corruption investigation, including $50 million in sponsorship to a sports team owned by AirAsia executives. SembMarine's ex-employee Martin Cheah Kok Choon and former consultant Guilherme Esteves de Jesus have been charged with corruption and money laundering in connection with Operation Car Wash in Brazil. The cases raise questions about disciplining big corporations and whether fines should be imposed on companies rather than executives.

site_title: 12 exhibitors, including 10 from China, withdraw from Singapore Airshow 2020
summary: Singapore Airshow 2020 to feature 12 exhibitors, including 10 from China, after some withdrew due to the novel coronavirus outbreak. Gulfstream and Textron Aviation also pulled out, citing health concerns. The event, originally expected to have over 1,000 exhibitors and 55,000 attendees, will have medical staff on standby and reduced the number of visitors. The decision is attributed to Singapore's travel restrictions and company policies on employee travel. Other countries, such as South Korea and Russia, are also scaling back their participation.

site_title: Johnson and Barnier clash over who sets rules for Brexit trade
summary: UK leader Boris Johnson clashed with EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier over who sets rules for a future Brexit trade deal. Johnson rejected Barnier's demand for strict rules to prevent unfair competition, instead opting for a relationship based on Australia's far-looser arrangements. The EU is seeking robust commitments from the UK to maintain a level playing field in areas such as taxation and environmental standards. The talks mark the start of 11 months of negotiations, with early signs indicating a hard-edged and tense process ahead.

site_title: More Singapore-listed firms reporting adverse impact on operations
summary: Singapore-listed firms are reporting adverse impacts on operations due to the novel coronavirus situation. Nico Steel Holdings' Suzhou, China operations will close until Feb 9, affecting 83.6% of the group's revenue. Powermatic Data Systems' Chinese units will also shutter operations till Feb 9. KTL Global faces transportation and movement restrictions in China affecting its operations. Zhongmin Baihui Retail Group has closed a mall in China and shortened mall hours due to the outbreak. Companies are closely monitoring the situation's impact on financial performance.

site_title: Yuan weakens but resilient yen signals risk recovery
summary: The Chinese yuan dropped to a seven-week low against the US dollar, but a resilient Japanese yen suggested fears surrounding the coronavirus in China are easing. The offshore yuan fell to 7.023 yuan per dollar, while the yen rose 0.2% to 108.49 dollars. The Chinese government took steps to shore up its economy by cutting interest rates, and European stocks rose despite the yen's decline. Analysts believe the slide in the yuan is largely a product of holiday-related selling pressure.

site_title: China seeks US flexibility on some promises in the Phase 1 trade deal
summary: China is seeking flexibility on some promises in the Phase 1 trade deal with the US amid the COVID-19 outbreak. The US-China trade deal has a clause allowing for consultation in the event of a natural disaster or unforeseen event. As of Sunday, China's death toll from the virus has risen to 361. China hopes for flexibility on the trade deal as it deals with the outbreak, which may slow its GDP growth and put pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Paradise lost looms for German farmers as swine fever nears
summary: Germany's pig farmers face a significant threat from African swine fever (ASF), which has already spread to Poland and could potentially infect Germany's 11,000-pig herd. A 120km electric fence was erected along the German-Polish border to prevent the spread of the disease, but farmers believe it may not be effective. A confirmed case in Germany could lead to an import ban on German pork, causing a dramatic fall in prices and significant losses for farmers, with estimates suggesting a triple-digit million euro sum.

site_title: Ex-president of SembMarine unit charged in Brazil with money laundering, graft
summary: Former Sembcorp Marine president Martin Cheah Kok Choon has been charged in Brazil with money laundering and graft over contracts with Sete Brasil in 2012. The charges relate to drilling rig construction contracts entered into by SembMarine subsidiaries. Cheah, who led Sembcorp Marine's Brazilian subsidiary Estaleiro Jurong Aracruz, faces serious allegations.

site_title: Ryanair reports profit, says Max boost a year away
summary: Ryanair reported a net income of 88 million euros for the third quarter, surpassing a year-ago loss due to lucrative last-minute bookings over the Christmas and New Year holiday period. However, the airline's earnings boost from the grounded 737 Max jetliner is expected to be delayed until September or October, pushing back its target of surpassing 200 million passengers a year to fiscal 2025. Ryanair reiterated its full-year profit guidance of about 1 billion euros and plans to halt share buybacks after July to retain cash for debt repayment.

site_title: US class actions pile up against Australia's Westpac amid money-laundering scandal
summary: Westpac Banking Corp, Australia's No 2 lender, faces a second US class-action lawsuit over its financial crime monitoring amid a money laundering scandal. The lawsuit, filed by Bernstein Liebhard, accuses the lender of failing to carry out due diligence on transactions in South-east Asia and the Philippines, and not monitoring terrorism financing risks. This comes after Austrac sued Westpac for 23 million alleged breaches of anti-money laundering laws, including payments between known child exploiters. Similar class-action lawsuits have been announced by six US-based law firms, with Westpac warning that similar suits may follow.

site_title: Chinese chip makers keep factories humming despite coronavirus outbreak
summary: Chinese technology firms, including Huawei, Yangtze Memory Technologies, and Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corp, have continued to manufacture parts and products despite government calls to halt production due to the coronavirus outbreak. Huawei resumed production of consumer devices and carrier equipment, while Yangtze Memory Technologies and SMIC kept production running throughout the Chinese New Year holiday. The move highlights the critical importance of China's domestic tech supply chain, which has sparked friction with the US. Operations are reported to be normal, with measures in place to ensure employee safety.

site_title: Hong Kong economy shrinks for the first time in a decade
summary: Hong Kong's economy contracted 1.2% in 2019, its first annual decline in a decade, due to the US-China trade war and months of pro-democracy protests. The city's gross domestic product shrank in the fourth quarter, with total exports declining amid a difficult external environment. Economists predict the coronavirus outbreak will prolong the recession, with Capital Economics forecasting a bigger negative impact in the first quarter of 2020. The protests, which began over a proposed extradition bill, have achieved few of their demands and have left Hong Kongers feeling rattled by Beijing's increasing assertiveness.

site_title: The US impeachment (non)drama: another game changer bites the dust
summary: The US impeachment process against President Trump has been deemed a "non-drama" after the House of Representatives failed to approve articles of impeachment, falling short of the required two-thirds majority. The Democrats had sought to use the impeachment process to remove Trump from office, but ultimately decided to focus on the 2020 presidential election. Despite the House's failure to impeach, the impeachment process has still had an impact, with many Americans disapproving of the process and the country remaining polarized. The outcome of the 2020 presidential election will ultimately determine Trump's fate, with voters deciding whether to send him to his "new address in Florida."

site_title: Wistron to assemble key iPhone component in new India plant: sources
summary: Taiwan's Wistron Corp plans to assemble printed circuit boards (PCBs) for iPhones at its new plant in southern India, marking Apple's push to expand manufacturing in the world's second-biggest smartphone market. The facility, expected to be operational by April, will produce up to eight million smartphones annually, with some models being exported. This move aims to save Apple on import taxes and capitalize on India's growing smartphone market. Wistron's rival Foxconn already assembles PCBs for iPhone XR models in India.

site_title: Verbal fireworks likely in Trump's State of the Union speech
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to deliver a State of the Union speech on Tuesday night, where he is expected to address the impeachment effort and offer to work with his Democratic opponents on issues like healthcare and infrastructure. Despite advisers' concerns about dwelling on impeachment, Trump plans to emphasize the US economy and highlight his policies, including trade agreements and national security moves. The speech comes ahead of the Democratic primary election and the Senate's expected acquittal of Trump on impeachment charges.

site_title: Cruise ships to ban recent China visitors: global industry body
summary: Cruise lines worldwide will deny boarding to passengers and crew who have recently traveled to China due to the deadly new coronavirus, according to the Cruise Lines International Association (CLIA). CLIA members have suspended crew movements from mainland China and will enforce a 14-day travel ban from mainland China. This measure aims to prevent the spread of the virus among passengers and crew. The ban affects all CLIA members, including major cruise lines such as TUI, AIDA, MSC, and Carnival Cruises.

site_title: iSTOX graduates from MAS fintech sandbox
summary: Singapore-based capital markets platform iSTOX has graduated from the Monetary Authority of Singapore's (MAS) FinTech Regulatory Sandbox, marking its transition to a fully licensed operational platform. The graduation allows iSTOX to remove restrictions on issuance sizes and investor participation. Designed with blockchain and smart contract technology, iSTOX aims to efficiently facilitate the buying and selling of securities using fiat currency. Its graduation follows other sandbox participants, including PolicyPal, Kristal.ai, and Thin Margin, and is backed by prominent investors such as the Singapore Exchange and Temasek.

site_title: US construction spending posts first drop since June
summary: US construction spending declined 0.2% in December, its first drop since June, due to a 1.8% fall in nonresidential structures and a 0.1% drop in private projects. Despite this, homebuilding increased 1.4% and residential construction was supported by lower mortgage rates. For 2019, construction spending fell 0.3%, the first annual decline since 2011, as economists had forecast a 0.5% gain.

site_title: Virus outbreak hits operations of Nico Steel, KTL Global unit
summary: Singapore-listed companies Nico Steel and KTL Global have reported impacts on their operations due to the novel coronavirus outbreak. Nico Steel's operations in Suzhou, China, will be temporarily closed until Feb 9, affecting 83.6% of its revenue. KTL Global's Chinese employees may not work due to travel restrictions, and some of its vendors, suppliers, and clients have closed their offices. Both companies will closely monitor the situation's potential impact on their financial performance.

site_title: Money Hacks podcast: Demystifying managed portfolios (Ep 64)
summary: The Money Hacks podcast (Ep 64) explores managed portfolios, discussing what they are, how they're managed, and the pros and cons of DBS Bank's digi portfolio solutions. Christophe Marciano, head of discretionary portfolio management at DBS Bank, shares insights into the process and available ETFs in these portfolios. The podcast aims to demystify managed portfolios, providing actionable financial tips for listeners in Singapore.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish with small gains
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.17% on Monday, closing at 26,356.98, after last week's sharp losses. Investors remain cautious due to concerns over China's deadly virus. The benchmark Hang Seng Index gained 44.35 points.

site_title: Potentially 'long road ahead' for Wuhan virus: Gan
summary: Singapore's Health Minister Gan Kim Yong warns of a potentially long road ahead in managing the Wuhan coronavirus. The government is preparing for various scenarios, including community spread and potential mutations. If community spread occurs, measures such as cancelling mass gatherings and suspending schools may be considered. The government has increased isolation bed capacity and testing capacity, and will provide an assistance package to communities in China affected by the virus.

site_title: London - world's most female-friendly megacity - finds room for women-only ventures
summary: London, a city ranked as the world's most female-friendly megacity, is witnessing the emergence of women-only ventures, including female-only housing schemes and dedicated women's marketplaces. The city's Older Women's Co-Housing complex, established by Shirley Meredeen, provides a self-managed space for older women to meet and support each other. Similar projects, such as the Lady Lane women-only street market, are also being launched, aiming to combat loneliness, empower female entrepreneurs, and diversify public spaces. The initiatives are part of the city's efforts to address the needs of women, with London Mayor Sadiq Khan's "#BehindEveryGreatCity" campaign promoting gender equality in public spaces.

site_title: Virus outbreak may impact level of world trade in 2020
summary: A potential coronavirus outbreak may impact global trade in 2020, with supply-chain disruptions and decreased demand from China's shutdown of factories. China, the world's second-largest economy, is a key player in global manufacturing, and its disruption has ripple effects worldwide. Economists warn that the outbreak could alter the brightening outlook for global trade, with the International Monetary Institute predicting a slowdown in Chinese economic growth. This could lead to a dent in hopes for a better 2020, following a decline in global trade in 2019.

site_title: Opec+ considering further 500,000 bpd oil output cut
summary: Opec+ is considering a further 500,000 barrels per day (bpd) oil output cut due to the impact of the coronavirus on oil demand. The potential cut comes as oil prices have fallen to US$56, lower than needed by many Opec countries to balance their budgets. Iran's oil minister has called for efforts to stabilize prices, and Russia is ready to bring forward Opec+ meetings to February. The Joint Technical Committee will assess the virus's impact on demand and make a recommendation on further action.

site_title: Temasek's Accuron Technologies takes stake in UK additive manufacturing startup
summary: Accuron Technologies, a Temasek-owned company, has invested in UK-based additive manufacturing startup WAAM3D, taking a 20% stake in the company. WAAM3D aims to scale up operations and add 20 employees, specializing in wire-based additive manufacturing, a form of 3D printing that produces large metal components with low costs and short lead-times. Accuron believes WAAM3D's process has the potential to "transform manufacturing" and will help the company realize its true potential with its capital investment and industrial knowledge.

site_title: US manufacturing activity rebounds in January
summary: US factory activity unexpectedly rebounded in January with the Institute for Supply Management (ISM) index rising to 50.9, the highest level since July, from 47.8 in December. This marks the end of a five-month contraction and suggests a bottoming out of business investment slump. The improvement is attributed to ebbing trade tensions between the US and China, following the signing of a Phase 1 trade deal. However, US tariffs on Chinese imports remain a constraint on manufacturing, and factory employment index remains weak, increasing by 46,000 jobs in 2019.

site_title: Singapore electronics mood brightens in Jan, but supply chain break looms
summary: Singapore's electronics sector showed cautious optimism in January, with the Purchasing Managers' Index posting a 50.1 expansion, its first positive reading in 14 months. The improvement was attributed to the US-China trade truce. However, economists warn that the outlook may be temporary due to the novel coronavirus outbreak, potentially affecting supply chains.

site_title: Thailand sees benefit from using drug mixture on coronavirus
summary: Thailand is using a combination of antiviral drugs, including Kaletra and Tamiflu, to treat patients infected with the coronavirus, with initial results showing promise. The treatment involves administering Kaletra, a cocktail of HIV medicines, along with Tamiflu, an anti-flu medication. Two of the three patients in Thailand on this unique therapy are continuing to receive the medications, with one patient testing negative for the virus. Thailand has reported 19 confirmed cases of the virus, with 11 hospitalized and 311 people being monitored for possible infection.

site_title: Hong Kong plunged into recession in 2019
summary: Hong Kong confirmed it plunged into recession in 2019, suffering its first annual contraction in a decade due to the US-China trade war and pro-democracy protests. The city's gross domestic product shrank 1.2% on-year for 2019, with the fourth quarter clocking a 2.9% contraction. The economic woes are compounded by the outbreak of a deadly new coronavirus strain. Economists predict the city will remain in recession, with a bigger negative impact in the first quarter of 2020.

site_title: US: Wall Street rises at open after steep selloff
summary: Wall Street rose at the open on Monday, following its worst week in four months due to coronavirus growth concerns. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.23% to 28,319.65, while the S&P 500 gained 0.31% to 3,235.66 and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.43% to 9,190.72. The recovery comes after a steep selloff, with stocks closing at record highs on Friday.

site_title: Singapore's electronics sentiment turns positive after 14 months
summary: Singapore's electronics sector has entered positive territory for the first time in 14 months, driven by a US-China trade truce and a growth in manufacturing sentiment. The Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) for the electronics sector posted an expansion of 50.1 in January, while the manufacturing PMI recorded a growth of 50.3. However, economists warn that optimism may be temporary due to the novel coronavirus outbreak, which could disrupt the regional supply chain and negatively impact the services cluster.

site_title: Johnson and Barnier clash over who sets rules for Brexit trade
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson and EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier clashed over who sets rules for a future Brexit trade deal. Johnson rejected Barnier's demand for strict rules to prevent unfair competition, instead opting for a relationship based on Australia's far looser arrangements. The EU's draft mandate requires robust commitments to ensure the UK doesn't undercut the bloc, while Johnson's framework rejects aligning with EU rules and standards. The talks, set to last 11 months, face significant challenges, with the EU warning that the UK's choices will lead to a level playing field in areas such as taxation and environmental standards.

site_title: Aqua Munda again extends deadline for Hyflux debt buyout
summary: Aqua Munda has extended the deadline for Hyflux's debt buyout offer to Feb 22, citing recent events as raising concerns around Hyflux's situation. The investor is committing S$208 million to fund the offer, which covers nearly two-thirds of Hyflux's total debt. The offer is open to holders of various senior unsecured debts and is now set to close on Apr 24, with a long-stop date of July 17. This is the second extension of the original Jan 31 deadline.

site_title: Financiers worry about virus, Hong Kong braces for business slowdown
summary: Hong Kong's finance sector is bracing for a potential business slowdown due to the fast-spreading coronavirus, with some firms asking staff to work from home and others cancelling meetings. The city's economy and market have already suffered from months-long protests and the US-China trade war. The spread of the virus has wiped billions off China's stock value and led to travel bans, prompting expatriate professionals to send their families abroad. Schools have been closed until March 2, and face masks are in short supply, further exacerbating concerns.

site_title: Singapore shares slide 1.2% as virus worries hit China markets
summary: Singapore's stock market slid 1.19% on Monday, following a sharp sell-off in China amid the ongoing coronavirus outbreak. The Straits Times Index fell as much as 1.26% and closed at 3,116.31. Local banks, including DBS and UOB, were among the top decliners, with shares dropping 1.85% and 1.40% respectively. The decline was attributed to concerns about the virus's impact on the global economy.

site_title: Blockchain capital markets platform iSTOX graduates from MAS fintech sandbox
summary: Blockchain capital markets platform iSTOX has graduated from the Monetary Authority of Singapore's (MAS) FinTech Regulatory Sandbox, becoming fully licensed and operational. This removal of restrictions allows iSTOX to host larger issuances and onboard more investors. Designed by ICHX Tech, iSTOX uses blockchain and smart contract technology to efficiently buy and sell securities. The platform plans to bring on more issuances across different asset classes, offering private market opportunities to accredited and institutional investors. The MAS sandbox enables innovation while maintaining financial system soundness.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore shares fell 1.2% on Monday as the coronavirus outbreak weighed on markets. The STI closed at 3,116.31, with financial and real estate stocks leading the decline. Firms may receive interim support ahead of the Budget virus package, and Singapore banks have "good capital buffers" to weather the outbreak, according to S&P Global Ratings. Meanwhile, Citibank Singapore's head of retail banking has resigned after 20 years, and GTRIIP raised 7-figure Series B funding to expand in Asia-Pacific.

site_title: Vaccine giant Glaxo joins global race to combat coronavirus
summary: GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) has partnered with the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations (CEPI) to accelerate the development of a vaccine against the coronavirus. The project aims to utilize GSK's adjuvant system to enhance the body's immune response and create a stronger, longer-lasting protection. CEPI and GSK will work together to provide rapid vaccine doses, with the goal of initiating human testing in as little as three months. The UK government has also committed £20 million to fund new vaccines against the coronavirus and future infectious diseases.

site_title: Hit to Chinese property market from virus temporary, analysts say
summary: China's property market is expected to recover from the coronavirus outbreak, with analysts predicting a short-term decline in home sales that will be offset by latent demand. The virus has prompted over 100 cities to close property showrooms, but analysts believe buyers will delay purchases rather than cancel plans. Historical data from the SARS outbreak in 2003 shows that property sales rebounded after the initial decline, and experts expect a similar outcome this time. Developers with high leverage may benefit from easing liquidity policies, which could limit the impact on the property market for the rest of the year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 9.11 points to 1,521.95. The market saw a volume of 4 billion lots worth RM2.9 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 738 to 280.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rebound at open
summary: European stock markets rebounded at the open on Monday, recovering from a pre-weekend slide due to concerns over the coronavirus. London's FTSE 100 index rose 0.3%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 climbed 0.4%, and the Paris CAC 40 won 0.3%. The gains were attributed to mining and healthcare sectors, while US-EU trade talks were also in focus.

site_title: China counts cost of virus as markets plunge, death toll up
summary: China's coronavirus epidemic has mounted significant economic and diplomatic costs, with the value of US stocks plummeting by $400 billion and the government accusing the US of over-reacting. China's death toll from the virus has risen to 361, while the number of new confirmed infections has increased to 17,205. The US has imposed travel restrictions on Chinese nationals, and the US and other countries are trying to evacuate their citizens from locked-down Wuhan. The World Health Organization has declared the outbreak a public health emergency, but has warned against unnecessary travel restrictions.

site_title: China 'urgently needs' medical masks to tackle virus
summary: China urgently needs medical masks to tackle the highly contagious coronavirus, with the death toll exceeding 360, surpassing the 2002 SARS crisis. The country is struggling with equipment shortages, with factories producing only 20 million masks per day at full capacity. The government has received donations from countries like South Korea, Japan, and Hungary, and is bringing in masks from Europe and the US to meet demand. Several provinces have made mask-wearing compulsory in public to curb the spread of the virus.

site_title: Firms may get interim help ahead of Budget virus support package: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore to provide interim support to firms affected by the Wuhan virus, including the Singapore Tourism Board, to help with cleaning and disinfection costs. The government will also provide quarantine allowance to affected workers and offer ComCare financial assistance to those in need. A Budget package of measures is expected to be announced, targeting sectors such as tourism and transport, as well as related industries and firms. The government will also take action against irresponsible landlords who evict Chinese tenants on leave of absence.

site_title: Singapore banks have 'good capital buffers' to weather virus outbreak: S&P
summary: Singapore banks have "good capital buffers" to withstand the immediate impact of the coronavirus outbreak, according to S&P Global Ratings. Weaker loan growth and volatile earnings are expected due to depressed credit demand, particularly in the tourism and hospitality sectors. However, the ratings agency believes the impact will be manageable, given the banks' healthy profit levels and financial strength. A prolonged outbreak could lead to higher delinquencies, but the government's support and extraordinary intervention would mitigate the situation.

site_title: Australia: Shares close at 3-week low on virus fears; NZ drops
summary: Australian shares fell 1.3% to a three-week low on Monday, amid fears of a slow global economic growth due to the coronavirus epidemic. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,923.3 points. Mining stocks dropped 1.3% and energy stocks fell 4.1% after oil prices dropped. China's central bank injected 1.2 trillion yuan of liquidity to soothe markets, but investors still sought safe havens. New Zealand's benchmark index also fell 1.4% to its lowest close in three weeks.

site_title: GTRIIP raises 7-figure Series B funding to expand in Asia-Pacific
summary: GTRIIP, an identity verification software provider, has raised an undisclosed mid-seven figure US dollar sum in its Series B round. Investors include Keppel Corporation, Accord Ventures, and Global Brain, aiding the company's Asia-Pacific expansion plans in hospitality and commercial properties. GTRIIP aims to launch specialized products for commercial properties and enlist more developers and sales team members. The company, founded in 2014, has 20 employees and completed installations for over 13,000 rooms and access points, projecting revenue of US$6 million in 2020.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks recoup early losses on bargain hunting, China support plans
summary: South Korean stocks ended flat on Monday after a 1.7% drop in early trade, recouping losses due to bargain hunting and Chinese government support measures. The KOSPI fell 0.13 point, or 0.01%, to 2,118.88. China's central bank injected US$174 billion into the markets, while foreigners sold US$258 million worth of shares. The KOSPI has fallen 3.59% this year, but local institutions and individual investors were net buyers, supporting the market.

site_title: US disinfectant maker boosts output as China hospitals battle virus
summary: US disinfectant maker Decon7 Systems is boosting production of its hydrogen peroxide-based disinfectant, D7, to meet surging demand from Chinese hospitals battling the coronavirus epidemic. The company, which has six facilities, will run double shifts at three new US sites to air freight seven containers of the product, each containing 80,000 pounds, to hospitals in Hubei and neighboring regions. Demand has increased by 10-fold in the last fortnight, with hospitals seeking disinfectant to protect medical workers and combat the virus, which has killed 361 people and infected over 17,000.

site_title: Zhongmin Baihui announces shorter hours, Hunan mall closure
summary: Zhongmin Baihui Retail Group, a Chinese mall operator, has announced control measures in response to the coronavirus spread. An outlet mall in Hunan province has been temporarily closed until Feb 9, while other malls have shortened their operating hours to 10am-6pm daily until Feb 8. Employees will also have their Chinese New Year break extended until Feb 9, with health and safety supplies provided and mandatory mask-wearing in public areas.

site_title: Drone on virus patrol busts Chinese villagers' mahjong game
summary: In rural China, officials are using drones to enforce social distancing measures amid the coronavirus epidemic. A video showed a drone spotting villagers playing mahjong outside, prompting officials to order them to disperse. Despite the severe health scare, some Chinese netizens were amused by the clip, which quickly went viral. The Chinese government has called for people to stay at home and avoid gatherings to prevent the spread of the virus, with over a dozen cities in Hubei province in lockdown.

site_title: Wuhan virus may hit regional supply chain if not contained: report
summary: A J. P. Morgan report warns that if the Wuhan virus is not contained, it may have a greater regional impact on the supply chain than the 2002-2003 Sars outbreak. Economic activity in affected countries could contract, but recover in the second quarter. Tourism may be more affected than manufacturing, particularly in Thailand, Hong Kong, and Vietnam, which have high exposure to tourist receipts. A prolonged outbreak could lead to a severe supply shock, particularly in the tech sector, with Taiwan, Vietnam, Malaysia, and South Korea expected to be the hardest hit.

images.alt_text: Mask-wearing tourists at the Grand Palace in Bangkok. In the region, Thailand has the greatest tourism exposure to China.

site_title: Toyota uses big data to guard against accelerator-brake mix-up
summary: Toyota unveiled an emergency safety system using big data to prevent accelerator-brake mix-ups in new cars starting this summer in Japan. The "accelerator suppression function" will ignore the accelerator if the driver unintentionally steps on the pedal, addressing a common cause of traffic accidents among elderly drivers. This system is part of Toyota's efforts to develop fully autonomous cars, following similar advancements by competitors Honda and Nissan.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares fall on virus worries
summary: Tokyo stocks fell on February 3, 2020, due to concerns over the Chinese market's reaction to the new coronavirus outbreak. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 1.01% and the Topix index fell 0.70%. This decline followed the global market's downturn during the extended Chinese holiday.

site_title: Honda to close Wuhan plants until Feb 13, no restart date set
summary: Honda Motor Co plans to extend the closure of its three car plants in Wuhan, China until Feb. 13, following local government policy, instead of resuming production on Feb. 14 as previously announced. The Japan-based representative did not provide a restart date. The closure is due to the ongoing COVID-19 outbreak in the region.

site_title: Huawei, Chinese chip makers keep factories humming despite coronavirus outbreak
summary: Chinese tech companies, including Huawei and chip makers Yangtze Memory Technologies and Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corp, have continued to manufacture parts and products despite government calls to halt production due to the coronavirus outbreak. Huawei resumed production of consumer devices and carrier equipment, while Yangtze Memory Technologies and SMIC kept production running throughout the Chinese New Year holiday. The companies cited critical industry exemptions and implemented safety measures to ensure employee safety. This move reflects the importance of China's domestic tech supply chain to Beijing, sparking friction with the US.

site_title: Apple supplier Wistron to assemble key iPhone component in new India plant: report
summary: Taiwan's Wistron Corp plans to assemble printed circuit boards (PCBs) for iPhones at its new plant in southern India, marking a significant expansion of Apple's manufacturing presence in the country. The facility, expected to produce up to eight million smartphones annually, will help Apple save on import taxes and support local manufacturing. Wistron's move follows that of Foxconn, which assembles PCBs for iPhone XR models in India. The development is part of Wistron's 30 billion rupee investment proposal submitted to the Karnataka state government in 2018.

site_title: Citibank Singapore's head of retail banking resigns
summary: Citibank Singapore's head of retail banking, Charles Wong, has resigned after nearly five years in the role. Wong spent over 20 years at the US bank, leading the unit to deliver "consistent double-digit growth" under his leadership. Wong's departure follows that of another Citi veteran, Han Kwee Juan, who resigned as Citibank Singapore CEO in 2019. The bank's interim head of retail banking is Chan San-San, who will oversee the unit until a permanent successor is found. Wong will leave to pursue opportunities outside the firm.

site_title: Pakistan resumes flights with China
summary: Pakistan has resumed flights to and from China, days after suspending them due to the coronavirus outbreak. The World Health Organization declared the epidemic a global health emergency on Friday. A China Southern Airlines flight with 145 passengers will land at Islamabad International Airport on Monday. The move comes as a growing number of airlines have suspended flights to China due to the outbreak and shrinking demand.

site_title: China to subsidise interest payments for some firms hit by virus outbreak: state media
summary: China's finance ministry will provide subsidies on interest payments for firms affected by the coronavirus outbreak, covering 50% of central bank loans for a year. The move aims to support businesses impacted by the epidemic.

site_title: Chinese treasury futures surge on concerns of coronavirus spread
summary: Chinese treasury futures surged 1.5% on Monday due to concerns over the spread of a newly identified coronavirus, with the 10-year treasury futures for March delivery reaching 101.3 as of 0131 GMT. This increase is attributed to investors' worries about the potential economic impact of the virus.

site_title: Virus worries wipe US$420b off China's stock market
summary: China's benchmark stock index plummeted 8% on its first trading day after the Lunar New Year, wiping out $420 billion in value. The Shanghai Composite index fell to a one-year low, with commodity prices also dropping sharply. The yuan weakened to a 2020 low, and bond prices surged. The central bank injected $173.8 billion into the financial system to support the economy.
