The total number of coronavirus deaths in China rose to 361, sparking concerns about the economic impact of the virus.

site_title: Japanese government bonds rise as coronavirus fears pound China markets
summary: Japanese government bond prices rose on February 3, 2020, as Chinese stocks fell due to concerns over the new coronavirus outbreak. The death toll in China rose to 361, with 17,205 infections. Benchmark 10-year JGB futures rose 0.16 points to 153.02, while the 10-year JGB yield fell to minus 0.075%. This move was seen as a response to China's economic worries, with the 30-year JGB yield remaining flat at 0.365%. The decline in Chinese markets led to a rise in Japanese government bonds.

site_title: Holland Village shophouse units, land parcels up for sale at S$13.8m
summary: A two-unit shophouse in Holland Village, Singapore, has been launched for sale at S$13.8 million. The freehold properties include a first-floor restaurant unit and a second-floor former hair salon unit, with adjacent land parcels totaling 1,020 sq ft. The properties are expected to appeal to investors due to the URA's growth plans for the area and proximity to the Holland Village MRT station. Foreigners can purchase the properties, and the expression of interest exercise closes on March 5. The sale price is indicative, and the eventual buyer may apply for a change of use for the second-floor unit subject to approval.

site_title: Indonesia January inflation 2.68%, lower than expected
summary: Indonesia's annual inflation rate in January was 2.68%, lower than the 2.86% expected by analysts. The inflation figure was calculated using a new formula that changes the base year of the Consumer Price Index (CPI) to 2018. The annual core inflation rate, excluding government-controlled prices, was 2.88%. The new inflation rate is not comparable to the 2.72% rate in December, calculated using the old formula.

site_title: Hugs, a guru and a favourite tree: Djokovic's unusual route to the top
summary: Novak Djokovic, the Australian Open champion for an eighth time, credits his unorthodox approach to success, including a strict vegetarian diet, meditation, and spiritual guidance from guru Pepe Imaz. The 17-time Grand Slam winner has overcome a series of injuries and retirements, including a 43-match winning streak, to become one of the best players in tennis history. Djokovic's dedication to his "love and peace" philosophy has inspired others, including his decision to become a "plant-based athlete."

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon down 1% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) resumed trading on Monday, losing 1% to 3,122.04, with 1.14 billion securities worth S$614.5 million changing hands. Banking stocks, including DBS, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank, fell 1-1.3%. The decline was partly attributed to the ongoing coronavirus outbreak, which drove a 8.1% drop in the Shanghai Composite Index. The Asia-Pacific region saw mixed performances, with Japan's Topix index down 0.7% and South Korea's Kospi slipping 0.1%.

site_title: Main contractor for Pacific Star's Bangkok project stops construction amid dispute
summary: Main contractor China Railway Construction (Southeast Asia) Co (CRCC) has stopped construction works on Pacific Star Development's Posh Twelve project in Bangkok due to disputes over payments and construction progress. Pacific Star Development is seeking "constructive solutions" with CRCC to resume construction work. The company had previously announced the liquidation of its aluminium business division to focus on property development. The project's status remains uncertain, and its impact on Pacific Star Development's financial performance is yet to be determined.

site_title: Koon Holdings names new CFO
summary: KOON Holdings appoints 66-year-old Peter Tan as new CFO, replacing Yee May Yo who resigned after about a year to pursue personal interests. Tan's appointment comes as the company holds creditors' scheme meetings this month.

site_title: Indonesia central bank says intervening to steady the rupiah
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, intervened in the foreign currency market to stabilize the rupiah, which fell 0.4% to its weakest level since mid-January. The move was attributed to a drop in China's equity market amid a rapidly spreading virus epidemic. The bank is buying bonds and offering non-deliverable forwards to stabilize the currency, with the goal of ensuring rupiah stability.

site_title: Philippines' UnionBank offers banking, fintech programme for SMU students
summary: UnionBank of the Philippines has partnered with the Singapore Management University (SMU) to offer a 12-week overseas talent development programme on banking and fintech. Up to 10 SMU students will participate in the Global Innovation Immersion (GII) programme, working on UnionBank projects in selected markets. The initiative aims to develop tech talent in the Philippines and strengthen links with schools and universities in the South-east Asian region. The programme is supported by the Singapore government's Global Innovation Alliance.

site_title: The world's biggest carnivores are turning their backs on beef
summary: Argentina, known for being the world's biggest carnivores per capita, has seen a significant decline in red-meat consumption, falling to its lowest level in a century. This decline is attributed to rampant local inflation, increasing prices of beef globally, and a growing movement toward healthier proteins. The new president, Alberto Fernandez, is considering price caps to make beef affordable again, a move that could impact ranching profits and supply. The country's cattle herds have dwindled, and the industry is struggling to recover, with some predicting a tall order to return to its beef-bingeing past.

site_title: Trump says US has 'shut down' coronavirus threat; China shuns US help
summary: The US has taken measures to protect Americans from the coronavirus, declaring a public health emergency and screening travelers from China, while offering help to China. President Trump said the US "shut down" the threat, but a national security adviser stated China has not accepted US offers of assistance. The US has also set up screening at eight airports and is providing housing for those who may need to be quarantined. The virus has spread to over 30 countries, with 350 deaths reported in China and 171 cases in the US.

site_title: Banks shut Hong Kong, Macau branches in response to virus outbreak
summary: Banks in Hong Kong and Macau have temporarily closed branches due to the Wuhan virus outbreak. OCBC Wing Hang Bank closed 6 branches, while Standard Chartered suspended operations at 18 branches and HSBC closed 24 branches. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has urged banks to maintain basic services and inform customers of closures. This move follows the city's 15 confirmed cases of the virus and comes amid a global outbreak that has sickened over 17,000 people and killed over 360.

site_title: Irish housing crisis derails Varadkar's re-election bid
summary: Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar's re-election bid is at risk due to the country's rapid housing market recovery, which has left many struggling to afford rising rents and house prices. Since 2010, Ireland's economy has transformed, but the boom has created a housing crisis, with house prices increasing 86% in seven years and rents averaging higher in Dublin than in Tokyo, Sydney, or Singapore. The Fine Gael party, which was propelled to power by the 2010 property crash, may lose the general election as a result.

site_title: Maldives bans travellers from China over virus fears, minister says
summary: The Maldives has banned travellers arriving from China due to concerns over the spread of coronavirus, with over 280,000 Chinese tourists visiting the country in 2019. The ban follows the emergence of a flu-like disease in China, which has caused over 350 deaths. The move is a precautionary measure to combat the spread of the virus.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower as investors await China market's reopen; STI down 0.8%
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.8% on Monday, with the Straits Times Index closing at 3,128.55, as investors awaited the reopening of China's markets after a closure due to the Wuhan coronavirus outbreak. The US and European markets also declined on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 2.1% and the S&P 500 losing 1.8%. The decline was attributed to fears that the outbreak would significantly dent global growth.

site_title: AirAsia shares plunge after Airbus bribery allegations
summary: Malaysia's AirAsia Group shares plummeted 10% after allegations by Britain's Serious Fraud Office claimed Airbus paid a $50 million bribe to win plane orders from AirAsia. AirAsia X shares fell 12%. The Malaysian anti-graft agency is investigating, but AirAsia denies making purchase decisions based on Airbus sponsorship and vows to cooperate.

site_title: BlackGold suspends trading pending announcement
summary: BlackGold Natural Resources, a coal mining firm, has suspended trading of its shares pending an announcement about "certain agreements executed" by the company. This follows a previous trading halt on January 29 and unusual price movements on January 14, attributed to potential corporate funding exercises. The shares closed at 1.5 Singapore cents on January 28, up 13% from the previous day. The company's announcement is expected to provide further details on the agreements.

site_title: Broker's take: OCBC downgrades CDLHT to 'hold' on coronavirus outbreak
summary: OCBC Investment Research downgraded CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT) to "hold" due to concerns over the coronavirus outbreak's impact on travel demand, particularly in Singapore, where the company generates 62.3% of its net property income. Despite Q4 results meeting expectations, OCBC lowered its fair value estimate to S$1.62 from S$1.69, citing the risk of booking cancellations and lower RevPAR.

site_title: China: Stocks plunge nearly 9% on virus fears
summary: Chinese stocks plummeted nearly 9% at the start of trade on Monday, February 3, 2020, amid fears over the spiraling coronavirus. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index both fell 8.73% and 8.99% respectively, while the Hong Kong Hang Seng Index edged up 0.17%. The decline was attributed to investor concerns over the extended Chinese New Year holiday and the outbreak.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares down at Monday's open
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 10.4 points or 0.68% to 1,520.6 at Monday's open. The market saw 257.4 million lots traded worth RM79.4 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 435 to 36.

site_title: Irish manufacturing grows for just second time in eight months
summary: Irish manufacturing activity grew for the second time in eight months in January, according to a survey, driven by increased certainty around Brexit and signs of a slowdown in euro zone economic activity. The AIB IHS Markit manufacturing PMI rose to 51.4 from 49.5 in December, with output increasing even further. This follows six years of unbroken growth, which ended in June. The positive data coincided with the week of national elections in Ireland, with economists attributing it to improved euro zone and UK growth prospects, as well as Brexit certainty.

site_title: China iron ore, steel futures tumble as virus fears escalate
summary: China's iron ore and steel futures plummeted on fears of a rapidly spreading virus outbreak, which has killed 350 people and led to travel restrictions. The outbreak's epicenter, Hubei province, has prompted concerns about demand and economic impact. The Chinese New Year holiday break has been extended to curb the spread of the virus, further exacerbating market uncertainty. As a result, investors are reevaluating market outlooks, tariffs, and sanctions, affecting global commodity prices.

site_title: Some exhibitors drop out of Singapore Airshow due to coronavirus
summary: Some aerospace companies, including Textron Inc and General Dynamics Corp's Gulfstream division, dropped out of the Singapore Airshow due to the new coronavirus epidemic. The trade show is set to begin on February 11, but the government measures will likely reduce the number of expected exhibitors and visitors. Despite this, major exhibitors such as Boeing, Airbus, and Lockheed Martin Corp still plan to attend. The decision by Textron and Gulfstream is a precautionary measure to protect employee health. The show will continue with measures in place to address visitor health concerns.

site_title: Police shoot man dead in London after stabbing described as terrorism
summary: Police in London shot and killed a man after he stabbed two people on a busy street in south London, described as a terrorist incident linked to Islamist militancy. A hoax device was found on the man's body, and witnesses reported he was armed with a machete. One man is being treated for life-threatening injuries, while another woman suffered less serious wounds. The incident was contained, and an investigation is underway to establish the full facts. The attack follows a similar incident in November, and the government has announced plans to change the system for handling terrorism offenders.

site_title: Russian oil output up to 11.28m bpd in January, highest since August
summary: Russian oil output rose to 11.28 million barrels per day (bpd) in January, the highest since August, according to Energy Ministry data cited by Interfax. This marks a slight increase from December's 11.26 million bpd. Oil output in tonnes rose to 47.72 million, surpassing December's 47.63 million. The increase aligns with previous reports, solidifying Russia's position as a major oil producer.

site_title: UAE allocates US$2b for investment in Mauritania: state media
summary: The United Arab Emirates (UAE) has allocated US$2 billion for investment and development projects in Mauritania, according to state media. The allocation was announced during a visit by Mauritania's President Mohamed Ould Ghazouani, who is known for his anti-jihadist stance. The UAE and Mauritania have a long history of strong relations, with the UAE seeking to deepen ties and enhance cooperation in various fields. The investment aims to support Mauritania's economic development, which ranks among the poorest countries in the world despite rich natural resources.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS downgrades Far East H-Trust to 'hold' amid virus spread
summary: DBS Group Research downgraded its rating on Far East Hospitality Trust (Far East H-Trust) to "hold" and lowered its 12-month price target to S$0.69, citing "cautious sentiment" amid the coronavirus outbreak. The analyst believes the trust's operations will be negatively impacted due to its exposure to the Singapore market and hotel sector. The revised price target represents a 1% upside from the trust's recent close. The downgrade comes as the trust faces a travel ban on inbound travellers from China and soft corporate demand.

site_title: Philippines' Manila Water sells $286m minority stake to port tycoon
summary: Philippines' Manila Water Co Inc sold a 25% minority stake worth $285.6 million to Prime Metroline Holdings Corp, owned by port tycoon Enrique Razon, for 13 pesos apiece. The deal comes as the company faces scrutiny over concession deals signed in 1997, with President Rodrigo Duterte calling them "onerous and disadvantageous" for ratepayers. The sale is seen as a way to spread risk and forego rate increases, following a significant market loss since Duterte's criticism in December.

site_title: India bonds poised to rally as government skips further borrowing plans
summary: India's bond market is poised for a rally as the government's revised fiscal deficit targets for the current and next fiscal years align with market expectations. The Finance Minister's budget for 2020/21 outlined a multi-billion dollar package for farm and infrastructure spending, but the stimulus fell short of market expectations. The revised deficit targets of 3.8% and 3.5% for the current and next years, respectively, have sparked optimism among bond market players, leading to potential rallies in the market.

site_title: South Korea vows to address financial market volatility amid virus outbreak
summary: South Korea has pledged to implement policies to minimize the impact of the coronavirus outbreak on its economy, with Finance Minister Hong Nam-ki warning against price gouging for face masks and sanitary gels. The government will deploy market stability measures according to contingency plans, and will punish those engaging in price-rigging. The virus has spread globally, with 350 deaths reported in China's Hubei province.

site_title: US stock futures rebound after China stimulus calms virus fear
summary: US stock futures rebounded 0.3-0.2% as China's emergency stimulus aimed to calm the coronavirus outbreak, which has killed over 300 people and infected over 14,000. The move follows a two-week period of volatility in global markets. Despite the stimulus, concerns about the virus's impact on the global economy remain, with the S&P 500 experiencing its largest daily swings in four months. Market experts expect volatility to continue for several weeks.

site_title: Australians boarding for evacuation from China as virus deaths mount
summary: Australians boarded a Qantas flight in Wuhan, China, on Feb 2, 2020, to evacuate from the epicentre of the coronavirus outbreak, with 270 people, including health officials and 18 crew, on board. The flight, chartered by the Australian government, will take passengers into quarantine on Christmas Island in the Indian Ocean. Australia has barred entry to foreign nationals from mainland China and raised its travel warning to the highest level, advising against visiting the country. The evacuees will undergo medical screening and quarantine before being transported to Christmas Island.

site_title: WeWork picks real estate veteran Sandeep Mathrani as new chief executive
summary: WeWork has appointed real estate veteran Sandeep Mathrani as its new CEO, replacing Artie Minson and Sebastian Gunningham. Mathrani, previously chief executive of Brookfield Property Partners' retail group, aims to refocus the company on co-working and abandon unrelated ventures. He will report to executive chairman Marcelo Claure and join the company on February 18. Mathrani's appointment comes after a failed attempt to take the company public and a rescue package from SoftBank Group Corp.

site_title: Australian home prices start year on strong note, building to follow
summary: Australian home prices rose 0.9% in January, the fastest pace since 2017, driven by major cities like Sydney and Melbourne. This brings annual growth to 4.1%, a reversal of the declines seen last year. Despite bushfires and the coronavirus scare, the housing market supports consumer wealth and confidence. Analysts expect the Reserve Bank of Australia to cut interest rates, with a 20% chance of a quarter-point cut this quarter. The rebound in home prices is seen as a boon for wealth and consumer spending, boosting perceived wealth and confidence.

images.alt_text: Australia's housing market started the year with a bang as annual price growth accelerated to the fastest pace since late 2017, supporting consumer wealth and confidence in the face of damaging wildfires and the coronavirus scare.

site_title: Vallianz expects to complete IPT policy review by Feb 29
summary: Vallianz Holdings, a Catalist-listed offshore support vessel provider, expects to complete its review of its interested person transactions (IPT) policy by February 29, 2020, after initially extending its deadline to January 31, 2020. The review aims to tighten measures to ensure compliance with regulatory disclosure requirements and analyze future transactions for possible IPTs. The company will also hold an extraordinary general meeting to seek shareholders' approval and ratification for relevant IPTs by April 30, 2020.

site_title: Sarine Tech sues for IP infringement in India
summary: Sarine Tech, a precision technology products company, has filed additional lawsuits in India alleging patent and copyright infringement against manufacturers of "Galaxy" machines used in diamond production. The lawsuits target locations in Surat city, where court-appointed commissioners conducted surprise inspections. Sarine's "Galaxy" systems are allegedly being manufactured and used in violation of its intellectual property. The company's CEO, David Block, expressed encouragement over the Indian authorities' response to the issue, noting a drop in response time. The cases will proceed through the courts.

site_title: SembMarine unit's ex-president charged with money laundering, corruption
summary: Martin Cheah Kok Choon, former president of SembCorp Marine's Brazilian subsidiary, has been charged with money laundering and corruption in connection with 2012 drilling rig construction contracts with Sete Brasil. Cheah's employment was terminated in 2015, and Guilherme Esteves de Jesus was also charged. SembMarine has suspended consultancy contracts with companies linked to Esteves, and will lodge a further suspicious transaction report with the Singapore Police Force. This development follows a 2019 corruption probe and a 2019 settlement with Sete Brasil for seven drillship contracts worth billions.

site_title: China's Hubei reports 56 new coronavirus deaths, total at 350
summary: China's Hubei province reported 56 new coronavirus deaths, bringing the total to 350, and confirmed 2,103 new cases, increasing the total to 11,177. The province is the epicentre of the outbreak.

site_title: Plane carrying Portuguese from coronavirus-hit Wuhan touches down in Lisbon
summary: A military plane carrying 20 Portuguese nationals from coronavirus-hit Wuhan, China, landed in Lisbon on Sunday. The evacuees, including two diplomats, agreed to 14-day self-isolation as a precautionary measure. They underwent medical tests before departure and upon arrival to check for coronavirus symptoms. The group was part of a larger repatriation effort of 250 European nationals from Wuhan.

site_title: M Development inks pact to buy Antai Mining International in RTO deal
summary: M Development has entered into a sale and purchase agreement to acquire Antai Mining International, a marble mining firm in China, in a reverse takeover deal. The acquisition is expected to result in a reverse takeover and will be subject to shareholder approval. The cost of the acquisition has not been disclosed, and M Development has appointed Zico Capital, RSM Chio Lim LLP, and Drew & Napier LLC as financial adviser, reporting accountant, and legal adviser, respectively. The deal is conditional on completion of due diligence and valuation by February 29 and April 30.

site_title: Iraq bars foreign arrivals from China over coronavirus fears
summary: Iraq's interior ministry announced it will not allow foreigners traveling from China to enter the country due to coronavirus fears, citing protective measures to safeguard public health and safety. No coronavirus cases have been detected in Iraq or among Iraqi expatriates abroad. The decision follows a global health emergency declared by the World Health Organization, which has reported nearly 14,500 cases and over 300 deaths in China and over 100 cases in 20 other countries, including the US.

site_title: Paradise lost looms for German farmers as swine fever nears
summary: Germany is at risk of losing its pig farmers due to African swine fever (ASF) after a case was discovered in a wild boar in Poland near the border. To prevent the disease from spreading, the state of Brandenburg has erected 120 km of electric fencing. However, farmers believe the barrier is unlikely to be effective, and a confirmed case in Germany could lead to an import ban on German pork, causing a significant drop in prices and potential losses of at least €300 million.

site_title: 'Britain will prosper': PM Johnson sets out tough terms for EU talks
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson will outline his negotiating terms for EU talks, emphasizing that Britain will prosper even without a preferred trade deal. Johnson will say Britain will not adhere to EU rules and regulations, instead pursuing a trade arrangement similar to Australia's, which has a looser relationship with the bloc. He will promise to maintain "the highest standards" and suggest the EU has already offered a free trade deal comparable to the one with Canada, which does not have to follow EU rules.

site_title: China oil demand has plunged 20% because of the virus lockdown
summary: China's oil demand has plummeted 20% due to the coronavirus lockdown, equivalent to a 3 million barrel daily drop. This is the largest demand shock since the 2008 global financial crisis and the most sudden since the 9/11 attacks. China's central bank is taking measures to boost liquidity, while OPEC is considering an emergency meeting to cut production and stabilize prices. The collapse in Chinese oil consumption is reverberating across the global energy market, with sales of some crudes slowing and benchmark prices in free-fall.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SembMarine, SIA, Ascendas Reit, Sarine, Pacific Star, Lifebrandz
summary: SembCorp Marine faces charges of money laundering and corruption in Brazil, affecting its shares. Singapore Airlines suspends flights to mainland China due to the Wuhan virus, impacting its shares. Ascendas Reit's distribution per unit fell 12.3% due to a rights issue, while Sarine Technologies files lawsuits in India over intellectual property infringement. Pacific Star Development's construction project in Bangkok halted due to payment disputes. Lifebrandz proposes a 50-to-1 share consolidation and rights issue to repay shareholder advances.

site_title: Singapore market welcomes first 2020 listings
summary: Singapore's stock market welcomed its first 2020 listings with Resources Global Development's debut on the Catalist Board, marking the second listing of the year. The market saw a decline in IPOs in 2019, but the number of listings is symptomatic of economic growth, with Singapore's economy growing 0.7% in 2019. Key sectors like property trusts and Reits performed well, with the STI benchmark delivering a 9% dividend-inclusive return.

site_title: Police end protest at German coal plant site, activists plan repeat
summary: Police broke up a protest by about 100 environmental activists at the Datteln 4 coal-fired power plant in western Germany, where activists had occupied the site for nine hours. The protest, led by the Ende Gelaende movement, aimed to block coal delivery to the plant and draw attention to its carbon emissions. Despite the police intervention, the group vowed to continue their demonstrations, likening the protest to a previous occupation of a lignite mining site. The protesters are opposed to the plant's exemption from a national plan to exit coal power by 2038.

site_title: Opec to discuss oil price fall after virus epidemic
summary: Opec members, including Russia, will convene a technical meeting to analyze the recent 18% drop in US benchmark oil prices due to the coronavirus epidemic. The meeting aims to understand the impact of the virus on oil demand, particularly in China, the world's second-largest economy. Experts will discuss how psychological factors and pessimistic views have contributed to the price decline. The Opec cartel, led by Saudi Arabia, has been closely monitoring the situation and has extended an agreement to curb crude oil production to maintain prices.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Reinventing the retail experience
summary: DiSa, a Singapore-based digital security company, has launched an integrated mobile phone warranty programme protecting users against cyber theft. The programme aims to reinvent the retail experience for customers, suppliers, and retailers in tech, with DiSa's group CEO Eddie Chng sharing insights on the initiative.

site_title: Allied Tech independent directors assisting in CAD probe
summary: The Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) of Singapore is investigating Allied Technologies, a Catalist-listed firm, following the disappearance of S$33 million in funds parked with its former partner JLC Advisors. Two independent directors, Pok Mee Yau and Lim Jin Wei, have been assisting the CAD in the probe. The company has cooperated fully with the investigation and has not disclosed any further details. A former managing partner, Jeffrey Ong Su Aun, has been slapped with 26 charges, including criminal breach of trust, related to the missing funds.

site_title: 'Bad Boys' stays on top of the box office in its third weekend
summary: "Bad Boys for Life" stays at the top of the box office for its third weekend, earning an estimated US$17.7 million in domestic ticket sales, bringing its cumulative domestic sales to around US$148.1 million. The film's distributor, Sony, reports an additional US$142.7 million overseas. Newcomers "Gretel & Hansel" and "The Rhythm Section" underperformed, with domestic sales of US$6.1 million and US$2.8 million, respectively. Holdovers "1917," "Dolittle," and "The Gentlemen" rounded out the top five.

site_title: Aramco-like mammoth IPO proposed for India's biggest insurer
summary: India's government plans to sell a part of its stake in the state-run Life Insurance Corporation of India (LIC), targeting a record asset-sale target of 2.1 trillion rupees. The sale, likened to Saudi Aramco's record-breaking IPO, could fetch the government between 850 billion to 900 billion rupees. However, the process may be delayed due to the need to amend the law, and the sale's impact on the market is uncertain, with some analysts predicting a 10% dilution could be difficult to absorb.

site_title: Djokovic beats Thiem in five-set thriller to win his 17th Grand Slam title
summary: Novak Djokovic defeated Dominic Thiem 6-4, 4-6, 2-6, 6-3, 6-4 in a five-set Australian Open final, claiming his 17th Grand Slam title and regaining the world number one ranking. Djokovic, 32, overcame intense pressure to win his eighth Australian Open title and moved into third place on the all-time Grand Slam list, behind Rafael Nadal and Roger Federer.

site_title: Chinese central bank to pump US$173b into economy in virus fight
summary: China's central bank announced a US$173 billion injection into the economy to combat a deadly virus, aiming to maintain liquidity and a stable currency market. The 1.2 trillion yuan (reverse repurchase operation) will be launched on Monday, exceeding last year's liquidity by 900 billion yuan. This move aims to mitigate the economic impact of the virus, which is expected to hit growth. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) will provide support to the banking system and currency market during the epidemic.

site_title: Measuring the impact of the Wuhan virus
summary: The Wuhan virus is expected to have a "much wider and deeper impact" on global health, according to recent assessments. The outbreak, which originated in China, has spread to multiple countries, raising concerns about its long-term effects. As of February 2, 2020, the virus has been linked to cases in several countries, including the US, Japan, and South Korea. The impact of the virus on global markets is also being closely monitored, with stock markets experiencing volatility due to concerns about its spread and potential economic disruption.

site_title: Beijing announces stability measures as markets brace for sell-off on Monday
summary: Beijing has announced measures to ensure stability in its $45 trillion financial system amid the spreading coronavirus. The People's Bank of China will supply 1.2 trillion yuan to money markets and halt night sessions for futures trading. The securities regulator will allow share pledge contracts to be extended by up to six months. These measures come as the nation's economy is expected to slow, with Citigroup forecasting a 4.8% growth rate for the quarter. Policymakers aim to prevent irrational behavior and support the nation's fight against the virus outbreak.

site_title: UK commercial property investments forecast to rise by 9.3% this year: JLL
summary: UK commercial property investment transactions are forecast to surge to £55 billion in 2020, a 9.3% increase from 2019, according to JLL estimates. The market is expected to recover as investors become more confident following the Conservative victory and Brexit, with warehouses, logistics, and offices providing opportunities for local and foreign investors. The retail sector is expected to remain weak, but the government's plans to redevelop depressed regions and boost funding for infrastructure may benefit the property market in cities such as Birmingham and Manchester.

site_title: Libra Group replies to SGX queries on board reconstitution
summary: Libra Group has responded to Singapore Exchange (SGX) queries regarding its board reconstitution. CEO Christine Liu will remain in her role, overseeing day-to-day operations. Former chairman Chu Sau Ben resigned but will assist Liu as deputy general manager of Kin Xin Engineering. Independent director Joel Leong Kum Hoe resigned due to differing views on restructuring. New director Calvin Tan Siok Sing holds past directorships in troubled companies, but Libra's board and sponsor RHT Capital argue there's no reason to consider this unsuitable. Financial and legal advisers have been appointed to assist the restructuring process.

site_title: French couple living off-grid challenges French zoning laws
summary: A French couple, Jonathan Attias and Caroline Perez, are challenging the country's zoning laws by building an off-grid cabin in a forested area. They aim to demonstrate that people can live in harmony with nature, rather than against the law. The couple, who own a car and have medical insurance, tend a vegetable garden and use solar power to heat their home. They believe their lifestyle upgrades the environment, not degrades it. Their movement, Desobeissance fertile, seeks to change the law and allow more people to live off-grid, with the support of landowners.

site_title: French transport strikes hold healthier upside for Parisians
summary: French transport strikes have brought short-term disruption but may lead to long-term benefits for Parisians. The strikes, which lasted over a month, forced commuters to find alternative modes of transport, leading to a shift towards cycling and electrically assisted bikes. A study found that 19% of commuters discovered new modes of transport during the strikes, with 59% of those who switched to cycling expressing interest in continuing to use it. Economists see potential lessons in the impact of the strikes on transport, health, and worker productivity, suggesting that workers may adopt healthier habits and more efficient ways of commuting.

site_title: Kuwait serves up a swarm of locusts - boiled, baked and dried
summary: In Kuwait, locusts are consumed as a delicacy, particularly among older citizens, who consider them a nutritious and tasty snack. Locusts are imported from Saudi Arabia and can be boiled, baked, or dried. While some people, like journalist Moudi al-Miftah, enjoy eating them, others, including younger generations, find the idea repulsive. Locusts are rich in protein and are considered a sustainable food source by experts, but authorities have faced challenges in regulating their sale due to concerns over contamination.

site_title: Livingstone looks to fresh shot at listing
summary: Livingstone Health, a Singapore-based healthcare firm, is rebranding as it prepares to list on the capital market via an IPO or backdoor listing within 12-18 months. The company has deconsolidated from its founder and CEO Sean Ng, who left after a patient's death under his care in 2016. Livingstone has expanded its business segments and added new services, including cardiology and family medicine, and aims to export Singapore's healthcare reputation to ASEAN countries. The company has signed contracts in Cambodia, Vietnam, and Thailand to provide medical services and expertise.

site_title: Market heads into Feb with virus outbreak worries
summary: Singapore's stock market is expected to see more decline in February due to the escalating Wuhan coronavirus situation. The Straits Times Index fell 0.5% last Friday, and the US' S&P 500 reached its lowest since October. Companies such as Starbucks and Apple warned about the impact on their performance. Singapore-listed firms like Ascott Residence Trust and CapitaLand Retail China Trust are also affected, with some providing updates on business impact. The market is expected to remain volatile until the situation improves.

site_title: Rental prices on Berlin apartments frozen or lowered for 5 years in bid to slow gentrification
summary: Berlin's leftist government has frozen or lowered rental prices for over 1.5 million apartments for five years, aiming to slow gentrification and make housing more affordable for lower- and middle-income residents. The measure caps most rents at 2019 levels, limiting increases based on apartment conditions and amenities. Critics argue the move will harm the property market and discourage affordable housing development, while supporters say it will ease strain on renters and encourage private developers to build more lower-priced properties.

site_title: ESG, SBF head business mission to Jakarta
summary: Enterprise Singapore (ESG) and the Singapore Business Federation (SBF) are leading a business mission to Jakarta during President Halimah Yacob's state visit. The mission aims to discuss business opportunities in infrastructure and manufacturing, particularly in priority sectors such as manufacturing, digital economy, and consumer services. This follows previous agreements between ESG and Indonesia's Ministry of Industry to strengthen partnerships between Indonesian manufacturers and Singapore manufacturing innovation enablers. The visit is seen as a way to promote growth and connectivity in the region.

site_title: Pasteurised camembert? French cheesemakers vote 'non'
summary: French cheesemakers have voted against allowing pasteurised versions of camembert, a traditional raw-milk cheese, with 53% rejecting a plan to give industrial producers the "Camembert of Normandy" label. The decision aims to preserve the cheese's authenticity and quality, with critics arguing that pasteurisation would alter its flavor and texture. The vote reverses a proposal that would have increased dairy farming in western France and required industrial producers to use more traditional methods and native Normande cows.

site_title: CMT-CCT merger: Should minority investors back the deal?
summary: Minority investors of CMT and CCT are weighing the merits of a proposed S$8.27 billion merger that would create a third-largest Reit in the Asia Pacific. The merger, expected to boost CCT's distribution per unit and CMT's earnings per share, may favor CCT's minority investors due to its office properties, which could diversify CMT's portfolio away from retail risks. However, CMT's retail properties may face persistent risks as e-commerce disrupts traditional shops. The merger's outcome may ultimately benefit CapitaLand, the sponsor of the merged entity, as it aligns with its strategic pivot away from the retail property sector.

site_title: China's plant-closing cascade may cut 1.7m cars
summary: China's car sales are expected to plummet due to the coronavirus outbreak, potentially cutting 1.7 million cars from production. If sales drop 20% from last year, it would threaten to end China's decade-long run as the world's largest car market. The epidemic has triggered a cascade of plant closings, with 14 provinces and cities shutting businesses and factories until at least mid-February, affecting major manufacturers like General Motors, Honda, and Nissan. The impact on the global car industry is expected to be significant, with supply chains and domestic sales suffering greatly.

site_title: Yen, Swiss franc advance as virus fears snowball
summary: The yen and Swiss franc surged to multi-week highs as concerns over the global economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak in China intensified. The US dollar fell, while the Australian dollar hit a four-month low. The World Health Organization declared the outbreak a global emergency, prompting the US to tighten travel curbs. The death toll rose to 213 in China, with over 9,800 confirmed cases. Investors prioritized the virus's impact on the global economy over expected economic data.

site_title: Philippines offers zippy growth in the consumer space
summary: The Philippines is experiencing zippy growth in its consumer space, driven by a population of 107 million and growing income levels. The country is expected to continue its upward growth, with the Asian Development Bank projecting a 6.4% GDP growth in 2020. The food and non-alcoholic sector dominates consumer spending, with over 200 mid-range and luxury foreign retail brands entering the market in recent years. However, Singapore companies may face challenges such as brand competition and regulatory requirements, with a paid-up capital requirement of US$2.5 million. To succeed, companies should take a long-term approach, exercise flexibility in pricing, and localise product offerings to suit local tastes and preferences.

site_title: Singapore tech firm survives China to return to Asean
summary: Singapore-based tech firm ADERA, which previously operated in China, is shifting its focus to the underbanked and unbanked populations in South-east Asia. With ambitions for an initial public offering, ADERA aims to leverage its secured data handling expertise to provide digital ID, digital payments, and digital automation solutions to banks and governments in the region. The company has already established a presence in several countries, including Vietnam, Malaysia, and the Philippines, and is working with local lenders to develop automated banking solutions. ADERA's CEO, Anthony Ong, believes the region has huge potential for financial inclusion and is committed to expanding the company's presence prudently.

site_title: Fewer director filings as earnings season picks up
summary: Fewer director filings were reported as earnings season picked up, with 50 changes in director interests and substantial shareholdings filed for 25 primary-listed stocks. Share buybacks totaled S$3.7 million, led by Singapore Exchange, Stamford Land Corporation, and Singapore Press Holdings. Notable transactions included Koh Brothers Eco Engineering's issuance of 233 million new shares, increasing the direct interest of Koh Brothers Group in the company, and ARA Trust Management's (Cache Logistics Trust) strategic partnership with LOGOS Group. Other companies saw increases in substantial shareholder stakes, including Hwa Hong Corporation, GuoLine Overseas Ltd, and CIM Investment Management Ltd.

site_title: UOB and its clients raise over S$1.8m for charity at Chinese New Year fundraiser
summary: UOB's group commercial banking unit and over 800 clients raised S$1.8 million for local charities at the bank's Chinese New Year fundraiser. The event, held at The Ritz-Carlton, Millennia Singapore, saw UOB match clients' donations dollar for dollar up to S$250,000. This year's total surpassed last year's amount, demonstrating the bank's commitment to giving back to the community.

site_title: Critical to have Business Continuity Plans in place
summary: Businesses should implement robust Business Continuity Plans to mitigate the risks of the Wuhan coronavirus, prioritizing employee safety and adapting to changing circumstances. Experts emphasize the importance of proactive measures, situational awareness, and timely decision-making. Key recommendations include reviewing and updating plans, minimizing non-essential travel, and promoting flexible work arrangements. Employers should also encourage employees to follow guidelines, maintain good hygiene practices, and provide support during the crisis. By striking a balance between "business as usual" and risk management, businesses can minimize disruptions and maintain operations while prioritizing employee and customer safety.

images.alt_text: Cheung Pui Yuen, Chief Executive Officer, Deloitte Singapore.
Chris Burton, Managing Director, South East Asia, Vistra Group.

site_title: Libra Group replies to SGX queries on board reconstitution
summary: Libra Group, a Singapore-based company, has addressed queries from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) regarding its board reconstitution. The SGX had raised concerns over Calvin Tan's past directorships in troubled companies. Libra stated that no regulatory actions were taken against Tan or the companies. The company's CEO, Christine Liu, will remain in charge, and former chairman Chu Sau Ben will assist her in day-to-day operations. Libra has also appointed financial and legal advisers to aid in the restructuring process. The board's plans to restructure the group via a scheme of arrangement will continue.

site_title: UK, EU businesses quiver as leaders play tough-guy
summary: UK and EU business leaders are concerned about the potential division between the two parties in trade negotiations, fearing increased uncertainty at a time when the Wuhan coronavirus is affecting economies. The UK's Prime Minister Boris Johnson wants a free trade deal with the EU by the end of 2020, but the EU is pushing for a more comprehensive agreement. A "Canada-style deal" proposed by Johnson would not cover the UK's financial services sector, and the EU is demanding key European rules be met. Negotiations are expected to be uncompromising, raising fears of a deal collapse and reliance on World Trade Organisation rules.

site_title: Use of facial recognition in Europe setting off some alarm bells
summary: The European Union has acknowledged the use of facial recognition technology, but aims to regulate its use to ensure it adheres to European values such as strict personal privacy. The US and China dominate the industry, with Hangzhou Hikvision Digital Technology and Zhejiang Dahua Technology controlling one-third of the global market for video surveillance. The EU's proposed regulations would target high-risk applications and require companies to hand over documentation of their systems' data sets and programming for inspection. Facial recognition has been criticized for its inaccuracies, particularly for women and people with darker skin tones.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary: Singapore Government Bonds quotation results were not mentioned in the provided articles. Key market news includes oil rising over 2% due to investors weighing market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions; stocks in Europe and the US down due to bank and healthcare drag, as well as US-EU tariffs; NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed; US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats; and Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss below targets. Additionally, Heathrow eyes higher fees for a £10b upgrade, and an Indonesian employee was detained in a graft case.

site_title: Budget 2020: A game changer for Singapore's climate policies?
summary: Singapore's Budget 2020 may include climate policies, such as incentives for electric vehicles and green financial instruments, as the government updates its climate pledge under the Paris Agreement. The country aims to reduce emissions intensity by 36% by 2030 and peak emissions around the same time. However, experts believe there is a limit to how much the government can impose curbs on businesses, particularly multinational corporations. The government could consider promoting the use of electric vehicles, subsidizing public transportation operators, and increasing the carbon tax to fund greening initiatives.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for the week ending February 2, 2020, reveals a negative week for the tanker and dry bulk market. The Baltic Capesize Index (BCI) turned negative, closing at -20, while the average route price settled at $3,973. The Q1 weakness, Chinese New Year, and the rapidly evolving coronavirus crisis weighed heavily on the market. Rates for various routes, including the North Atlantic, Panamax, Supramax/Ultramax, Handysize, VLCC, Suezmax, and Aframax, fell significantly. The market remains cautious, with owners reluctant to trade vessels to China, and limited fixture activity reported from the Pacific basin.

site_title: Wuhan virus outbreak likely to have 'much wider and deeper impact' than Sars: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing warns that the Wuhan virus outbreak is likely to have a wider and deeper impact on the global economy than the Sars outbreak in 2003. China's GDP has more than doubled, increasing global interlinkages, making disruptions to the Chinese economy more severe. Singapore has implemented travel restrictions, and the government is studying measures to help affected industries, including tourism, aviation, and manufacturing, with the goal of maintaining air connectivity between Singapore and China.

site_title: Wuhan virus support package to help firms retain and retrain workers: DPM Heng
summary: Singapore Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announced plans to unveil targeted measures to support businesses affected by the Wuhan coronavirus outbreak at Budget 2020 on Feb 18. The measures include wage support to help companies retain and retrain workers, as well as assistance with short-term cash flow problems. Heng emphasized the need for flexibility, stating that the situation is "fast-evolving" and that the final package will be decided based on the evolving situation. The government is prepared to support Singapore firms in the event of a broad-based slowdown, but no specific details have been released.

site_title: LifeBrandz proposes 50:1 share consolidation and rights issue
summary: LifeBrandz proposes a 50:1 share consolidation and a renounceable non-underwritten rights issue to repay shareholder advances. The consolidation will reduce volatility and fluctuations in market capitalization, while the rights issue will raise S$6.55 million in the maximum subscription scenario. Two shareholders, Bounty Blue Capital and Capital Square Co, have received irrevocable undertakings to subscribe for a portion of their entitlements, totaling S$1.857 million. The share consolidation and rights issue are subject to shareholder approval at an extraordinary general meeting.

site_title: Allied Tech independent directors assisting in CAD probe
summary: The Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) is investigating Allied Technologies, seeking assistance from independent directors Pok Mee Yau and Lim Jin Wei. The investigation began after $33 million in funds went missing and the company's managing partner, Jeffrey Ong Su Aun, was slapped with 26 charges. CAD has seized documents and interviewed Allied Tech's executives, but has not disclosed further details. The company intends to cooperate fully with the investigation, which has been ongoing since May. Trading in Allied Tech shares remains suspended.

site_title: US: Wall Street plunges at the open as pandemic fears heighten
summary: US stocks plummeted at the open on Friday, February 28, 2020, as investors sold equities amid fears of a global recession due to the rapidly spreading coronavirus outbreak. The Dow Jones fell 1.92% to 25,270.83, the S&P 500 dropped 2.08% to 2,916.90, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 3.46% to 8,269.74. The market downturn occurred despite the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records just days earlier.

site_title: LifeBrandz proposes 50:1 share consolidation, rights issue
summary: LifeBrandz proposes a 50-to-1 share consolidation and a rights issue to repay shareholder advances. The consolidation aims to reduce volatility in its share price, while the rights issue will raise up to S$6.55 million, primarily used to pay off shareholder advances and professional fees. The company has received irrevocable undertakings from two shareholders to subscribe for a portion of their total entitlements, with the issue price representing a discount of approximately 93% to the closing price of S$0.40 per share.

site_title: IBM's new CEO is mastermind behind cloud-for-growth tack
summary: IBM's new CEO, Arvind Krishna, is the mastermind behind the company's hybrid multi-cloud strategy, a game-changer for the company. Introduced in 2017, the strategy connects clients' data to public cloud servers, and IBM launched its product three months later. Krishna, who has spent his entire career at IBM, is seen as a "Nadella-like" leader, calm and deep, and represents a new leadership style for the company. He will take over as CEO on April 6, replacing Ginni Rometty, who will step down after nearly 40 years at the company.

site_title: Stocks fall on fears of virus outbreak; red flag up for oil
summary: US stocks fell on February 2, 2020, due to fears of a coronavirus outbreak, with the number of infections surpassing 14,000 and deaths exceeding 300. The World Health Organization upgraded its assessment to a global public health emergency, contributing to market volatility. The sell-off raised concerns of a potential correction. Meanwhile, oil prices rose over 2% amid market uncertainty and global economic concerns.

site_title: Wuhan virus: STB to waive licence fees for hotels, travel agents and tour guides, and help with hotels' cleaning costs
summary: The Singapore Tourism Board (STB) will waive licence fees for hotels, travel agents, and tourist guides affected by the novel coronavirus outbreak. STB will also cover up to 50% of third-party cleaning fees for hotels with confirmed cases. The measures aim to support tourism-reliant businesses hit by the virus spread. The full package of relief measures will be announced on February 18. This move comes as over 14,000 cases and 300 deaths have been reported worldwide, with Chinese tourists accounting for 20% of Singapore's international visitor arrivals.

site_title: Europe: Stocks shed US$1.5t as virus fears spur week-long selling frenzy
summary: European shares plummeted by US$1.5 trillion in their worst weekly performance since the 2008 financial crisis due to sustained selling fueled by coronavirus fears and the risk of a recession. The STOXX 600 index fell 3.5% on Friday, marking a 13.2% decline from its record high. Analysts attribute the decline to systematic position reductions, driven by self-enforcing market flows.

site_title: US flight rules on China visits will pose new airline challenges
summary: The US Department of Homeland Security has issued new rules requiring US-bound passengers who have recently visited China to undergo enhanced screening, including a question about mainland China travel. Airlines are expected to scrutinize passports and may require passengers to arrive earlier for flights. The rules apply to passengers who have been in China within the last two weeks, with Americans subject to up to 14 days of mandatory quarantine if they visited Hubei province. The new rules impact flights from China and American travelers, with eight major US airports designated for enhanced screening.

site_title: Goldman sees safe-haven gold hitting US$1,800
summary: Goldman Sachs raised its 12-month gold forecast to $1,800 an ounce due to the coronavirus, depressed real rates, and increased focus on the US election. Spot gold traded at $1,651.70 an ounce, near a seven-year high, as investors sought safety in gold and bonds. The bank expects prices to climb to $1,700 an ounce in three months and $1,750 in six months. Investors are betting on rate cuts by the US Federal Reserve and other central banks, reducing the opportunity cost of holding gold, driving demand for the metal as a haven.

site_title: Australia: Shares battered as pandemic fears mount; NZ down
summary: Australia's shares plummeted 2.3% on Wednesday as pandemic fears intensified, with the S&P/ASX 200 index falling to its lowest close in nearly two months. The global market also suffered, with MSCI's World Index losing US$3 trillion. The US warned of an inevitable pandemic, while Asia reported hundreds of new coronavirus cases. The flu-like virus has infected 80,000 people and killed over 2,700, mostly in China. Financial stocks, including the "Big Four" banks, were the biggest drag, with New Zealand's benchmark index also falling 1.6%.

site_title: Is craft beer losing its fizz?
summary: Singapore's craft beer market, dominated by big brands, has seen a rise in small-batch brewers, with over 20 local brands now available. Despite growing demand, craft beer accounts for only 3% of the market, with Tiger Beer being the most popular. New entrants, such as Off Day Beer Company, are debuting, and online channels like RedMart are increasing exposure. However, stiff competition from commercial breweries and high costs, including taxes and labor fees, hinder growth. Local breweries are adapting by focusing on niche markets and events to reach new audiences.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks enjoy rare upturn
summary: Hong Kong stocks experienced a rare upturn on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.31% to 26,778.62, driven by signs of easing coronavirus spread in China. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained 0.11% and 0.24%, respectively. This marks a positive trend as the spread of the virus showed more infections reported outside China than inside, suggesting a possible slowdown in the outbreak's impact on markets.

site_title: French carmaker PSA unveils mini electric Citroen car
summary: French carmaker PSA unveiled a mini electric Citroen car, branded "AMI", priced at US$7,500, set to go on sale by June. The two-seater vehicle, measuring 2.41 meters long, targets young city dwellers and can be driven without a license in major European markets. The move aims to stimulate demand for electric models as carmakers face tougher regulations.

site_title: Bank of Korea seen cutting rates to record-low to battle coronavirus: poll
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, is expected to cut its policy rate to a record-low of 1.00% in February to combat the impact of the coronavirus on its economy, which is heavily reliant on trade. The move is seen as a pre-emptive measure to offset the disruption to global supply chains and demand. Analysts predict the rate cut, with some expecting further easing by May, as the economy faces a grave situation with rising confirmed cases and a sharp decline in consumer sentiment.

site_title: ST Engineering's Q4 profit up 36.2% at S$169.5m
summary: ST Engineering's Q4 net profit rose 36.2% to S$169.5 million, driven by a 29% increase in revenue. The company expects continued growth momentum in 2020 despite the COVID-19 outbreak, with its aerospace sector likely to bear the brunt of the impact. However, the firm is working with affected airlines to reschedule maintenance, repair, and operations (MROs). Revenue growth was led by the marine and aerospace sectors, with the company also set to deliver 20 electric buses for public transport in Singapore.

site_title: Men In Blue
summary: Singapore's police force, established in 1820, has come a long way since its underpaid and understaffed beginnings. The SPF 200 Exhibition at National Museum of Singapore documents its history through archival photos, videos, and artefacts. The police force has dealt with various crimes, including secret society riots and communist-motivated crimes. The exhibition features interactive experiences, guided tours by retired police officers, and a re-enactment of a real-life crime scene. Singapore ranked second safest city in the world in 2019, according to the Economist Intelligence Unit. The exhibition runs until May 17.

site_title: Disrupting ageing
summary: US National Academy of Medicine president Victor Dzau advocates for "disrupted ageing" where individuals can achieve healthy longevity through various means, including technology advancements. He emphasizes that healthy longevity is about improving physical, mental, and social well-being, rather than just treating diseases. Dzau believes that societal factors, such as climate change, mental health problems, and stress, can impact biology and longevity. Despite concerns about the world's ability to contain the Covid-19 outbreak, Dzau remains optimistic about the response and the potential for a vaccine to emerge in four months.

site_title: Boeing CEO faces long to-do list to collect bonus
summary: Boeing CEO Dave Calhoun is eligible for a $7 million bonus, but must first resolve issues with the 737 Max, Starliner spacecraft, KC-46 tanker, and other programs. He must also guide the 777X through regulatory review and achieve long-range milestones. If not achieved by the end of 2023, the bonus will be forfeited. Critics argue the bonus creates a financial incentive to prioritize profit over safety, while Boeing claims it aligns with prioritizing safety and the safe return of the Max.

site_title: ANA orders 15 more Dreamliners worth US$5b, switches to GE engines
summary: ANA Holdings Inc ordered 15 Boeing 787 Dreamliners worth $5 billion, including 11 787-10s and 4 787-9s, with options for 5 more 787-9s. The deal marks Boeing's first commercial order in 2020 and follows ANA's decision to switch from Rolls-Royce to General Electric engines to minimize single-source risks. The first delivery will be in April 2022, bringing ANA's total 787 purchase to 98 planes, of which 71 are in service.

site_title: SGX gives all firms 2-month breather to hold AGM amid virus outbreak
summary: SGX RegCo grants all firms, regardless of operations, a 2-month extension to hold annual general meetings (AGMs) due to Covid-19 concerns. Firms with a Dec 31, 2019 financial year-end now have until June 30, 2020, to hold their AGMs. The extension allows companies to consider alternative arrangements, such as virtual information sessions and proxy voting, to minimize congregation size and ensure timely information sharing with shareholders.

site_title: Plácido Domingo had 'inappropriate activity' with women, union finds
summary: Opera superstar Plácido Domingo, 79, has been found to have engaged in "inappropriate activity, ranging from flirtation to sexual advances" by the American Guild of Musical Artists. The investigation, prompted by over 20 women's allegations of sexual misconduct, concluded that Domingo's actions caused fear of retaliation in the industry, preventing some from coming forward sooner. Domingo apologized, accepting full responsibility and stating he has grown from the experience. His career was previously sidelined last year by similar allegations, with several US companies canceling his appearances.

site_title: Coronavirus outbreak slashes China's carbon emissions: study
summary: A study by the Centre for Research on Energy and Clean Air found that China's carbon emissions have dropped by at least 100 million metric tonnes over the past two weeks due to the coronavirus epidemic, which is nearly six percent of global emissions during the same period last year. The drop in demand for coal and oil led to a decrease in power generation and steel production. However, environmentalists warn that this reduction is temporary and that a government stimulus could reverse the environmental gains, potentially resulting in "retaliatory pollutions" when production resumes.

site_title: Grab, Chubb offer free Covid-19 insurance benefit to drivers, delivery workers
summary: Grab and insurer Chubb are teaming up to offer a free Covid-19 insurance benefit to drivers and food delivery service providers until March 19. The Driver Care benefit provides lump-sum payouts of S$1,000 to drivers diagnosed with Covid-19, while others receive S$500. This initiative aims to give drivers better peace of mind as they continue to provide services amid the virus situation. Drivers can access the additional insurance coverage immediately without further actions required.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand: Shares hit record high on China stimulus hopes
summary: Australian shares reached a record high, up 0.4% to 7,175.70, driven by hopes of China's stimulus amid the coronavirus outbreak. China is expected to cut its benchmark lending rate, and new cases in Hubei province dropped to 349, boosting risk sentiment. Key sectors, including mining, retail, and energy, also rose, with Qantas Airways gaining 8.4% on a share buyback and dividend announcement. The New Zealand benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index also surpassed 12,000 for the first time.

site_title: Charged up: Singapore's journey to the future of cars begins now
summary: Singapore aims to phase out internal combustion engines by 2040, making electric vehicles (EVs) the primary choice. Currently, EVs make up 0.2% of the 1,125 cars on the road. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat outlined this vision in his Budget speech, despite criticism from Tesla's CEO Elon Musk in 2018. The government's push for EVs is part of its efforts to reduce carbon emissions and promote sustainable transportation.

site_title: Thailand denies PM aided Malaysia 1MDB graft scandal
summary: Thailand's government has denied allegations that Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha aided in the cover-up of Malaysia's 1MDB graft scandal by allowing fugitive financier Jho Low to pass through the country. The Future Forward Party, which accused Gen Prayuth of obstructing international justice, was dissolved by a court and its members banned from politics for a decade. A Thai government spokesman said the accusations are "not true" and that the concerned ministries are considering legal action against the party.

site_title: Agile marketer
summary: IBM's Michelle Peluso emphasizes the importance of listening to customers and understanding their needs in today's data-driven marketing landscape. She advocates for a personalized approach, using authentic and human stories to connect with customers. To achieve this, companies must tailor their stories to local markets and deliver effective solutions. Peluso also stresses the need for marketers to be agile, leveraging technology such as AI to augment their role and tap into customer data. She believes a dynamic partnership between humans and technology is key, and companies must balance personalization with customer privacy concerns. Peluso also champions diversity, citing IBM's efforts to increase representation of women in management roles.

site_title: Apple says will not meet revenue forecasts due to virus
summary: Apple reports it will not meet revenue forecasts due to the novel coronavirus, citing disruptions in production and demand in China. The company expects a slower return to normal conditions than planned and will experience "temporarily constrained" worldwide iPhone supply. Apple forecasted revenue of $63-67 billion for the second quarter, but now expects to fall short. The COVID-19 virus has infected over 70,500 in China and sparked economic jitters globally, with the IMF warning of a potential 0.1-0.2 percentage point cut to global growth.

site_title: China pledges more fiscal support as virus roils a slowing economy
summary: China pledged to implement more effective fiscal stimulus measures to support its slowing economy amid the COVID-19 outbreak. Finance Minister Liu Kun announced plans to reduce corporate taxes and cut unnecessary government expenses to boost production. Despite concerns about widening the fiscal gap, authorities emphasized the need to step up spending to contain the disease. Targeted and phased measures, including tax cuts and increased funds for provincial authorities, will be implemented to ensure steady growth.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 2.57 points or 0.17% to 1,539.65. Volume was 61.04 million lots worth RM26.45 million. Gainers outpaced losers 102 to 61. This follows a global market trend, with stocks in Europe and the US experiencing fluctuations due to concerns over US-EU trade tensions and tariffs.

site_title: Budget 2020: Singapore should preserve fiscal buffers to bounce back 'if tide turns against us'
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need for Singapore to maintain fiscal buffers to address unexpected shocks and long-term challenges. He announced two special packages worth S$5.6 billion to alleviate the impact of the novel coronavirus outbreak and allocated S$800 million to support frontline agencies. The government aims to preserve fiscal buffers, investing accumulated surpluses in past reserves, and remains disciplined in its use of borrowings to ensure long-term financial sustainability.

site_title: UK police rule out terror in London mosque stabbing
summary: British police have ruled out terror involvement in a London mosque stabbing that injured an elderly worshipper, who suffered non-life-threatening injuries. A 29-year-old man was arrested and charged with attempted murder after attacking the mosque's Muazzin, a religious leader, during prayers. The suspect, described as a white man in a red hooded top, was apprehended by worshippers before police arrived. Authorities have not confirmed a motive and are investigating the incident, which comes after a similar attack in Germany the day before.

images.alt_text: British police on Thursday said they were not treating as terror related a London mosque stabbing in which an elderly worshipper suffered non life-threatening injuries.

site_title: Singapore's property market can withstand the impact of Covid-19
summary: Singapore's property market is expected to withstand the economic impact of the Covid-19 pandemic, thanks to its diversified economy and resilient real estate sector. Unlike in 2003 during the Sars outbreak, occupier demand for office space has broadened, and the retail sector is expected to recover better due to e-commerce growth. Leasing demand for private homes may stay soft, but underlying buyer demand remains healthy, and prices are unlikely to drop significantly. Overall, Singapore's medium- and long-term market fundamentals remain intact, supporting the real estate industry during this period.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Singapore, Sri Lanka celebrate 50 years of diplomatic relations
summary: Singapore and Sri Lanka celebrate 50 years of diplomatic relations, marked by cordial socio-economic and diplomatic ties since their independence. High Commissioner of Sri Lanka to Singapore Sashikala Premawardhane discusses a possible revival of the free trade agreement and Sri Lanka's post-2019 Easter bombings recovery. This milestone highlights the strong relationship between the two nations, with both countries cooperating on various fronts despite global challenges.

site_title: Budget 2020 offers chance to build enduring home base
summary: Singapore's Budget 2020 aims to provide a strong foundation for the economy amidst global uncertainties, including the Covid-19 outbreak. The government plans to offer targeted relief packages, including financial subsidies and levy waivers, to affected industries. The budget also seeks to promote long-term transformation by leveraging the pandemic to redirect resources to valuable activities, such as upskilling and digitalization. The government may introduce incentives for businesses to invest in training and digital systems, and consider tweaks to tax incentives to attract global companies. A bundled approach is proposed to deepen commitment to Singapore, strengthen its attractiveness, and create good job opportunities for locals.

site_title: Tech advocate
summary: BSA's CEO Victoria Espinel has charted a new course for the global software advocacy group, shifting its focus from protecting intellectual property to influencing global tech policy-making. Espinel, a seasoned trade negotiator and lawyer, has expanded the alliance's agenda to prioritize data privacy, security, and the free movement of data. She emphasizes the need for policymakers to understand the trade-offs between data privacy and services, ensuring transparency and control for consumers. Espinel also highlights the challenges of policymaking in the era of rapid technological change, advocating for a more participatory, agile, and self-critical approach. She stresses the importance of diversity in the workforce, including digital skills, and collaboration between industry and government to address the global talent shortage.

site_title: National Australia Bank to raise A$750m via capital notes issue
summary: National Australia Bank (NAB) plans to raise approximately A$750 million through the issue of capital notes, which will qualify as additional tier 1 capital for the group. The capital notes will be issued to strengthen the bank's capital base and support its long-term growth.

site_title: Virus outbreak could 'maybe' impact US GDP in Q1: White House economic adviser
summary: US economic adviser Larry Kudlow said the coronavirus outbreak in China may impact the US GDP in Q1 by 2-3 tenths of a percent. The National Economic Council director made the statement during an interview on Fox Business Network. This potential economic hit comes as the US economy is already facing other challenges.

site_title: Starland posts 83% slump in FY2019 net profit of 1.54m yuan
summary: Starland, a CATALIST-listed property developer, reported a 83.2% year-on-year slump in its FY2019 net profit to 1.54 million yuan, citing a weak market in China. Revenue fell 55.8% to 29.6 million yuan, with cost of sales eating into lower turnover. Earnings per share dropped to 0.01 yuan, while net asset value decreased to 1.01 yuan per share.

site_title: Indigenous anti-pipeline protests spread across Canada
summary: Indigenous protests against the Coastal Gas Link natural gas pipeline in Canada have spread nationwide, causing major disruptions. The protests, sparked by opposition from Wet'suwet'en hereditary chiefs, have led to train blockades, port blockades, and sit-ins at government offices. Rail disruptions have forced over 20,000 Via Rail passengers to cancel trips, while dozens were arrested for attempting to block access to ports. The government is concerned about the "illegal" and "significant" disruption, urging a resolution as quickly as possible to impact the country's economy.

images.alt_text: Indigenous protests against a new pipeline in westernmost Canada scaled up across the country on Tuesday with major train disruptions, port blockades and sit-ins at government offices.

site_title: Hutchison Port Holdings Trust trims Q4 DPU to 5 HK cents
summary: Hutchison Port Holdings Trust (HPHT) has trimmed its Q4 distribution per unit (DPU) to 5 HK cents, down 35.3% from 8.48 HK cents previously. Revenue declined 11% year-on-year, while operating expenses didn't fall as fast, affecting operating profit. The trust's net profit for the year was HK$528.2 million, down 28.4% due to impairments. Management remains cautious about future cargo trends amid ongoing trade disputes and supply chain disruptions.

site_title: Coronavirus exposes cracks in carmakers' China supply chains
summary: The coronavirus outbreak in China is causing disruptions in the global car supply chain, with major manufacturers such as Hyundai, Tesla, Ford, and Nissan shutting down factories in China. The shutdowns, the first outside of China, could lead to shortages of essential components and materials, affecting production lines worldwide. Many carmakers have inventories of parts to use, but the duration of the shutdown is uncertain, raising concerns about depleting inventory and potential long-term disruptions. The impact on the car industry, already facing challenges from trade tensions and the shift to electric cars, is expected to be significant.

site_title: World Bank not considering new China loans to fight coronavirus, president says
summary: The World Bank's president, David Malpass, stated that the organization is offering technical assistance to China to combat the coronavirus, but no new loans are being considered due to China's ample resources. The World Bank is working with the WHO to aid China in areas such as health, sanitation, and disease policies. China has $3.115 trillion in foreign exchange reserves, and the World Bank's experts are in discussions with Chinese authorities to provide assistance on disease surveillance and analysis of the outbreak's economic impact.

site_title: OCBC hires another HSBC banker to drive Greater China business
summary: OCBC Bank's Bank of Singapore has hired Joanna Ho, a senior HSBC banker, to drive its wealth business in Greater China and North Asia. Ho, formerly HSBC Private Banking's head of wealth planning, Asia Pacific, will focus on expanding wealth planning and investment offerings for the region. This is the latest high-profile hire from HSBC, following Helen Wong's appointment as head of global wholesale banking earlier this year. The hires are seen as a response to the growing wealth in the Greater China region, which is expected to transfer trillions of dollars over the next decade.

site_title: The kindest cut?: How to better manage a retrenchment exercise
summary: Companies are increasingly recognizing the need to better manage retrenchment exercises, which can have a significant impact on employees and the employer's reputation. Experts advise that a retrenchment exercise should be carried out with advance notice, dignity, and support for departing staff. Key best practices include involving employees in the process, providing adequate severance packages, and engaging outplacement consultants to help staff transition to new roles. Companies should also consider alternative options, such as reskilling and redeploying affected staff. Failing to do so can result in reputational damage and costly consequences in future retention efforts and recruitment of talent.

site_title: Pangolin identified as potential link for coronavirus spread
summary: Chinese scientists have identified the pangolin as a potential link in the spread of the novel coronavirus across China, with genome sequences of viruses found on pangolins showing 99% similarity to those on coronavirus patients. The scaly mammal, trafficked for its scales and meat, is considered an endangered species with over 1 million snatched from Asian and African forests in the past decade. Experts call for more data to confirm the link, and conservationists urge a permanent ban on wildlife trade to prevent deadly disease outbreaks.

site_title: Property stalwart
summary: Knight Frank group chairman Alistair Elliott remains optimistic about the real estate sector despite global economic uncertainties. He attributes the sector's stability to its global nature, with opportunities for growth in Asia, particularly in Singapore and China. Despite challenges in the UK and Hong Kong, Elliott expects the UK to experience a busy year in both residential and commercial markets. He believes real estate will continue to be a pivotal part of the global economy, driven by trends such as urbanization, student populations, and retirement living.
